title: Planet Us: Coral Man
description: Ken Nedimyer has started a nursery for staghorn coral in the Florida Keys.

title: Courting, Fish Fry and All
description: The Democrats debate last week offered a prime site for presidential hopefuls to promote their ideas, credentials and, most important, affection for Representative James E. Clyburn, Democrat of South Carolina.

title: Romney Favors Hubbard Novel
description: Whats your favorite novel? is a perennial campaign question, the answer to which presumably gives insight into leadership.

title: 2008 Contenders in the Senate and the War
description: President Bush this week will formally reject the Iraq spending bill, with its timeline for winding down the war. But that will hardly bring the matter to a close for the Democratic presidential hopefuls, especially those in the Senate.

title: Coachella: View From the VIP Trailer Park
description: Indio, Calif.  If performers are going to come all the way out here, they might as well experience the desert lifestyle, which in this part of California often involves spending time in an RV. Coachella approximates this experience by stowing its artists in a sort of upscale trailer park tucked away on one side of the polo grounds. Virtually every performer, from the co-headlining Red Hot Chili Peppers on down, spends time here, idling between the rows of trailers (they are spruced up with white picket fences and little lawn tables for entertaining guests).

title: Lonesome George Isnt Looking So Lonesome
description: Startling news from the Galapagos: Lonesome George could have company. The giant tortoise became an international symbol of conservation as the last surviving member of his species  the rarest living creature, according to Guinness World Records. But now it looks as if hes not the only Pinta island tortoise left on Earth.

title: Davis Is Face of a Warriors Team Made of Castoffs and Renegades
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 30  Baron Davis was hopping, strutting, smiling, almost dancing across the Golden State Warriors practice court Monday morning as his teammates waged a half-court shooting contest.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Sesame Street Takes On a Role in the Middle East

title: Sunni Ministers Threaten to Quit Cabinet in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, April 30  The largest bloc of Sunni Arabs in the Iraqi Parliament threatened to withdraw its ministers from the Shiite-dominated cabinet on Monday in frustration over the governments failure to deal with Sunni concerns.

title: The Times Building Is Resold for 3 Times Its 2004 Price
description: Less than three weeks after putting the historic headquarters of The New York Times Company on the block, Tishman Speyer Properties sold the building for $525 million, three times the $175 million it paid in November 2004.

title: Its Personal Up in the Stratosphere
description: LONDON, April 30  Nagi Kawkabani, the co-chief executive of Brevan Howard Asset Management, a London-based hedge fund, went on a global road trip to drum up interest in a public offering.

title: Brooklyn Driver Charged in Bicycle Fatality
description: A Brooklyn man who was arrested Sunday on drunken-driving charges near the scene of a hit-and-run accident that killed a 13-year-old boy riding a bicycle was charged yesterday with vehicular manslaughter, the police said. They said that the boy, Anthony Delgado of Brooklyn, was struck just after midnight on Sunday at the intersection of Palmetto Street and Central Avenue in Bushwick. The man, Melvin Morales, 34, was arrested a short time later, after being stopped for a reason unconnected to the hit and run, the police said. Investigators said that evidence on his sport utility vehicle linked it to the hit and run, and that a surveillance camera had captured images that would provide evidence against Mr. Morales.

title: A West Coast Orchestra, Distinctly Unmellow
description: The Los Angeles Philharmonic is an exciting orchestra. First, its exciting for superficial reasons: it plays in a hot new hall designed by Frank Gehry, and it has just announced its impending transition from one crack former wunderkind conductor, Esa-Pekka Salonen, to another, Gustavo Dudamel, in 2009. But its also exciting because of the sound it makes, big and compelling, under Mr. Salonen, who, still boyish and very much in command, showed off the ensemble he has helped to shape on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Uptown, a Company No Longer Plays Nice
description: It was not a major cultural event when the Jean Cocteau Repertory left its longtime home on the Bowery, a few blocks from CBGB, on the Lower East Side. No one protested. For unlike CBGB, which closed to much fanfare in 2006, the Jean Cocteau, which also left that year, was never at the forefront of anything  and perhaps its charm was that it never tried to be.

title: New York Art College Canceled Deal With Lender After Learning of High Interest Rates
description: Pratt Institute, a New York art and design college, had a deal in 2005 with a student loan company: The lender would provide grant money for needy students if Pratt students over all took out $1 million or more in loans.

title: Olmert Rebuked by Israeli Panel on Lebanon War
description: JERUSALEM, May 1  Despite a resounding chorus of calls in Israel for the prime minister, Ehud Olmert, to resign following a report on Monday that excoriated Mr. Olmert for severe failures in last summers war against the Lebanese militia Hezbollah, his aides insisted today that he had no intention of leaving office.

title: Baldness and Longevity
description: Q. Is balding an indicator of more rapid aging and a shorter life span?

title: Bloodlines Worth Their Weight in Gold
description: The dream of Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum to win the Kentucky Derby died this year in the same place it took flight: his desert kingdom, Dubai. His last 3-year-old prospect, a colt named Day Pass, struggled to finish ninth in the U.A.E. Derby.

title: Protesters Press for Path to Citizenship
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1  Tens of thousands of people pressing for immigrants rights demonstrated on Tuesday in dozens of cities. But with advocates splintered over tactics, the crowds paled in comparison with the turnout last year.

title: In Ducks, War of the Sexes Plays Out in the Evolution of Genitalia
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn.  This guys the champion, said Patricia Brennan, a behavioral ecologist, leaning over the nether regions of a duck  a Mellers duck from Madagascar, to be specific  and carefully coaxing out his phallus.

title: Secularism and Democracy in Turkey
description: The long struggle between Turkeys generals  the self-appointed custodians of secularism  and the growing popularity of parties rooted in Islam has taken a dangerous turn. Both sides need to step back from the brink for the sake of Turkeys democracy and its hopes of joining the European Union.

title: Qaeda Leader May Have Been Killed, Iraqi Official Says
description: BAGHDAD, May 1  The Iraqi government said today that it was investigating reports from reliable sources that the leader of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, the radical Islamist insurgent group, had been killed in an ambush by a rival insurgent faction.

title: Why Congress Should Embrace the Surge
description: WHEN the civilian hierarchy fails them, soldiers tend to seek solace in Clausewitzs observation that war is an extension of politics. But in 2005 and 2006 the reverse was true in Iraq: the battle churned in place, steadily eroding the administrations credibility and Americas psyche, while most politicians stood on the sidelines, content to hurl insults at one another until the battlefield offered a clear political course.

title: Ivica Racan,  Former Croatian Premier, Is Dead at 63
description: Ivica Racan, the former Croatian prime minister who rebuilt economic and trade ties with Europe after the civil wars of the 1990s, died Sunday in Zagreb, the Croatian capital. He was 63.

title: In Moscow in 1996, a Doctors Visit Changed History
description: It was the fall of 1996, and Boris N. Yeltsin was running for re-election as Russias first president in the post-Soviet era. But he faced a crisis far more threatening than any opponent: he was desperately ill.

title: Dawn Upshaw's Beautiful World of Song
description: Its great to be here, the soprano Dawn Upshaw said on Sunday afternoon at the beginning of her recital at Town Hall. I mean, really great, she added, looking misty-eyed, to which the audience responded with a long round of applause and cheers.

title: A Governor Truly Tightens His Belt
description: SALEM, Ore., April 27  He swore off beer, had to put the pricey organic bananas back on the supermarket shelf and squeezed four meals out of a single chicken, all in the name of reducing hunger. And this is not even an election year.

title: BP Chief Resigns Amid Battle With Tabloid
description: Lord John Browne of Madingley, an aggressive but mannered British magnate who transformed BP into one of the most successful, global companies, resigned abruptly on Tuesday in a court battle with a tabloid over details of his personal life.

title: High Court Puts Limits on Patents
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  The Supreme Court, in its most important patent ruling in years, on Monday raised the bar for obtaining patents on new products that combine elements of pre-existing inventions.

title: X Is for Wonderment
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: New York Gambling Treatment Court Stresses Help
description: AMHERST, N.Y.  The docket in front of Justice Mark G. Farrell one recent Tuesday afternoon looked like a routine roster of small-time crime: petty larceny, attempted burglary, check forgery. But the offenders shared a single motivation: money to gamble.

title: One More Tango for Brando and His Golden Mumble
description: He was sort of a different type of a person, ventures Betty Gossell, who went to high school with Marlon Brando in Illinois. A different type of person. That may be the last word on Brando, who died in 2004.

title: Tommy Newsom, Saxophonist, Dies at 78
description: Tommy Newsom, the good-humored backup bandleader on The Tonight Show who earned fame as Johnny Carsons comical punching bag  and respect among musicians as a composer, arranger and saxophone soloist  died on Saturday at his home in Portsmouth, Va. He was 78.

title: Torre and Cashman Are Safe, for Now
description: George Steinbrenner made it clear yesterday that he was not ready to fire anybody after 23 games. But with 14 losses already, and a pitching staff that has been exposed as inferior to that of the Boston Red Sox, it is convenient that the Yankees play in Texas this week.

title: Questions Over Routine Screening for a Leading Cause of Blindness
description: GLAUCOMA, a chronic condition characterized by damage to the optic nerve, is the second-leading cause of blindness in the United States, but routine screening for it is controversial.

title: Ex-Senator Seen as Rehearsing for Prime Time
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  When 10 of the declared Republican presidential candidates gather for their first debate on Thursday at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Southern California, Fred D. Thompson, the actor and politician, will not be among them. But he will not be far offstage.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Friday about a new book by George J. Tenet, the former director of central intelligence, gave the incorrect name in some copies for the 2004 award bestowed on him by President Bush. It is the Presidential Medal of Freedom, not the Presidential Medal of Honor.

title: Citing Rigid Deadline, Bush Vetoes Iraq Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  President Bush vetoed the Iraq-war spending bill this evening, calling it a blueprint for failure and defeat and intensifying a showdown with the Democratic-controlled Congress.

title: Letters
description: The Mystery of Vanishing Bees

title: Mets Depth Faces Test as 2 Players Go on D.L.
description: By almost all measures, the Mets had an impressive April. On the last day of the month, however, they were confronted with injuries to two prominent players, then were hammered by the Florida Marlins at Shea Stadium.

title: Philippine Police Close Case in Americans Killing
description: MANILA, May 1  The Philippine authorities say they consider a case in which an American Peace Corps volunteer was brutally killed to be closed after a suspect confessed to the crime.

title: The Names Are Vintage, the Touches Modern
description: THEY used to say that life begins at 40. For a familiar advertising character, the lonely Maytag repairman, a new life is beginning at 40 as he gets a major personality makeover.

title: Torn by University Shootings, Virginia Town Turns Inward to Mend
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 28  In a small yarn shop near the Virginia Tech campus, Molly Heterick sat knitting at a wooden table with her friends this week, looping coarse strands of wool over her needles until a small patch in the colors of the university started to take shape.

title: Bill on Iraq to Be Delivered 4 Years After Bushs Words
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  Democratic leaders in Congress are planning a special ceremony on Tuesday afternoon to send President Bush a bill that sets timetables for troop withdrawal from Iraq.

title: Ortiz Writes Another Chapter in a Yankees Horror Story
description: Its a good thing for Joe Torres tenuous job security that the Tampa-based George Steinbrenner seldom ventures into Midtown Manhattan anymore. The Boss, already in a blue statement-making mood yesterday, would have had the same visceral reaction that some Yankees fans had on their lunchtime strolls past the Barnes & Noble bookstore on Fifth Avenue.

title: Israeli Leader Resists Calls to Resign
description: JERUSALEM, May 1  The newspapers were vituperative, opposition politicians fulminated and a young cabinet minister resigned, but Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel pressed ahead today with what aides called a normal working schedule, in the wake of a damning report about his performance in the first few days of last summers war against Hezbollah.

title: Victim Describes 13 Hours of Sexual Torment, and Clues Left Behind
description: She was putting the finishing touches on a Halloween costume from Cheap Jacks Vintage Clothing store on Oct. 31, 2005, when she heard the pounding at the door of her Chelsea apartment. Through the peephole, she saw thick white smoke and a man in full firefighting gear, a plastic visor obscuring his face, who demanded to be let in.

title: G.E. Moves Ahead on Removal of PCBs From 2 Rivers, but Frustration Remains
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass.  More than 30 years have passed since Congress banned a broad range of synthetic compounds called PCBs. Yet 2.65 million cubic yards of mud on the bottom of the Hudson River remain contaminated with the chemicals, which are considered neurotoxins and probable human carcinogens.

title: Officer Testifies Against U.S. Military Jailer in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, April 30  A senior commander in the American militarys main detention center here testified Monday at a military hearing that his predecessor, Lt. Col. William H. Steele, gave computer programs and other gifts to the daughter of a high-value detainee.

title: Gold Stars and Dunce Caps
description: In this presidential campaign, we need somebody who wants to address the question President Bush once raised: Is our children learning?

title: How to Be More Effective (and Less Annoying and Counterproductive)
description: IT takes both a special mind-set and certain skills to build a successful company.

title: Satire With the Blessing of Lady Luck Herself
description: Most humor sites begin when some smart-aleck at an old media company begins nagging: We have to launch a more robust entertainment vertical, guys. But Black20 has a cool creation myth.

title: Food Imports Often Escape Scrutiny
description: Early in the 20th century, the safeguarding of food at American ports often amounted to inspectors from the Food and Drug Administration prying open containers of molasses or sugar and examining them for mold or insect parts.

title: New Orleans Homecoming (for the Lucky Ones)
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 30  Every so often at this years New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival over the weekend, musicians would announce that they were finally back in their old homes after being displaced for a more than a year by Hurricane Katrina.

title: Administration Proposes New Energy Drilling
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  The Bush administration proposed on Monday leasing out millions of acres along the coasts of Alaska and Virginia to oil and gas drillers, a move that would end a longstanding ban on drilling in those environmentally sensitive areas.

title: What's on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) BRANDO Before Brando, actors acted, says Michael Winner, who directed Marlon Brando in The Nightcomers. After Brando, they behaved. That is the difference  an extraordinary effect on the history of drama and the history of movies. This two-part documentary tries to unlock the enigma of Brando (above, in The Wild One, from 1953) through interviews with everyone from his former high school classmates to the likes of Al Pacino, Martin Scorsese, Jon Voight, Jane Fonda, Robert Duvall and Dennis Hopper. It also includes film of Brando onstage and on screen, from Truckline Caf, which first earned him recognition on Broadway, through A Streetcar Named Desire, which catapulted him over the top, with stops at Julius Caesar, in which he proved he could enunciate; The Godfather, his signature work; and the intimate Last Tango in Paris.

title: Court Strikes Law Barring Sale of Drug Data
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that the pharmaceutical industry could continue to use computerized data showing which doctors are prescribing what drugs.

title: Depression Raises Risk of Diabetes, Study Finds
description: Depression is associated with an increased risk for diabetes in older adults, even in people who have no other risk factors for the disease, a new study reports.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about plans by the injured New Jersey governor, Jon S. Corzine, to leave a Camden hospital early this week and continue his recovery at Drumthwacket, the governors mansion in Princeton, gave an erroneous figure in some copies for the estimated value of his assets, as reported in a 2005 financial disclosure form for the United States Senate, where he served before being elected governor. He said his assets were worth up to $261 million, not up to $61 million. An article about Governor Corzines discharge from the hospital yesterday appears today on Page B1.

title: Senate Takes Up Bill to Change Drug Agency Operations
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  The Senate began debate on Monday on a bill that could fundamentally change the way the Food and Drug Administration operates by giving it more power and money to ensure that drugs are as safe as advertised.

title: Abuse Victim Suing Church Testifies He Is Still in Pain
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., April 30  The body language may have been as telling as the testimony.

title: A Meal, a Smile, a Word: Thanks in a Thousand Ways
description: To operate on a patient without receiving a fee is the most satisfying of memories, the greatest of privileges. It leaves a glow, a high  the feeling young doctors must get these days when they go to third-world countries, repair cleft lips and palates, or build hospitals.

title: Corzine Leaves Hospital After Accident
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 30  Gov. Jon S. Corzine apologized to New Jersey residents on Monday as he left the hospital 18 days after being critically injured in a car crash in which he was being driven at 91 miles per hour on the Garden State Parkway while riding without his seat belt.

title: Even After Two Overtimes, the Rangers Stay Fresh
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., April 30  On a rink filled with the young players who never miss a practice, optional or not, Rangers forward Jaromir Jagr skated around with a big smile.

title: Searching for Sleep and Decent Clothing
description: I never wanted to be the poster boy for the bad effects of jet lag. I always had visions of myself as being the archetypal business traveler: one of those folks who arrives at the airport fresh and pressed, and somehow manages to exit the plane looking the same way.

title: Memo Pad
description: CESSNA DELIVERS VERY LIGHT JET As the very light jet market stirs to life, the Cessna Aircraft Company delivered its first retail Citation Mustang jet last week to Goode Ski Technologies. Goode is currently flying a Cessna 310 twin-engine piston propeller aircraft, and says it bought the Mustang to make it easier to travel to ski locations to test its products. Cessna already has two Mustangs flying for marketing purposes. The $2.5 million, four-passenger Mustang is the latest model of a very light jet to enter commercial service. Eclipse Aviation recently delivered three of its Eclipse 500 very light jets to DayJet, a company that plans to begin on-demand air-taxi service in June and has ordered 239 of the aircraft. Competitors producing very light jets, which are sometimes called microjets, include Adam Aircraft, Honda, Embraer and Piper. A new online magazine, www.verylightjets.com, is devoted exclusively to the new aircraft.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on April 21 about the French film actor Jean-Pierre Cassel omitted some survivors. Besides his son the actor Vincent Cassel, they include another son from his first marriage, Matthias; his second wife, Anne Clrier; and their daughter, Ccile.

title: Signs of Mourning Follow the Cardinals
description: MILWAUKEE, April 30  The little boy and the little girl wore St. Louis Cardinals jerseys and caps, stationed themselves by the third-base dugout and held a tribute sign for Josh Hancock. They had drawn a red-and-white uniform with Hancocks name, his No. 32 and the words Will Be Missed.

title: Newspaper Circulation in Steep Slide Across Nation
description: Newspaper sales continue a steep slide nationally, figures released Monday show, but two New York City tabloids continued to buck the trend, posting the largest gains among major papers.

title: Elliott Skinner, Scholar and Former Ambassador, Dies at 82
description: Elliott P. Skinner, a former United States ambassador to the Republic of Upper Volta, the West African nation now known as Burkina Faso, and a former chairman of the anthropology department at Columbia University, died April 1 at his home in Washington. He was 82.

title: Bush Steps Up Effort to Persuade Putin on Missile Defense Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  President Bush, under pressure from allies in Europe to be more forthcoming about his plans for basing missile interceptors in the region, said Monday that he was intensifying his efforts to persuade Russia to cooperate with the United States on the initiative so that they dont see us as an antagonistic force, but see us as a friendly force.

title: Recruiting Plankton to Fight Global Warming
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 30  Can plankton help save the planet?

title: The Power of Negative Thinking
description: We Americans believe instinctively in the power of positive thinking. Whether one is fighting a cancer, an insurgency or just an unyielding problem at work, the prevailing wisdom is that thinking positive is the key  The Secret, even  to success. But the key, it seems to me, is actually negative thinking: looking for, and sometimes expecting, failure.

title: Among Chimps and Bonobos, the Hand Often Does the Talking
description: Why is it that when people are yakking away on their cellphones, they often accompany their activity with face and hand gestures, a performance that their distant listener cannot see and does not need?

description: THE FACTS

title: Interpreting Some Overlooked Stories From the South
description: The gripping black-and-white photographs of civil rights protesters in the South reflect the black-and-white morality tale that generally accompanies them. Hateful, jeering white mobs and attack dogs versus peaceful marchers asking to vote and to walk in the front door.

title: A New Policy on Iran (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Simple Need, All Too Often Unmet
description: On a recent trip to Sydney, Australia, I discovered the true meaning of civilization  public toilets, lots of them, clean, neat, safe, free of graffiti, working flushes and faucets, and well-stocked with toilet paper, along with paper towels or hand dryers. Most are free (some are automatic pay toilets) and available 24 hours. One free 24-hour toilet under the Darling Harbor Bridge appeared to have just been remodeled with colorful tiles.

title: How to Halve the Death Rate From Colon Cancer
description: EVEN though screening tests can prevent colorectal cancer or find it early enough to cure, the disease is still the second-leading cause of cancer death in the United States, with nearly 165,000 new cases and more than 52,000 deaths expected this year.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about violence in movies involving college students in the wake of the shootings at Virginia Tech referred incorrectly to Battle Royale, which is about ninth graders imprisoned on an island who are forced to kill one another. It was originally a novel, not a video game.

title: Google Calls Viacom Suit on YouTube Unfounded
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., April 30  Responding to Viacoms $1 billion copyright infringement suit over video clips on YouTube, Google said Monday that it would not back off, declaring that the law was on its side.

title: Morocco Talks Set in Western Sahara Dispute
description: Morocco and the Polisario Front, which are struggling for control of resource-rich Western Sahara, agreed to hold direct talks for the first time under the terms of a unanimously passed United Nations Security Council resolution. Morocco, which annexed the Front in 1979, hopes to incorporate it as an autonomous province with its own regional government. The Polisario Front wants a referendum that will offer the 260,000 residents the choice of autonomy or independence from Morocco.

title: Amid Bare Breasts and Love Stories, Audience Participation
description: A warning: breasts will be bared in Exposed: Experiments in Love, Sex, Death and Art, a new show at Collective: Unconscious in TriBeCa. Since Annie Sprinkle, the pornography star turned performance artist, is a key participant in the proceedings, this is not entirely surprising. But amateur exhibitionists, too, are given a chance to display their wares in one of the evenings interactive moments, when Ms. Sprinkle and Elizabeth Stephens, her partner in three of the four titular experiences, swarm the audience with digital cameras early on, looking for volunteers to join the party.

title: Staten Island Borough Has Citys Worst Smog
description: New Yorkers who moved to Staten Island to escape congestion and pollution will be disappointed to hear that while air quality deteriorated in all five boroughs over the past year, it is worst in Staten Island, according to the eighth annual air pollution report by the American Lung Association. The report, which is scheduled to be released today, found that ozone pollution  or smog  is highest on Staten Island. And particle pollution, usually known as soot, has become substantially worse there, as well as in Brooklyn and Manhattan. Louise A. Vetter, chief executive of the American Lung Association of the City of New York, said that among the factors that contribute to Staten Islands pollution are the heavy volume of vehicular traffic and diesel exhaust from ferries and barges in New York Harbor. Prevailing winds and other meteorological phenomena may also cause pollution from other states to hover over Staten Island, Ms. Vetter said.

title: This One Will Floor You
description: A new campaign is seeking to take the hard out of buying hardwood floors.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 30, 2007

description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Wants to Know: Whos on Escort Service List?
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  The woman who faces charges of running a prostitution ring in Washington that serviced the prominent and powerful said Monday that she intended to force many of those clients to testify in her behalf.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about a New York subway track worker who was struck and killed by a train at Columbus Circle included erroneous information from the State Transportation Department about an investigation of the accident. New York City Transit is investigating  not the Transportation Department, which investigates only passenger accidents.

title: Wider Screenings for H.I.V. Are Recommended
description: WHILE the annual number of new H.I.V. infections is sharply lower than in the peak years of the 1980s, the effort to reduce the infection rate further has stalled in the last decade. So the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention now recommends screening for H.I.V. as a routine part of health care, and not just for people in known risk groups.

title: U.S. Says Some Chicken Feed Tainted
description: CHICAGO, April 30  Government investigators said Monday that byproducts from pet food contaminated with wheat gluten imported from China were used in chicken feed on some farms in Indiana.

title: Virginia Ends a Loophole in Gun Laws
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  Gov. Tim Kaine of Virginia closed a loophole Monday in the states gun laws that allowed a mentally disturbed Virginia Tech student to buy the guns used in a shooting rampage that left 33 dead at the university on April 16.

title: A Day After a Fiery Crash, Bay Area Commuters Enjoy a Surprisingly Easy Ride
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 30  A day after a fiery gasoline tanker crash melted and collapsed a critical highway interchange near the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge, drivers in the Bay Area enjoyed a relatively painless commute on Monday as an expected rush hour nightmare largely failed to materialize.

title: 5 Britons Guilty; Tied to 2005 London Bombers
description: LONDON, April 30  A jury found five British Muslim men guilty on Monday of planning fertilizer-bomb attacks around London, ending a yearlong trial that linked the plotters with two of the four men who blew themselves up on Londons transit system in July 2005.

title: Japan Wages Fell in March
description: Wages in Japan fell for a fourth month in March, signaling that growth in consumer spending will be limited. Monthly wages, including overtime and bonuses, fell 0.4 percent after dropping 1 percent in February, the labor ministry said. In China, manufacturing activity expanded at the fastest pace in more than two years in April, according to a survey of purchasing managers. The Purchasing Managers Index rose to 58.6 from 56.1 in March, the statistics bureau said. That is the highest since the index started in January 2005.

title: Looking for a Home in the Limbo of Alaska
description: From the moment of his precocious debut in 1988 with The Mysteries of Pittsburgh, it was clear that Michael Chabon was an immensely gifted writer and a magical prose stylist. The tales in A Model World and Other Stories and Werewolves in Their Youth showcased his ability to do wonderful things with words, to conjure everything from the banalities of daily life to the most bizarre of melodrama, just as Wonder Boys demonstrated his ability to do slapstick comedy with as much ardor and panache as more serious, emotional material.

title: Sudan U.N. Peacekeeping Mission Extended
description: The Security Council endorsed a resolution extending by six months the 10,000-member United Nations mission that helps enforce the 2005 peace accord that ended decades of civil war in southern Sudan. The measure expressed grave concern over the crisis in Darfur, in western Sudan, but to achieve the unanimous backing of the 15-member Council the United States had to drop language putting pressure on Sudan to accept a proposed United Nations-African Union peacekeeping force there.

title: Atlantas Mayor Defends Chief Against Misconduct Accusations
description: ATLANTA, April 30  Mayor Shirley Franklin defended the citys police chief Monday against charges by federal prosecutors that a culture of misconduct in the Police Department contributed to the shooting death of an elderly woman in a botched drug raid last fall.

title: Secaucus Turnpike Carjacking Reported
description: Three men posing as police officers pulled over a vehicle on the New Jersey Turnpike yesterday afternoon, forced the passengers to the ground and stole the car, the state police said. The victims, who were not identified, told the police that three men in a white Ford Explorer pulled alongside their southbound Toyota Avalon near the Alexander Hamilton rest area on the turnpike, held up silver badges on chains around their necks, and motioned for the driver to pull over, said Sgt. Jeanne Hengemuhle, a spokeswoman for the state police. The men pulled into the rest area, where they were forced out of the car and onto the ground. One of the men from the Ford got into the Toyota, which had a New York license plate, DUU-2791, and both cars sped off, the sergeant said.

title: Parish Puts Vandalized Statue Back on Its Feet, Again
description: SOMEBODY keeps knocking Jesus off his pedestal outside St. Martin of Tours Church in the Bronx. This time, vandals streaked the face with black marker and wrote devil and 666, and the half-smashed statue spent most of last week propped up against the pedestal as if recovering from a dizzy spell.

title: S.I.-Linked Murder Suspect Is Returned to Colombia
description: One of the men suspected in last months murder and dismemberment of a Staten Island woman in Panama has been returned to his native Colombia by Costa Rica despite being one of Panamas most wanted men, the authorities in Panama and Costa Rica said yesterday.

title: Fireproofing of Most Overpasses and Bridges Is Costly and Rare
description: LOS ANGELES, April 30  They are built in most cases to withstand ferocious winds and, here in California, the heaving of earthquakes. But most major highway bridges and overpasses are not fireproof and probably never will be.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption in The Arts on Saturday with an article about Carol Williams, the civic organist for San Diego, carried an erroneous credit. The photograph, of the organ she plays and the pavilion that shelters it, was by Robert Harrington, not Donald MacKenzie.

title: Views of Parents, Students and Teachers Sought
description: The Department of Education has begun a citywide survey of more than 1.8 million parents, students and teachers concerning their attitudes about the public schools, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced yesterday.

title: Conduct Costs Some Players More Than Others
description: Perhaps it was fitting that one of the biggest stories of the N.F.L. draft was the acquisition of a player with a long and colorful history of character issues by a team that usually stays away from them. Maybe that player, Randy Moss, will never pretend to moon a bunch of Jets fans. But the New England Patriots were willing to take that risk, one day after they also took one with their first-round pick, Brandon Meriweather, who was prominently involved in an on-field brawl last season only months after he fired his gun when defending his roommate during a robbery attempt.

title: Instead of Leaping, Sumatran Orangutans Sway From Tree to Tree
description: For animals that spend most of their time in trees, getting around can be costly. Jumping the gap from a thin branch to another tree can be inefficient (not to mention risky), because the bending branch absorbs some of the jump energy. Another option is climbing down one tree and up the other, but this takes energy, too.

title: Coals Energy Potential Is an Engineering Challenge Now
description: WASHINGTON  Coal is so cheap and so widely available that its increased use is inevitable, but clearing the hurdle to burning it on a wide scale  separating the carbon dioxide and sequestering it  could turn out to be one of the great engineering challenges of the century, energy experts say.

title: Mental Abilities: Sleep on It, It Appears, Really Is Good Advice
description: Sleeping on the job is not generally a good idea, but when it comes to the brain it may be another matter.

title: Turkish Court Blocks Islamist Candidate
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 1  Turkeys constitutional court today supported an effort to block a candidate for the countrys presidency whose background is in political Islam, pitching the country into early national elections and a referendum on the role of religion in its future.

title: Heated Cross-Examination at the Conrad Black Trial
description: CHICAGO, April 30  The cross-examination of a crucial witness at the trial of Conrad M. Black grew heated on Monday when a defense lawyer attempted to portray the witness as forgetful or inept.

title: Profit Surges at Loews
description: Loews, a holding company run by the Tisch family of New York, said yesterday that first-quarter profit climbed 42 percent on gains in its insurance, cigarette and oil-drilling units.

title: Terrorist Attacks in Iraq and Afghanistan Rose Sharply Last Year, State Department Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  Terrorist attacks against noncombatants nearly doubled in Iraq from 2005 to 2006 and were up sharply in Afghanistan, with those two countries alone accounting for a 29 percent increase in terrorism worldwide, according to a report released Monday by the State Department.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about Senator John McCains presidential campaign misstated the cause of a fire aboard the aircraft carrier Forrestal, which killed 134 of Mr. McCains shipmates during his Navy career. It resulted from the explosion of an American rocket on the deck, not an attack.

title: Report Assails Wal-Mart Over Unions
description: In its first study of how an American company treats its workers, Human Rights Watch asserted yesterday that Wal-Marts aggressive efforts to keep out labor unions often violated federal law and infringed on its workers rights.

title: Free Drug Samples? Bad Idea, Some Say
description: Everyone loves freebies, and patients are no exception. So drug company sales representatives try to keep sample cabinets in medical offices well stocked with the latest medications, for doctors to dispense as the need arises.

title: A Slam-Dunk of a Book Tour Comes to Town
description: George J. Tenet, originally of Little Neck, Queens, returned to his hometown yesterday to peddle a book and, not coincidentally, himself.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a reduction in the number of schools that the New Jersey Schools Construction Corporation says it can build or rehabilitate with the money it has on hand referred incorrectly to the status of the agencys previous projects and to their costs. Fifty-six  not zero  projects have been completed in the past five years, including 30 new schools and 26 major renovations. The more than $5 billion spent so far includes $1.25 billion for these projects as well as land acquisition and planning for others; the $5 billion was not spent on land purchases and planning costs alone. title: Trenton Additional Storm Disaster Designations
description: Three New Jersey counties  Camden, Gloucester and Mercer  were added yesterday to President Bushs disaster declaration in regard to the northeaster of April 15. Last week, the president declared disaster areas in Bergen, Burlington, Essex, Passaic, Somerset and Union Counties, with Hudson, Middlesex and Morris added on Saturday. Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey had requested that the entire state receive the designation, which gives residents access to federal aid. The president also allowed for infrastructure repairs to municipalities in 11 counties.

title: Coral Is Dying. Can It Be Reborn?
description: TAVERNIER, Fla.  Clouds were moving across the sun and a 20-knot northeast wind was stirring a 3-foot chop as Meaghan Johnson headed her open boat into the Florida Straits.

description: If lowering sodium intake reduces the risk of high blood pressure, and high blood pressure can lead to heart disease, does eating less salt improve the health of ones heart?

title: Raise for State Judges Gets Caught in Crossfire Between Spitzer and Bruno
description: ALBANY, April 30  State judges have gone more than eight years without a pay raise. It appears they may not get one soon.

description: REEL BASEBALL: 1899-1926

title: A California Max Yasgur for a New Woodstock
description: INDIO, Calif., April 29  Alexander Haagen III is an unfamiliar figure to the tens of thousands of music fans who converged in the California desert this past weekend for the annual Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival. But more than any rock hero, he wields profound influence here: he is the real estate developer who owns the Empire Polo Club, the gilt-edged grounds where the festival is staged.

title: Unspent 9/11 Funds Returning to New Jersey Coffer
description: TRENTON, April 30  In 2003, when post-9/11 security fears were still fresh, New Jersey appropriated $23 million to help local governments buy equipment they might need to meet emergencies. But according to the state attorney general, municipalities failed to spend $2.78 million of that money.

title: Correction
description: An article on Thursday about a reduction in the number of schools that the New Jersey Schools Construction Corporation says it can build or rehabilitate with the money it has on hand referred incorrectly to the status of the agencys previous projects and to their costs. Fifty-six  not zero  projects have been completed in the past five years, including 30 new schools and 26 major renovations. The more than $5 billion spent so far includes $1.25 billion for these projects as well as land acquisition and planning for others; the $5 billion was not spent on land purchases and planning costs alone.

title: How Does Your Waistline Matter? Let Us Count the Ways.
description: AT age 39, with diabetes and high blood pressure in her family, Linda M. was starting to worry about her weight and its health consequences. She was 5 feet 6 inches tall and weighed 170 pounds, which placed her in the overweight category, according to the standard definition. Although she was not officially obese, she said, I realized I was not at my ideal weight.

title: Post-Minimalist Inspirations, From Bells to Subway Noise
description: The basic elements of Minimalism  tonality, rhythmic regularity, repetition of brief melodic cells  are reasonably easy to summarize. Post-Minimalism is harder to pin down: Composers lumped under this untidy rubric vary widely in style. Just how widely was demonstrated in a program presented on Saturday night by the adventurous new-music ensemble Opus 21, based in Kalamazoo, Mich., at the Leonard Nimoy Thalia Theater at Symphony Space.

title: Two Stars Push Each Other, and Nets, to New Heights
description: Coming off a two-game tour de force, the Nets stars Jason Kidd and Vince Carter are showing why they may be considered among the N.B.A.s greatest perimeter tandems. But they are still without a championship, and their place in history remains to be determined.

title: To: The Temporarily Able-Bodied
description: Just about everyone who works pays taxes into the fund for federal disability benefits. But mercifully, relatively few people ever collect. To qualify, you must be unable to work, and your disability must be of such severity that youll be out for at least a year or youre likely to die from it.

title: Cambodia Tribunal Clears Procedural Hurdle
description: BANGKOK, May 1  For a moment, it appeared that $2,700 might be enough to save the mass killers of the Khmer Rouge from going on trial.

title: For Motherly X Chromosome, Gender Is Only the Beginning

title: Senators Question Halliburton Executive About Dealings in Iran
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  A Halliburton executive, facing withering criticism from Democratic lawmakers during a Senate hearing on Monday about the companys business dealings in Iran, insisted that the firm had not broken any laws.

title: Dont Trust Your Ears: This Play Is Not a Musical
description: On a recent evening, the creative team of a new Broadway show were entrenched in a technical rehearsal. A cast of 40 waited onstage for instruction while the shows composer, Adrian Sutton, consulted with its director, Melly Still, about an element of the sound design. Mr. Sutton then dashed down the aisle to the orchestra pit for a tte--tte with the musical director, Constantine Kitsopoulos.

title: Help, by the Book
description: The State of Washington is looking out for students and their families by passing a law requiring textbook companies to disclose prices and other relevant information when they market books to college professors in the state. Lawmakers hope that professors who learn the costs upfront will opt for reasonably priced textbooks that cash-strapped students can afford.

title: Magazine Learns to Heed Its Own Advice
description: Business 2.0, the technology-aware magazine published by Time Inc., periodically reminds readers of the importance of backing up computer files. A 2003 article likened backups to flossing  everyone knows its important, but few devote enough thought or energy to it.

title: A Rock Festival Whose Hallmark Is Taste
description: INDIO, Calif., April 30  The Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival may have to start sharpening its identity.

title: Court Backs Police in Chase That Hurt Driver
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  The police did not violate a speeding drivers rights by ramming his car and causing an accident that left him permanently paralyzed, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday by a vote of 8 to 1.

title: Arctic Sea Ice Melting Faster, a Study Finds
description: Climate scientists may have significantly underestimated the power of global warming from human-generated heat-trapping gases to shrink the cap of sea ice floating on the Arctic Ocean, according to a new study of polar trends.

title: Steroids Dealer Testified to the Bonds Grand Jury
description: Kirk Radomski, the former Mets clubhouse assistant who has admitted selling performance-enhancing drugs to dozens of current and former professional baseball players, testified last Thursday in front of a federal grand jury investigating steroid use in sports.

title: War in the Pacific: Its Hell, Especially if Youre a Goat
description: PUERTO AYORA, Galpagos Islands  Gripping a semiautomatic rifle, Alonso Carrin, a ranger at Galpagos National Park, recently showed off an impressive arsenal inside a well-guarded complex here.

title: Chinese E-Commerce Company Said to Plan Public Offering
description: SHANGHAI, April 30  Alibaba.com, Chinas leading e-commerce company, is planning to go public later this year in what could be the biggest initial public offering ever for a Chinese Internet company, according to people briefed on the deal.

title: Trail Mix Isnt Just for Hikers
description: As tarmac-sitting stories mount and the Transportation Department investigates the possibility of unrealistic flight schedules, nutrition experts are in agreement: carry-on food is crucial for business travelers.

title: Revised Genocide Exhibit Opens
description: A United Nations exhibit on the Rwandan genocide that was dismantled three weeks ago after Turkey objected to a reference to the Armenian genocide was opened in revised form by Secretary General Ban Ki-moon. Where the original exhibit had an entry called What is genocide? that cited the deaths following World War I of a million Armenians in Turkey, the revised entry is called Defining the Crime and refers to mass killings of Armenians in the Ottoman Empire during World War I. Some 1.5 million Armenians were killed by Ottoman Turks, but Turkey says they were victims of war and unrest instead of genocide. The exhibit observes the 13th anniversary of the 100-day slaughter in Rwanda of 800,000 Tutsis by Hutus.

title: Two Giants Vie for Bank in Chicago
description: Like deep-dish pizza, the Cubs and a mayor named Daley, LaSalle Bank has long been a Chicago institution. But until a few weeks ago, few would have called it a global banking prize.

title: Wolfowitz Goes on the Attack, but Hints at a Deal
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  Paul D. Wolfowitz defended himself vigorously on Monday, declaring that it would be unjust and frankly hypocritical for the World Banks board to find him guilty of ethical lapses. But he also hinted that he would discuss whether to resign as bank president if the board cleared him of misconduct.

title: The Fountain of Youth Is as Near as the Next Party
description: Jules Peimer was a white-capped wave in a sea of staid blue suits. He wore a black velvet jacket, a white silk shirt and a psychedelic tie you might find in the artist Martin Sharps closet.

title: Some Ask if U.S. Attorney Dismissals Point to Pattern of Investigating Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  When a jury acquitted Carl J. Marlinga, a former county prosecutor from suburban Detroit, of bribery charges last year, his initial reaction was to write off the episode as a terrible mistake that at least had been corrected.

title: Costs and Divestitures Cut Verizon's Profit
description: Merger costs and the divestiture of some businesses drove Verizons profit down 8.4 percent in the first quarter, but the company continued to have strong growth in wireless and broadband subscriptions.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about a federal investigation of misconduct in the Atlanta Police Department misidentified an officer charged in a botched drug raid whose lawyer is John Garland. He is Jason R. Smith  not Arthur Tesler, another officer charged in the raid.

title: As Deportation Pace Rises, Illegal Immigrants Dig In
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass.  The day after his wife was deported to their home country, Honduras, Lilo Manca grieved as though she had died.

title: A Pianist With an Ear for Structure
description: The degree to which structure and symmetry matter to the pianist Maurizio Pollini is evident in the two programs he assembled for his Carnegie Hall recitals this season. The first, on Sunday afternoon, balanced two standard repertory composers, Chopin and Debussy, against a modernist, Pierre Boulez. The second, scheduled for May 12, is built similarly, with Beethoven and Schumann from the standard canon, and Karlheinz Stockhausen as the contemporary voice. The composers on the first program all worked in Paris, although one (Chopin) was an immigrant. On the second, the composers are all German, although one (Beethoven) moved to Vienna.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Appeal of Mexican Death Row Inmate
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear an appeal from a Mexican citizen on death row in Texas whose case has embroiled the World Court, the Bush administration and the State of Texas in a conflict that has only deepened in the two years since the justices last considered how to resolve it.

title: Safety Panel Blames Pilot Error in Lidle Crash
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  The crash that killed Cory Lidle, the Yankees pitcher, and his flight instructor in Manhattan on Oct. 11 was caused by inadequate planning, judgment, and airmanship by the two men, the National Transportation Safety Board concluded today.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a Media Talk report in Business Day yesterday, about an accusation by the magazine Radar that a Chilean publication had plagiarized its article Toxic Bachelors, misspelled the surname of a book author who had previously used the title phrase. She is Danielle Steel, not Steele.

title: Secular Parties Vow to Battle Prime Minister in Turkish Vote
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 30  Turkeys secular political leaders promised Monday to mount a unified challenge to Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan in what are likely to be early national elections. The countrys financial markets, meanwhile, dropped sharply.

title: Lord Arthur Learns About Love and Death and the Importance of Being Insouciant
description: Oscar Wildes short story Lord Arthur Saviles Crime is a clever mystery, written to indict the fate industry  the palmists, spiritualists and telepathists, frauds every one of the them, with whom late-19th-century aristocrats seemed so enthralled. The writer Rob Urbinati has used the story, with its dramatic twists and turns, as a blueprint for his latest theatrical effort, West Moon Street. And while it might seem a bit like taking paprika to Hungary, to lighten up Oscar Wilde he has molded the story into a briskly paced comedy of manners true to its authors greater spirit.

title: U.S. Says Raids Killed Taliban; Afghans Say Civilians Died
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 30  United States Special Forces said they killed more than 130 Taliban in two recent days of heavy fighting in a valley in western Afghanistan, but hundreds of angry villagers protested in nearby Shindand on Monday, saying dozens of civilians had been killed when the Americans called in airstrikes.

title: Bloomberg Unveils Plan to Redevelop Willets Point
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled today what he called his master plan to transform the Willets Point section of Queens, an unsightly enclave of junkyards and auto-repair shops near Shea Stadium, into a retailing and entertainment district with new homes and office space.

title: Octavio Frias, 94, Brazilian Media Executive, Dies
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 30  Octavio Frias de Oliveira, who built one of Brazils biggest and most influential media empires, died at his home in So Paulo on Sunday. He was 94.

title: Business Class to London: Cheaper Than You Might Think
description: HOW about some good news for a change? Business-class fares on trans-Atlantic routes are coming down. Major airlines are improving their international routes and reducing capacity on domestic routes as lower-fare competition becomes more aggressive.

title: Work Stays on Hold After Deaths in Subway
description: In response to the deaths of two track workers in accidents, transit officials yesterday suspended more than 20 maintenance projects for subway tracks, signals and tunnels for at least two more days.

title: Law Day
description: President Dwight Eisenhower established May 1 as Law Day to co-opt the biggest day on the socialist calendar. While much of the world marked May Day with critiques of capitalism and parades celebrating working men and women, the United States would honor, President Eisenhower declared, the national dedication to the principle of government under laws.

title: An Acting Governors Balancing Act: Taking the Lead Without Stepping on Toes
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  First, there was a vicious northeaster, a deadly, drenching storm that pinwheeled its way across New Jersey, soaking the state with one of its worst water-related disasters in more than a century.

title: The Wheezing That Could Signal Childhood Asthma
description: LATE last fall, Carrie R., a public relations executive who lives in Riverdale in the Bronx, noticed that her 2-year-old daughter had been suffering from a nagging cough for far too long. She assumed the toddler had caught a cold or was reacting to the change in weather.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 3 about efforts by Gov. Rick Perry of Texas to require sixth-grade girls to be vaccinated against a virus that causes cervical cancer misstated the length of time over which the vaccines three shots are administered. (The error was pointed out after it was repeated in an article on Thursday.) They are given over six months, not eight months.

title: Nutrition: Shortage of Vitamin D May Weaken the Elderly
description: Too little vitamin D is a common problem among elderly people that may help bring on medical conditions that cause weakness and disability.

title: Getting the Clearest Look at a Hurting Hip
description: LAST fall, after experiencing a dull ache in his hip for months, Frank Berger felt the pain escalating so much that he couldnt sleep. Walking became so difficult that Mr. Berger, a 59-year-old accountant in Nantucket, Mass., had to ask his secretary to bring him documents from the printer only 40 feet away.

description: WHEN George Skouras, an investment manager in New York, turned 52, he decided to go for a complete physical exam. He felt perfectly healthy, but wanted to know if there was anything to worry about.

description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, May 1  Prime Minister Tony Blair offered an indirect endorsement of Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, as his successor today, saying that in all probability, a Scot will become Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.

title: Fidel Castro Fails to Appear at Parade
description: HAVANA, Cuba, May 1 The throngs were out in the streets with their red shirts and banners, just as they always are on May Day. But Cubas holiday honoring workers came and went today without the boss ever showing his face.

title: Accounting Said to Hide Lender Losses
description: In the spring of 1998, the chief financial officer of New Century Financial, a lender to home buyers with blemished credit, wrote an unusual paper describing a then little-known accounting technique.

title: N.C.A.A. Cracks Down on Prep Schools and Angers Some
description: The N.C.A.A. quietly passed legislation last week to continue its fight against prep schools that require minimal academic study. In perhaps its most significant move to deter diploma mills, the N.C.A.A. will limit high school students to one core course that would count toward college eligibility after a students four-year high school graduation date.

title: 34 Duke Business Students Face Discipline for Cheating
description: Thirty-four first-year business graduate students at Duke University cheated on a take-home final exam, a judicial board has found, in what officials called the most widespread cheating episode in the business schools history.

title: Scientists Look to Vaccines in the War on E. Coli
description: Shousun C. Szu, a scientist at the National Institutes of Health, says the best way to prevent people from being poisoned by deadly E. coli would be to vaccinate all infants against the bacteria.

title: Consumer Spending Slows, Portending Weaker Economy
description: Personal spending in the United States rose less than forecast in March, a sign that higher gasoline prices and a sagging housing market are chipping away at a mainstay of economic expansion.

title: Your Comments on my Education Column
description: Please post your comments here on my Tuesday column about education. I particularly welcome comments from teachers or others who have seen these issues first-hand. And if you disagree with me, tell me what you would like to see as school reforms.

title: Safeguarding Food From Overseas
description: Globalization and new manufacturing capabilities have changed the makeup of the food that Americans put on their table. Food processors in the United States are buying a greater number of ingredients from other countries, becoming more of an assembler in the nations food supply chain.

title: $3 Million Homes
description: Tour a 135-acre Vermont estate, a contemporary home in Sun Valley, Idaho, and a three-bedroom condo on the beach in Malibu, Calif.

description: An enormous movie theater in Washington Heights has been turned into a major indie music venue, bringing scores of scenesters to 175th street.

description: Some of the largest of the demonstrations were in Los Angeles and in Chicago.

title: Full steam ahead: the French property market
description: The Property Finders, an international buying agency, has extended its service into the French Riviera with the appointment of Martha Saavedra. Ms. Saavedra will be covering the French Riviera from Mandelieu to Menton including St. Tropez and the East-Var.

title: Dolans Near Deal for Cablevision
description: Cablevision Systems Corporation is near a deal to sell the company to its founding family, the Dolans, for about $10.5 billion in cash, according to people involved in the discussions.

title: President Bushs Speech on the Iraq Spending Bill
description: The following is a transcript of President Bush's speech regarding his veto of the Iraq war supplemental spending bill as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.

title: Ex-Westar Executives to Face a Third Trial
description: Two former executives at Westar Energy, David C. Wittig and Douglas T. Lake, will face trial for a third time on criminal charges that accuse them of trying to loot the utility, a federal prosecutor said Monday.

title: Merrill Lynch Plans Buyback
description: Merrill Lynch said Monday that it would buy back as much as $6 billion of its common stock over time, as the firm looks to return capital that is building up on its balance sheet to investors.

title: Maker of Yoga Gear to Go Public
description: Lululemon, a Canadian retailer of yoga-inspired apparel, filed with regulators to raise as much as $230 million in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq and the Toronto Stock Exchange. The companys backers include private equity firm Advent International and venture capital firm Highland Capital Partners.

title: I.S.E. Says I Do to Deutsche Borse
description: The German stock exchange operator Deutsche Brse said Monday it is in discussions to buy the American options exchange International Securities Exchange Holdings for $2.8 billion. Deutsche Brse said its offer would value the exchange at $67.50 a share, a premium of nearly 50 percent over its closing stock price on Friday. Deutsche Brse said that it had agreed to pay $67.50 a share for the exchange, a 48 percent premium over its closing price on Friday.

title: Accounting Said to Hide Lender Losses
description: New Century Financial, the subprime lender, has a host of woes at the moment and it seems it can add the use of a certain accounting technique to that list.

title: For Buyout Firms, Patience Is a Virtue
description: Low interest rates arent the only reason that private equity firms are having a buyout bonanza, Derek DeCloet writes in The Globe and Mail. These firms have something that fund managers and the public markets seem to lack: A long-term perspective.

title: ReVision Sees $25 Million in New Round
description: The optical implant developer ReVision Optics raised $25 million in a Series D financing led by Domain Associates to support clinical trials in its quest to deliver the first commercial implants to replace reading glasses in an aging population.

title: Delta Air, Out of Bankruptcy, Sports a New Paint Job
description: Delta Air Lines emerged from bankruptcy protection Monday after surviving a hostile takeover bid and cutting billions in costs in a 19-month overhaul. The board will now turn its attention to picking a successor to its chief executive, Gerald Grinstein, and deciding whether to sell or spin off its regional feeder carrier, Comair.

title: Buyout Shop Scores Big in Deal for Tube Maker
description: Castle Harlan, the private equity firm, will make about two and a half times its money after just a year when it sells the tubing company RathGibson to DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, according to The Deal.com. DLJ Merchant Banking, the private equity arm of the Credit Suisse Group, said Monday that it would pay $440 million for RathGibson.

title: IMG Picks Up College-Sports Licensing Firm
description: IMG, the sports and media marketing firm led by the financier Theodore J. Forstmann, said Tuesday it would buy the Collegiate Licensing Company, a trademark licensing agency whose clients include the Rose Bowl, the Heisman Trophy and the N.C.A.A. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Interactive Brokers Targets $1 Billion in I.P.O.
description: The Interactive Brokers Group, an electronic broker and market-making firm controlled by Thomas Peterffy, increased the size and price range of a proposed initial public offering on Monday and said it expects to raise about $1 billion.

title: As ICEs Bid for C.B.O.T. Rises, Will the Merc Match?
description: The pressure on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to raise its bid for the Chicago Board of Trade intensified on Monday as the premium in the rival offer from the Intercontinental Exchange touched $1.5 billion for the first time, The Financial Times said.

title: Comcast Takes Stake in Cable Networks
description: Comcast said Monday it would pay $570 million for an interest in two regional cable sports networks, one in San Francisco and the other in New England. In a cash transaction withRainbow Media Holdings, Comcast will purchase a 60 percent interest in FSN Bay Area and a 50 percent interest in FSN New England.

title: Former Tyco Exec Settles With S.E.C.
description: A former Tyco International executive has agreed to settle civil charges that he helped inflate the companys profits through sham transactions, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Monday.

title: Reuters Acquires ClearForest to Enhance Text Searches
description: Reuters announced on Monday that it would acquire a text analytics company, ClearForest, to enhance its advanced search capabilities. Up until this point, ClearForest had primarily marketed its products, text analytics technologies and a tagging platform, to business clients that need to manage and facilitate access to large amounts of information.

title: BCE Shakes Up Bidding Process
description: BCE, Canadas largest telephone services provider, said Monday that it intends to attract multiple takeover bids as it considers going private.

title: V.C.-Backed Pure Digital Aims for YouTube Users
description: Pure Digital, a tech firm with some impressive financial backing, is hoping to piggyback on the success of YouTube and other online video sites with a new, inexpensive camcorder geared to older consumers who may not be as tech-savvy as their kids.

title: As Triarc Reshuffles, Some See a Future Bid for Wendys
description: Adding fuel to the speculation it could be a suitor for Wendys, The Triac Companies said Monday that it was selling its controlling stake in the money management firm Deerfield & Company for about $300 million to become a pure play restaurant operator.

title: D.E. Shaw Mulls Private Equity Fund, Report Says
description: As the line between private equity and hedge funds becomes ever more blurred, The Financial Times reports that D.E. Shaw, the $29 billion hedge fund, is considering setting up a private equity fund into which it could inject some of its existing holdings, potentially including the storied toy shop FAO Schwarz.

title: Heated Cross-Examination at the Conrad Black Trial
description: The cross-examination of Marie-Jose Kravis, a crucial witness at the trial of Conrad M. Black, grew heated on Monday when a defense lawyer attempted to portray the witness as forgetful or inept. In response, Mrs. Kravis, a former director of Mr. Blacks company, Hollinger International, maintained that she and other directors were misled about millions of dollars in payments Mr. Black and other executives received.

title: For Silver Lakes New Fund, Less Is More

title: Albany Republicans Seek Tax Rebate Increase
description: Senate Republicans said yesterday that they would seek to increase by $200 million the school property tax rebate checks that taxpayers 65 and older are eligible to receive, but Gov. Eliot Spitzers administration indicated that it would not support the proposal. Under a budget deal announced in late March, state officials added $1.3 billion to the states School Tax Relief Program, making it a nearly $5 billion-a-year program. But the several hundred thousand elderly homeowners who are eligible for higher benefits saw almost no increase when tax exemptions and rebate checks available under the program were taken into consideration. Its clear we have the resources available to give seniors greater tax relief, Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, said in a statement. But Jeffrey Gordon, a spokesman for the governors Budget Division, said Mr. Spitzer will include more relief in next years budget and will not bust the budget by adding more spending on property tax relief this year.

title: Britain: Blair Gives a Nod to Gordon Brown
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair offered an indirect endorsement of Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the Exchequer, as his successor, saying that in all probability, a Scot will become prime minister of the United Kingdom. Mr. Blair did not identify Mr. Brown by name when he addressed Labor Party supporters in Edinburgh. Labor is expected to lose ground in regional voting on Thursday, which would help set Mr. Blairs schedule to resign as party leader.

title: Owning a Home in the Suburbs of London
description: Alexandra Gilmores three-bedroom home in Surrey, a suburban county about an hour southwest of London, could not be more different from the spacious house with a big backyard and lots of storage space in which she grew up just outside Dallas.

title: Newark Man Convicted in Witnesss Murder
description: A Newark man was convicted yesterday of conspiring in the murder of a witness against him in a drug case, federal prosecutors said. The man, William Baskerville, faces either the death penalty or life in prison without parole, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey. The jury in Federal District Court is scheduled to reconvene next week to decide whether the death penalty should be applied, he said. Mr. Baskerville, charged in 2003 with selling crack cocaine to Kempo Deshawn McCray, was convicted of ordering the hiring of a hit man to kill Mr. McCray, who was a cooperating witness, Mr. Christie said. Mr. McCray was shot three times in the head on March 2, 2004.

title: You Can Almost Eat the Dishes
description: IF were not vigilant, who knows what could happen? We could wake up one dark chocolate morning to an East River of cocoa and a Hudson of hot fudge, slices of banana bobbing on its surface. The streets would be paved with bonbons, the skyscrapers bricked with fudge. Calorie counts would skyrocket. And a pox of tooth decay would descend.

title: Recipe: Mole Blanco
description: Adapted from Carmen Ramrez Degollado

title: Behind the Voice-Over, a Familiar Screen Face
description: In a studio in Manhattan last Friday, Liev Schreiber was recording the narration of Brooklyn Dodgers, a two-part documentary that HBO will show on July 11. He was a few hours from heading uptown to the Longacre Theater, where he is starring in the Broadway revival of Talk Radio as Barry Champlain, an abrasive talk show host who loathes his listeners and is losing control of himself just as his program is being syndicated.

title: Gaza: Demands for BBC Journalist Rejected
description: Palestinian Authority officials said the kidnappers of Alan Johnston, the BBC correspondent in Gaza who was abducted March 12, have made specific but unacceptable demands, the first time there has been formal contact. Azzam al-Ahmed, the deputy prime minister, said the demands were linked with ideology and politics but refused to detail them. Another security official told a Palestinian newspaper that the kidnappers were known, but that the British had urged that force not be used to free Mr. Johnston, 44, whom Palestinian officials say is alive.

title: Pet Food Chemical Unlikely to Pose Threat to Humans, Experts Say, as U.S. Continues Inquiry
description: Toxicologists monitoring the American food supply for traces of melamine after it was found in imported ingredients in the contaminated pet food that has killed at least 16 dogs and cats and sickened thousands of others said yesterday that even if there were small amounts of it in the American food supply, it would be unlikely to pose much of a threat to humans.

title: Revealing the Innovator Behind the Music
description: The rise of the music producer Ahmet Ertegun was more like the intensely groovy embellishment of the lofty status he was born with.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,344 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

description: In Transition

title: Rupert Murdoch Offers $5 Billion Bid for Dow Jones
description: In a bold move to expand his global media empire, Rupert Murdoch, the head of the News Corporation, has made an unsolicited $5 billion offer to buy Dow Jones & Company, the venerable publisher of The Wall Street Journal, which he has long coveted.

title: Torre Says He Is Grateful for Steinbrenners Support
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 1  Joe Torre called George Steinbrenner, the Yankees principal owner, on Monday night to thank him for his latest statement, in which Steinbrenner said he believed in Torre and the rest of the Yankees.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about Mark Halperin, who stepped down as the political director of ABC News and will join Time magazine, misstated his role at both media outlets. He is a political  not a policy  analyst. Because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly to John F. Harris who, with Mr. Halperin wrote a book about the 2008 presidential race. Mr. Harris, who was at The Washington Post when the book was published last fall, is now editor in chief of The Politico, which covers national politics.

title: Iraqi Officials Say Top Qaeda Leader May Have Been Killed
description: BAGHDAD, May 1  The Iraqi government said Tuesday that it was investigating reports from reliable sources that the leader of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, Abu Ayyub al-Masri, had been killed in an ambush by a rival insurgent faction.

title: In Subways, Safety Course for Workers
description: The curriculum drawn up to give New York City Transit workers an urgent refresher course in safety after two fatal on-the-job accidents last month draws a single, blunt conclusion for avoiding future disasters: No Short Cuts.

title: Yield Documents, Lawmaker Tells White House
description: The chairman of the House education committee asked the White House yesterday to turn over all its communications about the scandal-tarred student loan program and also Reading First, the administrations $1-billion-a-year reading initiative, which has been besieged by accusations of conflict of interest.

title: Court Says Congressman Must Pay Damages
description: A federal appeals court in Washington ruled Tuesday that Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, must pay damages to another congressman for giving reporters a tape of an illegally intercepted telephone call.

description: Adapted from Mario Batali

title: A Harsh, Healthy Verdict in Israel
description: Israels government badly botched the war in Lebanon last summer. But you have to admire the work of the investigating commission that same government appointed to analyze what had gone wrong. In its initial report, the commission pointed to severe failures of judgment, responsibility and prudence on the part of Prime Minister Ehud Olmert.

description: Adapted from New Arabian Cuisine by Ingo Maass and Lutz Jkel (Umschau)

title: Players Gather Round to Kiss a Music Hall Good Night
description: For those of us born in the 1960s, it is a little unnerving to watch Lincoln Center, another child of the 60s, being treated for the manifestations of advanced age. As part of the complexs continuing reconstructive surgery, Alice Tully Hall  the penultimate Lincoln Center edifice to be completed when it opened in 1969  is getting a complete overhaul in the next 18 months. To send it off into its Brnnhilde-like slumber, a gala concert called Good Night Alice was held on Monday night, showcasing most of the halls major functions and tenants over the last 38 years. It struck the perfect tone: half festive, half somnolent.

title: Timing of Fund-Raisers Gives Fuel to Spitzers Critics
description: ALBANY, May 1  Gov. Eliot Spitzer has made tightening New Yorks campaign finance laws his principal goal for the rest of the Legislative session, going so far as to mount a statewide tour to attack Senate Republicans who oppose his plan.

title: A New (Very New) Generation Steps Into Its Shoes
description: The gala for the Youth America Grand Prix, Stars of Today Meet the Stars of Tomorrow, has never been a staid affair. Rather, this presentation  the culminating performance of an international dance competition conceived and coordinated by two former Bolshoi members, Gennadi and Larissa Saveliev  moves closer to So You Think You Can Dance every year.

title: Recipe: Plantain and Black Bean Empanadas
description: Adapted from Carmen Ramrez Degollado

title: Steroid Lugs Grab Midol, Manssieres and Clomid
description: Any baseball lug on a steroid bender can remain in touch with his feminine side but still feel a tad self-conscious when encountering a Midol moment or when shopping for a manssiere in the Seinfeld catalog.
