title: Cyberonics Names Chief and Says Marketing Will Shift
description: Cyberonics, the troubled maker of implantable stimulators, said yesterday that it had recruited a senior Boston Scientific marketing executive to become its chief executive and that it would aim to return to profitability by cutting back on efforts to market its device as an antidepression treatment.

title: Interior Official Steps Down Over Rules Violation
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  A deputy assistant secretary at the Interior Department resigned Monday, a month after the departments inspector general issued a stinging report that said she violated federal rules by giving industry lobbyists internal agency documents and rode roughshod over agency scientists.

title: Study of N.B.A. Sees Racial Bias in Calling Fouls
description: An academic study of the National Basketball Association, whose playoffs continue tonight, suggests that a racial bias found in other parts of American society has existed on the basketball court as well.

title: Easing Swimming Pool Maintenance
description: A sparkling and refreshing swimming pool may be the ultimate symbol of relaxation on a warm weekend, but pools also have a less desirable quality: they can be distinctly high maintenance.

title: Japanese Gardens Meet American Activities
description: The Mannes Contemporary Music Festival is presenting a diverse array of modern works over four nights this week, some still hot off the laser printer. The festival began on Monday night with a concert by the ensemble NewMusicMannes, directed by Madeleine Shapiro, in the concert hall of Mannes College the New School for Music. The program held to no overarching theme, but the best of what was offered neatly illustrated the diversity of options available to modern composers.

title: Uzbekistan: Rights Worker Imprisoned
description: A court in Tashkent sentenced Umida Niyazova, a journalist and human rights worker, to seven years in prison. Amnesty International has called Ms. Niazova a prisoner of conscience. According to local reports, her lawyer was given only 30 minutes warning before the resumption of the trial, in which she was found guilty of smuggling and distributing illegal material. Four days earlier, the authorities had sent a well-known Uzbek doctor, Gulbahor Turayeva, who advocated for patients rights, to prison for six years. She was arrested in January when the police said she possessed several banned books.

title: Turkish Court Blocks Islamic Candidate
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 1  Turkeys highest court on Tuesday blocked a presidential candidate with a background in Islamic politics, pitching the country into early elections and a referendum on the role of religion in its future.

title: Qwests Profit Nearly Triples
description: Qwest Communications, the telephone carrier, reported yesterday that its quarterly profit nearly tripled mostly because of cost cuts and an increase in broadband Internet customers.

description: BANGKOK, May 2  Ousted as prime minister in a coup last September, Thaksin Shinawatra has made a move to console himself with the possible purchase of an English soccer club.

title: Lacking Alps, Goats Settle in Westchester
description: Few farms remain within an hours drive of New York City, and to have one added instead of subtracted is an achievement. In Bedford Hills, N.Y., a Westchester County playground for moguls, Lisa and Mark Schwartz gradually accumulated 35 acres that they turned into Rainbeau Ridge, where they have 24 Alpine goats and make cheese.

description: Peter J. Gomes has been at Harvard University for 37 years, and says he remembers when religious people on campus felt under siege. To be seen as religious often meant being dismissed as not very bright, he said.

title: Driver in Tanker Crash Served a Sentence for Drugs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1  The driver of a gasoline tanker that overturned early Sunday, sparking a fire that destroyed a vital highway interchange near downtown Oakland, has a criminal record, including a two-year prison sentence for drug possession, the authorities said Tuesday.

description: Qwest Communications, the telephone carrier, reported yesterday that its quarterly profit nearly tripled mostly because of cost cuts and an increase in broadband Internet customers.

description: AMHERST, Mass.

title: Turkish Man Arrested After Group Disrupts Book Reading
description: A Turkish native was arrested after he and others disrupted a book reading about the Armenian genocide at a Barnes & Noble store on the Upper East Side last night, the police said.

title: Icahn Uses Ad in Seeking Seat on Motorola
description: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn published a letter to Motorola shareholders as a full-page advertisement in The Wall Street Journal yesterday, stepping up his campaign to get a seat on the companys board.

description: Cablevision Systems announced an agreement today to sell itself to its founding family, the Dolans, for more than $10.5 billion in cash.

description: ON Monday the years biggest gathering of chefs, food journalists, and other culinary professionals and amateurs will convene at one of the grander locales in New York, Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center, for the James Beard Foundation Awards.

description: For a native New Yorker mounting a first bid for national office, Rudolph W. Giuliani has shown an impressive ability to raise money in Texas, where his Republican presidential campaign collected $2.2 million in the first quarter of the year, far more than any other candidate.

title: The Philippines: Charge in Peace Corps Killing
description: The police have filed a murder complaint against a woodcarver who confessed to bludgeoning to death a Peace Corps volunteer who was hiking in the mountains on April 8. They said the woodcarver, Juan Duntugan, 24, told them he had hit the volunteer, Julia Campbell, of Fairfax, Va., with a stick and a rock because he was angry at a neighbor. Asked by an investigator how long he had hit her, The Associated Press reported, he replied: I think about five minutes. I dont remember how many times I hit her with that stone. Ms. Campbell, 40, had worked as a freelance journalist for a number of publications including The New York Times.

title: Election Commission Imposes Fines
description: The campaign of Representative Rick Renzi, Republican of Arizona, agreed to pay a $25,000 fine for underreporting contributions and expenses, the Federal Election Commission said. The Renzi campaign said that the mistake was unintentional. The agency also said that the Democratic National Committee agreed to pay an $82,000 fine for improperly reporting more than $1 million it spent in the 2004 presidential campaign.

title: Deportation in Narration
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Kent State Tape Is Said to Reveal Orders
description: KENT, Ohio, May 1  An audio recording of the shootings 37 years ago at Kent State University includes the voices of Ohio National Guard leaders ordering troops to fire into a crowd of students, according to a man wounded in the shootings, who obtained a copy of the recording.

title: Doubt at Derby After Road That Included Synthetic Surfaces
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30  They will put 20 horses in the starting gate Saturday, evenly matched 3-year-olds in from all corners of the country, none of whom had ever raced at a mile and a quarter. The Kentucky Derby is already the sports most difficult handicapping puzzle, and this year there will be a new twist. For the first time, horses that have earned their way into the field after winning major prep races over synthetic racing surfaces will be among the 20 starters. How will they do? No one seems to know.

title: Israels Foreign Minister Says Olmert Should Go
description: JERUSALEM, May 3  Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmerts deputy called on him to resign today after a harshly critical government report about his management of last summers war against Hezbollah.

description: Is Willets Point, the eyesore near Shea Stadium that is known for its auto parts stores, its potholes and its puddles, about to go green?

description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1  The San Francisco Giants gave their first public tribute to Barry Bonds before he played his first game with them.

description: The Welsh Girl is a distinguished, beautifully written example of a small but enduring genre. Call it the counterwar novel. Not antiwar, exactly; it lacks the belligerence.

title: A Green Face-Lift for the Governors Mansion
description: ALBANY, May 1  The house at 138 Eagle Street here does not immediately seem like a fixer-upper. A stately 20,000-square-foot mansion, home to New Yorks governors and their families since 1875, it has a pool, a tennis court and views of the Hudson River.

title: Like a Politician, Delta Hits the Comeback Trail
description: IT is no coincidence that an ambitious effort by Delta Air Lines to restore luster to its tarnished brand image resembles attempts by elected officials who fall from grace to regain public confidence.

description: John Browne, an aggressive but mannerly British magnate who transformed BP into one of the most successful global companies, resigned abruptly yesterday after losing a court battle with a London tabloid over details of his relationship with a younger man.

title: Wolfowitz Gets Chilly Reception in Brussels
description: BRUSSELS, May 2  Paul Wolfowitz, the embattled president of the World Bank who came to Brussels today to mobilize world governments on education policy in the developing world, was forced instead to dodge questions about an intensifying ethics scandal.

title: Tom Poston, Virtuosic Comic Actor, Is Dead at 85
description: Tom Poston, an Emmy-winning comic actor whose television characters ranged from the slow-witted Everyman on "The Steve Allen Show" to a cantankerous closet-dwelling clown on the recent sitcom "Committed," died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 85.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption in some copies on Sunday with a Sports of The Times column about the PGA Tours handling of Tiger Woods given his support among corporate sponsors misidentified the man shown with Woods. He is AT&Ts chairman and chief executive, Edward E. Whitacre Jr.  not Tim Finchem, the PGA Tour commissioner.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary yesterday about Tommy Newsom, the backup bandleader for The Tonight Show whom Johnny Carson used as a comical target, misstated part of the name of the Air Force jazz ensemble in which he played. It is the Airmen of Note, not Airman.

description: Rabbits will fall by the wayside for the New York City Marathon.

title: Laid-Back Risotto
description: AS soon as this springs vegetables began to appear, I wanted to revisit a favorite dish, a risotto that features asparagus front and center.

title: Immigrant Rights Rallies Smaller Than Last Year
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1  Tens of thousands of people pressing for immigrants rights demonstrated on Tuesday in dozens of cities. But with advocates splintered over tactics, the crowds paled in comparison with the turnout last year.

title: Loopholes and More Loopholes
description: Virginia claims that it has closed a loophole that put guns in the hands of a deranged student who killed 32 people at Virginia Tech. But theres always the next loophole to worry about when it comes to the lack of gun control in this country.

title: For Most Bush Voters, No Regrets After 2 Years
description: George W. Bush was elected to a second term by a big majority of Republicans, half of political independents and 11 percent of Democrats. Now, more than two years later, the majority of those voters say they are satisfied with the Bush presidency. But some have lost faith, and those who have say it is because they can no longer back Mr. Bushs support of the war in Iraq.

Hammer, the longtime trustee for the family, quipped to a reporter: Wed rather sell at $60 a share. If you know any buyers, send them my way.

description: Sometimes beauty of tone is everything, and sometimes it can turn a meaty work into nothing but ear candy. It depends on the music at hand, and a musicians sense of when to luxuriate in tonal richness and when to let other qualities seize the moment.

title: Jury Hears Victims Terror in 911 Call After Her Ordeal
description: Her demeanor on the witness stand was calm and crisp as she testified on Monday about being dosed with chloroform, stripped and tied to her bed by a masked man on Oct. 31, 2005.

title: Spying on Americans
description: For more than five years, President Bush authorized government spying on phone calls and e-mail to and from the United States without warrants. He rejected offers from Congress to update the electronic eavesdropping law, and stonewalled every attempt to investigate his spying program.

description: WASHINGTON, May 1  Momentum is building in Congress behind a measure that would push states to report their mental health records to the federal database used to conduct background checks on gun buyers.

title: Lottery Numbers
Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (22, 26) ATLANTIC RECORDS: THE HOUSE THAT AHMET BUILT Ahmet Ertegun, left, was living in Washington when he first heard African-American music in that citys segregated clubs. The son of a Turkish diplomat, he exported that sound to England, where he merged it with a European sensibility, and then brought it back to the United States, where he started an independent label with Herb Abramson and a $10,000 loan from his dentist. One result was the boogie-based, saxophone-driven Atlantic Sound, which changed the face of contemporary American music. Mr. Erteguns roster at Atlantic Records included Ray Charles, Ruth Brown, Big Joe Turner, LaVern Baker and the Drifters. In this documentary, Eric Clapton, Aretha Franklin, David Geffen, Mick Jagger, Kid Rock, Henry Kissinger, Jimmy Page, Robert Plant and Jann Wenner, among others, talk about the musical influence of Mr. Ertegun, who died in December.

title: U.S. Seeks Closing of Visa Loophole for Britons
description: LONDON, May 1  Omar Khyam, the ringleader of the thwarted London bomb plot who was sentenced to life imprisonment on Monday, showed the potential for disaffected young men to be lured as terrorists, a threat that British officials said they would have to contend with for a generation.

title: If Your Martini Needs Company, Look to the East
description: A well-made dry martini is a serious, contemplative drink, one that can easily overwhelm anything served with it. But a nibble that offers a touch of fat and salt is always welcome. Good potato chips would be the ticket.

title: A No-Hit Bid by Hughes Ends With a Leg Injury
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 1  The Yankees were gazing hopefully at their future on Tuesday when the present intervened. It was sudden, it was deflating, and it was cosmically cruel.

title: Corzine Fined, at His Request, for Not Wearing a Seat Belt
description: TRENTON, May 1  Gov. Jon S. Corzine voluntarily paid a $46 fine on Tuesday for failing to wear a seat belt, as required by law, on the day when his state vehicle crashed on the Garden State Parkway last month, state officials said.

title: Staten Island Councilmans Staff Did Personal Work
description: The citys Conflicts of Interest Board has found that Councilman Michael E. McMahon, left, had one of his staff members perform personal tasks for him on city time, including helping his 12-year-old daughter with her homework. The inquiry began last year when city officials received an anonymous letter claiming that Mr. McMahon, a Staten Island Democrat, was using his city-paid staff for political campaigning. Mr. McMahon was cleared of that allegation, but investigators found that he had allowed his administrative assistant to type a poem for his daughter while she was visiting his Council office. Mr. McMahon also had his assistant call parents of a youth soccer team he coached to tell them of scheduling changes or that he would be late for games or practices because of Council-related business. Mr. McMahon, who did not dispute the findings, said his staff would no longer perform personal tasks because that is the strict letter of the rules. The board recommended no fines or penalties, given the limited nature of the violation. City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn said she would refer the findings to the Councils Standards and Ethics Committee for further review.

title: Donald P. Lay, 80, Federal Judge Notable in Rights Cases, Dies
description: Donald P. Lay, a former chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit who rigorously defended the rights of women, Native Americans and convicts during his 40 years on the bench, died Sunday at his home in North Oaks, Minn. He was 80.

title: Are Book Reviewers Out of Print?
description: Last year Dan Wickett, a former quality-control manager for a car-parts maker, wrote 95 book reviews on his blog, Emerging Writers Network (emergingwriters.typepad.com/), singlehandedly compiling almost half as many reviews as appeared in all of the book pages of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution.

description: Qwest Communications reported today that its quarterly profit nearly tripled, mainly because of cost cuts and an increase in broadband Internet customers.

description: WASHINGTON, May 1  President Bush vetoed a $124 billion war spending bill on Tuesday, setting up a second round in his long battle with Congressional Democrats who are determined to use the financing measure to force the White House to shift course in Iraq.

title: Elections in Britain Reveal a Scottish Line in the Sand
description: KIRKCALDY, Scotland, April 30  Gordon Brown, Britains presumed prime minister-to-be, is usually associated with a somewhat dour manner and a mastery of statistics. But here, he displays other skills  a bolt-on smile and a ready handshake to work sparse crowds between the discount stores on the High Street, asking parents with strollers whether their new babies are keeping them awake at night, and inquiring whether the men support the local Raith Rovers soccer team.

title: No Sign of Fidel Castro on Cuban Holiday
description: HAVANA, May 1  The throngs were out in the streets with their red shirts and banners just as they always are on May Day, but Cubas holiday honoring workers came and went Tuesday without their longtime leader ever showing his face.

title: Your Plate Is Bigger Than Your Stomach
description: Late last year, a little book called Mindless Eating started appearing in bookstores. It was written by Brian Wansink, a Cornell professor who has spent his career doing brilliantly mischievous experiments about the psychology of eating.

title: After 27 Years, Yonkers Housing Desegregation Battle Ends Quietly in Manhattan Court
description: The federal judge had been on the bench just over a year when the lawsuit first hit his docket; now he is semi-retired. The lawyer for the plaintiffs, now 53, was three years out of law school when he was assigned the case. And the current president of the Yonkers branch of the N.A.A.C.P., which filed the suit on behalf of poor blacks and Latinos living in segregated public housing, was still in her teens at the time the litigation began.

title: Closing the Claremont Stables
description: Almost nothing captures a sense of the past like the sound of a horses hooves on the pavement of Manhattan  nothing, that is, except the smell of a horse. The island was once pervaded by both. Now all that is left of those great urban herds are the carriage horses in Central Park, the police horses in Midtown and, until last Sunday, the horses of the Claremont Riding Academy on West 89th Street.

title: In a Reversal, U.S. Says Medicare Wont Cover Stents for Neck Arteries
description: Responding to criticism from surgeons, the government has dropped its previously announced plans to expand Medicare coverage for the use of stents to prop open neck arteries to prevent strokes.

title: House Fails to Override Bush Veto on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  House Democrats fell far short of overriding President Bushs veto of the $124 billion war spending bill this afternoon, clearing the stage for negotiations between the president and lawmakers on a new bill.

title: Iraqi Blocs Concerned Over Oil Bill
description: ERBIL, Iraq, May 2  Kurdish and Sunni Arab officials expressed deep reservations today about the draft version of a national oil law and related legislation, misgivings that could derail one of the benchmark measures of progress in Iraq laid down by President George W. Bush.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about Symphony Space and the various arts programs it presents referred incompletely to the American Symphony Orchestras presence in New York City. While the orchestra is moving its annual series of concerts at Miller Theater to Symphony Space, it will continue its annual series of concerts at Lincoln Center.

title: After Working the Streets, Bunk Beds and a Mass
description: Every Sunday morning in a second-floor apartment in Astoria, Queens, the Rev. Louis Braxton Jr. rouses a half-dozen sleeping bodies from bunk beds in two cramped rooms littered with stiletto heels and skimpy dresses.

title: Turkish Prime Minister Calls for Early Elections
description: ISTANBUL, May 2  Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan asked the Turkish parliament today to approve early national elections for June 24 and his party began to press for several constitutional changes that would bring it advantages in the coming political battle.

title: And to My Loyal Feng Shui Adviser, I Leave $3 Billion
Sirius Loss Narrows and Beats Estimates

title: Guantanamo as the Lesser Evil

[C]losing GTMO would much more [likely] result in more detainees being held in facilities closer to the actual battlefield, such as Bagram, rather than in domestic [facilities], writes Georgetown law professor Marty Lederman at the group legal blog Balkinization. And that would hardly improve matters from a legal or human rights perspective. Moreover, if GTMO were closed, more of the detainees there might be transferred to nations such as Libya, where there is a real risk that they may be tortured. He concludes, A better idea would be for Congress to require that due process and some form of meaningful judicial review be provided at GTMO and at other detention facilities around the globe.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs proposal to hire 32 more New York City fire marshals misstated the number of fires in 2006 and included an erroneous comparison to statistics from earlier years. There were 27,817 fires in 2006, according to the Fire Department  not 6,023, which was the number of fires investigated that year. In the early 1980s, fire marshals investigated about 13,000 fires a year; that is not the number they fought.

title: A Planet Denser Than Earth
description: Despite being the size of Jupiter and made mostly of hydrogen, a planet around a star 440 light-years away is denser than Earth, astronomers at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass., announced. The astronomers were able to measure the size of the planet, designated HAT-P-2b, because it passes directly in front of the star every 5 days and 15 hours, causing it to dim slightly. HAT-P-2b, in the constellation Hercules, is more than eight times the mass of Jupiter, and the immense gravity crushes the planet down to its relatively small size and Earth-like density.

title: Canada: Earnings Rise at Telephone Giant

Poor performance in the wireless unit meant that Bell Canada revenue rose just 0.4 percent over the same quarter a year earlier, reaching 3.58 billion Canadian dollars ($3.22 billion). Bell Mobility signed up just 13,000 cellphone subscribers during the period compared with 76,000 a year earlier. Recent price increases by Bell Mobility have not been matched by competitors. BCE said last month that it was in talks with Canadian pension funds and private equity investors that might lead to its going private.

After that we started to negotiate my future in Europe, and we are almost closing on it, she said in a recent e-mail message from her native Brazil. I am still racing F3, but now I will start to drive the British F3 car in the U.K. It could lead to an opportunity to race bigger cars, she said, and I would love to do it.

Mr. Gates appeared at a Pentagon news conference with Togo D. West Jr. and John O. Marsh Jr., two former Army secretaries who were co-chairmen of an independent review group appointed in February after disclosures of poor conditions and bureaucratic delays at Walter Reed, the Armys main hospital for treating soldiers wounded in Iraq and Afghanistan. Some members of Congress have called for reconsidering a Pentagon plan to close the medical center by 2011. But Mr. Gates said it would be far better to make an investment in brand-new 21st-century facilities.

At Sugarbush Resort in Vermont, mountain biking returns after a 12-year break; Tahoes Northstar Resort, closed to riders last summer, also re-opens its fat-tire trails. For the first time, Jackson Hole in Wyoming will crank up the Bridger Gondola to 9,095 feet for paragliding, rock climbing and backpacking. And Whistler-Blackcomb in British Columbia has the best of both worlds: a new mountain-top yoga session at Whistler and schussing throughout the summer on Blackcombs glacier.

description: A front-page article yesterday about the News Corporations bid for Dow Jones & Company referred imprecisely to the number of paid subscribers to WSJ.com, the online version of The Wall Street Journal. It has 931,000, rather a lot more than 700,000.

title: A Dual-Screen DVD Player, Suited to Separating Feuding Children
description: Nothing beats a portable DVD player for a long trip  except perhaps one with two screens. Designed for those with more than one child, the Disney Dual Screen Mobile DVD Player can simultaneously display a movie or video game on two 7-inch screens.

title: Boldness That Won Him Wide Attention Costs a Brash Young Mayor His Re-election Bid
description: NEW PALTZ, N.Y., May 2  Jason West first shocked this funky village of 6,000 residents in 2003, when as a 26-year-old house painter, puppeteer and environmentalist he was elected mayor after two establishment candidates split the vote. He became the first Green Party member to be a mayor in New York State.

title: No Store Is a Hero to Its Valet
description: THE butler did it. Or  wait  maybe it was the maid. Or maybe, just maybe, it was the scowling doormen who looked me up and down disapprovingly and made me feel like Oprah trying to shop at Herms.

title: All His Rooms Are Living Rooms
description: Crteil, France

title: Gene Links Longevity and Diet, Scientists Say
description: Scientists have identified a gene that makes roundworms live longer when they eat less, a finding they hope could lead to drugs that promote human longevity, but without the pain of strict dieting.

title: Investor-to-Be in Starrett City Is Bargaining for New Deal
description: Rebuffed by state and federal regulators over his plan to buy Starrett City for $1.3 billion, David Bistricer is now bargaining with the current owner over a lower sale price and devising a plan that he hopes will pass muster with government officials, local politicians and the 14,000 tenants at the vast Brooklyn housing complex.

title: Canada: Real Estate Concern Plans Spinoff
description: Brookfield Asset Management said it would focus on its real estate holdings, which include the World Financial Center in Manhattan, by spinning off about $1 billion in infrastructure assets to shareholders. The assets, which will be held by a newly created company, Brookfield Infrastructure Partners, include 1.2 million acres of timberlands in Canada and the United States, as well as electrical transmission facilities in Canada, Brazil and Chile. Brookfield Asset, based in Toronto, will hold a 40 percent stake in the new company. Brookfield Asset also said it would split its shares 3-for-2.

title: Feeling Warmth, Subtropical Plants Move North
description: ATLANTA, May 2  Like a true belle, this city flounces into bloom when the weather turns, its redbuds, azaleas and forsythia emerging like so much lace on a bodice.

title: Robert M. Warner, 79, the National Archivist, Dies
description: Robert M. Warner, who built a legislative consensus to wrest the National Archives from political control when he was its director, died on April 24 in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 79. The cause was a heart attack after a yearlong battle with cancer, his son, Mark Warner, said.

title: Beware the Afterglow
description: YEARS before Ursula Andress, the Swiss actress who was the first Bond girl, emerged from the waves in Dr. No with her caramel skin offset by a blindingly white bikini, the tan had taken hold as the abiding fashion image.

title: F.D.A. Expands Suicide Warning on Drugs
description: The Food and Drug Administration ordered drug makers yesterday to add warnings to antidepressant medications, saying the drugs increase the risk of suicidal thinking or behavior in some young adults.

title: The Lost Get a Hand From a New Entrant in G.P.S. Devices
description: Why dont you pull over and ask for directions? Portable G.P.S. navigation is helping to cut down on that particular form of nagging. Last year, according to the Consumer Electronics Association, sales of G.P.S. units topped $800 million.

title: Cablevision Deal Remains Very Much Up in the Air
description: At the Cablevision Systems annual board meeting in Palm Beach, Fla., in March, the companys founding Dolan family held a private meeting with the boards special committee  the two men who had rejected previous buyout offers from the family.

title: The Yester Dressers
description: SNAP-BRIM hats, cool shades and pearls  they are the ingredients of self-invention. Stirred with a pinch of audacity, they yielded a few of the giddy turnouts on parade at the vintage fashion fairs that sprang up last month all around town.

title: Next Week
description: Carlo Rotella writes about the Mayweather-De la Hoya bout and the current state of boxing.

title: Mr. Smith Goes to Baltimore
description: Every time a great college football player slides toward the bottom of the N.F.L. draft, I get a feeling like mind erasure. The players rejection by the pro teams seems to stand as a repudiation of his college achievements. Wait a second, I think, wasnt this guy a holy terror on Saturdays?

title: In the Swirl of Bodies, a Flurry of Emotions
description: Alonzo King and his San Francisco-based Lines Ballet have long been a puzzle. Mr. King has his feet planted in two popular choreographic worlds: African fusion, and the go nowhere fast school, though the movement uncharacteristically wells up from the dancers bodies rather than being laid on them. So his work is different and his own.

title: A Radical Idea: Close the Door
description: Peter Kaufman is an unlikely urban guerrilla. Would he toss a bomb? Not a chance. Encourage mass civil disobedience? Hardly his style. Picket government buildings or refuse to pay his taxes? No and no.

title: Reforming the F.D.A.
description: A bill headed for a vote in the Senate would usher in much needed reforms at the Food and Drug Administration. But it also risks making the agency even more dependent on funds from the industry it regulates.

title: Bloomberg in Spanish: Now He Can Hold Up His End of the Conversation
description: On his recent jaunt to Mexico, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg fielded questions from Mexican reporters and, to the surprise of many, responded in Spanish.

title: First the Bid, Now the Jockeying
description: And now for the charm offensive.

title: Court Rejects Limit on Bids by Convicts for DNA Tests
description: CINCINNATI, May 2  In a unanimous decision, the Ohio Supreme Court overturned on Wednesday the part of a broader 2003 law that required prosecutors consent to allow felons who had pleaded guilty to crimes to seek DNA tests that could prove their innocence.

title: U.N. Says Bosnian Police Officers May Reapply
description: The Security Council has ruled that 700 former Bosnian police officers dismissed by United Nations police trainers after the 1992-1995 civil war for misconduct or alleged involvement in war crimes can reapply for law enforcement work, though not necessarily the same jobs they had. Emyr Jones Parry, the British ambassador to the United Nations, president of the council in April, said in a letter to Bosnian authorities that the countrys standards for recruitment and selection were now acceptable and that individuals could regain police jobs as long as they met those standards. In recent years, 260 of the officers have protested their firings, saying they were guilty only of minor misconduct. Mr. Jones Parry said that his letter should not be interpreted as guaranteeing reinstatement.

title: Taking Risks for Mideast Peace (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Outing Finds Bush in the Thick of Softball Season
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  President Bush did not leave Washington on Wednesday. But for at least two hours he was transported to a different world, away from inquiries involving the credibility of top aides and questions about the war in Iraq. The place was a hotel ballroom just a couple of blocks from the White House, where he took questions from supporters. It was not so much a grilling as a warming.

title: Concern Is High and Unity Hopes Are Nil at Talks on Iraq
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, May 2  Four years ago at this Red Sea resort, leaders of Saudi Arabia and Egypt were photographed as passengers in a golf cart driven by President Bush. The symbolism led to taunting headlines in the regions newspapers.

title: A Book Full of Tips for Use in the Trenches
description: Mel Colchamiro is a professional bridge player and teacher who lives in Merrick, on Long Island. He has distilled his bridge experiences into a book titled How You Can Play Like an Expert (Magnus Books).

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A Sports of The Times column in some copies on Sunday, about the continuing problems with steroids in Major League Baseball, referred incorrectly to the origin of a rule covering conduct detrimental to the sport. The top professional leagues included a conduct clause in their governing agreement in 1896, and baseball historians say the notion probably emerged before that. The concept was not created by Kenesaw Mountain Landis, who was elected baseballs first commissioner in 1920, and who is credited with rigorous enforcement of the conduct clause.

title: Former Taipei Mayor Nominated
description: The Central Standing Committee of the opposition Nationalist Party nominated Ma Ying-jeou, the former mayor of Taipei, to be the partys candidate in presidential elections to be held early next year. A full party congress on June 24 is expected to confirm the nomination. Mr. Ma, a Harvard-educated lawyer, has long been seen as the most likely Taiwanese official to bring about a partial reconciliation with the mainland. But he stepped down as party chairman in February after he was indicted for using $339,000 from a mayoral expense account for personal needs; prosecutors have begun a crackdown on the widespread practice among Taiwanese officials of treating expense budgets as part of their personal compensation.

title: Judges Charge 2 Top Sudanese With Atrocities in Darfur Area
description: PARIS, May 2  Judges at the International Criminal Court in The Hague have issued arrest warrants for two citizens of Sudan, the first to be charged with grave atrocities in Darfur, the court said Wednesday.

title: Arts Library Planned in Brooklyn Hits a Snag
description: The new arts library designed by Enrique Norten that was supposed to rise like the prow of a glass ship near the Brooklyn Academy of Music now seems likely to sink, unrealized, into the pavement.

title: Common Gene Raises Heart Risk, Studies Find
description: Two rival teams of scientists have discovered a genetic variation that increases the risk of heart disease, the leading cause of death worldwide, by up to 60 percent in people of European descent. They hope a test for the variant will enable physicians to assess patients at risk more accurately and to recommend early intervention.

title: Qaeda Figure in Iraq Is Killed, U.S. Military Says
description: BAGHDAD, May 3  American troops killed a senior propagandist for Al Qaeda in Iraq who was involved in kidnapping westerners, including Jill Carroll, the American journalist, American military officials said today. But they denied claims from Iraqi officials that the body was identified as the leader of the group.

title: A Puck-Crazed Town in Sweden Churns Out N.H.L. Stars
description: ORNSKOLDSVIK, Sweden, April 27  Everyone here seems to agree that Victor Hedman is a hockey prodigy. At 16, he not only has the skills, speed and size  6-foot-5, 215 pounds  to be a great defenseman, but, according to his coach, Hedman also possesses that rare, quiet determination that elevates raw talent into stardom.

title: Hi-Def Camcorders
description: New camcorders from Sony and JVC give home movies the same kind of clarity as Hollywood releases.

title: In Web Uproar, Antipiracy Code Spreads Wildly
description: After several Web sites posted a secret code used to prevent piracy of high-definition movies, corporate lawyers demanded that the code be removed. Internet users responded by distributing it even more widely in what was characterized as an exercise of free-speech rights.

title: On the Web
description: Images from "Spider-Man 3."

title: The Get
description: Tee-hee towels, the sharpest knives and more.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary yesterday about Carl Friedrich von Weizscker, a German scientist and peace activist, misstated the year American troops raided his laboratory and found no evidence of progress toward making a workable nuclear weapon. It was 1944, not 1940.

title: In-Store | The Hungry Eye
description: Nicole Farhi combines style and sustenance. Sandra Ballentine joins her well-laid table.

title: The New Collectibles
description: To have and to hold on to.

title: Strategies for Success
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Trunk Food
description: On the road with beach-blanket favorites.

title: Excerpts From Previous French Debates
description: Since 1974, the two presidential candidates in the runoff have squared off during a televised debate aired live between the two rounds of the elections. The exception to the rule was in 2002, when incumbent President Jacques Chirac refused to meet Jean-Marie Le Pen, the far right leader who had qualified in an upset by defeating the socialist candidate Lionel Jospin.
For a bunch of big-city aesthetes, Burgenland is their own private paradise.  Maura Egan stops and smells the strudel.

title: Single Space
description: Bachelor pads that redefine the Alpha male's natural habitat.

title: Senator Clintons Remarks
description: Following is the text of Hillary Rodham Clinton's remarks on legislation to end authority for the Iraq War:

description: Five women who defined  and defied  a generation's standards of beauty.

description: Five notable performances from the summer movies season.
