description: Calico

title: A Note to Readers: Change to Columnist Schedule
description: The Op-Ed columnists appear on the following schedule.

title: Letting Go of the Elephant
description: Dularys exit from The Philadelphia Zoo this week did not lack for fanfare.

title: Dow Jones: Well-Timed Options Trades Stir Suspicions
description: Did word of Rupert Murdochs offer for Dow Jones & Company leak out early?

title: Boston Scientific Deal Maker to Step Down
description: Lawrence Best, chief financial officer of Boston Scientific and the architect of the companys $27 billion Guidant acquisition, will leave his job in July, Boston Scientific said Wednesday. He will be succeeded by Sam Leno, chief financial officer of Zimmer Holdings, a maker of artificial knees, hips, and other orthopedic implants.

title: Fujitsu Buys French Computer-Services Firm
description: Fujitsu plans to buy GFI Informatique of France for 419 million euros ($569 million) to add computer-services clients and reduce its reliance on Japan. Fujitsu, based in Tokyo, intends to offer 8.50 euros for each GFI share and 3.15 euros for each warrant of the company, a computer consultant based in Paris.

title: The Same Goal, but Two Very Different Bankers
description: The biggest takeover battle in the banking industry, the fight for control of ABN Amro Holding, the Dutch bank, brings head to head two very different personalities atop Europes banking world. The New York Times takes a look at how the distinct styles of the two chieftains affect their deal making and the institutions they run.

title: Major Parts Maker in Talks With Auto Unions
description: The auto parts maker Magna International, which is considering a bid for Chrysler, is in talks with Canadian and American auto unions about adding Magnas tens of thousands of workers to their ranks, according to the president of the Canadian union.

title: Of Big Buyouts and Pink Slips
description: As cash-rich private equity firms continue to buy many of the largest public companies, there is a new focus on one question: Do these big buyouts create jobs or destroy them? The claim that private equity shops are enriching themselves on the backs of employees at their portfolio companies has been circulating in European for some time. Last week, a report by The Service Employees International Union, which represents nearly 2 million United States workers including health care employees and janitors, raised similar concerns.

title: Cavium Networks Shines in Debut
description: Shares in a networking semiconductor start-up, Cavium Networks rose more than 27 percent in their first day on the Nasdaq stock market Wednesday.

title: Littlejohn Rolls Up Intertape
description: A buyout shop, Littlejohn & Company of Greenwich, Conn., has struck a deal to take the Intertape Polymer Group,a maker of plastic tape, private for $500 million, including $305 million of debt. Littlejohn has agreed to buy all the companys common stock at $4.76 a share, valuing the companys equity at $195 million.

title: Friendlys Delays Shareholder Meeting Amid Proxy Fight
description: Friendly Ice Cream, the struggling restaurant chain, postponed next weeks annual shareholder meeting, delaying a showdown with activist investors who are trying to gain more control of the company. Friendly said its executives needed more time for a review of the companys strategic alternatives, including a possible sale of the business, that was disclosed in March.

title: V.C. Funding to Bring You Ugly Bettys Ear Muffs
description: An Internet retailer, Delivery Agent, raised $18.5 million in an insider round led by Bessemer Venture Partners to take advantage of partnerships with television networks and other content distributors that steer audiences to its online store to purchase goods featured on the air.

title: D.E. Shaw Appoints European Private Equity Head
description: D.E. Shaw, the $29 billion hedge fund, announced Wednesday that it had hired Michael Joseph, a former banker at Lloyds TSB, to head its fledgling European private equity unit, D. E. Shaw Direct Capital. Mr. Joseph, a former managing director of structured finance at Lloyds TSB, also served as an investment director at the British buyout shop 3i Group.

title: Malaysian Billionaire Offers $4.6 Billion for Control of Maxis
description: As expected, Malaysian billionaire T. Ananda Krishnan has offered to buy full control of Maxis Communications, the countrys biggest mobile-phone company, for 15.8 billion ringgit ($4.6 billion) to facilitate its overseas expansion.

title: N.Y.S.E. and Nasdaq Vie for Chinas Offerings
description: As the Nasdaq Stock Market and the New York Stock Exchange battle each other at home and abroad for new listings, China has become a key battleground, BusinessWeek notes.

title: Blackstone, Carlyle May Bid for Australian TV Network, Report Says
description: The Blackstone Group and the Carlyle Group may join forces to bid as much as 2.7 billion Australian dollars ($2.2 billion) for Ten Network Holdings, Australias third most-watched television station, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Morgan Stanley Makes China Appointment
description: Morgan Stanley has hired a former banker at Credit Suisse, Carlos Oyarbide, as chief operating officer in China. Mr. Oyarbide, 48, will be a managing director, reporting to Wei Christianson, chief executive of Morgan Stanleys operations in China. He will start in July, Morgan Stanley said.

title: Clear Channel Sells Stations as Part of Buyout Plan
description: Clear Channel Communications said on Wednesday it had agreed to sell 362 radio stations for $820 million as it divests assets in accordance with its embattled $27 billion plan to go private. Clear Channel, the nations largest radio station operator, did not name any of the buyers.

title: Cumberland Pharmaceuticals Files for I.P.O.
description: Cumberland Pharmaceuticals intends to raise $115 million in an initial public offering, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The firm, which plans to list on the Nasdaq Stock Market, did not say how many shares it planned to sell, or at what price.

title: A.G. Edwards Settles Market-Timing Charges
description: A.G. Edwards will pay nearly $4 million for a role in the mutual fund market-timing trading scandal. The Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday accused the firm of failing to supervise several brokers who allegedly engaged in illegal market-timing activities.

title: Burkle Eyes American Media, Report Says
description: Ron Burkle, the Los Angeles billionaire who lost his bid to buy Tribune, is now sizing up the tabloid publisher American Media, according to The New York Post.

title: Citigroup Took $12 Billion Loan to Seal Nikko Deal, Report Says
description: Citigroup borrowed 1.45 trillion yen ($12 billion) in a syndicated loan to pay for its purchase of Nikko Cordial, according to Bloomberg News.

title: Russias Norilsk Launches Rival Bid for LionOre
description: The Russian metals giant Norilsk Nickel said on Thursday it was making an all-cash bid worth 5.3 billion Canadian dollars ($4.8 billion) for LionOre of Canada, trumping an offer from London-listed Xstrata.

title: Jones Apparel to Unload Moderate Brands
description: The Jones Apparel Group, the owner of Barneys New York and Nine West, said Wednesday that it would close or sell some of its moderately priced apparel brands by year-end, a move that would help reduce its exposure to department stores.

title: Murdochs Next Move: Charming the Bancrofts
description: And now for the charm offensive.

title: Citi Executive Joins University Pension Fund
description: The University of Texas Investment Management Company, the investing arm of the University of Texass pension system, has hired Bruce Zimmerman, former chief investment officer and global head of pension investments at Citigroup, as its new chief executive.

title: Cablevision Deal Remains Up in the Air
description: Cablevision Systems board said Wednesday it had accepted a $10.6 billion buyout offer from its founding family, the Dolans, but the deal is far from assured. The buyout is subject to approval of more than half of Cablevisions shareholders, excluding the Dolans and the companys directors and officers, and analysts and investors are still concerned that the price is too low.

title: UBS to Close Hedge Fund After Disappointing Returns
description: In a shocking move, UBS said it would scrap its hedge fund, Dillon Read Capital Management, after losses at the unit contributed to a third straight decline in quarterly profit. We concluded that the DRCM initiative did not meet our expectations, UBSs chief executive, Peter Wuffli, said in a statement.

title: New York Fed Warns On Hedge Funds
description: In what Reuters describes as its sternest warning to date on the state of the hedge-fund business, the New York Federal Reserve said Wednesday that the funds could represent the biggest risk for a financial crisis since 1998, when the implosion of Long-Term Capital Management threatened global markets.

title: Too Manly for His Own Good
description: George W. Bushs disastrous presidency is linked to the fact that the United States is a country that is anxiously hypermasculine, writes Mark Dery on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times. George W. Bush learned an unforgettable lesson about the anxious nature of American masculinity when Newsweek branded his father a wimp, a perception Bush 41 never really overcame, Dery writes. The resolve never to look like a wimp is the key to Dubyas psychology. Dery adds:

title: Ferrari wins again!
description: But this time, it is the unusual distinction of winning the title of the Best Place to Work in Europe 2007.

title: Obtaining a Vietnam Visa Outside the United States
description: I am currently traveling throughout SE Asia and would like to add Vietnam to my itinerary. However, Vietnam requires that American tourists obtain a visa through a local consulate prior to arrival. Im not able to travel to a city that has a consulate and wait two days for my application to be processed. Do you know of any reputable companies that can help expedite the visa for me?

title: 2008: Debate in the Shadow of Reagan
description: As the G.O.P. contenders gather for their first debate in at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library tonight in Simi Valley, Calif., each will clamor to mount praise on the Gipper. But another Republican president is causing more of a strategic conundrum. The Timess Adam Nagourney reports:

title: This Desert Life
description: When I started on the Mets beat in August 2005, my first road trip was an Arizona-San Francisco swing  just like this one. The Mets swept the D-Backs in four games, prompting a few to wonder whether I was a good-luck charm. Then they lost two of three in San Francisco, and that took care of that.

title: Obamas Misadventures in MySpace
description: The decision by Barack Obamas campaign to seize control of a MySpace page created by a (former) Obama supporter has angered many of the activists in the Democratic netroots. [T]he Obama campaigns reputation as the most net-savvy of 2008 has taken a big hit, writes Micah L. Sifry of techPresident. And MySpace executives have been forced to take extraordinary action to resolve a dispute between two high-profile users of their invaluable site, one a passionate volunteer with a huge network of friends and the other a front-running presidential candidate who has helped make MySpace a new factor in the 2008 contest.

title: Safe on the Track?
description: A year ago, some fateful missteps by Barbaro in the Preakness resulted in a fractured right hind leg that eventually led to his being put down in January. But the sad ending appears not to have swayed the thinking of horse racing fans about the inherent safety of the sport. A recent New York Times/CBS News poll of people who said they followed racing showed that 63 percent think the sport is safe for the horses, and only 21 percent said it was too risky. Ten percent said it depends on certain factors like track conditions, and 5 percent said they dont know.

title: A Guide to the Republican Debate
description: LOS ANGELES  The Republican presidential candidates are gathering this evening at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library  at the invitation of Nancy Reagan  for their first debate. It begins at 8 p.m. Eastern time, lasts for 90 minutes, and will be broadcast on MSNBC, which is sponsoring it with Politico.com. The moderator is Chris Matthews.

title: Pogues Picks
description: I don't know how the other Times columnists keep up with all their reader e-mail, but I'll tell you how I handle mine: with great difficulty. I try to answer pretty much all of it, thanks to some kind of weird Midwestern sense of obligation.

title: Sale Could Enrich Top Dow Jones Executives
description: Shareholders of Dow Jones & Company, whose stock price until recently has languished in the mid-30s, are not the only ones that could see a windfall if the company ends up being acquired by News Corporation at $60 per share. The deal is far from certain: A majority of the Bancroft family, which has a controlling interest in the company, currently stands opposed to Rupert Murdochs proposal. Still, The New York Timess Eric Dash looked through regulatory filings and found that a sale, if it happened, might mean multimillion-dollar paydays for the top managers of Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal.

title: Storm Over Immigration Protest in L.A.
description: The Los Angeles Police Department is facing public outrage over its officers use of batons and nonlethal rubber bullets to disperse an immigrant-rights rally on Tuesday.

title: Judge Halts Bank Sale in ABN Amro Takeover Duel
description: Hold that deal.

title: Big Island Bliss
description: Largest and southernmost in the Hawaiian chain, the Big Island of Hawaii is synonymous with stunning landscapes and luxurious retreats.

title: A Career in Space
description: Walter Schirra was the only man to fly on all three of NASA's early space missions.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Coram Boy" and "American Fiesta."

title: Podcast: Downtown Gender Gap
description: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

title: Journal Reporters Start Anti-News Corp. Campaign
description: Hoping to fend off the News Corporations $5 billion bid, employees at Dow Jones & Company are pushing back. Jesse Drucker, a Wall Street Journal reporter and representative of the papers union, has written an e-mail to his colleagues, asking them to write short letters to three members of the Bancroft family, which controls more than 60 percent of Dow Jones.

title: On The Market
Memories of Montrachet
description: This happens to be a painful post for me to write because it concerns Montrachet, a formative restaurant for both American wine lovers and for me personally. Montrachet closed last summer with not nearly the ceremony it deserved. In fact, as late as January 2007 Drew Nieporent, one of the owners, still had not acknowledged that the restaurants run was over. But if you were still holding out hope, forget it. Next Friday, May 11, Zachys will auction off what it bills as a significant offering from the cellars of Montrachet.

title: A Push for Cleaner-Fuel Taxicabs
description: If New York City ordered that the nearly 13,000 Ford Crown Victorias be replaced with Kia Rondos  the compact, minivan-like vehicles shown at the Taxi07 exhibition last month  it could potentially save 22.3 million gallons and $66.2 million worth of fuel each year and reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, a leading greenhouse gas, by 88,400 tons per year, according to a new analysis by Consumer Reports.

title: Pogues Picks
description: I dont know how the other Times columnists keep up with all their reader e-mail, but Ill tell you how I handle mine: with great difficulty. I try to answer pretty much all of it, thanks to some kind of weird Midwestern sense of obligation.

title: Unraveling Qaeda Deaths in Iraq
description: Earlier today, the Iraqi interior ministry announced another insurgent leaders death. This time, it was Abu Omar al-Baghdadi, said to be the leader of an umbrella group, The Islamic State of Iraq.

title: Compass to Hold $128 Million Offering
description: Compass Diversified Trust, a publicly held private equity firm, said on Thursday that it would hold a $128 million follow-on public offering to repay its corporate debt. In a press release, the firm, which currently holds six middle-market companies in a range of sectors, will sell eight million shares at $16 a share.

title: Into the Groove with a CIBC Bank Analyst
description: Lets face it: Its hard out there for an analyst who wants to stand out from the crowd, especially if you stick to the standard buy-hold-sell script. Last year, a Credit Suisse semiconductor analyst, Mike Masdea, shook things up with a mass voicemail to clients in which he imitated rapper Eminem as he gave his take on the chip business. The voicemail made the rounds on Wall Street and was preserved for posterity on Dealbreaker. (Masdea may want to check himself before he wrecks himself, one trader quipped to the New York Post.)

title: M.B.A.s Dream of Google and Goldman
description: As business school students prepare for graduation, they will face an inevitable barrage of questions from friends and relatives  most prominent among them: So, where are you going to work?

title: Credit Suisse Shuffles Bankers in Asia and Europe
description: Credit Suisse is moving Paul Raphael from London to Hong Kong to run its investment banking group in Asia, excluding Japan, the firm said in an internal memo. In London, Mr. Raphael was co-head of the European global markets solutions group. Mr. Raphael is taking a role previously held by Joe Gallagher, who becomes Credit Suisses head of mergers and acquisitions for the Asia-Pacific region, a new position at the firm. Jim Amine, who had been co-head of European global markets solutions with Mr. Raphael, takes over as the groups sole head.

title: Finding Media Buyout Targets in Unlikely Places
description: Private equity firms have historically looked askance at technology companies, whose volatile earnings dont always mix nicely with heavy debt loads. Which is why the recent findings by Jason Bazinet, a media analyst at Citigroup, are fairly remarkable. Using what he called fairly conservative assumptions, Mr. Bazinet screened 100 global media stocks and decided that most of them are not likely to be targets of a leveraged buyout offer anytime soon. Of those that made the cut, however, most were Internet companies.

title: Oprah Endorses Obama
description: In Chicago, there is no question who carries the title of the Big O. That would be Oprah Winfrey. Its a safe bet that Senator Barack Obama doesnt mind playing second fiddle to the talk show icon, particularly when he has her endorsement at his disposal.

title: Proposed Building Code Overhaul
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the buildings commissioner, Patricia J. Lancaster, today presented a comprehensive overhaul of the citys building code to the City Council  the first since 1968. The mayor said the rewriting of standards and rules would improve safety, efficiency and environmental sustainability.

title: Leadership, Republican Style
description: Readers respond to David Brookss May 3 column, Wolfowitzs Big Mistake.

title: War? What War?
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts May 3 column, An Invisible War.

title: Clinton: Sunset Iraq Authorization
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, on the Senate floor just a few minutes ago, proposed Oct. 11, 2007 as the expiration date for the Iraq war.

title: Lawmaker: Make Gore Mandatory
description: Assemblyman Peter M. Rivera, a Bronx Democrat, said today he plans to introduce a bill that would make An Inconvenient Truth, the global warming documentary produced by Al Gore, mandatory viewing for all school age children.

title: Poll Suggests Manhattan Driving Is Mostly Optional
description: The vast majority of New York City residents who drive in Manhattan on weekdays do not do so because they lack mass-transit options, according to a survey just released by the Partnership for New York City, an influential business group that has prodded Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to support a charge on driving into the city.

title: New Century to Close Home-Lending Business
description: New Century Financial, the biggest subprime mortgage company to declare bankruptcy, will close its home-lending unit and fire about 2,000 employees after failing to find a buyer. Chief Executive Brad Morrice informed employees of the failed search in a conference call Thursday, said Dan Gagnier, a spokesman for the Irvine, Calif.-based company.

title: Park Down, Mr. Infinity Up
description: No surprises here: The Mets optioned Chan Ho Park to Class AAA New Orleans today. In his place, however, they summoned the reliever Lino Urdaneta and not, as expected, Jorge Sosa. Willie Randolph will say in a few hours who will replace Park in the rotation, but it is likely that Urdaneta will take over Aaron Seles spot, and Sele will pitch Saturday. The Mets may have just added Urdaneta to be available today and tomorrow and then send him back to New Orleans and recall Saturdays starter.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Away From Her'
description: A.O. Scott reviews "Away from Her," about an aging couple dealing with the ravages of Alzheimer's.

title: Bullpen Blows Another for Pettitte
description: Jerry Hairston just took Luis Vizcaino into the left-field seats to tie the game here, 3-3. Thats the third time this season the bullpen has blown a potential victory for Andy Pettitte. Itll be hard for him to reach 200 wins at this rate; he has 187 now.

title: Gilmore Girls, 2000-2007
description: Gilmore Girls: goodbye, sweet princess.

title: Obama Placed Under Secret Service Protection
description: The decision to assign agents to protect Senator Barack Obama, a full nine months before the Democratic primary, is the earliest the Secret Service has ever issued security detail to a presidential candidate. Russ Knocke, a spokesman for the Department of Homeland Security, said today he could not comment on whether the decision was made in response to a specific threat against Mr. Obama or his family, but that several criteria were taken into account before the authorization was made.

title: When That Guy Died on My Show
description: Hey, Dick, Ill never forget the look on your face when that guy died on your show.

title: The First Presidential Decision
description: The first important decision any president makes comes well before taking office: his choice of a running mate at the time of his own presidential nomination, or even before. Presidential nominations now are all but assured well in advance of the party conventions.

title: Q. and A.: Climate Talks in Bangkok
description: Andrew C. Revkin, an environment reporter at The Times, has spent the week covering talks in Bangkok on the latest report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a U.N.-sanctioned body.

title: Escape from the Gender Ghetto
description: The very same morning that I began to read the new essay collection: One of the Guys: Women as Aggressors and Torturers, which examines the role of women in the Abu Ghraib prison scandal and in other instances of American military abuse, I came upon a man out for a walk with his baby daughter. He was wearing shorts; she was in a sunsuit. He wore a hat; she wore a bonnet. He carried her in a BabyBjrn-like-thing on his chest, and as he reached down for a moment to hike up her bottom (reassuring himself, I imagine, that she was still hanging in there), he looked so blissfully happy, so beatific, in fact, that I had to give him a smile.

title: Live Blogging the G.O.P. Debate
description: The After-Party: Now that weve had a chance to look over the transcript, weve caught a couple of moments that are worth going back to. One is that exchange with Mr. Giuliani about Christians. Mr. Matthews asked if the increased influence of Christian conservatives in the Republican party had been good for the party. Mr. Giuliani: Sure, the increased influence of large numbers of people are always good for us. Then he used his time to go back to an earlier question and said this: Neither party has a monopoly on virtue or vice. His context seemed to be that if the Republicans were going to win, they had to reach out to Democrats, but that was an unusual way to say it.

title: Down Syndrome
description: Some parents of children with Down syndrome want prospective parents to know the positive side of raising a child with the genetic condtion.

title: Difficult Diagnosis
description: When their unborn child was diagnosed with Down syndrome, one couple found it difficult to envision their future family. Then they met Troy.

title: Senators Seek to Provide Aid on Mortgages
description: Three Democratic senators yesterday proposed using $300 million in federal funds to help refinance troubled subprime mortgages and introduced a bill that would require brokers and lenders to act in the interest of borrowers.

title: Old Kansas, Still Growing Tall
description: THINK all of Kansas is flat? Think again. The Flint Hills, in the eastern part of the state, fan out over 183 miles from north to south, stretching 30 to 40 miles wide in parts, the land folding into itself, then popping up in gentle bumps, with mounds looming far off on the horizon. Seemingly endless, the landscape offers up isolated images  a wind-whipped cottonwood tree, a rusted cattle pen, a spindly windmill, an abandoned limestone schoolhouse, the metal-gated entrance to a hilltop cemetery.

title: Norway Keeps Nest Egg From Some U.S. Companies
description: OSLO  For a people whose deep national pride is in bestowing the Nobel Peace Prize, Norwegians are developing a reputation for throwing some sharp elbows.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about divisions among Republican presidential candidates on how to deal with the record of President Bush incorrectly identified one of the two candidates whose advisers said it was foolhardy to attack Mr. Bush. In addition to the campaign of Mitt Romney, advisers to Rudolph W. Giuliani  not Senator John McCain  made that assertion. The article also misstated the name of the California town where Mr. McCain spent the day Wednesday, preparing for a Thursday night debate. It is Coronado, not Coronado Beach. (Go to Article)

title: The Fairfax and Balsam Mountain Preserve
description: The Fairfax

title: Paris as Cinematic Souffl, From Quartier to Quartier and Director to Director
description: Paris Je TAime, a mosaic of 18 miniatures, each set in a different location in the City of Light, is a cinematic tasting menu consisting entirely of amuse-bouches. After two hours of such tidbits the palate is sated. But if there is no need for a main course, you still leave feeling vaguely disappointed at not being served one.

title: N.B.A.s Denials Overlook a Larger Point
description: So much for the racial dialogue the Imus-Rutgers imbroglio was supposed to provoke.

title: Europe: Limits on Cellphone Charges Advance
description: Negotiators for the European Parliament, the European Commission and the European Unions telecommunications ministers agreed to a compromise that could limit mobile phone roaming charges for 450 million European consumers by the end of the summer. The agreement would cap roaming charges at 0.45 euro a minute for outgoing calls, 0.20 euro for incoming and 0.29 for wholesale, excluding value-added taxes.

title: Superhero Sandbagged
description: If ever a movie had a case of the blues and the blahs, its Spider-Man 3, the third and what feels like the end of Sam Raimis big-screen comic-book adaptations. (Ready or not, the studio is talking about a fourth.) Aesthetically and conceptually wrung out, fizzled rather than fizzy, this latest installment in the spider-bites-boy adventure story shoots high, swings low and every so often hits the sweet spot, but mostly just plods and plods along, as if its heart were pumping tired radioactive blood.

title: ...Where Orfeo Sings His Way Out of Darkness
description: Typically, plans for a new production at the Metropolitan Opera do not get off the ground until a major singer commits to the project. So it was with Mark Morriss staging of Glucks sublime Orfeo ed Euridice, which was to have starred the mezzo-soprano Lorraine Hunt Lieberson as Orfeo, the mythic musician and grieving husband whose story has been told in countless operas and dramas.

title: Olmert Holds on for Now, Despite Huge Public Outcry
description: TEL AVIV, May 3  More than 100,000 protesters gathered in Rabin Square here on Thursday night to urge Prime Minister Ehud Olmert and his government to resign. The call followed the release of a damning report on the performance of the Israeli leadership during the war in Lebanon last summer.

title: Bush Warns of Vetoes Over Abortion Issue
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  President Bush told Congressional leaders Thursday that he would veto any legislation that weakened federal policies or laws on abortion.

title: Florida Acts to Eliminate Touch-Screen Voting System
description: MIAMI, May 3  Florida legislators voted on Thursday to replace touch-screen voting machines installed in 15 counties after the troubled 2000 presidential election here with a system of optical scan voting.

title: China Now Testing Food for Chemicals
description: SHANGHAI, May 4  Responding to the sweeping recalls of pet food in the United States and to worries about contamination in its own food supply, China said today that it has begun nationwide inspections to determine whether wheat gluten is being contaminated with chemicals, according to the state-controlled Xinhua News Agency.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about divisions among Republican presidential candidates on how to deal with the record of President Bush incorrectly identified one of the two candidates whose advisers said it was foolhardy to attack Mr. Bush. In addition to the campaign of Mitt Romney, advisers to Rudolph W. Giuliani  not Senator John McCain  made that assertion. The article also misstated the name of the California town where Mr. McCain spent the day Wednesday, preparing for a Thursday night debate. It is Coronado, not Coronado Beach.

title: Wolfowitz Rebuts Critics Over Tempest at World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  In a new rebuttal to charges that he violated ethics rules at the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz said Thursday that he had helped arrange a generous pay and promotion package for his companion soon after he became bank president in 2005 as a settlement of her potential claims if she sued for being relocated against her will.

title: Epilepsy Drug Can Increase Risk for Newborns, Study Says
description: Doctors reported yesterday that expectant mothers with epilepsy who took a commonly prescribed drug to control seizures were at increased risk of having a child with mental deficits.

title: Adding Reliever Gives Mets the Option of Recalling Sosa
description: PHOENIX, May 3  The Mets pitching was so thin at one point last season that they granted Jos Lima four starts, and they were so desperate that they let Geremi Gonzlez start three times. Their upgraded depth at Class AAA New Orleans allows them to be less tolerant with retreads this season, and after one ineffective start they designated Chan Ho Park for assignment Thursday.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: For the Record
description: A music review on Tuesday of the group Opus 21, at Symphony Space, misspelled the given name of the composer of Thaw, a work the group played. He is Mark Dancigers, not Marc.

title: Sex Charges Against Teacher Put Indian Reservation on Edge
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 3  Word began rippling through the small Onondaga reservation on the outskirts of the city last fall: a music teacher at the elementary school had been suspended, charged with sexually abusing two of his female students.

title: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with a theater review of Jump! and Realism, at the Kirk Theater on 42nd Street, misspelled the surname of an actress shown in Jump! She is Meredith Zinner, not Ziner.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about an online revolt against efforts by a trade organization to remove a secret antipiracy code from the Web erroneously included one Web site among those that received requests to remove the code. Wikipedia did not receive such a letter.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article last Friday about the spouses of the French presidential candidates referred incorrectly to the source of a 1995 quote by Ccilia Sarkozy, wife of the conservative candidate Nicolas Sarkozy, who said: I dont see myself as a first lady. That bores me. I am not politically correct. She spoke in an interview with a French television magazine, not on a television show.

title: Voices Rise in Mount Vernon Over How to Fight Crime
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 3  After two people were killed and two others were injured in two shootings and a stabbing here last week, local leaders called a meeting at a Baptist church on Tuesday, hoping to calm residents, hear their concerns and offer solutions.

title: Lamenting the Loss of a Historic Washington Market
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Richard Glasgow hoped he could recover the wooden sign that hung above his seafood stall. Chris and Maria Calomiris wanted to salvage the cans of Greek olive oil that had been delivered just days earlier. Mike Bowers wondered if the granite countertop could still be used for his cheese shop.

title: Dirty Tricks by Phone
description: The phone rings at 3 a.m. You pick it up, and a computerized voice seems to be pitching John Does campaign. You hang up. It calls back 15 more times. Are you going to vote for Mr. Doe? Probably not.

title: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the reduction in space for book reviews in some newspapers in the United States, and the emergence of Web sites that offer reviews, misstated the title held at Touchstone Fireside, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, by Trish Todd, who commented on the changes. It is editor-in-chief, not publisher.

title: Reading Russia Right
description: Moscow

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a crackdown on gun violence in Baltimore referred incorrectly to the trend in the rate of violent crime in the city. While shootings are up 36 percent this year compared with last year, violent crime  also including rape, robbery and assault  is down 15 percent. It is not rising.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: U.S. Says Its Troops Killed a Top Iraqi Insurgent Who Aided in the Kidnapping of Westerners
description: BAGHDAD, May 3  American military officials said Thursday that American troops had killed a senior propagandist for the insurgent group Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia who was involved in kidnapping Westerners, including the American journalist Jill Carroll. But the American officials denied claims from Iraqi officials that other leaders of the group had been killed.

title: Mothers S.U.V. Rolls in Bronx, Killing Boy, 1
description: A 1-year-old boy whose father died in Iraq weeks before he was born was killed yesterday afternoon after he was accidentally run over by his mothers sport utility vehicle near their home in the Bronx, according to the police and relatives.

title: Lottery Numbers
Newark: New Lawyer for Medical School
description: The embattled University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey has hired a new general counsel, Lester Aron. Mr. Aron is a member of the Newark law firm Sills, Cummis, Epstein & Gross. He represents about three dozen New Jersey school districts and serves as a trustee of Kean University. Mr. Aron replaces Vivian Sanks King, who resigned in 2005. A federal monitor is overseeing the operations of the university under an agreement with the United States attorneys office that allowed the school to avoid federal prosecution for Medicaid fraud. The monitor, Herbert J. Stern, criticized the university in July for its delay in hiring in a new general counsel.

title: Clinton Proposes Vote to Reverse Authorizing War
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton proposed Thursday that Congress repeal the authority it gave President Bush in 2002 to invade Iraq, injecting presidential politics into the Congressional debate over financing the war.

title: Con Edison Seeks 11.6% Rate Increase
description: Consolidated Edison yesterday asked state regulators today for permission to raise electricity rates substantially in New York City and most of Westchester County, starting next April.

title: Britain: Bid for Hanson Considered
description: HeidelbergCement, the biggest concrete maker in Germany, said it might bid for Hanson, the worlds largest supplier of crushed rock, setting off a 20 percent gain in Hansons stock price. HeidelbergCement is currently reviewing its options with respect to its interest in Hanson, including the possibility of seeking to acquire the company, HeidelbergCement said. Acquiring Hanson would increase HeidelbergCements revenue by more than two-thirds, add operations in Australia and bolster its range of products like crushed rock, concrete pipes and bricks.

title: A Veteran Dealer Sheds His Possessions
For $9,000, a Big-Race Competitor
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3  When a bay yearling by the sire Johannesburg entered the sales ring in October 2005, it is doubtful that any of the major players in the industry were paying attention. He was part of a sale, the Fasig-Tipton Kentucky fall yearlings sale, where the leftovers are sold  horses who, because of their pedigrees or conformations or both, cannot make the cut at the big sales frequented by the sports wealthiest owners.

title: In Jihadist Haven, a Goal: To Kill and Die in Iraq
description: ZARQA, Jordan  Abu Ibrahim considers his dead friends the lucky ones.

title: Walter M. Schirra Jr., Astronaut, Dies at 84
description: Walter M. Schirra Jr., one of the original Mercury Seven astronauts and the only astronaut to fly in all three of NASAs earliest manned space programs  Mercury, Gemini and Apollo  died yesterday in San Diego. He was 84 and lived in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

title: Laws Proposed on Use of DNA to Help Prove Innocence
description: ALBANY, May 3  Alan Newton, a former bank teller from the Bronx, was freed from prison in 2006 after serving 22 years for a rape he did not commit. For more than a decade, Mr. Newton had asked the authorities to test his DNA against the physical evidence from the crime scene, only to be told that the evidence could not be found.

title: A Show Where Candidates Are More Prop Than Player
description: If ever there was an event that cried out for name tags, it was last nights Republican debate. Which in that long line of white men in bright ties and dark suits supported embryonic stem cell research? And who was it again who called for a flat tax?

title: China Makes Arrest in Pet Food Case
description: SHANGHAI, May 3  The general manager of a Chinese company accused of selling contaminated wheat gluten to pet food suppliers in the United States has been detained by the Chinese authorities, according to police officials here and a person who was briefed on the investigation.

title: Golfers Take Aim With Help of a Rifleman
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 3  In the past year, several professional golfers have traveled to Flower Mound, Tex., to meet a man trained to shoot a rifle between the beats of his pulse.

title: Washington: Bush Plans Appointments
description: President Bush said he intended to nominate a federal budget analyst, Kerry N. Weems, to run Medicare and Medicaid. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Weems would become administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, succeeding Dr. Mark B. McClellan, who resigned in October. Mr. Weems, 50, has spent almost half his life at the Department of Health and Human Services. Since early 2005, he has been deputy chief of staff for Michael O. Leavitt, secretary of health and human services. Mr. Bush also announced that he planned to nominate an aide, Tevi D. Troy, as deputy secretary of health and human services. Mr. Troy, 40, was deputy director of policy for the Bush-Cheney campaign in 2004 and now coordinates the presidents Domestic Policy Council.

title: Welcome, Interstate Satyrs
description: THE yawning atrium of the Holiday Inn in Memphis had been silent all morning, but by noon on a Friday in late March, it began to bustle and hum with the whispering thwip-thwip-thwip of cards being shuffled and the clacking rattle of dice being rolled, with the shouts of victorious adventurers and the death throes of impaled orcs.

title: Mexico: Drug Dealers Attack the Military
description: Five soldiers were ambushed and killed in the western state of Michoacn late Tuesday during an anti-drug operation, a brazen sign that drug dealers are willing to fight the military as it tries to rid the state of narcotics, the authorities said. Heavily armed men, whom investigators believe to be drug-cartel henchmen, opened fire on the soldiers at 11:30 p.m. as they were driving in pickups through Carcuaro, 85 miles south of the capital, Morelia. One gunmen was also killed in the ensuing exchange of fire. President Felipe Caldern has sent more than 6,000 soldiers into the state as part of a crackdown on drug traffickers that has failed to slow the pace of gangland-style executions.

title: Big Names, Big Wallets, Big Cause
description: Even in charity, the titans of hedge funds and private equity do nothing small.

title: Canada and Afghanistan Reach Accord on How to Treat Detainees
description: OTTAWA, May 3  The government announced Thursday that it had reached an agreement with Afghanistan on the treatment of detainees captured by Canadian troops.

title: A Question for the G.O.P. (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Clear Channel Board Rejects Sweetened Offer From Bidder
description: Clear Channel Communications, the nations largest radio broadcaster, said last night that its board had rejected a revised offer by two equity firms that had agreed to buy the company, but are now trying to keep the deal from falling through.

title: House Votes to Expand Hate-Crime Protection
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  The House of Representatives voted on Thursday to extend hate-crime protection to people who are victimized because of their sexuality. But the most immediate effect may be to set up another veto showdown between Democrats and President Bush.

title: De La Hoya Reaches Out to Father of Opponent
description: LAS VEGAS, May 3  The peculiar psychology of Saturday nights Oscar De La Hoya-Floyd Mayweather Jr. junior middleweight title bout can be summarized with this: Floyd Mayweather Sr., who nurtured his sons career but is now estranged from him, will attend the fight courtesy of four ringside tickets from De La Hoya, who replaced him as his trainer earlier this year.

title: A Dose of Funny Ha-Ha From the Good Old 90s
description: It is a clich to say so, but Saturday Night Live is an institution, kind of like comedys Junior League, continually nostalgic for its former cultural significance. Today YouTube makes that sort of self-reflection unnecessary: you can watch Phil Hartman playing John McLaughlin playing Frank Sinatra anytime you want. But NBC, which created retrospectives of SNL in the 1970s and 80s, and produced specials based on the work of individual performers, has now made Saturday Night Live in the 90s: Pop Culture Nation, a compilation of the highs and lows and highs again of the show during the Clinton period. (The program appears on Sunday night.)

title: Rosneft Buys Yukos Assets, Including Its Oil Refineries
description: MOSCOW, May 3  Rosneft, the Russian state oil company, acquired 37 subsidiaries of the bankrupt Yukos oil company at an auction on Thursday, expanding Rosnefts already large footprint in the industry.

title: Beyond Paintbrush Boundaries: Imagining Structures in 3-D
description: Perhaps Frank Stella should have quit when he was ahead. For some people that was as far back as the mid-1970s, when he began making a succession of increasingly colorful and ornate aluminum reliefs. They were often considered artistic apostasy, blatant betrayals of his ascetic striped paintings of the 1960s, which established his reputation as a wunderkind and premier New York artist, and he became one of the cornerstones of Minimalism.

title: Labor Party Battered in British Vote
description: LONDON, May 4  In a historic reversal, the separatist Scottish National Party emerged today as the biggest political force in Scotland, ending 50 years of dominance there by the ruling Labor Party and redrawing Britains political landscape.

title: U.S. Investigators Visiting Pet Food Makers
description: Federal investigators have begun visiting food and pet food makers that use vegetable protein concentrates imported from China to make sure that the additives are not contaminated, the Food and Drug Administration said Thursday.

title: Raptors Are Hurting at Guard Going Into Game 6
description: The status of the Raptors two top point guards remained unknown for tonights Game 6 against the Nets. The starter, T. J. Ford, left Tuesday nights Game 5 after he injured his neck in a first-quarter collision with the Nets Vince Carter. Ford, who did not practice Wednesday or yesterday, still felt tingling in his arms and was questionable for tonights game.

title: G.M. Turnaround Gains Little Traction
description: DETROIT, May 3  General Motors has placed all of its bets on its pickup trucks, which are strong enough to pull thousands of pounds through the mud, but from the looks of G.M.s first quarter, are unable to pull the automaker out of its financial downturn.

title: Queens Man Arraigned in School Bus Crash
description: A Brooklyn man was arraigned yesterday on charges including burglary and assault in connection with a police chase and bus crash that injured eight children and four adults, prosecutors said. The man, Thomas Hernandez, 43, of De Kalb Avenue, was held without bail after his arraignment in Criminal Court, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. He is charged with crashing into a school bus, which rolled onto its side, on Douglaston Parkway in Little Neck on Tuesday while fleeing the police, Mr. Brown said. The police said officers were pursuing Mr. Hernandez after he burglarized an officers house in Flushing and stole his sport utility vehicle.

title: U.S. Reviews Afghan Claims of Civilian Toll in Airstrikes
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  The top American commander in Afghanistan said Thursday he was investigating claims that dozens of civilians were killed and wounded recently by American airstrikes in the Western province of Herat.

title: Gene Identified as Risk Factor for Heart Ills
description: Two rival teams of scientists have discovered a common genetic variation that increases the risk of heart disease up to 60 percent in people of European descent.

title: Confusion and Deception as a Royal Family Affair
description: Modern-dress minimalism often seems to be the default choice for Shakespeare these days, but it can also be a straitjacket, as the Cheek by Jowl production of Cymbeline at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Harvey Theater unhappily illustrates. The great tragedies, with their mighty figures and penetrating psychology, can stagger us unadorned. The lively comedies possess a natural effervescence. But the latecoming romances dont always benefit from a distilled approach.

title: Secret Service Guards Obama, Taking Unusually Early Step
description: Senator Barack Obama, whose crowds at political rallies across the country have often numbered in the thousands, was placed under Secret Service protection yesterday, a spokesman for the agency said.

title: Bjork, in Fighting Spirit, Links Church and State
description: The last time Bjork played Radio City Music Hall, five and a half years ago, she was in heaven: dressed in white, accompanied by the harpist Zeena Parkins. But when she returned to the space on Wednesday night, she was somewhere else entirely. The night began with a reddish dress, scorching red flames and pummeling beats: it was clear she had descended into a post-disco inferno.

title: In a New Space and Time, a Classic Story of Tragic Love
description: When The Tristan Project was first presented in Los Angeles, at the end of 2004, it was clear that it would be one of the highlights of Esa-Pekka Salonens tenure as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic. At heart, it was a concert opera, but in a multimedia conception that promised to be so ingenious that listeners traveled long distances to catch it, and talked about it for months. The buzz started again when Lincoln Center announced that it would bring the production to New York, and now that its here  the first of two performances was on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall  it is a hot topic again, and a hot ticket as well: the performance was sold out, with the best seats priced at $500.

title: Heart of Hawaii
description: THE Poomau Ditch Trail hugs a mountainside, and we hiked carefully, looking down at the path so as not to take a false step and fall hundreds of feet to eternity. Gnarly ohia lehua trees lined the side away from the chasm, and abrasive blackberry bushes  not native to Hawaii, but thriving here on Kauai like so many other invasive imports  reached out their scratchy canes. Everything around us was green: mountains, canyons, tree canopy.

title: U.S. Issues Guidelines on Use of Face Masks in Flu Outbreak
description: If a flu pandemic ever emerges, surgical masks should be considered by anyone entering a crowd, and thicker industrial masks should be considered for anyone taking care of the sick, federal health officials said yesterday as they finally released guidelines for mask use.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on April 24 about mock elections held in Bhutan as a practice for parliamentary elections next year incorrectly described the status of King Jigme Singye Wangchuck. He abdicated late last year as part of his effort to move the country toward modernity; he did not recently announce plans to do so.

title: As the Climate Changes, Bits of Englands Coast Crumble
description: BECCLES, England  This winter a 50-foot-wide strip of Roger Middleditchs sugar-beet field fell into the North Sea, his rich East Anglian lands reduced by a large fraction of their acreage. The adjacent potato field, once 23 acres, is now less than 3  too small to plant at all, he said.

title: The (Vintage) Shirt Off Her Back
description: MY name is Annie, and Im a shopaholic. I love coming home with bags full of clothing, jewelry, vintage collectibles, whatever. The only problem is, I highly disapprove of my own shallow materialism. When most people in the world dont own a book or a toilet, it seems just a wee bit selfish to buy a wait-listed designer handbag for some astromaniacal sum. So to balance my moral high-mindedness with my base lust for goods, I spend my life scouring thrift shops, estate sales and flea markets; that way I can feel virtuous.

title: Pope Benedict XVI Meets With Ex-President of Iran
description: ROME, May 4  Pope Benedict XVI met today with Irans former president, Mohammad Khatami, who spoke here earlier in the day about the very deep wounds between Muslims and Christians.

title: In Search of the Master Teacher (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Murdoch on Owning The Wall Street Journal
description: Like any close reader of The Wall Street Journal, Rupert Murdoch has his opinions.

title: Bloomberg Outlines Plan to Rewrite Citys Construction Codes
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed yesterday overhauling the citys aged and notoriously byzantine building code by greatly expanding fire safety requirements, encouraging environmentally sound construction and simplifying operations at the Department of Buildings.

title: 8th-Seeded Warriors Stun Mavericks
description: OAKLAND, May 3  Mickael Pietrus had never crowd-surfed before.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A WORD WORTH A SECOND LOOK

title: Whos Afraid of Joan Baez? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Tiago Tries to Match Champion Sibling
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2  On the day that Giacomo won the 2005 Kentucky Derby, his little half brother, then a yearling, was ambling around the fields of Mill Ridge Farm in Lexington, about 75 miles from the Churchill Downs finish line. No one involved with the yearling could have imagined that two years later he, too, would take aim at horse racing's most coveted prize. The Kentucky Derby is limited to 20 starters and, with roughly 34,000 thoroughbreds born each year in this country, the odds of two horses with the same mother making the race are astronomical.

title: Republican Candidates Hold First Debate, Differing on Defining Partys Future
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif., May 3  The 10 declared Republican presidential candidates met together for the first time here Thursday night in what amounted to a tentative but occasionally vibrant competition to define the partys ideology and agenda in a post-Bush era.

title: Court Blocks Sale of an ABN Amro Unit
description: LONDON, May 3  The sale of LaSalle Bank, a longtime Chicago institution that has suddenly become a pivotal prize in the worlds largest banking takeover battle, was blocked by a Dutch court on Thursday.

title: For the Record
description: A listing on Wednesday about the amount of money presidential candidates raised in Texas during the first three months of this year omitted two Republican candidates. Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, raised $1,054,050, placing him fourth on a list of 17 candidates. Senator Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, raised $11,225, ranking him 14th.

title: J. Robert Bradley, 87, Charismatic Gospel Singer, Dies
description: J. Robert Bradley, whose deep, swooping, octave-leaping voice and charismatic presence made him one of the most important figures in gospel music, died yesterday in Nashville. He was 87.

title: Climate Panel Reaches Consensus on the Need to Reduce Harmful Emissions
description: BANGKOK, May 4  The worlds established and emerging powers will need to divert substantially from todays main energy sources within a few decades, to limit centuries of rising temperatures and seas driven by the buildup of heat-trapping emissions in the air, the top body studying climate change has concluded.

title: Swedish Steel Maker Acquiring Canadian Supplier of Oil Pipes
description: OTTAWA, May 3  Ipsco, a leading Canadian supplier of steel pipes to the oil and gas industry, agreed to be acquired by a Swedish steel maker, SSAB Svenskt Stal, for $7.7 billion in cash, the two companies said on Thursday.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

description: American soldiers today detained an alleged cell of smugglers who procured powerful, armor piercing bombs and other weapons from Iran, the military said.

title: More Troubles for Busta Rhymes
description: In the turbulent world of hip-hop, where the line between art and criminality is sometimes blurred, an arrest for drunken driving would normally attract little attention.
