title: The Other Boot
description: As Democrats in Congress and the Bush administration look for common ground on a workable trade policy, it is worth taking a harder look at the capricious system of tariffs that raise the price of goods and are all too often based on outdated political considerations that defy logic and good sense.

title: Canada: Court Rejects Wal-Mart
description: The Supreme Court of Canada rejected an appeal from Wal-Mart Canada over efforts to unionize another store in Quebec. As is always the case, the high court offered no reasons for its decision. The courts move appears to open the way for the automatic certification of a store in Gatineau, a city across a river from Ottawa. Were disappointed but not surprised, because the Supreme Court rarely hears cases like this, said Yanik Deschnes, a spokesman for Wal-Mart. Wal-Mart wanted a court order requiring that Quebecs labor board conduct a secret ballot of employees. The United Food and Commercial Workers has asked for automatic certification under Quebec law based on the number of union membership cards it signed at the outlet.

title: Behind Bars, Leader of Drug Gang Manages Real Estate Investments, Prosecutors Say
description: It is no small task to pass the time at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility, a maximum security prison in Ossining, N.Y., for male criminal offenders considered among the most dangerous in New York. But for nearly two decades, prosecutors say, one convicted drug kingpin has found a novel use for his time  dabbling in island real estate.

title: Suit Criticizes Conditions at Mental Hospital
description: A state agency that advocates for mentally ill people has sued New York City in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, alleging that psychiatric patients at Kings County Hospital Center endure squalid conditions and inhumane treatment.

title: Wind Farms May Not Lower Air Pollution, Study Suggests
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Building thousands of wind turbines would probably not reduce the pollutants that cause smog and acid rain, but it would slow the growth in emissions of heat-trapping gases, according to a study released Thursday by the National Academy of Sciences.

title: Dutch Composer Samples Pop Culture and Gives It a Melody
description: A museum is an appropriate setting for the music of the Dutch composer Jacob Ter Veldhuis, otherwise known as Jacob TV. His work engages in a kind of pop-culture appropriation that has distinct parallels to visual art. On the three-box CD set of his works, to be released today, his orchestral music resembles Jeff Koons in its earnest explorations of kitsch. His boombox pieces, for recorded tape and solo instruments, are analogous to Tom Wesselmanns slick collages, limning the outlines of larger-than-life American figures in a pop idiom (with digital sampling and D.J.-like repetitions). And there is an overarching element of Henri Rousseau: the bright colors and slightly crude outlines of a folk artist.

title: Where Words Go to Work and Play
description: AS any aspiring writer knows, sometimes the only route to productivity is escapism. Luckily, there are plenty of workshops and conferences around to supply it  and simultaneously offer not only inspiration but practical advice. Usually held in seaside cities and resort towns or on bucolic college campuses, these writers programs can be found year-round. But the summertime crop takes authors to particularly seductive spots.

title: Plan for Arabic School in Brooklyn Spurs Protests
description: The Khalil Gibran International Academy was conceived as a public embrace of New York Citys growing Arab population and of internationalism, the first public school dedicated to the study of the Arabic language and culture and open to students of all racial and ethnic backgrounds.

title: Action by Police at Rally Troubles Los Angeles Chief
description: LOS ANGELES, May 3  Chief William J. Bratton of the Los Angeles Police Department said Thursday that the episode here in which police officers clashed with demonstrators and journalists on Tuesday at an immigration rally was the worst incident of this type I have ever encountered in 37 years in law enforcement.

title: Verizon Vote on Pay Levels to Be Decided in a Recount
description: The shareholder vote on an executive pay proposal at Verizon Communications is too close to call and must go to a recount, the company said after its annual meeting in Pittsburgh yesterday. The results of the recount will be available within two weeks, a company spokesman said.

title: Seeing No Progress, Some Schools Drop Laptops
description: LIVERPOOL, N.Y.  The students at Liverpool High have used their school-issued laptops to exchange answers on tests, download pornography and hack into local businesses. When the school tightened its network security, a 10th grader not only found a way around it but also posted step-by-step instructions on the Web for others to follow (which they did).

title: Sometimes You Can Go Home Again
description: When Gene Bauer told his mother he was buying a second home in Williamstown, Mass., in 1998, she couldnt believe it. Mr. Bauer, a Boston lawyer who graduated from Williams College in 1971, had complained heartily about the frigid, snow-filled winters there when he was a student. My mother said, You swore youd never go through another Williamstown winter again,  he recalled recently.

title: Taking Advantage of the Issue of the Moment
description: Heres a case that would seem to defy the laws of political science.

title: Seeking an Edge, Florida Changes Its Primary Date
description: MIAMI, May 3  Casting more uncertainty over the presidential nominating process for 2008, the Florida Legislature on Thursday moved the states primary up to Jan. 29, ignoring the threat of sanctions from the national Republican and Democratic parties.

title: U.S. Officials Meet Briefly With Iranians
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, May 4  American and Iranian officials spoke briefly today at a regional conference here on the Iraq situation, in a rare direct conversation between representatives of the two antagonistic nations.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Era of Cabaret, in Avant-Garde Lines
description: Spurred by its recent architectural makeover, the past-loving Morgan Library & Museum has decided to bring new life to its illustrious collection of works on paper by expanding it into the 20th and 21st centuries. As an early step on its trek to modernity, the Morgan is presenting the small but intense collection bequeathed to it by the Broadway lyricist Fred Ebb (1928-2004).

title: OSHAs Enforcement (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Speaking Love With Kurt and Lotte
description: Two luminous, life-infused portraits glow from within a dim, heavy frame at the Biltmore Theater, where LoveMusik opened last night. This bio-musical about the marital and professional relationship of the German-born composer Kurt Weill and the actress Lotte Lenya, directed by Harold Prince, is sluggish, tedious and (hold your breath) unmissable  at least for anyone who cherishes stars who mold songs into thrilling windows of revelation.

title: Should S.E.C. Act Against Lawyers?
description: If you are going to commit fraud, you may need a good lawyer. In some cases, you have to have a lawyer to pull off the fraud at all.

title: In Victory or Defeat, the 8th-Seeded Warriors Never Go by Unnoticed
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 3  The Golden State Warriors are the rare professional basketball franchise that has spent generations just dreaming of being a No. 8 seed.

title: The Times Names Public Editor
description: The New York Times today named its next public editor, Clark Hoyt, a former Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter and editor who oversaw the Knight Ridder newspaper chains coverage that questioned the Bush administrations case for the Iraq war.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 9 P.M. (Disney Channel) HIGH SCHOOL MUSICAL: THE CONCERT More than 100 million children, teenagers and (admit it) parents have watched High School Musical  in which a brainiac and a basketball player step out onstage and relegate the drama-club darlings to understudy oblivion  since the movie first hit the Disney Channel in January 2006. Its soundtrack was that years top-ranking album, with more than 3.7 million copies sold. And then came the concert tour, above, in which Vanessa Anne Hudgens, Ashley Tisdale, Lucas Grabeel, Corbin Bleu, Monique Coleman and Drew Seeley strutted their triple-platinum stuff. This special ventures behind the scenes with the performers and some of the screaming concertgoing masses.

title: Rest for the Roses
description: ON one of my first visits to Belmont Park, I saw a fatal breakdown from a few feet away and realized that my enjoyment of horse racing would come with a price. Some people in the sport dismiss the problem by saying that equine breakdowns are part of the game. That may be a fact  but that doesnt make it any more acceptable.

title: Climate Panel Reaches Consensus on the Need to Reduce Harmful Emissions
description: The world needs to divert substantially from todays main energy sources within a few decades to limit centuries of rising temperatures and seas driven by the buildup of heat-trapping emissions in the air, the top body studying climate change has concluded.

title: After a Four-Day Safety Review, Subway Work Is Resuming
description: Transit officials said yesterday that they planned to resume regular maintenance and construction work on subway tracks and tunnels this morning, returning workers to the job after more than four days off for a safety review prompted by the deaths of two track workers struck by trains.

title: Another Hockeytown
description: BUFFALO, May 3  In the summer of 2002, one of the few similarities between the Buffalo Sabres and the Detroit Red Wings was that both N.H.L. franchises were located in Rust Belt cities just across a river from Canada  and even that connection was tenuous. While the Red Wings and their fans were celebrating the citys latest Stanley Cup, the Sabres were in danger of moving out of town.

title: Mark Morris Descends to the Underworld ...
description: Orpheus, the isolated musician whose sufferings take him to hell and back, is the most potent archetype of the creative artist in Greek mythology, as he has remained for the performing arts since the Renaissance. Onstage we know him in innumerable works, from Monteverdis opera to the Stravinsky-Balanchine ballet and a Tennessee Williams play, but none have more enduring dramatic resonance than Glucks Orfeo ed Euridice. Since Gluck and his artistic collaborators built this opera with extensive dance opportunities in all three acts, it has always attracted eminent choreographers, and three of the greatest have chosen also to direct it: George Balanchine, Frederick Ashton and now Mark Morris.

title: Hoppers America, in Shadow and Light
description: BOSTON, April 30  A certain slant of light was Edward Hoppers thing. And he made it our thing, hard-wired it into our American brains: white late-morning light scraping across a storefront; twilight, plangent with heat and regret, settling over a city; slabs of late-night lamplight chilling the walls of Lonely Hearts Hotels everywhere.

title: At Rutgers, 2 Players Complete Little Circle
description: Amid the celebration after the final out of the 1998 Little League World Series, Todd Frazier and Casey Gaynor shared a thought: It does not get any better than this. Nine years after they led Toms River, N.J., to a Little League championship, they are finding out that maybe it does.

title: Greece: Conviction in C.I.A. Death Upheld
description: A special appeals panel in Athens upheld the 2003 terrorism conviction of Alexandros Yiotopoulos, who led a Marxist terrorist group for 27 years, starting in 1975 with the assassination of the Athens C.I.A. station chief, Richard Welch. The court upheld sentences for 12 other members of the November 17 terrorist organization but cleared two additional suspects because the crimes they were convicted of had fallen outside the statute of limitations. Named after a 1973 student uprising that was crushed by the tanks of a military junta that ruled Greece, November 17 killed 23 people, including American and British diplomats and military officers. It disbanded after a botched bomb attack in 2003.

title: Next Venture From Stewart: Costco Food
description: The long, fastidious reach of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia extends into the magazine, television, furniture, bedding, paint, glassware, and even home building businesses.

title: After BP Executives Exit, a Fleet Street Debate
description: LONDON, May 3  Was John Browne, who quit as chief executive of BP after losing a legal battle to keep details of an affair with another man out of the newspapers, the victim of a tabloid press bent on outing public figures, or a casualty of his own bad judgment?

title: Yankees Sweep Rangers in Doubleheader
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 3  The Yankees have won their last 10 games here, including two more in a doubleheader sweep of the Texas Rangers on Thursday. They won a day game, 4-3, and a night game, 5-2, and probably did not want to leave.

title: Friendlier Skies to a Home Abroad
description: OWNING a second home in Europe is surely many peoples idea of a dream come true. Problem is, the commute can be a nightmare.

title: Finding Fellowship (Hairy Feet Optional)
description: Fifty-three years ago in The New York Times, the poet W. H. Auden reviewed the first volume of J. R. R. Tolkiens epic trilogy, The Lord of the Rings.

title: With Pettitte Struggling, Yankees Find Just Enough to Get By
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 3  Each time the Yankees won the World Series in the 1990s, they rolled past the Texas Rangers in the first playoff round, winning all their games at the Rangers home ballpark. In this decade, the Yankees have never had a losing record here for a season.

title: Theater Listings
description: THEATER

title: 3-Run Homers by Easley and Wright Power Mets in the Ninth
description: PHOENIX, May 3  Even with them trailing the Arizona Diamondbacks by a run entering the ninth inning Thursday, the Mets had little reason to worry. Due up fourth was their best clutch hitter recently, Damion Easley, and he would bat as long as someone got on base.

title: Superhero Worship, Gotham to Riverdale
description: There is no better day to visit your neighborhood comic store than tomorrow: Free Comic Book Day, the annual industry promotion in which participating retailers nationwide will give away titles ranging from Little Archie and The Amazing Spider-Man to The Lone Ranger and Transformers, a spectrum as wide as the stores that sell them.

title: Turkish Party Sees Victory in Grass Roots
description: ISTANBUL, May 3  In the course of a single week, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan has taken on Turkeys Parliament, its highest court, even its military. Then he called for early national elections.

title: For New Chief, BPs Problems Range From Rusted Pipes to a Tarnished Image
description: Tony Haywards honeymoon is likely to be quite brief.

title: Monet Arrives and Ripens
description: Seeing a good-sized museum-quality show squeezed into a commercial gallery can sometimes feel like having dinner with a celebrity. A familiar distance falls away; the intimacy startles. So the show of around 60 paintings by Claude Monet at Wildenstein & Company may take getting used to, or it may simply take your breath away. It surveys Monets astounding 60-year trajectory in the span of three crowded galleries that would easily fit in one of the coat rooms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Back in U.S., Queen Celebrates Ex-Colony
description: RICHMOND, Va., May 3  A girl standing with her school marching band said she was on hand on Thursday to see whether the queen of England really waved with a cupped hand.

title: Yanks Set for 10th Starting Pitcher
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 3  Matt DeSalvo had slipped so far down the Yankees depth chart that he was taken off the 40-man roster in January to make room for Miguel Cairo. Every team had a chance to claim DeSalvo, but none did.

title: The U.S. Attorney, the G.O.P. Congressman and the Timely Job Offer
description: There is yet another United States attorney whose abrupt departure from office is raising questions: Debra Wong Yang of Los Angeles. Ms. Yang was not fired, as eight other prosecutors were, but she resigned under circumstances that raise serious questions, starting with whether she was pushed out to disrupt her investigation of one of the most powerful Republicans in Congress.

title: A Paragon of the Arts, as Both Man and Titan
description: Lincoln Kirstein  patron of the performing, visual, and literary arts; novelist; poet; critic and historian of dance, photography and painting  was one of natures titans. He looked the role. Nobody who saw or met him can easily have forgotten the imposing physical impression he made. Tall, strong-browed, massive of shoulders, thorax and head, he might have modeled as Atlas, who in Greek mythology carried the world on his shoulders. His energies were titanic too, as the anthologies and bibliographies of his work have revealed. But what made him exceptional was that he acted as if his main motto were not I am or I do but I serve. He put those shoulders to many wheels, often effacing his own contribution in so doing.

title: Coordinates of the Rich and Famous
description: WHEN I agreed to represent Gawker, the Web site I co-edit, on an episode of Larry King Live last month, I didnt expect to be shouted at, cut off, talked down to and told that I was going to hell. But as everyone who caught the show  or has seen it since on YouTube  knows, thats exactly what happened, courtesy of Mr. Kings fill-in, Jimmy Kimmel. If you saw the clip, you probably noticed that I looked sort of stunned. I even rolled my eyes a few times. Heres why.

title: Midterm Vote Could Give Blair a Last Hurrah, or a Swift Kick
description: LONDON, May 3  Voters across Britain went to the polls on Thursday in midterm regional elections that are considered likely to set the tone for Prime Minister Tony Blairs expected departure as prime minister in the coming weeks.

title: G.M. Profit Down 90% From 2006
description: DETROIT, May 3  The General Motors Corporation reported a 90 percent decline in first-quarter profit today as losses at its finance arm overshadowed the gains from restructuring its automotive operations.

title: Ex-Justice Dept. Official Defends Ousted U.S. Attorneys
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  A former deputy attorney general told the House Judiciary Committee on Thursday that he regarded most of the fired United States attorneys as highly competent prosecutors who should not have been dismissed.

title: Bill Proposes Climate Study Focused on U.S. Defense
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Given the jobs of hunting Al Qaeda, tracking nuclear programs in Iran and North Korea, and monitoring the civil strife in Iraq, American spy agencies are not lacking for work these days. Should they also take on the task of analyzing global warming?

title: Suspects Purchases Are Cast as Window Into Dark Mind
description: Prosecutors say that during the 13 hours Peter Braunstein held a woman captive and sexually assaulted her in her Chelsea apartment in October 2005, he used chloroform, a gun, a military-style mask and other menacing paraphernalia to terrorize her.

title: From Voice of the Bottle Bill to Keeper of the Green
description: ALBANY

title: Wall St. Banker Jailed in Trading on 9 Deals
description: Federal authorities arrested an investment banker yesterday and charged him with illegally leaking confidential information on nine deals, including the $45 billion buyout of the Texas energy giant TXU.

title: Defusing Buffalo Power Play Boosts Rangers
description: A big reason for the Rangers success against Buffalo has been their ability to frustrate the Sabres power play. In the series, which is tied 2-2, Buffalo has converted only 3 of 25 chances, including 1 of 13 in two losses at Madison Square Garden.

title: In Iran, Tactics of Fashion Police Raise Concerns
description: TEHRAN, May 3  Only days after Irans annual crackdown on immodest dress began in mid-April, with teams of police officers stopping women in major squares and subway stations to warn them about their attire, the security authorities came under fire.

title: For the Love of Barbaro and the Love of Money
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Prosecutors Ask Jail For Paris Hilton

title: Wal-Mart Discloses Some Compensation Details
description: Wal-Mart Stores, which used to closely guard information about its employees pay, disclosed yesterday for the first time its annual contributions to workers retirement accounts, profit sharing program and stock purchase plan.

title: Family Values, Betrayed
description: When George W. Bush was running for president in 2000 as a new kind of Republican  the caring kind  he had a ready answer for those skeptical of his moderate views on immigration. Family values do not stop at the Rio Grande, he said, again and again. He was standing up for immigrants who come here seeking better lives for their children, and he repeated the message so often that it stuck.

title: British Bankers Dwell in a Strange Houston Limbo With a Trial at the End
description: HOUSTON, May 3  What you have here is a U.S. government brick, said Giles Darby, as he heaved a bulky global positioning device onto the table in front of him.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the victims testimony in the Manhattan trial of Peter Braunstein, a former magazine writer accused of sexual abuse and kidnapping, misidentified the publication from which the victim, a 36-year-old woman, resigned. It was W, not Womens Wear Daily.

title: Inspector of Projects in Iraq Under Investigation
description: A federal official whose investigations of waste and corruption in Iraq have repeatedly embarrassed the Bush administration is now being investigated himself by an oversight committee with close links to the White House and by the ranking Republican on the House Government Reform Committee.

title: Assemblyman Is Censured for Fraternizing With Intern
description: ALBANY, May 3  An upstate assemblyman was removed from his post as ranking member of the Assembly Committee on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse on Thursday after revelations that he slept at the home of a 21-year-old female intern last month after a night of heavy drinking.

title: Queens Man Charged With Killing Girlfriend
description: A Queens man has been arraigned on charges of killing his girlfriend in Jackson Heights last month after she tried to break up with him, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Shane Tomlinson, 20, of Springfield Gardens, was charged with second-degree murder in the shooting of Chameka Miller, 18, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Tomlinson shot Ms. Miller April 15 after a confrontation at her home on 77th Street.

title: Highlights From the IPCC Report
description: Measures to reduce emissions can, in the main, be achieved at starkly low costs, especially when compared with the costs of inaction, said Achim Steiner, the executive director of the United Nations Environment Program, which, together with the World Meteorological Organization, established the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change in 1988.

title: Zimbabwe: Journalists Forbidden to March
description: Police officials barred journalists from marching to commemorate World Press Freedom Day, saying it was prohibited under an emergency decree banning political demonstrations. Journalists had planned 10 separate marches throughout the nation to underscore what they say are increasing restrictions on the news media and a growing number of arrests, jailings and attacks involving journalists.

title: The Times Names Clark Hoyt as New Public Editor
description: The New York Times yesterday named its next public editor, Clark Hoyt, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter and editor who oversaw the Knight Ridder newspaper chains coverage that questioned the Bush administrations case for the Iraq war.

title: The Pokers High Stakes, the Couples in Love and the City Is Mostly Sin-Free
description: Cards on the table: I find it hard to dislike a movie that delivers songs by George Jones and Bruce Springsteen within the first five minutes or so. The rest of the music in Lucky You is of a similarly high, canonical quality (even when its Drew Barrymore rather than Mr. Jones singing Cold Hard Truth), but by the time the brand-new, specially commissioned Bob Dylan number plays over the end credits, it feels less like an apotheosis than like a consolation prize.

title: The Aussie Big Dry
description: SYDNEY, Australia

title: Garden City Officers Patrol Car Hit
description: A highway patrolman who was parked on the shoulder of the Long Island Expressway was seriously injured early yesterday when his patrol car was struck by another car whose driver was drunk, the police said. The patrolman, Officer Edwin Martinez, suffered head injuries and was taken to Nassau University Medical Center in East Meadow, where he was in serious but stable condition last night. Officer Martinez had been patrolling a construction zone on the expressway, near Exit 43 at South Oyster Bay Road in Syosset, shortly after midnight when he pulled over a car driven by Andrew Mericle, 27, of Oyster Bay, for speeding, the police said. A car driven by Yookyung Kim, 19, of Bayside, Queens, rear-ended the officers car, which then hit Mr. Mericles car, the police said. Mr. Mericle and Mr. Kim were treated for minor injuries at the scene. Mr. Kim was charged with driving while intoxicated and arraigned in First District County Court in Hempstead. Mr. Kims license was suspended, and bail was set at $15,000 bond or $5,000 cash.

title: UBS Closing Hedge Fund; Losses Cited on Mortgages
description: LONDON, May 3  After turning UBSs investment bank into one of the elite on Wall Street, John P. Costas gave up the chief executives post to run a hedge fund for the company, sensing the opportunity to build another world-class business.

title: Four-Legged Friends
description: WHO Mary Whitehead, 67, and her husband, Michael Whitehead, 70, a retired structural engineer, from Poway, Calif.

title: Israel Wary of U.S. Proposals on Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, May 4  The United States, seeking doggedly to push along improvements in relations between Israel and the Palestinians, has given both sides a set of modest goals for easing Palestinian travel and bolstering Israeli security.

title: When Pennies Fail to Pay the Bill, a Bronx Man Pushes for Change
description: Every penny counts. But 10 of them didnt one recent night in the Bronx, and thats how the trouble started.

description: DIA BORROWS SPACE

description: ART

title: Wally Schirra, One of the Original Mercury Seven Astronauts, Dies at 84
description: Wally Schirra, one of the original Mercury Seven astronauts and the only astronaut to fly in all three of NASAs earliest manned space programs  Mercury, Gemini and Apollo  died yesterday in La Jolla, Calif. He was 84 and lived in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

title: For the Record
description: A picture in the auto sales chart in Business Day on Wednesday was published in error. It showed a Nissan Altima Coupe, which is not on the market yet, rather than the Altima sedan, which had a 12.4 percent drop in sales in April. (The error first occurred in the sales chart on Jan. 4.)

title: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with an article about plans to condense versions of Charlies Angels into three-and-a-half- to five-minute episodes misstated the length of the original program, including one episode in which the cast was shown solving a crime. The program was 60 minutes, not 30.

title: Lawyer Says Imus to Sue CBS, Accusing It of Breaking Contract
description: The lawyer for the ousted radio host Don Imus said yesterday that he would file a $40 million lawsuit against CBS next week, accusing it of breach of contract.

title: Loan Inquiry Turns to Deals With Alumni Associations
description: Even as universities are agreeing not to accept cash incentives from student lenders, dozens of college alumni associations are taking payments from loan companies and providing names and addresses of graduates that the companies can use for marketing purposes.

title: On Oahu
description: Home to Honolulu and Waikiki, Oahu offers visitors and second-home owners a quintessential Hawaiian experience.

title: Paradise Island
description: The essence of Maui: crystal blue water, big surf, emerald fairways and brilliant sunsets.

title: The Republican Candidates First Debate
description: The first Republican presidential debate between a field of 10 presidential hopefuls highlighted a party in flux as it struggles to figure out how to retain the White House for a third consecutive term. While several of the candidates invoked Ronald Reagan, a few tried to distance themselves from President Bush on Iraq.

title: Yanks Take Two From Texas
description: It was a long day in Texas, but the Yankees wont complain. Since that homer by Hairston, they grabbed back the lead to win Game 1, 4-3, and then cruised in the second game, 5-2.

title: Pulse
description: What I'm wearing now, the platform wedge sandal, Burt's Bees and more.

title: Its in the Cards
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Benedict to Face Challenges in Latin America
description: Benedict XVI travels on Wednesday to Brazil, in his first trip as pope to Latin America, home to nearly half the worlds Catholics. He arrives at a time of paradox for the church there. With Catholicism in decline in Europe, the developing world is seen as the future of the church. Yet the church in Latin America faces many challenges  which Benedict is expected to address in his four days in Brazil.

title: Bid for Hanson Considered
description: HeidelbergCement, the biggest concrete maker in Germany, said it might bid for Hanson, the worlds largest supplier of crushed rock, setting off a 20 percent gain in Hansons stock price.

title: London luxury
description: Coming on the market in two months is perhaps the most state-of-the-art house to ever be built in central London.

title: Swedish Steel Maker Acquiring Canadian Supplier of Oil Pipes
description: In announcement that took Canadas financial industry by surprise, Ipsco, a leading Canadian supplier of steel pipes to the oil and gas industry, agreed to be acquired by a Swedish steel maker, SSAB Svenskt Stal, for $7.7 billion in cash, the two companies said on Thursday.

title: Rosneft Buys Yukos Assets, Including Its Oil Refineries
description: Rosneft, the Russian state oil company, acquired 37 subsidiaries of the bankrupt Yukos oil company at an auction on Thursday, expanding Rosnefts already large footprint in the industry.

title: Paper Mill Makes Progress
description: The fate of the Paper Mill Playhouse, which has been struggling with a $2.8 million shortfall, is still very much up in the air, but the theater has been scrambling to raise money from every resource it can find.

title: The Pre-Trial Limbo of the NatWest Three
description: Since their extradition from Britain in July, three London bankers  known as the NatWest three  have been living in a peculiar limbo, as they await trial in Houston his fall on charges stemming from the collapse of Enron.

title: Ex-Governor Denies Approval of Payments to Conrad Black
description: Former Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois wrapped up three grueling days on the witness stand Thursday with an emotional denial that he had approved millions of dollars in payments now at the heart of a racketeering and fraud case against the media mogul Conrad M. Black.

title: Big Names, Big Wallets, Big Cause
description: Even in charity, the titans of hedge funds and private equity do nothing small.

title: For New BP Chief, Rusted Pipes and a Tarnished Image
description: Tony Haywards honeymoon is likely to be quite brief.

title: Interactive Brokers Prices I.P.O.
description: Interactive Brokers Group late Thursday priced its initial public offering at $30.01 per share, near the high end of the expected range, raising roughly $1.2 billion.

title: Deadline Looms for Bids on K.K.R.s Primedia
description: The New York Post notes that Friday is the deadline for Henry Kravis to receive final offers in the wild auction for Primedia Enthusiast Group, a process that has gotten a lot more complicated now that two potential suitors  tabloid publisher American Media and the firm owned by billionaire supermarket mogul Ronald Burkle  are reportedly in merger talks of their own.

title: Analyzing Love
description: Based on Daniel Menaker's well-received novel of the same title, "The Treatment" is a movie with its heart and head in the right place. Too bad its aesthetic sensibilities and technical coordinates are not as well situated. Directed by Oren Rudavsky, who wrote the intelligently streamlined screenplay with Daniel Saul Housman, the film pivots on a New Yorker, Jake Singer (Chris Eigeman), whose love affair with a newly widowed beauty, Allegra Marshall (Famke Janssen), functions in a curious, sometimes comically bewildering counterpart to his psychoanalysis with the self-described "last Freudian" Dr. Morales (Ian Holm).

title: ABN Holds Constructive Talks With RBS Group
description: A group led by Royal Bank of Scotland Group is in takeover discussions with ABN Amro Holding, after last week saying it may launch a $98 billion hostile bid for the Dutch bank.

title: Westwood Mulling Sale, Report Says
description: Radio network Westwood One has tapped investment bank UBS to identify potential buyers in anticipation of putting itself on the block next month, The New York Post reported. Westwood One is apparently waiting for shareholder approval for its pending content syndication deal with CBS Radio, tentatively targeted for May 15, before it formalizes an auction.

title: AMC Brings Curtain Down on I.P.O.
description: It was curtains for AMC Entertainments market debut, as the theater chains owners yanked its planned $789-million initial public offering from the stock market Thursday rather than cut the proposed share price in response to tepid investor demand at its asking price.

title: Qantas Buyout Comes Down to the Wire
description: Macquarie Bank and its partners said shareholders owning 36 percent of Qantas Airways, Australias largest airline, have agreed to their A$11.1 billion ($9.1 billion) takeover offer, due to expire Friday. The buyout will fail unless the group reaches 50 percent by 7 p.m. in Sydney Friday. The bidders held about 33 percent of the airline yesterday, they said in a statement.

title: NBC And Citadel Get Ion Despite Opposition
description: Television broadcaster Ion Media Networks on Thursday approved a takeover offer from NBC Universal and hedge fund Citadel Investment Group, despite three opposing board members and threats from a dissident group of shareholders.

title: From Scraps of Metal to Biking Medals
description: "A washing machine on wheels" is the derisive description officials of the World Cycling Association give to the revolutionary racing bike designed by the Scottish cyclist Graeme Obree (Jonny Lee Miller) in "The Flying Scotsman." In 1993 Mr. Obree broke the one-hour world record on his homemade contraption, built from scrap metal and washing-machine parts and nicknamed Old Faithful. The powers that be were not amused and frantically invented rules to try to disqualify him.

title: Frengo Dials Up Funding
description: Fengo, a mobile social network, announced on Thursday that it has raised $5.7 million in its first round of venture capital financing, led by Trilogy Equity Partners. Other investors included Khosla Ventures and Index Ventures.

title: Starbucks Chairmans Two-Way Funding Bet
description: Starbucks chairman and founder Howard Schultz, through his venture capital firm, has made a strategic investment decision that is rare, if not unprecedented, The Red Herring reports. He put money into two companies with opposing missions: one that promotes so-called typosquatting, the buying of Internet domain names that closely resemble big brand names, and another that combats it.

title: Milberg Weiss Lawyer Asks for Dismissal of Fraud Charges
description: A former partner in New York law firm Milberg Weiss & Bershad, accused by the government of paying illegal kickbacks to class-action clients, has asked a federal court in Los Angeles to dismiss the fraud charges against him. The motion could undermine much of the governments case against Milberg Weiss, The Los Angeles Times noted.

title: The Debates Within the Debate
description: May 4 - At the Republican debate, many of the running themes provided a window into the party's ideological ferment.

title: End of a UBS Hedge Fund Is a Blow to Banker
description: UBSs announcement Thursday that it would shutter its hedge fund following losses at the unit was an embarrassment both for the bank and for John P. Costas, who gave up his post as chief executive of investment banking to run the hedge fund for the company.

title: Clear Channel Board Rejects Sweetened Offer From Bidder
description: Clear Channel Communications, the nations largest radio broadcaster, said last night that its board had rejected a revised offer by two equity firms that had agreed to buy the company, but are now trying to keep the deal from falling through.

title: Credit Suisse Banker Jailed in Trading on 9 Deals
description: Federal authorities arrested a Credit Suisse investment banker on Thursday and charged him with illegally leaking confidential information on nine deals, including the $45 billion buyout of the Texas energy giant TXU.

title: Proposed Tax Levies, State Aid and STAR Rebates in New York School Districts
More Than Friends With Benefits
description: In "Race You to the Bottom," Russell Brown's enervated relationship drama, a pair of thoroughly unlikable 20-somethings explore the possibility of becoming more than friends with benefits. First, however, they must decide what to do about their pesky, live-in boyfriends.

title: Paranoia in a New Age
description: This initially promising, ultimately irritating psychological thriller recreates the paranoia of the weeks after Sept. 11, when every jet seemed to be flying too low.

title: CVC and PAI Launch Rival Bid for Altadis
description: CVC Capital Partners and PAI Partners offered 12.8 billion euros ($17.4 billion) for Altadis on Friday, topping Imperial Tobacco Groups bid for the Spanish maker of Gauloises cigarettes.

title: EMI Says Bidders Are Circling
description: British music group EMI, home to Robbie Williams and Coldplay, said on Friday it had received a number of takeover approaches, following a report that private equity firm One Equity Partners had joined the list of suitors.

title: Murdoch Speaks on Plans for the Journal
description: So what would Rupert Murdoch do if his $5 billion bid to buy Dow Jones comes to pass?

title: Reuters Receives Takeover Approach
description: Theres another media megadeal in the air.

title: Deadpan on Ice
description: This debut feature by the filmmaking team of Dominique Abel, Fiona Gordon and Bruno Romy earns two adjectives that rarely go together: breezy and bold. The film charts one woman's journey from dronelike suburban mom and fast-food manager to would-be Arctic explorer. It starts when the heroine, Fiona (Ms. Gordon), is trapped in a restaurant freezer overnight and realizes she enjoyed the experience. She subjects herself to increasingly severe endurance tests and becomes obsessed with images of icebergs, even carving one in her freezer at home (like Richard Dreyfuss creating Devils Tower from mashed potatoes in "Close Encounters of the Third Kind").

title: Preparations for a Queen
description: In the West Wing, the talk was of negotiations with Syria, but the East Wing bustled with activity in anticipation of a state dinner for Queen Elizabeth II.

title: 2008: The Reviews Are In, G.O.P. Edition
description: While the candidates were prepping for the debate, the staffs and surrogates were prepping for the debate about the debate that is the spin cycle.

title: Of Jackals, Bigfoot and Cavemen
description: The terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal will stand trial once again in France, a judge announced today. This time, he faces charges in attacks that killed 12 people from 1982 to 1983. A European news site reports that one of the three attacks allegedly targeted Jacques Chirac, who was then mayor of Paris. If hes convicted, the punishment will be a moot point: Carlos is already serving a life sentence.

title: Plan B  and Plan C
description: When our architects, Greg Huddy and Bill Harris, met with us to review preliminary sketches, they had three designs for us to consider. The first was a two-part house that Paul loved but that was large, expensive to build and, in my view, provided a little too much privacy.

title: Republican Debate Redux
description: The wide-open nature of the campaign for the 2008 Republican presidential nomination is reinforced by the disparate reactions among conservative journalists and bloggers to last nights debate.

title: Wolfowitz Learns That Bosses Are Not All-Powerful
description: The boss is not all powerful, particularly at a proud institution where others have their own power bases.

title: A Terrorist by Any Other Name
description: Is Abu Ayyub al-Masri, the leader of Al Qaeda in Iraq, dead or alive?

title: Comment Zone: On the Mayors Mind
description: Updated. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has wrapped up his weekly radio discussion with John Gambling on WABC. They started taking calls near the end  starting with a guy on a cellphone who said he was in (near?) the Holland Tunnel. Subject: cost of the mayors congestion pricing proposal. The second and last caller asked if Mr. Bloomberg would support an anti-war protest in the city. Mr. Bloomberg focused on safety and security issues in his reply.

title: Defying the Laws of Political Science
Damion Easley: Hit Man
description: It happens every spring: The Mets sign a second baseman in the off-season. He struggles early on. And then, because of injury, he slides into the starting role and delivers key hit after key hit. Last year, it was Jose Valentin. Everyone had given up hope on him after his miserable first six weeks. This time around, it is Damion Easley, who replaced the injured Valentin at second base.

title: The Sharm el Sheikh Kabuki
description: As leaders from about 60 nations gathered at a conference in Sharm El-Sheikh, Egypt, on Iraqs future, American and Iranian officials have been watched closely for any signs of direct dealings. Those signs have been trickling out all week in the careful language of diplomacy.

title: A $1 Billion Vote of Confidence for Icahn
description: With the Motorola proxy showdown set for Monday, billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn appears to have a new ally. ClearBridge Advisors, a money manager owned by brokerage firm Legg Mason, said it would support his bid for a seat on the cellphone makers board  something the company has adamantly opposed in a series of increasingly hard-edged announcements. Given recent events at the company, we believe it is in the best interest of all shareholders to have a new representative on the board, ClearBridge said in a press release. The firm did not say which events it had in mind, but Motorola has been struggling mightly in the past few months. In March, it slashed its revenue forecasts announced a management shake-up.

title: The 8th Fastest Walkers in the World
description: For most out-of-towners fond of a porch swing, a beach blanket or a wandering Sunday stroll, the phrase New York Minute has come to mean a peculiarly local delirium of impatience that results in the shrinking of time itself.

title: Listening in on Customer Service
description: Youre about to meet a guy whos already had two killer ideas.

title: Water Rate Increase: A Tax or Not?
description: John Gambling, who plays host to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg every Friday on his WABC talk show, said today that City Council members have called the proposed water rate increase just another tax. What did the mayor think of that? Heres a rough transcript of Mr. Bloombergs reply:

title: The Drunken Father
description: He planted a vineyard; and he drank of the wine, and became drunk, and lay uncovered in his tent. And Taylor, 16, the daughter of Hasselhoff, who once starred on Baywatch, saw the drunken nakedness of her father.

title: A Longer, Better Life
description: Author Sara Davidson talks to two medical scientists about how the body ages and the research on trying to extend our healthy life span.

title: Con Ed Seeks to Raise Electricity Rates
description: Consolidated Edison today filed an application with the New York State Public Service Commission to raise electricity rates. Starting next April, the typical residential customer would pay 17 percent more, while the typical business would pay 10.7 percent more.

title: Can Dow Joness Board Just Say No?
description: Rupert Murdochs bombshell $5 billion bid for Dow Jones has a lot of legal types talking make-up. More specifically, theyre talking about Revlon, the subject of a 1985 ruling that helped define a corporate boards duties when a company is up for sale. Dow Jones, like The New York Times Company and the Washington Post Company, has a dual-class share structure that gives majority voting power to its controlling family and insulates it from the whims of Wall Street. But the Bancroft familys initial resistance to News Corp.s overture raises questions. What are the boards responsibilities when a controlling family rejects offers that minority shareholders would jump at? In particular, how do the so-called Revlon duties play into these situations?

title: Two Years Later, an Ethics Fine
description: About two years ago, the states Lobbying Commission settled with Syracuse University over gifts the school had made to various state officials with which it did business. One of those officials was Jeffrey Lovell, at the time a senior policy adviser to then-Gov. George E. Pataki, now an aide to Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno, both of them Republicans.

title: T Style | Living
description: Cover shoot video for the T Style Living Spring 2007 issue.

title: Drought Brings About a Political Storm
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans May 4 column, The Aussie Big Dry.'

title: A Long, Long Lull at Correspondents Dinner
description: Readers respond to Frank Richs Apr. 29 column, All the Presidents Press.

title: Commander Guy, Redux
description: News flash from the White House: President Bush is not the commander guy after all.

title: The Guidelines on Our Integrity from 1999 Are Worth a Look
description: The journalistic standards spelled out in The Timess 1999 Guidelines on Our Integrity are a supplement to the papers Ethical Journalism handbook of 2004, which is a more complete compilation of ethics rules for news staffers. I think readers may find that the specificity of the 1999 guidelines makes them particularly interesting.

title: Calm Before D.C. Madam Report, and After
description: [Update | 8:56 AM ET No storm, just calm. No new high-profile names were dropped in a TV interview with a woman accused of running a Washington-area prostitution ring, The Associated Press reported.]

title: Mayor Calls for Prompt Action on PlaNYC
description: Calling for quick action on enabling legislation for his long-range growth plan for the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg today invoked the ill-fated past of the Second Avenue Subway and other major transit projects that did not survive shifts in the citys political and financial winds.

title: EN NW PKG RADIO SEGO SARKO
description: EN NW PKG RADIO SEGO SARKO

title: EN NW PKG DEBAT ADAPT V2
description: EN NW PKG DEBAT ADAPT V2

title: Mortgages Get Tight
description: Mortgages are suddenly hard to get. And that is why those hoping that the real estate decline is almost over should not take comfort from the fact that mortgage loan applications are strong.

title: Save Darfur  Somewhere Else
description: I had an interesting note from a woman in Boulder named Rachel who put up a green Save Darfur sign on her lawn. Her home-owner association has ordered her to take it down. She sent out an open letter:

title: Microsoft in Early Talks With Yahoo
description: Microsoft and Yahoo are in talks about a joint venture or some other form of cooperation, according to people briefed on the talks. The discussions are part of a continuing dialogue that the two companies have been holding for more than a year, but are still in preliminary stages, these people say.

title: Vows: Jennifer and Gregory
description: Jennifer Kohns and Gregory Rathe speak of meeting on motorcycle night at a Chelsea bar, and then riding in a direct line to the altar.

title: Democrats War Release Wars
description: E-mail is cheap and instantaneous, meaning we get deluged with messages about the candidates thoughts on just about everything  especially each other. E-mail has become the weapon of choice in the war to win over the netroots and anti-war grassroots.

title: Manufacturers and Certified Cars
description: Certified used cars have become popular with buyers over the past five years, offering reassurance from manufacturers that consumers wont get stuck with a lemon. But Christopher Jensen, who wrote about certified pre-owned programs for The Times, found some consumers who discovered that certification did not protect them entirely.

title: Elephant (Ears) in the Room
description: How must it feel to drive for Hondas Formula One team? First of all, youre saddled with the gnarliest livery on the grid, which wouldnt matter so much if it were fast.

title: Executive Pursuits
description: Harry Hurt III learns to sell hot dogs at a New York Mets game.

title: American Album: Spell Utah
description: Kunal Sah, 13, hopes that winning the Scripps National Spelling Bee will bring attention to the plight of his parents, who were deported to India.

title: Why the Silence from Goldilocks?
description: My colleague Dennis Overbye has started working out the logistics of getting to Gliese 581c, the Goldilocks planet (not too hot, not too cold) thats the best prospect yet for extraterrestrial life. But could we expect to find intelligent beings there? Since we havent detected any electronic signs of life from that neighborhood, are the prospects grim of finding anyone at home?

title: Thompson, Not Yet a Candidate, Outlines Views
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., May 4  Former Senator Fred Thompson, whose possible bid for the Republican nomination for president could radically alter an already wide open race for the White House, gave a preview of what his candidacy might look like at a speech before a prominent party organization here late Friday night.

title: How Slow Can It Go?
description: Last week, when the government reported that the economy had slowed to a crawl in the first quarter of the year, any lingering hope for robust employment growth was tempered accordingly. But no one was quite prepared for a job report as weak as the one released yesterday. Only 88,000 jobs were created in April, the smallest gain in nearly two and half years and a sharp deceleration from job growth in the recent past.

title: Out of Static and Bleeps Can Come, Yes, Melodies
description: Annie Gosfield writes music that ranges from improvisatory and serendipitous to carefully notated. But running through much of her work is a fascination with noise. Her pieces are often about the ways that noise can be manipulated and put to musical use. Sometimes they are about the reverse: the way purely musical sounds can be made into noise, and then turned to expressive use.

title: Bank of America Files Suit Over Deal to Buy LaSalle
description: Bank of America asked a federal court yesterday to prevent the Dutch bank ABN Amro from selling its Chicago subsidiary, LaSalle Bank, to rival bidders after its $21 billion acquisition of LaSalle was halted by a Dutch court.

title: Keeping Faith in a Venture Built on Faith
description: I found the Chapter 11 period exhilarating, Steven Waldman was saying the other day.

title: Reuters Approached About a Takeover
description: LONDON, May 4  Reuters, the 156-year-old news agency and the worlds largest publicly traded provider of financial data, has been approached by the Thomson Corporation of Canada about a takeover, a person close to the situation said today.

title: The French Abroad Get a Days Head Start in Voting
description: Jean Karoubi, a French hedge fund investor who has lived in New York since 1977, plans to spend much of the today at home, doing my due diligence, he says. He is going to read a ream or two of recent coverage of the French presidential campaign and, more importantly, telephone a number of friends in Paris in search of insight.

title: Scottish Nationalists Upset Labor in Elections
description: LONDON, May 4  In a historic reversal, the separatist Scottish National Party emerged Friday as the biggest political grouping in Scotland, ending 50 years of dominance there by the governing Labor Party and redrawing Britains political landscape.

title: Kentucky Derby Field Screened for Blood-Doping Agent
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4  The 20 horses set to run in Saturdays Kentucky Derby were tested for the performance-enhancing drug erythropoietin Wednesday, the first surprise prerace test in the Derbys history.

title: Riverside Takes On the Task of Rebuilding a Church
description: Around the grand Gothic edifice of Riverside Church in Manhattan, a structure designed to evoke authority and permanence, there rises a scaffolding of tube pipes and raw boards. Its purpose is to allow workers to repoint the buildings stone facade, but it serves also as a handy metaphor for the paradox of Riverside, the capital of a theological movement that has been slowly deteriorating.

title: Murdoch, Reuters and Scandal. Wait, Were Not Finished.
description: Rupert Murdoch was the man in the news this week as word got out that he wanted to buy Dow Jones & Company.

title: A Split Emerges as Conservatives Discuss Darwin
description: Evolution has long generated bitter fights between the left and the right about whether God or science better explains the origins of life. But now a dispute has cropped up within conservative circles, not over science, but over political ideology: Does Darwinian theory undermine conservative notions of religion and morality or does it actually support conservative philosophy?

title: Construction Accident Kills Laborer at School
description: A day laborer from Ecuador was killed yesterday when an eight-foot-deep trench collapsed at a Brooklyn elementary school, burying him under hundreds of cubic yards of dirt, officials and his employer said.

title: Mayhem on the Screen (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: BMW Oracle Wins Tight Boat Race
description: VALENCIA, Spain, May 4  Arms folded, Larry Ellison looked satisfied, at least for the moment, as he stood on the deck of USA 98 and gazed through his dark glasses at the Italian boat that had not found a way to catch him and his BMW Oracle Racing team.

title: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 4  Louisiana on Friday picked one of the nations most prominent education reformers to run the troubled school district of New Orleans, as schools here continue to grapple with physical and administrative damage from Hurricane Katrina.

title: Ukraines Quarreling Leaders Agree on Early Elections
description: MOSCOW, May 4  Ukraines warring president and prime minister reached an agreement on Friday to hold early parliamentary elections, possibly ending a monthlong political standoff in the former Soviet state but leaving some crucial details unresolved.

title: N.Y. Schools Seek Higher Taxes Despite Extra Aid
description: John Caruana, an electrician, has been startled by how fast the taxes in his suburban community of North Massapequa have risen since he moved into his small Cape Cod home six years ago with his wife and their three children.

title: Carlos the Jackal to Be Tried for Role in 4 Bombing Attacks in 80s
description: PARIS, May 4  The cold-war-era terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal, already serving a life sentence, will be tried in connection with four bombing attacks that killed 11 people and wounded almost 200 in France in 1982 and 1983.

title: Judge Orders Release of Police Files on Convention, Pending a Stay to Appeal
description: A federal judge yesterday ordered the New York Police Department to release 600 pages of secret documents related to its security preparations for the Republican National Convention in 2004, but he gave the city a 10-day stay to file an appeal.

title: Paper Jam at FedEx Kinkos
description: DALLAS  Tag along and marvel as Kenneth A. May, the chief executive of FedEx Kinkos, works a roomful of employees.

title: In French Bid, Immigrants Son Battles Reputation as Anti-Immigrant
description: PARIS, May 4  The possible next president of France is the son of an immigrant with a very un-French name who has done as much, if not more, than any other French official to improve the status of minorities.

title: Venezuela: A Chill Follows Threat by Chvez
description: Financial markets reacted with concern to a threat by President Hugo Chvez to nationalize the banking system. Mr. Chvez said Thursday that banks should finance industry at a low cost. If banks dont agree with this, its better that they go, that they turn over the banks to me, that we nationalize them and get all the banks to work for the development of the country and not to speculate and produce huge profits, Mr. Chvez said. Venezuelas currency, the bolvar, fell more than 3 percent in unregulated trading to about 3,950 to the dollar, traders said, and investors sold government bonds amid fears that a state takeover of banks could weaken the economy.

title: The Little Dog Has His Day
description: Miami Beach

title: First Response to Corzines Crash: V.I.P.! Everyone Out Here Now!
description: TRENTON, May 4  Shortly before 6 p.m. on April 12, a state police dispatcher assigned to the Garden State Parkway got a frantic call about a major car accident north of the Atlantic City Expressway. V.I.P.! came the urgent female voice. Everyone out here now!

title: Corrections
description: Editors Note

title: Easley Is Saving His Best (and the Mets) for Last
description: PHOENIX, May 4 Damion Easleys family left Chase Field a few innings before the end of Thursdays game. It was getting late, and his four children had to get up early for school the next morning.

title: Small Businesses Premiums Soar After Illness
description: To understand the challenges of insuring the health of the nations work force, consider Varneys Book Store.

title: Nine Ways to Elect a President
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Evgeny Kissin Warms Up, and He Keeps on Cooking
description: There is a sense of breathless anticipation before some concerts at Carnegie Hall, with people seeking and selling tickets amid the multilingual crowds milling outside. Evgeny Kissin, the Russian pianist, lived up to that excitement at his Carnegie appearance on Thursday night, but mostly after the scheduled program  when he played a marathon 12 encores.

title: Challenging Saudi Arabias Powerful, One Caller at a Time
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia

title: Looking Back at 6 Decades of Subway Worker Deaths
description: One tripped and fell on the third rail. One was walking along an elevated track when a board gave way and he fell to his death. One, walking on the tracks without carrying a light, was run over by a train.

title: For Queen and First Lady, Bush Will Try White Tie
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  How does George W. Bush, a towel-snapping Texan who puts his feet on the coffee table, drinks water straight from the bottle and was once caught on tape talking with food in his mouth prepare for a state dinner with the queen?

title: New Twists and New Bitterness in Suit Over Montana Resort
description: HELENA, Mont., May 4  Greg LeMond, the champion cyclist who won the Tour de France three times, may have thought his retirement would be quiet and comfortable. But judging from this weeks latest twist in a lawsuit he originally filed last year, Mr. LeMond will be locked in a battle for the edge yet again.

title: Being Green Doesnt Mean Buying More
description: IT has never been so trendy to be green. By that I dont mean that suddenly everyone is installing solar panels at home or making a commitment to reduce, reuse and recycle as many goods as possible. Now you can think of yourself as an environmental champion just by going shopping.

title: Sabres Steal Victory From Rangers
description: BUFFALO, May 4  For a while, the Rangers locker room stayed nearly empty, except for goalie Henrik Lundqvist, who was encircled by reporters and photographers. He was talking quietly, a blank look on his face, describing the Rangers stunning loss to Buffalo on Friday night.

title: A Beautiful Mine
description: Rowdy, Ky.

title: Called, Increasingly, to a Somber Duty: Last Respects for the Militarys Dead
description: A gray Dodge Caravan with government plates stopped in a section of St. Raymonds Cemetery in the Bronx on Tuesday and three young soldiers in dress blue uniforms stepped out. Specialist Rebecca Santana, 23, carried a black case holding a ceremonial bugle. Staff Sgt. Noel Rodriguez, 26, and Specialist Ruben Martinez, 23, walked toward a mound of fresh earth amid narrow rows of well-tended graves. The three were there to serve as official Army representatives at the funeral of a World War II veteran.

title: Many Detainees at Guantnamo Rebuff Lawyers
description: Many of the detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, are no longer cooperating with their lawyers, adding a largely invisible struggle between the lawyers and their own clients to the legal battle over the Bush administrations detention policies.

title: Date Set for Appeal of Jones Suspension
description: Pacman Jones, the troubled Tennessee cornerback, will appeal his season-long suspension from the National Football League on Friday, when he will meet with Commissioner Roger Goodell.

title: City to Change Taxi Rules After Inquiry Into Bidding
description: New York City will rewrite the rules governing how it auctions off valuable taxi licenses after concerns of collusion were raised in some of the latest auctions, city officials said yesterday.

title: For the Record
description: A chart yesterday about changes in the dates of Democratic primaries and caucuses from 2004 to 2008 misidentified the time frame for the selection of the District of Columbias delegates to the partys nominating convention. While Washington does hold a primary before the Jan. 14 caucuses in Iowa, the results are nonbinding; the actual delegate selection will not take place until February.

title: Changing the Cast but Keeping the Quality
description: The Ohio-born tenor Lawrence Brownlee is no newcomer to big-time opera. Last season he sang the role of Count Almaviva in Rossinis Barbiere di Siviglia for his debut at La Scala in Milan.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article on April 22 about Russian news coverage misstated the date that a state television network, Rossiya TV, led its newscast with a report about President Vladimir V. Putins attending a martial arts competition with the Belgian actor Jean-Claude Van Damme. It was Sunday, April 15, not Saturday, April 14, though an earlier edition of Rossiyas newscast in St. Petersburg did report on the event that Saturday.

title: Job Growth Was Slower Last Month
description: Businesses significantly pared back hiring last month, a sign that the job market may be starting to feel the drag of slower economic growth.

title: Leadership Woes at the World Bank (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Many of the Self-Employed Are Simply on Their Own
description: The small businesses that struggle the most with health insurance may be the smallest of all: those with only one employee.

title: Jackson Emerges as the Unlikely Leader of the Warriors Improbable Run
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 4  By all rights, Golden States Stephen Jackson should have been ejected with 4 minutes 26 seconds left in the third quarter of Game 6.

title: Fehr Is Standing Strong Against a Raging Tide
description: I dont know Donald Fehr. Before an hour-long interview in his office Thursday, my only contact with him had been a question at a news conference, or hearing sound bites on TV. I was familiar with his reputation as a ferocious negotiator.

title: For the Record
description: An article on April 5 about details of Gov. Eliot Spitzers first New York State budget included erroneous information from a Spitzer aide about the position of fish pathologist for the Department of Environmental Conservation. (The error first appeared on Feb. 5 in the Empire Zone column, about Mr. Spitzers first month in office.) The budget adds one position to those that already exist; the fish pathologist to be hired will not in fact be the states first.

title: Can This Patient Be Saved?
description: As a surgeon, Ive seen some pretty large tumors. Ive excised fist-size thyroid cancers from peoples necks and abdominal masses bigger than your head. When I do, this is what almost invariably happens: the anesthesiologist puts the patient to sleep, the nurse unsnaps the gown, everyone takes a sharp breath, and someone blurts out, How could someone let that thing get so huge?

title: Winning Goal Comes From Unlikely Source
description: BUFFALO, May 4  Nobody saw Sabres forward Maxim Afinogenovs star turn coming Friday night. Not Rangers goaltender Henrik Lundqvist, who was screened on Afinogenovs game-winning shot in overtime, and certainly not the season-ticket holders in the HSBC Arena sellout crowd who had witnessed Afinogenovs miserable play here in the first two games of the Eastern Conference semifinal series.

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 9 P.M. (Hallmark) A STRANGERS HEART (2007) Bring out the tissues. Billed by Hallmark as a touching story about a second chance at life ... and love, this feel-good weepy stars Samantha Mathis (above, far left, with Mary Matilyn Mouser) as a magazine reporter who receives a long-awaited heart transplant, only to find that she cant stop dreaming about a young girl she has never met. Turns out that another heart recipient (Peter Dobson) has the same dreams. Which leads them to ask, Who is the girl, and whats her connection to us? Bet you can guess.

title: Ida R. Hoos Is Dead at 94; a Critic of Systems Analysis
description: Ida R. Hoos, a prominent critic of assessing technology solely on the basis of mathematical models that failed to take account of societal factors, died on April 24 in Boston. She was 94 and lived in Brookline, Mass.

title: Many Detainees at Guantnamo Rebuff Lawyers
description: Many of the detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, are no longer cooperating with their lawyers, adding a largely invisible struggle between the lawyers and their own clients to the legal battle over the Bush administrations detention policies.

title: On Bulls, Wallace Shows Worth
description: Ben Wallace has a $60 million contract and $15 shoes.

title: A Young Saxophonist in Good Post-Bop Company
description: Joel Frahm, who has been playing at Sweet Rhythm this week, has established an identity over the last decade as a post-bop tenor saxophonist with a deft and assertive command. He has sharpened his skills alongside members of his peer group, like the singer Jane Monheit and the drummer Matt Wilson. A few years ago he recorded an album of duets with Brad Mehldau, a pianist with a much higher profile, but it was a meeting of equals, and not just because the two musicians had met in their teens.

title: PBS Supports Ken Burns Against Latinos Complaints
description: Public broadcasting executives are defending the right of the filmmaker Ken Burns to tell the history of World War II as he sees fit, in the face of escalating complaints and veiled threats of a boycott from Latinos who say his coming PBS documentary The War slights Hispanics contributions to the war effort.

title: Zambia: Ex-President Told to Repay Stolen Millions
description: A British judge delivered what some experts called a signal verdict against African corruption, ordering the former Zambian president Frederick Chiluba, left, and 19 others to return at least $46 million it said they had stolen while in power in the 1990s and early this decade. The London judge, Peter Smith, ruled that Mr. Chiluba, in power from 1991 to 2001, was uniquely positioned to stop corruption in government, but that he elected instead to join in it. Zambias government sued in London because it alleged that Mr. Chiluba and his associates had bought assets in Britain and elsewhere in Europe. Mr. Chiluba said in a statement that he did not recognize a British courts authority in Zambian issues, arguing that the case circumvented Zambias justice system. Other African experts said the verdict, the first against a current or former head of state, could set an anticorruption precedent.

title: Brazil Overrides Merck Patent on AIDS Drug
description: The government, whose spending on AIDS drugs has skyrocketed as more patients have needed costly, patented medicines, overrode the patent held by the pharmaceutical company Merck on the antiretroviral drug efavirenz. The cost of Mercks drugs has been $580 annually per patient. Brazil said the company had offered a 30 percent discount, but the government opted instead to buy the generic version from India for less than $170. For years, Brazil has considered exercising its rights under international trade rules to make or import generic versions of patented AIDS drugs, but has until now backed away, fearing trade retaliation from the United States. For more than a decade, Brazil has provided universal free access to drug treatment for people with AIDS. Almost one in four patients in Brazil are now taking efavirenz. With the new price, Brazil estimates that it will save $237 million on efavirenz by 2012 when the patent expires. Thailand, which also has an ambitious AIDS treatment program, overrode Mercks patent on the same drug in November.

It was erected a few blocks down from the bustling Capitol, in easier days of righteousness. Then, prostitute was an occupation on census lists, and the citys lobbying arts more routinely extended to sexual quid pro quos. Ms. Hall ran a classic parlor house, with Brussels carpets and red plush furniture. It was so fine  upper ten, by the Zagat-like ratings of Victoriana  that it was pronounced the best among the 450 brothels the Army provost marshal cataloged like neighborhood botes.

title: Talk Dirt to Me
description: Its hard to have a conversation about wine these days without hearing the French word terroir. Derived from a Latin root meaning earth, terroir describes the relationship between a wine and the specific place that it comes from. For example, many will say the characteristic minerality of wines from Chablis comes from the limestone beds beneath the vineyards (although, when pressed, they generally admit that theyve never actually tasted limestone). The idea that one can taste the earth in a wine is appealing, a welcome link to nature and place in a delocalized world; it has also become a rallying cry in an increasingly sharp debate over the direction of modern winemaking. The trouble is, its not true.

It is the season of mass distraction, of the tent pole, the event movie, the blockbuster.

The word filioque (and from the son), which appears in the Catholic liturgy but not in Orthodox liturgy, occurs in the Credo section, not the Sanctus.

title: Midlife Vehicle Administration
description: My little white Hyundai died a couple of years ago at 75,000 miles, died beyond repair or resuscitation. I was sad to see it go, towed away one day before I even had the chance to clean it out. I bought it brand-new and pearl white for what seemed like a huge sum, back then  $4,000. That car carried me through my 30s and into my early 40s. With it went a lot of time, a lot of ideas dreamed up behind its sticky wheel, a lot of babies crying and late-night fights, a lot of conversations with my sister.

title: Local Forecast: Bad
description: THE recent heavy storms that left downtown Manville, N.J., under 10 feet of water; filled the basements of Mamaroneck, N.Y.; and flooded rivers and downed power lines in Connecticut may have provided a glimpse of our future. Climate change is accelerating, and the prognosis for the region is alarming, as it is for the rest of the world. No matter how effectively we begin to curb our greenhouse-gas emissions now, we are destined to see significant climate changes because these gases remain in the atmosphere for a long time. We cannot delay planning for the environmental and human calamities that lie ahead.

This is the stated objective of the Betty Crocker Card Game. The unstated objective is to amiably enact what weve long known to be true: that every dinner party is an unspoken competition with your guests, i.e., I see your beef Wellington and raise you a cassoulet. The B.C.C.G. allows you to compete openly over ludicrously time-consuming food, and for prizes.
