description: THE way homes for sale are being dressed up, or staged, these days can provoke an overwhelming love-at-first-sight, I-want-it, I-want-it-all kind of fervor in certain buyers, real estate sales agents are noticing.

title: A Drastic Cure for Procrastination
description: I STUMBLED over the accordion in the basement, its case already as deep in water as I was  water pouring in from foundation crevices, billowing up through floor tiles into the fringed magenta rug and, more repulsively, backing up from the street through the sewer cap that we had opened in a feeble attempt to drain away the flood. The April northeaster had hit New Jersey, and we were in its path.

title: In Florida, a Home Market Still in Flux
description: FOR several years, the defining images of Floridas frenzied real estate boom were crowded open houses and speculators flipping preconstruction condominiums. But since the market sputtered in mid-2005, as sales fell and inventories soared, property auctions and price cutting have become commonplace.

title: Free-Agent Pitchers Come at High Cost, Most With No Payoff
description: Jason Marquis pitched so poorly last September that he won none of his five starts, lost four of them, compiled a 7.25 earned run average, didnt appear in the St. Louis Cardinals first playoff series against San Diego and was left off the roster for the league championship series and the World Series.

title: Emily Gregory, Daniel Hopkins
description: Dr. Emily Flora Gregory, the daughter of Rona H. Gregory of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Joel W. Gregory, who lived in Montreal, is to be married today on Cape Cod to Daniel Jacob Hopkins, a son of Dr. Alice S. Prince of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Dr. B Smith Hopkins III. Rabbi Barbara Penzner officiated at the vacation home of the bridegrooms mother in Orleans, Mass.

title: Big Bird Meets the Big House
description: When Greg Scheinman and his wife, Kate, moved to Houston four years ago, they were expecting their first child.

title: Gentlemen of the Road
description: Conclusion: On Following the Road to One's Destiny, With the Usual Intrusions of Violence and Grace

title: Manchester United Closes in on a Title
description: Manchester United goalkeeper Edwin van der Sar saved a penalty kick yesterday to help his team defeat host Manchester City, 1-0, and close in on its first English Premier League title since 2003.

title: Correction: Comparative Literature
description: A statistical report on April 15 about the international book market misspelled the surname of the author of Measuring the World, a top international fiction best seller for 2006. He is Daniel Kehlmann, not Kellman.

title: Beware the Siren Lebanon
description: JERUSALEM

title: Final Days for a Moldy Nixon Retreat
description: Saddle River

title: Wang Keeps Demeanor Calm and Sinker Low
description: Chien-Ming Wangs audition for the Yankees took place in a gymnasium in Taiwan seven years ago. It rained that day, so Wangs workout was moved indoors. Wang threw for about a half-hour before he was offered a $1.9 million signing bonus. He accepted.

title: A Two-Wheeled Option (With a Battery) for Commuters
description: JEFF BAUM has a breathtaking daily commute. He travels 10 miles each way from his home in Frisco, Colo., to his office in Breckenridge  up and down winding roads that eventually climb to 9,800 feet in the Rockies  to his job as the executive director of the Breckenridge Music Festival.

title: Correction: Caption in The Grand Surprise Review
description: A picture caption on April 22 with a review of The Grand Surprise: The Journals of Leo Lerman, misspelled the given name of the actress shown with Lerman in 1952. She is Luise Rainer, not Louise.

title: Not Hot Just Yet, but Newark Is Starting to Percolate
description: NEWARK, May 2  You live where?

title: Promiscuities
description: The protagonist of Lynn Stegners stunning new novel is a self-destructive hussy who isnt above locking her child in a car for several hours while she amuses herself with an afternoon tryst. Kate Riley needs to be desired  constantly, achingly, even violently desired  in order to feel truly alive. Lunging from one sensual high to the next, she leaves a crowd of broken people in her wake.

title: Propaganda Fear Cited in Account of Iraqi Killings
description: Recently unclassified documents suggest that senior officers viewed the killings of 24 Iraqi civilians in Haditha in late 2005 as a potential public relations problem that could fuel insurgent propaganda against the American military, leading investigators to question whether the officers immediate response had been intentionally misleading.

title: A Scandal That Keeps Growing
description: Attorney General Alberto Gonzales declared recently, while batting down bipartisan calls for him to resign, that he had many things to do and cant just be focused on the U.S. attorneys situation. Its not surprising that Mr. Gonzales wants to change the subject. At best, the firing of eight United States attorneys, most of them highly respected, is an example of such profound incompetence that it should cost Mr. Gonzales his job. At worst, it was a political purge followed by a cover-up. In either case, the scandal is only getting bigger and more disturbing.

title: From Arabic to Hebrew
description: One day in 10th-century Baghdad a visiting foreign student named Dunash Ben Labrat showed his teacher, the revered scholar Saadia Gaon, a poem he had composed in a novel style. Saadia handed the poem back with the comment Nothing like it has ever been seen in Israel. This dubious compliment, which all teachers of creative writing might wish to employ, failed to discourage Dunash. He took himself, and his new poetry, back home to Muslim Spain. There, despite the dismay his mediocre verses prompted in other aspiring Hebrew poets, his style caught on. Within a few decades, from these unpromising origins, a brilliant and original body of Hebrew verse began to take shape. Virtually stagnant since late Biblical times, Hebrew poetry and the language itself would be transformed by a succession of poets of genius and their imitators. In Peter Coles rich new anthology, the extent of their astonishing achievement is fully revealed for the first time in English.

title: Increased State Aid or Not, Districts Seek Higher Taxes
description: DESPITE record increases in state aid for next school year, most districts on Long Island and in other New York City suburbs have also proposed property tax increases well over the inflation rate. District officials say they are handcuffed by big annual increases in teachers salaries and the rising costs of pensions and health insurance, as well as higher energy prices.

title: Getting the Most Bang Out of Quarks and Gluons
description: UPTON

title: Vivaldi Arrives Fashionably Late
description: IN fashion, everything old eventually becomes new again. No matter how old.

title: Kate DeScherer, Edwyn Ossa
description: Kate Anne Kaltman DeScherer, the daughter of Jennie L. DeScherer and Richard K. DeScherer of New York, is to be married today to Edwyn Patrick Ossa, the son of Patricia Stypula of Newark, Ohio, and the late Julio E. Ossa. The ceremony will be at the William Aiken House, a 19th-century mansion in Charleston, S.C. Richard A. Brown, the Queens County district attorney and a friend of the bride and her family, is to officiate by a special order of the Probate Court of Charleston County.

title: Annsley Rosner, Gregory Slawsky
description: Annsley Elin Rosner, the daughter of Krista Berneike Hart of Woodbridge, Conn., and Robert A. Rosner of West Haven, Conn., was married yesterday to Gregory Jonathan Slawsky, a son of Halina Slawsky and Richard E. Slawsky of Milford, Conn. The Rev. Sandra A. Belcher, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the First Church of Christ in Woodbridge, with the Rev. Dr. Sara Penn-Strah, a minister of the United Church of Christ, taking part.

July
description: JULY

title: Certified? Yes. Satisfied? Not Always.
description: GETTING halves of two cars was not what Paulette Day expected when she bought a red 2004 Chevrolet Monte Carlo that year from a dealership near Detroit for $22,000. The car was used, but it was a G.M. certified car, meaning it had supposedly passed a rigorous inspection by the dealer. As General Motors says in its marketing material, buying a certified car means the reliability of new and the affordability of used.

title: How to Leap Into Fame and Keep Your Head
description: LONDON

title: Portrait of a Village as an Arts Haven
description: PATCHOGUE

description: PARIS

title: Dear S.E.C., Reconsider Arbitration
description: ARGUING that it is wrong to force investors into arbitration when resolving disputes with their brokers, two prominent United States senators have asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to ban the Wall Street practice of requiring customers to sign away their rights to bring their grievances to court.

title: Mr. Spitzers Gold Rush
description: In a case of particularly bad timing, Gov. Eliot Spitzer flew to California last week to raise campaign funds. Rushing to California to raise money is not illegal or even uncommon for a New York politician. But Mr. Spitzers trip came while he has been chastising legislators back home for failing to reform the states shameful campaign fund-raising system.

title: After the Horrors of War, a Helping Hand at Home
description: WHEN soldiers from the Connecticut Army National Guard returned from Afghanistan two weeks ago, barricades could not stop their families and friends from greeting them as they got off planes at the Army Aviation Support Facility in Windsor Locks.

title: Giving the Last Laugh to Lifes Losers
description: schlub U.S. slang. A worthless person, a jerk, an oaf.  Oxford English Dictionary

title: A Winning Producer Chronicles a Broadway Season on Film
description: ONE opening night has come and gone, leaving mostly big smiles in its wake. But for Dori Berinstein, one of the three leading producers of Legally Blonde, which opened on Broadway April 29, the anticipation has just begun. On Friday she will make her debut as a film director when ShowBusiness: The Road to Broadway, a full-length documentary that she also produced, opens in Manhattan.

title: Raise You One
description: Odds are, you wont be competing at Wimbledon this year. Nor will you be sporting an Olympic medal, a Super Bowl ring or the Masters green jacket anytime soon. And given that others spend their lives training for these things and you dont, that seems only fair. But as Anthony Holden points out in his engaging new book, Bigger Deal, lack of experience neednt prevent any of us from participating in  and possibly winning  the worlds largest, most lucrative sports competition: the World Series of Poker. In 2006, 44,500 entrants vied for a prize pool of more than $150 million, and the $12 million title event was won by a Hollywood producer taking time off from filming a reality show called Americas Hottest Mom. In 2005, the title came down to a head-to-head between two mortgage brokers. At the W.S.O.P., amateurs compete with pros and regularly trounce them. So why not you? Or me? Or Holden?

title: Marcia Yablon, Geordie Zug
description: Marcia Anne Yablon, a daughter of Joan and Charles M. Yablon of New York, is to be married today to Charles Gordon Zug IV, the son of Sara G. Zug of Gladwyne, Pa., and Mr. Zug III of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Kayelily Middleton, a nondenominational minister, is to officiate at Fearrington House, a restaurant and inn in Pittsboro, N.C., with Rabbi Andrew V. Ettin taking part.

title: When a Kiss Is More Than a Kiss
description: RICHARD GERE, while not the first person youd think most likely to invoke the wrath of a conservative religious mob by kissing somebody in public, was at least a passably recognizable symbolic target for Hindu demonstrators last week, when they burned his figure in effigy in cities across India.

title: A Close Call, and a Sign of a Thriving Animal World
description: MIDDLETOWN

title: A Young Playwright Gets Her Say, and Teenagers Their Day
description: SEVERAL teenagers from New Haven will be visiting Yale this month, and it wont be for early orientation. The Wendy Play, written by Amy Herzog, a third-year playwright at Yale Drama School, will feature young actors from the Educational Center for the Arts (E.C.A.) run by ACES, Area Cooperative Educational Services.

title: Antiwar Groups Use New Clout to Influence Democrats on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  Every morning, representatives from a cluster of antiwar groups gather for a conference call with Democratic leadership staff members in the House and the Senate.

title: Mets Gamble on Sosa Pays Off for One Night
description: PHOENIX, May 5  Last seen in spring training: A right-handed pitcher named Jorge Sosa, about 6 feet 2 inches, who spent a good portion of his time watching balls sail over the fence. Seen at Chase Field on Saturday: A guy who looked like Sosa, same height and build and fastball, who spent a good portion of his night watching zero after zero pile up next to ARI on the center-field scoreboard.

title: Laid-Back Labor
description: The $140 Homemade Scarf

title: For a Small Slaughterhouse, a Dash of Local Glory
description: About a dozen speckled Plymouth Rock hens sat at the front of the poultry section. They and their neighbors  hundreds of Rhode Island hens, Muscovy drakes and other fowl  warbled quietly in their pens. Lambs and goats munched alfalfa grass in a roomier wing next door.

title: Invisible Palestinians Exist in Legal Limbo in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 5  Three generations of the Hamdallah family have lived in Lebanon. And for three generations not a single member of the family has been allowed to graduate from school, legally marry, or hold a job, or even set foot outside of the rundown camps that have been home to generations of Palestinians.

title: Beer-Soaked Myths, Boarded Up for Now
description: BY early last week, the word seemed to have gotten out about Chumleys. The former speakeasy and literary haunt in Greenwich Village, closed since its chimney collapsed on April 5, was still boarded up, and even tourists with their noses buried in guidebooks passed by without looking up.

title: The Week in New Jersey
description: Storms Prompt Bill on Buying Flood Properties

title: Laugh Lines: Jay Leno, David Letterman and Conan OBrien
description: JAY LENO

title: An Indie Star Whose Life Is an Indie Film
description: AFTER a breakfast interview with Parker Posey in the East Village in March that careered through yoga, Mel Gibson and how not to play the Hollywood game, it was time to go. She offered to walk a reporter toward the subway, stopping at her apartment to get her little fluffy white dog, Gracie. Ms. Posey smiled to herself as she came down the steps with Gracie in a floral shoulder bag, then pointed to a small stuffed Snoopy in the tree above us.

title: Sex, Drugs and Hot Tubs
description: People of a certain age will remember Esalen, the famous (or infamous) spa in Big Sur on the California coast, founded in the 1960s as a center of the human potential movement. In his book Esalen: America and the Religion of No Religion, Jeffrey J. Kripal describes it as a utopian experiment creatively suspended between the revelations of the religions and the democratic, pluralistic and scientific revolutions of modernity. In 1990, someone painted graffiti (unprintable in its entirety here) at the entrance: Jive ... for rich white folk.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,353 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: The Rangers Bury the (Immediate) Past With Optimism
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., May 5  From the looks of the Rangers practice, with players laughing and joking, trash-talking with the backup goaltenders during drills, Saturday seemed like a normal day.

title: The New Staples
description: According to Peppadew lore, a man referred to only as J. S. discovered an unusual pepper plant a decade ago near his home in South Africa. Delighted by the fruits sweet and spicy kick, he began a global marketing campaign. Pickled, the pepper has since become a fixture at restaurants like Little Giant in New York, where the bartender whips up this Peppadew martini.

title: Julie Katz, Brian Karp
description: Dr. Julie Ann Katz and Dr. Brian James Karp are to be married this afternoon at the View on the Hudson, an events space in Piermont, N.Y. Rabbi Joshua Z. Gruenberg is to officiate.

title: The Guy Who Picks the Best Places to Live
description: EVERY so often, a report comes out listing the best (or worst) cities to live in, the most romantic, the most child-friendly or the most affordable.

title: The Older Woman
description: Q: Despite your reputation as a seriously witty journalist, screenwriter and director, youve recently emerged as the poster girl for a whole new wrinkling and sagging population, thanks to your essay collection I Feel Bad About My Neck: And Other Thoughts on Being a Woman. How old are you, exactly? Im 65 going on 66, as we used to say when we were 12.

title: Where Are All the Black Swans?
description: IN 1933 Lincoln Kirstein wrote a passionate 16-page letter to his friend A. Everett Austin Jr., the director of the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, introducing a man named George Balanchine and a dream: to remake ballet for America. The plan, as Kirstein wrote, was to have four white girls and four white boys, about 16 years old, and eight of the same, negros.

title: Whats on Sunday Night
description: 9 P.M. (NBC) SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE IN THE 90s: POP CULTURE NATION This was the decade in which S.N.L. went from being named a national institution by the Peabody Awards to being derided as Saturday Night Dead to being resurrected with the addition of new cast members including Will Ferrell. This special traverses the decades highs and lows through interviews with Lorne Michaels, Dana Carvey (above right), Mike Myers (above left), Jimmy Fallon, Mr. Ferrell, Tina Fey, Darrell Hammond, Norm Macdonald, Tim Meadows,  take a breath  Kevin Nealon, Cheri Oteri, Chris Rock and Molly Shannon, among others, as well as a little insight from two of its most frequent hosts, John Goodman and Alec Baldwin.

title: Walking on the Wild Side of a Montana University
description: MISSOULA, Mont.  The University of Montana is a wild place.

title: Against Moderation
description: Its odd the books people get asked to review. Take this one, a carefree history of our long love affair with drinking. I have no training as a historian, just some slight experience on both sides of bars. And perhaps an exaggerated reputation for disparaging todays ubiquitous alcohol-free business lunches. Barbara Holland, though, might empathize. She reminds us that in 1787, two days before their work was done, the 55 delegates to the Constitutional Convention adjourned to a tavern for some rest, and according to the bill they drank 54 bottles of Madeira, 60 bottles of claret, 8 of whiskey, 22 of port, 8 of hard cider and 7 bowls of punch so large that, it was said, ducks could swim around in them. Then they went back to work and finished founding the new Republic. Note the 55 delegates and 54 bottles of Madeira. Which founder was slacking?

title: Correction: 36 Hours in Dublin
description: The 36 Hours column on April 22, about Dublin, misstated the location of the Fashion and Design Market there. It is on Cows Lane, not Cows Land.

title: Hatland
description: A new gilded age was in full bloom at the 25th anniversary lunch of the Womens Committee of the Central Park Conservancy last Wednesday. Extravagant hats are always a signature of the event. This year the favorite colors were white, ivory, beige and black etched in white. Attended by 1,240 guests, the lunch raised $2.3 million. Over the years, the committee has raised more than $28 million.

title: In Praise of General Tso
description: IF there is a song of the lazy, unmarried man in New York, the words and music can be found most often in that pile of yellowed and stained takeout menus on top of his fridge.

title: A Victory for Open Space
description: In a state as densely populated and developed as New Jersey, even a small victory for preserving open land is worth celebrating. A unanimous appeals court ruling last week gave conservationists exactly that by saying that owners enrolled in the states farmland preservation program must allow the state to buy the land even it does not exactly match a developers offer.

title: But Would Thoreau Have Lived Here?
description: EAST LYME

title: MST3K: The Final Frontier
description: WHEN Mystery Science Theater 3000 was canceled after 11 seasons in 1999, 146 distraught fans bought a full-page advertisement in Daily Variety urging another network to continue the show. But the series was not revived, and today devotees cannot even tune in to reruns because its premise  a host and his two robot pals mock B movies  required securing those movies broadcast rights, which expired after the shows demise.

title: Inside the List
description: BIG IN BERLIN: J. R. Moehringers memoir The Tender Bar (2005), about how the author, as a boy, found a family of sorts in a Long Island saloon, was a best seller in the States  it spent four weeks on our hardcover list and seven more in paperback. Interestingly, the book has found an enthusiastic audience as well in Germany, where it was recently No. 3 on Der Spiegels best-seller list. The Book Reviews Bad for You issue seemed like an occasion to explore why this beer-soaked memoir is selling so well there, and we reached Moehringer by phone at a hotel room in Berlin, where hes still touring for his book. I wish I knew why its doing so well, he said. But it is interesting to discuss theories. I suspect its a combination of a bunch of things. Here, in Moehringers words, are what some of those things may be.

title: A Tale of Two Cities
description: THE question trails Robert Caro like a fly, buzzing in his ear. Over and over, at cocktail parties and museum receptions in the past few years, he hears variations on the same query.

title: Grill Seekers
description: Outdoor cooking used to be so easy. Youd douse briquettes in petrochemicals, overcook meat in the kettle grill from the hardware store and drink too much canned beer. But no more: like sports and deodorant, grilling has gone extreme. Interest in the nuances of grilling and barbecue has skyrocketed. Guys list the grills they own in barbecue chat rooms, while charcoal brands are rated at Nakedwhiz.com (sample: Whole Foods charcoal is mostly flooring scrap). These people are not just spending too much time thinking about outdoor cooking. Theyre spending too much money too: Kalamazoo Outdoor Gourmet, the leader in meticulously manufactured and conspicuously expensive grills, has discontinued production of its $1,600 entry-level model since orders for its custom outdoor kitchens (starting at $20,000) have shot up from 5 percent of its business three years ago to 40 percent today.

title: Prison Made of Type
description: While incarcerated in a madhouse in mid-18th-century England, Christopher Smart scribbled a poem suggesting that God was punching words onto the blank page of his imagination. Two centuries later, William S. Burroughs imagined the Soft Typewriter, a demiurge that writes each of us into being and controls our behavior. In The Iron Whim, Darren Wershler-Henry insists that, until quite recently, the act of typewriting exercised a sinister influence over our lives. Just because Smart and Burroughs were paranoid, he suggests, it doesnt mean their typewriters werent out to get them.

title: A Medicare Program (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Claire Israel and Oren Silverstein
description: Claire Deborah Israel and Oren Benjamin Silverstein were married last evening at Cupids Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The Rev. John Langford, a Pentecostal minister, officiated. The couple plan to have a Jewish service on June 9 at Nana restaurant in Brooklyn. Rabbi Dan Bromstein is to officiate.

title: Stella Mellas, Scott Hadfield
description: Dr. Stella Mellas and Scott William Hadfield are to be married today at Christ Church Warwick in Paget, Bermuda. The Rev. T. Alan W. Garrity, a minister of the Church of Scotland, will officiate. Afterward, the Rev. Demetrios Kehagias, is to perform a Greek Orthodox ceremony.

title: High Hopes for This Season. After That, Who Knows?
description: OCEANPORT

title: Hyatt Promises Homey Feeling in New Chain
description: The Global Hyatt Corporation is hoping the word Andaz will soon be a brand name as well known to consumers as, say, Hyatt. Meaning personal style in Hindi, the name is being given to a to the renovated Great Eastern Hotel in Londons financial district. This first Andaz is to open this fall and be followed in late 2008 by a second Andaz in New York at 75 Wall Street and a third, the following year, on Fifth Avenue across from the New York Public Library.

title: Stocks Rise as the Media Sector Is Rediscovered
description: Buoyed by reports of possible mergers and acquisitions, stocks surged last week, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to another record close on Friday.

title: Another Way to Go Green
description: With plenty of seats on hand and swift counter service, the Stand Cafe and Juice Bar would seem to be misnamed. But its not time on your feet that the name is meant to evoke. Instead its the wholesome image of a fruit or vegetable stand, said the owners, Carissa Dellicicchi and Michael Hvizdo, who by opening this vegan vegetarian eatery last December, also felt they were taking a stand.

title: Wearing a Hat and Wanted in 3 Counties
description: UNION

title: Iraqi Courts Seek to End Sunnis Immunity
description: BAGHDAD, May 5  Iraqs top judicial authority has asked Parliament to lift immunity for a prominent Sunni lawmaker, possibly clearing the way for his arrest on charges of provoking sectarian violence.

title: G.O.P. Leader Says Results Needed in Iraq by Fall
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  The House Republican leader, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, warned today that unless progress is evident in Iraq by early fall, many Republican lawmakers would begin losing patience.

title: Get Happy
description: So far as I know, Attila the Hun had nothing to say on the subject of happiness. In this, he appears to be unique among notable (and not so notable) figures from antiquity on down to the present day. Hes absent from those lists of quotable happiness quotes that litter self-help books and the Web, and he isnt among the many dozens of sources cited  from Ecclesiastes to Thomas Jefferson to Willy Wonka  in Jennifer Michael Hechts new book, The Happiness Myth: Why What We Think Is Right Is Wrong.

title: State Using Green Funds to Buy Parcel in Arrow Park
description: TO some, the $1.98 million is a good start. To others, it is simply not enough.

title: A Longer, Better Life
description: Sara Davidson talks to two medical scientists about how the body ages and the research on trying to extend our healthy life span. Participants: Lenny GUARENTE, PH.D.: Novartis professor of biology at M.I.T. and author of Ageless Quest: One Scientists Search for Genes That Prolong Youth.; Robert N. BUTLER, M.D.: Founding director of the National Institute on Aging, a founder of the Alzheimers Disease Association and winner of a Pulitzer Prize in 1976 for Why Survive? Being Old in America. He heads the International Longevity Center.; SARA DAVIDSON: Author, most recently, of Leap! What Will We Do With the Rest of Our Lives?

title: Jockey Wins Four on Derby Undercard
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5  When they hit the far turn in the 133rd running of the Kentucky Derby, Elizabeth Jones Valando could not have asked for more: Nobiz Like Shobiz was moving quickly toward the leader, Hard Spun.

title: Tracy Rohrlich, Jonathan Badner
description: Tracy Lynn Rohrlich and Jonathan Harris Badner were married last evening by Rabbi Norton D. Shargel at the St. Regis in New York.

title: University President Placed on Suspension
description: BATON ROUGE, La. (AP), May 5  The nations largest historically black university system suspended its president with pay Saturday and ordered him to cooperate with an investigation into the way sexual harassment charges against a fellow administrator were handled.

title: Its the Truth, but Not the Whole Truth
description: AN Ohio judge will decide on Friday whether to approve the settlement of a class-action suit against Carfax in which consumers could receive coupons worth about $20 and the lawyers representing them $566,000.

title: Make Cupcakes, Not War
description: A limited-edition T-shirt from Johnny Cupcakes is one of the few things that cant be bought in Manhattan. Cupcakes (a k a John Earle) and his upcake-and-crossbones logo took Boston by storm last year when he and his dad outfitted a storefront on tony Newbury Street to look like a bakery, with antique refrigerators, baking racks, a hulking 1930s dough mixer and a cast-iron wood-burning oven from the 1890s. The T-shirts have a Magnolia Bakery-like following: In October, more than 500 aficionados lined up to buy Cupcakes $55 monster tees. People like what no one else has, Earle says. Thats why I number my shirts and dont repeat my designs. Earle has also cooked up day-of-the-week undies and skateboard decks, available at his store as well as online. Go to www.johnnycupcakes.com.

title: Juilliard Recasts the Role of Mentor
description: JAMES HOUGHTON first auditioned for John Houseman in 1986. A young San Franciscan, barely out of the Meadows School of the Arts at Southern Methodist University, he won a coveted spot in Mr. Housemans elite classical theater group, the Acting Company.

title: Dear Anne, Not Ready to Kill You Yet
description: You watch The Tudors for the history the way you read Playboy for the articles. So far, five weeks into this popular Showtime series about a young, buff and lusty Henry VIII, theres a lot more off-with-your-velvet-frock than off-with-your-head. But not  yet  between two of historys most famous lovers, Henry Tudor and Anne Boleyn. (Henry does seem to sleep with everyone else, with the possible exception of his wife, while Anne sleeps with no one, with the possible exception of her brother.)

title: Renting Out Your Vacation House
description: FOR many, a vacation house is a personal oasis that offers a snug refuge from the world and its worries. For others, a vacation home is basically a cash cow.

title: A Shore Menu Thats Long on Value
description: GEMTLICH is the word that springs to mind (my mind at least) on entering the White Peach Restaurant in Gaylordsville (northwest of New Milford, on the road to Kent). The exposed log ceiling, posts, wood floors and handful of tables all evoke the coziness and congeniality that the German word suggests.

title: Knives on the Streets
description: ON March 26, as students poured out the front doors of the High School for Arts and Business in Corona, Queens, one 16-year-old boy frantically headed in the other direction, trying to reach the safety of the school lobby.

title: Trunk Food
description: Watermelon Juice

title: The Week in Connecticut
description: Towns Seek Flood-Prevention Solutions

title: And Now, a Few Words in Defense of Nostalgia
description: A FEW days before the start of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in California last week, fans of the reunited  and legendarily unpredictable  British group Happy Mondays got an unhappy surprise. The band would be playing its first American concert in 15 years without one of its best-loved members. Mark Berry, better known as Bez, had been denied a visa and wouldnt be appearing.

title: What to Do When Rupert Calls?
description: I DONT regularly watch the Fox News Channel, but when I do, I hardly think it is fair and balanced. I confess to reading The New York Post, but more as a delicious treat than a trusted news source. When I lived in London, I picked up The Times of London on my way to work every morning, but felt that the once-august publication had moved a bit down-market.

title: Fat Chance
description: If you had to choose, would you rather be fat or blind? When a researcher asked that question of a group of formerly obese people, 89 percent said they would prefer to lose their sight than their hard-won slimness. When youre blind, people want to help you. No one wants to help you when youre fat, one explained. Ninety-one percent of the group also chose having a leg amputated over a return to obesity.

title: Detroit Closes In on Conference Finals
description: DETROIT, May 5 (AP)  Pavel Datsyuk and Henrik Zetterberg each had a goal and two assists for the Detroit Red Wings on Saturday in a 4-1 victory against the San Jose Sharks in Game 5 of their Western Conference semifinal series.

title: Self-Nonmedication
description: Seven years ago, not long after my father died, with my editing job lost, my finances frail, my 26-year marriage failing, a child in college and a mortgage to pay, my brain seemed to lose its way. Sometimes it could barely think at all. Sometimes it tortured a single thought for hours. And sometimes, in desperation and without aim, it released a barrage of anger upon itself.

title: Oops, It May Be Time to Rebalance That Portfolio
description: AS stock indexes flirt with previous highs  or forge ahead of them  many investors have no urgent need for celebration.

title: When Words Speak Louder Than Actions
description: AGAIN this week, the key task for Federal Reserve policy makers will be to decide what to say, not what to do. Few people expect the central bankers to nudge interest rates up or down, but the usual language in the statement that accompanies the rate decision could be due for some tweaking, one analyst predicts.

title: Winning Isnt Everything. Check the Periphery.
description: COLLABORATION can be a powerful driver of innovation when it is done thoughtfully. But thoughtfulness can be hard to achieve in a traditional corporate or academic setting, where getting the best of others  whether by winning a sale or an argument  tends to be rewarded.

title: Reinventing Middle Age
description: Quick, what does the following list suggest to you: Lamaze classes; baby showers; parenting skills; preschool anxiety all the way up to college; transitional phases; timeouts; chronic credit-card debt; the indiscriminate wearing of athletic garb; political correctness; anti-political correctness; midlife crises; couples therapy; divorce mediation; Botox; dermatological fillers; cosmetic surgery; the new-and-improved menopause; wearing sunglasses in winter even though youre not famous; comb-overs; an obsession with the daily lives of the celebrated and merely notorious; real estate as a means to an end; a debilitating reliance on takeout dinners; a preference for esoteric coffee beans; an aversion to butter; an uneasy feeling of identification with Bob Dylan; a denial of death; cilantro, cilantro, cilantro; framing every photograph youve ever taken; the belief that your dog/cat is you; an excessively personalized vision of retirement; older single mothers; grandfatherly second-time fathers; a fear that youve become your mother or father; a free-floating feeling of grievance that youve failed to make obscene amounts of money as a hedge-fund manager; a gut instinct that immortality might be just around the next technological bend. If you still havent figured out that Im talking about the so-called baby-boomer generation, you might consider the possibility that the reason you are having difficulty making out the fine print of any given subtext is because you need reading glasses.

title: Kelly Mason, Benjamin Unger
description: The Rev. Kelly Murphy Mason and Dr. Benjamin Daniel Unger were married last evening in the chapel at Union Theological Seminary in New York. The Rev. Catherine Torpey, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated, with Rabbi Ronald Broden taking part.

title: Lauren Bisordi, Don Lepore
description: Lauren Constance Bisordi and Anthony Donald Lepore III were married yesterday at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel OReilly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: From Great Lake Swimmers All the Way to Timberlake
description: THE Tel Aviv-born Keren Ann Zeidel is a singer-songwriter who infuses her spare, poetic lyrics with subtle, complex and sometimes lush compositions. Her self-titled Keren Ann (Metro Blue) comes out Tuesday, her third album to be released in the United States. Raised in Paris, Ms. Zeidel, 33, speaks Hebrew, French, English and Dutch. While on tour in Europe (she moves on to the United States beginning next month), Ms. Zeidel spoke late at night with Winter Miller by phone as her bus rolled along the French countryside toward Brest in Brittany. We wake up in a different town every day, sometimes in a different country, she said. Here is what shes listening to and why.

title: Not Boring or Blah Here, but Classics in a Cozy Spot
description: EVERY town should have a restaurant like Juliannas. This cozy eating spot, subtitled an American bistro, is a terrific addition to the northwest side of the county, where there is a paucity of fun, informal places serving thoughtfully prepared food. The co-owners  Michael Carrozza, the talented chef, and Derek Palmisano, who handles the front of the house  are from the area and certainly have hit upon what this remote residential neighborhood needed.

title: Losing Her Accent
description: In the introduction to Shakespeares Kitchen, Lore Segals charming novel disguised as a book of short stories, the author offers an apology for not writing a more conventional narrative. Describing a meeting with a film producer who tells her that in a good plot nothing happens that is not the result of what happened before or the cause of what happens next, she says, I like reading stories like that, but I dont write them because thats not how life happens to me or to the people I know. Its an illuminating point, but less about the book than about Segal herself.

title: Chief Justice to Retire. Whos Next?
description: TRENTON

title: A Nervous Case
description: 1. Symptoms

title: Net Worth
description: At sunset on a clear June evening, Andrea Fariello steered his small boat to a chosen location two miles from shore. By day Fariello  tall, with rough, sun-stained skin, an unkempt beard and a few blackened teeth from years of smoking  tends his bar along the main strip of Marina di Pisciotta, a sleepy village about 70 miles south of Italys Amalfi coast. At night he is one of Marina di Pisciottas anchovy fishermen. What sets him apart from the other anchovy fishermen along the Mediterranean coast is that he is among the few who still use the menaica, a net dating to the ancient Romans.

title: The D.J. Rocked, and TV Shook
description: ALTHOUGH it was never meant to be the stuff of conventional entertainment, too much rock n roll has become just that. Rock stars are featured in reality shows and tabloids; previously sacrosanct Led Zeppelin and Nirvana songs are plugged into commercials and soundtracks; American Idol has devoted an entire evening to cluelessly sung renditions of British Invasion hits. The refrain of a Pink Floyd classic, Welcome to the Machine, has never stung more.

title: Dine by Diagram
description: Recipics may be an answer to todays cacophony of culinary chatter. Influenced by the field of instructional design and airplane-emergency-card instructions, the Australian graphic designer Lauren Bugeja began to create recipes using virtually text-free pictograms for a student project at the University of Technology in Sydney. Recently, she teamed up with designers to develop a Web site for sharing recipes and creating recipics (www.coo.kz), which will launch this month. Bugeja says recipics will appeal to visual learners and could also be useful for translating recipes across languages. While steps such as duration, measurement and actions can be diagramed relatively easily, Bugeja acknowledges the occasional stumbling block: The ingredients are still a work in progress, she said. For example, its hard to explain the difference between flour, baking powder, anthrax and cocaine without words.

title: A Crime in the Graveyard, Motive Unfathomable
description: As robberies go, it was no jewel heist. The stolen items included a clown doll with a porcelain face, a stuffed bear won at a fair, three small containers filled with the ashes of pet dogs that had died, a ceramic angel and an album of letters from grateful students.

title: Fresh-From-the Sea Fish Emporium
description: In the two years since Joe DiMauro, the owner of Mount Kisco Seafood, moved his business up the street to its present location, this once vest-pocket seafood operation has evolved into an emporium. We quadrupled our space, and we now have enough parking, he said, with a hint of wistfulness for the old place mixed with pride in the new. In the back of the shop is a big sleek kitchen; in front are luxuriously long ice-filled cases displaying the freshest-tasting seafood in the area.

title: Doh! Theyre Still Tinkering With Homer
description: OBSESSIVE fans of The Simpsons  and really, is there any other kind?  may remember an early episode of the show in which the denizens of Springfield brace themselves for the debut of a movie starring the cartoon cat-and-mouse pair Itchy and Scratchy. As the films premiere draws closer, the hype surrounding it becomes unavoidable, promotions and merchandising spin out of control and rabid moviegoers gather outside theaters in lines that stretch beyond the horizon.

title: French Voters Pick Sarkozy to Be President; Turnout High
description: PARIS, May 6  Nicolas Sarkozy, an immigrants son who had the French presidency in his sights for three decades, won a decisive victory in the election on Sunday, keeping the right in power for the next five years.

title: Paranoids, Grab Your Raid Cans
description: IN William Friedkins new film, Bug, paranoia is an infection that spreads from one character to another and eventually in the general direction of the viewer. A lurid psychological thriller with an acute case of the jitters and a nasty sense of humor, it does not exactly seem like the work of a mellowed old-timer, let alone that of a Hollywood veteran who made his most popular films when Richard M. Nixon was president.

title: A Crystal Ball Would Have Been Nice
description: IF they could have predicted the future, Julie and Neil Weintraub would have bought a one-bedroom co-op, not a two-bedroom, for their first home.

An article on April 22 about a DVD of the first season of the television series Maude misstated the date a two-part episode about abortion was broadcast. It was a few months before the Supreme Courts decision in Roe v. Wade in January 1973, not after.

title: Village People
description: RECENTLY, after decades of stalling, my sisters and I divided up our grandfathers diaries, 43 boxes chronicling in alarming detail a life that started on a Kansas farm in 1893, made a 12-box detour to Ohio and ended in 1988, at age 95, in his beloved Manhattan.

title: Torn From Parents, a Top Speller Vents His Anger, Letter by Letter
description: GREEN RIVER, Utah  Great spellers come in all types, from egotistical showoffs to loners who find sanctuary in the forest of words.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Call it plane travel, unplugged. Pared-down flights at super-cheap rates, which have been all the rage in Europe for years, will show up in the United States when Skybus Airlines (www.skybus.com) starts domestic operations on May 22. For budget-minded passengers, the compromise seems minimal; reservations must be made through the Web site (no customer relations phone number exists) and there are extra fees for services that are usually part of the fare  like bag check ($5 each for two bags, $50 for additional ones), soft drinks and seating requests. But the flights are cheap. Really cheap. One-way fares start for as little as $10, with a top one-way walk-up fare of $330 (all flights must connect in Columbus, Ohio). Skybus is not serving the New York area, but is flying to nine other cities, including Richmond; Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; Greensboro, N.C.; San Francisco; and Seattle. ... Tourists who want a break from the slot machines now have the option of bowling in Las Vegas 24 hours a day. Last month, Red Rock Casino, Resort and Spa, about 10 miles off the Strip (www.redrocklasvegas.com), opened a 72-lane bowling center (below). The center has a pro shop, an arcade, meeting rooms, a deli, a lounge and bar, dart boards, billiard tables, a shuffleboard table, plasma televisions and, surprise, slot and video poker games. There is also a 12-lane, nightclub-like V.I.P. suite, which can be subdivided into four or eight lanes for private parties. Three-hour V.I.P. rates range from $1,500 to $4,500; catered food and bottle service are available. Regular rates start at $3 per adult per game. ... All Holiday Inn hotels  nearly 1,000  will begin serving Rainforest Alliance certified coffee to guests by June. At least 30 percent of the beans used to make the coffee will be grown on farms that have met strict environmental and social standards on issues like worker protection and biodiversity conservation (www.rainforest-alliance.org).

title: The Empire Skate: New York Producing Players
description: There is something unusual about several of the key players in this springs big hockey tournaments: they come from New York State.

title: Immigration, Legal and Illegal; Theres More to Life Than the Ivy League (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Week Ahead: May 6 - 12
description: THEATER

title: The World Is Changing, and With It, This Corner
description: I AM moving. It is not the kind of move where you have to pack a single box, which is fortunate, because I have been known to disintegrate into a puddle when it comes to actual relocation. This particular move is from one section of this newspaper to another.

title: Now Pouring | Rhum Agricole
description: Lately, the most interesting rum to surface in the States is from the French island of Martinique. Unlike most rum, which is made from molasses, Martiniques rhum agricole is made exclusively from fresh sugar-cane juice. In addition to the sugary aroma, a tinge of herbal, floral or vegetal flavors evoke the islands rain forest. Depaz, Rhum Clment, Rhum JM, Neisson and La Favorite are labels offering clear, unaged rhum blanc and amber, wood-aged rhum vieux. Dont bother using rhum agricole in your mojito, though; it doesnt work. Try a Ti Punch (short for petit) instead.

title: Perfect Party Mix
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: A Parish Rallies and, After Many Delays, a Church Is Built
description: IN a happy ending to a torturous tale, Long Islands newest Roman Catholic church, St. Therese of Lisieux in Montauk, has thrown open its doors after a construction project that would have tried the patience of, well, saints.

title: When Picasso Went Down to Georgia
description: THE birth of Cubism may not seem like standard fodder for a graphic novel. But the painting breakthrough is at the heart of The Salon, by Nick Bertozzi, which quickly moves from art history to murder mystery with the help of a magical blue absinthe. Along for the ride are early-20th-century Modernist heavies like Braque, Picasso and Satie. And just as those artists provoked controversy in their day, the graphic novel has led to a skirmish about its depiction of nudity.

title: Matchmakers Know Superstars Need Love, Too
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Pocahontas II
description: Americans have been very, very bad. Gluttonous, warmongering, nonenvironmentally conscious bad. In Matthew Sharpes strange and strained Jamestown, set in the post-apocalyptic future, everything is ruined, even the country, even the people. Brooklyn and Manhattan are fighting each other; the Indians have, inexplicably, retaken the South. The East River is goopy (or goopier). The Chrysler Building is rubble. Hares stalk the dead landscape biting off the heads of rodents. If Sharpes book had come out in the 90s, Kevin Costner would be looking to direct.

title: Johnson Is and Isnt Where He Wants to Be
description: PHOENIX, May 5  For those Yankees fans feeling disconnected from their favorite (or least favorite) 6-foot-10 scowling left-hander, they could have done the unthinkable and tuned in to the Mets game against the Diamondbacks on Friday night.

title: A Young Man With an Eye, and Friends Up a Tree
description: IN the beginning Ryan McGinley was known for pictures of his young downtown Manhattan friends. By day he photographed them running, skateboarding, moving, always in motion. By night they were partying, having sex, taking drugs, living fast.

title: France Heads to the Polls After a Scorching Finale
description: PARIS, May 5  She apocalyptically predicted that France would blow up if he were elected. He dismissively scoffed that she was too moody to run the country.

title: The Many Perils of Unqualified Hypocrisy
description: In Michael Vicks version of HBOs Entourage, he is scolded for the actions of a posse that runs an alleged dog-fighting ring out of a mansion he owns but supposedly never visits.

title: Breaking Through
description: Alicja Bachleda-Curus

title: Devils Score First, but Ottawa Wont Let Series Last
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 5  The Devils closed their 25-year run at Continental Arena on Saturday night, but most of the sellout crowd that showed up early and had been in such a boisterous mood was unwilling to stick it out to the very end.

title: The Young and the Restless
description: When did teenage angst and arrogance begin? Many baby boomers, still fighting over the legacy of the 1960s as they lurch toward retirement, think of themselves as products of the rock n roll rebellion that shattered the bourgeois proprieties of the 1950s. Chronicled in song and witnessed by the new electronic media, the impudent saga of the 60s counterculture seemed unique.

title: Have vs. Have-Not, in Jail (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: College Rival Welcomes Another Shot at Woods
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 5  On the soggy grounds of the Quail Hollow Club, where pine needles gathered in bunches and fans did likewise, a cluster of golfers spent a gray Saturday afternoon stirring up shouts and knocking down flagsticks.

title: Patricia Gross, Gavin Franklin
description: Patricia Jane Gross and Gavin Richard Franklin are to be married today on the Brooklyn Bridge by Shivaun Manley, a friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event.

title: Rupert Murdoch, Once the Outsider
description: WASHINGTON

title: Transit Chiefs To-Do List: No. 1, New Hudson Tunnel
description: NEWARK

title: The Week in Westchester
description: 2nd Missed Name to Be Added to 9/11 Memorial

title: Mr. Bad Example
description: I got to be Jim Morrison a lot longer than he did, the wild-man Southern California singer-songwriter Warren Zevon liked to brag in his abbreviated later years. So we learn from Carl Hiaasens foreword to this effusive, seamy  effusively seamy?  oral biography assembled by Zevons ex. Short on perspective it may be, but  Ill Sleep When Im Dead  definitely piles up enough horrendous behavior to back the titles claim.

title: Going Where Toyotas Never Gone Before
description: LAST year, when Nathalie Guiraudet heard that Toyota was making the next-generation Tundra much bigger, she began to fret about her vehicular future.

title: Final Thoughts About My Tenure and The Timess Future
description: AS I conclude my tour of duty as the second public editor of The New York Times, here are some final thoughts and concerns about the paper and its journalism that flow from what Ive observed over the past two years from my perch outside the newsroom.

title: Victoria-Rong Shi and Christopher Kennedy
description: Victoria-Rong Shi and Christopher J. Kennedy were married last evening in New York. The Rev. Kevin D. Bean, an Episcopal priest and the vicar of St. Bartholomews Church, performed the ceremony there.

title: A Cooks Companions
description: There are, in my experience, two kinds of cooks: those knowledgeable enough to make it up as they go along, and those who wouldnt dream of setting out without a road map. Sadly, I am among the latter. Its no coincidence that I like to bake: I find precision reassuring. Just give me instructions, and Ill carry them out, to the letter.

title: 200 Teas? Thats De-Lovely
description: Ours may be a coffee-drinking society, as Robert Scott, owner of the Montclair teahouse Cha-Ma-Gu-Dao, readily concedes. But that doesnt mean the typical coffeehouse, all that foam and caffeine notwithstanding, can come close to serving up the sensuous, multitiered and occasionally mind-expanding experience a thoughtfully appointed tea spot can.

title: The Year of the Large Caps? This Time, Dont Laugh
description: LONG-SUFFERING blue-chip stocks are finally back.

title: Shortchanging Judges
description: A $141,000 salary seems generous, but for judges in New Jersey it is unrealistically low. Unless the Legislature acts soon to raise it substantially, the states judiciary, which legal scholars have long rated as one of the nations best, will decline in stature as fewer and fewer top lawyers will be interested in serving.

title: Changes to Cheer About. Really.
description: IF you ask most people what comes to mind when they hear the word Rahway, the first answer is likely to be the state prison. A second response might have something to do with Rahways role as a major stop on the New Jersey Transit lines leading into New York City.

title: Following Matsuzaka on the Emerald Isle
description: The legend of Daisuke Matsuzaka was born in Japan and is taking shape in the United States now that he is pitching for the Boston Red Sox. Matsuzakas tale has even trickled to at least one spot in Ireland, a country that did not have a legitimate baseball field until 1998.

title: Thats Amari
description: If youve ever entered a caff bar in Italy, you cant help but notice all the splashy, unfamiliar bottles with labels as luridly colorful as old Cinecitt movie posters. Five years ago you were hard-pressed to find any of these amari in America, but bars and restaurants are waking up to the bitter reality.

title: The Case of the Dwindling Dunes
description: SEA GATE, the gated community on the western tip of the Coney Island peninsula, is shielded from the rest of Brooklyn by a guardhouse and a long fence along West 37th Street. But in recent years, the neighborhood has been under siege along its exposed southern flank  from the sea itself.

title: Learning the Language of the Drum
description: RIVERHEAD

title: A Family Torn Apart by Deportation (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Chicken Coops to Give Way to Animal Refuge
description: ASHFORD

title: Taste Maker
description: Innovative design and delicious food meet at Proef, Marije Vogelzangs design studios/restaurants in Amsterdam and Rotterdam. Weekend visitors can participate in her oddball creations, such as salads whose ingredients were grown in the dark. Vogelzang became interested in food as a material while studying industrial design. She now creates food concepts for events for clients ranging from Herms to Nike. (For a Dutch lingerie launch, she placed beribboned hors doeuvres on swaying rods to mimic a swarm of butterflies.)

title: The Gipper as Diarist
description: Anyone hungering for historical disclosure and nuance in Ronald Reagans presidential diaries will have to settle for a prosaic and amiably unrevealing drone in the daily ruminations of the private Reagan. Theres a wisp of tidy news headline reader that summons Reagan the heartland radio announcer. And a tone of thats-the-way-life-goes utterances worthy of the Our Town stage manager, whom the actor Reagan could intuitively play. A haircut & then over to the Soviet embassy to sign the grief book, the Great Communicator notes of the passing of Konstantin Chernenko as Kremlin ruler.

title: Not All Donations Are Created Equal
description: Those seeking a lesson in how to shake people up for money may want to take a page from the playbook of Hilary M. Weston, who has led fund-raising efforts for the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto.

An article last Sunday about the film actress and director Sarah Polley referred incorrectly to the setting of Avonlea, the Canadian television series in which she starred. It was set on Prince Edward Island, not the prairie.

title: Planning, and Policing, Prom Night
description: THIS spring, there will be about 65 proms in Westchester, and there is a flurry of planning all over the county. First, there is the matter of securing a date, which can be filled with as much drama and tension as any episode of 24. Then there are the dress shopping and tuxedo fittings, hair and manicure appointments, limousine rentals and plans for the after-prom, the celebration after the dance that can last anywhere from a few hours to a long weekend.

title: Forget Wholl Win in France. Change Is a Loser.
description: PARIS

title: In Search of the Real Flamenco
description: STEPPING into the almost hidden doorway of the flamenco bar La Sole in Madrid, one enters a smoky L-shaped room, its walls adorned with blue and white tiles. Well after midnight on a recent Thursday the place was packed with Gypsies and Madrileos, all in thrall to the rhythmic, heartfelt music produced by a Gypsy guitarist and a singer, both dressed in black pants and white shirts. Soon, they were joined by a woman with flowing black hair. Luckily for the customers, she was a master of cante jondo, or deep song, and for the next hour, her voice rose and fell, as she sung a tale of lost love  a favorite flamenco theme.

title: Long Islands Land Rush
description: On Course for Failure is the unpleasantly blunt title of a report by the Long Island Pine Barrens Society about what it calls the unacceptably slow pace of open-space preservation in these parts. The organization argues that at the rate were going, when the final buildout of Long Island occurs  the day in 2015 when there is no land left to develop or preserve  we will be left with far too many malls and McMansions and much too little farmland and open space, and no chance ever again to correct the imbalance.

title: The (Not So) Eagerly Modern Saudi
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia

title: An Ancient Coda to My 21st-Century Divorce
description: I WAS finally getting married. Thats what I kept telling people. I didnt say I was finally getting married again, because bringing up a first marriage during the planning of a second is a major buzz kill for everyone involved.

title: Gin Joint
description: Todays typical Chicago saloon has Old Style in the can, the Cubs on the tube and video poker in the corner. Weegees Lounge, in the Logan Square neighborhood, has none of these. We like to think of ourselves as the kind of bar you would have found in Chicago in the 40s, says Alex Huebner, who, with his wife, Lynne Marrs, opened Weegees last June. This means jazz on the stereo and a cocktail repertory featuring classics like the Pink Squirrel, the grasshopper and the Knickerbocker. Huebner licensed the fabled crime-scene shutterbugs name thinking that Weegee would have found the still-gritty area stimulating. No doubt. 3659 W. Armitage Ave.; (773) 384-0707.

title: First World, Third World (Maybe Not in That Order)
description: WOULD you risk part of your childrens college fund or your retirement in third-world equities? You may already have.

title: Lela and Deedie Rose | Designer and Philanthropist
description: Mother Deedie supports the Dallas Museum of Art and the Dallas Center for the Performing Arts with her glittering benefits; her designing daughter, Lela, dresses many of the high-profile guests, as well as her own coterie of followers in Manhattan, where she lives.

title: Giuliani, Speaking at the Citadel, Calls for a Bigger Army
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., May 5  Rudolph W. Giuliani called on Saturday for a large-scale increase in the overall troop strength of the Army and the creation of a special force to specifically handle post-combat operations.

title: Protecting Against the Dread What If?
description: AS summer approaches and travelers plunk down nonrefundable deposits to secure their vacation plans, many will inevitably be pressed  or at least invited  to purchase travel insurance. But is it really worth it? Some travelers dont think so, having taken trip after trip without any problems, or, because of some exclusion, found out they werent covered when they thought they were. Others have been relieved to be reimbursed for their lost airfare and hotel fees when illness or some other misfortune unexpectedly kept them home.

title: Up Front
description: Is everything good bad for you? Probably not. In the extreme, maybe. Yet bad things can form the basis of some interesting  and amusing  books.

title: Is Condi Hiding the Smoking Gun?
description: IF, as J.F.K. had it, victory has a hundred fathers and defeat is an orphan, the defeat in Iraq is the most pitiful orphan imaginable. Its parents have not only tossed it to the wolves but are also trying to pin its mutant DNA on any patsy they can find.

title: Gay Art: A Movement, or at Least a Moment
description: MAYBE it doesnt signal the arrival of a major arts movement and maybe it is just a symptom of another consumer-driven microtrend, but it would seem that something is afoot in the contemporary art world and it concerns what you could call, for lack of more comprehensive terminology, a burgeoning of gay male art.

title: Republicans Add Their Two Cents
description: State budgets are cobbled together not only by people who can count to 10 but also by those who can factor in political gains and losses. There has been plenty of political adding and subtracting in the General Assembly, especially by the minority Republicans. They proposed a budget of their own late last month  and in so doing effectively abandoned their Republican leader, Gov. M. Jodi Rell.

title: His Friends: A Whos Who. Him: Just ...Who?
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Making the Yonkers-Manhattan Commute by Water
description: Yonkers

title: A Bowling Ball With Snap (and Scent)
description: A MYRIAD of odors permeates American bowling alleys: nacho cheese, stale beer and the mineral oil that coats the lanes. The delicate scent of orange ginger, however, is not one typically associated with the pursuit of spares and strikes.

title: Molto Mochi
description: Its been eaten by Japanese noblemen for centuries; it contains phytins, which are thought to prevent cancer; and its said to be impervious to the Heimlich maneuver.

title: After a Long Journey, a Jets Safety and His Mother Are in a Better Place
description: On the second day of the N.F.L. draft last week, Erik Coleman and his mother, Cynthia Bracey-Coleman, sat side by side on the sofa in his apartment in Westbury, N.Y., counting their blessings as they did on the same Sunday three years earlier after Coleman was drafted in the fifth round by the Jets.

description: THIMPHU, Bhutan  Explore the World, promised the signboard outside.
