description: Tarrytown

title: You Do the Math
description: Do birthday parties held in restaurants give you a palm-dampening, heart-palpitating anxiety attack? Youre not alone.

title: An Extra Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Street Sense Wins Derby Despite Fields Head Start
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5  Calvin Borel had Street Sense in 19th place and about a half a block behind the leaders as the field hit the backstretch in the 133rd running of the Kentucky Derby. Was he worried? Hardly. He had the agile colt next to his beloved rail, and they dont call the jockey Bo-Rail here at Churchill Downs for nothing.

title: Once-Feared Serbian Hard-Liners Fade Into Shadows
description: KRUSEVAC, Serbia, May 5  Hard-line nationalists gathered Saturday in this city with a plan to save Kosovo as a part of Serbia. But they were a shadow of the paramilitary groups that had caused untold trouble in the 1990s.

title: Eastward Ho
description: After eight decades of false starts, the Second Avenue subway line may finally become a reality, but it will be years before the line runs through the East Village. In the meantime, these restaurants will attract diners arriving by cab, car, bus and, of course, foot.

title: The Talk
description: salumi / n. / the generic Italian term for salt-cured pork and beef products, such as salame, prosciutto, coppa, lardo and bresaola, e.g., People used to make fun of Marios lardo pizza, but now every Italian restaurant has a $20 platter of salumi from Fra Mani; the name of the Seattle restaurant run by the salumi-making side of the Batali family.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Music and Dance

title: What to Do About Wanderlust
description: Q. You are comfortably settled in a career, and making good money. But you dont feel fulfilled, and you think you may want to move to a completely different field. Should you even consider such a change?

title: Businesses Try to Make Money and Save the World
description: ALTRUSHARE SECURITIES is a brokerage firm, engaged in the sort of things you might expect of a Wall Street outfit, like buying and selling stock, and providing research on companies. Unlike its peers, however, the firm is majority-owned by two charities that each control about one-third of it.

title: Hot Links
description: Americans have been high on the hog lately. Thanks to the reintroduction of heritage breeds, humble pork cuts like belly, neck and Boston butt have gained entree status at restaurants of every caliber, and bacon is suddenly suitable as a gift. If you want to outclass your competitive eating friends this summer, may we suggest bringing homemade sausage to the table?

title: 36 Hours in Istanbul
description: THE Turks have changed tactics. For centuries, the sultans of Istanbul sent forth their armies, seizing territories across Europe, the Middle East and North Africa. This time, it's a style offensive. And the spoils of the conquests are everywhere. Downbeat neighborhoods have re-emerged as artist and night life enclaves. Medieval Ottoman motifs are winding up on T-shirts and design products. Plain kebabs are getting epicurean makeovers, and Old World hammams are being converted into jet-setters' spas. With architecture from the Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman periods as a backdrop, Istanbul is now the rare place where readers of Archeology and Wallpaper magazines can clink glasses with equal zeal.

title: Vogue Plays Fairy Godmother
description: A WEEK before the Costume Institute party at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the actress Elizabeth Banks, needing a gown for the event, arrived at the offices of Vogue. Editors had assembled a rack of eight dresses, and Ms. Banks tried each one on, had it pinned around her slender frame and posed for a Polaroid camera.

title: June
description: JUNE

title: Stress on Troops Adds to U.S. Hurdles in Iraq
description: The detailed mental health survey of troops in Iraq released by the Pentagon on Friday highlights a growing worry for the United States as it struggles to bring order to Baghdad: the high level of combat stress suffered during lengthy and repeated tours.

title: Rome: Bassetti Tessuti
description: Bassetti Tessuti is more than Rome's largest fabric store. It's a secret world in a nondescript palazzo that is the textile superstore for many of Italy's top designers, dressmakers and debonair businessmen alike.

title: When Carbon Is Currency
description: AMID steadily increasing carbon emissions, and a federal government hesitant to take the lead on climate legislation, 10 states have joined to create the first mandatory carbon cap-and-trade program in the United States. They aim to reduce emissions from power plants by 10 percent in 10 years.

title: Bad Behavior Within Reason
description: The novel in stories is the Rube Goldberg contraption of the literary world, fiction that works in wondrous and roundabout ways. While the short story pauses to explore an illuminated moment, and the novel chugs toward a grand conclusion, the novel in stories moves in spirals and loops, a corkscrewing joy ride. Read the chapters in any order, and the overall narrative experience often remains virtually the same. For this reason alone, the novel in stories may be the most tuned-in form of contemporary storytelling. Nothing is lost in setting ones reading on shuffle.

title: Why the Movies Keep Digging Into TVs Bottomless Dustbin
description: SAMUEL JOHNSON notoriously compared a woman preaching to a dog walking on its hind legs. It is not done well, he mused, but you are surprised to see it done at all. Johnsons view of animal behavior may be as dated as his ideas about women. At least in movies, the spectacle of a dog walking, talking, dancing and flying does not seem especially surprising.

title: Hyatt Promises Homey Feeling in New Chain
description: The Global Hyatt Corporation is hoping the word Andaz will soon be a brand name as well known to consumers as, say, Hyatt. Meaning personal style in Hindi, the name is being given to the renovated Great Eastern Hotel in Londons financial district. This first Andaz is to open this fall and be followed in late 2008 by a second Andaz in New York at 75 Wall Street and a third, the following year, on Fifth Avenue across from the New York Public Library.

title: Correction: Adventures in Low-Cost Travel
description: An article April 22 about budget airlines in Europe misstated the number of airports in the London area. There are five (Heathrow, Gatwick, Luton, Stansted and London City), not four.

title: Helena Yu and Anthony Yu
description: Helena Alexandra Yu, the daughter of Choon E. Yu and Dr. Young J. Yu of Lewiston, N.Y., was married yesterday to Anthony Francis Yu, a son of Carmen Yu and Dr. Guan-Hiok Yu of Dix Hills, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Rex T. Stewart, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Youngstown, N.Y.

title: The Heel Is Rising
description: WE were bound for a farmhouse, and I had my doubts.

title: Life Comes Full Circle While Driving on an Oval
description: RICHMOND, Va., May 5  Strands of gray have crept into Jeff Gordons stylish sideburns, betraying the youthful, metrosexual image that has helped sell watches, cologne, clothing, food, drink and Nascar to the masses.

title: A Secret Garden of Golf (Mind the Jungle)
description: FIVE years ago, after a hiatus of nearly three decades, I began swinging the driver again in Indonesia.

title: Student at Risk? He Can Help. Hes Been There.
description: New Haven

title: The Faith of Obama (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Hail to the Analysand
description: WHEN a pretension to free the world from evil ends only in a new proof of the danger of a fanatic to the commonweal, then it is not to be marveled at that a distrust is aroused in the observer which makes sympathy impossible.

title: With Move Into 2nd Round, Nets Leave Struggles Behind
description: By the time Richard Jefferson secured the Nets a spot in the Eastern Conference semifinals late Friday night, the perils of a rocky regular season seemed to be but a scuff on their shoes.

title: Halfway Humanity
description: In your discussion of the term age-appropriate, writes Prof. Erik Smith of Concordia University, Montreal, you identified Harrison Ford as middle-aged. Mr. Ford is 64. If he were literally middle-aged, then he could expect to live to 128. By describing themselves as middle-aged, are not those in their 60s and even 70s guilty of some rather overoptimistic math?

title: Austro Turf
description: Burgenland unfurls like a long ribbon through eastern Austria, nudging up against Hungary, Slovenia and Slovakia. Here the Alps loom farther in the background; the land is somewhat flat, a patchwork of sunflower fields, farmsteads and small, scraggy-looking vineyards perched on hills. Until 1989, when the Iron Curtain came down, a high chain-link fence crisscrossed the border between Burgenland and Hungary. No one wanted to come here, explained Gerhard Kracher, a third-generation vintner whose family has been producing prestigious wines here for decades. It was the end of the world, but there was great weather and world-class sweet wines.

title: The Short Supply of Competitive Balance
description: Last Thursday the Golden State Warriors eliminated the Dallas Mavericks. That was a shock, since it was the first time since the N.B.A. went to a best-of-seven format in the first round of the playoffs that the lowest- seeded team in a conference defeated the top seed.

title: Now Mowing | No-Impact Sheep
description: Don Watson raises some of the best milk-fed lambs on the planet. The ones that dont make it to Chez Panisse are rented out as lawn mowers in Northern California. Watson says his Wooly Weeders can digest noxious plants and manage steep hillsides and tightly spaced vineyards while leaving behind rich fertilizer. Vintners, like the Mondavi family, have hired them to snack on leaves that drain nutrients from grapes. Others use them to prevent brush fires. Guarantees Watson, Five hundred sheep will turn 10 grassy acres into a golf course, overnight.

title: F.A.A. Downgrades Indonesian Air System
description: Anyone jetting off to Jakarta, Bali or the other islands of Indonesia, take note: On April 16, the United States Federal Aviation Administration announced that it had changed Indonesias air safety oversight category from a 1 to a 2, because of serious concerns over safety.

title: The Week on Long Island
description: Dwindling Funds Jeopardize Immigrant Center

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture on the cover of Arts & Leisure today of the dancer Aesha Ash, with an article about the small number of black ballerinas in classical troupes, appeared in mirror image. (Go to Article)

title: Worshiping at the Altar of Pay-Per-View
description: LAS VEGAS

title: Increased State Aid or Not, Districts Seek Higher Taxes
description: IN spite of record increases in state aid for next school year, most districts in Westchester and other New York City suburbs have proposed property tax increases well above the rate of inflation. District officials say they are handcuffed by big annual increases in teachers salaries and the rising cost of pensions, health insurance and energy.

title: Correction: DJ AM: His Life, Times, Shoes		fashion
description: An article last Sunday about DJ AM, a leading party D.J., misspelled the surname of the editor of Us Weekly, which chronicled his relationship with Nicole Richie. She is Janice Min, not Minn.

title: Laura Lyons, Gregory Karrh
description: Laura Anne Lyons, a daughter of Eleanor Fitzgerald Lyons and Joseph L. Lyons of Okatie, S.C., was married on Friday to Gregory French Karrh, a son of Paula French Karrh and J. Randolph C. Karrh Sr. of Swainsboro, Ga. Msgr. Michael J. Dempsey, a cousin of the bride, officiated at St. Andrews Roman Catholic Church in Bluffton, S.C.

title: Samantha Miller, David Noever
description: Samantha Elizabeth Miller and David Anthony Noever were married on Friday at St. Mary of the Visitation Church in Huntsville, Ala. The Rev. Glen Sayers, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony with Robert Tracy, a Roman Catholic deacon and an uncle of the bride, participating.

title: At Religious Preschools, Worries About Others Looking Over Their Shoulders
description: The citys health code spells out hundreds of regulations governing preschools and day care centers, ranging from the urgent (rooftop play areas must be fenced; teachers must get inoculations and pass background checks) to the comparatively minor (one toilet per 15 children, and 30 square feet of space per child; no television for children under 2; no whole milk for children over 2).

title: Correction: The Amis Inheritance
description: An article on April 22 about the writers Kingsley and Martin Amis omitted a word in a quotation from Kingsleys biographer, Zachary Leader. He referred to Kingsley as the finest British comic novelist of the second half of the 20th century, not the finest comic novelist.

title: Tobacco Road
description: It is a familiar exchange: I step up to the counter at a convenience store and order my daily ration of Camel cigarettes, which I have been smoking since the Reagan administration and, as it happens, am smoking as I type this. Sliding the pack across the counter, the clerk  female clerks, typically; male clerks are more laissez-faire  sighs and says to me, You know you need to quit. My response, well honed over the years, goes like this: I know I should quit, I say, but theres one problem. I enjoy it. On rare occasions, the clerk startles and smiles  thats how it played out this morning  as if tickled by this forbidden admission. Far more frequently, however, I find myself at the receiving end of a uniformly bemused, pitying and faintly disgusted stare. I cannot possibly mean what I have just uttered, the stare says to me. The victim cannot confess to the crime. The cash register rings its tinny ring as the clerk slides the drawer shut and sadly wags her head.

title: Keypad Economics: Why Talk When You Can Type?
description: Talking is starting to seem so old school to many cellphone users.

title: Wizards in the Studio, Anonymous on the Street
description: THE songwriting session was so fresh that the aroma of the evenings chicken wings still lingered. Behind the vast mixing board of a dimly lighted Manhattan recording studio, two producers and their co-writer greeted a record executive who had come to hear their work. With the press of a button, the room filled with sound: somber guitar arpeggios over a slow, sleek hip-hop beat, with layers of falsetto harmonies leading to a big, glittery, instantly memorable chorus. It was pure candy  sweetly melodic, but just funky enough to have a dance groove.

title: Suicide Attacks and Gunfight in Afghanistan Kill 10 Police Officers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 5  A wave of suicide attacks in four provinces of Afghanistan on Saturday killed two police officers and wounded a NATO soldier and two other Afghan policemen, and eight other Afghan police officers were killed in a gun battle with the Taliban, officials said.

title: The Silver Lining to Impending Doom
description: ACROSS the world, doomsayers are smiling. The mounting signs of climate change have forced onto center stage the challenges of reducing carbon emissions and quickly adapting human activities to thrive in higher temperatures and more unpredictable weather.

title: Sex Changes
description: My wife of 30 years and I are in our 60s. A few years ago she asked that we no longer engage in sex. Its not such a big deal anymore, she said. She would not see a doctor or consider other help. I began an affair with a widow. Recently my wife found out and went ballistic. If she can casually renounce sex, cant I seek it elsewhere?  name withheld, Massachusetts

title: Trying to Discourage Draws That Please Players, Not Fans
description: Imagine going to a big tennis match and watching the players hit a few balls, shake hands and split the prize money. Of course, this is impossible in tennis, but something like this has gone on in chess for decades.

title: Playing Survivor in Washington
description: Washington

title: One Plate the Ceramist Doesnt Throw
description: YOU would think that ceramists like Adam Silverman would be grateful to Jonathan Adler for bridging the earnestness of pottery and the glibness of postmodern fashion. Mr. Adlers peppy aesthetic revived interest in what had become an almost embarrassingly sincere form of craft.

title: Ah, the Days of Spectacle and Bad Taste
description: IF there was any doubt that songs and sketches from classic Broadway revues could be reintroduced to the stage almost a century later, the director Jerry Zaks may have been feeling it.

title: New Hawaii Ferry Is Set for July
description: Island hopping, at least from Oahu to Kauai and Maui, will be easier starting in July, when the Hawaii Superferry catamaran begins daily service from Honolulu. After six years of planning and more than a few battles with environmentalists, the ferry (below) has been cleared to operate between the three islands, which are now linked only by commercial airliner service.

title: Joining the Crowd
description: Joining the Crowd

title: The Details Are in the Beauty
description: To a certain extent, the abstract style known as Color Field painting is a one-shot deal: what you see is what you get. Natvar Bhavsar, an Indian-born artist who has lived in New York since the 1960s, is trying to do something else with this fairly straightforward genre, as a stimulating retrospective of his work at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum in New Brunswick seeks to show.

title: New Aging Medicine
description: Heres a sampling of innovations being developed by medical researchers to combat conditions and diseases associated with aging. Some are close to becoming reality; others are farther out on the horizon.  JOHN GLASSIE

title: Lauren Oelkers, Hayden Baker
description: Lauren Beth Oelkers and Hayden Sheffield Baker were married last evening at St. Ann Roman Catholic Church in Naples, Fla. The Rev. Elias Lorenzo performed the ceremony.

title: Focused Pistons Start to Look Like Champions Again
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., May 5  The Detroit Pistons had been at home for a full week, having swept the Orlando Magic so quickly it seemed as if the first round had never happened.

title: Julianne Reynolds, Gordon Anderson
description: Julianne Reynolds, the daughter of Bonnie F. Reynolds of Baltimore and Michael F. Reynolds III of Bangkok, was married yesterday to Gordon T. Anderson, a son of Elizabeth T. Anderson and Leonard Anderson of Dalton, Mass. The Rev. C. J. Waitekus, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Ann Church in Lenox, Mass.

title: Wheels of Good Fortune
description: New Paltz, N.Y.

title: Flavoring-Factory Illnesses Raise Inquiries
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 5  The workers, by and large, have been young and healthy. None were smokers, and none had any history of lung disease. But after working at plants that produce food flavorings, they all had one thing in common: they could not breathe.

title: Alexandra Braunstein, Brendan OConnor
description: Alexandra Lara Braunstein, a daughter of Joan Braunstein and Dr. Robert Alan Braunstein of New Vernon, N.J., was married last evening to Brendan OConnor, a son of Joan OConnor and Kevin OConnor of Colorado Springs. Rabbi Joseph H. Gelberman officiated at the Harold Pratt House in New York.

title: Turkish Candidate With Islamic Base Withdraws
description: ISTANBUL, May 6  A Turkish presidential candidate with a background in Islamic politics withdrew his candidacy today, ending a weeks-long struggle over the position that has sharply divided Turkish society and reshaped the political landscape.

title: Sarah Lucey, David Biester
description: Sarah Linn Lucey, a daughter of Suzanne L. and Gordon M. Lucey of Wilton, Conn., was married there yesterday to David Robertson Biester, a son of Elizabeth L. and Edward G. Biester Jr. of Furlong, Pa. The Rev. Brigitta S. Remole, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Wilton Congregational Church.

title: Old Friends? New Foes? Your Choice
description: All dates are subject to change.

title: Family Community Loses a Black Sheep Member
description: REXBURG, Idaho

title: Now Registering | Wine Is Thicker Than Porcelain
description: For the New York investment banker Said Armutcuoglu, wedding gifts dont get much better than the case of wines he got from Premier Cru. We didnt need another bowl, he acknowledged. Although the bowls arrived anyway, the starter cellar that Armutcuoglu received ranged from Mouton to the rare Quintarelli amarone. Of course, not everyone has such generous friends, but that doesnt affect the growing trend of registering for wine. People want to be different, said Carley Roney, the editor in chief and co-founder of the bridal magazine The Knot Weddings. Theyre getting married later and already have the espresso machine. The process often starts with a consultation. Nicole Serle, in charge of wedding registries at Vino in New York, advises requesting an assortment of everyday bottles as well as wines that will appreciate in 5-, 10- and 15-year increments (proper storage is key). Stores like Kermit Lynch in Berkeley, Calif., and Sherry-Lehmann in New York are preparing for summer-wedding requests.

title: Busted at the Regal
description: The mission was a botch. We debriefed over Chinese. Cherkis speared a piece of vegetarian black-pepper chicken and jabbed it in my direction.

title: Spunky Nancy Drew Faces Her Hardest Case: Hollywood
description: ASK a healthy sampling of American women under 100 about Nancy Drew and chances are they will remember three things: the girl detectives titian hair, her chums Bess and George and her blue roadster. The totemic automobile made its debut in 1930 in the first sentence of the first Nancy Drew mystery, The Secret of the Old Clock. In the years  and books, films, television shows and computer games  that followed, it morphed into a blue convertible, a red Mustang and a blue hybrid. Now the roadster is back, as blue and distinctive as ever, in Nancy Drew, which Warner Brothers will release on June 15.

title: Other Reasons Borrowers Falter
description: FOR housing economists, the best gauge of whether borrowers will repay their mortgages is their job status. When unemployment jumps, foreclosures are not far behind.

title: First Twenty20 Title Event Challenges World Cup
description: Crickets World Cup, which ended in farcical conditions after seven weeks of scant drama, could be upstaged by the inaugural championship in the sports shortest version, officials and players said.

title: The Older-and-Wiser Hypothesis
description: In 1950, the psychoanalyst Erik H. Erikson, in a famous treatise on the phases of life development, identified wisdom as a likely, but not inevitable, byproduct of growing older. Wisdom arose, he suggested, during the eighth and final stage of psychosocial development, which he described as ego integrity versus despair. If an individual had achieved enough ego integrity over the course of a lifetime, then the imminent approach of infirmity and death would be accompanied by the virtue of wisdom. Unfortunately for researchers who followed, Erikson didnt bother to define wisdom.

title: The Pursuit of Dreams and a Harvard Degree; Call for a Watchman of the Waterways (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Its the Truth, but Not the Whole Truth
description: AN Ohio judge will decide on Friday whether to approve the settlement of a class-action suit against Carfax in which consumers could receive coupons worth about $20 and the lawyers representing them $566,000.

title: Alyssa Qualls, John McCormick
description: Alyssa Anne Qualls and John Patrick McCormick were married yesterday at the First Unitarian Church of Providence in Rhode Island. The Rev. Charles F. Flagg performed the ceremony.

title: 3 Are Arrested in Shootings; 1 More Sought
description: Detectives in Brooklyn were looking yesterday for the person who fatally shot a 20-year-old man in his apartment in Wingate, the police said.

title: Erica Lubow, Edward Necarsulmer IV
description: Erica Isabella Lubow, a daughter of Anne van der Does Lubow and Arthur D. Lubow of New York, was married last evening to Edward Necarsulmer IV, the son of Terry OToole Necarsulmer and Mr. Necarsulmer III of Quogue, N.Y. The Rev. Robert J. Verrigni, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Cathedral in New York.

title: From China to Panama, a Trail of Poisoned Medicine
description: The kidneys fail first. Then the central nervous system begins to misfire. Paralysis spreads, making breathing difficult, then often impossible without assistance. In the end, most victims die.

title: How Cars Rate in Saving Our Necks
description: WHEN the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety recently rated 2007 cars for rear-impact protection, it found that almost two out of three did not do a good job protecting occupants from neck injuries.

title: A Season of Events for Auto Lovers
description: AS the days grow warmer, a car lovers cup runneth over. Whether its a concours or a swap meet, or some of the worlds most prestigious races, spring brings more than enough activities to keep an auto enthusiast happy  and busy.

title: Where Their Heads Are in the Clouds
description: THE rain fell steadily from an impenetrable gray sky on a recent weekday morning, and an unseasonably cold wind whipped around the corner of 34th Street and Fifth Avenue. But nothing seemed to deter the raincoat-clad, umbrella-clutching line of figures wending their way into the lobby of the Empire State Building, not even the conspicuous sign bearing the words Zero Visibility. No View.

title: Iced Storm
description: Unless youre familiar with coffee concentrate, New Orleans iced coffee is a puzzling ritual. The first time I had it, I watched skeptically as a friends mother filled a plastic Mardi Gras cup with ice, poured in an inch of inky coffee from a mayonnaise jar, then topped it off with milk. It was as smooth as a milkshake but had a rich coffee flavor and packed a caffeinated punch. It was easily the best iced coffee Id ever had, yet another thing that tastes better in New Orleans.

title: Turning the Familiar Into Something Novel
description: MOKSHA is a good restaurant, with several dishes that have spoiled me for lesser versions. But one of my favorite things about it is inedible: the rough white washcloth handed to each patron that, when unrolled and used to clean ones hands, sends up rose-scented steam all around. It helped us make the transition from the rainy gantlet of traffic and road construction along the way.

title: As a Big Landowner Plans to Sell, Mouths Begin to Water
description: In the lobbies of some of the buildings near the Brooklyn waterfront owned by the Watchtower Bible and Tract Society, visitors can pick up plastic-wrapped packets of postcards depicting the organizations various properties. On one, an aerial view of Brooklyn Heights, it seems as if nearly every third building is a Watchtower dormitory.

title: Corzine to Resume Duties as Governor on Monday
description: HOBOKEN, N.J., May 5  Gov. Jon S. Corzine plans to return to office on Monday, three and a half weeks after he suffered serious injuries in a car accident, his spokesman said Saturday.

title: Secrets and Lies
description: When they asked me why I lied, I lied, confesses Steve Geng, small-time crook, sometime actor, drug addict and drunk. (Or is he lying and was he, in fact, telling the truth?) At the time, Geng was living at the Daytop Village rehab facility on Staten Island, wearing a Pinocchio nose and a can labeled A Can of Lies to remind him of his predilection. Youve gotta love the literalness of recovery programs.

title: A Beach Resort Thats Quiet Enough for a King
description: AS the late afternoon sun bathes the horizon in purple and crimson, I wander slowly down the long, curving beach. Though rocks mar part of the five-mile-long stretch, most of the waterfront is covered with white sand. On the southern end of the beachfront, a towering, slim golden Buddha statue peers out over the sea, and I can see small white and yellow shrines cut into the rocks of a nearby mountain fringed with low mist.

title: Tea-Totalers
description: Teatime and cocktail hour have finally collided. Witness the Beijing Peach, made with jasmine-green-tea-infused vodka, served at the Flatiron Lounge in New York; the Mate Mojito (yerba mate tea, mint, rum and soda) served at the Camellia Lounge in Portland, Ore.; and the Pomy Leng from the Poleng Lounge in San Francisco.

title: Does It Even Matter if the U.S. Has a Cold?
description: FOR the last several decades, the United States has functioned as the main engine of growth in a global economy that has been moving with synchronicity.

title: Joanna Bloom, Brett Lindenbach
description: Joanna Faye Bloom and Brett David Lindenbach were married at the Municipal Building in New York on Friday by Blanca Martinez, a marriage officiant in the City Clerks office.

title: Secret San Sebastian
description: Regulars at Aloria Berri  recently named the best bar in Spain by the prominent guidebook Gourmetour  used to tease its owner, Jos Ramon Elizondo, that they had to cross the desert to eat his alta cocina en miniatura. Actually, just a river. His place is a short walk from San Sebastians Old Quarter, on the other side of the Urumea River, in the emerging neighborhood of Gros. Once the province of working families and car-repair shops, Gros has become a draw for locals looking for an alternative to the citys popular pintxo (tapas) bars. And besides, everyone knows the best pintxos are in Gros, says Elizondo, whose txirristra de mar (an architectural concoction of mackerel, vegetables and foie gras) took first prize in the National Tapas Competition in 2006.

title: Passing the Bucket
description: Across Tokyo, snooty barkeeps who practice molecular mixology have held on to at least one tradition: an old-fashioned ice bucket made by hand. These smooth-hewn caddies are shaped from Sawara wood, a cypress native to central Japan. Its a superb natural insulator that keeps ice drier and less slushy than a metal strainer or bowl. Although Sawara trees are now protected by a government quota, prices are still reasonable: expect to pay about $160 (www.edocraft.com), while a stylish take on the traditional, made from another type of cypress, is $353 (www.b-zenjapan.com).

title: Emily Lasner, Nicholas Brod
description: Emily Anne Lasner and Nicholas David Brod were married last evening at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington. Dr. Rodney Mariner, a rabbi, officiated.

title: Lessons From the Diamond
description: IM a pretty good baseball player and a really terrible guitarist. What Ive learned from baseball has had a great impact on the kind of manager Ive become, but it was the guitar that landed me my first technical job.

title: On a Quiet Lane, an Unsettling Discovery
description: THE scene outside the Whitestone Lumber shop on April 26 did not entirely shatter the reputation of this Queens neighborhood as a quiet place: No shots were fired. But less than two weeks after a gunman at Virginia Tech killed 32 people and himself, the arrest of a Whitestone couple in their apartment above the store prompted residents to reflect on their own vulnerability.

title: What Counts Most in College Admissions; Sound Barriers Make Perfect Sense (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking the Long View
description: UNLIKE Fifth Avenue, whose mansions and museums keep a walkers attention near to the ground, Central Park West is a skyscape, a panorama of tops and towers best seen from a distance. Now each end of this legendary street is anchored by modern architecture: at 106th Street, the 2004 condominium building and, just this year, 15 Central Park West, at 61st Street, an urbane mega-tower designed by Robert A. M. Stern to display a rich tapestry of historical allusion.

title: Stupid and Contagious
description: Until I received the assignment to review Everett Trues Nirvana, I hadnt listened to the band much in recent years. In this I suspect Im like most of us who were in our late teens or early 20s when Nirvanas singer, songwriter and guitarist, Kurt Cobain, died in April 1994, hardly two and a half years after the release of Nevermind. There was so much hype  inevitable word  over Nirvana and its demise that the music later seemed somehow buried beneath the ephemera it occasioned. It became almost embarrassing to listen, in ones dorm room, to Cobains strangely sarcastic and inviting voice, when journalists had called him the voice of our generation. And the bands tortured ambivalence over its tremendous popularity grew to seem sadly quaint. When Nevermind came out, the marketing of the Persian Gulf war as a blockbuster action film was a fresh outrage, as was the recruitment of the Beatles song Revolution as an advertising jingle; we were not yet thoroughly familiar with the emotional indecency of commercialization. We are now four years into the gulf wars skillfully marketed sequel, while Cobains widow, Courtney Love, has recently licensed her husbands song Breed for use by a manufacturer of video games. How to listen to the anthems of the early 90s in what are already the late 00s? What does Smells Like Teen Spirit sound like when youre in your 30s, as Kurt Cobain, dead at 27, of course will never be?

title: Hamas Rejects U.S. Proposals as Terrorist
description: JERUSALEM, May 5  Hamas, which leads the government of the Palestinian Authority and dominates its legislature, on Saturday poured scorn on American proposals to increase Palestinian movement and Israeli security.

title: Who Can Use Co-ops Roof?
description: Q How can a shareholder in a co-op determine if the owner of the penthouse has exclusive use of the roof? At the annual meeting a few years ago, the board president suggested making a roof garden. I later found out that the owner of the penthouse threatened to sue the board if the issue was pursued.

title: Wangs Bid for Perfection Couldnt Come at Better Time
description: Chien-Ming Wang of Tainan, Taiwan, is a talented and polite Yankees pitcher who has little to say in two languages. But Wang came close to giving the baseball world and 51,702 witnesses something special to talk about yesterday at Yankee Stadium.

title: With Ryan Getzlaf
description: Anaheim center Ryan Getzlaf has had 7 points in 10 playoff games as the Ducks have advanced to the N.H.L.s Western Conference finals. Getzlaf, who turns 22 on Thursday, said he would spend his free time golfing as Anaheim awaited the winner of the Detroit-San Jose series. MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

title: Shock Radio Shrugs at Imuss Fall and Roughs Up the Usual Victims
description: Almost two weeks after CBS Radio fired Don Imus for his racially and sexually demeaning remarks about the Rutgers womens basketball team, Nick Di Paolo opened his talk show on another CBS station in New York by mocking a manual that, he said, one of his bosses had given him that morning.

title: Home in the Range? Who Can Sing What

A friend of mine, a pop music writer, was agog at the feat. Isnt this a very difficult aria to sing? he asked. Isnt it amazing that she could do it?

title: Immigrants Hopes, and Their Fears, Change a Westchester Town
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., May 4  For Alex Gregorio and Aydee Romero, these are good times in Mount Kisco.

title: Mayweather Wins Decision Over De La Hoya
description: LAS VEGAS, May 5  Floyd Mayweather Jr. had just defeated Oscar De La Hoya in their superwelterweight title bout in a split decision Saturday night when a controversy threatened to delay, if not upend, his victory.

title: Energy and Safety
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has now added his voice to the chorus of New York lawmakers imploring the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to conduct a thorough, independent safety inspection at the Indian Point nuclear plant in Buchanan  not the routine maintenance and oversight that the commission insists is all thats needed, but a special, meticulous, top-to-bottom review that includes experts from outside the region and input from the state.

title: Mariners Reliever Mateo Is Charged With Assault
description: Julio Mateo, a relief pitcher for the Seattle Mariners, was arrested yesterday after an early-morning incident in which, the police said, he struck his wife in a Midtown Manhattan hotel room.

title: My Warming Garden
description: Gardeners are used to change. No two summers are alike, and what one year offers in rainfall is withdrawn the next in drought. In many gardeners  especially in the North  there is also a resignation to the limits of their growing seasons. But those are changing, and more quickly than anyone could imagine. The National Arbor Day Foundation has published a new hardiness zone map, based on climate data from the past 15 years, that clearly shows the warming trend across the country.

title: Get Back to Work
description: Imagine a shy, observant American girl, born in the middle of the last century. For years, her mother comes home from her job as an editor and puts in a second shift cooking, cleaning and supervising homework while Dad dozes in front of the TV. Gradually, the girl realizes that something is very wrong. When she is 13, her mother gives her a newly published book and says, Read this, and her life begins to change.

title: In a Tangled Family Drama, the Son Grasps for a Role
description: Theres a broad spectrum of feeling and behavior buried within the deceptively simple words family drama; the term can cover everything from Agamemnon to Hamlet to The Sopranos. But mostly we tend to think of such plays as smaller in scale, more personal and less cosmic  even when they are masterpieces, like A Dolls House or Long Days Journey Into Night.

title: Edward F. Boyd Dies at 92; Marketed Pepsi to Blacks
description: Edward F. Boyd, who as a young sales executive parlayed his assignment to promote Pepsi-Cola to fellow blacks into a war against white racism and black stereotypes, meanwhile selling oceans more soda, died on April 30 in Los Angeles, PepsiCo announced. He was 92.

title: An Errant Deputy Is Reined In
description: JUDITH A. JACOBS, the presiding officer of the Nassau County Legislature, removed her deputy, Roger Corbin, last month, the latest flare-up between the two Democratic leaders. But Mr. Corbin may be able to resume his leadership position.

title: A New Style of Hotel Where Work Meets Play
description: SIMON SINEK is a communications consultant who lives in Manhattan  at least when hes not traipsing around the country on business. In just one month, he will have traveled to five different cities, from Atlanta to Seattle, and spent a considerable amount of time in hotels.

Corzines life-threatening injuries from his traffic accident three weeks ago seemed to suck much of the oxygen from the everyday political battles here  except for a few stray elbows thrown among the staffs of the governor and his stand-in, Senate President Richard J. Codey.

Her manifesto, as she explained it, was to make a magazine with less spirituality than Oprahs magazine, one that would be more realistically crafty than Marthas. And, she added, it will have a lot more of my annoyingly Democratic politics in the middle.

title: Putting the Avant in Avant-Garde

Like many New York parents, Jenny 8 del Corte Hirschfeld (the numeral is her middle name) had a vision for her daughters birthday party, though hers was more Dal than Disney. In place of balloons and goody bags, this one had a working title  El Ataque de los Trapos (The Attack of the Cleaning Cloths)  and would be filmed using seven movie cameras, all borrowed for the occasion.

title: Why Not the Worst?
description: Last year, I stumbled upon a remarkable book called The Talisman of Troy. Written by Valerio Massimo Manfredi, The Talisman of Troy chronicled the adventures of Diomedes, a second-tier hero in the Iliad, after the fall of Troy. Bristling with sentences like Anchialus shuddered: in that boy was the awesome power of the son of Peleus, but not a crumb of his fathers piety, nor his hospitable manners, the novel advanced the theory that Helen of Troy had not really been abducted by Paris, son of Priam, but had deliberately gone to Asia Minor in order to get her hands on a sacred totem  the talisman of Troy  that would enable women to rule the world. The book is thus one of lifes unalloyed pleasures: an uncompromisingly stupid novel in a world filled with stupid novels that do make compromises. And, by virtue of its faux Hellenic inanity and all-purpose Delphic hootiness, it is also a powerful weapon in the hands of those of us who work night and day to resist the tyranny of the good.

title: Carley Graham, David Garcia
description: Carley Alison Graham, a daughter of Jane P. Graham of Winchester, Mass., and Stuart W. Graham of Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday to David Robert Garcia, the son of Graciela E. OHara of Montclair, N.J., and the stepson of John J. OHara. The Rev. Elea Kemler, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Arlington Street Church in Boston.

Four days after 9/11 the company opened a delayed season with new productions of Wagners Flying Dutchman in the afternoon and Gilbert and Sullivans Mikado in the evening.

title: U.S. Bishop, Making It Official, Throws in Lot With African Churchman
description: WOODBRIDGE, Va. May 5  The Anglican archbishop of Nigeria, Peter J. Akinola, on Saturday installed Bishop Martyn Minns of Virginia as the new leader of a diocese that would take in congregations around the country that want to leave the Episcopal Church. In doing so, Archbishop Akinola rejected requests by leaders of the worldwide Anglican Communion and the Episcopal Church to refrain from taking part in the ceremony.

description: Some three million visitors are expected in Cape Town and the Western Cape in 2010, when Cape Town will be one of nine host cities in South Africa for the soccer World Cup. In anticipation of this influx, Cape Town Tourism (www.tourismcapetownco.za), in partnership with other city organizations, has implemented a safety plan it hopes will create a more secure environment  though it seems in some ways to be less about prevention than helping the latest victims.

title: Statue of Limitations
description: Historical mysteries often convey a sense of yearning for people and places irretrievably lost in time. That feeling surfaced in Mark Millss haunting first novel, Amagansett, as a lyrical lament for a Long Island fishing community whose traditional way of life was doomed by the booming prosperity of postwar America. Although a keen sense of loss and longing also suffuses Millss second novel, THE SAVAGE GARDEN (Putnam, $24.95), the youth of its protagonist and the thrill of his exploits as an amateur sleuth keep depression at bay in this romantic and gracefully executed literary puzzle.

title: Ellen Hayes, Robert Friedman
description: Ellen Louise Hayes, a lawyer, and William Robert Friedman Jr., an investment banker, are to be married today. David N. Dinkins, the former mayor of New York, is to officiate at the All Souls Unitarian Church in New York, with the Rev. Galen Guengerich, a Unitarian minister, taking part.

description: FOR many New Yorkers, familiarity with nature comes mainly in the form of extravagant salads, but for Steve Brill, extravagant salads come from his familiarity with nature. He has been living off the bounty of the citys parks for 25 years, feasting on wild edibles and leading foraging tours twice a week.

title: Lessons of the Game

title: Paris: The Five Htel
description: THE BASICS The Five Htel, open for about seven months now, aims to compete with the new boutique hotels now scattered about Paris. The interior design is so striking it can be fatiguing  especially in the red-leather paneled hall. The tiny lobby  warmed with a red-painted gas fireplace  is filled with purposefully mismatched geometric shaped chairs in black and white patterns. Every room has a different color scheme  gray wallpaper accented with teal velvet; stripes of blood red and orange; black and taupe. All feature tiny white lights that create a planetarium effect.

title: A Liberal Case for Gun Rights Sways Judiciary
description: In March, for the first time in the nations history, a federal appeals court struck down a gun control law on Second Amendment grounds. Only a few decades ago, the decision would have been unimaginable.

title: A Scoop, Topped With Politics
description: Residents of the West Village may debate whether scrappy political activism, once a staple of the neighborhood, is still alive and well in this quaint maze of tree-lined streets or finally has given way to a shameless pursuit of the sumptuous life. But Adam Riff, a legislative aide to State Senator Thomas Duane, has found an unlikely way to marry the two currents.

description: PARIS, May 6  Arrogant, brutal, an authoritarian demagogue, a perfect Iago: the president-elect of France has been called a lot of unpleasant things in recent months and now has five years to prove his critics wrong.

title: Book of Revelations
description: If theres such a thing as boomer cuisine, it can be found in the pages of The Silver Palate Cookbook. With its chirpy tone and Moosewood-in-the-city illustrations, the book, published in time for Mothers Day in 1982, gave millions of home cooks who hadnt mastered the art of French cooking the courage to try sophisticated dishes like escabeche, wild mushroom soup and that new thing called pesto. Years later, mothers sent their grads into the world with their raspberry-vinaigrette-stained copies. And now, with the 25th-anniversary edition, a new generation will try dishes like chicken Marbella, which once seemed as risky (capers! prunes!) as the East Village.

description: Los Angeles

title: Coastal Croatia by Bicycle: Sea, Sun, Truffles
description: THERE was an elegant simplicity to Zarko Bartolic's beige 1982 Renault, a battered four-door that  if I succeeded in deciphering his Slav-accented Italian with my rusty Utah Spanish  was paid for entirely with money he earned finding truffles in the Croatian mountains and selling them to local restaurants.

description: More than 40 years after their first days in Kew Gardens, Queens, the children from Public School 99 came together again last week  older, grayer, more distinguished, maybe a little shorter. They had met up in the past, of course, sharing rugelach on a walk through the neighborhood or chatting across the world on the phone, but Monday night was different. This time, they would be on film.

description: VALENCIA, Spain, May 5  It made its mark on sailings most prestigious regatta, with its rainbow coalition of a crew and its ability to give stronger, richer syndicates plenty of trouble.

title: Ice-Cream Capades
description: Mister Softee meets his match when Heartschallenger rolls into the Big Apple this month. The powder-pink trucks are stocked with ice cream and global treats served up by Leyla Safai, an L.A.-based artist, and her musician beau, Ben Pollock, who wrote a collection of modern melodies to accompany their arrival (think Good Humor with an electro-pop twist). The couple, who also perform as the band Heartsrevolution, travel wherever the truck is hired to enliven weddings, birthday parties, even film festivals. Heartschallenger also collaborates with local artists across the country to curate curbside exhibitions, show films, play music and share sweets like the artist Gary Garays ice pops shaped into peace signs. Next stops: England and France. Go to www.heartschallenger.com.

title: States Ponder Laws to Keep Web Predators From Children
description: HARTFORD, May 4  Nearly every American teenager, it seems, has a Web page displaying his or her life details. And nearly every parent has nightmares that someone might visit those pages, easily discovering where the children live and what they like.

description: The deaths of two subways workers, each hit by trains in separate accidents in the last two weeks, reminds us that maintaining New Yorks subway tracks is necessary and dangerous work. The system is vital to hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers, requiring expeditious repair when things break down; it is also a century old, with many original and near-original components that need constant attention or replacement.

Weatherbury Farm (www.weatherburyfarm.com) in Avella, Pa., offers suites in a renovated livery stable overlooking its cattle-grazing meadow.

title: Youve Got Trouble
description: A few years back, when my son was in college, he had to mail a letter. I dont remember the specific reason, but I do remember having a conversation with him in which he complained bitterly about the amount of work involved  finding a place where he could purchase a stamp, figuring out what kind of stamp he needed, actually writing the letter, locating an envelope, putting the letter into the envelope, having to physically leave his dormitory room to mail the envelope and so on. I grew exhausted just listening to him describe this series of arduous tasks, one coming right after another. I was glad, for my sons sake, that he never had to live in a world  as I once did  where the only way to change channels was to walk all the way to the TV set and manually turn a knob.

title: A Prince of Pulp, Legit at Last
description: ALL his life the science fiction writer Philip K. Dick yearned for what he called the mainstream. He wanted to be a serious literary writer, not a sci-fi hack whose audience consisted, he once said, of trolls and wackos. But Mr. Dick, who popped as many as 1,000 amphetamine pills a week, was also more than a little paranoid. In the early 70s, when he had finally achieved some standing among academic critics and literary theorists  most notably the Polish writer Stanislaw Lem  he narced on them all, writing a letter to the F.B.I. in which he claimed they were K.G.B. agents trying to take over American science fiction.

title: TVs Silver Age
description: TV Land, that cable network repository of pop-culture comfort food, knows how to put on a splashy marketing event. The current resting place for series like The Andy Griffith Show, Bewitched and Little House on the Prairie, TV Land transformed a restaurant in Times Square into the Bat cave, complete with Adam West and Julie Newmar prowling the premises and the Batmobile parked outside, to celebrate its fifth anniversary in 2001. On a rainy afternoon in March, however, the network forsook its usual irreverent shout-outs to televisions past glory. Instead, for its latest effort to woo advertisers and media buyers, TV Land hired Bill Clinton to speak soberly about the future of the planet.

Nothing like it had been seen in these conservative, well-heeled parts.

Nothing seemed impossible. He spoke of a new dawn. The partys campaign song declared, Things can only get better.

title: Bridgeport: Stop Litigating
description: Bridgeport owes at least $2 million in legal fees and millions more in interest incurred during its six-year effort to avoid paying a contractor, C. R. Klewin Northeast, for its work on the Arena at Harbor Yard in 2001.

title: It Slices. It Dices...
description: The Cuisinart food processor was the right machine at the right time for Sheila Lukins and Julee Rosso. When we started the Silver Palate in 1977, we didnt have a real kitchen, Rosso says of their gourmet takeout shop and catering business on New Yorks Upper West Side. The health department demanded it, so we opened one around the corner with three used refrigerators and three brand-new Cuisinarts.

title: Esalen
description: Esalen is on the edge. Located in Big Sur, California, just off Highway 1 on approximately one hundred and fifty acres of stunning natural beauty, Esalen is, geographically speaking, a cliff suspended about one hundred feet above the crashing surf and kelp-congested tides of the Pacific Ocean. By all measures, it is a stunning place, replete with natural beauty and a certain physical paradox, partly produced by the proximate presence of mountains and ocean; indeed, the rocky heights seem to drop directly into the watery depths here or, more true to the place's primeval geological history, it is as if the heights rise up out of the depths. Henry Miller called Big Sur "a religion where extremes meet." Indeed. The physical paradox of the land is deepened further by a simple, but somehow profound, historical and geographic fact: these, after all, are grounds that both constitute the very edge of the American frontier and look due west to see the East. Certainly Walter Truett Anderson had it right when he wrote, "If a place can have charisma, then surely this one has it."

title: Later, at the Bar
description: That winter there were two snowstorms. The first one was expected. Born in Florida and galvanized by the damp winds of the Pennsylvania mountains, it was strong as a wildcat by the time it reached upstate New York. The YMCA closed early and so did the library. The mayor declared a state of emergency, which it was. There were three head-on collisions on Route 19 and a teenager froze to death after falling into one of the gorges on the north end of town. Hank Stevens, who owned Hank's Diner, couldn't get out of his driveway and had to stay at home with his children. ("No," he said all afternoon. "Daddy cannot go outside and build a fort. Daddy doesn't own snow pants.")

title: Send
description: Bad things can happen on email. Consider Michael Brown, the director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, who committed the following thoughts to email during the very worst days of Hurricane Katrina.

title: The Happiness Myth
description: Know yourself. This is the key to all philosophy, the center of all wisdom, the one thing that decides if you are the actor in a tragedy or a comedy. This chapter points out three major interpretations of this singular injunction. The first is the Socratic, and it has to do with knowing what you believe. The second is Freudian and has to do with knowing who you are. The third is lonely and has to do with training yourself to take your intellect as your own companion.

title: Bigger Deal: A Year Inside the Poker Boom
description: In 1978, the year I first visited Las Vegas for the World Series of Poker, Bobby "the Owl" Baldwin beat a record field of forty-two players to the title of world champion and a handsome first prize of $270,000. A decade later, in 1988, the first time I played in the main event myself, there were all of 167 starters and the title was worth $700,000. By 2005, when I take part again at the beginning of this book, the field has risen to nearly six thousand. The first prize is $7.5 million and all nine players who reach the final table become dollar millionaires.

title: The Joy of Drinking
description: Here on my scruffy, untamed mountainside in northern Virginia, if you stand on the kitchen steps and pitch a rotten peach into the woods, in a few years you will have a fine peach tree. In years when May doesn't spring a sharp freeze and the squirrels don't, for reasons inscrutable, harvest the unripe crop, you will have more peaches than anyone can possibly eat or freeze.

title: Ill Sleep When Im Dead
description: Warren's father, William Rubin Zivotofsky, was born in Kiev, Ukraine, in 1903. His father, Rubin, left for New York in 1905, and the Zivotofskys of Ukraine became the Zevons of Brooklyn.

title: Thick as Thieves
description: One of these days that kid's gonna get his tit in a wringer. It was the voice of an old, familiar ghost, and it spoke to me as I stumbled through waist-high drifts in the blizzard of '96. According to newscasters, this was the worst snowstorm to hit New York in decades. Parked cars on Tenth Avenue were visible only as little bumps on the white, silent landscape. And still it came down, big wind-whipped flakes that nipped my cheeks and scrambled my senses. I wasn't exactly homeless, but some instinct had been driving me through the streets, hunched into the storm. There was little refuge back where I'd come from.

title: Rethinking Thin
description: If you met Carmen J. Pirollo, you might not realize that he has a weight problem. He's a square-jawed, animated man, who talks in exclamation points, favors preppy clothes, and-the big hint that he's a bit self-conscious-sometimes doesn't tuck in his shirts. Yet while you may notice his abdomen under that shirt, he is not what you might think of as obese. He does not seem to have any trouble moving, and when he sits down, he does not spill out of his chair. He's not like one of the subjects in those insulting, deliberately humiliating photos that show up in magazine articles or on television programs to illustrate the horrors of the obesity epidemic-those familiar images of round-faced, double-chinned people captured stuffing hamburgers into their mouths or of a fat family lumbering past fast food restaurants, dipping into bags of popcorn or licking ice cream cones.

title: Its the Truth, but Not the Whole Truth

title: Editors Choice
description: EDITH WHARTON, by Hermione Lee. (Knopf, $35.) This meticulous biography shows Whartons significance as a designer, decorator, gardener and traveler, as well as a writer.

title: Paperback Row
description: EVERYMAN, by Philip Roth. (Vintage International, $13. ) A nameless protagonist grapples with aging, physical decline and impending death in this slender, elegant novel. Roth begins with Everymans end: the novel opens at his funeral, and goes back in time as he ponders his middleclass New Jersey boyhood, his successful advertising career on Madison Avenue, his three failed marriages and a series of increasingly frequent health crises. Everyman won the 2007 PEN/Faulkner award for fiction. Roth takes the writers free acknowledgment of many literary modes, Nadine Gordimer wrote in the Book Review, while unceasingly experimenting with his own.

title: A Former P.O.W., Now Sentenced to Loneliness
description: One of the strongest elements of Tom Cipullos opera Glory Denied is the use of supertitles as a visual element, an integral part of the proceedings. The words spread across the stage behind the singers like concrete poetry. Sometimes they are repeated to form a kind of verbal screen; sometimes they are in different colors; sometimes they are words the singers arent even singing but tell a part of the story. Sometimes they are grievously misspelled too, but whether one ascribes that to Mr. Cipullo or to the students of the Brooklyn College Opera Theater, led by Richard Barrett, which gave the opera its first complete staging this weekend, this is a creative use of titles, weaving them into the fabric of the piece rather than taping them across the proscenium as a barrier between the viewer and the action on stage.

description: BONE THUGS-N-HARMONY Strength & Loyalty (Interscope)

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the first debate of the Republican candidates for president referred incorrectly in some copies to Duncan Hunter, one of the 10 participants. He is a current  not former  congressman from California.

title: For the Record
description: An article and picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday about efforts to re-establish coral reefs referred incorrectly to the networks of pipes on which coral is grown in the Mote Marine Laboratory in Florida. The pipes are made of PVC, not iron. The article also carried an incomplete list of American territories where corals occur. Besides Florida, Hawaii, the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico, corals also grow in warm and cold water in several other areas, including American Samoa and the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Louisiana and Texas.

title: Brooklyn Man Killed Outside Lounge
description: A man was stabbed and shot to death during a fight outside a club in Bushwick yesterday morning, the police said. The fight occurred shortly after 3 a.m. at the Groove Lounge, the police said. Patrons spilled outside the club, and witnesses said they heard several gunshots. The victim, Luis Ruiz, 24, of Clinton Hill, a single father who worked in Manhattan in computer graphics, had visited the club for the first time that night, said Noemi Galletti, his landlord and friend. Someone called him to come over because they were having a party there, she said. Another man was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center with a head injury, but he was in stable condition yesterday, the police said. There were no arrests yesterday.

title: For the Record
description: A map on Tuesday with an article comparing two PCB-removal projects by General Electric  one on the Hudson River in New York and the other on the Housatonic in Massachusetts  misspelled part of the name of a city near the G.E. factory in Hudson Falls, N.Y. It is Glens Falls, not Glen Falls.

title: Students Search for the Words to Go With Their Cultural Pride
description: CLOSTER, N.J.  Last summer, watching Al Jazeeras reports of the war in Lebanon between Israel and Hezbollah, Fidele Harfouche was startled to realize that in addition to understanding the Arabic spoken by the anchors, she could, for the first time, read some of the words marching across the bottom of the screen.

title: A Big Stretch
description: I GREW up watching my father stand on his head every morning. He was doing sirsasana, a yoga pose that accounts for his youthful looks well into his 60s. Now he might have to pay a royalty to an American patent holder if he teaches the secrets of his good health to others. The United States government has issued 150 yoga-related copyrights, 134 patents on yoga accessories and 2,315 yoga trademarks. Theres big money in those pretzel twists and contortions  $3 billion a year in America alone.

title: Paying Dearly in Desperation
description: Its Roger Clemenss ball, and he can throw it wherever he wants. Beginning June 1, hell throw it for the Yankees.

title: Studying Religion in Todays World (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Flooding Forces Evacuations in Plains
description: Two more bodies were discovered today in Greensburg, Kan., raising the death toll in the little town that was devastated by a tornado on Friday night to 10. Weather officials estimate that the storms winds blew at over 200 miles an hour as it all but leveled the town.

title: Only 4 Coffins, but 265 Victims Are Mourned at Mass in the Bronx
description: Red roses in hand, about 45 mourners emerged yesterday from a Spanish-language Mass and walked a quarter-mile to a majestic mausoleum at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx. For some of those being mourned, it was a second or even third funeral.

title: Mets Come Up Empty in Their Bag of Tricks
description: PHOENIX, May 6  Mike Pelfrey and John Maine were sitting around the Chase Field clubhouse Thursday reminiscing about the bad old days. The conversation centered on last July, when Maine fell to 0-3 with a loss to the Florida Marlins but had pitched well enough to think he had reached a turning point in his season. In his next start, Maine threw a shutout that started his 26-inning scoreless streak.

title: Epidemic Is Killing Pigs in Southeastern China
description: HONG KONG, May 7  A mysterious epidemic is killing pigs in southeastern China, but international and Hong Kong authorities said today that the Chinese government is providing little information about it, or about the contaminated wheat gluten that has caused deaths and illnesses in other animals.

title: Victory Challenge Still Has Chance at Americas Cup Semifinals
description: VALENCIA, Spain, May 6  Eighteen months ago, the crew and support staff of Victory Challenge were on the verge of unemployment.

title: N.J. Governor Ready to Resume Duties
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 7  Saying that his prolonged absence from a job that he loves was driving him stir crazy, Jon S. Corzine resumed his official duties as Governor of New Jersey this morning, three and a half weeks after sustaining serious injuries in a car accident.

title: With Sarkozy, Bush May Find a Close Friend in France
description: PARIS, May 7  Two days before the first round of the presidential election last month, Nicolas Sarkozy donned a red checked shirt, jeans and cowboy boots, mounted a small white horse named Universe and rode around the Camargue country in Frances deep south. A gaggle of reporters and cameramen followed him in a cart pulled by a tractor. The black bulls on the nearby pasture stayed away.

title: Once Again, Murdochs Siren Song
description: Rupert Murdoch, the thrill-ride version of the modern media mogul, delivered a particularly head-snapping jolt last week when the News Corporation said it intended to buy The Wall Street Journal and the rest of Dow Jones & Company for $5 billion. Now that some of the commotion has eased, it might be worth a few minutes to examine the proposal bearing in mind Mr. Murdochs unique business DNA.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Sept. 30 about a lawsuit to force the Department of Veterans Affairs to add the Wiccan symbol to the list of approved emblems for headstones included erroneous information from the suit about a Pentagon survey of Wiccan participation in the military. (The error was pointed out after it was repeated in an article on April 23 about the suits settlement.) There were more than 1,800 Wiccans in the Air Force, not in all of the armed forces. (The Pentagon did not survey the entire military.)

title: Rumpled Sheets and Notions Among Strange Bedfellows
description: An unlikely affair is the most likely thing imaginable in a romantic comedy, but the match in An Octopus Love Story, Delaney Britt Brewers drama that comes on strong before settling into the rhythm of a sitcom, does have an unusual twist.

title: Afghan Media Face Threat of Controls
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 6  Afghanistans government, competing with the Taliban for public support and trying to fend off accusations that it is corrupt and ineffective, is moving to curb one of its own most impressive achievements: the countrys flourishing independent news media.

title: Journalists Intend to Sue Hewlett-Packard Over Surveillance
description: In an unusual step for the news media, three journalists whose private phone records were scrutinized by investigators working for Hewlett-Packard intend to sue the company for invasion of privacy.

title: The Fishing Is Canceled, but Kayakers Are Buoyant
description: Kayak fishing is a sport still obscure enough that just about anyone who shows up for a tournament quickly finds that there are no strangers.

title: Beyond Books: Oprah Winfreys Seal of Approval Goes Presidential
description: Its usually pretty easy to quantify what Oprah Winfreys stamp of approval can mean: her book club catapults titles to the top of best-seller lists, and her nods at other products send consumers racing to buy them.

title: With Game Deserting Him, Woods Manages to Hold On
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 6  There have been tidier victories to come out of the golf bag of Tiger Woods, but he has even mastered making the stressful and dramatic look like expressions of himself.

title: Rough Alliance Built on Commandeered House in Anbar
description: JUWAYBA, Iraq  Nearly every day, the sheik stops by the villa that was once his home but is now an American garrison. Sometimes he comes with tips about the insurgency, or with news of political developments in this rural village near the Euphrates River.

title: The Soft Bigotry of Iraq
description: Whether out of blind loyalty or blind denial, most Congressional Republicans are prepared to back up President Bushs veto of the Iraq spending bill. It is now essential that the revised version not back away from demanding that Iraqs prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, finally deliver on the crucial national reconciliation measures he has spent the last year dodging. And it must make clear that American support for his failures  and Mr. Bushs  is fast waning.

title: Getting Their Faces Done but Not Their Brains
description: For well over a decade now it has been fashionable to think of adolescent girls as the gender wars neediest casualties. Their self-esteem, we are told, is siphoned off by a culture that mutes their instincts. Girls go underground. Their voices are sublimated; they eat too much or they eat too little. Unable to express themselves, they become what they buy, succumbing to commercial demands about what girlhood should look like.

title: Reviews and Success for Movies
description: Spider-Man 3 set box office records this weekend despite getting mostly luke-warm reviews. 300 and Wild Hogs, which were both surprise hits for the movie industry, also managed to be hot at the box office without critical acclaim.

title: Lawyers, Guns and Meaning
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Royal Visit
description: President Bush welcomed Queen Elizabeth II to the White House with remarks that celebrated the values that have bound the United States and Britain across the Atlantic and across the centuries.

title: Crispin Porter Acquires Radar Communications
description: Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami, part of MDC Partners, has acquired and absorbed Radar Communications in Boulder, Colo., a consulting company specializing in market research that seeks to better understand consumer behavior. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: About.com Buys ConsumerSearch.com
description: About.com, a Web information service owned by The New York Times Company, plans to announce Monday that it has bought ConsumerSearch.com, a Web site that compiles reviews of consumer products, for $33 million.

title: V.C.s Dial Up $10 Million for Mig33
description: A start-up, Mig33, has snagged $10 million in funding for its mobile Internet telephony and instant-messaging services, the Red Herring reported. The funding, led by Accel Partners and RedPoint Ventures, and which included Technology Venture Partners, is expected to be announced Monday, the publication said.

title: May Could Bring a Sweet I.P.O. Market
description: Start-ups preparing to go public and the bankers backing them are hoping for a merry, merry month of May. The Red Herring notes that bankers are hoping to raise $1.4 billion this week with six new stocks coming to market, and have $1.3 billion lined up for the following week.

title: Wells Fargo Gobbles Up Greater Bay Bancorp
description: In the eat-or-be-eaten world of banking, Greater Bay Bancorps network of Bay Area community banks became a snack Friday for giant Wells Fargo. Wells Fargo agreed to pay about $1.5 billion in stock for the East Palo Alto, Calif., holding company, which is better known to most customers for its individual banks, including Santa Clara Valley National Bank, Mid-Peninsula Bank, Peninsula Bank of Commerce and Mount Diablo National Bank.

title: Netgear Bulks Up with Infrant Buy
description: Netgear, a Santa Clara, Calif. maker of equipment that lets customers set up household Internet networks, agreed to buy closely held Infrant Technologies for $60 million to gain access to its data storage products. Additionally, Netgear may pay as much as $20 million in cash over three years if Infrant meets revenue goals, Netgear said Thursday in a statement.

title: Losses Narrow at Trump Casinos, but Buyers Remain Elusive
description: With its three Atlantic City casinos being eyed by potential buyers, Trump Entertainment Resorts said Thursday that its first-quarter loss shrank, despite increasing competition from slot-machine parlors in Philadelphia and New York. Perhaps more worrisome news is that potential white knights have yet to materialize.

title: ABN Amro Rejects $24.5 Billion Bid for Lasalle Bank
description: The Dutch bank ABN Amro, the subject of one of the largest takeover battles in history, said Monday it had rejected a $24.5 billion offer for its Lasalle Bank subisidiary from a group including the Royal Bank of Scotland, finding it did not constitute a superior proposal to a previous bid from Bank of America. Nevertheless, ABN said it would allow shareholders to vote on the competing bid and others, as required by last weeks ruling in an Amsterdam court.

title: Sears Chairman Eyes Possible Deals
description: With more than $2 billion in cash to burn, Sears Holdings chairman Edward Lampert told shareholders Friday the retail giant is considering numerous possibilities for acquisitions or investments.

title: Activist Shareholders Hit a Hot Streak
description: As activist investors like Carl Icahn, who is currently waging a proxy war with Motorola to gain a seat on its board, become more determined, the companies boards are apparently getting softer.

title: Safeway Wont Shop Dominicks, C.E.O. Says
description: Dominicks, the Chicago-area grocery chain, is not for sale, the chief executive of Safeway, its parent company, told The Chicago Tribune. But at the same time, Safeway is not going to rapidly expand the size of the chain, which was cut to 83 stores earlier this year when it closed 14 underperforming stores, said the executive, Steven Burd, who engineered Dominicks acquisition in 1998 in a deal then valued at $1.9 billion.

title: Alliance Boots Buyers Must Pay Into Pension Fund
description: The trustees of the pension fund at Alliance Boots, the British drugstore chain, are demanding that the private equity bidders planning to take over the company commit 1 billion pounds ($2 billion) to its pension plan.

title: Carlyle Eyes British Submarine Dock
description: The Carlyle Group is one of two bidders expected to put in final offers to buy the Devonport submarine dockyard near Plymouth in Britain this week. Final offers for the Devonport Management Limited, the company that runs the submarine refueling and maintenance yard, are due on Tuesday following a first round of bidding that valued it at about 350 million pounds ($697 million).

title: Alcoa to Bid $33 Billion for Alcan
description: Alcoa, the worlds No. 1 aluminum company, said Monday it would make an unsolicited bid it valued at $33 billion for Alcan, a Montreal-based rival. Alcoa said the proposed bid came after lengthy negotiations between the two aluminum giants failed to produce a mutually agreed deal. This offer follows almost two years of discussions between our companies regarding a variety of potential business combination transactions, including unsuccessful board-level discussions of a merger transaction last fall, Alcoas chief executive Alain J.P. Belda said in a statement. We are very disappointed that those efforts did not result in a negotiated transaction  a conclusion we would have strongly preferred.

title: 3 Buyout Firms to Battle for EMI, Report Says
description: A takeover battle for the EMI Group, the British music company, may be in the offing, but Warner Music, which has been interested in EMI for years, will not be among the bidders.The Financial Times reported that three private equity firms in the United states  Fortress, Cerberus and One Equity  are set for a 3 billion pound ($5.98 billion) takeover battle during the next two weeks for control of EMI, the worlds third-biggest music group.

title: Buffett Talks About Succession and Big Deals
description: Berkshire Hathaways Warren Buffett said he would love to find a $40 billion acquisition and would figure out a way to come up with $60 billion for the right deal, Bloomberg News reported. Speaking at his companys annual shareholder meeting in Omaha over the weekend, he also suggested that he might hire up to four people as chief investment officers when he steps down.

title: Goldman Runs Numbers on Buyout Candidates
description: Predicting the next buyout target has become a cottage industry on Wall Street, with analysts seeming to churn out lists of suggestions  usually based on a screening of stocks according to set criteria  on a weekly basis. Dan Primack of PEHub said he has gotten ahold of one such leveraged buyout model produced by Goldman Sachs for its institutional clients, and it apparently offers some intriguing candidates that private equity funds might be considering.

title: KPMG Resigns as New Century Auditor
description: KPMG has quit as auditor of the bankrupt subprime lender New Century Financial, which has hired forensic accountants to investigate how the company valued its stake in mortgage-backed bonds.

title: Debate Escalates Over Hedge Fund Fees
description: Are hedge fund managers fees getting too rich for investors blood? While managers of these regulated investment pools are getting richer  they took home an estimated $14 billion last year  there are grumblings among some investors that their returns are not worth the fees.

title: ABN Amro Rejects Rival Bid for LaSalle
description: ABN Amro rejected a $24.5 billion offer for its LaSalle Bank unit from a group led by the Royal Bank of Scotland Group, as the biggest takeover battle in the financial-services industry intensified.

title: Clear Channel Bidders Said to Consider Changing Offer
description: Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners discussed possible changes to their bid for Clear Channel Communications over the weekend, The Financial Times reported, citing undisclosed sources. A price increase was unlikely, the newspaper said, but other terms could change ahead of Tuesdays shareholder vote on the proposal.

title: Qantas Bid Is Up in the Air
description: The investment group whose bid of 10.8 billion Australian dollars ($8.9 billion) for Qantas collapsed over the weekend said Monday it might make a new bid for the airline, as regulators sought clarification that the old offer was indeed dead.

title: BAE in in Talks for Armor Holdings, Report Says
description: In a possible transAtlantic combination of defense contractors, Britains BAE Systems is in final negotiations for the $3.5 billion purchase of Armor Holdings, a United States maker of military and heavy vehicles, Humvee armaments and soldier body armor, according to The Wall Street Journal. The deal with BAE would pay Armor Holdings shareholders about $88 a share, or a 7 percent premium to the companys closing price Friday of $82.15 a share, the report said.

title: Bail Denied for Banker Held for Illegal Trades
description: A former Credit Suisse banker accused of running a $7.5 million insider trading ring from April 2006 until this February was denied bail yesterday at a hearing in federal magistrate court in Manhattan. Magistrate Judge Theodore H. Katz said that the banker, Hafiz Muhammad Zubair Naseem, a Pakistani citizen, met virtually every criteria as a flight risk.

title: In Chasing Dow Jones, What Does Murdoch Want?
description: Synergies aside, is Rupert Murdochs $5 billion bid for Dow Jones & Company really about the media moguls desire to acquire the patina of respectability that has eluded him as he built his News Corporation empire?

title: Not Reading the Fine Print
description: State Senator Antoine M.
