Thompson of Buffalo, a freshman Democrat, made a fiery speech on the Senate floor last week, denouncing a bill to increase legislators salaries when it came up for a vote in his chamber. He cited the lack of raises for Buffalo city workers, police officers, teachers and sanitation workers, and said, I cant in good conscience vote for myself, or anyone else, a raise.

title: A New Investing Tactic: Hedging Hedge Funds
description: Can you hedge a hedge fund? An investment currently being marketed to the rich is trying in essence to do just that, and the approach is bound to be offered to the rest of us soon, The New York Times reports.

title: Tech Investors Cull Start-Ups for the Pentagon
description: The nations military, in its search for the next surveillance system, bioterror vaccine or robot warrior, has decided to take a peek into the garage. Through a program that recently emerged from an experimental phase, the Defense Department is using some of the nations top technology investors to help it find innovations from tiny start-up companies, which have not traditionally been a part of the militarys vast supply chain.

title: A (Fictional) Wall Street Predator to Make a Comeback
description: Greed is still good.

title: In Congress, Working on Plan B
description: Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the House Republican leader, had a clear message for the White House Sunday  the clock is ticking.

title: AT&T Mergers Chief to Step Down
description: A week after AT&Ts chief executive said he would step down, the head of the telecommunication companys mergers and acquisitions team announced he also will retire. James Kahan, the senior executive vice president for corporate development who helped spearhead $200 billion in deals, including the acquisition of BellSouth, will step down on June 30, the company announced Saturday.

title: Apparently, Rudy Can Fail
2008: New Primary Focus
description: The Timess Adam Nagourney looks at how California, armed with an early primary, is changing presidential politics:

title: A C.E.O. Pitches Universal Health Care
description: Thirty-six companies have decided to join forces in a push to extend health insurance to all Americans, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: Sarkozys Lesson for Republicans
description: Jacques Chirac leaves office after two terms as Frances president, largely deemed a failure. He gets credit in France for standing up to President Bush over Iraq, but on the domestic front it was a time of drift, with efforts on reform collapsing as soon as protesters took to the streets. Voters rejected the European Union constitution he supported. He decided against seeking a third term only when polls made clear he could not win.

title: Trying to Make a Feast From a Political Food Fight
M.T.A. Chairman Is Resigning
description: Peter S. Kalikow, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority since 2001, announced this morning that he would resign when Gov. Eliot Spitzer names his replacement, after six eventful years at the helm of the nations biggest and busiest mass transit system.

title: Rove in Limbo
description: The revelation  dropped by Christopher Hitchens in an interview with New York magazine  that Karl Rove is an atheist has enabled the Bush administration to, at long last, deliver on its 2000 campaign promise to change the tone in Washington. Exhibit A: Ive never said this before, and never will again, but Im with Karl Rove, writes The American Prospects Ezra Klein on his personal blog. (Hitchens told New York, Karl Rove is not a believer, and he doesnt shout it from the rooftops, but when asked, he answers quite honestly. I think the way he puts it is, Im not fortunate enough to be a person of faith. )

title: Insurer Liberty Mutual Acquires Ohio Casualty
description: The Liberty Mutual Group, a home and auto insurer based in Boston, said Monday it had agreed to buy the Ohio Casualty Corporation for $2.7 billion.

title: Celestial Snapshots
description: Pictures from the flyby of Jupiter by the New Horizons spacecraft.

title: When We Blew It
description: In retrospect, its clear that we in the news media let the public down in the run-up to the Iraq war. This was the point of Bill Moyers recent documenary, Buying the War. Michael Getler, as experienced and savvy a journalist as any, has a thoughtful take on the documentary, and I recommend it. Getler writes in part:

title: Patina to Take Smith & Wollensky Off the Menu
description: In what may be the end of a months-long battle for the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, the national steakhouse chain said on Monday that it has agreed to a sweetened $94.6 million buyout offer by the Patina Restaurant Group. Patinas newest bid, which raised the cash per share to $11 from $9.25, bested a rival $84 million proposal by the Landrys Restaurant Group.

title: The Nice Little Steamroller
description: While J. Christopher Callaghan, the former candidate for state comptroller, stole the show at the 107th Legislative Correspondents Association dinner over the weekend, Gov. Eliot Spitzers video had its moments.

title: A Set-Top Box for the Junk Heap
description: I was never very impressed with Akimbo, the set-top box that was going to give you access to any TV show ever aired, on demand, via the Internet. The problem wasnt the concept; it was that they couldnt get the rights to any decent shows.

title: Dissolving and Consolidating
description: Perhaps in advance of the just-announced Assembly oversight hearing at which they will be appearing tomorrow, officials at the Empire State Development Corporation issued a press release today announcing the consolidation of some of its many, many subsidiary development corporations.Of all the states hundreds of public authorities, the development corporation is one of the biggest and most sprawling and controls some of the biggest pots of money. According to the release, it is dissolving 13 subsidiaries and collapsing 25 others into a single holding company to promote good corporate governance and ease oversight burdens.

title: Tornado Chasing on the Web
description: Whats left behind after most natural disasters is usually death, destruction and a lingering curiosity about what could have caused it.

title: Hostile Bid for Alcan May Chafe in Canada
description: Alcan, the Montreal-based aluminum giant, had a relatively low-key public reaction Monday to Alcoas surprise $33 billion hostile bid, saying in a short press release that it would consider the proposal. Canadian politicians may not be so measured. The uninvited offer from Alcoa, which is based in Pittsburgh, is likely to rekindle a national debate in Canada about the recent surge in foreign takeovers of large Canadian companies and whether it represents a threat to the countrys economic prestige  not to mention a potential loss of lucrative underwriting, accounting and legal work for the nations financial professionals.

title: Clear Channel Delays Vote as Bid Talks Continue
description: Its the buyout deal that wouldnt die.

title: Stupid Restaurant Tricks
description: After tipping over a glass filled with red wine because  for the gazillionth time  I caught the sleeve of my jacket on the edge of one of those paper tablecloth tops, my next blog came into sharp focus: annoying restaurant practices.

title: Investors Place Their Bets in Motorola Match-Up
description: Motorola chief executive Edward Zander and activist investor Carl Icahn have been at each other like antsy pugilists trying to work the media for a prefight edge, writes Roger O. Crockett in BusinessWeek. And Monday is fight day: Motorolas annual shareholder meeting in Chicago.

title: Monday Motorsports
description: In Nascar, Jeff Gordon started on pole in Richmond, his third straight pole, but faded in the final 15 laps to finish fourth. His Hendrick Motorsports teammates, Jimmie Johnson and Kyle Busch, finished one-two. Hendrick drivers are four-for-four in Car of Tomorrow races. ESPN takes a closer look at the teams domination.

title: Lawmaker Plays Down Private-Equity Tax Chatter
description: Private equity chiefs worried about a much bigger tax bite can take some comfort  though its unclear just how much  from Senate Finance Committee Chairman Max Baucus. The Democratic lawmaker from Montana told the National Press Club on Monday that his committee is nowhere close to drafting a bill that could affect the amount of tax that private equity funds and hedge funds have to pay. Mr. Baucus called recent reports that such legislation is already being drafted pure speculation, according to Bloomberg. People need to keep their shirts on here.

title: More Woes for Wolfowitz
description: Even before a top aides resignation was announced this afternoon, Paul D. Wolfowitz was facing a fresh wave of doubt that hed survive turmoil at the World Bank over his handling of a companions pay raise.

title: Executive Pursuits
description: Harry Hurt III learns to sell hot dogs at a New York Mets game.

title: Executive Pursuits
description: Harry Hurt III takes on a well-prepared opponent at the Fencer's Club in Chelsea.

title: Executive Pursuits
description: Harry Hurt III attempts a specially choreographed 15-second routine with a ballerina from the New York City Ballet.

title: Executive Pursuits
description: The Times's Harry Hurt III heads to the Shawangunk Mountains to try his hand at rock climbing. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: Executive Pursuits
description: The Times's Harry Hurt III learns how to defend himself in a class on ki chuan do. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: Executive Pursuits
description: Harry Hurt quarterbacks three plays as a "Paper Jet." He didn't run for daylight, but he didn't fumble either.

title: Bloomberg: A Thousand Times No
description: At a news conference this afternoon announcing the results of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs self-evaluation of his progress in keeping campaign promises (Surprise! Hes doing really well, with 91 percent kept), the subject turned, as it so often does, to his presidential prospects.

title: Fox Interactive Nears Deal to Buy Photobucket
description: Photobucket, a four-year-old, rapidly growing Web company, is in advanced talks to be acquired by Fox Interactive Media, a division of the News Corporation, reports Brad Stone of The New York Times.

title: Springtime for Spitzer. For Real?
description: Relations between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and members of the Legislature have been notably more sour during the last few weeks, as the governor butted heads with lawmakers over campaign reform, school districts, and other issues.

title: A Thousand Times No
description: Diane Cardwell, The Timess City Hall bureau chief writes in our sibblog, The Empire Zone, that a news conference this afternoon announcing the results of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs self-evaluation of his progress in keeping campaign promises, the subject turned, as it so often does, to his presidential prospects.

title: When Order Creates Itself
description: An anonymous commenter, responding to my previous column, suggested that my title Our Lives as Atoms is more than a little puzzling, and wondered Where will all this lead us? Ive written about the amplified polarization of opinion in the political blogs, and about the abuse at Abu Ghraib prison, which had a disturbingly eerie resemblance to famous experiments at Stanford University 36 years ago. What does any of this have to do with atoms? Fair question. Id like to start my answer by telling you about a strange phenomenon in Spitsbergen.Spitsbergen is a Norwegian island in the Svalbard archipelago. It has spectacular mountains, abundant glaciers and desolate tundra, where stones are littered over a flat and mostly featureless terrain. In places on this tundra, the stones are arranged in a remarkable way; they lie not in a chaotic, haphazard jumble but in an ordered array of hauntingly beautiful, nearly perfect circular piles. You really have to look at a photo to believe it.

title: Pardon Me? A Congressional Pardon?
description: The power to pardon traditionally belongs to the president. But Representative Duncan Hunter, who is seeking the 2008 Republican nomination, isnt waiting for Inauguration Day.

title: Almost There
description: When we met with Greg Huddy and Bill Harris, our architects, the next day for breakfast, I wasnt expecting much.

title: Wrestling With God at the Public Library
description: The New York Public Library is hosting a debate tonight between the author Christopher Hitchens and the civil rights leader the Rev. Al Sharpton. The question: Is God great?

title: By the Numbers: Clinton, Obama and Iraq
description: Senator Hillary Clintons current opposition to the war in Iraq is enough to satisfy members of her overwhelmingly anti-war party, despite her support for the invasion four years ago. While three quarters of Democrats in a New York Times/CBS News poll last month said the United States should have stayed out of Iraq, seven in 10 of them still expressed a favorable opinion of Mrs. Clinton. The poll was conducted before Mrs. Clintons call last week to deauthorize the war.

title: The Peace Presidents
description: On Feb. 8, 2004, George W. Bush proudly proclaimed to Tim Russert on Meet the Press, I am a war president. Like an 8-year-old playing with toy soldiers, Bush, an Air National Guard dropout, looked at war with vicarious enthusiasm. Contrast the attitude of the nations peace presidents  supreme commanders who led the nation to victory in the greatest wars the country faced: men who had experienced the grim reality of battle and wanted no part of it.

title: The End of Cocaine the Beverage
description: The short life of a highly-caffeinated beverage known as Cocaine has come to an end.

title: Hes Off to See the Doctor  Again
description: Matt DeSalvo is wearing No. 14 tonight in his major league debut for the Yankees. Maybe they should have given him No. 45.

title: Hitchens, Sharpton and Faith
description: You could tell from the background music that played beforehand  alternating recordings of James Brown and Gregorian chant  that this was going to be an unusual debate.

title: Speaking Presidential at Graduation
description: It is cap-and-gown season, and for the presidential candidates, that means the opportunity to spend May weekends delivering speeches at colleges and universities that are carefully selected to fit a strategic purpose.

title: Clinton Stumps in Obamas Backyard
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York has been battling Senator Barack Obama of Illinois for primacy in the Democratic field of presidential hopefuls, and now she is taking the battle to Chicago  his home turf and her former hometown.

title: Eve? Lonesome Suzie? Old Weird Alice? Name Lonesome Georges Mate
description: If they finally find a mate for Lonesome George, what should she be called? I suggest Eve in my Findings column about George, the famous giant tortoise from Pinta Island in the Galapagos. For decades, he was thought to be the last of the Pinta species, but biologists now think theres probably at least one more mixed in with the tortoises on another island. They hope to find one next year, preferably a female they could take back to Georges pen.

title: The Genetics of Obesity
description: In an article in todays Science Times, Gina Kolata reports on research showing that obesity is largely determined by genetics, a message that is at odds with popular conceptions of weight loss. What does that say about societys obsession with dieting?

title: The Best Park in Baseball (Not Chan Ho)
description: For those of you who love baseball and have never watched a game here, I say only this: Do not pass Go, do not collect $200, get thee here as fast as you can. If God were an architect  and who knows, He could be  Im convinced that He designed AT&T Park. Just finished taking a lap around the main concourse, which, between the foul lines, is uncovered and allows fans to gaze at the Bay Bridge, the Bay and dozens of souvenir shops/tasty concession stands (Im eating one of these  right now)

title: Johnson & Johnson Wont Seek Approval for a Heart Stent
description: Johnson & Johnsons hopes for an early return on its recent $1.4 billion acquisition of Conor Medsystems have been dashed by the failure of Conors heart stent design in a pivotal medical trial comparing it with a Boston Scientific stent.

title: Flying This Summer? Fasten Your Seat Belt
description: REMEMBER the summer of 2000, when delays, cancellations and work slowdowns by pilots sometimes brought the air travel system to near collapse?

title: Jupiter Gets Its Close-Up
description: On the way to Pluto, the New Horizons spacecraft has provided planetary astronomers their first close-up look in several years at Jupiter and its moons.

title: Manhattan: Viacom Moving Downtown
description: After nearly a year of negotiations, Viacom, the giant media company, signed a 15-year lease yesterday with Trinity Real Estate for about 400,000 square feet for offices and production facilities at 345 Hudson Street, the real estate company said. The annual rent was believed to average in the mid-$40 range per square foot over the life of the lease. Early next year, Viacom plans to relocate some 1,000 employees from several buildings in Midtown, including its MTV Networks Entertainment Group, which includes Spike TV, Comedy Central and TV Land.

title: Astronomers Report One for the Record Books
description: Kaboom indeed.

title: In World Skyscraper Race, It Isnt Lonely at the Top
description: SHANGHAI  When work began on the Shanghai World Financial Center in 1997, in the headiest days of Chinas economic takeoff, Shanghai was already a city that was hard to impress.

title: Sarkozy Sets a New Course for Relations With U.S.
description: PARIS, May 7  Two days before the first round of the presidential election last month, Nicolas Sarkozy donned a red checked shirt, jeans and cowboy boots, mounted a small white horse named Universe and rode around the Camargue country in Frances deep south. A gaggle of reporters and cameramen followed him in a cart pulled by a tractor. The black bulls in the nearby pasture stayed away.

title: Germany: No Pardons for 2 in Terrorism Gang
description: President Horst Khler turned down a politically contentious request for clemency by a terrorist from the far-left Red Army Faction, also known as the Baader-Meinhof gang. Mr. Khler met last week with the man, Christian Klar, who has served 24 years of a life sentence for the murder of a German prosecutor in 1977. The meeting drew protests from conservative politicians, who said Mr. Klar had shown no remorse for his crimes. Speculation that he might be freed rose after a fellow gang member, Brigitte Mohnhaupt, was released in March after serving 24 years in prison for murders in the 1970s. The president also denied clemency to another member, Birgit Hogefeld.

title: Sounds of Silence in Northern Ireland
description: IT was summer 1975 when the chilling report filtered through to our suburban Dublin kitchen: thered been another killing in Northern Ireland. Members of a well-known music group, the Miami Showband, had been driving home to Dublin after a gig in County Down. They were stopped at a false checkpoint 30 miles south of Belfast by members of the paramilitary Ulster Volunteer Force. As one of the terrorists tried to plant a bomb in the back of the bands van, it exploded. In the confusion, three of the musicians who had been lined up along the side of the road were executed.

title: Cesium Time
description: Q. Why is cesium used in atomic clocks?

title: Stomping Through a Metaphoric Jungle, Parasols at the Ready
description: Of all the worlds left to explore, the only one completely forbidden to mankinds prying eyes has always been the future. In an amusing revival of Eric Overmyers On the Verge, by the Phoenix Theater Ensemble, three Victorian-era American ladies set out for an unspecified virgin territory.

title: Former Associate Testifies Black Was Kept Informed
description: CHICAGO, May 7  The star witness in the criminal case against the former media baron Conrad M. Black, F. David Radler, took the stand Monday and portrayed himself as a close partner of Mr. Black who did not make a major move without talking with him.

title: A Met Gala for Feathered Friends and Acquaintances
description: Early yesterday afternoon, a peahen  a female peacock  escaped from a 20-foot-high gilded bird cage that had been constructed inside the main entrance of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, causing a brief stir as organizers of the annual Costume Institute gala clumsily chased her about the Great Hall. The bird, an indentured guest with pristine white feathers, seemed to be setting a tone for the untamed evening that was to come.

title: Skiers Dive Into a Sport, and Soar Back Up Again
description: LA GRAVE, France  Franois Bon, a 34-year-old from Les Arcs, France, is a pioneer in a sport that is so new that it has not even settled on a name.

title: New DVDs
description: CHINA DOLL

title: Medicare Privatization Abuses
description: It seems that outrageously high government subsidies arent enough to satisfy the private plans that participate in Medicare. Some of these Medicare Advantage plans have been caught using hard-sell tactics to pressure elderly Americans into signing up for policies that may leave them worse off than they would be with traditional Medicare coverage. The unscrupulous sales pressure is one more argument for removing the subsidies that are the only crutch allowing many of these plans to survive.

title: China Tells Little About Illness That Kills Pigs, Officials Say
description: HONG KONG, May 7  A mysterious epidemic is killing pigs in southeastern China, but international and Hong Kong authorities said Monday that the Chinese government was providing little information about it or the contaminated wheat gluten that has caused death and illness in pets in the United States.

title: 6 Arrested in Plot to Attack Fort Dix
description: Six people have been arrested in a plot to fire grenades and kill scores of soldiers at a New Jersey Army installation, the United States attorneys office in New Jersey said at a news conference today. Four of them were born in the former Yugoslavia, one was born in Turkey and one in Jordan, said a spokesman for the office, Greg Reinert.

title: Brooklyn Firefighters Find Homicide Victim
description: A 31-year-old Bedford-Stuyvesant woman whose body was found by firefighters after a fire broke out in her home early yesterday died of strangulation, the city medical examiners office said last night, adding that the death had been ruled a homicide. The police said the woman also had puncture wounds to her torso. Firefighters were called to the home, on Rochester Avenue, about 1:30 a.m. and discovered the body of the woman, who was identified by acquaintances as Wanette Douglas. The womans 5-year-old daughter, Tkyha Douglas, was treated for smoke inhalation, the authorities said.

title: Letters
description: Saving Coral Reefs

title: Swedes Stay Alive With Victory in Louis Vuitton
description: VALENCIA, Spain, May 7  To the uneducated observer, clarity can be hard to come by in an Americas Cup race as 17 men and the occasional woman crouch, scurry and lean on the deck of their cutting-edge yacht and try to read the invisible wind.

title: Steakhouses Accept Offer
description: The Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, the New York-based steakhouse chain, said yesterday that it agreed to be bought by the Patina Restaurant Group for $94.6 million, topping a rival proposal from Landrys Restaurants.

title: HBO Chief Takes Leave After Assault Arrest
description: The chairman and chief executive of HBO, Chris Albrecht, announced this afternoon that he was taking a leave of absence after being charged with assaulting a girlfriend in a Las Vegas parking lot early Sunday. .

title: Rookie Gives the Yankees a Lift Before They Fall
description: Twenty years from now, Matt DeSalvo said, the image that will stand out most from his major league debut is the first one he saw from the mound last night.

title: Suicide Bombers Kill 25 Near Ramadi, Dealing Blow to Recent Gains Against Insurgents
description: BAGHDAD, May 7  Two suicide car bombs killed 25 people near Ramadi on Monday, the provincial security chief said, dealing a blow to a city recently considered a showcase for the strategy of integrating former insurgents into the Iraqi security forces.

title: Pavano Visiting Doctor; Igawa Packs for Class A
description: The Yankees planned for Carl Pavano and Kei Igawa to hold down spots in their rotation this season. Yesterday, both were making plans to leave town.

title: Japanese Premier Makes Gift to War Shrine but Does Not Visit
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, May 8  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan made a ceremonial offering to a controversial Tokyo war shrine last month but did not go himself, a shrine official said Tuesday.

title: Senate Vote Upholds Drug Import Limits
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  The Senate voted on Monday to preserve current restrictions on the importing of lower-cost prescription drugs from Canada and other countries, fearing that such imports could pose risks to consumers, even with new safeguards.

title: Report on Child Deaths Finds Some Hope in Poorest Nations
description: The rate at which young children perish has worsened most disastrously over the past 15 years in Iraq, hard hit by both sanctions and war, and in Botswana, Zimbabwe and Swaziland, devastated by AIDS, according to a report released yesterday by Save the Children. But researchers also found against-the-odds progress in some of the worlds poorest nations.

title: Liberty Mutual to Buy Ohio Casualty
description: The Liberty Mutual Group, one of the largest business insurers in the United States, agreed yesterday to buy a competitor, the Ohio Casualty Corporation, for $2.7 billion in cash to increase its sales through independent agents.

title: Watching Kids Behind Bars as They Ripen Into Adults
description: A cheap and easy critical approach to a crime documentary is to look at the opening scene. Try this at home: If a program opens on a rough, hot city block with torn chain link and kids hanging out, the film is probably going to have a bleeding heart. In its long and loving look, misty as a bobby-soxers gaze at James Dean, we get the picture. These are the neglected toughs who might be rehabilitated by the gentle hand of a social worker or a Brown-educated filmmaker.

title: Manhattan School Survey Pushed Back
description: The Department of Education has extended a deadline for surveys measuring satisfaction in the schools from May 18 to June 1, officials said. The surveys, for parents, teachers and students from grades 6 to 12, are part of a $2 million city effort. The Education Departments Web site said the auditing giant KPMG, which produced the survey, was not able to send out all copies on time, but promised all parents should receive them sometime this week. A spokesman for KPMG said the extended deadline ensures the broadest possible participation. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced the project last week, calling it the most extensive effort in the history of American education to solicit a communitys ideas and views about their public schools.

title: Manhattan Drug Research Benefits University
description: New York University received $650 million Friday from Royalty Pharma, a privately held New York company, for rights to a portion of its royalties from the drug Remicade, an anti-inflammatory agent used to treat rheumatoid arthritis. Jan Vilcek and Junming Le, researchers at N.Y.U.s School of Medicine, helped develop the monoclonal antibody that led to the drug, in collaboration with Centocor, a biotechnology company. Since Remicade came to market in 1998, the university has received about $365 million in royalties from it, including about $90 million last year. In 2005, Dr. Vilcek, a professor of microbiology, pledged to give N.Y.U.s medical school $105 million. The Remicade royalties have helped place N.Y.U. among the universities collecting the most royalties annually.

title: In Return to Work, Corzine Agrees to Take Things Gradually
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 7  Saying that his absence from a job that he loves was driving him stir-crazy, Gov. Jon S. Corzine resumed his official duties on Monday morning, three and a half weeks after sustaining serious injuries in a car crash.

title: Obama Criticizes Automakers on Fuel Economy
description: DETROIT, May 7  Senator Barack Obama of Illinois delivered a stern message to Detroit auto companies on Monday, saying they had done little to lessen the nations dependence on foreign oil and needed to improve the fuel efficiency of their vehicles.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Thursday about negotiations between the White House and Congress over a new war-spending measure carried an inaccurate transcription by the White House for a comment by President Bush, who had criticized Congress for trying to use an Iraq spending bill to mandate troop withdrawal. Mr. Bush said, Im a commander guy, meaning he was siding with military commanders, not politicians. He did not say, Im the commander guy. The White House issued a corrected transcript on May 4 after reviewing a recording. (Go to Article)

title: More Hotel Rooms May Temper Rate Rises
description: With many new hotel rooms planned in the next couple of years, the industry is clearly optimistic that it will have little problem filling them.

title: Plan B for Iraq Exists, Like It or Not (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkey With All the Trimmings in Pakistan
description: There is nothing easy about business travel. Nothing. And I should know. Im traveling about two weeks a month, both domestically and internationally. Ten countries and 10 states in 10 weeks is my personal record.

title: Where History Reigns
description: Although as a child I had turtles named Disraeli and Gladstone, I was never invited to sip Champagne with the queen until yesterday. Although Ive been an Anglophile all my life, I was never able to participate in a fawning orgy of Albion worship until the British ambassadors party for the monarch yesterday afternoon.

title: A White-Tie Dinner for Queens White House Visit
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Presidents come and go, but for more than half a century, the queen has always been the queen.

title: President of Jewish Congress Resigns After 3 Years Turmoil
description: The World Jewish Congress, the tiny nonprofit organization that won billions of dollars for Holocaust survivors, said yesterday that Edgar M. Bronfman Sr., the billionaire liquor magnate who is its largest patron, had resigned as its president.

title: Find a Penny: This Is a Real New York Story (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Wall St. Journal Editors Held News of Murdoch Bid
description: One of the trickiest things for a news organization to do is cover itself.

title: British Bachelor-Partiers Are Taking Their Revels East
description: PRAGUE  By midnight, wearing nothing but his socks, Paul Roe had crawled the length of a strip club catwalk here, led on a leash by one barechested blonde woman while another whipped him with a belt.

title: Official Who Oversees Gulf Oil Drilling to Retire
description: Johnnie Burton, the top federal official overseeing Gulf of Mexico oil and gas drilling, will retire, effective at the end of this month, Dirk Kempthorne, the interior secretary, said yesterday.

title: Guests at the State Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, were the guests of honor Monday at a state dinner at the White House.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 9:30 P.M. (Sundance Channel) ART FROM THE ARCTIC  Between 2003 and 2005 David Buckland, a British filmmaker, organized three sailing expeditions to the high Arctic as part of his Cape Farewell project, a collaboration among artists, educators and scientists created to focus attention on climate change. This film follows those expeditions as artists like the sculptors Max Eastley and Rachel Whiteread, the photographer Alex Hartley and the writer Ian McEwan are inspired by the otherworldly sights and sounds. Above, an installation by Heather Ackroyd and Dan Harvey.

title: Board Urges Modest Range for Rises in Stabilized Rents
description: The board that regulates rents for New York Citys one million rent-stabilized apartments proposed tentative increases last night of 2 to 4.5 percent on one-year lease renewals and 4 to 7.5 percent on two-year leases, which could mean smaller increases than last years when the board holds a final vote next month.

title: Doing Good on Company Time
description: Companies have been using off-site meetings and retreats to foster a sense of camaraderie among employees for decades, but obstacle courses or golf tournaments are becoming as dated as guaranteed frequent-flier upgrades to first class. Today, more corporations are turning to hands-on volunteer projects to get their people motivated and working as a team.

title: Deal Is Offered for Chiefs Exit at World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Leading governments of Europe, mounting a new campaign to push Paul D. Wolfowitz from his job as World Bank president, signaled Monday that they were willing to let the United States choose the banks next chief, but only if Mr. Wolfowitz stepped down soon, European officials said.

title: Stamping Out Diverse Voices
description: Postal rate increases are an unwelcome fact of life for every magazine publisher. But it seems the steep new increases for periodicals, scheduled to begin on July 15, will inflict undue hardship on small independent magazines that do much to inform the national discourse on politics and culture. They will be required to pay a much higher percentage increase than some of the largest magazines.

title: HBO Chairman Held in Dispute With Girlfriend
description: Chris Albrecht, the chairman of HBO, was charged with domestic assault and battery after an altercation with a girlfriend Sunday morning, a Las Vegas police spokesman said yesterday.

title: A Misunderstanding, and a Simple Life Descends Into a Nightmare
description: The heroine of Richard Flanagans stunning new novel is an Australian pole dancer known as the Doll, and like Cary Grant or Jimmy Stewart in a Hitchcock movie, she finds herself being mistaken for someone else and falling, abruptly, down a black rabbit hole, her identity stolen, her daily life torpedoed, her most fundamental expectations about life blown to smithereens.

title: Russell W. Kruse, Auctioneer of Classic Autos, Dies at 85
description: Russell W. Kruse, whose sonorous voice auctioned off everything from funeral parlors to castles, but who achieved fame for thinking up and building the business of auctioning classic cars, including ones owned by the pope and Al Capone, died Friday, in Fort Wayne, Ind. He was 85.

title: Inquiry Into Mans Death Fuels Unease in Mount Kisco
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., May 7  At 10:47 p.m. on April 28, a homeless Guatemalan man known to roam the streets, plucking cans and bottles from trash cans and causing trouble when he was drunk, dialed 911 from the pay phone at a Laundromat here.

title: Brooklyn Woman Found Dead After Fire
description: The police and the city medical examiner said yesterday they were investigating the death of a 31-year-old Bedford-Stuyvesant woman who was burned when a fire broke out in her home, but who also suffered puncture wounds to the front and back of her torso. Firefighters were called to 39 Rochester Avenue about 1:30 a.m. and found the woman, who was identified by acquaintances as Wanette Douglas. Her 5-year-old daughter, Tkyha Douglas, suffered smoke inhalation and was treated at Kings County Hospital Center, the authorities said.

title: House Democrats May Seek Short-Term Financing of War
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  House Democrats may push ahead this week with a new war spending bill that would provide money for combat operations through midsummer, with the rest of the funds sought by President Bush withheld until commanders in Iraq provide a report on conditions there.

title: EADS Hoping to Increase Military Work for the U.S.
description: TOULOUSE, France, May 7  The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company wants to expand its military activities in the United States, and friendly governments in both France and Germany could help further that goal, the companys co-chief executive said on Monday.

title: East Coast Money Lent Out West
description: AGOURA HILLS, Calif.  Visitors to Ownit Mortgage Solutions offices here are met by an abandoned reception desk and three dying potted plants that appear to have gone months without water.

title: Baseball Ignores a Problem More Deadly Than Steroids
description: Alcohol last week killed one more major league baseball player than steroids ever have.

title: Couple Expected to Plead Guilty to Insider Trading This Week
description: A former Morgan Stanley compliance officer and her husband are expected to plead guilty this week to charges stemming from an insider-trading case that prosecutors say was part of the largest such scheme on Wall Street since the 1980s.

title: A Lonesome Tortoise, and a Search for a Mate
description: It is a truth universally acknowledged, at least among humans, that a giant tortoise in the possession of the last sperm of his species must be in want of a wife. But what if the tortoise prefers a different lifestyle?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A theater review yesterday about Bad Blood (Malasangre), at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater on West 47th Street, misspelled the surname of the actor who plays Don Augusto. He is Felipe Javier Gorostiza, not Corostiza.

title: New Bid for Energy Concern
description: The Macquarie Bank, Australias largest securities firm, made a new takeover offer for the energy transmission company Alinta to challenge Alintas agreement to be acquired for 7.4 billion Australian dollars ($6.1 billion) by Babcock & Brown and Singapore Power. Alinta, based in Perth, Australia, is seeking further information on the revised offer. Macquarie, based in Sydney, said its proposal included three options, one of them an all-cash bid. Macquarie did not disclose further details. Both Macquarie and Babcock plan to break up the utility, which has a nationwide network of gas and power lines, and generates electricity at five plants. Alinta rejected Macquaries earlier offer on March 30.

title: Study Suggests Meditation Can Help Train Attention
description: In meditation, people sit quietly and concentrate on their breath. As air swooshes in and out of their nostrils, they attend to each sensation. As unbidden thoughts flutter to mind, they let them go. Breathe. Let go. Breathe. Let go.

title: How the Inca Leapt Canyons
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Conquistadors from Spain came, they saw and they were astonished. They had never seen anything in Europe like the bridges of Peru. Chroniclers wrote that the Spanish soldiers stood in awe and fear before the spans of braided fiber cables suspended across deep gorges in the Andes, narrow walkways sagging and swaying and looking so frail.

title: Lottery Numbers
Earnhardt Becomes the Latest Driver to Turn Against the Car of Tomorrow
description: CONCORD, N.C., May 7  After four races in the Car of Tomorrow, Dale Earnhardt Jr. said he had had enough. On Monday, Earnhardt, the sports most popular driver and among the most influential, joined the list of critics of the new racecar, which is being phased into the Nextel Cup series this season.

title: U.S. Debates Deterrence for Nuclear Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Every week, a group of experts from agencies around the government  including the C.I.A., the Pentagon, the F.B.I. and the Energy Department  meet to assess Washingtons progress toward solving a grim problem: if a terrorist set off a nuclear bomb in an American city, could the United States determine who detonated it and who provided the nuclear material?

title: France Under New Leadership
description: The French (like many Americans) have grown increasingly tired of their cranky and ineffective president, Jacques Chirac. With Nicolas Sarkozy theyve certainly gotten a very different sort of leader. A graduate of a non-elite university, and the son of a Hungarian immigrant, he won this weeks election promising sweeping change to voters impatient with their countrys long economic and diplomatic decline. But to succeed, Mr. Sarkozy will need to keep his own impatience, and his destructive penchant for divisive rhetoric, under firm control.

title: Ukraine Gas Pipeline Hit by Blast
description: An explosion destroyed a section of a pipeline in Ukraine carrying Russian natural gas to Europe. No injuries were reported, and technicians quickly rerouted the gas to other pipelines. In a telephone interview, Ihor I. Kroll, a spokesman for the Ministry of Emergency Situations, played down the possibility of sabotage. But later in the day, the minister for transport, Mykola Rudkovsky, said on Ukrainian television that the pipe might have been sabotaged as part of a planned attempt to destabilize the country, the Interfax news agency in Russia reported. Russia provides about a quarter of Europes natural gas, 80 percent of which is pumped through aging pipes on Ukraines territory. Gazprom, the Russian natural gas company, said its customers in Europe would not be affected.

title: Special of the Day: Peace of Mind
description: WATCHUNG, N.J.

title: Isabella Blow, Flamboyant Discoverer of Fashion Talent, Dies at 48
description: Isabella Blow, a British fashion editor, aristocrat and aesthete whose gift for identifying and promoting new talent was occasionally overshadowed by her own Surrealist plumage, died yesterday in Gloucestershire, England. She was 48.

title: The Struggle to Move Beyond Why Me?
description: Six days after my husband and I returned from a trip to Aruba  our first real vacation without our children  my doctor told me I had breast cancer. I had felt a lump in my breast before the trip, but decided to wait to have it checked. Id had lumps before, and they had always turned out to be nothing. But this one wasnt nothing. It was Stage 2 invasive ductal carcinoma.

title: For Democrats, New Challenge in Age-Old Rift
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Almost nothing rouses as much passion, anger or history for the Democrats as the issue of trade.

title: Liquor Maker Ups the Ante a Bit in Discouraging Young Drinkers
description: THERE was another round yesterday in the continuing sparring over alcohol advertising, as Beam Global Spirits and Wine  which makes brands like Jim Beam and Makers Mark bourbon and Canadian Club whiskey  announced it would voluntarily adopt stricter rules to keep messages away from young people.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Advertising Club, New York, presented the 2007 International Andy Awards for campaigns that appeared in 2006. For the first time, the Best of Show Award, known as the Grandy, was presented to a digital campaign. The winning agency, R/GA, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was honored for work for Nike Plus, the running shoe that comes with an iPod Nano. The campaign also won another award, sponsored by Yahoo, called the Big Idea Chair. Offices of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, won the most Andys, 14, followed by offices of Leo Burnett Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe, with 10. The honor for best in show for public service advertising, known as the Richard T. OReilly Award, went to the Truth anti-smoking campaign created by Arnold Worldwide, Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas, and Crispin Porter & Bogusky, Miami, part of MDC Partners.

title: Yankees Rein in Expectations of Clemens
description: The Yankees have gotten the headlines and the hope. They will have to wait several weeks to see if the signing of Roger Clemens actually gets them much-needed victories.

title: In the Desert, a Festival of Country and Its Kin
description: INDIO, Calif., May 7  What does country music sound like in 2007? Well, around 3:15 on Sunday afternoon here in the California desert it sounded like a Chinese folk song struggling to be heard over a Guns N Roses medley.

title: At Risk: Study Shows Flu Season Increases Heart Ailments
description: Heart attacks and chronic heart disease both increase sharply during flu season, according to a large new study based on autopsy reports in St. Petersburg, Russia.

title: Pakistan Court Halts Inquiry of Top Judge
description: The Supreme Court suspended proceedings against Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, Pakistans suspended chief justice, before a five-judge panel known as the Supreme Judicial Council. The council began hearing accusations of misconduct and abuse of power against Mr. Chaudhry after President Pervez Musharraf suspended him in March. Mr. Chaudhry, meanwhile, went to the Supreme Court to challenge the councils authority and impartiality. In addition to halting the council inquiry, the Supreme Court also recommended that Mr. Chaudhrys complaints be heard by the full Supreme Court. The decision followed a mass rally in support of Mr. Chaudhry over the weekend.

title: Top Chef Dreams Crushed by Student Loan Debt
description: Rick Park started working at a Jack in the Box in Austin, Tex., when he was 18. He moved on to sub shops, pizza parlors and chain restaurants, turning out hundreds of meals during a shift.

title: U.S. Trainers Killer Was Afghan Soldier
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 7  The man who shot and killed two American military trainers and wounded two others on Sunday was a soldier in the Afghan National Army, the Afghan Defense Ministry confirmed Monday.

title: Tapes Capture Bold Claims of Bronx Man in Terror Plot
description: You really want to learn how to rip somebodys throat out? Tarik Shah asked the man he thought was a terrorist. It was March 2004, and Mr. Shah did not know that the man was recording him for the government.

title: Manhattan Challenge for Metal Bat Law
description: Several baseball bat manufacturers, baseball coaches, parents and players filed a lawsuit yesterday seeking to overturn New York Citys recent ban on metal bats in high school baseball games. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, claims the new law unjustifiably prohibits the use of bats that are preferred by the vast majority of players, coaches and teams and that are already regulated by national high school sports officials. The City Council, which approved the ban last month over Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs veto, said baseballs fly off metal bats faster than they do off wooden ones, making them more dangerous. Officials of the city Law Department said they would evaluate the lawsuit thoroughly.

title: Child Care: Regular Television Time Starts for Many at 3 Months
description: For many families, apparently, it is never too early to watch television. Researchers reported yesterday that 40 percent of infants are regular viewers of television or videos by age 3 months, and 90 percent are watching regularly by age 2.

title: Cuomo Announces Inquiry Into Conflicts Under Hevesi
description: ALBANY, May 7  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday that his office was investigating very troubling, serious, systemic conflicts of interest in the way the comptrollers office has managed the states $145 billion pension fund.

title: Political Progress in Iraq as Violence Continues
description: BAGHDAD, May 8  The threat of a walkout by Iraqs leading Sunni Arab bloc in Parliament and the Cabinet seemed to subside Tuesday after a meeting between Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a Shiite, and Tariq al-Hashimi, the Sunni vice president.

title: Pavlovics Offense Is No Longer His Defense
description: CLEVELAND, May 7  Sasha Pavlovic insisted he was trying to make a joke. Perhaps it was lost in translation, considering Serbian is his first language.

title: The Claim: Aspirin Can Reduce the Risk of Alzheimers Disease
description: THE FACTS

title: Quebec Separatist Leader Resigns
description: QUEBEC, May 8  The leader of the separatist Parti Qubcois, Andr Boisclair, resigned today, further destabilizing a sovereignty movement that was left in shambles after a third-place finish in provincial elections in March.

title: Congress and the Student Loan Scam
description: Republicans in Congress have generally defended corporate welfare for companies involved in the student loan business: lenders that collect billions of dollars in federal subsidies in return for issuing government-backed loans that represent no real risk to the companies themselves. But support for these wasteful subsidies is waning in both parties, thanks to recent revelations showing just how corrupt and costly the program has become.

title: Romeos and Juliets: Young, Impetuous, for Real
description: New York City Ballets new Romeo and Juliet begins with a bit of mood-creating romantic spontaneity for Romeo: two or three arabesque poses alone, then, when his chums Mercutio and Benvolio join him, he waxes more poetic with a few richly dimensional pirouettes. As a solo, it at first looks piffling. But Peter Martins, this productions choreographer and the companys ballet master in chief, is giving audiences a choice of four Romeos and four Juliets, and that sketchy opening dance demonstrates how he has encouraged his Romeos to find their own voices.

title: ABC Sets Spring 2010 as the End for Lost
description: LOS ANGELES, May 7  ABC announced on Monday that it would broadcast three more seasons of its hit castaway mystery, Lost, ending the show in 2010 after a run of six seasons.

title: From DNA Analysis, Clues to a Single Australian Migration
description: Geneticists re-examining the first settlement of Australia and Papua-New Guinea by modern humans have concluded that the two islands were reached some 50,000 years ago by a single group of people who remained in substantial or total isolation until recent times. The finding, if upheld, would undermine assumptions that there have been subsequent waves of migration into Australia.

title: Power Sharing Begins in Northern Ireland
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 8  Paying tribute today to the thousands of victims in one of Europes bloodiest sectarian conflicts, the leaders of Northern Ireland drew a formal line under decades of hostility and strife, re-establishing a power-sharing local authority of once implacable foes.

title: Deciphering the Results of a Prostate Test
description: After his annual physical, a middle-age man is told that his PSA level has jumped to 2.3 after having been stable for years at 1.5. Should he be alarmed?

title: Waiters Claim Harassment at Mr. Chow
description: Michael Chow, a flamboyant artist, entrepreneur and owner of two elegant Chinese restaurants in Manhattan, does everything with singular flair, so it was hardly surprising that when three waiters sued him yesterday, it was in no way a run-of-the-mill lawsuit.

title: Los Angeles Punishes Police Official Over Clash at Demonstration
description: LOS ANGELES, May 7  The citys mayor and its police chief said Monday that one of the highest-ranking officials in the Police Department would be demoted and transferred in the wake of a violent confrontation between officers and demonstrators at an immigration rally last week.

title: Genes Take Charge, and Diets Fall by the Wayside
description: It was 1959. Jules Hirsch, a research physician at Rockefeller University, had gotten curious about weight loss in the obese. He was about to start a simple experiment that would change forever the way scientists think about fat.

title: Sun Plans Version of Java for Web-Linked Cellphones
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 7  Sun Microsystems plans to revamp its Java software in an effort to compete more effectively in the fast-growing market for Internet-connected mobile phones.

title: More Than Just Talk
description: New Orleans

title: Carving Out Havens and Facing Down the Skeptics
description: Enforcement officers from the citys Department of Parks and Recreation sat in two cars and guarded the locked gates of Hunts Point Riverside Park in the South Bronx last Wednesday.

title: Foes Wary of Street Sense in Preakness
description: Street Sense seems to have some trainers thinking twice about taking him on in the Preakness Stakes on May 19 in Baltimore. From the Derby field, only the runner-up, Hard Spun, has been committed to the Preakness, the second leg of the Triple Crown.

title: Beating by Guards Fails to Stop Voting, Iranian Students Say
description: TEHRAN, May 7  Students at Amir Kabir University fended off club-wielding university security guards on Monday and went ahead with elections for a pro-democracy association.

title: Shanahan and Rangers Left With Questions to Ponder
description: Of all the sadness, disappointment and heartbreak in the Rangers locker room Sunday after they were eliminated from the playoffs, forward Brendan Shanahan wore his most acutely. As the Rangers oldest player, a 38-year-old forward in a younger mans sport, he could not find a minutes solace in the teams hopes for next season.

title: Brooklyn Firefighters Find Homicide Victim
description: A 31-year-old Bedford-Stuyvesant woman whose body was found by firefighters after a fire broke out in her home early yesterday died of strangulation, the city medical examiners office said last night, adding that the death had been ruled a homicide. The police said the woman also had puncture wounds to the front and back of her torso. Firefighters were called to the home, at 39 Rochester Avenue, about 1:30 a.m. and discovered the body of the woman, who was identified by acquaintances as Wanette Douglas. The womans 5-year-old daughter, Tkyha Douglas, was treated for smoke inhalation, the authorities said.

title: Manhattan Court Upholds School Cellphone Ban
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that New York Citys rule prohibiting students from bringing cellphones to public schools was rational, rejecting an effort by parents who had sought to overturn the ban. In a 50-page decision, the justice, Lewis Bart Stone, said the court could decide only whether the rule was a reasonable way to prevent students from using cellphones in school and that he could not suggest a different rule, even if he preferred one. The court finds that banning possession in the school is not an irrational method to accomplish such goal, he wrote. Justice Stone also rejected a claim that the rule violated students and parents constitutional rights. Neither the state nor federal constitutions include any express constitutional right to bear cellphones, he wrote. Norman Siegel, above, a lawyer for the parents, said they were considering an appeal. We will not rest until the ban is lifted, he said. David Cantor, a spokesman for Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, said the city was pleased with the decision.

title: Judges Libel Victory Against Paper Is Upheld
description: BOSTON, May 7  The highest court in Massachusetts upheld a $2 million libel verdict on Monday against The Boston Herald and one of its reporters for articles that said a Superior Court judge had made disparaging comments about crime victims and that he was lenient with criminals.

title: A Producer and a Studio Stay Close Despite Split
description: LOS ANGELES, May 7  Some couples get along better after the divorce. But few stay quite as intimate as Paramount Pictures and its erstwhile producing partner Scott Rudin.

title: Electronic Voting May Be Ready by Fall 08, Official Says
description: Despite earlier predictions to the contrary, New York State could well replace its aging voting machines by September 2008, a co-chairman of the New York State Board of Elections said yesterday.

title: A Sheik and His Uninvited Guests Mirror Uneasy Iraq-U.S. Ties
description: JUWAYBA, Iraq  Nearly every day, the sheik stops by the villa that was once his home, but is now an American garrison. Sometimes he comes with tips about the insurgency, or with news of political developments in this rural village near the Euphrates River.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Paris Hilton Rolls a Head

title: Kalikows Departure Brings Assessments of His Six Turbulent Years as Chairman of the M.T.A.
description: When Peter S. Kalikow announced yesterday that he would be stepping down as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, it marked the end of six eventful and turbulent years, including a bitter transit strike, a bookkeeping scandal and the start of the first major expansion of the citys transit system in decades.

title: Study Links Rescuers Lung Ailment to Trade Center Collapse
description: In the first clinical study to clearly link World Trade Center dust to serious and sometimes fatal diseases, doctors have found that the number of New York City rescue and recovery workers with a rare type of lung-scarring condition soared in the year after the trade center collapsed.

title: A Saucy Way to Get Noticed
description: A new campaign for a popular brand of pasta sauce is taking a humorous tack in an effort to stir the pot in a sleepy category and gain the attention of grocery shoppers.

title: New Coalition of Christians Seeks Changes at Borders
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  A new coalition of more than 100 largely evangelical Christian leaders and organizations asked Congress on Monday to pass bills to strengthen border controls but also give illegal immigrants ways to gain legal residency.

title: No Objections to Immunity Grant
description: Justice Department officials said they would not object to a Congressional grant of immunity to a former senior aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales who played a central role in the dismissals of federal prosecutors. The decision appeared to increase the likelihood that the aide, Monica Goodling, will soon appear before a Congressional panel, under a grant of immunity, to answer questions about last years firings of eight United States attorneys.

title: 50 Years Later, Little Rock Cant Escape Race
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  Fifty years after the epic desegregation struggle at Central High School, the school district here is still riven by racial conflict, casting a pall on this years ambitious commemorative efforts.

title: For Indias Airlines, Passengers Are Plentiful but Profits Are Scarce
description: NEW DELHI, May 7  Emergency landings, chronic delays and millions of dollars in losses  and that is just the month of April.

title: Smithsonian Search Committee Named
description: The Board of Regents at the Smithsonian announced the members of the search committee charged with finding a new secretary of the institution. The chairman of the committee is Alan G. Spoon, a regent and managing general partner of Polaris Venture Partners. Other members are Representative Xavier Becerra, Democrat of California; L. Hardwick Caldwell, chairman of the institutions National Board; Anne dHarnoncourt, a regent and director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art; Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont; Walter E. Massey, president of Morehouse College in Atlanta; Jeffrey Minear, administrative assistant to Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.; and Roger W. Sant, chairman of the regent executive committee.

title: Answering Al Qaeda
description: Washington

title: Fox Interactive Nears Deal to Buy Photobucket
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 7  Photobucket, a four-year-old, rapidly growing Web company, is in advanced talks to be acquired by Fox Interactive Media, a division of the News Corporation, a person briefed on the negotiations said Monday.

title: U.S. Apologizes to Families for Killing Afghan Civilians
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  An Army commander apologized and paid compensation on Tuesday to families of Afghan civilians killed by marines after a suicide attack in March, marking the first formal acknowledgment by American authorities that the killings were unjustified.

title: Chevron Seen Settling Case on Iraq Oil
description: Chevron, the second-largest American oil company, is preparing to acknowledge that it should have known kickbacks were being paid to Saddam Hussein on oil it bought from Iraq as part of a defunct United Nations program, according to investigators.

title: Hundreds Are Arrested in Post-Election Riots Across France
description: PARIS, May 7  Violent protests against the election of Nicolas Sarkozy as president of France ended early Monday after hundreds of people were arrested, hundreds of cars gutted, and hundreds of windows smashed in several cities across France.

title: Stealth Killer Puts Doctor on Mission With N.F.L.
description: The long ago quarterback and retired heart surgeon was 58 when he discovered how much he knew about human frailty, just not his own.

title: Relationship Counseling, With Hand Signs for Sex and Cry
description: Its hard to write a comedy thats funny in more than one language. Christopher Durang can congratulate himself. More than a quarter-century after he wrote Beyond Therapy, it is still very funny in a language not generally mentioned in discussions of the translators art: American Sign Language.

title: Revisiting, and Revising, a Very Familiar Legend
description: She was bright and curious, probably between 10 and 14. He was a cocky adventurer, short and hairy, about 28 when they met.

title: Errors Lead to Giants Big Inning and Doom Mets
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 7  The Mets spent so much time in the field during the fifth inning of Mondays game that they could have counted how many fans were sitting in Section 108. Anything to distract them from Giants stampeding around the bases. In all, 12 came to the plate, and surprise, surprise, Barry Bonds played only a minor role as his teammates tagged the Mets for nine runs in their 9-4 victory.

title: Nigerian Bishop Criticizes Episcopal Church
description: In a letter to the archbishop of Canterbury, the Anglican Archbishop of Nigeria, Peter J. Akinola, harshly criticized the Episcopal Church for what he called an insulting and condescending response to demands by primates of the worldwide Anglican Communion to establish a parallel oversight structure for disaffected congregations and dioceses in the United States. Archbishop Akinola arrived in Virginia late last week to install a new bishop for one such structure, rejecting requests to cancel his trip from the archbishop of Canterbury, the leader of the communion, and the presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church, the American branch of Anglicanism. Archbishop Akinola dismissed concerns that he was exacerbating tensions over a longstanding dispute regarding the churchs liberal stance on homosexuality, blaming instead the Episcopal Church for the crisis.

title: Adolescence: No Link to Promiscuity Found in Youths Using Condoms
description: A new study has found that adolescents who use condoms the first time they have intercourse do not go on to have more sexual partners than others, and that they have lower rates of sexually transmitted diseases than those who do not use condoms the first time.

title: Albany: New Rules for Tuition Loans
description: Both houses of the State Legislature passed legislation yesterday to sharply restrict the relationships between colleges and the companies that make tuition loans to their students. The legislation follows an investigation by Andrew M. Cuomo, the state attorney general, into hundreds of colleges, lenders and alumni associations that have admitted to or are suspected of steering loans to prospective students in exchange for gifts, trips or payments from lenders. The bill, which Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to sign, prohibits colleges from soliciting or accepting any gifts or money from lenders in exchange for recommending them to students, and prohibits lenders staff members from working out of college financial aid offices, among other provisions.

title: Alcoa Makes a Hostile Bid for Alcan
description: MONTREAL, May 7  The success of Alcoas hostile $27 billion takeover offer for the rival Alcan of Canada may rest as much with politicians as investors.

title: Boy, 1, Dies and 3 Are Hurt in Brooklyn Basement Fire
description: A 1-year-old boy was killed and three of his relatives were critically injured yesterday morning when a fire broke out in an illegal basement apartment in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: A Moment of Revelation, Preserved in a Test Stick
description: If I ever manage to assemble a baby book about my son, here are some of the things Ill put in it: the tiny onesie I bought when I was just a few weeks pregnant, and the first ghostly ultrasound print my husband and I received. (We named it Reclining Nude.)

title: Clear Channel Postpones Vote, Giving Suitors Bid More Time
description: Clear Channel Communications, owner of the largest network of radio stations in the nation, yesterday postponed a shareholder vote on a revised buyout offer by two private equity firms.

title: Soaring for the Most Important Women in Their Lives
description: Mothers Day is hardly a red-letter event in the modern-dance world. But for Urban Bush Women, who open tonight at the Joyce Theater, it seems only natural that the company would celebrate the holiday in a performance this Sunday afternoon.

title: Jury Is Still Out on Gluten, the Latest Dietary Villain
description: Brandi Walzer, a 29-year-old cartographer in Savannah, Ga., loves bread, not to mention pizza and beer. But she tries to avoid them, because they contain gluten  a substance she says upsets her stomach, aggravates her arthritis and touches off depression.

title: Consumer Borrowing Increased in March by Most in 4 Months
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (Bloomberg News)  Consumer borrowing increased in March by the most in four months as Americans charged more purchases to their credit cards and took out more car loans, Federal Reserve figures show.

title: Laptops in School: Boon or Bane? (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Alcoa Makes a Bid for Alcan of Canada
description: MONTREAL, May 7  Alcoa made an unsolicited $27 billion offer today for rival Alcan of Canada, which would propel it to the top spot in the aluminum industry, a position it surrendered just months ago.

title: Ramapo Man Arrested After Gunfire in Courtroom
description: A 60-year-old man was arrested last night after he fired a .22 caliber rifle in a village courtroom in Rockland County, the police said. No one was injured when, the Ramapo Police Department said, Leo Lewis, a party in a civil case in the village court in Sloatsburg, pulled out the rifle and fired a single shot toward the front of the courtroom. Mr. Lewis had been scheduled for a hearing around 6 p.m. at the Sloatsburg courthouse, which also serves as the village hall. The police said it was unclear if Mr. Lewis was aiming at anyone. They said he ran out of the courtroom after the shot, and a Sloatsburg court officer and Ramapo police officer gave chase. The Ramapo officer fired one shot during the chase, but it did not hit anyone, the authorities said. A civilian outside the building helped the officers catch Mr. Lewis. No charges had been filed as of late last night.

title: Cheering Change at the lyse, and in Neighbors Attitudes
description: All in all, the French who live and work in New York had reason to feel chipper yesterday. In even greater percentages than their compatriots back home, they had voted strongly for Nicolas Sarkozy to be Frances next president. On Sunday, their jour de gloire arrived.

title: Across the Sea Under Power From the Sun
description: So far, the five Swiss sailors aboard the sun21 have not run into trouble the way Giovanni da Verrazano did.

title: Memo Pad
description: AIR TRAVEL DELAYS ARE UP Delays on domestic flights rose in the first quarter, with 25.25 percent of flights arriving late, compared with 21.35 percent in the first quarter of last year, the Bureau of Transportation Statistics said yesterday. The number of lost or otherwise mishandled checked bags rose in March  to 7.71 per 1,000 passengers compared with 5.81 per 1,000 passengers in March 2006.

title: Bonds Is Doing His Talking With a Bat in His Hands
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 7  Barry Bonds has averaged a home run once every three games this season. So, entering Monday nights game against the Mets needing 12 home runs to break Hank Aarons record of 755, it stands to reason that Bonds is more than capable of coming to Shea Stadium in three weeks with a chance to make history. Wouldnt that be fun?

title: 20 Years Later, Again Assigned to Fight Climate Change
description: Gro Harlem Brundtland is back on the case.

title: Monroe Township: Minor Injuries in School Bus Crash
description: Twenty-two elementary school students sustained minor injuries yesterday morning when two school buses collided in central New Jersey, the authorities said. A driver of one of the buses was also hurt in the crash, which occurred about 9 a.m. in Monroe Township. The authorities said the collision, near the intersection of Buckelew Avenue and Schoolhouse Road, occurred when a bus that had stopped to pick up children was rear-ended by another bus. The students, some of whom were removed on backboards and wearing neck braces, were treated at four area hospitals. The injuries included facial cuts and complaints of back and neck pain. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: People
description: People

title: An Irish Taste for Real Estate in Manhattan
description: They live an ocean away, but that has not stopped the Irish from lining up to buy condominiums in Midtown Manhattan, often years before they are built.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,361 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Icahn Appears to Fall Short at Motorola
description: CHICAGO, May 7  The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn came to Chicago on Monday to attend Motorolas shareholders meeting, with some expectation that he would get elected to the board.

title: Sale of Carbon Credits Helping Land-Rich, but Cash-Poor, Tribes
description: LAPWAI, Idaho  On the Nez Perce reservation here, land that was cleared in the 19th century for farming is being converted back to forest, in part to sell the trees ability to sequester carbon.

title: ABN Amro Rejects $24.5 Billion Bid for LaSalle
description: LONDON, May 7  ABN Amro on Monday rejected a $24.5 billion bid from the Royal Bank of Scotland Group and two partners for its American unit, the LaSalle Bank  putting the fate of the Dutch bank, which is at the center of a large and complex takeover battle, more in the hands of shareholders.

title: Virginia Lacrosse Team Finds  Reluctant Leader
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 3  Ben Rubeor rolls up his sleeve to show the underside of his left forearm. The raised scars that are scattered from his wrist to his elbow are pinkish now, but for a long time they were almost purple.

title: Clemens, Redux (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Museum for Artifacts of the News Medias Hunters and Gatherers
description: WASHINGTON  Time magazines armored truck from the Balkans, pockmarked with bullet holes, has been hoisted into place. The laptop used by Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter murdered in Pakistan in 2002, has arrived. So has the vest that Bob Woodruff of ABC was wearing last year when he was wounded by a roadside bomb in Iraq.

title: Patterns: Early Menarche Linked to Heavier Children
description: The younger a woman is when she has her first period, the more likely her children are to be overweight, a new study suggests.

title: Israeli Premier Survives Votes in Parliament
description: JERUSALEM, May 7  Israels prime minister, Ehud Olmert, survived three no-confidence votes against his government on Monday, part of the political fallout from a harsh report on the countrys leadership during last summers war in Lebanon.

title: Abortion Rises Anew for Giuliani
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Rudolph W. Giuliani told a gathering of conservatives Monday that his campaign could be boiled down to two major themes: national security and economic security.

title: Mozarts Figaro, With a Cast in First-Marriage Age Bracket
description: Mozarts Nozze di Figaro often has an added resonance when performed by a cast of young, eager singers who have fresh memories of adolescent crushes and romantic stirrings. This was true of the production by Mannes Opera on Sunday afternoon in the Kaye Playhouse of Hunter College. (The performance was the second of two.) The likable, well-schooled and endearing cast had both undergraduates and students in the masters programs at Mannes College the New School for Music, so the average age was the early 20s.

title: Devil Rays Tempting Fans With a Field Trip
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 3  Under the dome of Tropicana Field, Carlos Pea hit a pop-up that never came down. It lodged in the ceiling for a foul ball. Next time up, in the 10th inning, Pea hit another pop-up that caromed off a catwalk and landed for a single behind the confused Minnesota infielders.

title: Its Still Dark Out, So Why Are the Birds Singing Away?
description: Being the divas that they are, songbirds dont like noise. Urban birds have been known to alter their songs to be heard above the racket  making them shorter, higher pitched or louder, or changing their patterns.

title: Lost on Metro-North, but Most Likely Found
description: It is not too much of a stretch to say that Mike Nolan has seen just about everything there is to see in his line of work, from commuters searching for their false teeth to Pete Seegers banjo to thousands of dollars in cash tucked into a pair of socks.

title: Pavano Says He Has Elbow Tear
description: Carl Pavano talked after the game and said he would meet with Dr. Frank Jobe on Wednesday in California. A couple of writers reminded him he was actually seeing Dr. Lewis Yocum.

title: Top Chef Dreams Crushed by Student Loan Debt
description: Many would-be top chefs face a challenge that most lawyers, engineers or nurses do not: few jobs in their chosen field pay enough for them to retire their student loans. As a result, as many as 11 percent of graduates at some culinary schools are defaulting on federal student loans. The national average for all students last year was roughly half that, at 5.1 percent.

title: Tread Lightly
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Replacing Kyoto
description: More than 1000 Delegates from more than 160 nations began meeting today in Bonn to decide what kind of treaty should replace the 10 year old Kyoto Protocol, which expires in 2012. That program, which sets targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions in developed nations, was never signed by the United States (the worlds largest emitter) and did not apply to China and India (two other major polluters) because they are developing nations.

title: The Exodus
description: Millions of Iraqis have fled their country, creating the largest Mideast refugee problem since 1948.

title: Trouble in paradise  or not
description: A rash of alarming headlines regarding the Spanish property market in recent weeks are enough to give anyone the impression that the market is on the verge of collapse. The event that inspired the doom-and-gloom articles was a share price correction of property companies quoted on the Madrid stock exchange. But, according to one expert, falling stock market confidence is not the same as a housing market crash.

title: Zurich Capital Settles Probe into Market-Timing
description: Zurich Capital Markets agreed to pay $16.8 million to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of alleged market-timing of mutual funds. The S.E.C. said that between 1999 and 2003, Zurich Capital, a unit of Zurich Financial, made $11 million by helping four hedge funds that were defrauding mutual funds through illegal market timing.

title: Macquarie Fires Up New Alinta Bid
description: The Macquarie Bank, Australias largest securities firm, made a new takeover offer for the energy transmission company Alinta to challenge Alintas agreement to be acquired for 7.4 billion Australian dollars ($6.1 billion) by Babcock & Brown and Singapore Power.

title: Buyout Group Abandons Qantas Bid
description: The buyout group bidding for Qantas Airways of Australia on Tuesday declared its offer of 11 billion Australian dollars ($9 billion) had lapsed after deciding not to pursue a legal case to keep the takeover alive. The group, Airline Partners Australia, said it believed that Qantas shareholders need more certainty and, accordingly, it has determined that its bid should be treated as having lapsed on May 4, 2007.

title: BAE Buys Armor Holdings for $4 Billion
description: The military contractor BAE Systems said it had agreed to buy Armor Holdings, a maker of armored vehicles for the United States military, for $4.1 billion. BAE Systems, based in London, agreed to pay $88 a share for Armor Holdings, a 7 percent premium over its closing price Friday. BAE is also assuming $388 million in debt.

title: Fund With Rinker Stake Backs Cemex Offer
description: The largest shareholder of the Rinker Group, an Australian building company, said it had approved a $14.25 billion bid from Cemex, the Mexican cement company. Perpetual, a fund manager in Sydney that owns a 10.5 percent stake in Rinker, said it would accept Cemexs amended offer.

title: Subprime Mortgages: A Cross-Country Blame Game
description: What used to be a profitable partnership between subprime lenders and Wall Street banks has degenerated into a cross-country blame game. Lenders in California say big investment banks encouraged and pushed them to make risky loans. On Wall Street, bank executives say mortgage lenders became sloppy and did not pay enough attention to fraud.

title: Could BHP Be the First $120 Billion Buyout Target?
description: BHP Billiton once considered a possible suitor for Alcoa, which began a hostile bid of its own for Alcan, may become a target itself.

title: Icahn Appears to Fall Short at Motorola
description: The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn came to Chicago on Monday for Motorolas shareholders meeting, with some hope that he would be elected to the board. But by late in the day, as the politics played out, Mr. Icahn conceded that he had lost his proxy fight and had failed to garner enough support from large funds to become a director.

title: Theater Awards Are Announced
description: The New York Drama Critics' Circle has named "The Coast of Utopia" by Tom Stoppard the best play of the 2006-7 season.

title: J.P. Morgans Dimon Talks Deal Making
description: Following comments last year by James Dimon that J.P. Morgan Chase was ready to do some deal making, the banks chief executive provided a few more details on the subject, but still appeared to be hedging his bets.

title: Jerry Mathers Joins the Cast of Hairspray
