description: Jerry Mathers, best known for his portrayal of Theodore (Beaver) Cleaver in the 1950s family comedy "Leave it to Beaver," will be joining the cast of "Hairspray" on June 5.

title: Deutsche Sells 60 Wall St. for $1.1 Billion
description: Deutsche Bank said Friday that it is selling its North American headquarters in Manhattan for $1.18 billion to the Paramount Group, a real estate firm. Deutsche, the latest company to take advantage of a sizzling commercial real estate market, bought the 1.6 million-square-foot 60 Wall St. from J.P. Morgan Chase in July 2001.

title: Couple Expected to Plead Guilty to Insider Trading
description: A former Morgan Stanley compliance officer and her husband are expected to plead guilty this week to charges stemming from an insider-trading case that prosecutors say was part of the largest such scheme on Wall Street since the 1980s.

title: Judge Rules Broadcom Suit Can Proceed
description: A judge Monday denied a request by the Broadcom founders Henry Nicholas and Henry Samueli and other company directors to dismiss a lawsuit filed by investors accusing them of improperly backdating stock options. Judge Manuel Real of United States District Court in Los Angeles made the ruling without further comment. Judge Real last month denied a similar motion by the company to dismiss the case for lack of merit.

title: Liz Claiborne Dresses Up with Narcisco Rodriguez Deal
description: Few dresses have attained the glamour than the dress that Carolyn Bessette wore to marry John F. Kennedy Jr. in 1996. But its designer, Narcisco Rodriguez, has since fallen on hard times. In a rare move in the fashion world, however, he asked for help.

title: Clear Channel Postpones Shareholder Vote on Buyout
description: Clear Channel Communications, owner of the largest network of radio stations in the nation, on Monday postponed a shareholder vote on a revised buyout offer by two private equity firms.

title: London Stars Join George on Broadway Next Year
description: The Olivier Award winners Daniel Evans and Jenna Russell will reprise their starring roles when the Menier Chocolate Factory of London production of Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine's Pulitzer Prize-winning musical "Sunday in the Park With George" opens next year in New York.

title: Portola Raises $70 Million to Prep for I.P.O.
description: Vascular anticoagulant drug developer Portola Pharmaceuticals raised $70 million in a third round of venture financing from a deep-pocketed group of hedge fund and crossover investors. The firm will use the cash to fund late stage clinical trials, and prepare for an initial public offering in its next capital call.

title: Solar Power Start-Up Absorbs $27 Million
description: Solaicx, a developer of solar wafers, said on Tuesday it had received an additional $27.1 million in funding, giving it the funds it needs to increase production. The firm said it had developed a new process for making single-crystal silicon wafers-designed specifically for solar panels-more efficiently and cheaply.

title: Marsha Mason at Playwrights
description: The four-time Academy Award nominee Marsha Mason will star when Playwrights Horizons presents the world premiere of "A Feminine Ending" next fall.

title: S.E.C. to Consider New Proxy Rules
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will float a proposal this summer to address controversy over shareholder democracy and hopes to have new rules in place by fall, in time for corporate annual meetings in 2008, the agencys chairman, Christopher Cox, said Monday.

title: A Deal To-Do List for Warren Buffett
description: After Warren Buffett said would love to find a $40 billion acquisition, BusinessWeek has put together its list of possible targets for the Berkshire Hathaway chieftain.

title: Wall Street Journal Editors Held News of Murdoch Bid
description: One of the trickiest things for a news organization to do is cover itself.

title: Are Heavyweight Investors Turning on Private Equity?
description: The balance of power between institutional investors, like Fidelity Investments and T. Rowe Price, and buyout deal makers such as Henry Kravis, David Bonderman and Leon Black, is beginning to shift, says Bloomberg News.

title: Thomson in Talks to Buy Reuters for $17.6 Billion
description: Big-time deal making has officially hit the media market.

title: Former Associate Testifies Black Was Kept Informed
description: The star witness in the criminal case against the former media baron Conrad M. Black, F. David Radler, took the stand Monday and portrayed himself as a close partner of Mr. Black who did not make a major move without talking with him.

title: Arcelor Mittal Is Said to Eye AK Steel
description: Deal making in the metals sector is flourishing. The Financial Timess Alphaville blog reported Tuesday that Arcelor-Mittal, the steel empire run by Lakshmi Mittal, is considering a deal for AK Steel, a smaller Ohio-based rival. Arcelor-Mittal may offer as much as $4.5 billion, or $40 a share, Alphaville said. Shares in AK jumped 3.5 percent to $32 in New York on Monday as news of the impending deal appeared to emerge.

Mr. Packer, who took control of Publishing and Broadcasting following the death of his father, said he would separate the companys fast-expanding gaming and casino operations from its traditional businesses of television and magazines to raise the stock price and pursue growth.

title: Poirets Descendents
description: Paul Poiret, the subject of the new costume exhibition at the Metropolitian Museum of Art, was one of the worldliest of the worldly, at least as the world looked right after the First World War. He was as famous for his elegant, Oriental dresses as he was his dazzling costume parties, including one, La Mille et Deuxime Nuit, that featured live monkeys and parrots, as well as actors hired to play beggars and rug merchants as 300 guests dined on lobsters, goose liver and 900 liters of Champagne. Poiret sat on a throne.

title: Citadel Gets Active With Networking Firm 3Com
description: Kenneth Griffin doesnt shy away from unloved assets. As the market for subprime mortgages  loans to homeowners with weak credit histories  began to fall apart this year, his $13.5 billion fund, the Citadel Investment Group, snapped up assets in the industry. Now, Citadel is putting a chunk of money into a beaten-down technology company. Citadel has spent $135 million to buy an 8.4 percent stake in 3Com, a maker of networking equipment that was a Wall Street darling in the 1990s, before it spun off its Palm subsidiary and the technology boom subsided. Times have changed, and 3coms stock has lost about half its value since early 2004.

title: Joe Perella Gets His Headline Deal
description: Since it was founded a year and a half ago with a roster of brand-name investment bankers, Perella Weinberg Partners has left many on Wall Street wondering when it would get its first marquee deal  the kind of blockbuster transaction that involves well-known companies and lots of zeroes in the price tag. On Tuesday, the doubters seemed to get their answer: The boutique investment bank, led by Joseph R. Perella, is a co-lead adviser to the Thomson Corporation, alongside Bear Stearns, in its negotiations to acquire the Reuters Group for 8.77 billion pounds ($17.5 billion).

description: Some top universities may be getting caught up in a wide-ranging congressional examination of the tax treatment of hedge funds and private equity firms. The scrutiny from Washington has been a prime concern for many buyout chiefs, who fear that cherished tax loopholes may be closed. (PEhub, writing about the topic Tuesday, poked some fun at such concerns, noting the horror of being filthy rich instead of obscenely rich.) On Tuesday, Bloomberg News reported that, in addition to looking at how private equity and hedge funds are taxed, the Senate Finance Committee also discussed offshore investments of pension funds, foundations and universities including Harvard, Yale and Stanford.

Less than a week after Dow Jones confirmed receiving a $5 billion takeover bid from News Corporation, a Hong Kong couple stands accused of insider trading in Dow Jones shares before the approach was made public. In a civil complaint filed Tuesday in New York, the Securities and Exchange Commission said the couple spent $15 million to engage in highly profitable and highly suspicious trades in Dow Jones shares from April 13 to April 30. When the bid was announced on May 1, Dow Joness shares shot up by 58 percent.

title: Grasso Wins Round in Lawsuit Over Pay

The former chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange won a partial legal victory on Tuesday when an appeals court threw out four rulings against him in a suit over his $190 compensation package. The reversal was on technical grounds, The Associated Press said; Bloomberg News reported that the state of New York can still go to trial against Mr. Grasso on other claims. A spokesman for New York Governor Eliot Spitzer, who, as New Yorks attorney general, first sued Mr. Grasso to seek the return of the money, said the state planned to appeal Tuesdays decision. But the final decision on an appeal will be up to New Yorks current attorney general, Andrew Cuomo.

title: Raw Deal?
description: Speaking of public authorities and economic development, a labor-backed group called New York Jobs With Justice has taken a closer look at another, especially convoluted and under-examined kind of authority: Local business-promotion agencies known as industrial development authorities. IDAs, as they are known, account for more than half of all the authorities on state books, according to this handy list put out by the state comptrollers office. In a nutshell, IDAs are set up, usually with the consent of state lawmakers, to support the development of everything from manufacturing facilities to hotels to horseracing tracks. The deal is, the IDAs give developers a tax break, or financing through tax-exempt bonds, in exchange for the promise of creating jobs and economic activity.

title: Brooklyn: Deal Offered in Case of Fake Veterinarian
description: A man charged with operating on animals without a license was offered a deal yesterday to avoid prison time by completing a psychiatric program, prosecutors said. The man, Steven Vassall, 29, was accused of botching an operation on a Boston terrier named Burt. Prosecutors deployed a so-called undercover cat, known as Fred Wheezy to his family and Detective Fred to his public. Fred was not harmed in the course of duty, but he later ran into traffic and was killed. Mr. Vassall was offered a deal to plead guilty to felony charges of practicing unlicensed veterinary medicine and scheming to defraud. Under the deal, he must complete a three-year outpatient mental health program and refrain from working with animals or children or in health care, prosecutors said. Mr. Vassall was given until May 22 to decide.

description: RACE POND, Ga., May 8  Tuesday was a red-flag day in southeast Georgia, meaning that a continuing drought had turned low, scrubby underbrush into the ideal fuel for fires.

Angola: U.S. Advised to Strengthen Ties to Stabilize Oil Supply

It noted that Angola had one of the worlds fastest-growing economies but remained one of the worlds least-developed countries. Cronyism and the labyrinthine bureaucracy that businesses must navigate to turn a profit frighten away all but the most courageous investors, the report said.

That show was also a launching pad for Jasper Johns, Ellsworth Kelly, Robert Rauschenberg and Frank Stella  all younger than Nevelsons son.

description: To the Editor:

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: Lazard Posts Higher Profit, but Misses Estimates
description: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit increased 5 percent from the quarter a year ago, helped by gains in its asset management business.

title: Staten Island: Men Sentenced in Deaths of Officers
description: Two men were sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to 15 years to life in prison for their roles in the murders of two undercover police detectives in 2003. The men, Mitchell Diaz, 22, and Jessie Jacobus, 21, members of a robbery ring prosecutors called the Stapleton Crew, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder charges within days of the killings. Both testified at the trial of Ronell Wilson, who was convicted on federal capital murder charges and sentenced to death for shooting the detectives, Rodney J. Andrews and James V. Nemorin. Mr. Diaz confessed to providing the gun, and Mr. Jacobus confessed to accompanying Mr. Wilson to rob the detectives.

title: Sosa and Palmeiro Cited in Steroid Investigation
description: Investigators of steroid use in baseball are seeking medical records from at least two of the games premier sluggers over the past dozen years, Sammy Sosa and Rafael Palmeiro, along with records from dozens of other players suspected of using performance-enhancing drugs, a baseball official with direct knowledge of the request said.

title: After Years in Wait, a Lab Is Born
description: Five years after a similar project was announced but never built, ground has finally been broken on a $145 million biomedical laboratory for research on cancer and other diseases at Landmark at Eastview, an office park straddling the towns of Greenburgh and Mount Pleasant in Westchester County, N.Y.

title: Brooklyn: Womans Defense in Babys Death
description: A woman accused of killing her newborn daughter was unaware of her pregnancy and has no memory of giving birth, her lawyer said in State Supreme Court yesterday. The woman, Laura Sergio, 25, has been charged with second-degree murder. The police found the baby, who was said to have died of hypothermia and asphyxiation, on the back porch of the family home in Bay Ridge on April 7. In an interview, a lawyer for Ms. Sergio, Thomas Cascione, described the case as a classic neonaticide, a term used to describe the killing of a baby by the mother within 24 hours of birth. In such cases, the mother is generally in denial of her pregnancy. Ms. Sergio was ordered held without bail.

title: The Bicycle in New York, From an Artistic Viewpoint
description: To look at nearly any bicycle  from graceful racers with inch-thick tires to the clunky, rusted workhorses of food delivery fleets  is to behold a union of form and function that has existed for nearly two centuries. Bicycles, after all, have been transporting people at least since 1817, when Baron Karl von Drais invented a contraption in Germany that operated without pedals and required riders to push against the ground with their feet to propel themselves.

title: About-Face as Nash Helps Suns Knot Series
description: PHOENIX, May 8  Steve Nash did not need to wear 20 gauze pads, 10 Band-Aids and a box full of steri-strips just to make a point.

title: Manhattan: Mayor Opposes Limits on Gun Trace Data
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg released a letter yesterday urging Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales to reconsider limits on the use of gun trace data compiled by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. The limits bar the bureau from releasing gun-trace data except to police officials and prosecutors working on a particular crime. The mayor sent a copy of the letter to members of Congress. He wrote that although the chief argument supporting the limits concerns protecting the anonymity of undercover officers, no one has been able to identify a single instance when trace data compromised the anonymity of an officer or the integrity of an investigation. Erik Ablin, a Justice Department spokesman, said the limits were in keeping with the bureaus longstanding policy of disclosing firearms trace results only to the law enforcement agency that recovered the crime gun.

title: Prim but Satisfying, Venerable Sweets From Milan
description: Chocolates for Mothers Day can come in an elegant navy blue silk faille box, like this assortment from Cova, a chocolatier in Milan that has been in business since 1817, first next to La Scala opera house, and since 1950 on the chic Via Montenapoleone.

title: Mets Getting Their Heads Together
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8  As his teammates shuffled into the clubhouse bathroom, Shawn Green sat in front of his locker running his fingers through his hair for the final time. After much prodding and teasing, Green surrendered to the peer pressure and let Carlos Beltrn, the Mets center fielder/resident barber, pare his brown locks into a crew cut.

title: Love, Honor, Cherish and Buy
description: Gazing upon the Custom Liquid booth at the Great Bridal Expo, where the half-liter water bottles picture a bride and a groom on the label ($48 a case, plus shipping), Rebecca Mead announced, This is a new one on me.

title: Kansas Tornado Renews Debate on Guard at War
description: CHICAGO, May 8  For months, Gov. Kathleen Sebelius of Kansas and other governors have warned that their state National Guards are ill-prepared for the next local disaster, be it a tornado, a flash flood or a terrorists threat, because of large deployments of their soldiers and equipment in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Scrutiny Seen of Trading in Dow Jones
description: Federal regulators are expected to examine the role of a Dow Jones director in the possible leak of inside information to a Hong Kong couple, who were accused yesterday of making millions of dollars from trading shortly before news of Rupert Murdochs takeover offer.

title: Tennessee Carries Out First Execution Since Lethal Injection Review
description: NASHVILLE, May 9  Philip R. Workman's execution date has come and gone five times in the quarter-century since his conviction for shooting a Memphis police officer. Early Wednesday, he was finally executed at the Riverbend prison on the industrial outskirts of this city.

title: In a Quiet Part of Florida, a Bid to Bring in the Crowds
description: PANAMA CITY, Fla.  This corner of the Florida Panhandle already has an airport, but it is sleepy, with a runway too short for the heavy jets that bring well-heeled crowds. Tourists come for the quartz-sand beaches, but most make the trip by car from Alabama, Georgia and Tennessee.

title: The Five-Second Rule Explored, or How Dirty Is That Bologna?
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago I saw a new scientific paper from Clemson University that struck me as both pioneering and hilarious.

title: Fidelity Units Settle Complaints Over Military Fund Sales
description: Two Fidelity brokerage units have agreed to pay $400,000 in fines to settle regulatory complaints accusing them of producing misleading sales materials for two archaic Fidelity mutual funds that were sold almost exclusively to military consumers.

title: Official Takes Case to U.S., but Skeptics Dont Budge
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  Mowaffak al-Rubaie, the national security adviser to Iraqs prime minister, undertook on Tuesday what may have been his most challenging mission yet: trying to persuade American lawmakers who have all but run out of patience that still more patience is required.

title: Ending Speculation, Gov. Spitzer Says Hell Back Clinton for President
description: ALBANY, May 8  After sitting on the fence for months, Gov. Eliot Spitzer said on Tuesday that he had decided to endorse Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, his fellow New York Democrat, for president.

title: When Tranquillity Trumps Equality
description: The libbers for lob equality once risked their wood Wilsons so prize purses for women would mean more than a nice clutch bag, so gender equity would include the right to a shared pot.

title: Senators Reach Outline on Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  Key senators said Tuesday that they had agreed on the outlines of a bipartisan bill that would toughen border enforcement and provide a path to legal status for illegal immigrants.

title: Food Calendar
description: Wine in Brooklyn

title: Officer Says Civilian Toll in Haditha Was a Shock
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 8  The only Marine Corps officer who was in Haditha, Iraq, when American troops killed 19 civilians in their homes in 2005 testified at a military hearing on Tuesday that he was shocked to find only unarmed people, including women and children, among the dead. But he said the marines had not violated any law of war.

title: Working in the Sewers Is a Dirty Job, but Someones Got to Win
description: A sewer is a slippery workplace. Water can move at the speed of oncoming traffic, even when it is not laden with tree branches, two-by-fours and the waste products known in the business as turtles. A single footstep in the water can stir up enough gas to knock a man unconscious. And then there is the smell.

title: Prominent Iranian-American Academic Is Jailed in Tehran
description: Haleh Esfandiari, an Iranian-American academic who is prominent in Washington, was imprisoned yesterday in the Iranian capital of Tehran after being barred from leaving the country four months ago, said the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars.

title: Burress Shows Up at Camp; Shockey Stays Away
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 8  A spring ritual for the Giants is trying to lure receiver Plaxico Burress and tight end Jeremy Shockey from Florida to Giants Stadium for workouts that are officially voluntary but viewed as nearly mandatory.

title: Canada: Quebec Separatist Leader Quits Party After Election Loss
description: Andr Boisclair, left, the leader of the separatist Parti Qubcois, resigned, further destabilizing an independence movement that was left in shambles after a third-place finish in provincial elections in March. The current conditions dont allow me to do this anymore, he said. The party was poised to have a strong showing in the elections, with some even predicting a win for the separatists, who want Quebec to be a nation. But instead they had their worst showing in decades. When he was elected party leader in November 2005, Mr. Boisclair, 41, made headlines for being openly gay and for admitting to having used cocaine while a cabinet minister. His relative youth also marked a departure from previous sovereignty leaders, most of whom traced their roots to the partys founding in the late 1960s. He fought back tears as he announced his resignation, ending it with a familiar rallying cry among separatists: Vive le Quebec!

title: Councilman Seeks a Top Job in Brooklyn
description: City Councilman Charles Barron said yesterday that he would run for Brooklyn borough president in 2009 and would not challenge Representative Edolphus Towns next year for his Congressional seat, as had been widely expected.

title: Clumsy Tools to Aid a Family After the Death of a Son
description: In one of the most virtuosic monologues of the theater season, Christina Kirk, the rangy grande dame of the downtown stage, encapsulates an entire marriage in a series of declarative statements and hackneyed phrases. The poetic high point of Jenny Schwartzs Gods Ear, a formally inventive and superbly performed drama about how the death of a son shatters a family, this ode to love, loss and the routines of life has the economy and dry wit of a Sondheim love song.

title: Queens: Ferry to Rockaways
description: New York City hopes to expand private ferry service from Manhattan to the Rockaways in Queens as a way to relieve traffic congestion and provide quicker commuting for residents in one of the most remote areas of the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The citys Economic Development Corporation will ask private ferry operators to propose service for one or more routes that would, at a minimum, run weekdays during peak commuting hours. Operators will have about six weeks to submit responses. The price for the service will depend on the proposals, but officials said they hoped it would cost about the same as express bus service, about $4 each way.

title: Pupil Needs Shape Budget for Schools in New York
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein released next years budgets for New York Citys more than 1,400 public schools yesterday, using a new financing system that will drive far more money to schools serving low-achieving students, children from low-income families and those who speak limited English.

title: Classic Book About Americas Indians Gains a Few Flourishes as a Film
description: LOS ANGELES, May 8  When the historian Dee Brown published Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee in 1971, it became an instant sensation. In an age of rebellion, this nonfiction book told the epic tale of the displacement and decline of the American Indian not from the perspective of the winners, but from that of the Indians.

title: A Cruise, and in Turn, Perhaps a Loan?
description: Oh, to be a university financial aid administrator on the loose in Manhattan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To Love a Martini

title: A Man, a Woman and a Day of Terror
description: No writer has been as prescient and eerily prophetic about 21st-century America as Don DeLillo. His novels, from Players and White Noise through Libra and Mao II and the remarkable Underworld, not only limned the surreal weirdness of the waning years of the 20th century, but somehow also managed to anticipate the shock and horror of 9/11 and its darkly unspooling aftermath.

title: Ethics Panel Clears Corzine in Labor Talks
description: TRENTON, May 8  There was no conflict of interest in Gov. Jon S. Corzines conduct during labor negotiations with a union led by a woman with whom he once had a romantic and financial relationship, an ethics panel reported on Tuesday.

title: Marks Mysterious and Foundlings Sad: O, Tangled Web!
description: Guy Maddins Brand Upon the Brain! takes place in an orphanage where tiny tots earn their keep by the sweat of their brows and adults exact a savage price on their tender souls. A baroque entertainment with one foot in silent cinema and the other gingerly toeing the sound waves, the film centers on a man who, in visiting the now-emptied foundling home, journeys deep into his childhood. There, amid secrets and lies, open wounds and monstrous parental narcissism, he discovers what made him tick and why, and how between his mothers terrifying love and his fathers sadism he learned all the cruel tricks of desire.

title: Hewlett-Packard Says Quarterly Results Will Top Forecast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8  Hewlett-Packard said Tuesday that its earnings for the quarter just ended would be higher than previously forecast, largely because of strong worldwide sales of personal computers. The announcement pushed the companys stock to its highest point in more than six years.

title: A No-Frills Kitchen Still Cooks
description: THE question Im asked more often than any other is, What kitchen equipment should I buy?

title: Negotiating a Shadow World, With Bumps
description: The tight-lipped protagonist of Christoffer Boes film Allegro is a familiar type found in Scandinavian movies: an Olympian talent  in this case a concert pianist named Zetterstrom (Ulrich Thomsen)  cut off from his own emotions in his drive for perfection.

title: Glavine Wins His 294th, but the Buzz Is About the Hair
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8  Tom Glavine arrived at AT&T Park on Tuesday afternoon to find that the Mets clubhouse had turned into a barbershop. As he walked toward his locker, he glanced around and saw a bald Mike Pelfrey, a buzzed Joe Smith and a flat-topped David Wright, and then peered into the bathroom to see Carlos Beltrn wielding an electric razor.

title: Mets Wright Begins to Show Frustration Over His Slump
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8  It was just David Wrights luck. In his first three at-bats Monday night, he broke his bat against Barry Zito, whose fastball hardly resembles Mariano Riveras vaunted cutter. After selecting a new bat for the third time, in the sixth inning, Wright missed a good pitch to hit and lofted a fly ball to left.

title: Disney Profit Up on Wild Hogs
description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that its quarterly profit rose 27 percent on the surprise hit movie Wild Hogs and higher advertising rates at ABC television.

title: Agency Affirms Mandates for Drivers Licenses
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The Homeland Security Department said Tuesday that it would plow ahead with national standards for drivers licenses, despite a highly unusual level of activity by state legislatures opposed to the idea, and substantial second thoughts in Congress.

title: Federal Student Loan Official Is Resigning
description: Under criticism that it has been lax in policing the $85 billion student loan industry, the Education Department announced yesterday that the chief official responsible for overseeing the loan program was stepping down.

title: Creating a Fable for Our Times, Based on Very Thin Evidence
description: In a world dominated by machines and awash in paper, it is little wonder that a discarded, computer-printed bar receipt could end up being one mans ticket to bedlam. That, at any rate, is the premise behind The Receipt, a clever and funny show concocted by Will Adamsdale and Chris Branch and being presented at 59E59 Theaters as part of the Brits Off Broadway festival.

title: 4 Arrested in 2005 London Transit Bombings
description: LONDON, May 9  British police today arrested three men and the widow of a suicide bomber involved in the terror attack on the London transit system in 2005 on suspicion they helped in the atrocity that killed 52 people.

title: Norway: Police Hold Suspect in Bosnia War Crimes
description: The police arrested a 40-year-old native of Bosnia, now a Norwegian citizen, on suspicion of committing war crimes against Bosnian Serbs while serving in an ethnically Croatian military unit in 1992. The man, who in keeping with Norwegian police practice was not identified, faces up to 21 years in a Norway prison if convicted on charges of assault, rape and illegal detention at a prison camp during the wars over the former Yugoslavia. The police have said they are investigating 70 immigrants to Norway who are suspected of war crimes in a number of countries. The arrested man arrived in Norway with his family in 1993 and received citizenship in 2001.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A theater review on Thursday about Coram Boy, at the Imperial Theater, misstated the definition of the term Coram boy. It refers to a child abandoned by his parents, not an orphan. (It is derived from the name of Thomas Coram, who in the 18th century established the Foundling Hospital to care for abandoned children in London.)

title: Cheney Presses Iraqi Leaders to Act Decisively
description: BAGHDAD, May 9  After a day of talks here with Iraqs fractious political leaders, Vice President Dick Cheney said Wednesday that he detected a greater sense of urgency among them in tackling a list of divisive issues that the Bush administration sees as the key to any sustained progress against the countrys insurgent and militia groups.

title: U.S. Pays and Apologizes to Kin of Afghans Killed by Marines
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  An Army commander apologized and paid compensation on Tuesday to families of Afghan civilians killed by marines after a suicide attack in March, in the first formal acknowledgment by the American authorities that the killings were unjustified.

title: Practice in the Poconos: U.S. Details How Men Prepared
description: It was a terror plot that hinged, in no small part, upon a map snatched from a New Jersey pizzeria. The plotters honed their shooting skills on semiautomatics at the firing range, though they also spent time conducting what the authorities called tactical training by playing paintball in the woods.

title: Pentagon Tells 35,000 Troops They May Be Deployed to Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The Pentagon said Tuesday that it had informed an additional 35,000 soldiers that they were likely to be heading to Iraq by December, a move that would allow the Army to maintain heightened American troop levels into next year.

title: Fine Season Leaves Rangers Wanting to Stay Rangers
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., May 8  Two days after they were ousted from a promising playoff run, the Rangers had their traditional breakup day, but it did not include much talk of breaking up.

title: Putin Cites Third Reich in Veiled Criticism of U.S.
description: MOSCOW, May 9  President Vladimir V. Putin obliquely compared the foreign policy of the United States to the Third Reich in a speech on Wednesday commemorating the 62nd anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany, apparently in an escalation of anti-American talk within the Russian government.

title: A Trashy Tupperware Lady With a Mans Touch
description: Meet Dixie Longate. Shes so excited to be here tonight, she could just throw up blood! But Miss Dixie Longate, queen bee of the one-woman show Dixies Tupperware Party, has bigger things on her mind, like selling the audience some of her plastic junk: the kiwi- green and tangerine-orange and mixed-berry plastic ware that decorates the stage at Ars Nova, a tiny Off Broadway theater.

title: Doctors Reap Millions for Anemia Drugs
description: Two of the worlds largest drug companies are paying hundreds of millions of dollars to doctors every year in return for giving their patients anemia medicines, which regulators now say may be unsafe at commonly used doses.

title: National Study Gives Gateway Park Low Marks
description: Gateway National Recreation Area, the sprawling waterfront park that stretches from Jamaica Bay to Sandy Hook in New Jersey and is home to several threatened species, is in the worst condition of any national park surveyed by an advocacy group, according to a report to be released today.

title: Author and Surfer to Share in Proceeds of Waves Book
description: For writers of narrative nonfiction, one of the biggest challenges is getting access to sources and events that they might not otherwise see.

title: 6 Men Arrested in a Terror Plot Against Fort Dix
description: CAMDEN, N.J., May 8 Six Muslim men from New Jersey and Philadelphia were charged Tuesday with plotting to attack Fort Dix with automatic weapons and possibly even rocket-propelled grenades, vowing in taped conversations to kill as many soldiers as possible, federal authorities said.

title: The Democrats Pledge
description: Last year, Congressional Democrats allowed the Bush administration to ram through one of the worst laws in the nations history  the Military Commissions Act of 2006. This year, the Democrats pledged to use their new majority to begin repairing the profound damage the law has done to the nations justice system and global image.

title: Cisco Systems Says Quarterly Earnings Soared 34%
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8  Cisco Systems, the network equipment maker, reported a 34 percent gain in quarterly profit on Tuesday that it attributed to strong demand for high-speed networking, particularly in international markets.

title: Prenatal Test Puts Down Syndrome in Hard Focus
description: DETROIT  Sarah Itoh, a self-described almost-eleven-and-a-half, betrayed no trace of nervousness as she told a roomful of genetic counselors and obstetricians about herself one recent afternoon.

title: The Arab Commission
description: Hezbollahs leader, Hassan Nasrallah, made a remarkable statement last week. He praised Israel for conducting an inquiry into last years war with Hezbollah  an inquiry that accused Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of serious failure in exercising judgment, responsibility and prudence.

title: Archaeologist Says Remnants of King Herods Tomb Are Found
description: JERUSALEM, May 8  After a long quest in search of King Herods tomb, an archaeologist announced Tuesday that he had found what appear to be the ornate remnants of the Roman-era kings burial site on the edge of the Judean Desert.

title: Science Fiction Sneaks Up
description: Make your own spatula or SpongeBob key ring. That is the promise of the 3-D printers that may soon be gracing your kitchen or family room.

title: Josephine Baker Unfit for the Mail? (It Wasnt Even a French Postcard)
description: On the endless march toward liberty and justice for all, a new cause has joined the parade: postcards featuring the breasts  clad, unclad, and pretty much clad  of Josephine Baker, famous long ago and dead these many years.

title: Jurors Seated in Terror Trial of Padilla and 2 Others
description: MIAMI, May 8  A jury was seated Tuesday for the trial of Jose Padilla, the American who was initially designated an enemy combatant but was then moved to the criminal justice system to face terrorism conspiracy charges with two co-defendants.

title: Get Off the Chaise Longue
description: Paris

title: War Shrine Gift by Japan Leader Prompts Concern
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, May 9  China and South Korea made subdued expressions of concern on Tuesday after disclosures that Japans prime minister had presented an offering to a Tokyo war shrine, as officials in Tokyo tried to play down the gifts significance.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) STAGE DOOR (1937) Turner Classic Movies continues its salute to Katharine Hepburn on the centennial of her birth with four of her best-known films, starting with the Academy Award-nominated Stage Door (1937), about a society beauty with Broadway dreams who moves into a boardinghouse full of actresses, played by Ginger Rogers, Lucille Ball, Eve Arden and Ann Miller, then largely unknown. Starting at 10, Hepburn joins forces with Cary Grant in three classic comedies: Bringing Up Baby (1938), above, about a scatterbrain who uses her pet leopard to catch the attention of a starchy paleontologist; Holiday (1938), in which a freethinker engaged to a millionaires daughter decides that her sister just might be a better match, at 1:15 a.m.; and The Philadelphia Story (1940), about an ice princess socialite on the verge of remarrying who is forced to rethink everything, at 3. At midnight theres Hepburns first television interview, on The Dick Cavett Show, from 1973.

title: A Master of Song, Operating at Full Power
description: If there is one quality that distinguishes Matthias Goernes singing  apart from the rich, large sound of his baritone  it is his ability both to create and to inhabit the emotional world a song describes. In his recital at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening, Mr. Goerne worked his magic quickly: within a bar or two, he sounded fully at home in a song, and he maintained an interpretive suppleness that kept his expressive moves fresh and unpredictable.

title: English Language Learners as Pawns in the School Systems Overhaul
description: Lets call this the mystery of the missing ELLs. An ELL, you need to know, is the abbreviation for English Language Learner. These students, immigrants or their children, are legally entitled to special classes intended to make them fluent readers, writers and speakers of their new language.

title: To Regain His Thump, Abreu Is Bumped to 7th
description: Nearly every time he is asked about Bobby Abreu, Joe Torre calls him the perfect No. 3 hitter in the Yankees lineup. Abreu is among the most patient hitters in baseball, forcing pitchers to throw strikes and allowing teammates to see many pitches.

title: Opposition Splits While Zimbabwe Slips
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 8  The last couple of years have been exceedingly tough for the Movement for Democratic Change, the only opposition political party of any note in authoritarian Zimbabwe. Party officials have been beaten with stones and logs; their cars have been hijacked; their posters have been methodically stripped from street poles. In one memorable instance, thugs tried to toss the partys director of security down a sixth-floor stairwell at its headquarters.

title: Get a Dog From a Shelter (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Driven by International Bidders, Prices Soar at Sothebys Sale With No Blockbuster
description: Its a new world, said Tobias Meyer, the auctioneer conducting Sothebys sale of Impressionist and modern art last night, as his hammer pounded the rostrum like a loud exclamation mark. After an intense war between two telephone bidders, a canvas by the Expressionist painter Lyonel Feininger had just sold for $23.2 million, more than two and a half times its high estimate and a record for the artist at auction.

title: Lottery Numbers
Confronting Questions of Faith With a Few New Responses
description: People of faith are often treated as either jokes or villains in the downtown theater scene, but that may be starting to change. Les Freres Corbusier was evenhanded in Hell House, and the Civilians, a company not known for being dogmatic, is working on a new docudrama about evangelicals.

title: Two Former Enemies Are Sworn in to Lead Northern Irelands Government
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 8  Paying tribute to the thousands of victims in one of Europes bloodiest sectarian conflicts, the leaders of Northern Ireland on Tuesday drew a formal line under decades of hostility and strife, re-establishing a power-sharing local authority of once implacable foes.

title: Thomson Confirms Offer for Reuters
description: OTTAWA, May 8  Thomson, the Canadian electronic information company, said today that it was offering $17.5 billion in cash and shares for the Reuters Group, the financial and general news service.

title: In Los Angeles, the Accidental Pizza Maker
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Positions Available: $12,900 to Start, Advancement Possible
description: The Major League Soccer players union released salary information last week that showed that the leagues more than 90 developmental players each earn less $20,000. That stands in stark contrast to the salaries of the leagues marquee players, some of whom make 50 times that or more.

title: Diego Corrales, Fighter and Victim of Motorcycle Crash, Dies at 29
description: Diego Corrales, who once held four world boxing championships and was remembered most for a pair of brutal lightweight bouts two years ago, died Monday night in a motorcycle accident on the outskirts of Las Vegas. He was 29.

title: Saving, Not Victimizing, Children
description: Sexually exploited children can be helped by the law or victimized by it, depending on where they are from. An Eastern European child smuggled into this country as a sex slave is offered protection under the federal Trafficking Victims Protection Act. An American child who flees abusive parents and ends up selling her body on the streets is labeled a criminal and sent to the juvenile equivalent of prison.

title: Combined Thomson-Reuters Would Challenge Bloomberg
description: OTTAWA, May 8  Thomson, the Canadian electronic information company, on Tuesday sketched out the broad details of its $17.5 billion offer for the Reuters Group, the financial and general news service.

title: Telling Bogus From True: A Class in Reading News
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y.  It was early in the morning, but the class was lively. Perhaps it had something to do with the news article the professor had just handed out for the students to read.

title: Glimmers of a Turnaround in Springfield, Mass.
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.  Late last century, this once-thriving New England city, like many of its neighbors, fell victim to a causal chain of events  mills closed, jobs disappeared, crime rose and residents left.

title: Moving Day for the Devils, in More Ways Than One
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 8  As a woman mopped the aisles and as the ice at both ends began to melt, the Devils posed for their last team photograph Tuesday at empty, forlorn Continental Arena. Even Lou Lamoriello sounded wistful.

title: Maryland Is First State to Require Living Wage
description: Gov. Martin OMalley of Maryland signed the nations first statewide living wage bill yesterday, giving fresh momentum to a movement that seeks to raise wages through legislation.

title: Lesotho: 39 Die in Bus Crash
description: At least 39 people died late Monday when a bus carrying 103 textile workers collided with a tractor-trailer truck in northern Lesotho, a police spokesman said. The accident occurred while the bus, traveling between Maputsoe, a garment-making center on the South Africa border, and Fobane, a village about 15 miles south, was on a winding road. One or both vehicles may have been speeding, the police said.

title: What You Get for ... $1.6 Million
description: Keswick, Va.

title: Germany Conduct Raids Ahead of G-8 Summit
description: FRANKFURT, May 9  Four weeks before leaders of the worlds big industrial nations are to gather at a Baltic Sea resort in northern Germany, the police conducted sweeping raids on Wednesday on the offices and homes of left-wing campaigners whom they suspected of planning to disrupt the meeting.

title: Corrections
description: A list of gins with an article last Wednesday about the best gins for martinis misstated the strength of the alcohol in Junipero, made by Anchor Distilling. It is 98.6 proof, not 86.

title: Doctors Getting Paid to Prescribe Drugs
description: Two of the worlds largest drug companies are paying hundreds of millions of dollars to doctors every year in return for giving their patients anemia medicines, which regulators now say may be unsafe at commonly used doses.

title: No More Freedom Fries?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Cape Town With Kids
description: Cape Town's beaches, parks and gardens are a perfect playground for children and families.

title: Brazilians Focusing on Popes Arrival
description: It is always remarked that Latin America is the most Roman Catholic part of the world, with nearly half the world's one billion Catholics living in the region. But in the same way that Indonesians are said to follow a more relaxed version of Islam than their brethren in the Arab world, Catholicism in Latin America is often more informal than that practiced elsewhere: many Latin Americans who describe themselves as Catholics either don't attend mass, or, as is often the case here in Brazil, mix Catholicism with African or Indian rites.

title: Personal Shopper
description: The modern slipper chair, as distinctive as ever.

title: London lures Purple Prince
description: Pop star Prince has confirmed that hell be looking this summer for a house to buy in London, where he will kick off a 21-concert tour on Aug. 1st.

title: Physical Culture | Gear Test, Racing Shoes
description: Purists dont dare race in trail running shoes. Enter trail racing shoes with stickier, firmer soles and less weight than everyday trail running shoes.

title: Fine Points | No Hands
description: The fanny pack: it's not just for Michelin guides.

title: Currents
description: Dressing rooms in the Hamptons, reimagining cardboard, far outside the box, rare rugs and more.

title: Tyco Reports Lower Earnings Ahead of Break-Up
description: Tyco International, which plans to split into three companies in coming weeks, reported lower quarterly earnings Tuesday as revamping costs reduced earnings but a low tax rate helped results beat Wall Street expectations.

title: Warners Loss Widens Amid Fading Deal Hopes
description: The Warner Music Group posted a wider quarterly loss Tuesday and said it would cut about 400 jobs as it shifts resources to increase digital distribution of music and video. The announcement comes as Warners hopes for a deal with its British rival, the EMI Group, are fading in the face of private equity bids for EMI.

title: Gates Discusses Software, but Talk of a Yahoo Deal Persists
description: Bill Gates, Microsofts chairman, spoke to hundreds of marketers and advertising agencies in Seattle on Tuesday amid rumblings about his companys struggle to compete against Google in online advertising and about its efforts to court Yahoo for some sort of partnership.

title: Fidelity Units Settle Complaints Over Military Fund Sales
description: Two Fidelity brokerage units have agreed to pay $400,000 in fines to settle regulatory complaints accusing them of producing misleading sales materials for two archaic Fidelity mutual funds that were sold almost exclusively to military consumers.

title: Longtime Hollinger Partner Says He Diverted Millions
description: Conrad M. Blacks longtime business partner, F. David Radler, testified Tuesday at Mr. Blacks criminal fraud trial that the two men conspired to divert millions of dollars of payments for assets of the newspaper company Hollinger International.

title: BNP Paribas Reports 25% Jump in 1st-Quarter Profit
description: BNP Paribas, the French bank, reported a 25 percent increase in first-quarter profit on higher corporate and investment bank earnings and gains from asset sales. The shares rose to a record.

title: Hedge Fund Targets Movie Gallery
description: An activist hedge fund, Schultze Asset Management, vowed Tuesday to press Movie Gallery to take steps to increase shareholder value.

title: KBW Chief Casts Skeptical Eye on Private Equity
description: The chief executive of the boutique investment bank Keefe Bruyette & Woods, adding his voice to the growing chorus of those warning of the dangers of the current buyout boom, said that the private-equity frenzy could end as badly for investors as the technology-stock bubble did.

title: Former Credit Suisse Banker to Be Freed on $1 Million Bail
description: A former Credit Suisse banker charged with masterminding a $7.5 million insider trading ring will be released on $1 million bail Wednesday after a federal magistrate judge questioned the strength of the governments case.

title: Rumors of BHP Bid for Rio Tinto Send Shares Soaring
description: Days after an analysts report suggested that BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, could become a target for private equity buyers, speculation surfaced that the company is considering a bid for a rival, the Rio Tinto Group.

title: Proenza Schouler Close to Financing Deal, Report Says
description: A New York design house, Proenza Schouler, is close to scoring a much-needed cash injection from a European luxury firm, The New York Post reported. While Proenza Schoulers founders, Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez, have experienced an almost meteoric rise in fashion circles, they have been looking for additional financing after buying out a German venture capitalist, Markus Hofels, last year, The Post said.

title: OakTree Swings Deal for Taiwans Fu Sheng
description: Oaktree Capital Management, a buyout firm with $40 billion of assets, plans to take over Fu Sheng Industrial of Taiwan, the worlds biggest maker of golf-club heads, for 28.3 billion Taiwan dollars ($851 million).

title: Bank of Montreal Puts 2 Commodites Bankers on Leave
description: Bank of Montreal, which said last month that it would report a pretax loss of as much as 450 million Canadian dollars ($407 million) from trading natural gas, placed two New York bankers on leave. A natural gas trader, David Lee, and Bob Moore, executive managing director of commodity products, are on leave as Bank of Montreal conducts an external review, a spokesman, Ralph Marranca, told Bloomberg News.

title: Grasso Ruling Makes States Case Tougher
description: The ruling by a court of appeals Tuesday dismissing some of the claims brought against Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, is likely to make it more difficult for the state of New York to force him to return the bulk of his pay package.

title: Fresh Buyout Rumors Dog Countrywide
description: The share price of Countrywide Financial, the largest mortgage lender in the nation, jumped Tuesday on renewed speculation of a buyout. The stock climbed $2.77, or 7.2 percent, to $41.28 after rising as high as $42.19.

title: Strong Demand Seen for Secondary Buyout Funds
description: Goldman Sachs and Coller Capital are among the firms raising secondary buyout funds, that acquire private equity portfolios rather than portions of companies as appetite for these kinds of investments seems to be hitting a high. Financial News cites estimates that $15 billion has been raised this year for secondary funds, more than the amount raised in the last two years combined.

title: Wildfire in Los Angeles
description: A raging fire in Griffith Park has forced evacuations of homes and city landmarks.

title: Regulators Are Said to Examine Role of Dow Jones Director in Leaks
description: Federal regulators are expected to examine the role of a Dow Jones director in the possible leak of inside information to a Hong Kong couple, who were accused Tuesday of making millions of dollars from trading shortly before news of Rupert Murdochs takeover offer.

title: Morgan Stanley May Sell Korean Unit, Report Says
description: Morgan Stanley is in talks with foreign money managers, including the ING Group, to sell its South Korean asset management firm in a deal local media valued at up to $220 million, Reuters reported.

title: SAP Buys OutlookSoft to Advance in Battle Against Oracle
description: The German software maker SAP said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy OutlookSoft, a planning, budgeting, forecasting, and consolidation software maker that competes with Oracle.

title: Taking Stock of EMCs Software Spinoff
description: VMware, EMCs fast-growing virtualization software unit, plans to offer 10 percent of its stock in an initial public offering. But a report from The 451 Group asks: If VMwares newly enriched founders should leave the company, will the juggernaut they created keep its momentum? Though comparisons with similar publicly traded companies is difficult, analysts at The 451 Group estimate that VMware could be valued at $7 billion or more once its shares begin trading.

title: Buyout Suitors Said to Pay a Call on Alltell
description: The rural wireless telecom service provider Alltel is being courted by at least three groups of private-equity buyers about a potential purchase, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Jana Urges Alcoa to Be Prey, Not Predator
description: A hedge fund that has a stake in Alcoa wants the company to drop its $33 billion hostile bid for its Canadian rival Alcan so that it can be bought instead.

title: Fortress Buys Florida East Coast
description: The Fortress Investment Group is taking Florida East Coast Industries private in a deal valued at $3.5 billion. The buyout agreement follows Fortresss announcement that it has closed on the first $2.8 billion of a new $5 billion private equity fund.

title: Dimon Was the Only Source for Dow Chemical Firings
description: The story behind the firing of two Dow Chemical executives for allegedly being involved in unauthorized discussions with third parties about the potential acquisition of the company became even more bizarre  and clouded  as the two men sued Dow Chemical, contending that they were defamed. The company, in turn, has sued both men.

title: Intercasting Nets New Funding
description: Once narrowly focused on a mobile blog publishing application, Intercasting of San Diego now hopes to be the largest intermediary between mobile phone carriers and social networking sites. Its investors have shown their support for the second time, providing $12 million in new capital to support Intercastings growth initiatives. Venrock Associates, the venture capital vehicle of the Rockefeller family, led the new round.

title: Meet the Bancrofts
description: Who does Rupert Murdoch need to win over in his $5 billion bid to acquire Dow Jones? To answer that question, The New York Observer drew up a family tree of the Bancrofts, who control the publishing company through a special class of stock. Family members include a champion power-boat racer, a retired American Airlines pilot and the head of a Texas private equity firm.

title: The Moss Model
description: Storekeepers praise the Moss model even as they turn away from it.

title: Citis Consumer Arm Loses Senior Managers
description: Citigroups consumer operations have lost nearly half of their senior management in the last 18 months, The Financial Times reported. Several of these high-level employees have left for J.P. Morgan Chase, while three others joined Brysam Global Partners, a private equity firm co-founded by Bob Willumstad, a former chief operating officer at Citi.

title: Another Call for Habeas Corpus
2008: Second Chances with Conservatives
description: In the wake of less-than-stellar reviews of his speech last week, Fred D. Thompson is working on Stump Speech 2.0 for a second shot this weekend, report Jonathan Martin and Mike Allen at Politico.com. Friends working on the speech say it will include more of a call to arms than the entertaining but unfocused after-dinner address Thompson gave to an eagerly expectant audience Friday night at the Balboa Bay Club and Resort in Newport Beach, Calif., they write. Mr. Thompson is slated to appear in Northern Virginia on Saturday before the Council for National Policy, an organization of conservative leaders.

title: One Reason Drug Prices Are So High
description: Why are prescription drugs so expensive? One reason is that the system does not encourage price competition.

title: Republicans and the Abortion Issue
Deadline: Iraq
description: Its not Walter Cronkite, but still: National Review White House correspondent Byron York questions the article of faith in Republican circles that Congress should not impose deadlines on the U.S . troop presence in Iraq. He writes at The Corner:

title: Mob Hits and Misses
description: Mafia clans are known to fight over turf, but credit for a double murder? F.B.I. documents cited by The Associated Press today recount a conversation between two rival families.

title: Design Stores
Cravath Woos Skadden Partner for Restructuring Group
description: Cravath Swaine & Moore, the New York law firm, is putting its white shoe firmly in the bankruptcy business. The firm, which frequently counsels companies in multibillion-dollar mergers, said Wednesday it has formed a corporate restructuring and insolvency group and hired Richard Levin, a former partner at Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom, to lead it. The move comes as Skadden and other law firms with established restructuring practices have been recruiting new talent, anticipating that the long lull in large corporate bankruptcies might be nearing an end.

title: For Poverty Lesson, Edwards Enrolled at a Hedge Fund
description: John Edwards has made poverty a top issue as he stumps for the Democratic Presidential nomination. So his connections to Fortress Investment Group, a highly profitable hedge fund and private equity firm with several executives on Forbes latest billionaires list, have provoked quite a bit of interest from campaign watchers. Asked about his decision to join Fortress as a senior adviser in 2005, Mr. Edwards told The Associated Press on Tuesday that he did it mainly in order to learn about the relationships between financial markets and poverty.

title: A Refresher Course in English
description: Oh, lordy, how long Ive been waiting for this!

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The On Education column yesterday about Columbus High School, misstated its location. The principal says the Bronx school considers Pelham Parkway to be its home. The school is not in Pelham Bay.

title: Spitzerisms, Lt. Gov. Edition: Dialectic
description: In which your correspondents track the unusual verbiage of Gov. Eliot Spitzer, a highly precise public speaker who often uses words or phrases that rarely alight upon the ears in normal conversation, and occasionally Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson, who appears to be picking up some of his bosss habits.

title: 24/7 Natalie Portman?
description: Imagine that there was a way to know what Natalie Portman was doing all the time. Would indulging in that be  weird? Would you do it anyway?

title: The Gore Reunion
description: There were campaign-style buttons passed around last night at a gathering of former Al Gore donors in Washington, but they did not augur a presidential run by Mr. Gore (to the disappointment of some). Al Gore Reunion 2007, they read.

title: A Rally Turns Tragic in Macedonia
description: A week ago, there was a disastrous crash on the Gumball 3000, an annual rally through Europe that advertises itself as 3,000 miles of adventure with the most eccentric group of thrill-seekers imaginable, partying every night with the whos who of international society and pop culture. As you would expect, most of the participants drive exotic cars.

title: Executive Pursuits
description: Harry Hurt III tries his paws at dog sledding.

title: Dairy Queen Ads
description: Dairy Queen Ads

title: Dairy Queen Ads
description: Dairy Queen Ads

title: Dairy Queen Ads
description: Dairy Queen Ads

title: Scene from 'Cellular'
description: A.O. Scott describes the movie "Cellular" as "a minor, highly enjoyable recent addition to the canon of Los Angeles crime films." This scene takes place on the Santa Monica Pier.

title: Wednesday at the ZOPA Cabana
description: Thats ZOPA, as in Zone of Potential Agreement, a term Senate Minority Leader Malcolm A. Smith picked up in a Harvard seminar, and Cabana, as in the place where deals get made, according to the song Mr. Smith and his fellow Senate Democrats sang in a skit at last weekends Legislative Correspondents Association dinner

title: Falling Dow: Doubts Grow About Murdochs Bid
description: If Rupert Murdoch is feeling anxious about the fate of News Corporations $5 billion bid for Dow Jones, he didnt let on at Tuesday nights Alexander Hamilton dinner in New York, organized by the Manhattan Institute. According to DealBreaker, Mr. Murdoch told the audience a joke, or tried to:

title: Network Chipmaker Xelerated Lands $23 Million
description: Xelerated, a maker of processors for network routers and switches, has landed $23 million in financing from a group of investors led by Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund.

title: Executive Pursuits
description: Harry Hurt III tries his paws at dog sledding.

title: Teamsters Pan Zells Buyout Plan for Tribune
description: Is Tribunes unusual buyout plan a coup for labor groups seeking a piece of the private equity pie?

title: Hezbollah Faces Harsh Consequences of War
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans May 9 column, The Arab Commission.

title: Homeland Circuit City Dept.
description: Circuit City confirmed today that one of their employees tipped off authorities to the Fort Dix suspects in January 2006. The employee works at the Mount Laurel, N.J., branch, but has yet to step forward.

title: The Morning After
description: The day after the Mets played bald, Carlos Beltran, the Barber of Sheaville (that was the New York Posts back page headline when Rey Sanchez received a haircut during a game), walked around the clubhouse with a digital camera. He stuck the camera about two feet away from John Maine, todays pitcher, who was sitting on the couch. The usually unflappable Maine burst out laughing.

title: Randolph Notches 200th Win as Manager
description: Barry Bonds hit his 745th home run last night. Tom Glavine won his 294th career game. Feeling left out, Manager Willie Randolph accomplished his own milestone, winning his 200th game as Mets manager. For those interested, he ranks seventh on the franchises all-time list and is pretty much assured of sliding into sixth within the next few months and all the way up to fourth early next year.

title: Best Eyes Ive Ever Seen
description: In recent years, Barry Bonds has not made it a habit of playing in day games after night games, but he is in todays lineup.

title: My Times News
description: Dear My Times Beta tester,

title: The Best-Laid Plans
description: A nanosecond is one-billionth of a second.

title: Murdochs Cricket Murder Ruling
description: Theres been no shortage of theories as the investigation continues into the death of Bob Woolmer, the Pakistani cricket coach who died hours after his strongly favored team lost to a neophyte squad from Ireland.

title: Audio: Giuliani on Ingrahams Show
description: As we mentioned earlier today, Rudolph W. Giuliani appeared on Laura Ingrahams talk radio show yesterday and discussed his stance on abortion and answered questions about his previous donations to Planned Parenthood.

title: More About Mozza
description: For my story in todays newspaper about Pizzeria Mozza, I talked to several of its ardent fans, and a theme that came up repeatedly in their comments  comments that didnt wind up working their way into the story  was that Mozza seemed more like a New York restaurant than a Los Angeles one. These fans stressed that the two cities restaurant cultures were very different.

title: Romney and Sharpton on Mormons
description: FORT DODGE, Iowa  Mitt Romney criticized today comments made by the Rev. Al Sharpton about Mormonism and his candidacy, calling the remarks bigoted and proof that bigotry still exists in some corners.

title: Clinton as First Spouse
description: Bill Clinton plans to be a First Husband for the 21st century: A post-modern, post-ego presidential spouse who doesnt earn an income of his own, but rather pays the bills from family savings and does what he can to help the missus down in the Oval Office.

title: Crash Inquiry Concludes in Brazil
description: An criminal inquiry in Brazil has concluded that two Americans were responsible for piloting a private jet into a collision with a commercial airliner in September 2006, according to O Globo, a Brazilian newspaper.

title: Ann Romneys Planned Parenthood Donation
description: Mitt Romneys campaign confirmed to ABC News today that his wife, Ann Romney, donated $150 to Planned Parenthood in 1994. The news comes just two days after reports resurfaced that Rudolph W. Giuliani donated $900 to Planned Parenthood during the 1990sand the day before Mr. Romney is scheduled to receive a Political Leadership Award form Massachusetts Citizens for Life.

title: An Endless Tug of War With Congress
description: In the dying days of the Bush presidency, it looks as though Congress and the president are engaged in one of their repeated tussles over control of foreign policy. The Constitution has always provided the potential for conflict, of course. Dividing up powers means that neither branch of government likes what they get. But it usually takes a dramatic event or a catastrophe (you can decide which of those the current occupation of Iraq is) to stir up the conflict.

title: The Roots of Ethnic Violence
description: One week ago, the International Criminal Court in The Hague issued arrest warrants on charges of war crimes and crimes against humanity for Ahmad Muhammad Harun, Sudans former interior minister who oversaw the Darfur Securty Desk, and Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-al-Rahman, a leader of the Janjaweed militia. Mr. Harun is now Sudans minister of humanitarian affairs. The two men seem to be rather small fry compared to Omar Hassan al-Bashir, the Sudanese president, but its a step in the right direction. Too little, too late, of course, for the hundreds of thousands whove been tortured, raped and murdered in the Darfur region over the past four years.

title: Back On With the Show
description: Pardon my modest blush while I do something here that may appear uncomfortably self-serving. A recurrent theme in your replies to these columns has been how much people miss my old show(s) and how they wish they could see them now. A recent commenter confessed to a life-long crush on Katharine Hepburn and just learned that I did two full shows with her on my ABC late-night show. Another writer, Hepburn-smitten, would give anything to see them. You, sir (as I recall), can give considerably less than that. And you could probably see them today. Another writer suggested that DVDs of the shows would be a good idea. I dont know which of us should be embarrassed but DVDs are already out here.

title: Your Comments on My Column about Genocide and Psychology
description: So what do you think? Can a puppy save Darfur? My column benefited tremendously from this journal article, and I encourage you to look it up.

title: Suggested Reading
description: Dave Anderson, who covered Muhammad Ali throughout his career, knows a big fight, and a big fight night, when he sees one. Here he recalls the first Ali-Frazier fight in 1971 and wonders whether boxing can recover the majesty and energy of nights like that. From PLAYs suggested reading list:

title: Curing the System
description: The American health insurance system is a slow-creeping ruin, damaging people and increasingly the employers that hire us. Yet there is another truth as well: the vast majority who have decent coverage are happy with the care we get  I am writing this, for instance, as I sit with my 11-year-old son waiting for an M.R.I. to check the cardiac repair that has saved his life for a decade. So most have resisted large-scale change, fearing that it could make some lives worse, even as it makes others better.

title: Some Other Takes, From Coast to Coast, on Contemporary Design
description: The Conran Shop

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day last Thursday, about research into the discrepancy between stock market returns and individual investors returns, misstated the average yearly dollar-weighted return for a hypothetical investor who bought 100 shares of a company at $10 a share, then a year later bought 100 more shares when the share price was $20, then sold all 200 shares when the price fell to $10 a share at the end of that second year. The investors average yearly return was a negative 26.8 percent, not a negative 16.8 percent.

title: Silence on Guns
description: The tragedy of our runaway gun culture can only deepen now that its clear the new Democratic Congress operates in fear of the gun lobbys well-practiced demagoguery and rich campaign treasury. A collective silence descended on the Capitol after the pro forma expressions of outrage over the Virginia Tech gun massacre.

title: Extra! Extra! Now the Post Doesnt Cost That Extra 25 Cents
description: To recap New York Citys tabloid price war: the tabloid costing 25 cents went to 50, so the one at 50 went to 25, but it will return to 50 soon. And now, the one that just went to 50 has gone back to 25. Got that?

title: Sarkozys Achievement (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: International Bidders Raise Prices at Art Auction
description: Its a new world, said Tobias Meyer, the auctioneer who conducted Sothebys sale of Impressionist and Modern art on Tuesday night, as his hammer pounded the lectern like a loud exclamation mark. After an intense war between two telephone bidders, a canvas by the Expressionist painter Lyonel Feininger had just sold for $23.2 million, more than two and a half times its high estimate and a record for the artist at auction.

title: Tennessee Inmate Executed
description: The convicted killer Philip R. Workman was executed, the first execution in the state since the release of new state procedures for administering lethal injections. Mr. Workman, who had been on death row since 1982, was executed after the United States and Tennessee Supreme Courts refused to issue a stay. Mr. Workmans last-minute appeals included challenges to the states revised lethal injection protocols. The protocols were released last week after a 90-day review and moratorium on executions.

title: Europes Satellite Navigation System Will Miss a Deadline
description: BERLIN, May 9  The European Commission is abandoning plans to build a satellite navigation system in partnership with private industry after the consortium chosen for the project became mired in disputes about financing, jobs and management structure, officials said on Wednesday.

title: At the Stadium, Stay Put When the Music Plays
description: The most patriotic moments at Yankee Stadium can also be the most confining.

title: Harvard Task Force Calls for New Focus on Teaching and Not Just Research
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8  Joshua Billings, 22, says he did not come to Harvard for the teaching.

title: The Yoga Therapist Will See You Now
description: FOR three years after a car crash left her with chronic pain, Deanna Adams searched high and low for relief. Mrs. Adams, 41, a stay-at-home mother in West Palm Beach, Fla., consulted a physical therapist, a chiropractor, two doctors (a pain specialist and a neurologist) and an acupuncturist  to no avail.

title: Mayweather Victory Sets Pay-Per-View Mark
description: Floyd Mayweathers split decision against Oscar De La Hoya in Saturday nights superwelterweight title fight generated 2.15 million pay-per-view buys  eclipsing the 10-year-old record for the second Evander Holyfield-Mike Tyson fight.

title: Verizon Drops Pop Singer From Ads
description: Many music fans know that Pete Wentz, the bassist for the rock band Fall Out Boy, found himself overexposed last year when sexually explicit pictures of him surfaced on the Internet. Many also know that Keith Urban, the country superstar, recently endured a stint in rehab.

title: East Patchogue: Man Found Dead in Yard
description: A 3-year-old boy was found lying unharmed next to his fathers body on Tuesday afternoon near their house in East Patchogue, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The father, Carlton Shaw, 38, had been shot in the chest and was found in a yard next to his house on Amsterdam Avenue about 4:45 p.m., the police said. The shooting was under investigation yesterday.

title: U.S. Attorneys, Reloaded
description: As the United States attorney scandal grows, so does the number of prosecutors who seem to have been pushed out for partisan political reasons. Another highly suspicious case has emerged in the appointment of Bradley Schlozman, a controversial elections lawyer, to replace a respected United States attorney in Missouri. From the facts available, it looks like a main reason for installing Mr. Schlozman was to help Republicans win a pivotal Missouri Senate race.

title: Whose Face Is It, Really?
description: IS a face one of a kind, an original like a snowflake and of such fragile beauty that its uniqueness perishes when tampered with? Or is a face malleable, like dough, the easier to mold into identical cookie-cutter shapes?

title: Cheney Visits Baghdad and Presses Leaders on Political Progress
description: BAGHDAD, May 9  After a day of talks here with Iraqs fractious political leaders, Vice President Dick Cheney said Wednesday that he detected a greater sense of urgency among them in tackling a list of divisive issues that the Bush administration sees as the key to any sustained progress against the countrys insurgent and militia groups.

title: 2 Arrested in Jailhouse Plot to Kill Queens Police Officer
description: A police officer who broke up a fistfight in front of his Queens home in August became the target of a murder plot, the authorities said yesterday, when a man he arrested that day tried to hire a hit man from his Rikers Island jail cell.

title: The Collarbones Connected to Slimness
description: LETS say a woman clocked a few hundred crunches a day, Stairmastered her bottom into a replica of J. Los and avoided carbs so assiduously that the waiters at her regular restaurants knew not to bother with a breadbasket. If no one could see results of all of this exertion and deprivation, would it count?

title: Giuliani to Support Abortion Rights
description: After months of conflicting signals on abortion, Rudolph W. Giuliani is planning to offer a forthright affirmation of his support for abortion rights in public forums, television appearances and interviews in the coming days, despite the potential for bad consequences among some conservative voters already wary of his views, aides said yesterday.

title: Senate Approves Tighter Policing of Drug Makers
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  By a vote of 93 to 1, the Senate passed a bill on Wednesday that would give the Food and Drug Administration new power to police drug safety, order changes in drug labels, regulate advertising and restrict the use and distribution of medicines found to pose serious risks to consumers.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with the Advertising column about cellphones affiliated with particular organizations carried an incorrect credit. The photograph was by Evan J. Thomas  not Michael Caulfield/Wire Image.com for CNN.

title: Earnhardt Could Take a New Turn
description: Dale Earnhardt Jr., Nascars most popular driver, has scheduled a news conference for 11 a.m. today amid speculation about his future with the race team Dale Earnhardt Inc.

title: Afghans Say U.S. Airstrikes Killed 21 Civilians
description: HERAT, Afghanistan, May 9  Afghan officials said Wednesday that airstrikes called in by American Special Forces against Taliban fighters in Helmand Province had killed 21 civilians, the latest in a series of claims of noncombatant casualties that have strained relations with the Afghan government.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the arrests of six men in New Jersey on charges of plotting to attack the Fort Dix Army base referred imprecisely to the relationship between three suspects  the brothers Eljvir, Dritan and Shain Duka  and a fourth, Mohamad Shnewer. Mr. Shnewers sister is married to Eljvir Duka, so only Eljvir  not all three Duka brothers  is legally Mr. Shnewers brother-in-law.

title: Frustration Ends for Delgado and Wright
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9  Atop their division is probably not where one would expect to find the Mets with Carlos Delgado and David Wright mired in season-long slumps. But that is where the Mets sit after Delgado and Wright, partners in frustration, redeemed themselves Wednesday with clutch doubles in consecutive innings to boost the Mets to a 5-3 victory against the San Francisco Giants at AT&T Park.

title: In Churchills Rise to Power, a Rough Path of Rebellion
description: Historical memory, like a skilled film editor, compresses the past. In the minds newsreel of the late 1930s Neville Chamberlain steps off the plane from Munich, declaring peace in our time, the camera quickly pans over German troops on the march, and in the next instant Winston Churchill strides toward 10 Downing Street flashing the V-for-victory sign, ready to lead Britain at war.

title: The Netherlands: Stiffer Sentence for Iraq Poison Gas
description: An appeals court raised the 2005 prison sentence of a Dutch businessman, Frans van Anraat, to 17 years from 15 for selling chemicals to Saddam Hussein. The chemicals were used in poison gas weapons in the 1980s and against Kurdish villagers. Prosecutors had demanded a conviction for complicity in genocide, but the appeal judges rejected that, saying Mr. van Anraat was driven not by genocidal intent but by greed.

title: Brooklyn: Illegal Steroids Seized
description: More than $100,000 worth of illegal steroids were confiscated from a pharmacy yesterday by the New York State Bureau of Narcotic Enforcement, officials said. The authorities were led to a Lowens Pharmacy in Brooklyn as part of an investigation by the Albany County district attorney. The investigation so far has led to the prosecution of at least 20 people.
