Christopher Baynes, an assistant district attorney for Albany County, said that investigators found large amounts of Chinese growth hormone and testosterone that had not been approved by the Food and Drug Administration at Lowens Pharmacy. As of last night, no charges had been filed, Mr. Baynes said.

title: Save the Darfur Puppy
description: Finally, were beginning to understand what it would take to galvanize President Bush, other leaders and the American public to respond to the genocide in Sudan: a suffering puppy with big eyes and floppy ears.

title: Mubarak Meets Israels Foreign Minister
description: CAIRO, Egypt, May 10  President Hosni Mubarak met with Israels foreign minister, Tzipi Livni, today and agreed that a team of Arab officials would soon visit Israel to discuss a peace proposal initiated by Saudi Arabia and endorsed by all members of the Arab League.

title: New Zealand Goes Right, and Grabs the Advantage
description: VALENCIA, Spain, May 9  So who is the heavyweight challenger now?

title: Romney Accuses Sharpton of a Bigoted Remark
description: FORT DODGE, Iowa, May 9  Mitt Romney said Wednesday that a comment by the Rev. Al Sharpton about Mr. Romney and his Republican presidential candidacy was proof that bigotry still exists in some corners.

title: Olmerts Testimony on War Is Made Public
description: JERUSALEM, May 10  In confidential testimony on last summers war with the Lebanese militia Hezbollah, Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said that the Israeli killing of a group of civilians in the town of Qana in late July was a turning point that delayed a diplomatic resolution.

title: Defense Attacks Credibility of Blacks Former Associate
description: CHICAGO, May 9  A defense lawyer in Conrad M. Blacks criminal fraud trial attacked the credibility of the chief prosecution witness, F. David Radler, on Wednesday by pointing out the numerous times Mr. Radler had lied before he cut a deal with federal prosecutors.

title: A Site Where Virtual Barbies Can Compare Their Makeovers
description: Barbie dolls collide with Web 2.0 with the release of BarbieGirls.com, a free online community which Mattel hopes will pull young girls away from competitors like Ty Girlz, Neopets and Webkinz. Once children pick a screen name and password, they can dress up their own Barbie avatar, a fun process of mixing and matching hairstyles, clothing items and shades of lipstick. Theres no bad hair; in fact, every creation looks like a slightly different beauty queen.

title: Manhattan: Gay Festival in Jeopardy
description: The organizers of PrideFest, the gay-themed street fair that generally accompanies the citys gay pride parade on the last Sunday in June, voted on Tuesday night to tell city officials that they would cancel this years festival unless they could find a better location. The members of Heritage of Pride, which organizes the festival and the parade, have said that the previous site, in the West Village, was cramped and dangerous, and that they wanted to move to Chelsea. On April 27, city officials denied permission for the change and urged the organizers to keep the event at the original site. The citys comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., has sent the mayor a letter urging the city to reconsider.

title: The Real Owner of All Those Planes
description: LOS ANGELES  When Steven Udvar-Hazy was a teenager in New York City, he would often head after school to Idlewild Airport, as Kennedy International was known then, to watch planes take off and land.

title: Chefs Topped With Debt
description: The chef behind your light souffl may be bending under the weight of heavy debts. The servitude of student loans extends well beyond college and graduate programs and straight into the culinary schools, where many aspiring young Mario Batalis and Daniel Bouluds take on tens of thousands of dollars in debt that they will spend years struggling to pay back if they dont quite make the big leagues.

title: Elevated Levels of Chemical Found in Queens Drinking Water
description: Slightly elevated levels of an industrial chemical have been found in the water supply of as many as 64,000 Queens residents, prompting officials to recommend the use of bottled water for drinking and cooking until the source is determined.

title: Fire Chars Part of Major Los Angeles Park
description: LOS ANGELES, May 9  A stubborn brush fire burned nearly a fifth of Griffith Park, among the largest municipal parks in the country, before firefighters brought the blaze under control on Wednesday.

title: Religion Guided 3 Held in Fort Dix Plot
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 9  The three Duka brothers  Eljvir, Shain and Dritan  not only prayed here at the Al Aqsa Islamic Center, but also recently began repairing its roof.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,365 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Disillusioned Diva With Glimmers of Soul
description: Amy Winehouse is a tease. The songs on her second album, Back to Black (Universal Republic), revive the sound of 1960s and 1970s soul with tales of plunging into temptation and toughing out the consequences. She drinks, she cheats, she falls for the wrong guys, she cries; she refuses rehab with a magnificently simple refrain, I said no, no, no.

title: Earbuds for Fashion and Sound That Adjust So They Dont Fall Out
description: Its called T.E.S.  tiny ear syndrome. No, its not a new medical malady but the problem many people have with the earbuds that ship with portable music players. They dont always fit comfortably and sometimes pop out unexpectedly.

title: Seizing the Moment
description: DIGITAL cameras are amazing. Even compact digital cameras selling for less than $100 take photographs with great resolution.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on April 28 about American diplomatic protests over the cancellation of a British government inquiry into bribery by BAE Systems, Britains top military contractor, to secure contracts in Saudi Arabia, misattributed the announcement of the cancellation. Also, because of an editing error, a correction in this space on May 2 misstated the month the announcement was made. The Serious Fraud Office made the announcement, not Lord Peter Goldsmith, the attorney general. The announcement was made in December, not January. (Go to Article)

title: For Clemens, Leg Work Is the Key to Success
description: When Roger Clemens was a Yankee in his previous life, Mel Stottlemyre was his pitching coach. Stottlemyre is retired now, playing golf and fishing among the fir trees and lakes of Washington State, but if he were monitoring Clemenss new life as a Yankee, he would be concerned more with the strength in Clemenss legs than in the arm with 348 career victories, the most of any active pitcher and eighth on the career list.

title: Calendar
description: All Irises

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on April 28 about American diplomatic protests over the cancellation of a British government inquiry into bribery by BAE Systems, Britains top military contractor, to secure contracts in Saudi Arabia, misattributed the announcement of the cancellation. Also, because of an editing error, a correction in this space on May 2 misstated the month the announcement was made. The Serious Fraud Office made the announcement, not Lord Peter Goldsmith, the attorney general. The announcement was made in December, not January.

title: A Top Russian Marathoner Fails a Drug Test
description: Lyubov Denisova, a 35-year-old Russian who has finished in the top 10 in the New York City Marathon four times, has tested positive for an elevated testosterone level.

title: As Top Seeds Dominate in East, Fans Head West
description: Vince Carter has settled for fadeaway after fadeaway after fadeaway in Cleveland, and the empty thud of his misses has echoed the Nets playoff plight.

title: Faster Fashion, Cheaper Chic
description: LOS ANGELES

title: South Korea: Big Plans for Solar Energy
description: South Korea plans to break ground for the worlds biggest solar power plant as it tries to diversify its power sources and use cleaner energy, the government and developers said. The $170 million plant, being built in Shinan, near the southwestern tip of South Korea, is part of an effort to seek new and renewable energy sources and is scheduled to be completed by late 2008. The plant will produce more than 27,000 megawatt-hours of electricity a year, enough to supply 6,000 to 7,000 households, said Kim Ji Hun, president of the Korean subsidiary of SunTechnics, the German solar power company that will build the plant. It will be operated by Dongyang Engineering and Construction.

title: House Passes Ban on Gifts From Student Lenders
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly Wednesday to ban gifts and payments by student loan companies to universities, showing bipartisan resolve to clean up the $85 billion industry.

title: Irvington: Sergeant Charged With Theft
description: A police commander and the owner of an auto yard were arrested yesterday and charged with stealing items from vehicles that had been seized, the Essex County prosecutors office said. Sgt. Barry Halpern, 51, of Kenilworth, a 24-year veteran of the Irvington Police Department and commander of the auto squad unit, was charged with second-degree official misconduct and third-degree theft. Mark Minett, 51, of Tinton Falls, the owner of MTS Towing in Irvington, was charged with third-degree theft, said the prosecutor, Paula T. Dow. An inquiry began in January 2006 after several people reported items like laptop computers and power tools missing from their cars. Sergeant Halpern is being held in $50,000 bail and Mr. Minett is being held in $30,000 bail.

title: Britain Arrests 4 Suspected of Ties to 2005 Transit Bombings
description: LEEDS, England, May 9  The British police on Wednesday arrested three men and the widow of a suicide bomber involved in the terrorist attack on the London transit system in 2005 on suspicion that they helped in the atrocity, which killed 56 people, including the 4 bombers.

title: A Familys Films, Like No Home Movies Youve Seen
description: Like father, like son? That question hovers evocatively over the nine-title program, Generation Garrel, that opens today at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics BAM Rose Cinemas. Dedicated to three male members of the same filmmaking family  the actor Maurice, his director-son Philippe and actor-grandson Louis  the programs relative modesty doesnt justify sweeping claims about how the ties that bind can lead to a life in the movies. But it does suggest that all three Garrels share a cinematic culture of experimentation and provocation and offers hard proof that together and alone they have done exceptional work.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about the six suspects in the Fort Dix case misstated which two of the suspects are brothers-in-law. Eljvir Duka and Mohamad Shnewer are related, not Mr. Duka and Agron Abdullahu. The article also misstated the number of Mr. Shnewers sisters. He has five, not two.

title: Facing the New Motherhood, Cutthroat and Neurotic
description: In Amy Wilsons new solo comedy, Mother Load, she tackles a subject that has suffered inadequate attention perhaps only on Jupiter. A mother of two, Ms. Wilson is addled by the whole neurotic culture of modern parenthood. The pressures! The lactation consultants! The baby rice cakes!

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in the special Personal Health section on May 1, about sexually transmitted diseases, misidentified the viruses that cause herpes, the most common sexually transmitted disease in the United States. They are strains of H.S.V., or herpes simplex virus  not H.P.V., or human papillomavirus.

title: Italy: Profit Rises 12% at Utility
description: Enel, an Italian utility, said first-quarter profit unexpectedly rose 12 percent, fueled by increased foreign sales and cost cuts. Net income climbed to 943 million euros ($1.28 billion), or 16 cents a share, from 842 million euros, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. Enel, which is bidding for the Spanish utility Endesa, sold power in Eastern Europe and Russia in the period to make up for falling electricity demand at home. Costs were reduced by 7.2 percent, helping offset a drop in Italian sales. Sales declined 5.1 percent, to 9.73 billion euros. The bid for Endesa values the company at 43.7 billion euros and will give Enel access to another 22 million customers. The deal will create a platform to sell electricity across borders when the EU energy market opens to competition on July 1.

title: A Sensible Solution to Thin Traffic, and One for Easing Concerns About Fairness
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg recently proposed charging a fee to motorists who enter Manhattan south of 86th Street on weekdays. Drivers of cars would face a daily charge of $8 from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m., while the fee would be $21 for driving commercial trucks.

title: France: Profit Up 25% at BNP Paribas
description: BNP Paribas, the French bank, reported a 25 percent increase in first-quarter profit on higher corporate and investment bank earnings and gains from asset sales. Income climbed to 2.51 billion euros ($3.4 billion), from 2.01 billion euros a year earlier, BNP Paribas said. Revenue rose 21 percent, to 8.21 billion euros. Profit beat the 2.06 billion euros expected by analysts. BNP Paribass stock rose 3.65 euros, to 91.15 euros. Pretax profit at the corporate and investment bank rose 12 percent. Earnings at the French branch network declined 2.2 percent, while pretax profit at BancWest, a unit based in Hawaii, slipped 20 percent. Excluding Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, earnings at BNP Paribass international retail bank decreased 5.3 percent.

title: Legislators Ask to Revise Plan for Hospitals
description: ALBANY, May 9  The Republican and Democratic leaders of the State Legislature said Wednesday that they wanted Gov. Eliot Spitzer to reconsider a plan approved last year to close, merge or shrink dozens of hospitals across the state.

title: A Spaniard With a Taste for Drama
description: When the Spanish singer Martirio performed the slow bolero Si Te Contara on Tuesday night at Joes Pub, her backing trio narrowed to only a plucked bass, and her physical emphasis moved to the areas beyond her wrists: the swivel of her hands, the tense arcs of her fingers.

title: Chemicals Found in Queens Water Since 2003, Reports Say
description: The area of New York City where officials this week found industrial chemicals in the drinking water has had problems with contamination by the same chemicals for several years.

title: Correction: Currents
description: A report in the Currents column last Thursday gave an incorrect telephone number to order the Butch & Harold line of wall decals. The number is (212) 712-0616.

title: All-in-Ones: Bring on the Tiny Purse
description: NO strangers are we to multitasking; it was only a matter of time before we demanded our makeup do the same. These days, sticks, pencils and compacts can perform multiple beauty duty without dominating the purse  or the wallet.

title: Less Green at the Farmers Market
description: Boston

title: Yankee Rings Become Issue for Giuliani
description: With his official interlocking NY cap, shiny team jacket and seats near home plate, Rudolph W. Giuliani has often looked as if he might just bleed pinstripes if his beloved Yankees lost a game.

title: A BlackBerry for Collars of All Colors
description: As a human being, youre pretty much stuck with the features you had on the date of manufacture. Very few adults ever become substantially taller, faster or more artistic.

title: Arabic School Finds Temporary Home in Brooklyn
description: The Department of Education has found a temporary site for the Khalil Gibran International Academy, a public school devoted to the study of Arabic language and culture that is scheduled to open in September.

title: A Player Who Never Found His Stage
description: London

title: Room to Improve
description: A. Simplicity goes a long way toward making a bathroom feel as if it is from another time. The most difficult part of the job may be undoing old decorating. Before you bring in new fittings, fixtures or furniture, take stock of what you have and remove ill-conceived flourishes. Vinyl flooring or carpet? Rip it out. Jaunty wallpaper? Tear it off.

title: House Panel Considers Cuts for Missile Defense
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  The Bush administrations proposal to construct two American missile defense bases in Europe has roiled relations with Russia and provoked sharp questioning even in NATO capitals, where critics ask: With the system still unproven and, under the best of circumstances, years from completion, why rush construction now?

title: G.O.P. Moderates Warn Bush Iraq Must Show Gains
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  Moderate Republicans gave President Bush a blunt warning on his Iraq policy at a private White House meeting this week, telling the president that conditions needed to improve markedly by fall or more Republicans would desert him on the war.

title: Indictment in 65 Killing That Inspired March
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 9  A grand jury in Alabama handed up an indictment on Wednesday in an obscure killing that helped inspire the historic Selma-to-Montgomery march in 1965. The case is the latest in a series of belated prosecutions of crimes from the civil rights era.

title: Manhattan: Notification of Building Permits
description: The City Council passed legislation yesterday requiring the Buildings Department to notify the Fire Department when alteration permits are issued for buildings. The bill was submitted after a 2006 Bronx fire in which two firefighters were killed when a floor collapsed in a building that had undergone renovations, though the cause of the collapse is still under investigation. The bill passed 51 to 0, and the mayor is expected to sign it.

title: Germany Conducts Raids Ahead of G-8 Summit
description: FRANKFURT, May 9  Four weeks before leaders of the worlds big industrial nations are to gather at a Baltic Sea resort in northern Germany, the police conducted sweeping raids on Wednesday on the offices and homes of left-wing campaigners whom they suspected of planning to disrupt the meeting.

title: Alan Lowenstein, 93, Lawyer, Is Dead; Revised Newark Government
description: Alan V. Lowenstein, a prominent New Jersey lawyer who headed the commission that drafted the restructuring of Newarks government in the 1950s, allowing for the direct election of the mayor, and who also led one of the nations early attempts at employee ownership of a major company, died Tuesday at his home in Maplewood, N.J. He was 93.

title: European Buyers Enjoy Weak Dollar at Art Auction
description: A sea change in the art market was stunningly apparent last night at Christies sale of Impressionist and Modern art, where most of the buyers spending millions of dollars on everything from stark Giacometti sculptures to dreamy Signac landscapes were mainly Europeans taking advantage of the weak dollar.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on May 1 about an accounting technique used by New Century Financial misstated the year that the companys chief financial officer, Edward F. Gotschall, stepped down from that job. It was 2004, not 2006. (Mr. Gotschall is still with the company as a vice chairman.)

title: 2 Convicted of Leaking Memo on Bush-Blair Talk
description: LONDON, May 9  A British court found a civil servant and a legislators aide guilty on Wednesday of breaking the Official Secrets Act by leaking a classified memorandum concerning a conversation at the White House between Prime Minister Tony Blair and President Bush.

title: Ways to Speed an Exit From Iraq (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Blair Says He Will Leave Office in June
description: LONDON, May 10  After months of coy hints and fevered speculation, Prime Minister Tony Blair announced today that he would leave office on June 27 after a decade in power in which he sacrificed his popularity to the war in Iraq and struggled at home to improve schools, policing and hospitals.

title: The Hague: Bosnian Serb Wins Genocide Appeal
description: An appeals court of the United Nations war crimes tribunal overturned a 2005 conviction for complicity in genocide against a former Bosnian Serb officer, Vidoje Blagojevic, saying it had no proof that he had known of the genocidal intent of the perpetrators of the 1995 massacre of Muslims at Srebrenica and provided only logistical support. The court reduced his prison sentence to 15 years from 18, and upheld several related war crimes charges.

title: Missouri Prosecutor Says He Was Pushed to Resign
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  The former United States attorney in Kansas City, Mo., said Wednesday that he was pushed to resign last year after disagreements with the Justice Department over politically sensitive cases. That would make him the ninth federal prosecutor forced out by department officials in Washington.

title: Toyota Profit Robust, Forecast Cautious
description: TOKYO, May 9  Toyota reported another year of record profit today but signaled a slowdown in the current year because of weakness in North America and increased spending.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Saturday about Gordon Scott, an actor who played Tarzan in the 1950s, misspelled his surname at birth. He was Gordon W. Werschkul, not Werschkull. The obituary also misspelled the given name of his surviving brother. He is Rafield Werschkul, not Rayfield.

title: Nothing Like the Suns, Thomas Mixes It Up
description: PHOENIX, May 9  If the Phoenix Suns ran a footrace against one another in practice, Kurt Thomas might well finish last.

title: Microsoft to Invest in CareerBuilder Web Site
description: SEATTLE, May 9  Microsoft said Wednesday that it would take a small equity stake in CareerBuilder, a popular job recruitment site operated by three big media companies. The deal deepens an existing partnership in a lucrative category of online classified advertising.

title: Magna Chairman Confirms an Offer for Chrysler
description: OTTAWA, May 9  Frank Stronach, the chairman of the auto parts maker Magna International, confirmed Wednesday that his company and Onex, a Canadian investment company, have made a bid for Chrysler, the struggling American unit of DaimlerChrysler.

title: Queens: Woman Admits Fatally Beating Father
description: A woman yesterday admitted fatally beating her father with a hammer in a November 2004 attack, prosecutors said. The woman, Laura Martin, 46, of Long Island City, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to first-degree manslaughter, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Ms. Martin admitted repeatedly striking her father, John Martin, 67, in the head in their apartment. She had told the police that he had been killed in a break-in, Mr. Brown said. In exchange for her plea, Ms. Martin will be sentenced to 20 years in prison, Mr. Brown said.

title: On the High-Definition Front: A Laptop With Blu-ray
description: The war between the HD-DVD and Blu-ray formats rages on, but it is still quite difficult to find PCs and laptops that can handle either of the new standards for high-definition video.

title: Growing Numbers on L.I.R.R. Ride Against Commuter Tide
description: As city residents continue to take more jobs in the suburbs, the number of reverse commuters during the morning rush on the Long Island Rail Road has jumped 76 percent since 1998, according to a study to be released today.

title: From a Nevada Tournament, Defense by the Textbook
description: The Cavendish Invitational tournament started yesterday at the Green Valley Ranch Resort in Henderson, Nev. The main events are the John Roberts Teams and the Cavendish Invitational Pairs, with a secondary competition, the World Bridge Productions Pairs, also scheduled. Details: cavendishinvitational.com. Play can be seen live at www.bridgebase.com.

title: The Role of an F.B.I. Informer Draws Praise as Well as Questions About Legitimacy
description: It was August 2006 when one of the young Muslim men accused of plotting to kill soldiers at Fort Dix first broached the idea, according to the authorities. Talking to an informer who was secretly taping the exchange, the young man said that he thought he could round up six or seven other men willing to take part, and that a rocket-propelled grenade might be the most effective weapon, the authorities said.

title: Bush Threatens Veto
description: The House approved legislation that proposes $39.8 billion for the Homeland Security Department next year. President Bush has threatened to veto the measure over its pro-union provision. The measure, which passed 296 to 126, would strike a provision in the 2002 legislation creating the department that allowed the president to waive collective-bargaining rights for department workers.

title: As Mayor Says No to 08 Bid, Revived Web Site Fuels Skeptics
description: Does the mayor protest too much?

title: The Incredible Flying Granny Nanny
description: ANGELA KIM spends two days a week baby-sitting for her 2-year-old grandson, Noah, while her daughter, Andrea, a doctor, works nine-hour hospital shifts.

title: A New Attitude for the Hip
description: IN Australia, they call it a bum bag. In France, its le banane. Apparently much of the world regards the fanny pack, that belted pouch often seen around the enlarged waists of unsophisticated travelers, as little more than a gag item.

title: Battle of Britains Free Newspapers
description: LONDON  British tabloids typically send out paparazzi to poke into the lives of the royals, soccer coaches and supermodels. Lately, however, two free newspapers fighting a circulation battle on the streets of London have turned the cameras on each other.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Picture captions in The Arts yesterday with a theater review of Radio Golf, at the Cort Theater, reversed the identities of two actors. In the picture on the cover of the section, the actor on the right was James A. Williams, not John Earl Jelks. In the picture with the continuation of the review, the actor on the left was Mr. Jelks, not Mr. Williams.

title: Order and Chaos in a Single Heartbeat
description: Los Angeles

title: Pope Opens Trip With Remarks Against Abortion
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, May 9  Benedict XVI arrived in Brazil on Wednesday, starting his first papal trip to Latin America with strong words against abortion, and roiling a Catholic continent increasingly divided by the issue.

title: Curtis Harrington, Director of Horror Films, Dies at 80
description: Curtis Harrington, who dived under his seat while watching his first horror film as a child, then went on to be a filmmaker known for his elegant, edgy cinematic forays into the macabre, died on Sunday at his home in the Hollywood Hills section of Los Angeles. He was 80.

title: Japan: G.E. Buys Rest of Sanyo Credit
description: The General Electric Company said today that it had paid 126.3 billion yen or $1.05 billion for the Japanese leasing company Sanyo Electric Credit Company. G.E. paid 3,250 yen a share for 97 percent of Sanyo Credits stock, the company said in a statement. The company bought the shares from Sanyo Electric and two Goldman Sachs units. G.E. is focusing on lending to companies after the Japanese government tightened consumer credit rules.

title: The Morning Line on Tony From Jersey
description: A certain gent in New Jersey is hereby urged to call this number before his life spins totally out of control: 1-800-522-4700. That is a national help line for problem gamblers, open 24 hours a day.

title: From Intel and A.M.D., Rival Boasts of Technology
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9  The fierce rivalry between the chip makers Intel and Advanced Micro Devices is ratcheting up as both companies claim superiority in technology used for notebook computers.

title: Iran Frees Former Atomic Negotiator on Bail
description: TEHRAN, May 9  A former nuclear negotiator who was arrested over a week ago was released Wednesday after a hefty bail was paid for him, the ISNA news agency reported.

title: Taking Suggestions While Searching
description: Q. I recently did a Web search with Google on my daughters computer. When I entered the information, a drop-down menu appeared with suggested Web addresses and additional words. How can I get my own computer to suggest words and Web sites?

title: Manhattan: Database for Birth Statistics
description: The public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, introduced legislation yesterday that would require the citys health department to create an online database of birth statistics, including the number of delivery procedures, like Caesarean sections, performed at hospitals. She said the database would help expectant parents choose a hospital. State law requires hospitals to provide women with maternity information, but surveys by Ms. Gotbaum in 2005 and 2006 found that many were not in compliance.

title: PGA Tour Caddies Finally Take a Load Off Their Shoulders
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., May 9  There was a tip jar on the 17th tee at the T.P.C. Sawgrass filled with golf balls, coins and crinkled dollar bills.

title: Reyes Keeps His Head, and Hair
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9  Carlos Beltrn, bald as a cue ball, walked around the clubhouse Wednesday admiring his handiwork. He went from Jorge Sosa to John Maine to David Newhan, snapping photos with his digital camera, before stopping in front of Jos Reyes, who was seated at a table. Beltrn shook his head.

title: Prominent in Hong Kong and, Perhaps, in the Dow Jones Inquiry
description: HONG KONG, May 9  Like David Rockefeller in the United States and a succession of Rothschilds in Europe, David K. P. Li has long received the accolades that come to aristocratic bankers who combine wealth, political influence and public service.

title: U.S. Report Cites Lightning and Old Cable in Mine Blast
description: BUCKHANNON, W.Va., May 9  A lightning bolt was the likely cause of the Sago Mine explosion last year that killed 12 miners, a 16-month federal investigation has concluded.

title: Toyota Posts Another Record but Warns of Slowdown
description: TOKYO, May 9  Toyota reported another year of record profit on Wednesday but signaled a slowdown in the current year because of weakness in North America and increased spending.

title: Death Penalty Sought in a Fatal Wildfire
description: LOS ANGELES, May 9  The Riverside County district attorney has decided to seek the death penalty against a man accused of starting a wildfire last year that killed five firefighters.

title: Uneasy Rider: Insuring Clemens a Big Risk
description: Between now and the time that Roger Clemens joins their roster, the Yankees will search for a disability policy to insure him against a season-ending injury. It is not certain they will get one, or that it will be affordable.

title: Windows Upgrade for Smartphones Improves Search and E-Mail Features
description: Youll never be able to buy a boxed version of Microsofts latest mobile operating system, but who needs boxes? Windows Mobile 6, a considerable upgrade to the companys operating system for smartphones and P.D.A.s, is now available as a free download for owners of the T-Mobile Dash. Versions will soon be released for other smartphones, old and new, from multiple carriers.

title: Manhattan: Deal for Marine Terminal Lease
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey reached a $51 million deal yesterday to allow one of its tenants, Orient Overseas International Ltd., which is based in Hong Kong, to sell its lease of a Staten Island marine terminal to the board of the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, which is buying the lease as an investment. In return for signing off on the $470 million transaction, the authority will receive $16 million in cash, up to $5 million to cover construction costs and a commitment from the pension board to invest $30 million in the Howland Hook terminal.

title: Two Special Elections Later, New Councilman Takes Oath
description: With his hand on a Bible and his family at his side, Mathieu Eugene was sworn into the City Council yesterday, apparently putting to rest questions about his residency.

title: Roundabout to Fill a Brand-New 89-Year-Old Theater
description: If everything stays on schedule, the number of Broadway theaters will increase by one in the fall of 2008, with the opening of Henry Millers Theater, behind an 89-year-old facade of old Broadway on 43rd Street that will be surrounded by the glass modernity of the new 54-story tall Bank of America Tower.

title: Next Week
description: Rob Weintraub looks ahead to the N.B.A. draft lottery and how the presence of two super freshmen, Greg Oden and Kevin Durant, could affect the dynamics of the decision making. Gretchen Reynolds examines a new study on hydration.

title: Correction: Up, Up and ... Never Mind
description: An article on April 26 about efforts to encourage people to learn to fly referred incorrectly to a new category of airplanes, light sport aircraft. They are indeed being built.

title: Group Seeks Trade for Captive BBC Journalist
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, May 9  The Palestinian Authority information minister, Mustafa Barghouti, said Wednesday that there had been very important developments in the last 24 hours concerning the kidnapped BBC journalist Alan Johnston.

title: Short Route to the Races
description: The triathlon season is in full swing, but it's not too late to start training to compete in one, even if youre starting from the couch. First-timers should focus on the sprint events, such as the popular "short course" race at the Life Time Fitness Triathlon in Minneapolis on July 14. It features a 0.4-mile swim in Lake Nokomis, 15 miles on a bike, and then a 3-mile run around the lake. Seasoned triathletes seeking a more rigorous challenge can compete that day in Olympic-distance races that roughly triple the short-course lengths. For an extensive list of triathlon coaches, local clubs and events, visit the USA Triathlon Web site.

title: Parents and District Settle Dispute on Teachers Religious Remarks
description: The Kearny Board of Education in New Jersey and the parents of Matthew LaClair, a 17-year-old junior at Kearny High School, settled their dispute on Tuesday night about a teacher who proselytized in class.

title: Its Her World, Were Just Buying It
description: KATE MOSS pondered the question for a moment. Her shoulders heaved forward to hold up a wisp of fabric in a print of white barbed wire that could qualify as a dress only on her. She gestured beyond the colossal security guards in three-piece suits, the scruffy entourage, the D.J. girls with the cropped platinum hair wearing her little dresses, the waiters clearing the detritus of broken Champagne glasses left in their wake and the sea of gawking news-media types whirling in the background with notepads in hand. Then she said what she wanted:

title: Poisoned Medicines (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column last Thursday about lawsuits over the ownership of the 16th-century diptych Adam and Eve, by Lucas Cranach the Elder, misstated the name of the organization that now owns it. It is the Norton Simon Art Foundation, not the Norton Simon Foundation. The report also misstated the paintings history. The foundation bought it in the mid-1960s directly from an heir to the Stroganoff dynasty of Russia. It did not buy it at auction.

title: Neither Rain Nor Love, Till a Guy Promises Both
description: Is it possible for a performance to be too good? Audra McDonald brings such breadth of skill and depth of feeling to the Roundabout Theater Company revival of 110 in the Shade that she threatens to burst the seams of this small, homey musical. Ravishing of voice and Olympian of stature, shes an overwhelming presence in an underwhelming show.

title: Yanks Work Through Problems to Get Back to .500
description: In the American League East, the second-place Yankees remain closer to last place than to the first-place Boston Red Sox. But a sense of stability has returned to the Bronx, and it was evident last night in a methodical 6-2 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: Legal Victory by Militant Cuban Exile Brings Both Glee and Rage
description: MIAMI, May 9  An elderly exile linked to deadly bombings in Cuba and on a Cuban airliner was on his way back to Miami as a free man on Wednesday, his indictment on charges of immigration fraud dismissed by a federal judge in Texas.

title: Heel Injury Forces Giambi to Sit as Lineup Shuffles
description: Jason Giambi, often the designated hitter and sometimes the first baseman, was out of the starting lineup because of a bone spur in his left heel last night when the Yankees played Texas in the second game of a three-game series at Yankee Stadium.

title: New York City Renters Cope With Squeeze
description: Like the legions of aspiring poets, tap dancers and musicians who came before her, Nina Rubin, a 29-year-old graduate of Wesleyan University, has struggled to find halfway decent housing in New York. Earlier this year, she ended up in her most unusual home yet: an office.

title: Mamet to Return to Theater of Politics
description: The last time David Mamet dipped his sharp pen into presidential politics was in 1997, when he was a co-author of the screenplay for Wag the Dog, about a  ahem  fictional president who tries to stage a fake war to distract from a damaging sex scandal.

title: Visiting Troops, Cheney Gives Sober Case for Iraq War
description: BAGHDAD, May 10  Vice President Dick Cheney spoke to American troops stationed near former Iraqi President Saddam Husseins birth place today, but the visit was far from a victory lap.

title: Aspiring to the Throne
description: LAST Friday afternoon, Jamie Gray, the owner of the Brooklyn design boutique Matter, stood in an empty storefront in Lower Manhattan, scraping away at a stubborn plastic UV filter that covered the front window. The work was punishing  hopefully there wont be any scratches or blood loss, he said, though he ended up calloused and bleeding  and very time consuming, considering he had less than two weeks left until the opening of Matters new Manhattan branch. A lot of problems remained to be dealt with, including glass doors he had trouble mounting on the display cases, and the important shipment of Established & Sons furniture stuck in customs limbo.

title: In Guilty Plea, OxyContin Maker to Pay $600 Million
description: ABINGDON, Va., May 10  The company that makes the narcotic painkiller OxyContin and three current and former executives pleaded guilty today in federal court here to criminal charges that they misled regulators, doctors and patients about the drugs risk of addiction and its potential to be abused.

title: Mahler Supplies the Emotions, Yet There Are No Guarantees
description: For an ensemble like the Philadelphia Orchestra, dazzling an audience with Mahlers Second Symphony should be an easy nights work. This orchestra has all the ingredients: the highly polished string sound that has traditionally been its strength; the solid, gleaming brass playing it has cultivated more recently; woodwinds that convey shapeliness and lyricism; and percussionists who arent afraid to play at full throttle.

title: No Nook Unbuttered, No Slice Unturned
description: THE ideal breakfast consists of a cup of coffee, the newspaper and a toasted English muffin. All three should be consumed in silence.

title: Pier 40s Fields of Dreams (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Sergeant Urinated on Body in Haditha
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 9  A marine sergeant testified on Wednesday that he urinated on the bloody remains of one of five unarmed Iraqi men whom his squad leader had fatally shot in late 2005 moments after a roadside bomb had killed one of their comrades in Haditha.

title: Fed Leaves Key Interest Rate Unchanged
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  The Federal Reserve acknowledged today that the economy is slowing but offered little hint that it is ready to lower interest rates anytime soon.

title: HBO Chief Executive Resigns After His Arrest
description: Time Warner announced this evening that Chris Albrecht, the chairman and chief executive of its Home Box Office unit, had agreed to resign at the companys request, three days after he was arrested and charged with assaulting a girlfriend in a Las Vegas parking lot.

title: Still Making Waves
description: Shirtless and barefoot in his living room two summers ago, Kelly Slater was demonstrating the bodyweight movement inside a radical surf maneuver. I was interviewing Slater about his ongoing rivalry with Andy Irons for an article that ran in PLAY last summer, and Slater radiated balance and calm as he flowed across his floor like a tai chi master. This season, on surfings 2007 World Tour, Slater is showing the same form. Two competitions have been completed, with Irons finishing last in the first one and second in the next  typically erratic. Slater, meanwhile, landed a respectable third and then a fifth, putting him right on target for what many expect to be a slow, steady march to a ninth world title.

title: Visas and Security (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Take Me to Your Designer
description: IN anticipation of commercial space tourism, which has been promised by several companies now busily competing to develop aircraft for suborbital flights as soon as 2009, this may be an appropriate moment to ask, what does one pack for space travel?

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Sometimes Rock Belongs to the Quiet and the Shy
description: On Tuesday night at Town Hall, Ben Gibbard thanked his fans for coming to see him, and then he went further. I know theres a lot of stuff going on in town, especially with the Arcade Fire show tonight, he said. For a moment, one of indie-rocks most popular singer-songwriters sounded a little bit like a flight attendant: He knew we had our choice of concerts, and he thanked us for choosing his. (Somehow he refrained from wishing us a pleasant stay in New York, or wherever our final destination might be.)

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Henry and Eliza, Back on Broadway

title: Some Leeway for Wolfowitz, Who Gets a Good Word From Rice
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  Bowing to pressure from the Bush administration, the World Bank board agreed Wednesday to give Paul D. Wolfowitz, the banks president, slightly more time to defend himself against charges of misconduct before the board decides his future.

title: Death Finds a Crack in the Life of the Guys at the Social Club
description: Two old men in baseball caps sat in two old chairs in front of an old building under a warm sun. A passer-by on Classon Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant might have thought they were having a lovely and peaceful Monday, but that would have been way off.

title: Putin Is Said to Compare U.S. Policies to Third Reich
description: MOSCOW, May 9  President Vladimir V. Putin seemed to obliquely compare the foreign policy of the United States to the Third Reich in a speech on Wednesday commemorating the 62nd anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany.

title: Bill Clinton Ponders a Role as First Gentleman
description: Bill Clinton plans to be a first gentleman for the 21st century: a post-modern, post-ego presidential spouse who does not earn an income of his own, but rather pays the bills from family savings and does what he can to help the missus down in the Oval Office.

title: Straight From the Heart
description: Personal heart-rate monitors, which read your pulse and send the number to a wrist-watch-like display, were once balky and pricey. Theyre now inexpensive, (starting around $50), reliable and featherweight. One sportswear company, Numetrex, is developing a workout shirt with heart-rate monitoring capabilities woven into the fabric. But does your average athlete need so much data? Sure, says Lindsay Hyman, a coach with Carmichael Training Systems who works with elite and professional athletes. Heart rate helps you refine your training and track your fitness. Most sporting goods stores sell monitors. To learn how to train with one, click around the Internet. The Tri-eCoach.com site has an estimable overview, as does the Flora London Marathon, which also, for $2.38, offers a downloadable heart-rate monitor guide.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Rhododendrons in Distress

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 16 about airline food in the special Business Travel section incorrectly attributed comments about a private-jet company, New York Aviation, and about business travelers in general. The comments, Well go into the city and get dinner at Le Cirque if people want it, about the services New York Aviation provides, and As long as theres booze on board, theyre happy, referring to business travelers, were by Jack Gentile, founder of New York Aviation  not by Hector Adler, senior vice president for customer experience at Eos Airlines.

title: I.B.M. Effort to Focus on Saving Energy
description: I.B.M. is beginning a $1-billion-a-year investment program intended to double the energy efficiency of its computer data centers and those of its corporate customers.

title: Scot With Baggage Readies for Leaders Role
description: LONDON, May 9  With Prime Minister Tony Blair expected to announce Thursday his plans to step down as leader of the Labor Party, Britons seem set to trade the Great Communicator for the Great Puzzle  Mr. Blairs likely successor, James Gordon Brown.

title: Shortchanging the Census
description: The Bush presidency will be history in 2010, the year of the next nationwide census. But the administrations influence on the count could nevertheless be profound  and not, it seems, for the better.

title: The Minotaur and the Muse: Picassos Carmen Fixation
description: PARIS, May 9  Mistresses and wives successively served as Pablo Picassos muses, but they were not enough. He also sought inspiration from fictional women. And who better than Carmen to personify the themes of sex, love, violence, tragedy and death that run through so much of his work?

title: A Workers Compensation Fraud Case, on Tour in Europe
description: The bus driver was a drummer in a rock band.

title: Fed Gives No Signal of Rate Shift
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  The Federal Reserve acknowledged Wednesday that the economy was slowing, but offered little hint that it was ready to lower interest rates anytime soon.

title: Text of the Feds Statement on Interest Rates
description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Feds monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to leave interest rates unchanged.

title: For Cycling Around Town, a Three-Speed Automatic
description: If youve walked into a bike shop recently, youve probably noticed how complicated bicycles have become. In an era of carbon fiber, 27 or more speeds and disc brakes, riding a bike is not the playful pastime it once was.

title: Chief Agrees to Resign From HBO After Arrest
description: Time Warner announced last night that the chairman and chief executive of its Home Box Office unit, Chris Albrecht, had agreed to resign at the companys request, three days after he was arrested and charged with assaulting a girlfriend in a Las Vegas parking lot.

title: Gonzales Is Said to Seem Confident He Will Stay
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales appears increasingly confident that he will survive the crisis over the dismissal of federal prosecutors, as White House aides who view him as a liability see little point in trying to persuade President Bush to push him out, administration officials and Republican allies said.

title: The Woman No Hat Could Tame
description: ISABELLA BLOW, the English eccentric and sorcerer of talent who died this week, was a completely implausible figure. You could not explain her and you could not reason with her. She was incredibly bright on the subject of fashion and rarefied tastes, a fact she wore on her sleeve and on her head. She loved a bustle, a corseted waist and a spectacular hat. And not for her the mushy-pea variety, the Ascot bonnet.

title: China: Virus Suspected in Pig Deaths
description: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said Chinese officials had informed it that a pig epidemic was under control in Laosi, in southeastern Guangdong Province. Chinas Ministry of Agriculture is conducting tests to determine if the disease is porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome, a viral disease that began attacking North American and European swine farms in the late 1980s and is the costliest virus for swine herds in the United States. The disease does not infect humans, the United Nations agency said. China reported a similar epidemic of the pig disease to the agency in September.

title: Lottery Numbers
It Takes a Hammer to Grow This Salad
description: IF you love fresh greens, there is no reason not to grow them yourself, even if you have only a tiny terrace or handkerchief lawn.

title: In Court, Details of Sex Play With Suspect
description: The beauty editor of W magazine testified yesterday about fantasy role-playing with Peter Braunstein, her boyfriend at the time, that foreshadowed his attack on another woman, in which he dressed as a firefighter, stripped her and put high heels on her while sexually molesting her.

title: Aiming for a Drug-Free Workplace
description: There is no shortage of reasons employers test their workers for drugs. At one company, an employee high on marijuana forgot to lock the wheels on his forklift and it dropped five feet off a loading dock, while employees at another built a crystal meth lab in the back of a truck.

title: As We Try to Foil Another 9/11 (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Stomp, Sneeze, Grunt, Gasp and All That Body Language
description: The movement in David Parkers new Hour Upon the Stage, as seen at Dance Theater Workshop on Tuesday, is on several cusps at once: between basic and virtuoso, between modern dance and ballet, between generating self-made rhythm and responding to other rhythms. The central gimmick is that the eight dancers (the Bang Group) themselves make most of the sounds: They slap, click, grunt, gasp, all in rhythmic patterns. But they dont try to make a serious rhythmic accompaniment for one another.

title: Trying to Connect Dots in Notorious Killing
description: For nearly 15 years it has endured among the more bizarre mysteries in Mafia lore, a competitive field if ever there was one: When a young couple from Queens  armed with an Uzi, a Mercury Topaz and a dream  ventured out to rob social clubs run by the mob, how exactly were they expecting things to end?

title: Helping Immigrants, and a Town, Move Ahead
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y.

title: Bush Says Hes Open to Iraq Bill With Benchmarks
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  President Bush offered his first public concession to try to resolve the impasse over Iraq war spending today, as he confronted new pressure from his own party over the conflict and House approval of a plan that would provide money for combat operations only through midsummer.

title: House Democrats Raise New Criticism of Gonzales
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales endured new criticism on Capitol Hill today as House Democrats questioned his leadership of the Department of Justice and his personal candor.

title: Ottawa, East Finalist, Asks: Canada, Wheres the Love?
description: When the Ottawa owner, Eugene Melnyk, told a local chamber of commerce gathering last week that he believed all of Canada should be rooting for the Senators because they were the last Canadian team left in the Stanley Cup playoffs, he was exercising a bit of wishful thinking.

title: After a Museum Is Bombed, the Real Trouble Begins
description: In televisions war on terrorism youre either with us or a wrongly accused pawn set up by a sinister, high-placed conspiracy.

title: China Stocks, Rising Steeply, Test New Highs
description: SHANGHAI, May 9  After another feverish day of buying in this countrys amazing bull run, share prices in China broke records again Wednesday, sending the benchmark Shanghai composite index past the 4,000-point level for the first time.

title: Three Writers of Nonfiction Are Honored
description: Writing narrative nonfiction is grueling, lonely work haunted by the question of whether anyone will read the finished book. Youre always worried, Am I just banging my head against the wall?  said Robert Whitaker, who on Tuesday night was awarded the J. Anthony Lukas Work in Progress Award for Twelve Condemned to Die: Scipio Africanus Jones and the Struggle for Justice That Remade a Nation, to be published by Crown.

title: Bush Tours Tornado-Ravaged Town in Kansas and Promises Governor Help in Rebuilding
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  With memories of his administrations flat-footed response to Hurricane Katrina still lingering, President Bush visited a tornado-wrecked patch of Kansas on Wednesday to pledge administration vigilance in recovery efforts.

title: Boxings Big Night: What Was It We Saw?
description: The long estrangement between boxing and mainstream sports culture has made the actual fighting in a so-called superfight almost irrelevant. When a matchup catches the attention of the general sporting public and press, most casual observers are so out of practice at evaluating boxing that theres almost no consideration of substance to offset the hype.

title: Apolitical Justice Dept.? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Legal Advice Is a First Step in Setting Up Screening
description: Business owners interested in setting up a drug screening program should consult a lawyer first, as rules vary by state.

title: Psychiatrists, Children and Drug Industrys Role
description: When Anya Bailey developed an eating disorder after her 12th birthday, her mother took her to a psychiatrist at the University of Minnesota who prescribed a powerful antipsychotic drug called Risperdal.

title: Accumulate This
description: IN 1947, the bodies of the reclusive, eccentric Collyer brothers were discovered in their Harlem brownstone, amid tons of newspapers, musical instruments, sofas, chandeliers  the fruits of 40 years of obsessive collecting.

title: Feeling the Burn, and the Triumph, After Some Gritty Labors
description: When the members of Urban Bush Women took their bows at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night after Walking with Pearl ... Africa Diaries, they did not look like performers, though all are powerful dancers.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (BBCA) INNOCENT This British import from the producer of State of Play follows a team of law students as they re-examine the cases of those they believe wrongly convicted of serious crimes. Lloyd Owen (above, far left) plays their leader, Professor Jon Ford, a champion of the underdog who has established a legal center for those with nowhere else to turn. His team: the idealistic Adam (Luke Treadaway); the passionate Beth (Ruth Bradley); Nick (Oliver James), a charmer; Sarah (Christine Bottomley), who harbors a wealth of useless information; and Andrew (Stephen Graham), on sabbatical from a police department, who just might help the others grow up.

title: Blogging for Truth and Beauty
description: MOST bloggers have never met a beauty product or treatment they didnt love. The fill their columns with wildly enthusiastic prose about the latest blush, the newest procedure or research that they laud as cutting-edge.

title: Childs Play (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Radical Solutions for Paying the Rent in New York
description: With very low vacancy rates for apartments in New York, real estate brokers say radical solutions among young, well-educated newcomers to the city are becoming more common. Some new arrivals have even made homes in unoccupied office space.

title: Pope Steps to the Microphone
description: Pope Benedict XVI gave the first substantial press conference of his two year papacy, 35,000 feet above Algeria (on a plane that was still 4,600 miles from his destination, Sao Paulo). He did not fail to make news, as he seemed to raise the possibility of excommunication for Catholic politicians who support abortion laws. The Vatican quickly issued clarifications, saying that the pope did not mean to make new policy: Now, as before, the question of whether a pro-choice Catholic politician receives communion rests with his or her individual conscience.

title: Excerpts From 'Stuck in the Middle'
description: Selections from an anthology subtitled "Seventeen Comics From an Unpleasant Age."

title: Here Comes the . . . Bill
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: YOO!
description: YOOMexico

title: Henry and Eliza, Back on Broadway
description: The persnickety professor Henry Higgins and the courageous Cockney Eliza Doolittle will be at each other's throats once again in September, when the Roundabout Theater Company opens its 2007-8 season with a new production of George Bernard Shaw's "Pygmalion."

title: Energy Investors Look to Private Equity Partners
description: Venture investors are searching for a new model for alternative energy deals, and partnerships with private equity funds may be part of the solution, The Deal reports. These investors want to get high returns on early developments so they are not diluted when the time comes for raising capital for building production facilities. Volatile energy prices only add to the uncertainty. Its a very difficult balancing act for venture capital investors in energy right now, the head of the energy ventures group at Portland, Ore.-based law firm Stoel Rives tells The Deal.

title: Rags to Royalty
description: Images from "Poiret: King of Fashion" at the Metropolitan Museum's Costume Institute.

title: G.E. Buys Rest of Japans Sanyo Credit
description: General Electric said Wednesday that it had paid 126.3 billion yen ($1.05 billion) for the Japanese leasing company Sanyo Electric Credit. G.E. paid 3,250 yen a share for 97 percent of Sanyo Credits stock, the company said. The company bought the shares from Sanyo Electric and two Goldman Sachs units. G.E. is focusing on lending to companies after the Japanese government tightened consumer credit rules.

title: Morgan Stanley Will Pay $8 Million to Settle Fraud Case
description: Morgan Stanley agreed Wednesday to pay nearly $8 million to settle federal fraud charges stemming from its reported failure to get retail stock investors the best prices possible on more than a million over-the-counter transactions.

title: Supporting the King of Fashion
description: Photos from the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute Benefit Gala "Poiret: The King of Fashion."

title: Microsoft to Invest in CareerBuilder Web Site
description: Microsoft said Wednesday that it would take a small equity stake in CareerBuilder, a popular job recruitment site operated by Tribune, Gannett and McClatchy. The deal deepens an existing partnership in a lucrative category of online classified advertising.

title: Magna Chairman Confirms an Offer for Chrysler
description: Frank Stronach, the chairman of the auto parts maker Magna International, confirmed Wednesday that his company and Onex, a Canadian investment company, have made a bid for Chrysler, the struggling American unit of DaimlerChrysler.

title: TomoTherapy Stock Makes Healthy Debut
description: Shares of TomoTherapy, a venture-backed maker of medical devices, rose 20 percent in their first day on the Nasdaq. It was the years second-largest initial public offering of a life-sciences company.

title: Pressed by Police
description: Recent criminal cases have shown just how far the Japanese authorities will go in securing confessions.

title: Defense Attacks Credibility of Blacks Former Associate
description: A defense lawyer in Conrad M. Blacks criminal fraud trial attacked the credibility of the chief prosecution witness, F. David Radler, on Wednesday by pointing out the numerous times Mr. Radler had lied before he cut a deal with federal prosecutors.

title: Rosneft Buys More Yukos Assets
description: A subsidiary of Russias state-controlled oil company Rosneft bought the remaining production and refining assets of bankrupt Yukos on Thursday at an auction for 165.5 billion rubles ($6.42 billion).

title: 3i Has Record Year
description: 3i, the publicly listed British private equity firm, reaped a record 2.4 billion pounds ($4.8 billion) in sales proceeds from its investments in the past financial year, but expects returns from assets disposals to slow.

title: UniCredit Sizes Up Societe Generale and Capitalia
description: UniCredit, Italys biggest bank, is on the hunt and has Societe Generale and Capitalia in its sights. The bank, which just 18 months ago shelled out $21 billion to take over the HVB Group of Germany, said it is considering making a move either on the French bank or the Italian lender, which is controlled by a group of investors including ABN Amro.

title: Johnson & Johnson Leads $65 Million Round for CVRx
description: CVRx raised $65 million in a fourth round of funding as the company is poised to launch a pivotal clinical trial to win approval for the first implantable device for modulating high blood pressure. The deal brings total funding in the six-year-old company to $125 million.

title: Freshly Launched Joost Scores $45 Million
description: That was fast. The online video site Joost, the latest venture by the founders of Skype, has raised $45 million in funding from four venture capital and media groups, just a week after introducing the service.

title: Biotech on an M&A Tear
description: The pace of mergers and acquisitions in the biotechnology industry is expected to continue at a torrid pace through 2007, said panelists at the Biotechnology Industry Organization conference in Boston on Wednesday. The bullish forecast was issued after a recent Ernst & Young report found that biotech deals in the United States were valued at a record $23 billion in 2006 while high premiums drove the value of acquisitions to the second highest level in history.

title: At Tribune Meeting, a Passing of the Torch
description: The torch, it seems, has been passed. During an annual meeting that The Chicago Tribune notes was more noteworthy for its symbolism than its substance, Tribunes chief executive, Dennis FitzSimons, welcomed the Chicago billionaire Sam Zell to the Tribune board on Wednesday and all but said goodbye to its largest, most antagonistic shareholder, Californias Chandler family.

title: Depite Mixed Results, I.P.O.s from China Tempt Investors
description: In its IPO Report, MarketWatch.com notes that public offerings from Chinese companies listing in the United States are being well-received on Wall Street, although two new listings last week had mixed results.

title: BlackBerry Curve
description: May 10 - The Curve is a pleasant and logical descendant of the Pearl.

title: Northwest Creditors Approve Reorganization Plan
description: Taking another step toward leaving bankruptcy, Northwest Airlines said a majority of its creditors has approved its reorganization plan. Based on its unofficial count, 97 percent of the creditors that voted approved Northwests plan, the airline said.

title: Dow Jones Inquiry Could Be Awkward for Hong Kong
description: Many in Hong Kong were surprised to learn that a local aristocrat and business magnate, David K.P. Li, may come under scrutiny in relation to stock trading ahead of Rupert Murdochs $5 billion for Dow Jones. But the investigation by American regulators into the possible leak of confidential information could have wider effects, potentially damaging the citys attempts to shake its reputation for financial regulations that are weaker than the Wests, The New York Times reports. Hong Kong only made insider trading a criminal offense in 2003, and has not yet brought any prosecutions under the statute.

title: Amaranth Settles S.E.C. Charges
description: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that collapsed last fall losing some $6 billion, has agreed to pay more than $716,000 to settle charges of violating securities rules, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday.

title: S.E.C. to Weigh in On Merrill Lynch Rule
description: Wall Street brokerage firms are on edge awaiting a decision next week by the Securities and Exchange Commissions chief, Christopher Cox, that could put nearly $300 billion of their clients money in limbo.

title: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
description: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class, Skip McGee, Lehmans head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

title: The $1 C.E.O.: Narcissist or Everyman?
description: In an era of skyrocketing pay for chief executives and growing shareholder angst about it, a handful of C.E.O.s are opting to draw a $1 paycheck or none at all. Seven C.E.O.s in the Standard & Poors 500-stock index were paid $1 or less in 2006, including Apples Steven P. Jobs and Googles Eric Schmidt.

title: ABN Amros Finance Chief to Step Down
description: ABN Amro, the Dutch bank at the center of one of the biggest bidding wars in history, said Thursday that its chief financial officer, Hugh Scott-Barrett, would resign in August. News of Mr. Scott-Barretts departure came as ABN is trying to fend off an unsolicited $98 billion takeover approach so it can be acquired in a friendly deal by Barclays of Britain. ABN said late Wednesday it would appeal a decision in a Dutch court that halted the sale of the LaSalle Bank, its Chicago subsidiary, to the Bank of America. That side deal was widely seen as an attempt to drive off the rival bidding group, led by the Royal Bank of Scotland.

title: Is Alltel Out of Private Equitys League?
description: Following a report that Alltel, a rural wireless telecom service provider, is being courted by a slew of private equity firms, TheDeal.com suggests that the company might be too healthy to be a viable candidate for a leveraged buyout.

title: From Murdoch, Sweet Words, Not a Sweetened Bid
description: Rupert Murdoch, the chief executive of the News Corporation, on Wednesday defended his unsolicited offer for Dow Jones, which has run into opposition from the Bancroft family, the companys controlling shareholders, and from Dow Jones employees.

title: The Broad Scope of Broadway
description: The documentary "ShowBusiness" follows four Broadway musicals from rehearsal through the 2004 Tony Awards: "Caroline, or Change," "Taboo," "Avenue Q" and "Wicked." On top of the usual challenges (fund-raising, rewrites, tryouts, marketing), they all had to endure scrutiny by a Greek chorus of theater critics and gossip columnists. (The rogues' gallery includes Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood, critics for The New York Times, and The New York Post's dapper scorpion of a theater columnist, Michael Riedel.)

title: Inverness Raises Bid for Biosite
description: In the continuing battle over Biosite, a maker of laboratory medical tests, Inverness Medical Innovations has raised its bid to $92.50 a share, topping a rival bid by Beckman Coulter. Biosite said Thursday that it had received a letter from Inverness, which already holds a stake of about 5 percent in the company.

title: Apple Shareholders to Vote on Compensation Proposals
description: Even as its stock is riding high off the success of the iPod and anticipation of the iPhone, Apple will face some restive shareholders at its annual meeting Thursday, TheStreet.com reported. Labor unions who own Apple shares through pension funds, have put up proposals that require options to be priced on the day they are granted to eliminate the practice known as backdating; that give investors a nonbinding vote on executive compensation, known as say on pay; and that tie executive bonuses to the companys stock performance.

title: Cutting Hair and Cutting Remarks
description: In "The Salon" the normally vivacious Vivica A. Fox seems as artistically depleted as her surroundings: an urban beauty shop where cutting hair and cutting remarks go hand in hand. As Jenny, the beleaguered owner of a Baltimore beauty shop catering primarily to African-American women, Ms. Fox plays moderator to a relentless stream of high drama and low wit.

title: Beats With a Meaning
description: Giving "inspirational" a good name, Matt Ruskin's vibrant and soulful documentary "The Hip Hop Project" sets its universal message to an inner-city beat. Named for the New York City youth program founded in 1999 by Chris Rolle, known as Kazi, a Bahamian orphan forced to grow up on the streets of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the movie follows his efforts to encourage at-risk teenagers to express themselves in verse rather than violence.

title: Disney v. Hamas
description: An illegal Hamascot? The Los Angeles Times editorial page encourages Disney to sue Hamas over Farfur, a Mickey Mouse clone that until recently hosted Tomorrows Pioneers, a kids television show on Hamas Al Aqsa TV station. The editorial quotes the cartoon rodent as saying, We will liberate Al Aqsa, inshallah; we will liberate Iraq, inshallah; and we will liberate the Muslim countries invaded by murderers. Could Disneys ferocious army of copyright lawyers bring down a sponsor of international terrorism? Maybe:

title: A Sense of Purpose Takes Flight
description: Nic Bettauer's low-budget "Duck" is going for that warm-and-feathery feeling generated by the best of the human-bird love stories, movies like "Fly Away Home" and "Paulie." But it doesn't come within quacking distance, partly because it tries too hard and partly because, frankly, ducks aren't all that endearing.

title: The Cold Male Gaze
description: "Casting About," from the documentary filmmaker Barry J. Hershey ("The Empty Mirror"), is a record of casting calls for lead actresses in a dramatic feature that Mr. Hershey wrote but has yet to direct: a seemingly Hemingwayesque drama involving a wounded combat photographer, a nun, a dancer and a painter's model. From its opening montage of head shots through its fragments of auditions and between-performance chatter, "Casting About" is a solid documentary about how art is made.

title: Rock Off the Radar
description: See the churches, lofts, galleries, museums and silos where you can hear music, far from New York's madding clubs.

title: Blair Says He Will Leave Office in June
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair has announced that he will leave office on June 27 after a decade in power in which he sacrificed his popularity to the war in Iraq and struggled at home to improve schools, policing and hospitals.

title: The Pillar: Isabella Blow
description: Her arrival at a fashion show usually set off a current of excitement: Ah, theres Isabella. Whats she got on? It could be a McQueen couture dress, corseted and padded, so as to show off her figure. She wore McQueen better than anyone else; the clothes were realized on her in a way they were not on other women, and probably because she understood their entire aesthetic history. The meeting of Izzy Blow and Lee McQueen must have been one of those moments when you would have gladly consented to be a fly, just to observe the action. How would he have reacted to this woman? Knowing Izzy, she would have been smoking, the red lipstick stain going well up the paper. She would have almost certainly been wearing one of Philip Treacys hats; she had already recognized his talents. And her enthusiasm and energy would have been limitless, and a little terrifying.

title: 2008: Giulianis Political Science Experiment
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani is about to test decades of Republican precedent. Rather than walking the abortion tightrope (hate it personally, support choice as public policy, but would nominate strict constructionist judges), Mr. Giuliani plans to forthrightly express his support for abortion rights in upcoming appearances, report The Timess Adam Nagourney and Marc Santora. Will his strategic primary choices and post-9/11 leadership image be enough to help him clear this traditional hurdle?

title: Orbitz Shoots for $750 Million I.P.O.
description: Back so soon?

title: Giambi Sidelined but D.L. Not in Sight
description: Last nights Yankees lineup had a slightly different look. Jason Giambi was not in it for the game against Texas at Yankee Stadium due to a bone spur on his left heel.

title: Day of the Dead Tours in Mexico
description: I would like to travel to Oaxaca, Mexico and experience the festival of Da de los Muertos at the end of October/early November this year. Which groups offer good tours for this event?

title: Asterisk or No Asterisk?
description: By MARJORIE CONNELLY

title: Bulking Up in Baghdad
description: Strategies to stem Iraqs insurgency can be debated, but few would disagree that no matter what tack is taken, the violence there is not about to come to a halt anytime soon. So the United States is taking steps to try to save more lives when the enemy lands a blow.

title: Asking the Crowd to Spread the News
description: "Web 2.0," as I understand it, refers to Web sites whose contents are supplied by us, the people. What would Flickr be without its photos, YouTube without the videos, Craigslist without the ads, eBay without the auctions, TripAdvisor without people's travel reviews? These mega-sites would be only empty white pages if the audience didn't supply their materials.

title: Carry On, Blair
Remembering a Plutonium Scare
description: The discovery of slightly elevated amounts of tetrachloroethylene, an industrial chemical also known as perc, in the water supply in Hollis, Queens, dredges up memories of past scares about the safety of the citys water supply.

title: Long Term Capital Alumni Form New Fund
description: Nine years after the math whizzes at Long Term Capital Management found themselves on the brink of a market-rattling collapse  which they narrowly averted thanks to a huge bailout by a consortium of banks  some of the hedge funds former employees are having a reunion of sorts. Bloomberg reports that Eric Rosenfeld, one of Long Term Capitals co-founders, has joined with the funds former chief financial officer, Robert Shustak, and its former controller, Bruce Wilson, to open Quantitative Alternatives, which Bloomberg describes as a hedge fund that uses computers to pick investments. The fund apparently uses humans too: The Rye Brook, N.Y.-based firm is currently hiring research analysts and traders.

title: Asking the Crowd to Spread the News
description: Web 2.0, as I understand it, refers to Web sites whose contents are supplied by us, the people. What would Flickr be without its photos, YouTube without the videos, Craigslist without the ads, eBay without the auctions, TripAdvisor without peoples travel reviews? These mega-sites would be only empty white pages if the audience didnt supply their materials.

title: Blair to Step Down
description: British Prime Minister Tony Blair announced that he would leave office on June 27 after a decade in power.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Deuce" and "God's Ear."

title: Harvey Pitt on Insider Trading, Then and Now
description: The speed with which the Securities and Exchange Commission identified and took action against alleged insider trading in Dow Jones stock this week was a phenomenal achievement, Harvey Pitt, the S.E.C.s former chairman, declared in an interview with The Wall Street Journals Law Blog. Mr. Pitt, who served from 2001 to 2003, said that in the old days, it took a while to figure out who knew what, when and where. I would say enforcement is alive and well.

title: Goldman Unit Seeks to Sell Power Plants
description: Cogentrix Energy, an electricity producer owned by the investment bank Goldman Sachs, has put 14 power plants up for sale, the energy industry Web site SparkSpread reported Thursday. Cogentrix itself, which Goldman acquired in 2003 for $115 million, is not up for sale, the Web site said.

title: Ferraris Surprise Move
description: Just when everyone expected to arrive at the first European race of the season  notice I avoid using that phrase the start of the European season, since this particular European season will only last two races before the circus moves on for the start of the North American season?!  and everyone expected to see all sorts of new motor homes representing various states of team dreams of grandeurand when everyone expected that the most ostentatious display of the motor home art would likely come from McLaren, it turns out that the greatest example of motor home decadence yet to appear in the paddock comes from the team one least expected to see it come from: Ferrari. (That run-on Jamesian sentence, by the way, would be accept nowhere else today outside this blog. My apologies.)

title: At Last, Hope for Lonesome George
description: In the great quest to name Lonesome Georges new mate, I think the most promising new suggestions have come from those who know him best: the biologists whove been studying him. But readers also came up with some excellent nominations.

title: Hamas, Fatah and Mickey Mouse
description: Last night, a Palestinian minister appeared to answer a torrent of outrage when he announced the suspension of a childrens television show starring a Mickey Mouse clone who spouts Islamist slogans.

title: Better Than the First Time
description: Wil Nieves, the backup catcher for the Yankees, broke an 0-for-22 streak Wednesday night when he singled during the Yankees 6-2 victory over the Texas Rangers at Yankee Stadium.

title: Giambi Out Again
description: For the second consecutive game, Jason Giambi was not in the Yankees lineup due to a bone spur on his left heel. Manager Joe Torre said Giambi had a 10:30 a.m. appointment with a foot specialist but was expected back in time for this afternoons game with Texas.

title: Two New Guilty Pleas in Insider Trading Case
description: A former Morgan Stanley compliance lawyer and her husband pleaded guilty to insider trading in federal court Thursday, the latest pleas in a wide-ranging investigation that has touched employees at some of Wall Streets top firms.

title: Budget: $123.9 billion
description: Time for The Empire Zones budget minute, where we distill a new 205-page budget analysis [pdf] from the comptrollers office into four bullet points.

title: Theres Going to Be a Ballpark There
