description: Yankee Stadiums upper deck has a classical sweep. Despite the remodeling of the 1970s, the look is traditional, with three rows of lights above the highest rows of seats and only the sky above the lights. On most days.

title: Another Couple, Another Pair of Insider Trading Arrests
description: Weve begin to think they might want to add a few words to the traditional wedding vow:  Til death  or insider trading charges  do us part.

title: About a World Bank Girl
description: With Paul D. Wolfowitz today getting more time to respond to charges that he mishandled his companions reassignment and pay package, it seemed like a good time to take a look at the woman in question, Shaha Ali Riza.

title: A Private Equity Defender With a Taste for Mystery
description: Facing criticism from unions and lawmakers, the private equity industry has found a passionate champion on the Internet. The only problem is that its unclear who that person is. Percywalker.com, a financial blog of murky provenance, has entered the debate on the taxation of carried interest, a big source of fees for the people who run private equity funds. The blog claims to be written by a billionaire named Percival X. Walker, but when contacted last year by Forbes magazine  which failed to find any mention of Mr. Walker in public documents  the operator of the blog said: I lack the desire to establish that I even exist.

title: Podcast: Zane Greys Manhattan Frontier
description: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

title: 24/7 Media Confirms Hiring Investment Bank
description: The online marketing firm 24/7 Media on Wednesday disclosed that it has hired Lehman Brothers to help it assess strategic alternatives, adding credence to rampant speculation that the company is up for sale. The New York Post reported this week that both WPP Group, the London-based advertising and marketing group, and software gaint Microsoft were leading contenders to buy 24/7, which has a market capitalization of about $560 million.

title: Posada Ever So Briefly Leads the A.L. in Hitting
description: When Jorge Posada batted for the Yankees in the fourth inning, the message beside his picture on the scoreboard said that he led the American League with a .360 batting average.

title: Spitzer Camp: DiNapoli report Misleading
description: The Empire Zone weighs in with more news from the sizzling debate over the state budget. Is it $121 billion? Is it $123.9 billion?

title: At Moguls Trial, Lies! Lies!! Lies!!!
description: F. David Radler must have known that testifying against his boss of 30 years wouldnt be easy. But did he think it was going to get as heated as it did today?

title: 'City of Trash' Ad
description: Items collected from California's freeways and shoulders are shown in this public service announcement.

title: And Yet MORE on Mozza
description: Following the publication Wednesday of my article on Pizzeria Mozza, I received several e-mails from readers that represented the kind of discussion  quibbles, observations, suggestions  that should be seen by more eyes than just my own. Its the kind of discussion encouraged by, and often present on, this blog.

title: Terroir
description: If you want to start an argument in the wine world  and believe me, its not hard to do  all you have to do is mention the word terroir. It is one of the most overused, overworked, misunderstood and misrepresented clichs in wine, though it does have some stiff competition.

title: A Conspiracy So Vast
description: Overstock.com, which has a huge short position, has drawn my attention a few times in the past. (For blogs, see here. For columns, see here, here, here, and here.) I am attracted to the story because Patrick Byrne, the chief executive, has engaged in what he called a jihad against naked short sellers, who sell the shares without borrowing them, and has had some political success. I am more impressed by his jihad-making activity than by his corporate management, but he is certainly different from your average chief executive. He has sued an analyst firm, a hedge fund and most of the major Wall Street firms. An S.E.C. investigation is pending.

title: Sustainability for Rich and Poor
description: Rich and poor countries are deeply divided on many fronts, but perhaps none more so than on the question of who should do what about human-caused global warming.

title: Frank Torre Back in Intensive Care
description: Joe Torre, the Yankees manager, said Thursday that his brother, Frank, has returned to the intensive care unit of an area hospital due to an infection that followed a recent kidney transplant.

title: Movie Minutes: '28 Weeks Later'
description: A. O. Scott, the Chief Movie Critic of the New York Times, reviews "28 Weeks Later," the sequel to the 2003 film "28 Days Later."

title: Movie Minutes: 'Sleep Alone'
description: A. O. Scott, the Chief Movie Critic of the New York Times reviews "I Don't Want to Sleep Alone," set in the slums of Kuala Lumpur.

title: Candidates Live, From MySpace to Yours
description: MySpace has it out for Iowa and New Hampshire. First, the social networking site announced that it would hold the first primary of 2008, letting its users pick their favorite candidate throughout the first two days of January. Now its trying to break the early primary states monopoly on intimate, unrehearsed meetings with the candidates by offering all 66 million of its unique monthly visitors the chance to participate in town hall forums with the presidential candidates.

title: Giulianis Tough Week
description: First came the revelation that Rudolph W. Giuliani had given repeatedly to Planned Parenthood, furthering angering conservatives upset about his abortion stance. Then the Village Voice raised questions about whether he got a discount on four diamond rings commemorating the Yankees recent World Series rings. Could the week get any tougher for Mr. Giuliani?

title: High Line Festival
description: Melena Ryzik of The Times hits the the opening night party of the High Line Festival.

title: A White Tie Kind of Guy
description: So President Bush, it seems, confounded expectations and managed to keep it together for Queen Elizabeth IIs state visit this week. He didnt slobber, chug-a-lug from an Evian bottle, spew bits of buttered roll or engage in any impromptu shoulder massages.

title: Perils of an Ideological Presidency
description: That great pipe-puffing philosopher of the Nixon presidency, John Mitchell, once famously observed: Watch what we do, not what we say. In other words, forget the rhetoric and pay attention to the more telltale actions of what eventually became a disgraced administration.

title: Mia, the Gold Medalist
description: Sports Illustrated has a terrific column about Mia Farrow, the champion of the campaign to pressure China to behave better in Darfur. Mia has been relentless on Darfur and has used her megaphone to back the genocide Olympics campaign. The idea isnt to boycott the Olympics, but to make China realize that its Olympic dream will be marred if it continues to underwrite genocide in Sudan.

title: The Real Darfur Puppy!
description: After my column Thursday lamented the lack of a photogenic puppy that could focus public sympathy on the Darfur genocide, I had this remarkable email from an American who until recently worked in Sudan. Call ABC News  finally theyll cover the story!

title: Mayweather Tries Broadcasting, but Ponders His Future
description: Floyd Mayweather would make a good boxing commentator.

title: Facebook to Offer Free Classifieds
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 10  Facebook, the social networking Web site, is adding free classified ad listings, putting it into competition with dozens of established companies like Craigslist and many newspapers.

title: A Neighborhood of Colonials and Palm Trees
description: ANYONE who still considers St. Petersburg, Fla., the last stop before checking into a nursing home may be shocked by the transformation of this once sleepy Gulf Coast city. Construction cranes pierce the sky, topping off a series of new high-rise condominiums. Closer to the ground, daytime visitors tarry between art museums, a farmers market and the waterfront park, while young professionals pack restaurants and clubs at night.

title: Realism, Both Magic and Downright Mean
description: Aside from the presence of a few cars and a biplane, the setting of Disappearances  Kingdom County in Vermont during the closing days of Prohibition in 1932  might as well be 1870s Deadwood in the Black Hills of the Dakota Territory. In some ways life in rural New England was even more hardscrabble.

title: Shareholders Give Ex-Chief the Blame for Ford Woes
description: WILMINGTON, Del., May 10  A group of Ford Motor shareholders took turns blaming the companys executive chairman, William Clay Ford Jr., at the annual meeting Thursday, criticizing every decision he made as the former chief executive except one. That was his decision last September to hire a Boeing executive, Alan R. Mulally, as his successor.

title: Romney Works to Put Skeptics Doubts to Rest
description: AMES, Iowa, May 10  Bart Pals, a county chairman for Mitt Romneys presidential campaign, had been given talking points to use when he introduced the former Massachusetts governor at an event in northern Iowa on Wednesday.

title: Never Too Late to Vote
description: LAST month, Gov. Chet Culver of Iowa signed a bill authorizing Election Day registration, which allows previously unregistered voters with proper ID the opportunity to cast a ballot that day. This is a powerful tool to promote voting and, as secretaries of state of two states that already have this policy in place, we welcome Iowa in joining our ranks.

title: Sabbatinis Goal Is to Win Tournaments, Not Friends
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., May 10  In a sport light on trash talk and heavy on backslapping, Rory Sabbatini is an anomaly in an oversized belt buckle.

title: Juvenile Injustice
description: The United States made a disastrous miscalculation when it started automatically trying youthful offenders as adults instead of handling them through the juvenile courts. Prosecutors argued that the policy would get violent predators off the streets and deter further crime. But a new federally backed study shows that juveniles who do time as adults later commit more violent crime than those who are handled through the juvenile courts.

title: Nature, Nature, Burning Bright (High-Def Cameras Frame Thy Fearful Symmetry)
description: When it comes right down to it, there are precious few DVDs of television series that a modern gentleman or lady absolutely must buy, bind and emboss, and shelve for all time. These include My So-Called Life, the British Office, the soon-to-be complete Sopranos, VH1s I Love New York and Friday Night Lights. (That last acquisition should be made this summer, the minute the DVDs of that dramas great first season  the first of many great seasons, surely  goes on sale.)

title: A Loving Look at a Cinematic Tough Guy: Gangster, Hit Man, Gunslinger
description: Lee Marvin moved across the screen like a shark coming in for the kill. Long and lean, with shoulders that looked as wide as his hips and hair as silver as a bullet, he seemed built for speed. He roamed across genres, excelling at gangsters and cowboys. Romance was not his thing. He could make you laugh, at times uneasily, but its his bad men that stick in your head. They are scary as hell, sometimes seductively so, because their every punch and twist of the knife seems delivered not in the heat of violence but in its chill.

title: Brewers Off to a Fast Start
description: He used to be one of them. Craig Counsell grew up a Milwaukee Brewers fan in Whitefish Bay, Wis., partly because of location, and partly because his father, John, worked for the teams community relations department.

title: Fisher Is a Father First, and a Jazz Player Later
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 10  Derek Fisher had 30 minutes Tuesday morning to decide whether to remove his daughters left eye.

title: Because Its Good for You, Thats Why
description: There are many ways for a writer to tell you to eat your vegetables: earnestly, humorously, scientifically, self-righteously, instructively or so voluptuously that the page practically reeks of fertilizer. Barbara Kingsolvers way is both folksy and smart. While she is cogent and illuminating about serious matters of nutrition, Ms. Kingsolver also finds ways to convey what its like to be showered with friends plants as birthday gifts, regard a full supply of potatoes as homeland security, and fend off the amorous attention of a lovesick turkey hen.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about an ethics panel report clearing Gov. Jon S. Corzine, Democrat of New Jersey, of conflicts of interest in conducting state labor negotiations with a union led by a woman with whom he once had a romantic relationship referred incorrectly to The Timess efforts to reach the governors office for comment. The reporter sent an e-mail message to a Corzine spokesman; he did not place phone calls. (The message was never delivered because of technical problems, but the reporter was not aware of that until the next day.)

title: A Ski Community Where Theres No Such Thing as Too Much
description: THE homes at the Yellowstone Mountain Club would never be confused with the simple log cabins that once dotted the Old West.

title: The Art of Political Damage Control
description: Is Senator Barack Obama mastering the art of political damage control?

title: Blair Endorses Gordon Brown as His Successor
description: LONDON, May 11  A day after announcing that he would step down in June, Prime Minister Tony Blair offered a fulsome if long-delayed endorsement today of Gordon Brown as his successor, calling him an extraordinary and rare talent.

title: Electric Pulses, Instead of Shocks, Can Help Heart Patients
description: DENVER, May 10  Many heart patients who believe that their lives have been saved by shocks from implanted defibrillators could have survived without a jolt from the devices, according to research presented here today at a meeting of heart specialists.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,371 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Republicans in Congress Press Bush for Sanctions on Sudan
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  In the latest attempt to exert pressure on Sudan over the killing in the Darfur region, a group of conservative to moderate Republicans in Congress demanded Thursday that President Bush impose sanctions against the government for its failure to rein in the violence.

title: Ramos-Horta Wins East Timors Presidential Election
description: HONG KONG, May 11  Jos Ramos-Horta won a decisive victory in East Timors presidential election this week, a significant move toward creating genuine multi-party democracy in the country and breaking the dominance of the political organization that largely led its struggle for independence, analysts and election observers said today.

title: Earnhardt Drops Team Built by His Father to Become a Free Agent
description: MOORESVILLE, N.C., May 10  Dale Earnhardt Jr., the son of a legend and the most popular driver in Nascar, has put himself on the open market for 2008. His free agency will send ripples throughout the sport, potentially affecting driver salaries, merchandise sales and even television ratings, not to mention the balance of power among race teams.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: NBC Orders Five Dramas for Next Season
description: NBC took the first steps toward rebuilding its prime-time schedule yesterday by ordering five new hours of drama programs, which will be part of the fall schedule the network plans to announce to advertisers on Monday.

title: In Defense of the Right to a Defense
description: The distance from West 44th Street in Manhattan to Guantnamo Bay in Cuba is roughly 1,400 miles as the crow flies, assuming no grand detours by the crow. Metaphorically speaking, the distance between West 44th Street and Washington seems far greater right now.

title: For the Record
description: A theater review on Monday about Beauty on the Vine, at the Harold Clurman Theater, referred incorrectly to the plays sponsorship. Donna Karan contributed one costume and Lancme made a small financial contribution. The play is not sponsored by various cosmetic and fashion companies.

title: U.N. Security Council to Review Draft on Kosovo Independence
description: UNITED NATIONS, May 10  The United States and its European allies will circulate a draft Security Council resolution Friday to endorse a plan granting Kosovo supervised independence, Zalmay Khalilzad, the American ambassador to the United Nations, said Thursday.

title: In Houston, Giuliani Defends Abortion Stance
description: HOUSTON, May 11  Rudolph W. Giuliani directly challenged Republican Party orthodoxy on Friday, asserting that his support for abortion rights, gun control and gay rights should not disqualify him from winning the partys presidential nomination and that Republicans need to be tolerant of dissenting views on those issues if they want to hold the White House.

title: A Cheerleader for Brooklyns Treasury of Books
description: IF keeping intelligent tabs on the Brooklyn Public Librarys $92 million operating budget, 60 libraries, 1,100 full-time employees, five million circulating and reference items, and nearly 1.1 million cardholders  she thinks of them as shareholders in the New Age knowledge bank  is what passes for bookish these days, then Dionne Mack-Harvin is a consummate librarian.

title: Punishing Court Day for Blacks Ex-Deputy
description: CHICAGO, May 10  F. David Radler, the chief witness against the media baron Conrad M. Black, endured more withering cross-examination on Thursday, and was again called a liar before a federal jury hearing the case against Mr. Black and others accused of stealing millions from the publishing company Hollinger International.

title: The Somber Sound of Nondenominational Mysticism
description: Stretching time and collapsing space: Thats what Lisa Gerrard was up to when she performed at the Concert Hall at the New York Society for Ethical Culture on Wednesday night.

title: Channeling Group Dynamics Fueled by the Power of Funk
After Scandal, Cycling Struggles for Sponsors
description: PARIS  With the Tour de France approaching this summer, the sport of cycling is taking brutal spills in corporate suites, where deals are made to sponsor competitions with little attention to return on investment.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (Sundance) MUTUAL APPRECIATION (2005) This wonderful independent film directed by Andrew Bujalski looks like something that just came out of a time capsule, but theres nothing dusty about it, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, comparing its artfully artless, low-fi vibe to the French New Wave and the East Village film scene of the late 1970s. Alan (Justin Rice, above), a musician whose band has just broken up, arrives in New York in pursuit of a rock n roll career. Seung-Min Lee, at his left, plays Sara, a radio D.J. who would like more from Alan than he wants to give; Mr. Bujalski is Lawrence, Alans best friend; and Rachel Clift is Ellie, Lawrences girlfriend  and the woman Alan would take, if he could. Its the sort of unassuming discovery that could get lost in a crowd or suffer from too much big love, and while it wont save or change your life, it may make your heart swell, Ms. Dargis wrote. Its aim is modest and true.

title: Inquiry on New Jersey Prostitutes Deaths Slows, Frustrating Families
description: Nearly six months after the bodies of four prostitutes were found in a ditch on the outskirts of Atlantic City, tips have slowed to a trickle. The task force investigating the deaths, which used to gather every day after the gruesome discovery, now meets only twice a week.

title: Awaiting Rock-Eating Beast, L.I.R.R. Tunnel Is Poised to Finish Trip to Grand Central
description: All the parts needed to build a mammoth tunnel-boring machine are crossing the Atlantic Ocean on a boat from Italy and are due to arrive tomorrow at the port in Newark.

title: Bristol-Myers Agrees to Plead Guilty in Plavix Case
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb, the drug company, will plead guilty to criminal charges that it made false statements to the government  the same crime that landed Martha Stewart in prison  to end a federal antitrust investigation of its botched efforts to preserve a lucrative monopoly for the anti-clotting medicine Plavix.

title: JetBlues Leader Is Giving Up Chief Executive Title
description: Everyone takes things personally, but David G. Neeleman is that rare corporate executive who admits to those feelings.

title: U.S. Queries Filmmaker on Cuba Trip for Movie
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10  Michael Moore, the provocative filmmaker who has made a career out of skewering automakers, gun enthusiasts and the Bush administration, is being investigated by the Treasury Department over a trip he made to Cuba for his new film, Sicko.

title: Shots Fired at Residence of Aide to Pakistans Ousted Chief Judge
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 10  Shots were fired early Thursday at the home of a lawyer for the suspended chief justice of Pakistans Supreme Court, government officials said.

title: Toasting the Neighbors
description: WHO Ralph Erath, 45, an information technology help desk manager from Kennewick, Wash.

title: What to Wear to a Revolution
description: Poiret: King of Fashion, the Metropolitan Museum of Arts sumptuous survey of the designs of the French couturier Paul Poiret (1879-1944), will transform your understanding of the origin of modern fashion. Its radiant hand-painted silk backdrops may also increase your appreciation of the art of set design; they magically create an immersive beauty out of almost nothing.

title: Britain: Fashion Legend Drank Weed Killer
description: Isabella Blow, the colorful and influential British fashion editor, talent spotter and aristocrat who died in a hospital in Gloucestershire on Monday, ended her life by drinking the herbicide paraquat, The Times of London reported on its Web site. It said that at the opening of an inquest into her death yesterday, the deputy Gloucestershire coroner, David Dooley, reported that after Ms. Blow, 48, was found in a poorly state on Saturday and taken to the hospital, she told doctors she had taken paraquat, and tests proved positive for this liquid. Further toxicological tests are to be done before a full inquest in October.

title: Blair Choreographs End to a Stewardship Dogged by Iraq
description: LONDON, May 10  He announced the end with much the same flourish as, 10 years ago, he initiated a decade in power that became known as his era. By turns pensive, boastful and humble, Tony Blair made a final pitch to his followers on Thursday to accept that, whatever else, he did what he thought was right.

title: Corrections
description: The Shanghai Journal article on Tuesday, about competition among developers in Shanghai and elsewhere to construct the worlds tallest building, misidentified the builder of a 2,300-foot skyscraper in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, which will be the record-holder when completed. The skyscraper, called the Burj Dubai, is under construction by an international team that includes the Samsung Corporation of South Korea, the main contractor; Turner Construction International of New York; Skidmore, Owings and Merrill LLP, the Chicago-based architecture firm; and Emaar Properties, the Dubai-based developer that owns the property. The team does not include relatives of Osama bin Laden. (The Saudi Binladin Group, a construction company owned by Mr. bin Ladens relatives, was a finalist in the bidding to build Burj Dubai but lost to the Samsung team).

title: Duke Lacrosse Team Uses Work Ethic to Fix Image
description: DURHAM, N.C., May 9  These are heady times for the Duke mens lacrosse program. The Blue Devils earned their first top seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament, which begins Saturday. The team earned a cumulative 3.45 grade-point average during the fall semester, and by Sunday, its 13 seniors will have graduated.

title: On Carrier in Gulf, Cheney Warns Iran
description: BRUSSELS, May 11  Vice President Dick Cheney used the deck of an American aircraft carrier just 150 miles off Irans coast as the backdrop today to warn the country that the United States was prepared to use its naval power to keep Tehran from disrupting off oil routes or gaining nuclear weapons and dominating this region.

title: Passage of Drug Safety Bill Was Common Goal for Two Very Different Senators
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  Legislation to beef up drug safety, passed by the Senate this week with only one dissenting vote, grew out of an extraordinary pact between two senators and a frantic effort by the pharmaceutical industry to avoid any disruption in the approval of new drugs.

title: Correction: Old Kansas, Still Growing Tall
description: An article last Friday about the Flint Hills Scenic Byway in eastern Kansas misspelled the name of an anti-alcohol campaigner who was active a century ago in the area. She was Carry Nation, not Carrie, although she and others sometimes used that spelling.

title: The Human Community
description: The conventional view of Tony Blair is that he was a talented New Labor leader whose career was sadly overshadowed by Iraq. But this is absurd. Its like saying that an elephant is a talented animal whose virtues are sadly overshadowed by the fact that its big and has a trunk.

title: Germany: Protests Over Raids
description: More than 5,000 people poured into the streets of several cities to protest a crackdown on leftist groups before a Group of 8 meeting in the city of Heiligendamm next month. The police in Hamburg clashed with demonstrators there, arresting eight people. Some opposition leaders criticized the raids, saying the police were trying to intimidate legitimate opponents of the meeting.

title: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about winners of the Lukas Prize Project Awards, which recognize excellence in nonfiction writing, misspelled the name of the foundation that jointly administers the prizes with the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. It is the Nieman Foundation for Journalism at Harvard University  not Neiman.

title: U.S. Charges a Leading Chicago Political Figure With Fraud and Bribery
description: CHICAGO, May 10  A powerful former alderman who in the 1980s led a bitter rebellion of white politicians against the citys first black mayor was indicted Thursday on federal charges of fraud and bribery.

title: Wildfire Threatens a California Resort Island
description: Firefighters struggled early today to prevent a wildfire from reaching homes on the edge of Santa Catalina Islands main town, as residents and visitors fled the resort island off the Southern California coast.

title: A Slow, Steady Approach to Governing in Corzines First Week Back
description: TRENTON, May 10  When Mayor Jerramiah T. Healy of Jersey City listened to his messages last week, he was surprised to hear a 90-second one related to an environmental issue from someone who had just been released from the hospital: Gov. Jon S. Corzine.

title: British Officers Wont Be Disciplined Over Shooting
description: LONDON, May 11  An official police oversight body ruled on Friday that 11 officers involved in the fatal shooting of a 27-year-old Brazilian electrician they allegedly mistook for a terrorist would not face disciplinary hearings.

title: California: Ill Woman Is Dropping Marijuana Battle
description: A terminally ill woman who sued the United States government over the right to use medical marijuana, as state law allows, said she was dropping her five-year legal battle. The woman, Angel M. Raich, 41, of Oakland, said in a statement that she had decided to concentrate on radiation therapy to treat a brain tumor, rather than appealing a federal court ruling that she was not immune to federal prosecution despite California law. Im not a quitter, so this was a hard decision, said Ms. Raich, who has never been prosecuted. She said she intended to take her battle to Congress.

title: Civil Liberties Advocate Named Ombudsman for Texas Youth
description: HOUSTON, May 10  A leading civil liberties advocate was named Thursday as the first ombudsman of the Texas Youth Commission, after a sexual abuse scandal.

title: Police Officer Accused of Killing His Girlfriend
description: A 37-year-old police officer was arrested last night in connection with the fatal shooting of his girlfriend on a Queens street after she broke up with him, the police said.

title: The Sarkozy of the Future Jousts With the Chirac of the Past
description: PARIS, May 10  Repentance for the sins of the past has come easy to President Jacques Chirac. He will be remembered as the first French leader to recognize the countrys crimes against Jews in World War II and to commemorate formally its complicity in African slavery.

description: KONYA, Turkey, May 10  The Turkish Parliament approved a constitutional amendment on Thursday that would allow the president to be elected in a direct nationwide vote.

title: City Tests Idea of Building Apartments by Brooklyn Jail
description: City officials have devised what may be the ultimate test of demand for housing in New York: They are asking developers if they want to build apartments pressed up on the side of the Brooklyn House of Detention.

title: Retailers Issue Gloomy Sales Report for April
description: It was, in a word, dismal.

title: Senators Score Late and Often in Taking an Early Series Lead
description: BUFFALO, May 10  For a player who has struggled to find a home in Ottawas lineup since the Senators traded for him in late February, Oleg Saprykin found himself in the perfect spot Thursday night to become the Senators most unlikely star.

title: Carter Comes Close to Blaming Himself
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 10  Vince Carter had his entire arsenal going Thursday: the dismissive smirk, the practiced nonchalance, the mildly defensive monotone.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sowing the Substance of Life
description: Living where we do, it can be hard to tell how ordinary our Sun is, shining dimly in our ordinary galaxy. Then comes something to remind us. This time it is a colossal supernova, called SN 2006gy, the brightest ever recorded. A supernova is an exploding star. This one, first observed last September, lies about 240 million light-years from us in the constellation Perseus. The explosion was perhaps 100 times more powerful than an ordinary supernova, and the star that exploded may have been 150 times the Suns mass, freakishly massive, as one astronomer put it. A photograph of SN 2006gy shows that it vastly outshines the entire galaxy in which it is located. This takes some imagining.

title: Revisiting the True Story of a Battered Wifes Revenge
description: With its tone of unremitting gentility Provoked may be the most restrained wife-beating drama ever to grace a movie screen. Based on the true story of Kiranjit Ahluwalia (played by the Bollywood star Aishwarya Rai), a London housewife from Punjab who killed her sleeping husband in 1989 using a homemade cocktail of gasoline and caustic soda, the movie is tasteful to a fault. Unfortunately, in keeping its inflammatory subject matter at arms length, Provoked does exactly the same to its audience.

title: Elmira: Company Fined for Dumping
description: Kennedy Valve, an Elmira-based company that has been manufacturing fire hydrants since the 1890s, pleaded guilty yesterday in Chemung County Court to illegally dumping more than two tons of lead-contaminated waste from 2001 to 2004 in a county landfill that was not licensed to handle hazardous material. Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said the company claimed the material was not hazardous when it applied for a dumping permit. Samples of the waste were subsequently sent for analysis to laboratories that confirmed that it contained lead, Mr. Cuomo said. The company was fined $300,000 for unlawful dealing in hazardous wastes and agreed to pay $1.5 million to finance a lead removal program for children. Kennedy Valve is a division of McWane Inc., a manufacturer that has been convicted of safety and environmental violations in several states.

title: U.S. Backs Off Limits on Guantnamo Lawyers
description: The Justice Department yesterday withdrew one of its proposals to tighten restrictions on lawyers representing detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, but said it would continue to press a federal appeals court for a series of other limits on the lawyers.

title: Yankees Overwhelmed by Texas Rangers
description: In a decisive defeat, like the 14-2 loss the Texas Rangers handed the Yankees yesterday afternoon at Yankee Stadium, it might be an overstatement to cite one botched play as a turning point.

title: Theater Listings
description: GAYFEST NYC June is Gay Pride month, so we can expect the usual variety of special events around the city leading up to the Pride Day march on June 24. But since this is New York, we dont have to wait till next month  theres fabulous gay entertainment whenever we want.

title: Heading Toward Reform of the F.D.A.
description: The Senate passed a bill to reform the Food and Drug Administration this week by such an overwhelming margin  93 to 1  that some much needed changes now seem likely to gain full Congressional approval and become law. The downside is that an amendment to allow the import of safe and inexpensive prescription drugs from abroad had to be eviscerated to get a veto-proof majority.

title: Manhattan: Change at Downtown Alliance
description: Eric J. Deutsch, president of the Downtown Alliance since 2005, will leave the organization for a private-sector job, the alliance announced this week. Mr. Deutsch, former president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation, will leave the Downtown Alliance, a business improvement district, on June 1 and become managing director at the Clarett Group, a real estate development company. The alliance did not announce a replacement yesterday.

description: Beirut

title: Afghans Say Civilian Toll in Strikes Is Much Higher Than Reported
description: HERAT, Afghanistan, May 10  The toll of civilians killed in bombing by coalition forces on Tuesday night was much higher than the official figure of 21, and may be as high as 50 or even 80, residents reached by telephone said Thursday.

title: People
description: Richard Levin, formerly of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, is joining Cravath, Swaine & Moore as a partner to head the firms new restructuring and insolvency practice. Mr. Levin was one of the principal authors of the 1978 federal bankruptcy code.

title: F.D.A. Panel Seeks Limits on Cancer Patient Drugs
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., May 10  Bowing to safety concerns, government medical advisers urged on Thursday that additional restrictions be put on the use of drugs that treat anemia in cancer patients.

title: In Monterey, Where Sea Lions and Children Are at Play
description: IT'S doubtful the Spanish explorer Juan Cabrillo was thinking family friendly when he spotted Monterey Bay in 1542. But these days it's hard to visit the relaxed seaside city of Monterey, about 120 miles south of San Francisco, and think anything else.

title: A Tough Fight Still Looms, Cheney Warns G.I.s in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Friday, May 11  Vice President Dick Cheney spoke Thursday to American troops stationed near Saddam Husseins birthplace, Tikrit, telling them in somber tones that they were the front line in the fight against global terrorism and making no promise that an end was in sight.

title: A Musical World Traveler Who Likes to Mix Things Up
description: Anat Cohens quartet was playing jazz at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night, and it was jazz that imported elements from the Middle East and South America and the language of early-20th-century classical music. Thats impressive, but not so surprising; those elements have all become moving parts in a jazz composers vocabulary. More curiously, it was jazz that behaved like pop  determined, encased in strong melodies and played at medium-full projection  and the musicians were articulating every note.

title: A Nuclear Reactor Reborn
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  The Tennessee Valley Authority plans to reopen its Browns Ferry 1 nuclear reactor this month  22 years after it was shut for safety reasons and 5 years after extensive renovations began.

title: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the producer Scott Rudin referred incorrectly to the release date of his movie The Manchurian Candidate. It was released in July 2004; it was not among his movies that were released near the year-end holidays that year.

title: Pope Addresses Brazils Youth and Meets With the President
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, May 10  The 80-year-old pope, Benedict XVI, filled a stadium here on Thursday with 30,000 or more young Brazilians, whom he called the future of the church and of humanity.

title: Blissful and Benighted: Dispatches From the War of the Sexes
description: Whatever wars may capture the headlines, the one that still fires the greatest passions is the battle of the sexes. In Couples, an evening of eight one-acts being presented at the WorkShop Theater Company, Rich Orloff offers brief updates on several skirmishes in that never-ending conflict.

description: DALLAS  The $69 margarita at N9NE Steakhouse in Ross Perot Jr.s $3 billion Victory Park development is not the most expensive drink in town, but it is one way of toasting the better times that some see ahead for a long-struggling Big D.

It is the California Culinary Academy, not the California Culinary Institute. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the format of the ShawGuides to culinary schools. It is published online; it is no longer a book.

title: Bush and Democrats in Accord on Labor Rights in Trade Deals
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  The Bush administration and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, breaking a partisan impasse that had dragged on for months, reached an agreement this evening on the rights of workers overseas to join labor unions.

title: Albany: Dispute Over Budgets Size
description: State Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli issued a report yesterday that said the state budget is $2.9 billion larger than previously thought, but Gov. Eliot Spitzers budget director, Paul E. Francis, responded that the comptrollers numbers were inaccurate because he counted capital spending items not traditionally included in the budget. The governors office has estimated the budget at $121 billion, while the comptrollers estimate is $124 billion, leading to a dispute over how much the state is spending. The next step toward budget reform has to focus on spending restraint, said Mr. DiNapoli, above. Mr. Spitzer opposed Mr. DiNapolis appointment to the comptrollers office after the resignation of Alan G. Hevesi, saying that Mr. DiNapoli, then a Democratic assemblyman, did not have the knowledge of finance necessary for the job, but recently he has been more conciliatory.

title: Lesley Blanch, 102, a Writer and Traveler, Dies
description: Lesley Blanch, an English writer and traveler best known for The Wilder Shores of Love, a biography of four 19th-century women who cast aside convention to seek adventure and romance in the East, died on Monday in Menton, in the South of France. She was 102 and had lived in Menton for many years.

title: Israels Foreign Minister Meets Egypts Chief; More Talks Set
description: CAIRO, May 10  President Hosni Mubarak and Israels foreign minister, Tzipi Livni, met Thursday and agreed that a team of Arab officials would soon visit Israel to discuss a Saudi peace proposal endorsed by the members of the Arab League.

description: JetBlue Airways said today its founder, David Neeleman, is stepping aside as chief executive officer and will be succeeded in that role by David Barger, Mr. Neelemans long-time No. 2 executive.

title: Panel Seeks End of New Jerseys Death Penalty
description: TRENTON, May 10  A State Senate committee passed a bill on Thursday that would make New Jersey the first state to abolish the death penalty since states began reinstating their capital punishment laws more than three decades ago.

title: 6 Former Workers at a Day Trading Firm Are Acquitted
description: A federal jury in Brooklyn yesterday acquitted two former stockbrokers and four former employees of the A. B. Watley Group, a day trading firm, of securities fraud in what became known as the squawk box case.

title: President Open to Benchmarks in Iraq Measure
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  Hours before the House approved a plan on Thursday to finance the Iraq war only through midsummer, President Bush offered his first public concession to try to resolve the impasse on war spending, acknowledging rising pressure from his own party and the public.

title: Narcotic Maker Guilty of Deceit Over Marketing
description: ABINGDON, Va., May 10  The company that makes the painkiller OxyContin and three of its current and former executives pleaded guilty Thursday in federal court here to criminal charges that it had misled doctors and patients when it claimed the drug was less likely to be abused than traditional narcotics.

title: Manhattan: Police Clerk Charged With Theft
description: A civilian employee of the Police Department and two of his friends were charged yesterday with stealing about $30,000 worth of property that belonged to defendants and crime victims, prosecutors said. The employee, Kevin Byrd, 36, of Springfield Gardens, Queens, faces charges including grand larceny, forgery and criminal possession of stolen property, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. Mr. Byrd was the evidence and property control specialist for the 28th Precinct, in Harlem, Mr. Morgenthau said. He said that from October 2006 until January, Mr. Byrd forged vouchers for property and cash, and stole personal items, including a dead mans wedding ring. Mr. Byrds friends  James Goorahoo, 37, of Springfield Gardens, and Jermal Williams, 36, of Laurelton, Queens  were also charged with grand larceny. Pretending to be crime victims, they exchanged the fake cash vouchers for checks at Police Headquarters, then split the money with Mr. Byrd, prosecutors said.

title: Restoring an Old House and Putting Down Deeper Roots

It was a quiet second home on a lot thick with old-growth trees, away from the busiest parts of the roughly 260-year-old former whaling village on the South Fork of Long Island, but a short walk from a downtown lined with restaurants and small shops.

title: Marine Says His Staff Misled Him on Killings
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 10  The general who led a division in charge of the marines who killed 24 Iraqi civilians in Haditha in 2005 testified Thursday that he was kept from weighing accusations that the killings were illegal because his subordinate officers withheld information for nearly three months.

description: Three months after it cleared him of research misconduct, Purdue University has begun a new inquiry into a professor who claims to have generated nuclear fusion in a desktop experiment, the university acknowledged yesterday.

Massey, a member of the search committee. His reappointment to the board of regents is pending before Congress; he has not been a regent since his term ended in March. The report also misstated the title of Roger W. Sant, also on the search committee. He is chairman of the regent executive committee, not chairman emeritus.

title: Bush Expected to Renew Term of Chairman of Joint Chiefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  President Bush is expected to nominate Gen. Peter Pace of the Marines for a second term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, opting for continuity during a critical phase in the Iraq conflict, two Defense Department officials said on Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: The Shanghai Journal article on Tuesday, about competition among developers in Shanghai and elsewhere to construct the worlds tallest building, misidentified the builder of a 2,300-foot skyscraper in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, which will be the record-holder when completed. The skyscraper, called the Burj Dubai, is under construction by an international team that includes the Samsung Corporation of South Korea, the main contractor; Turner Construction International of New York; Skidmore, Owings and Merrill LLP, the Chicago-based architecture firm; and Emaar Properties, the Dubai-based developer that owns the property. The team does not include relatives of Osama bin Laden. (The Saudi Binladin Group, a construction company owned by Mr. bin Ladens relatives, was a finalist in the bidding to build Burj Dubai but lost to the Samsung team). (Go to Article)

title: Trade Deficit Hits a Six-Month High
description: Rising oil prices and a surge in pharmaceutical imports contributed to a significant widening of the nations trade deficit in March, the government said today.

title: National Guard to Patrol PATH Stations
description: Up to 40 National Guard troops will begin patrolling 13 PATH stations in New York and New Jersey starting next week, similar to programs already under way at Penn Station and Grand Central Terminal.

title: Mother Natures Helpers
description: IF you love the outdoors but are bored just lying in the sun, try traipsing the wilderness as a citizen scientist  no degree required. Summer is high season for the kind of naturalists adventures that pair amateurs with researchers to collect information and restore wild areas. On one level, its volunteer work  making a contribution to scholarship or cleaning up an environment. On another, its a good time in the outdoors with like-minded people.

title: Guggenheim Foundation Takes Steps to Preserve Its Artistic Legacy
description: As the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation gears up for its 70th anniversary next month, its officials have been pondering its legacy. To preserve the collection that the foundation got from Solomon R. Guggenheim, a copper mining magnate who died in 1949, it has designated 620 works by more than 60 artists as the Solomon R. Guggenheim Founding Collection. Each will be noted on its wall label.

description: The Yankees didnt look much like the anything else is a failure championship team yesterday that will eventually justify the enormous expenditure for a certain 44-year-old, six-inning starting pitcher soon to rejoin them.

description: STONY POINT, N.Y., May 10  Four years ago, a company that owns two local power plants settled a lawsuit with New York State by agreeing to install $100 million worth of pollution control technology at one of them, its coal-fired plant here, or shut it down.

title: In the Big House ... Just Visiting
description: A FEW blocks from the Philadelphia Museum of Art, a massive, crumbling building rises up like a medieval castle over blocks of modest, middle-class homes mixed with brownstones. Complete with ivy-covered walls, a tower and corner battlements, it casts a forbidding shadow over the city  as it was meant to. Built in 1829, this hulking pile of stone was Pennsylvania's Eastern State Penitentiary, a cautionary landmark for nearly a century and a half, the place nobody wanted to go.

title: Latin Food at Yankee Stadium. Now, How About That!
description: In the Bronx, Latin food has always been easy to find. But not in Yankee Stadium. It has been one place in the majority-Hispanic borough where the only thing that came close to qualifying as authentic Latin fare was an order of nachos.

title: Manhattan: Firefighters Ratify Contract
description: New York Citys largest fire union announced yesterday that its members had voted to ratify a 24-month contract that gives raises totaling 8.16 percent. The union, the Uniformed Firefighters Association, said the vote was 4,037 to 3,115 to approve the deal, which raises starting pay by $9,900 to $35,000 and increases base salary after five years on the job to $68,475. The deal is retroactive to Aug. 1, 2006 and runs through July 31, 2008. To help finance the raises, the agreement calls for new firefighters to receive lower night differential pay and six fewer paid holidays each year during their first five years on the job.

title: For the Record
description: A music column on May 1 about the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival referred incorrectly to a song performed by Bonnie Raitt, God Was in the Water. It is by Randall Bramblett and Davis Causey, not by Ms. Raitt.

description: What is it about married couples and insider trading?

title: Pressed by Police, Even Innocent Confess in Japan
description: SHIBUSHI, Japan  The suspects in a vote-buying case in this small town in western Japan were subjected to repeated interrogations and, in several instances, months of pretrial detention. The police ordered one woman to shout her confession out a window and forced one man to stomp on the names of his loved ones.

title: Bidding War Expected for Earnhardt Jr.s Services
description: MOORESVILLE, N.C., May 10 - Dale Earnhardt Jr., the most popular driver in Nascar, announced Thursday he will leave the race team his father built and will listen to all offers as he looks for a new team to drive for in 2008.

title: Queens: Officer Arrested in Slaying
description: An off-duty police officer was arrested for fatally shooting his 22-year-old girlfriend in the head last night on a Queens street, according to Paul J. Browne, a police spokesman. The girlfriend reportedly wanted to break up with the officer, investigators said. Witnesses said they saw the officer and his girlfriend fighting on the street, near the intersection of Atlantic Avenue and 82nd Street, shortly before 8 p.m. The woman broke away from the conversation, then the man took out his gun, ran up to her and shot her in the head, according to witnesses. She was declared dead at the scene. It was unclear last night what the charges against the officer would be. The police were not releasing the names of the officer or the woman.

title: Israels Bombing of Civilians Extended War, Olmert Told Panel
description: JERUSALEM, May 10  In confidential testimony on last summers war with the Lebanese militia Hezbollah, Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said that the Israeli killing of a group of civilians in Qana in late July was a turning point that delayed a diplomatic resolution.

title: For the Record
description: A report in the Sports Briefing column yesterday about the College Football Hall of Fames newest inductees misidentified the university affiliation of Herb Deromedi, a coach who will be enshrined. He coached at Central Michigan, not Eastern Michigan.

title: New London: Threat on Chalkboard Investigated
description: The police are investigating a threatening message found on a Connecticut College chalkboard Wednesday that seemed to make reference to the recent deadly rampage at Virginia Tech. Discovered at 6:34 a.m. by a campus security officer, the chalked message said, V.T. and I can kill more than that. Eric Cardenas, a spokesman for Connecticut College, said the New London police and the campus safety department were investigating. At this point, our best assessment is that it was a very ill-advised prank, but were taking it seriously, he said. Classes at the private four-year college end this week, but Mr. Cardenas said the Fanning Hall classroom, where the message was found, would not be used again this semester. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: From Wales, Tales of Berlin Then and Bethlehem Now
description: That historic cry The British are coming! could be used these days as a fanfare to herald each new Broadway season. British plays, British directors, British actors  even British productions of American classics  are such a familiar feature of the landscape that it was hardly surprising when Richard M. Nixon, that scowling gray ghost of American history, arrived on Broadway this year carrying a British passport, in the London-born Frost/Nixon.

title: Chasing an Old Flame, Taking No Prisoners
description: It may look like heaven, but the spacious loft that houses Sunburst Communications  the new-age Ohio advertising agency where much of the comic mischief in The Ex is hatched  is a vipers nest.

title: California: Plan to Privatize Lottery
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger will propose privatizing the states lottery as a way to generate money to pay down debt and finance his public works spending and health care proposals, a spokesman said. Mr. Schwarzenegger, a Republican, will detail the lottery proposal on Sunday when he revises his budget for the coming fiscal year, said the spokesman, Adam Mendelsohn. Under the plan, the state would lease the lottery to a private company in exchange for as much as $37 billion in either a lump sum or in payments.

title: You Go to a Fight, and a Boston Pops Concert Breaks Out
description: It was Lockhart on the mound, Gigi at the plate and Folds on deck. Play was halted when fans started fighting in the upper deck of Fenway Park. Wait, make that Symphony Hall, the buttoned-down bastion of proper Bostonians.

title: Dairy Council to End Ad Campaign That Linked Drinking Milk With Weight Loss
description: A national advertising campaign that associates dairy products with weight loss will be curtailed because research does not support the claim, according to the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Kirsteins Lust for Art and Artists
description: Tucked away on the top floor of the Whitney Museum of American Art is another centenary tribute, in a season of them, to the man who brought George Balanchine to the United States. Lincoln Kirstein (1907-1996) is best remembered for founding with Balanchine the New York City Ballet and the School of American Ballet. But as a friend of his put it, he had more arms than Shiva.

title: Citing Lighter Penalties, Titan Is Appealing Ban
description: When Tennessee Titans cornerback Pacman Jones was suspended last month for the 2007 season, an appeal of the punishment seemed unlikely.

title: Highway Debris, Long an Eyesore, Grows as Hazard
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9  It was just another California rush hour. On eastbound Interstate 580 near Pleasanton recently, a rocking chair brought traffic to a near-standstill, while on southbound I-680 near Walnut Creek, a trampoline blocked two left lanes, wreaking havoc on the morning commute. Bagged loaves of sourdough bread blocked U.S. 101, near Petaluma. The highway patrol had to be dispatched.

title: $45 Million Invested in Internet TV Venture
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 10  Joost, a start-up that delivers television programming over the Internet, said Thursday that it had received $45 million in financing from venture capitalists and content partners including CBS and Viacom.

title: Feliciano Uses Guile to Aid the Mets
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 10  When Pedro Feliciano played a season in Japan, he had a daily routine. He threw. Then he threw some more. After throwing, he would throw and then throw again.

The Ottaway and Bancroft families are the largest owners of Class B shares, they are not the sole owners. (Shareholders were given Class B shares in the 1980s.)

title: Washington: Whistle-Blower Ordered to Be Reinstated
description: The federal Merit Systems Protection Board has ordered the Smithsonian Institution to reinstate a whistle-blower fired in 2002. The board rejected an appeal from the Smithsonian, ruling Wednesday that the administrative judge made no error in law or regulation in finding that the whistle-blower, Michael D. Cross, had been fired for reporting illegal activities at the National Air and Space Museum, specifically that supervisors had told employees to do work outside their official duties.
