title: Theodore Maiman, 79, Dies; Demonstrated First Laser
description: Theodore H. Maiman, a physicist who on May 16, 1960, demonstrated the worlds first laser, a device small enough to fit in his hand, died on May 5 in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 79.

title: Some Unrest Is Bubbling Beneath the Top Tier
description: VENTURE capitalists are enjoying growing prominence and swelling investment coffers, and they are taking and receiving credit for considerable job and wealth creation.

title: Spellings Rejects Criticism on Student Loan Scandal
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  With scandal rattling the $85 billion student loan industry, Education Secretary Margaret Spellings argued at a House hearing on Thursday that she lacked legal authority to clamp down on many abuses.

title: Hey, California Girl, Dont Mess With Grandma
description: Georgia Rule, in which Jane Fonda washes Lindsay Lohans mouth out with soap, might easily have been a tepid, sudsy puddle of easy sentiment and soft comedy. Three generations of women  Ms. Fonda and Ms. Lohan are Georgia and Rachel, grandmother and granddaughter, with Felicity Huffman in between them as Lilly, Georgias daughter and Rachels mom  fuss, fail to communicate and, in the end, forgive one another. Small-town values triumph over flashy, big-city California relativism, as happens exclusively (and frequently) in Hollywood movies. Youve seen it all before.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: MISS NELSON HAS A FIELD DAY Some children are lucky enough to have a Miss Nelson: a sweet, sympathetic elementary school teacher who guides them gently over the rough spots in their paths toward higher education. Others must confront a Miss Swamp: an unforgiving, terror-inducing martinet whose tone and manner are as sharp and stinging as a rap across the knuckles with a ruler.

title: Queens Man Charged With Robbing Bishop
description: A St. Albans man was arraigned Wednesday night on charges of robbing the bishop of a Queens church and later assaulting a woman and an off-duty police officer at a restaurant, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Oluwafemi Olowofela, 25, of 194th Street, was charged with robbery, burglary and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Olowofela is accused of robbing the Rev. Melvin Artis, 67, at gunpoint on Tuesday afternoon inside the Greater Universal Highway Deliverance Church on Linden Boulevard. He is also charged with attacking a 43-year-old woman later that day, and fighting with Officer Malik Kirkland, who came to her aid and apprehended him, Mr. Brown said.

title: Europeans Press Wolfowitz to Quit as Bank Chief
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  European leaders have told the Bush administration that Paul D. Wolfowitz must resign as president of the World Bank in order to avoid a vote next week by the banks board declaring that he no longer has its confidence to function as the banks leader, European officials said Thursday.

title: Mixed Mood on Campus at Va. Tech Graduation
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., May 11  Commencement at the Virginia Polytechnic Institute was supposed to be a moment for parents to watch their children take a symbolic step. From a youthful safe haven, students would graduate into a larger and less predictable world.

title: Hamas, Fatah Gunfight Leaves 10 Wounded
description: JERUSALEM, May 11  In the worst factional violence in nearly two months, Hamas and Fatah gunmen shot at each other today in the Gaza Strip, wounding at least 10 people and putting new strains on the Palestinian unity government in which both parties participate.

title: ABN Amro Executive Resigns
description: LONDON, May 10  ABN Amro, the Dutch bank that is the target of one of the worlds largest takeover battles, said Thursday that Hugh Y. Scott-Barrett, its chief financial officer, had handed in his resignation, amid other departures from the bank.

title: Man Convicted in 1993 Restaurant Killings
description: CHICAGO, May 10  A man was convicted Thursday of murdering seven people at a restaurant in 1993, a crime that shook a quiet suburb and stumped investigators for years.

title: Iraq Petition Presses for Withdrawal of U.S. Troops
description: BAGHDAD, May 11  A majority of Iraqs parliament has signed a petition for a legislative timetable governing a withdrawal of American troops from Iraq, several parliamentarians said today.

title: Bush and Democrats in Accord on Trade Deals
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  The Bush administration reached agreement on Thursday with the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and other Democrats to attach environmental and worker protections in several pending trade accords, clearing the way for early passage of some pacts and improving prospects for others.

title: Qaeda Presence in Pakistan Worries Britain
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, May 10  A senior British diplomat said Thursday that his government was greatly concerned about the continued ability of leaders of Al Qaeda hiding in Pakistans northwestern tribal region to direct terrorist operations across the world.

title: Note From Guantnamo (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: At Vonage, Sales Increase as Litigation Clouds Future
description: Vonage said yesterday that its quarterly loss narrowed and sales rose 64 percent amid a fierce legal battle with Verizon Communications that has left its future in question.

title: Mr. Bush Alone
description: The difference between mainstream hawks and mainstream doves on Iraq seems to have boiled down to two months, with House Democrats now demanding visible progress by July while moderate Republicans are willing to give White House policies until September, but no longer, to show results.

title: We Are New Orleans (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, the NYC column last Friday  about Peter Kaufman, who takes action against air-conditioned commercial buildings that waste energy by keeping their doors open in the summer  referred incorrectly in some copies to comments from Robert W. Walsh, New Yorks commissioner of small business services, on proposed legislation that would fine violators. His comments  that before resorting to bans and fines, the city should educate the wastrels about the harm they do  should have been rendered as a paraphrase, not as a direct quotation.

title: Vonage Narrows Loss and Increases Sales
description: Vonage said today that its first-quarter loss narrowed and that sales rose 64 percent despite a fierce legal battle with Verizon Communications that has left the companys future in question.

title: Panel to Look at Conflicts in Consulting
description: Members of Congress are looking into the potential conflicts among executive compensation consulting firms that do other lucrative work for the companies whose pay they help devise.

title: Sothebys and Its Landlord Battle Over Buildings Sale
description: It sure looked like a perfect match in 2002.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: VALUED, BUT NOT SO VALUABLE

title: Intimate Nooks Filled With Unexpected Treasures
description: Once again the International Fine Art Fair is filling the Seventh Regiment Armory with booths of swanky art from the 14th century through the 20th. Organized by the Londoners Brian and Anna Haughton, it is surprisingly intimate as far as art fairs go. The booths are decorated to resemble European period homes and palace parlors. The invitation-only top-shelf dealers  60 this year  from Europe, America and Japan all specialize in painting and drawing. There is some sculpture floating about too, but in no way does it match the quality and intensity of the artwork on the walls.

title: Democrats Push Gonzales on Attorney Dismissals
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  House Democrats pressed Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales at a hearing on Thursday to provide specifics about why federal prosecutors had been dismissed, but he stuck to his past assertions that, although ineptly handled, the dismissals were justified and appropriate.

title: Contaminated Water in Queens Is a Repeat Performance
description: The area in Queens where city officials found an industrial chemical in the drinking water last week has had problems with contamination by the same chemical for several years.

title: Relatives Noticed Changes in Accused Plotters
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 10  Ramiz Duka said his three cousins started to change two to three years ago. Three young men who had grown up with more American friends than fellow ethnic Albanian immigrants began to lecture other Muslims about religion.

title: 6 Charged in Fort Dix Plot Held Without Bail
description: CAMDEN, N.J., May 11  Six Muslim men from New Jersey and Philadelphia charged with plotting to attack Fort Dix with automatic weapons were ordered held without bail today by a federal magistrate here.

title: Canadian Pension Funds Becoming Buyout Players
description: TORONTO, May 10  Public pension funds have long been big investors in private equity. Now, some big Canadian pension funds are taking a page from the private equity playback and taking the lead in buyouts.

title: Retail Sales Fell Sharply Last Month
description: From department stores to discount chains, sales were dismal last month, suggesting that rising gas prices and the flagging housing market are starting to weigh on American consumers.

title: The N.F.L. Loses a Cable Ruling
description: A Manhattan Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that Comcast, the nations largest cable operator, can carry the NFL Network on a digital sports tier. The decision could roil the channels goal to be carried on the levels of digital distribution that would give it the greatest number of subscribers.

title: Off the Beaten Beat
description: ON Monday night inside the GlassLands Gallery, a converted warehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 100 or so people, alerted by MySpace pages and music blogs, gathered for a concert by the Yeah Yeah Yeahs. For an hour, the singer Karen O yelped and shrieked and pranced around a makeshift stage in a paint-splattered gold bodysuit, often wading into the audience a few feet away. At the end of the night the band took requests; to close the set, as her band mates played on, Ms. O paraded most of the crowd toward an alley behind the building, a musical moment as intimate as a reigning rock star can have.

title: Bronx: Shooting Leaves One Dead and One Hurt
description: One man was fatally shot and another was critically wounded yesterday afternoon in an apartment building at 1143 Noble Avenue, the police said. The men, who were not identified by the police, were found in a hallway of the building at 2:42 p.m. One of the men, who had been shot in the head, was declared dead on arrival at Jacobi Medical Center. The other man, shot in the torso, remained in critical condition last night at Jacobi.

title: Rate in Europe Held Steady; Currency Rise Stirs Concern
description: FRANKFURT, May 10  The European Central Bank on Thursday signaled that it would lift borrowing costs as early as June to prevent a robust European economy from stoking inflation, even as the surging euro begins to crimp corporate profits and slow exports.

title: From Little Clubs to Big Halls, an Indie Band Evolves
description: Theres only about four security guards, said Win Butler, near the end of Arcade Fires show at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night. And so, he added, if fans wanted to rush toward the stage, itd be pretty easy.

title: Harlems Cultural Anchor in a Sea of Ideas
description: YOU could almost see the ghosts among the new furniture and modern recessed lighting. It was a few days before the staff at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, at 135th Street and Malcolm X Boulevard in Harlem, finished hanging two exhibitions and stripping the paper off the doors at its bigger, brighter new entrance. Amid the sounds of hammers and drills, they prepared for tomorrows public celebration of the centers two-year, $11 million renovation.

title: The Glittering A-List of Black History
description: Let Your Motto Be Resistance: African American Portraits at the International Center of Photography is a praise song in pictures, a shoutout to history. Its also a fancy-dress inaugural party for the yet-to-be-built National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington. As such, it is a little too fancy, too heavy on glitz, too short on grit. Still, what a party it is.

title: Puffing Away That PG Rating
description: The Motion Picture Association of America on Thursday said portrayals of smoking would be considered alongside sex and violence in assessing the suitability of movies for young viewers. Films that appear to glamorize smoking will risk a more restrictive rating, and descriptions of tobacco use will be added to the increasingly detailed advisories that accompany each rated film.

title: Want to live next to Tony Blair?
description: Exterior

title: Decades of Drama
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Its All About My Mother
description: If youre lucky, you inherit more than just the fashion gene.

title: Vatican and Brazil at Odds
description: In public, the meetings between Pope Benedict XVI and President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva have been all handshakes and smiles during the pontiff's first pastoral visit to Brazil. But behind the scenes, the Vatican and the Brazilian government seem to be at an impasse in their efforts to negotiate a new accord that would regulate the Roman Catholic Church's status and presence in the country that has the largest Catholic population in the world.

title: Clinton Campaign Video
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign has recently filmed this five-minute video of former President Bill Clinton talking about his wife's accomplishments and lavishing praise on her. The video has been sent to several hundred Clinton donors and supporters.

title: Can Religious Symbols Be Publicly Displayed?
description: Q I live in a two-family house in which both apartments are rented. One family is Catholic, and the other is Jewish. Is it permissible for a tenant to display a religious symbol in the window  a cross or a menorah  that is visible from the outside?

title: What Rules Apply on Bicycle Spaces?
description: Q I own a Manhattan co-op and have paid for a bicycle space through the end of the year. I have moved, and I have been told by the building's management company that I cannot sublet my bike space and that I cannot get a refund. This doesn't seem right to me.

title: Pulse | Dresses That Do Mean a Thing
description: This season, dresses are a swinging affair, with silhouettes that float far from the body and high above the knee.

title: An Uncertain Future
description: Salifou Yankene, a former child soldier from Ivory Coast who is seeking asylum in the United States, faces a long road to healing.

title: Theater Briefs
description: Works by Stephen Adly Guirgis and Neil LaBute, among others, will be in "Marathon 2007," Ensemble Studio Theater's 29th festival of new one-act plays, from May 31 through June 30 at the theater.

title: Russian Bank VTB Raises $8 Billion in I.P.O.
description: VTB, Russias second-largest bank, raised about $8 billion in its initial public offering, which drew heavy interest from the countrys institutional and retail investors. The bank sold a 22.5 percent stake in what was the largest I.P.O. of the year and Russias third-largest stock sale ever.

title: Law Firm Preps for Private Equity Flameouts
description: Amid concerns that the recent buyout boom could take an ugly turn, yet another law firm is gearing up to be in the right place at the right time if and when it does. OMelveny & Myers said Thursday that it hired a trio of bankruptcy specialists and the co-chair of Stroock & Stroock & Lavans restructuring practice in preparation for portfolio company blowups involving its private equity and distressed-debt fund clients.

title: For Tyco, Breaking Up Just Got Harder to Do
description: The American International Group has filed a bondholders lawsuit against Tyco International to stop the conglomerates planned bond tender offer, accusing Tyco of trying to buy back its debt on the cheap.

title: Punishing Court Day for Blacks Ex-Deputy
description: F. David Radler, the chief witness against the media baron Conrad M. Black, endured more withering cross-examination on Thursday, and was again called a liar before a federal jury hearing the case against Mr. Black and others accused of stealing millions from the publishing company Hollinger International.

title: Ex-Comverse Lawyer Going to Jail in Options Backdating Plan
description: The former top lawyer at the software maker Comverse Technology was sentenced Thursday to a year and one day in prison for his role in a stock options backdating scheme, becoming the first corporate executive to be sentenced for options-related crimes.

title: Some Unrest Beneath V.C.s Top Tier
description: Venture capitalists are enjoying growing prominence and swelling investment coffers, and they are taking and receiving credit for considerable job and wealth creation.

title: Investment Bank JMP Group Goes Public
description: JMP Group, a San Francisco-based investment bank, sold nearly 8 million shares at $11 apiece in its initial public offering. The shares represented a stake of about 38 percent in the company, according to its prospectus.

title: No Deal for Ford as Company Struggles to Regain Footing
description: Those hoping for transformative merger for the Ford Motor Company were disappointed Thursday when the troubled automaker poured cold water on the notion that it might be considering a deal.

title: Auction of American Golf Tees Off, Report Says
description: American Golf, the countrys largest golf course owner and operator, is on the block and may fetch more than $1 billion, according to The Deal.com. The company, which manages more than 160 courses, is owned by private equity affiliates of Goldman Sachs and prominent real estate investment business Starwood Capital Group.

title: In Another Blow for Macquarie, Alinta Backs Babcock Bid
description: The board of Australian energy company Alinta on Friday recommended shareholders accept an A$8 billion ($6.64 billion) takeover offer by investment bank Babcock & Brown and Singapore Power, potentially ending a bidding war with Macquarie Bank.

title: Canadian Pension Funds Becoming Buyout Players
description: Public pension funds have long been big investors in private equity. Now, some big Canadian pension funds are taking a page from the private equity playback and taking the lead in buyouts.

title: Texas Pacific and Warburg Team Up for British Retail Bid
description: In an era of mammoth buyouts, private equity firms Texas Pacific Group and Warburg Pincus  are apparently determined to exercise control in their bid for British retail chain New Look.

title: Turn-of-the-Century Charm
description: The well-kept turn-of-the-century houses in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, charmed Darcey Steinke.

title: Regulators Examine Suspicious Sallie Mae Trades
description: The SLM Corporation, the student loan provider better known as Sallie Mae, on Thursday said two regulators are probing trading in its stock prior to its April 16 announcement that it would be taken private in a $25.2 billion deal.

title: Banks Rush for South Korean Asset Managers
description: A flurry of banking deals in South Koreas asset management sector are in the offing, as a law that allows banks to bring asset management under the same roof as other financial services is expected to go into effect.

title: Penthouse Settles Fraud Allegations
description: Penthouse International settled charges of accounting fraud and financial reporting violations, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Thursday. Former Penthouse executive Charles Samel and former shareholder Jason Galanis also agreed to each pay $60,000 to settle accounting fraud charges, the S.E.C. said.

title: Whole Foods Deal Raises Regulatory Concerns
description: Whole Foods Market has confirmed that antitrust regulators appear have serious issues with the companys planned $700 million cash purchase of rival grocery store chain Wild Oats Markets.

title: NeuroVista Scores Second Round
description: NeuroVista, a Seattle medical device company developing treatments for epilepsy, has raised $33.8 million in a second round of funding led by Advanced Technology Ventures and Delphi Ventures.

title: Apple Shareholders Question Jobs on Options
description: Apple chief Steven P. Jobs faced a barrage of questions from shareholders about the companys handling of stock option grants and its policy of executive compensation, during a an annual meeting Thursday. But Mr. Jobs, with his typical flair for showmanship, elicited laughs and applause during the meeting despite rankling questions.

title: Oaktree to List on New Goldman Market, Reports Say
description: Private investment firm Oaktree Capital Management is set to be the first firm to list on Goldman Sachss new private market set to launch this month, according to press reports.

title: China Allows Banks to Buy Stocks Abroad
description: China will allow the countrys commercial banks to buy stocks abroad, in a move that may release some of the nations 35 trillion yuan ($4.6 trillion) of savings on overseas equity markets for the first time.

title: Historic Old Northeast
description: Scenes from the Historic Old Northeast neighborhood of St. Petersburg, Fla., a front-porch kind of place close to downtown.

title: Former Day Traders Acquitted in Squawk Box Case
description: A federal jury in Brooklyn on Thursday acquitted two former stockbrokers and four former employees of the A. B. Watley Group, a day trading firm, of securities fraud in what became known as the squawk box case.

title: Panel to Look at Conflicts in Consulting on Executive Pay
description: As the hew and cry over rich executive pay intensifies, members of Congress are looking into the potential conflicts among executive compensation consulting firms that do other lucrative work for the companies whose pay they help devise.

title: Hedge Fund Tells Wendys to Sell Itself
description: The largest institutional shareholder of Wendys International is urging the hamburger chain to sell itself to the highest bidder, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Terra Firma Flies Off With Pegasus
description: Terra Firma, the private equity group run by British financier Guy Hands, doubled the size of its aircraft leasing business on Friday with the acquisition of San Francisco-based Pegasus Aviation Finance for $5.2 billion.

title: Google C.E.O. On Dealmaking Strategy
description: Google, which last month announced a deal to buy online ad firm DoubleClick for $3.1 billion, said that while it has become more comfortable doing big acquisitions, it still sees small technology deals as its primary thrust for buying businesses.

title: Is JetBlue a Takeover Play?
description: David G. Neeleman, the founder of JetBlue Airways, reluctantly agreed to step aside as the companys chief executive Thursday. The move marked a turning point in the short history of the upstart airline, but it also gave new life to recent speculation that the low-cost carrier might be a candidate for a takeover. JetBlues shares rose 4.7 percent after the move was announced.

title: Latest Shock Jock Outburst
description: Opie and Anthony, who ended up on satellite radio after being fired from a New York radio station for mixing transgressive sex and religion, have sparked a new uproar. This time, it is over mixing transgressive sex and politics.

title: Carlyle Said to Plan Publicly Traded Fund
description: Carlyle Group, the private equity giant, plans to file to list its first publicly traded fund by the end of June, BusinessWeek.coms Deal Flow blog reported, citing people familiar with the transaction. The Washington-based firm will list a leveraged finance fund made up primarily of mortgage-backed securities on the Euronext.

title: Are Wacky Climate Solutions Worthwhile?
description: The more we hear about climate change, the more we hear about how business, government and green-minded consumers are going to collaborate to create a low-carbon economy. Politicians and chief executives say these initiatives could get us there within two or three decades.

title: Out of Brooklyn, Endlessly Blogging
description: Certain neighborhoods in Brooklyn seem to have become the most blog-rich areas of the United States, according to a recent informal survey by the blog Outside.in. So where better to take the pulse of this rapidly growing community of writers, thinkers and observers than the second annual Brooklyn Blogfest?

title: Former BP Chief Quits Goldmans Board
description: Goldman Sachs said Thursday that John Browne, who quit as chief executive of BP on May 1 after it emerged that he had lied during legal proceedings about how he met a former lover, had resigned from the Goldman board. Mr. Browne, who helped build the London-based BP into one of the largest oil companies in the world, had been a Goldman director since the investment bank went public in May 1999.

title: KB Home Receives Offer for Stake in French Home Builder
description: KB Home, the fifth-largest homebuilder in the United States, received an offer worth 580 million euros ($782 million) for its 49 percent stake in Kaufman & Broad, the biggest home builder in Paris and the surrounding region.

title: Giuliani Trips in the Abortion Minefield
description: The Wall Street Journal editorial page thinks Rudy Giulianis decision to run as a pro-choice presidential candidate will damage whomever emerges as the eventual Republican nominee in 2008: As if Republicans dont have enough problems, their presidential candidates and interest groups seem eager to re-stage a fight over abortion the American public doesnt want to hear. Blame both Rudy Giuliani and his conservative critics, but

title: Thomson Slims Down as Reuters Talks Continue
description: As Thomson lays the groundwork for a blockbuster merger with Reuters, the Canadian company said Friday it will sell its education and career units to two private equity funds for about $7.75 billion in cash.

title: 2008: Romneys Media Weekend
description: The Timess Michael Luo assesses the state of Mitt Romneys candidacy, detailing hurdles such as skepticism about his ideological shifts and Mormon faith, as well as strengths including a proven fund-raising capacity and even greater skepticism about his chief rivals, Senator John McCain and Rudolph W. Giuliani (who, as Katharine Q. Seelye pointed out Thursday, has been having a rough week).

title: Romney Elaborates on Evolution
description: DES MOINES, May 11  Mitt Romney expanded on his belief in evolution in an interview earlier this week, staking out a position that could put him at odds with some conservative Christians, a key voting bloc he is courting.

title: Sex Trafficking in India
description: Last month I visited India and wrote about the horrific sex trafficking situation there, through the story of a woman named Meena who had been imprisoned in a brothel herself, was bred, and then had her daughter prostituted as well. Meena is an incredibly gutsy woman, and she was able to rescue her teenage daughter, Naina.

title: Chicago Merc Raises Bid for CBOT
description: Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings sweetened its all-stock offer for CBOT Holdings, the parent company of the Chicago Board of Trade, in hopes of fending off a competing bid from the IntercontinentalExchange. The revised offer, announced early Friday, values CBOT at about $9.2 billion, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Mixed Mood at Virginia Tech Graduation
description: As thousands of parents arrived for graduation ceremonies, it was hard to tell the tears of joy from those of sadness.

title: Google Draws a Line With Thailand
description: Two months after Thailand blocked YouTube over video clips it said insulted the King, a response emerged from its owner, Google, in a letter released by the nations communications minister. Google has not commented so far.

title: Heidfelds Nurburgring ride nearly dominates the Friday press conference
description: The Friday press conference returned to a discussion of Nick Heidfelds drive on the Nordschleife last month. That is significant. The questions came not only from the official FIA interviewer, but from journalists andanother driver.

title: Drug Maker to Plead Guilty to Making False Statements
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb said Thursday that it would plead guilty to criminal charges that it made false statements to the government, a move meant to end a federal antitrust investigation of the drug makers botched efforts last year to preserve a lucrative monopoly for the anti-clotting medicine Plavix.

title: When Looks Deceive
description: I thought it would be much, much bigger, said one of my companions.

title: As SunTrust Rises, Takeover Talk Heats Up
description: In their search for the next takeover candidate, analysts and investors seem to be casting an eye on SunTrust Banks. Part of the reason is a recent comment from James Dimon, the chief executive of J.P. Morgan Chase, who said on a conference call Monday that his firm is ready to buy a domestic regional bank. Speculation immediately turned to SunTrust, which has a major presence in the Southeast, a market that J.P. Morgan may be targeting for growth.

title: $350 Liquor
description: My column today, arguing that such things as clubs charging $350 for a bottle of booze are simply ways that money is redistributed from the wealthy, provoked a telephone call from a reader who told me I write like a Republican. He did not mean it as a compliment, but did seem to take for granted that Republicans would be the kind of people to patronize such establishments.

title: Orbitz Prospectus Gets Mixed Reviews
description: The online travel site Orbitz Worldwide isnt a bad company, Kevin Kelleher writes on GigaOM.com. It is nevertheless a contender for the worst I.P.O. candidate of the year, he concludes.

title: Pakistani Banker Named in Insider-Trading Suit
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday accused a prominent investment-banking executive in Pakistan of taking part in a $7.5 million insider trading ring along with a former banker at Credit Suisse. In an amended complaint filed in federal court in Illinois, the S.E.C. said Ajaz Rahim, the country head of investment banking at Faysal Bank Limited of Pakistan, with making about $5 million in illegal profits by trading in TXU options before the Texas utility announced its $45 billion sale to two private equity firms.

title: Fried Frank Adds M&A Partner
description: Fried Frank Harris Shriver & Jacobson, one of the law firms advising Dow Jones as it considers a takeover bid from News Corporation, said Friday it hired a new corporate partner for its mergers and acquisitions practice. John E. Sorkin, previously a partner at Latham & Watkins, joins Fried Frank in its New York office.

title: Of Hedgehogs and Courtroom Moles
description: Like fedora-sporting reporters in old movies, hedge fund employees lately have been known to jump up from their courtroom seats as rulings are issued to get breaking news back to headquarters. But theyre not rushing to the bank of payphones in the lobby (which probably arent there anymore anyway). These guys are texting the hedge fund, so they can short the stock of whatever company just lost a patent suit, Ron Laurie, of Inflexion Point Strategy, an intellectual-property investment bank, told the trade publication IP Law and Business.

title: The Significance of paul99503
description: YouTube is magnetic. The average user spends nearly 30 minutes there, just hanging out. Part of the draw is the thick, lush, humid comments section. Its like a rainforest in there with, yeah, tons of bugs and some predators, but also plenty of dense and fascinating flora.

title: Mistakes Happen
Whats So Funny Bout Peace, Love and Understanding?
description: Readers respond to David Brookss May 11 column, The Human Community.

title: Giuliani in Houston
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani began his effort today to show a more consistent, if liberal, persona on the campaign trail, telling a conservative crowd in Houston that he favored abortion rights, gay rights (domestic partnerships but not marriage) and certain restrictions on guns.

title: Is Greenwich, Conn., Obama Country?
description: Considerable amounts of ink and pixels have been devoted lately to characterizing Barack Obama as the presidential candidate of the hedge-fund set. A Financial Times article last month quoted an anonymous United States businessman as saying, The whole of Greenwich is backing Obama  a reference to Greenwich, Conn., the leafy suburb that many hedge fund managers call home. (That breezy statement turns out to be quite untrue, as we will see later.)

title: The Day the Union Jack Got Beat Back
description: The good ol days of rebellion were back today in Delhi, India, where the 150th anniversary of Indias first revolt against British rule was celebrated.

title: Going Underground
description: Physicists are putting the final touches on the biggest and most expensive scientific experiment on Earth.

title: Decoding 'Code Monkey'
description: How Jonathan Coulton's song became a viral hit.

title: A Cabrera by Any Other Name
description: In case you thought the Yankees had somehow traded for Miguel Cabrera from the Florida Marlins without anyone noticing, theres a friendly reminder on your Times box score page nearly every day.

title: Asking the Obvious
description: With thanks to reader Ricardo B. for expressing something weve all thought at one time or another:

title: The Flight From Iraq
description: Nir Rosen reports on the refugee crisis at Al Tanf on the Syrian border with Iraq.

title: The Good News, and the Bad
description: As we sat waiting in Sarasota Airport for our flight, I was riding a roller coaster of emotions. One moment I was elated that we had made extensive progress on our house plans, the next I was depressed that the plans werent perfect.

title: Clinton Campaign Video
description: Former President Bill Clinton narrates a short biographical film about Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Oleg the Cab Driver
description: Fox's Advertising Experiment

title: A Long Tryout for First Lady
description: As she spends more time on the campaign trail, Michelle Obama is appearing in support of her husband but is also campaigning for herself.

title: The Flight From Iraq
description: Photographer Joachim Ladefoged speaks about his work with Iraqi refugees in Damascus.

title: A Prominent Iraqi Blogger Flees
description: A young Iraqi woman who chronicled the daily struggles of life in Baghdad is fleeing with her family.

title: More Problems Redeeming Miles and Using Miles on Partner Airlines
description: I recently called up Lufthansa Miles & More to reserve a flight using my miles from the program. Lufthansa said that I had enough miles for the flight, but that there were no seats available. I was able to make online bookings for the seats I wanted  as long as I paid for them. Is this a typical problem? Why am I storing up all these miles if I cant use them?

title: One More Thing About the Size of the Tundra
description: Tooling around Texas, I noticed that not only is the new Tundra much bigger than a Prius (as Micheline Maynard pointed out in her last post), but its also bigger than a Tundra. Check it out. The truck on the right is a first-generation Tundra.

description: BAGHDAD, May 12  A coordinated attack on seven American soldiers and an Iraqi Army interpreter early this morning south of Baghdad left five of them dead and three missing, the United States military said.

title: Alfred D. Chandler Jr., a Business Historian, Dies at 88
description: Alfred D. Chandler Jr., an economic historian who revolutionized the writing of business history, shunning the old debate about whether tycoons are good or bad, and instead arguing persuasively in almost two dozen books that it was the emergence of professional management that propelled modern capitalism, died on May 9 in Cambridge, Mass. He was 88.

description: When Dulce Pontes started a song with the words meu amor (my love) at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, she flooded them with emotion: longing, seductiveness, bravado, desperation, strength. It was quintessential Portuguese fado singing, with long-breathed swoops and tempestuous dynamic surges, simultaneously abandoned and refined.

title: East Timor Figures Victory Is Seen as Cause for Hope
description: HONG KONG, May 11  The decisive victory of Jos Ramos-Horta in East Timors presidential election was a significant move toward creating genuine multiparty democracy and breaking the dominance of the political organization that largely led the struggle for independence, analysts and election observers said Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Street Scene pages of Business Day on April 6 about a program geared toward training female lawyers to become directors of companies misstated the percentage of Fortune 500 companies that have women on their boards. It is 88.4 percent, not 14.6 percent. (Women held 14.6 percent of the board seats on Fortune 500 companies in 2006.) Catalyst, the research company that compiled the statistics, pointed out in an e-mail message this week that the article had misstated the findings.

title: For the Record
description: An article in some copies on Tuesday about proposed tentative rent increases for New York Citys one million rent-stabilized apartments included an outdated schedule for the boards final vote. It is now expected June 26, not June 22. The article also misstated the number of public hearings to be held on the increases. (The same error appeared in an article on April 25 about reports that building owners costs and revenues rose in the last year.) There will be two hearings, not three.

description: BLACKSBURG, Va., May 11  Commencement at Virginia Tech was supposed to be a moment for parents to watch their children take a symbolic step. From a youthful safe haven, students would graduate into a larger, less predictable world.

title: Bad Medicine, Sneaking In
description: As I read about the melamine-tainted pet food, and about the hundreds in Panama killed by phony glycerin from China, I remembered a patient I once saw. She was a dancer in her 40s who had hobbled into the emergency room one October night with a painful, bulging mass in her groin. I gently put my fingers to it. It was beet-sized and firm. When I placed my stethoscope on it, I heard gurgling. This was, I told her, a strangulating hernia  a rent in her abdominal wall had trapped a loop of intestine. The swelling was the knot of bowel; the gurgling, the fluid inside.

title: Earnhardt Free Agency Echoes Through Nascar
description: DARLINGTON, S.C., May 11  Dale Earnhardt Jr. was back in a racecar Friday, a welcome relief after the week he has been through. It did not seem to matter that he was driving the Car of Tomorrow, the Nascar-designed car that he has roundly criticized.

title: Mining a Rich Vein of Sequins in Revues
description: Encores! has built its own jukebox, and it gleams like gold. Stairway to Paradise, which runs through Monday at City Center, is an anthology of truly olden oldies, songs the theatergoing masses heard in musical revues in the first half of the 20th century. And yes, I know, it all sounds too quaint and camp and, well, dusty, for words.

title: Canada: Court Delays Terrorism Suspects Deportation
description: The Federal Court said the government may not deport an Algerian accused of having ties to Al Qaeda until it revised its law on detaining foreign-born terrorism suspects. The Algerian, Mohamed Harkat, was arrested in Ottawa in 2002 and became one of five Muslim men held without charges or a trial under the detention measure, the security certificate system, introduced late in 2001. In February, the Supreme Court found the measure unconstitutional and gave the government a year to change it. Mr. Harkat was released under restrictive conditions after the ruling as the government continued his deportation process.

title: Price of a Stamp Continues Its Upward March
description: The Postal Services new rates take effect Monday. The cost of a first-class stamp, which covers letters weighing up to one ounce, will increase to 41 cents from 39 cents, while the cost of each additional ounce will decrease to 17 cents from 24 cents. Items placed in mailboxes after Saturdays pickup must reflect the new prices. Also available will be the Forever Stamp, currently 41 cents, which covers the one-ounce letter rate regardless of any future increases. More information on pricing for domestic mail and new international rates can be found at www.usps.gov.

title: Damaged Shuttle Tank Is Called Ready for Flight
description: NASA officials said that the hail-pocked tank for the next shuttle mission had been repaired and that they expected to be ready for the shuttle Atlantis to blast off by the proposed launching date of June 8. A hailstorm in February left more than 4,000 dings in the foam insulation on the external tank while the shuttle sat on the launching pad. Analysts are confident that pieces of foam big enough to damage the shuttle during ascent  the problem that doomed the shuttle Columbia and its crew of seven astronauts in 2003  will not fall off the repaired tank, said N. Wayne Hale, Jr., the shuttle program manager. Our goal is zero, and our testing indicates it will be zero, Mr. Hale said.

As he swapped solos with the guitarist Rod Fleeman on Thursdays early show at Birdland, where Ms. Allyson is appearing through tonight, his shimmering blues-charged lyricism gave the music a mild percussive kick. It lent songs, several of which are found on her 2006 album, Footprints a discreet element of exoticism that suggested a dramatic indigo sky in a painting of a cornfield. (Ms. Allyson is from Kansas City.)

description: Come retirement, it will finally be time to get back the money that has been extracted from your paycheck your entire working life.

title: The Commissioner of Baseball Is on Deck
description: MILWAUKEE, May 11  Bud Selig, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, slowly turned the desk chair in his 30th-floor corner office toward a panoramic view of Lake Michigan. Few could see him here, but Selig knows the eyes of the nations baseball fans are watching him.

title: As Kennedy Traffic Rises, So Do Worries About Delays and Heavier Runway Use
description: Traffic at the New York areas busiest airport, Kennedy International, has jumped about 25 percent in the last year, aviation officials say. The increase raises concerns about serious flight delays as summer approaches and is pushing the Federal Aviation Administration to consider major changes in runway operations.

title: Sabres Happy to Be Here, or to Be at All
description: BUFFALO, May 11  The most popular of the Buffalo Sabres may not be the clutch-scoring forward Chris Drury, or the elastic goalie Ryan Miller, or even the scowling coach with the fitting surname, Lindy Ruff.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article last Saturday about a dispute among some conservatives over whether Darwinian theory undermines or supports conservative principles erroneously included one social Darwinist among Victorian-era social Darwinists who adopted evolutionary theory to justify colonialism and imperialism. Herbert Spencer opposed both.

title: Hepburn, Revisited
description: Palm Springs

title: A Feeble Performance
description: Attorney General Alberto Gonzales has reportedly begun telling friends and associates that he has weathered the storm over the firing of nine United States attorneys and that his job is safe despite widespread calls for his resignation. We can only hope he is wrong. Not only is the purge of the attorneys extremely serious, it is part of a long chain of evidence that Mr. Gonzales does not have the ability or the moral compass to do his vitally important job.

title: Cheney, on Carrier, Sends Warning to Iran
description: Vice President Dick Cheney used the deck of an American aircraft carrier just 150 miles off Irans coast as the backdrop yesterday to warn that the United States was prepared to use its naval power to keep Tehran from disrupting oil routes or gaining nuclear weapons and dominating this region.

title: Brahmin Vote Helps Party of Low Caste Win in India
description: NEW DELHI, May 11  In the age-old caste divisions of India, a new political calculus has emerged.

title: Medical Gear That Rarely Makes News
description: Becton, Dickinson & Company may well be the most invisible of the nations publicly traded medical device giants. Its revenue, which topped $5.7 billion last year, comes from the sale of syringes, diagnostic kits, lab equipment and related gear widely used at home and overseas in doctors offices and hospitals.

title: For the Record
description: The Sports of The Times column yesterday, about the significance of Roger Clemenss signing with the slow-starting Yankees, referred incorrectly to the timing of a pivotal play in the teams 14-2 defeat on Thursday by the Texas Rangers. The Rangers took the lead when the Yankees failed to execute a rundown in the fifth inning, not the fourth inning.

title: In the Gauzy Glow of the Mayfly
description: STARLIGHT, Pa., May 6  Just as spring follows winter, the annual progression of mayfly hatches on Eastern rivers provides a boost to the spirits of trout fishermen.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) AMERICAN DREAMZ (2006) This comedy directed by Paul Weitz (In Good Company and, with his brother, Chris, About a Boy), in which a bumbling American president (Dennis Quaid) signs on to judge a television talent show in an effort to boost his popularity, appears just as the American Idol season is nearing its climax. Above: Hugh Grant plays the Simon Cowell-esque host; Mandy Moore is the contestant-next-door with the voice of an angel whos hiding some arsenic under all that lace. And Willem Dafoe, doing his best Dick Cheney impersonation, is the presidents chief of staff, who thought up the publicity stunt in the first place.

title: Built to Last, and Lasting
description: NEWBERN, Ala., May 6  They used to serve the hog whole at the annual pig roast here in Hale County, in central Alabama. The architecture students who gathered to honor another year of designing and constructing buildings would slice their own fatty hunks of pork to pile on paper plates, alongside fried catfish, shredded coleslaw and hush puppies.

title: A Searchable List of Religious Earmarks
A Peek Inside a Beautiful Home
description: A look at one Chappaqua couple who agreed to allow scores of strangers into their home to benefit the local historical society.

title: Pope Warns Drug Dealers of Punishment From God
description: GUARATINGUETA, Brazil, May 12 -- Aiming to underline the church's concern for poverty and other social problems in Brazil, Pope Benedict XVI declared on a visit to a drug rehabilitation center here Saturday that God would punish drug dealers.

title: The Birds of Summer
description: Some pretty rare birds have been spotted this spring at ball parks around the country.

title: 2008: Abortion and Taxes
description: On Thursday at Houston Baptist College, Rudolph W. Giuliani tried out his new political strategy of confronting head on his departures from the traditional G.O.P. platform. The Timess Marc Santora and Adam Nagourney report that the speech appeared to reflect two calculations by his campaign.

title: And Then There Was Only Aaron Sele
description: Jose Reyes finally relented. No more hair. He emerged from the players lounge this morning rubbing his newly-smooth head with an I-told-you-so grin on his face. He wasnt resisting, he said, and it had nothing to do with his 14-game hitting streak ending last night; he was just waiting until the day after he shot footage for a reggaeton video. Didnt want to look silly for that. So he came in this morning and asked the teams regular barber, Jordan, (and not the higher-priced Carlos Beltran or Carlos Delgado), to buzz off his curls for the first time in about five years. It took about 10 minutes.

title: Senna Mania!
description: It was an absolute zoo after the GP2 race in Barcelona today as Bruno Senna, Ayrtons nephew, won the race in only his third GP2 race and with not quite three years of car racing behind him. He moves to third place in the series, which is a Formula One support race, and a final stepping stone to the highest level of racing. I wrote a little about Bruno after the first GP2 race in Bahrain, so I thought I should continue with the theme. In fact, I could not avoid the theme this time.

title: The More You Know
description: Went into the Brewers clubhouse this morning to catch up with outfielder/fellow unabashed Eagles fan Kevin Mench, who I covered in Dallas two years ago. On the way out, I couldnt help but notice that photographs of the umpiring crew, along with short biographies underneath, were stuck to the back of the door.

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu
description: Imagine this Sundays breakfast menu as a rather limited buffet. You can take huge, belly-busting helpings of presidential politics, but you might have to scrape at the bottom of the tray to get much of anything else.

title: Derek Jeter Outlasts Them All
description: I wrote a story for the Sunday paper about Derek Jeter, whos leading the A.L. in batting average and hits. Doug Mientkiewicz compares Jeter to his former teammate, Paul Molitor, who finished with 3,319 hits. Jeter has 2,200 hits, with no end in sight.

title: Fred Thompsons Just-Secret-Enough Meeting
description: Fred D. Thompson, the Law & Order star and subject of much speculation about his presidential ambitions, is practically above our head right now, speaking to a secretive group of conservative heavyweights and activists.

title: The Courage of Mel Stottlemyre
description: Mel Stottlemyre spent the afternoon at the incomparable Elliott Bay Book Co. in Seattles Pioneer Square, meeting fans and signing copies of his autobiography, Pride and Pinstripes, written with John Harper. Then Stottlemyre, the former Yankees pitcher and pitching coach, came by Safeco Field to see his old team for the second day in a row.

title: The Empire in the Mirror
description: The only sure thing that can be said about the past is that anyone who can remember Santayanas maxim is condemned to repeat it. As a result, the danger of not understanding the lessons of history is matched by the danger of using simplistic historical analogies. Those who have learned the lessons of Munich square off against those who have learned the lessons of Vietnam, and then they both invoke the bread-and-circus days of the overstretched Roman empire in an attempt to sound even more subtle and profound.

title: Traffic Cones, Missing in Action
description: LITTLE seemed unusual outside Public School 24 in Riverdale on Wednesday morning, as a parade of buses, S.U.V.s and sedans discharged children in scuffed sneakers in front of the two-story red brick school on West 236th Street.

title: Forget the Lamborghini. Hed Rather Drive a V-8.
description: SHEIK MARWAN AL-MUALLA has a new V-10 Lamborghini Gallardo that he has driven only once. Ditto for his new Ferrari.

title: Surprised? Maybe You Shouldnt Be
description: FOR weeks now, corporate earnings reports have outstripped analysts expectations, contributing in no small part to the fizzy mood on Wall Street. But heres a sobering thought: those expectations were way too low in the first place.

title: This Seasons Must-See Criminal Trial
description: Sex and the City, meet Law & Order.

title: When Children Fly Alone, Whos in Charge?
description: YOUR children are going to camp far from home this summer, but you cant get off work or justify the expense of an extra plane ticket just to fly them there. Should you trust the airlines to take care of them if they fly alone?

title: A Proposal for Mini-Spaces: Mini-Soccer
description: West Harlem is swarming with real estate speculators these days, so a worldly bystander might not have been surprised to see Irv Smalls Jr. looking covetously the other day at a trash-strewn lot on 114th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard.

title: Giants Both Hopeful and Wary of One Rookies Potential
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 12  It was the first N.F.L. practice for most of the 50 players at Giants Stadium. When it ended, about noon Saturday on the first day of the rookie minicamp, the new Giants wandered quietly around the locker room or ate lunch, getting used to unfamiliar surroundings and introducing themselves to one another.

title: Brief Histories of Time
description: In Berkeley, Calif., where Liza Dalby lives, the traditional notion of four seasons, each constituting a quarter of the year, is falsified daily. Dalby is an anthropologist  her first book chronicled her experience, in the mid-1970s, inside the flower and willow world of the Kyoto geisha (remarkably, she became one herself)  and here she adapts an ancient Chinese almanac whose division of the year into 72 five-day periods has influenced not only the Japanese concept of time but also her own. In 72 short essays, with lowercase titles like dormant creatures start to twitch, chrysanthemums are tinged yellow and magpies nest, Dalby meditates on the changes under way in her garden, tells stories from her years in the field and contemplates etymologies and linguistic puzzles.

title: A Downtowners Club for Poets on a Curfew
description: IN the annals of New Yorks postpunk, polysexual downtown bohemia, celebrated haunts are best known by their memorable evenings. The night at the Pyramid in 1984, when the Red Hot Chili Peppers first played the East Coast and shocked the dives drag queens with wardrobes limited to artfully placed socks. Or the final marathon, in December 2000, of the cult party Jackie 60, which reigned on Tuesdays in the 1990s at Mother, the club-cum-salon in the meatpacking district.

title: Not Yet in High School, but Focused on College
description: White Plains

title: Writing the Book on Hating the Sox
description: Jerome from Maine is a Yankees fan.

title: At the Pleasure
description: Pleasure is a beautiful word. That s in the middle, pronounced like the z in azure, a word favored by lyric poets, gives a little thrill to the mouth. The meaning in the noun alone  happy satisfaction or enjoyment; delight, gratification  runs 26 printed-out pages in the Oxford English Dictionary Online, including the indulgence of physical, especially sexual, desires or appetites specifically to take ones pleasure, a lazily elegant way of saying to have sexual intercourse.

title: The Odd Couple
description: Visionaries or cynics? Peacemakers or warmongers? Few individuals in recent times have provoked as much controversy as Richard Nixon and his partner in foreign affairs, Henry Kissinger. Admirers laud the two men for dramatically easing the cold war and sensibly recognizing the limits of American power to shape the world. Critics castigate them as Machiavellians who undertook reckless policies in the third world, often throwing American power behind brutal tyrants in elusive quests for international stability.

title: Melissa Holsinger, John-Paul Anderson
description: Melissa Costiere Holsinger, a daughter of Lorraine and John R. Holsinger of Hackensack, N.J., is to be married today to John-Paul Ryan Anderson, a son of Sandra and H. Charles Anderson of Boise, Idaho. The Rev. John J. Ranieri, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at Queen of All Saints Church in Brooklyn.

title: Stirring Up Support for Those That Walk, Fly, Swim and Slither
description: Darien

title: My First Lesson in Motherhood
description: I SAW the scar the first time I changed Natalies diaper, just an hour after the orphanage director handed her to me in a hotel banquet room in Nanchang, a provincial capital in southeastern China.

title: Plenty to Admire (Punctuation Aside)
description: THE arrival of Michaels at the Boardwalk has made Riverhead a dining destination. The restaurant, which opened in late March, is a beauty that would fit right into the Hamptons or Manhattan. In fact, it is the younger sibling of Michaels at Maidstone Beach in East Hampton, which dates from 1984 and was taken over in 2005 by Debra and Rich Gherardi. They breathed new life into the place, but kept the name with its misplaced apostrophe.

title: Yfat Reiss, Bradley Gendell
description: Yfat Miri Reiss and Bradley Howard Gendell were married last evening by Rabbi Sol Greenberg at the Wheatleigh, a hotel in Lenox, Mass.

title: Music, Love and Fatalism: How Irish
description: DONT get John Carney, the Irish-born director of Once, started on the topic of movie musicals. I like Guys and Dolls, Singin in the Rain and A Star Is Born,  he said in a recent interview in New York. When it works, a musical is an amazing thing. But it rarely works.

title: After Years of Turmoil, Miller Quits U.S. Team
description: Bode Miller, the former Olympic medalist and World Cup champion, announced his departure from the United States ski team yesterday, a day after his cousin Liko Kenney had a violent confrontation with a New Hampshire police officer that left the officer and Kenney dead.

title: The Year of the Dog
description: One of the tenderest, least self-interested love scenes to have graced a page in a decade or so pops up a little more than halfway through Cathleen Schines latest novel, The New Yorkers, when Everett, a gruff, divorced 50-year-old chemist who has been conducting a lazy affair with a 26-year-old named Polly (she lives in his building), is bowled over by a wave of bliss. As Everett sits in his apartment, reading the paper and sipping a martini, a pair of warm eyes unexpectedly meets his, and his world turns from blas to ros. Everett experienced an unfamiliar sensation, Schine writes. He was suddenly, intensely aware of the room around him, of the soft order of his furnishings and his life, of the soft order outside where day was giving way to night, of the TV sounds and the cold wet of the martini glass, of the smudgy feel of newsprint on his fingers, but mostly he was aware of joy  the wild, clattering joy of being alive. Howdy, he whispered.

title: Beethoven in a Barn, and More
description: Arizona

title: The Week on Long Island
description: New Prosecutors Will Fight Drunken Driving

title: Cloudy, With a Chance of Golf Balls
description: THE sun was finally out last week, and on a clear Wednesday afternoon, group after group of golfers stood on a grassy hill at the southern edge of Brooklyn, across the street from the leafy grounds of the Poly Prep Country Day School, and peered down the ninth fairway of the city-owned Dyker Beach Golf Course.

title: Nascar Teams Line Up to Make a Pitch for a Big Catch
description: DARLINGTON, S.C., May 12  The suitors are beginning to line up for the chance to talk Dale Earnhardt Jr. into driving for their race team next season.

title: An Appeal to Look East
description: MARC deVENOGE grew up in Manhasset, a wealthy enclave on the North Shore of Nassau County, but spent summers sailing and cycling on the North Fork at the East End of Long Island.

title: The What? Committee
description: The question surrounding New Jerseys legislative ethics committee is whether it is for ethics or against them. In the 34 years of its existence, a period marked by one Trenton scandal after another, the committee has imposed sanctions on only four legislators: three simple reprimands and a small fine.

title: Correction: Taking the Long View
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about residential towers on Central Park West, gave an incorrect cross street for the apartment building at 1040 Fifth Avenue, which is cited as an inspiration for the design of 15 Central Park West. It is East 85th Street, not 84th Street.

title: On the Snake River, Dams Natural Allies Seem to Have a Change of Heart
description: LOWER GRANITE DAM, Wash.  The wheat Bryan Jones grows in Eastern Washington begins its journey to Asia on barges along the lower Snake River. The river, once a wild, muscular torrent, was made barge friendly a quarter-century ago by four of the nations most controversial hydropower dams.

title: Monica Yang and Michael Tai
description: Monica Ina Yang, a daughter of Joung Sook Yang of Studio City, Calif., and the late Dr. Soon Chung Yang, was married yesterday to Michael Wei-kwun Tai, the son of Kay and Jackson P. Tai of Greenwich, Conn., and Singapore. The Rev. Dr. Stuart H. Hoke performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Caught in the Headlights
description: AS the Upper East Side braces for the commotion and transformation that will undoubtedly mark the first phase of construction of the Second Avenue subway, a very few of the neighborhoods residents face a more dramatic change. To make room for subway stations and other components of the system, some buildings and the people who live in them will have to go.

title: Homes for $1? Sure, but Theyre Real Fixer-Uppers
description: NORWICH

title: House Tours: Inviting Outsiders In
description: Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Antique Horror Show
description: As a literary form, pastiche has its pleasures, often witty ones, as the career of Arthur Phillips proves. His first novel, Prague, doesnt immediately read as an imitation, since it tells the contemporary tale of young expatriates in Budapest, loosely based on the authors own experiences in Hungary. But what about that anomalous section in the middle, a 70-odd-page history of a Hungarian printing family? As if to acknowledge the pleasures of such research, Phillipss follow-up novel, The Egyptologist, dispatched with a contemporary setting and fully embraced historical detail, this time more boldly, recreating the fantasia of 1920s Tut-mania, complete with desert brigands.

title: Floating Away
description: Several years ago, I worked as a student chaplain at a childrens hospital for six months. While there, I often heard that children were better at dying than adults. The idea that children have an innate understanding of death that adults lack is indeed compelling. But personally, I never saw it. The death I saw was painful. It was hard.

title: Getting Better All the Time
description: It should be said: Kevin Henkes is a genius. Not that he needs me to point this out. And not that it will be news to the many fans of his 37 books or the judges who have made him the rare author-illustrator to have received both a Caldecott Medal (the picture-book prize) and a Newbery Honor (the runner-up childrens fiction prize). And yet he isnt quite the household name that Dr. Seuss and Maurice Sendak are, though he should be.

title: The Week in Westchester
description: A Month After the Flood, Aid Requests Continue

title: Correction: Tell Them Seth Sent You
description: The Weekend in New York column on April 29 about former speakeasies referred incorrectly to the attention that one bar, Bills Gay Nineties, has received from guidebooks. It is included in the Zagat New York City night life guide; it has not been overlooked by Zagat.

title: Parkway Expansion Plan Draws Opposition
description: WHEN Gilmore Clark, the landscape architect who worked on many New York-area highways for Robert Moses, came to New Jersey to design the Garden State Parkway in the early 1950s, he held to certain principles to keep it both beautiful, like Connecticuts Merritt Parkway, and efficient, like the Pennsylvania Turnpike.

title: Earnings and Reports Give the Dow a Lift
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose again last week on strong corporate earnings and economic reports that sustained Wall Streets hopes for lower interest rates.

title: Charles Dickenss Books Are Basis for New Park
description: Charles Dickenss 19th-century characters are about to be brought to life in a decidedly 21st-century manner  as animatronic figures in a new theme park based on the authors books and life. Opening May 25, Dickens World (www.dickensworld.co.uk), in Chatham, Kent, England (where Dickens spent most of his childhood), will introduce visitors to life in Dickensian times  from the architecture and street scenes to the smells and sounds.

title: Lauren Berger, Stuart Ruderfer
description: Lauren Rachel Berger, a daughter of Marjorie Berger and Dr. Neil Berger of Penn Valley, Pa., was married last evening to Stuart Benjamin Ruderfer, the son of Jill Ruderfer and Irwin Ruderfer of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Geoffrey Spector officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Calendar of Events
description: COMEDY

title: Courtney Young, Laurin Penland
description: Courtney Brummett Young and Melinda Laurin Penland, both involved in the construction business, affirmed their partnership yesterday. Sara Smolik, a friend of the couple, led a commitment ceremony on the beach at Wrightsville Beach, N.C.

title: Deirdre Cahill, John Swagerty
description: Deirdre Anne Cahill, a daughter of Sheelagh and William T. Cahill of Bangor, Pa., was married yesterday to John Fitzgerald Swagerty, a son of Ann and Terry C. Swagerty of Roseburg, Ore. The Rev. Robert Beloin, the Roman Catholic chaplain at Yale University, officiated at St. Charles Borromeo Church in Brooklyn.

title: Warehoused Apartments
description: Q I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in a seven-unit building in Manhattan. The landlord has emptied the four apartments above me, and he lives in two apartments below me. For the last three years, he has warehoused the upstairs apartments, which had been rent-stabilized, but has allowed friends and religious students to stay there rent-free. Is he allowed to do this?

title: Hey, Pop Idol, Surrender My Name!
description: HOW do you compete with an Angel?

title: Loves Deity
description: It has always been convenient to see John Donne (1572-1631) as the St. Augustine of English letters, made priestly and pure in his own good time, and not too soon to have produced the brainy carnal thrustings of his early love poems. Donne himself made things misleadingly neat for posterity by drawing his own contrasts between Jack Donne and Dr. Donne, dean of St. Pauls Cathedral, and by setting the Mistresse of my youth, Poetry, against the wyfe of mine age, Divinity.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Hard Race From Backstretch to White House
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 10  There was the hug from President Bush, and small talk with Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., and the introduction to Queen Elizabeth II. Calvin Borel blushed as he recounted the fairy tale evening at the White House, a grin cracking across a face as well worn as an old saddle.

title: A Good Summer to Leave the Car in the Garage
description: The summer forecast for gasoline prices is out. Quick summary: you may want to stay home for your vacation and ask your boss about telecommuting.

title: No Muggings in New Dorp, and Game Fans Are Miffed
description: Imagine, if you will, that you are Niko Bellic, the main character of Grand Theft Auto IV, a video game due out in October. With free rein in Liberty City, a meticulously rendered stand-in for New York, you can carjack a hot rod in Dumbo and zoom down the Manhattan Bridge at 140 miles per hour. If youre short on cash, you can mug a tourist in Times Square or stick up a group of workers on the Red Hook piers.

title: A Joke Inspires a Hall of Fame Thats No Joke
description: Commack

title: Civilian Deaths Undermine Allies War on Taliban
description: ZERKOH, Afghanistan, May 9  Scores of civilian deaths over the past months from heavy American and allied reliance on airstrikes to battle Taliban insurgents are threatening popular support for the Afghan government and creating severe strains within the NATO alliance.

title: Voters in Dallas Suburb Back Limit on Renting to Illegal Immigrants
description: DALLAS, May 12  Voters in a Dallas suburb approved a contentious proposal Saturday to ban landlords from renting apartments to most illegal immigrants.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An entry in the hardcover advice best-seller list on Page 32 of the Book Review today, for The Loved Dog, omits the name of the writer with whom Tamar Geller collaborated on the book. She is Andrea Cagan.

title: A Mall Plan, a Call to Arms, a Plot of Land Still Empty
description: SYOSSET, N.Y.

title: Spangles All Around
description: WITH ink-black hair and silver-streaked eye shadow, Camille Wojtasiak, 47, is a dancer who inspires women to dip and swoon and men to take notes on her technique. As she confidently leads a swift fox trot or a gliding waltz, the only thing belying her calm is a pesky trickle of sweat.

title: Earth to G.O.P.: The Gipper Is Dead
description: OF course you didnt watch the first Republican presidential debate on MSNBC. Even the partys most loyal base didnt abandon Fox News, where Bill OReilly, interviewing the already overexposed George Tenet, drew far more viewers. Yet the few telling video scraps that entered the 24/7 mediasphere did turn the event into an instant Saturday Night Live parody without SNL having to lift a finger. The row of 10 middle-aged white candidates, David Letterman said, looked like guys waiting to tee off at a restricted country club.

title: Keeping Precious Artwork Safe
description: STEALING a painting, according to the artist Scott Richter, is a lot easier than youd imagine. Perhaps not from major museums, which have sophisticated alarms and guards in every room. But after 30 years working as a painter, sculptor and teacher , Mr. Richter has learned that lesser institutions can rarely afford such tight security.

title: Dinosaurigami
description: Big is beautiful  and it leaps directly off the page at you with teeth and claws bared in Encyclopedia Prehistorica: Mega-Beasts. This intricate pop-up book is billed as the third and final entry in Robert Sabuda and Matthew Reinharts Prehistorica series, following Dinosaurs and Sharks and Other Sea Monsters. Like the previous volumes, the book is filled with elaborately engineered paper creatures that burst forth in all their 3-D glory, no funky cardboard glasses required.

title: Nicole VanDernoot, Jared Hirsch
description: Nicole Ruth VanDernoot and Jared Brett Hirsch were married last evening at Boston Harbor Hotel in Boston. Cantor Jodi Sufrin officiated.

title: An Open, Sunlit Space at 7 World Trade Center
description: WHEN Mansueto Ventures bought the magazines Inc. and Fast Company from the German publisher Gruner & Jahr two years ago, it immediately began polishing the two titles. The paper quality was improved, staff changes were made and the editorial content was sharpened, according to Mansueto, the new owner. The company also wanted its new offices in New York to project the same retooled image, by emphasizing that the magazines were no longer part of a huge global stable of mainstream publications on subjects ranging from politics to parenting to decorating.

title: Jennifer Merzon, Christopher Evans
description: Jennifer Lee Merzon and Christopher Michael Evans were married last evening by the Rev. James L. Burns at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan. The Right Rev. Andrew St. John, the vicar of the Church of the Transfiguration in Manhattan, participated in the ceremony.

title: We Dont Need 169 Fiefs
description: Connecticut is an old state; many towns have been part of the landscape for more than 350 years. That provides residents with a rich history. It also carries a significant downside. Communities boundaries were set centuries ago, and so was the manner in which they raise money. Beginning in colonial times, Connecticuts towns and cities have come to rely heavily  too heavily  on property taxes to meet their civic needs.

title: Lauren Kelley, Martin Koopman
description: Lauren Hawkes Kelley, a daughter of Marcia Eve Kelley and Dr. William E. Kelley Jr. of Richmond, Va., was married there yesterday to Martin Julius Koopman, the son of Peggy Koopman-Boyden of Hamilton, New Zealand, and John Koopman of Christchurch, New Zealand. The Rev. James Glass, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Bridgets Catholic Church.

title: Kelly McMenamin, Frederick Wang
description: Colleen Cara McMenamin and Frederick William Wang were married yesterday at St. Thomas Church in New York. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: A Wished-For House With a Hideaway Nook
description: ON her fourth birthday, Abbie Hornburg made a wish on a party balloon as it floated up into the sky.

title: How the West Side Was Won
description: Q On the East Side of Manhattan the names of avenues, like First or Park, continue unchanged north of 59th Street, while on the West Side the names change. Ninth becomes Columbus, for instance. Why? ... Herb Dooskin, Manhattan

title: Venturing Out of the City and Into Creation
description: TIVOLI, N.Y.

title: Religious Groups Reap Federal Aid for Pet Projects
description: St. Vincent College, a small Benedictine college southeast of Pittsburgh, wanted to realign a two-lane state road serving the campus. But the state transportation department did not have the money.

title: Bigger Than Life
description: To the Editor:

title:
Nuclear Physics: Not Just for Men; Interfaith Preparation for Climates Hazards; What I Expect
From Poetry (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Natalie Lui, Stephen Duncan
description: Chunghymn Natalie Lui and Stephen M. Duncan were married yesterday at the Seminary Chapel at the Virginia Theological Seminary in Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Dr. M. Craig Barnes, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: In New Role, Senator Clintons Strategist in Chief
description: Bill Clintons connections, and his endless supply of chits, only begin to capture his singular role in his wifes presidential candidacy, advisers and friends of the couple say. He is the master strategist behind the scenes; the consigliere to the head of the family, as some Clinton aides refer to her operation; and a fund-raising machine who is steadily pulling in $100,000 or more at receptions.

title: Heart of a Company, and a Family
description: Irvington

title: The Charming Gadfly Who Saved the High Line
description: FOR all the giddiness surrounding the transformation of the High Line, the citys favorite elevated railway, into a linear park running from the meatpacking district to Hells Kitchen, nearly one-third of it remains in danger of being torn down. The stretch between 30th and 34th Streets, where the High Line loops gracefully around parts of the railyards between 10th and 12th Avenues, is shaping up as the last battleground for the innovative project.

title: Babymoon: Getting Away, While There Are Just Two of You
description: AT 20 weeks pregnant, Courtney Monardo, a 40-year-old processor for a mortgage company in Scottsdale, Ariz., was  to quote Madeleine Kahn in Blazing Saddles  so tired.

title: The Alchemy of Violence
description: The intellectual thriller, dripping with blood and erudition, was invented by Poe, refined by Borges and Umberto Eco, and eventually attained its popular apotheosis in The Da Vinci Code. By now, its cogs and pulleys are so familiar that seasoned readers dont flinch at time travel, cryptography, a famous ghost or two and the rest of the shopworn gadgetry of the genre. Rebecca Stotts intricately plotted Ghostwalk begins in the orthodox fashion, with a corpse, a clue and an armchair detective. title: Sex, Drugs and Updating Your Blog
description: Jonathan Coulton sat in Gorilla Coffee in Brooklyn, his Apple PowerBook open before him, and began slogging through the days e-mail. Coulton is 36 and shaggily handsome. In September 2005, he quit his job as a computer programmer and, with his wifes guarded blessing, became a full-time singer and songwriter. He set a quixotic goal for himself: for the next year, he would write and record a song each week, posting each one to his blog. It was a sort of forced-march approach to creativity, he admitted to me over the sound of the cafes cappuccino frothers. Hed always wanted to be a full-time musician, and he figured the only way to prove to himself he could do it was with a drastic challenge. I learned that it is possible to squeeze a song out of just about anything, he said. But its not always an easy or pleasant process. Given the self-imposed time constraints, the Thing a Week songs are remarkably good. Coulton tends toward geeky, witty pop tunes: one song, Tom Cruise Crazy, is a sympathetic ode to the fame-addled star, while Code Monkey is a rocking anthem about dead-end programming jobs. By the middle of last year, his project had attracted a sizable audience. More than 3,000 people, on average, were visiting his site every day, and his most popular songs were being downloaded as many as 500,000 times; he was making what he described as a reasonable middle-class living  between $3,000 and $5,000 a month  by selling CDs and digital downloads of his work on iTunes and on his own site.

title: The Right Stuff, but Usually the Wrong Stuff

Inside every sealed cardboard box is the possibility of a jewelry collection, a Civil War relic or a first-edition Superman comic book. God knows Ive had my fill of wistful Jews, starting with myself. Chabon, starting with himself as writers should, seems determined in The Yiddish Policemens Union to stave off wistfulness by any means, even if it requires him to turn the story of the endless, endemic disappointment of the Jews  their millenniums-old-and-counting wait for the Messiah  into a screwball, alternative-reality, hard-boiled mystery, set, for maximum incongruity, in Alaska. The impressively wacky premise is that after the Holocaust, large numbers of Jews were relocated to Sitka, where by statute they were allowed to make their home for the next 60 years, at the end of which the town would revert to the control of Alaska. Israel, it appears, didnt work out: the Jewish settlers there were ejected with savage finality in 1948. The Holy Land, the novel tells us, has never seemed more remote or unattainable than it does to a Jew of Sitka. The godforsakenness of the place is something more than a figure of speech.
