description: As deal making in the fast-food industry continues to heat up, an ice cream maker, the Cold Stone Creamery, and a fast-food operator, Kahala are teaming up to form a holding company they hope will be able to compete with private equity firms for a greater share of the sector.

title: Trial Highlights Blacks Rift With Lieutenant
description: The trial of Conrad M. Black has brought to the surface the simmering tensions that grew between the publishing magnate and his former partner, F. David Radler. The New York Timess Richard Siklos notes that it has also provided a reminder that, for the modern media mogul, a good No. 2 is hard to find.

title: A Deal (and Perhaps an Unveiling) for a Fake Steve Jobs
description: Guessing whos behind The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs, a satirical blog by an anonymous writer calling himself the Fake Steve Jobs, has become a parlor game in Silicon Valley, with several journalists, former Apple employees and even Steve Jobs himself topping the list of suspects.

title: CBOT-Merc Merger Faces Renewed Opposition
description: Despite the Chicago Board of Trades formal rejection of the Intercontinental Exchanges bid, following a higher offer from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, investors were betting that the battle for control of the Chicago derivatives exchange wasnt over.

title: Telefonica Unloads Endemol for $3.5 Billion
description: Spains Telefonica has reached a deal to sell the Dutch TV company Endemol, creator of the Big Brother show, for 2.63 billion euros ($3.55 billion) to a consortium including the Mediaset media empire controlled by the family of the former Italian Premier Silvio Berlusconi, Mediaset said in a statement.

title: As Hedge Fund Scrutiny Increases, So Does Political Spending
description: As lawmakers continue to scrutinize the hedge fund industry, a recent surge in the hiring of lobbyists and stepped-up contributions to political action committees by managers in the $1 trillion hedge fund industry and top officials of private-equity groups probably comes as no surprise.

title: CBS Is Reportedly in Deal to Buy WallStrip
description: WallStrip, the online television show that strives for a mix of Squawk Box and Saturday Night Live, is reportedly in talks to be bought by CBS for about $5 million, according to New York media blog Jossip. The blog said that as part of the deal, which is expected to be announced this week, WallStrips presenter, Lindsay Campbell, will become the next Amanda Congdon: frontin for CBS Web initiatives.

title: Mylan Labs in Deal to Buy German Generic Drug Unit
description: Mylan Laboratories has agreed to buy the generic drug unit of Merck, the German drug maker, for 4.9 billion euros ($6.7 billion) in cash. The acquisition will make Mylan the worlds third-largest maker of copycat versions of drugs, after Teva Pharmaceuticals of Israel and Novartis of Switzerland.

title: RBS Alliance Publishes Details of ABN Amro Bid
description: The consortium that wants to buy and break up ABN Amro on Monday published confidential details of its offer, which the Dutch bank rejected last week. The consortium, which includes Royal Bank of Scotland, Santander, and Fortis, said their proposal had lower execution risk than an agreed deal between ABN and Britains Barclays Bank and was worth more.

title: Private Equity Eyes Valentino Fashions
description: The Valentino Fashion Group said Friday that it had been approached by several private equity firms interested in buying a stake in the Italian fashion house, but said it had not received a formal offer. The chairman, Antonio Favrin, who made the comments at the companys annual shareholders meeting Friday in Milan, did not name any of the potential suitors for the firm, which controls Hugo Boss.

title: Alexandra Investment Gets a New Partner
description: A hedge fund, Alexandra Investment Management, said on Friday it was hiring John Hock as president and partner.

title: The Dirty 30
description: Steam rises from the cooling towers of Schwarze Pumpe power plant, Germany. Jockel Finck/AP

title: Former Times C.F.O. to Join Buyout Firm
description: Leonard Forman, the former chief financial officer of The New York Times Company, is joining a media-focused investment firm Veronis Suhler Stevenson in another sign that private equity continues to lure retired public company executives, the New York Post reported Monday. Mr. Forman plans to join Veroniss board of advisers, which already has nine former industry and government leaders, to help the firm identify deals in the specialty media sector.

title: Ford Family Said to Consider Trimming Stake
description: Members of the family that founded Ford Motor are discussing the possibility of selling some of their controlling stake in the company, Bloomberg News reported, citing three people with direct knowledge of the talks. Bloomberg said that Bill Ford, Fords chairman, told the companys directors about the family members views before last weeks annual shareholder meeting in Wilmington, Del. As has been previously reported, some family members have sought to hire an investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners as an outside financial adviser.

title: In Congress, Seeking a Compromise War Bill
description: Congressional Republicans evidently have found an Iraqi withdrawal plan they can accept.

title: Some Bancrofts Open to Meeting With Murdoch, Report Says
description: Some Bancroft family members want to meet Rupert Murdoch to discuss his $5 billion offer for Dow Jones but they face stiff opposition from other relatives, The Financial Times reported. Mr. Murdoch has been pressing for a meeting with the Bancroft family, which controls the publishing company through a special class of stock, since they rejected his $60-per-share offer for the company and its flagship Wall Street Journal nearly two weeks ago.

title: Brazils Wine Country
description: Wine is now being made in nontraditional areas like Brazils desert, challenging centuries-old grape myths.

title: Pentagon Blocks MySpace and YouTube
description: The Defense Department has decided to make it impossible to reach 13 Web sites from its network, citing an overabundance of recreational traffic.

title: Will the Popes U.N. Speech Be Green?
description: Tobin Harshaw

title: 2 Former Siemens Executives Are Convicted of Bribery
description: Two former executives at Siemens were convicted Monday of bribery and assisting bribery for their involvement in multimillion-dollar payments to officials at an Italian utility. The verdict came in the first trial over a series of scandals at the company.

title: Churning the Bottom
description: Satellite photos from around the world show the impact that fishing trawlers are having on the ocean bottom.

title: Meeting of the Minds
description: Last week Mr. Bruno and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver bumped into each other in the Capitol, and the two men, who cannot resist pushing each others buttons, took a moment to discuss a New York Post story that said Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was mulling a bid for governor in 2010.

title:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Investigations Editor Matthew Purdy
description: Matthew Purdy, The Times's investigations editor, answered reader questions May 14 through May 18, 2007.

title: Primedia to Sell Magazines to Burkle for $1.2 Billion
description: Primedia agreed on Monday to sell about 70 magazines, including Motor Trend, Hot Rod and Surfer, to Source Interlink, a company controlled by the billionaire investor Ronald W. Burkle, for about $1.2 billion in cash.

title: Monday Morning Motorsports
description: In Formula One, Felipe Massa started from pole in his Ferrari and survived a first corner charge from Fernando Alonso of McLaren to win the Spanish Grand Prix. Lewis Hamilton continued to impress, finishing second, well ahead of his McLaren teammate. He now leads the championship by two points. Heres the back story on Hamilton. Nothing we havent heard before, but a pretty good timeline of his rise to Formula One. At 22, Hamilton admits that hes an accidental role model. He said, You just need that wall knocking down and then you can have other people coming through. It hasnt been my plan, but I hope that it does that.

title: Notes on 5/14 Column, Divided Over Trade
description: A few notes on trade and wages.

title: Law Firms Help Drive Chrysler Deal
description: The winner of the auction for Chrysler, Cerberus Capital Management, is widely refered to as a private equity shop these days. But the firms longtime legal adviser, Schulte Roth & Zabel, reflects Cerberuss roots as a hedge fund  and one that knows its way around a bankruptcy courtroom. Schulte Roth, which counseled Cerberus in the Chrysler negotiations, is known as one of the top legal advisers to hedge funds, and it claims to represent more than one half of the 100 largest hedge funds listed in Institutional Investor. On many occasions, it has advised Cerberus when it bid for assets of bankrupt companies (or when Cerberuss portfolio companies tumbled into bankruptcy protection themselves).

title: Abandon Cruise Ship
description: Good Samaritans in the great state of Alaska are helping passengers escape their cruise ship, which is stuck and listing after running aground 15 miles southwest of Juneau.

title: Amid a Flood of Buyouts, Signs of Leakage
description: Is it coincidence that the boom in leveraged buyouts is being accompanied by a surge in suspicious pre-deal trading activity and a rise in insider-trading cases? Some research by FinancialWeek suggests there may be a connection between the two trends.

title: A Mom Running to Lead the Mommy Party
2007 Tony Award Winners
description: A list of winners of 2007 Tony Awards (denoted with a

title: TV Upfronts: Baby, Can We Start Fresh?
description: Were off to the prime-time prom: this week New York is host to the upfronts, where the networks roll out their new prime-time schedules for advertisers.

title: Scientologists Ambush the BBC
description: A 41-second video of a BBC reporter shouting at someone in rather unhinged fashion was posted on YouTube late last week as part of a campaign to discredit a documentary the British network is preparing about The Church of Scientology.

title: How Can Chrysler Get Back Its Vroom-Vroom-Vroom?
description: One of the classic scenes on the international auto show circuit took place in 2003, when Chryslers then-president, Wolfgang Bernhard, roared onto the stage in Detroit astride a thundering, gleaming-silver motorcycle called  the Tomahawk.

title: Take My Company, Please
description: The most amazing aspect of Daimlers giveaway of Chrysler is that it is considered good news by all. Ford and General Motors shares are up, despite the fact that Chrysler is deemed essentially worthless. Daimler bonds are up on the news, and the companys bond rating may be increased, despite the fact that it no longer will have Chrysler assets available to help provide the money to repay the bonds.

title: Obamas Sunday Debut
description: Although it may seem as if Barack Obama has been running for president ever since his big speech at the 2004 Democratic National Convention, yesterday in fact marked his first appearance on the Sunday gabfest circuit since his official announcement. He talked with George Stephanopoulos on ABCs This Week. So how did the rookie do?

title: TV Upfronts: Getting the 8206492 on Alec Baldwin
description: News about Alec Baldwin  breaking

title: Facing Reality
description: When all else fails, face the facts. And the fact was we needed to build a smaller house.

title: TV Upfronts: Waiting for NBC
description: Big happy Radio City. Im sitting next to an ad man, whose 16-year-old sons favorite shows are Friday Night Lights and Entourage.

title: TV Upfronts: The Search for More Mass
description: Tina Fey, in a low low cut black dress, is onscreen in a little movie. Shes so good at pushing the digital stuff and the product integration without not being funny.

title: Give Us Your Snakecharmers, Your Fakirs, Your Frauds
description: Nasdijj, the make-believe American Indian and perpetrator of what the LA Weekly exposed as the Navahoax, is back. Remember him? Remember The Blood Runs Like A River Through My Dreams, and the Esquire article that made him a National Magazine Award finalist?

title: Should Alcan Turn the Tables on Alcoa?
description: As aluminum giant Alcan considers how to react to the hostile $27 billion from Alcoa, an analyst at Prudential Equity Group has a suggestion that harkens back to the era when legwarmers were the height of fashion (though we hear they are making a comeback). The analyst, John C. Tumazos, is floating the idea that terms of the deal could be flipped so that Montreal-based Alcan buys New York-based Alcoa. Such a tactic first gained currency in the 1980s, when it became known as the Pac-Man defense, after the popular video game in which the player could change roles and go after his or her pursuers.

title: TV Upfronts: Everybodys a Detective
description: Applause at the news that NBC is keeping Friday Night Lights. Cool. (The news is not as good for fans of Aaron Sorkins Studio 60  NBC plans to burn off the remaining episodes this summer. Its doomed for next year.)

title: TV Upfronts: That Ones Got Me
description: Or so says the sweetheart ad salesman next to me of Journeyman, the weepie new NBC show about a time traveler with two wives. Or something.

title: TV Upfronts: The Too-Big Bed
description: Lipstick Jungle, the new Candace Bushnell cocktail, contains at least one effective sight gag: a giant, god-size bed, a visual sendup of all the too-big things that rich people outfit their houses with.

title: Lining Up for Clinton in Albany
description: Senator Hillary Clinton appeared just after noon today on the lofty steps of the state Capitol wearing a magenta jacket and surrounded by a phalanx of seven men in dark suits.

title: TV Upfronts: Better Than She Was Before
description: Bionic Woman. McG directed the pilot. This is the show thats said to be presold, because we remember its name from Lindsay Wagner days.

title: TV Upfronts: Bionic Woman contd.
description: Completely goofball reality pilots, but Im still thinking about Bionic Woman. It looks a bit like Buffy, though I know its a risk to say that. What I love about the idea is that  as Kevin Reilly said earlier  NBC is following what its sister channel Sci-Fi did with Battlestar Galactica: taking a dopey camp show and making it into something serious and intense.

title: TV Upfronts: Jerry Seinfelds Here  and Hes Funny!
description: Jerry Seinfeld is here! Jerry Seinfeld is here! Save us, Jerry Seinfeld!

title: TV Upfronts: Tinisodes
description: So Jerry Seinfeld has produced a bunch of short videos for NBC about the making of Bee Movie, his animated movie for DreamWorks. Im not crazy about what I saw. Hammy and sketchy and overproduced. I would have liked to have seen Mr. Seinfeld being kind of self-important in his new executive role, or just tired, like he was in Comedian, the documentary.

title: TV Upfronts: Wrapping Up NBC
description: While the hoarse, bulked-up sports guys are throwing footballs into the balcony  I actually love this stunt  I should mention Life, which has a title that rivals Heroes for lameness, and which is certainly expected to draw the same crowd. Its more spooky-sci-fi stuff. Theres also Chuck, which looks like My Name Is Earl meets Heroes, and thus like a big miss, which relies too much on Zachary Levi, its forgettable-seeming star.

title: The Clinton Pull
description: Dubious about the power that Bill Clinton has to woo Democrats to support his wifes presidential campaign? The Empire Zones Danny Hakim reports on how Bill Clintons powers of persuasion were on display up in Albany today, as Gov. Eliot Spitzer and others endorsed Senator Clintons candidacy.

title: The Buyout Discount, or Why Private Equity Pays Less
description: If you own shares in a takeover target, you might want to pin your hopes on a public company being the buyer. That is because these kinds of acquirers usually pay more in an acquisition than private equity firms do, according to a study cited by Mark Hulbert in The New York Times. The study, conducted by finance professors and called Why Do Private Acquirers Pay So Little Compared to Public Acquirers?, found that, on average, target shareholders receive 55 percent more if a public company instead of a buyout shop (or shops) is paying the bill.

title: At NYSE Euronext, a Franco-American Pay Chasm
description: When it comes to executive pay on both sides of the Atlantic, Jean-Franois Thodore is probably not shouting vive la difference. Financial News points out that Mr. Theodore, who was head of Euronext and is now deputy chief executive of the newly merged NYSE Euronext, was paid less than one-fifth what his new boss, John Thain, earned last year.

title: F.D.R.s Rough Road to Nomination
description: Presidential candidates now jockeying for position might take comfort when they recall Franklin D. Roosevelts perilous route to the Democratic nomination. Even F.D.R., one of Americas most successful presidents, had to work long and hard to get his partys support for the job. And the last night of that effort was the longest and hardest of all.

title: Bias as Usual or Foul Play?
description: David Stern, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, isnt too happy with the recent revelation that N.B.A. referees appear to have a racial bias in the way they call fouls. Hes questioned the validity of the statistical analysis by Justin Wolfers, an assistant professor of business and public policy at the Wharton School, and Joseph Price, a Cornell graduate student in economics, which suggests that white and black referees call fouls preferentially against players of the opposite race. The N.B.A. insists that its own analysis (of different data) reveals no such bias, although other experts whove seen both analyses say that the Wolfers and Price study is more convincing.

title: Law School Classmates Criticize Gonzales
description: Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, who has been under fire from politicians in both parties, was assailed today by several dozen of his classmates at Harvard Law School, Class of 1982.

title: If You Think Oswegos Cold, Try New Hampshire in January
description: We caught up with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on his way out of a meeting with Gov. Eliot Spitzer about the mayors plans to make the city more livable and evironmentally sound. (He needs the governors help for some of it, especially congestion pricing.) Mr. Bloomberg was mum about his plans reception  Im optimistic well that find a ways to get his support, but his staff wants to look at it first he said  but he did take another swing at the question of whether he would consider running for governor in 2010.

title: Johnson Prepares for Senate Return
description: Senator Tim Johnson of South Dakota is preparing for a return to the Senate after a brain hemorrhage in December, and fellow Democrats say they fully expect Mr. Johnson to be a candidate for a third term next year.

title: Television Upfronts: NBC
description: The Times's Bill Carter reports from Radio City Music Hall, where NBC presented its 2007 fall lineup.

title: Welcome Back, Cliff
description: Not to take any words out of my colleagues mouths (or blogs), but I can safely say that the one player we miss most around here is Cliff Floyd, who returns to Shea for the first time tonight as a member of the Chicago Cubs. A few days before players were scheduled to report to spring training, a few other beat writers and I were walking around the Mets clubhouse and I recall having a moment of silence in front of Cliffs corner locker that was then occupied by David Newhan.

title: Clinton Keeps Corporate Adviser
description: Add another consultant to the list of those advising Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton: John Kao, a corporate communications consultant who is based in San Francisco and advocates using the techniques of musical improvisation to get the creative juices flowing and leave competitors in the dust.

title: Harnessing the Large 2008 Field
description: When 10 Republican presidential candidates assemble on a stage Tuesday night in South Carolina for their second debate, viewers will get a reminder of how the sheer size of the field in both parties limits the opportunities for probing questioning.

title: Basic Instinct Politics
description: From the politics-meets-art/weirdness file: The Italian artist Francesco Vezzoli has hired the top campaign ad gurus for President Bush and Senator John Kerry from 2004, but this time to square off again as part of his installation in the upcoming Biennale in Venice.

title: Unseating the Border Patrol Chief
description: David V. Aguilar, the chief of Border Patrol, has managed to steer clear of the critics dogging other Bush administration officials these days. Instead, he has a union calling for his head.

title: Life After the Airline Industry
description: Members of the Schalk family of Oceanside, N.Y., talk about their jobs as airline mechanics and why they made a change.

title: Is Amputee Sprinter Too-Abled?
description: Oscar Pistorius of South Africa, who had both legs amputated below the knee when he was 11 months old, wants to be the first amputee runner to compete in the Olympics.

title: For ABC, Dramas Fill Out the Lineup
description: ABC will continue to be the most aggressive of the networks with its lineup of new shows for the next television season, ordering at least 11 new series, when it officially announces its fall schedule to advertisers today.

title: Napa Valley? Bordeaux? No, but Still Wine Country
description: RIO de JANEIRO, May 14  When the Portuguese winemaker Joo Santos first viewed his companys new vineyard in Brazil, he was crestfallen. How could he ever produce wine anywhere nearly as good as that made in Europe? The trouble was the palm trees.

title: Japan: Trade Surplus Rises to a Record
description: Japans current account surplus widened to a record in March, as exports to Asia and Europe helped counter slower growth in shipments to the United States. The surplus expanded 36.9 percent, to 3.32 trillion yen ($28 billion) from a year earlier, the ministry of finance said. In other economic news, Japans machinery orders fell unexpectedly for a second month in March. Non-government orders excluding shipping and utilities dropped 4.5 percent from a month earlier after declining a revised 4.9 percent in February.

title: Clinton and Obama Visits Suggest New Clout for Two States
description: New York and New Jersey have often been bit players in the presidential nominating process, with their primaries typically occurring after the nominees have been settled upon.

title: Swiss Investigating BAE in Money Laundering Case
description: PARIS, May 14  Law enforcement authorities in Switzerland confirmed Monday that they had opened a criminal investigation into possible money laundering at BAE Systems, adding to the international scrutiny of the company, the top British military contractor.

title: Guantnamo Detainees Suit Challenges Fairness of Militarys Repeat Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  The military system of determining whether detainees are properly held at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, includes an unusual practice: If Pentagon officials disagree with the result of a hearing, they order a second one, or even a third, until they approve of the finding.

title: Whats on Sale There? Confusion, but Its Cheap
description: A humble sign on the window of a new storefront in Lower Manhattan yesterday encouraged passers-by to take a trip, one that could be long or quite brief depending on the traveler: Explore Your Inner Self.

title: At Least 7 Killed in Gaza Fighting
description: NAHAL OZ, Israel, May 15  Fighters from the military wing of Hamas, one of the two main Palestinian political factions, attacked Palestinian Authority security forces loyal to the rival Fatah faction at a location in Gaza near the border with Israel today, killing nine people, according to Fatah officials.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (CW) GILMORE GIRLS Lorelai (Lauren Graham), center, and Rory (Alexis Bledel), right, that bantering mother-daughter duo, move on with their lives in the seriess final episode. Rory lands her dream job as a political reporter, and Luke (Scott Patterson) throws her a graduation party attended by all of Stars Hollow, including Emily (Kelly Bishop) and Richard (Edward Hermann). They are on hand to hear Rory thank Lorelai for giving her a such great start in life. And then shes off!

title: Scientists Back Off Theory of a Colder Europe in a Warming World
description: OSLO  Mainstream climatologists who have feared that global warming could have the paradoxical effect of cooling northwestern Europe or even plunging it into a small ice age have stopped worrying about that particular disaster, although it retains a vivid hold on the public imagination.

title: Nigeria: Election Body Must Produce Evidence, Court Says
description: An election tribunal ruled that the government must produce evidence that supports its declaration of a winner in last months presidential election, delivering an early victory to efforts to challenge the balloting in court. A tribunal judge said that electoral officials must allow Atiku Abubakar, the vice president and third-place finisher in the presidential contest, to examine the ballot papers, tally sheets and other materials used in declaring Umaru YarAdua, the candidate of the governing party, the winner. A European Union observer mission declared the voting not credible, and Nigerian observers demanded a rerun. Mr. YarAdua is set to be inaugurated on May 29.

title: Britain: Blair and Bush to Meet
description: Prime Minster Tony Blair plans to visit Washington this week and meet with President Bush to discuss issues related to the Group of 8 meeting in Germany next month. Mr. Blairs spokesman, who customarily speaks in return for anonymity, said the discussions would also cover climate change, Iraq and the Middle East. The Washington trip is being billed as part of Mr. Blairs farewell schedule before he leaves office on June 27.

title: U.S. Soldier Is Shot Dead in Ambush in Pakistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 14  An American soldier was shot dead and four other Americans were wounded in Pakistan on Monday after a meeting of Afghan, Pakistani and NATO officials at the border to try to resolve recent clashes between the neighboring countries, Afghan and NATO officials said.

title: One Secret to Middle School Success: Class Size (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Operas on the Horizon: Tantalizing Glimpses of Adventurous Productions
description: The New York City Opera has become savvy about promoting its Vox series as a hip and adventurous event. The purpose of this invaluable showcase is to present excerpts from new or unperformed operas by American composers in free concert tryouts with the City Opera Orchestra and strong casts of singers.

title: Bloomberg Pushes Green Plan, but Many Want to Talk of 08
description: ALBANY, May 14  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg came to the Capitol on Monday to pitch his plan for reducing traffic congestion in Manhattan to state lawmakers and Gov. Eliot Spitzer, but there is no apparent sense of urgency in Albany to move on the mayors complex environmental proposals.

title: Gonzaless Deputy Quits Justice Department
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  Paul J. McNulty, the deputy attorney general whose Congressional testimony in February provided a spark that turned a smoldering issue over the firings of federal prosecutors into a raging inferno, announced his resignation on Monday.

title: On the Web, an Advanced Carbon Calculator for Personal Use
description: A new Internet tool to help individuals and communities curb their role in adding global-warming carbon emissions will be announced today at a conference in New York of mayors from around the world, said a person who built the Web technology.

title: White House Shifts Course on Wolfowitz
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  The Bush administration, shifting strategy in the face of mounting opposition to Paul D. Wolfowitz, opened the door today to him resigning voluntarily as World Bank president if the bank board drops its drive to declare him unfit to remain in office.

title: Here Is New York: A Gallerys Album of 25 Years of City Life
description: In the early 1970s, when few art galleries showed photography, the Midtown Y Photography Gallery was a rare pioneer devoted to the medium. An exhibition at the New York Public Library revisits the gallerys 25-year history and the role it played as photography moved into the art world.

title: Fort Dix Background Checks Proposed
description: A congressman from New Jersey said yesterday that he would propose a bill that would require all visitors to military installations to undergo federal background checks. The proposal comes in the wake of the charges filed last week against six men accused of planning an attack on soldiers at Fort Dix. The congressman, Representative Jim Saxton, a Republican whose district includes Fort Dix, said his bill would require the background checks for all visitors, including contractors, delivery people and civilians. The authorities have linked the six terrorist suspects to a pizzeria that frequently delivered to the base.

title: The Familiar and the New, With Gusto
description: James Levine conducts seated these days. And at least a few of his performances in recent years have seemed apathetic. But on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall the lively and satisfying concert he gave with the Met Orchestra was a picture of robust good health.

title: Stuck on the Runway, Thinking Rebellious Thoughts
description: THE other day I asked G. Bruce Hedlund, a pilot for a major domestic airline who has about three decades in the air, when he was going to be able to retire.

title: The Right to Paid Sick Days
description: It sounds reasonable: seven paid sick days a year. Why should you have to lose a couple of days pay, or maybe even your job, because you had the misfortune to catch the flu?

title: Arts, Briefly
description: SOLDIERS IRAQ BLOG BECOMES PRIZE-WINNING BOOK

title: Central Asians Chase Jobs, and Endure Exploitation
description: JIBEK JOLY, Kazakhstan, May 14  Dressed in ratty sport coats and dirty T-shirts, Uzbek men clutching yellow job contracts squeezed recently into packed buses heading for cities to the north in fast-urbanizing Kazakhstan and on up to Russia.

title: Jerry Falwell, Leading Religious Conservative, Dies
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, the fundamentalist preacher who founded the Moral Majority and helped bring the language and passions of religious conservatives into American politics, died today shortly after he was found unconscious in his office at Liberty University in Lynchburg, Va. He was 73 years old.

title: A Corporate Divorce on the Cheap
description: STUTTGART, Germany, May 14  Nine years after they exchanged vows at a huge, lavishly choreographed news conference in London, Daimler and Chrysler signed their divorce papers Monday at a sparsely attended briefing in an auditorium at an aging Mercedes-Benz factory here.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on May 7, about yoga patents, misstated the responsibilities of the United States Patent and Trademark Office. It does not register copyrights; that is the job of the United States Copyright Office.

title: Words That Help When Life Is All Drama, No Comedy
description: ISARIS BAEZ is 11 and waiting for heart surgery. It gets a little boring being in a hospital all day. So she was happily surprised last Wednesday when she learned that there was to be a screening of TMNT, the latest Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles movie, followed by a poetry jam. Pizza! Popcorn! Poems!

title: Military Gives Details of Iraq Ambush of 7 G.I.s
description: BAGHDAD, May 15  The seven American soldiers involved in a deadly weekend ambush south of Baghdad were from the 10th Mountain Division, based in upstate New York, military officials announced today, as thousands of troops continued an intensive search for three of the soldiers, who disappeared and are presumed to have been kidnapped by Sunni Arab insurgents.

title: Letters
description: The Root of Obesity

title: Qaeda Group Calls Hunt for Soldiers Pointless
description: BAGHDAD, May 14  The search for three missing American soldiers abducted after an attack south of Baghdad continued Monday as the Qaeda group that claimed responsibility for the ambush said the soldiers would never be found.

title: New York Welcomes Floyd Back to Town
description: Cliff Floyd could rattle off a list of 100 reasons why he signed with his hometown Chicago Cubs in January, starting with more day games and more time with his family.

title: In Deal, a Test for the U.A.W.
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., May 14  Can private equity investors fix Chrysler for good, and can they avoid a confrontation with the United Automobile Workers union?

title: Mammograms in Decline
description: After years of going to their doctors in rising numbers to get annual mammograms, American women have begun skipping the procedure. The small, but significant decline  reported yesterday by researchers from the National Cancer Institute  is disturbing because it means that more women will fail to get the early detection that increases their chances of survival.

title: In Hive or Castle, Duty Without Power
description: I never much cared for royalty, although I admit that, for reasons my family and I are still struggling to understand, I named my first cat Princess Bubbles.

title: Look Back in Chagrin: A Rockers Progress
description: A portrait of the artist as a confused young black man emerges in vivid colors in the fresh, exuberant and bitingly funny new musical Passing Strange, which opened last night at the Public Theater. The biography of a songwriter on a wayward journey of self-discovery, this bracingly inventive show introduces an exciting new voice to contemporary musical theater, a witty wordsmith, composer and performer who goes by the single name Stew.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about the exhibition Lincoln Kirstein, at the Whitney Museum of American Art, misstated the name of the ballet school Kirstein founded with George Balanchine. It is the School of American Ballet, not the American School of Ballet.

title: Lawyers Argue Legal Status of Gay Unions
description: HARTFORD, May 14  Connecticuts highest court became the first in the nation on Monday to hear arguments over whether the establishment of civil unions created a fundamentally inferior status for gays and lesbians. But in pondering a new appeal for same-sex marriage, the State Supreme Courts seven justices also focused on another fundamental question: whether laws that make distinctions based on sexual orientation, like those governing marriage, merit scrutiny similar to that given laws that discriminate based on race or gender.

title: Science in the Court Room
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Marathoner Joins Central Park Race
description: Khalid Khannouchi, who has twice broken the world record in the marathon, yesterday joined the field for Saturdays Healthy Kidney 10-kilometer run in Central Park. He has never raced in the park.Khannouchi, 35, was born in Morocco, moved to Brooklyn in 1993 and lives in Ossining, N.Y. He became an American citizen in 2000. He set world marathon records of 2 hours 5 minutes 42 seconds in Chicago in 1999 and 2:05:38 in London in 2002. He has been slowed by foot injuries in recent years.

title: Lottery Numbers
Correction: For the Record
description: An article and picture caption in some copies on Friday about the killing of the New York police officers estranged girlfriend misidentified the Queens neighborhood where it occurred. It was Woodhaven, not Woodside. The article also gave an incorrect spelling from the police for the given name and surname of the victim. She was Guiatree Hardat, not Guyatree Hartati.

title: One Misstep and Theyre Out the Door
description: Misbehaving executives, take note: before you have your day in court, you may already be out of a job.

title: Broadways Year of Tepid Hits
description: All right, to recap:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the arraignment of a New York police officer on murder charges in the killing of his estranged girlfriend misspelled the surname of the assistant Queens district attorney who spoke in court. She is Annette Almazan, not Almaza.

title: Oklahoma Chides Insurer in Medicare Marketing Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  In the first major investigation of Medicare marketing, the Oklahoma insurance commissioner has documented widespread misconduct by agents working for Humana and has ordered the company to take corrective action to protect consumers against high-pressure sales tactics.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a bid by the equity group Cerberus Capital Management to buy a controlling interest in Chrysler referred imprecisely to the timing of Chryslers acquisition of Jeep. It was added in 1987 with Chryslers purchase of American Motors; Jeep was not part of Chrysler when it received a federal bailout in 1979.

title: In Divided New Orleans
description: When President Bush spoke to the nation soon after Hurricane Katrina, he was resolute that the city would be rebuilt. We will do what it takes, he said. We  the federal, state and city governments; elected officials and the citizens who hire them  have failed spectacularly. Homes and schools remain empty or imaginary; evacuees and survivors wait in cramped trailers, unable to return or rebuild. A huge silence still hangs over the Lower Ninth Ward, a place every American should see, to witness firsthand how truckloads of promises have filled New Orleanss vast devastation with nothing.

title: Giants Kicking Hopes Rest on Untested Legs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 14  The Giants have two place-kickers on their roster. One, Josh Huston, spent most of last fall with the odd job of cleaning junk out of foreclosed houses. He had his appendix removed last week and will probably not kick again until June.

title: Iraqi Military Faces Hurdles in Its Quest to Take Charge
description: KIRKUSH BASE, Iraq, May 9  The heat of the day was just beginning as Brig. Gen. Dana J. H. Pittard greeted Lt. Gen. Ali Ghaidan Majid, commander of ground forces in Iraq, and the two boarded a helicopter for Diyala Province, one of the most violent areas of the country.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the decision by a powerful Shiite party, the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq, to drop the word revolution from its name omitted the partys new name. It is the Iraqi Islamic Supreme Council.

title: Two Kinds of Oxygen
description: Q. I am a veterinarian. The last time I went to my supplier for medical oxygen, only industrial oxygen was available. What is the difference between the two products? Does industrial oxygen have harmful contaminants? I have heard that it is sometimes recommended for emergency use in third-world countries.

title: After 5 Years, Padilla Goes on Trial in Terror Case
description: MIAMI, May 14  The trial of Jose Padilla, the American convert to Islam charged with conspiring to support terrorism, opened Monday with federal prosecutors describing what they called a calculated plan to provide money, equipment and recruits to Al Qaeda.

title: Marine Refused Staffs Advice on Iraq Deaths, Major Testifies
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 14  A Marine Corps officer testified Monday that a commander in Iraq rejected recommendations from two subordinates that he investigate accusations that marines in his battalion deliberately killed a group of civilians in Haditha in late 2005.

title: Suns See a Dirty Player Where the Spurs See a Winner
description: SAN ANTONIO, May 14  The physical evidence has been quite obvious in the Western Conference semifinals.

title: Queens Worker Injured Chasing Shoplifters
description: A Jamaica clothing store employee who tried to stop two shoplifters was struck by their vehicle as they fled, the police said. The employee, whom the police identified only as a man in his 50s, saw a man and a woman take merchandise from the store, Pretty Girl, at 162-21 Jamaica Avenue about 1:20 p.m. and chased them. When the shoplifters got into a waiting minivan, the employee grabbed a door handle but was struck as the vehicle drove off, and received a head injury, the police said. He was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was in critical condition. The police said late yesterday that no suspects had been arrested.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,382 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans yesterday:

title: Nutrition: A Cardiovascular Argument for Eating Whole Grains
description: It is hard to escape the message that whole grains are good for you. But few Americans put it into practice.

title: Posada Is One Yankee That Cant Be Replaced
description: Only four catchers in major league history have spent more games behind the plate than Tony Pea. For 18 seasons, Pea squatted behind hitters, cajoled pitchers, absorbed foul tips and collided with charging runners. He is an expert on longevity at baseballs most rigorous position.

title: Stanley Holden, 79, a Dancer and Prominent Ballet Teacher, Is Dead
description: Stanley Holden, whose Chaplinesque blend of wistfulness and wit made him one of the finest character dancers in Britains Royal Ballet before he settled in Los Angeles and became one of the areas most popular ballet teachers, died on Friday in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 79.

title: New DVDs
description: CLASSIC WESTERN ROUND-UP: VOLUME 1

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about an agreement between Russia and two Central Asian countries for a new gas pipeline to Russia rendered incorrectly a word in a quotation from Vice President Dick Cheney on a visit to Kazakhstan in 2006. He said that Russia wields its energy supplies as tools of intimidation or blackmail, not tools for intimidation and blackmail. It also misstated the timing of his visit. It was May of last year, not last summer. The article also misstated the price Russia pays Turkmenistan for gas and the price for which it resells the gas to European customers. It buys the gas for $100 per 1,000 cubic meters and resells it for $250 per 1,000 cubic meters  not $100 and $250 per cubic meter.

title: Bush Calls for Work for Higher Fuel Efficiency
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  President Bush announced on Monday that he had directed his administration to begin the long process of establishing higher fuel efficiency standards for new cars.

title: Transit Chief Plans to Ask Riders to Grade Subway and Bus Lines
description: Griping about subway service is practically a vocation for many New Yorkers. Yet it often goes hand in hand with the conviction that no matter how much they complain, no one is ever likely to listen.

title: The Pesthouse
description: An unspecified war or series of wars has dragged the world back into a harsh, preindustrial existence. In what was the United States, its cities gone and its population vastly reduced, the survivors live meagerly off the land, using the most rudimentary of tools. A crude social structure has sprung up in isolated local communities; bandits maraud through stretches of countryside; and life has been reduced to the Hobbesian state: nasty, brutish and short.

title: In Study, College-Prep Classes Left Many Unready
description: Only one-quarter of high school students who take a full set of college-preparatory courses  four years of English and three each of mathematics, science and social studies  are well prepared for college, according to a new study of last years high school graduates released today by ACT, the Iowa testing organization.

title: Cowboys Camp Is Peaceful, at Least for Now
description: IRVING, Tex., May 14  Terrell Owens stood in front of his locker on Monday  the final day of the Dallas Cowboys minicamp  and described the difference between playing for Wade Phillips, the new coach, and Bill Parcells, who rarely spoke to Owens or even mentioned him by name.

title: The Conservative Path (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Should Run Your Company After You?
description: When it comes to succession, a typical chief executive has one person in mind. Thats simply not the way to go, says Barry S. Cain, managing director for the Family Business Center at Blackman Kallick, an accounting and consulting firm.

title: Palestinian Minister Quits, as Factions Battle On
description: GAZA, May 14  The Palestinian interior minister, Hani al-Qawasmeh, resigned Monday, and four more Palestinians were killed in fierce factional gun battles.

title: Sharing Values: Who Gets to Decide? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: HPV Vaccine: Few Risks, Many Benefits
description: What is it that some parents dont understand about the HPV vaccine, licensed last summer in hopes of preventing most cases of genital warts and cervical cancer?

title: Cerberus Goes Where No Firm Has Gone Before
description: In the last year, private equity firms have broken the mold over and over again. They have bought technology and finance companies, previously thought unsuitable for buyouts. The deals have gotten bigger; the financing more creative.

title: Spring Awakening Gets 11 Tony Nominations
description: In a season rich with contenders, Spring Awakening, a dark rock musical based on a 19th century German play about sexually anguished teenagers, led the field of Tony Award nominations this morning with 11, including chances at awards for best musical, director and best actor for two of its cast.

title: Plucking at Strings
description: What will the new Large Hadron Collider at Cern have to say about string theory, the alleged theory of everything that describes nature as composed of tiny wriggling strings?

title: Three Detectives Accused in Death of Sean Bell Seek Evidence
description: Lawyers for the three detectives charged in the shooting death of Sean Bell complained yesterday that prosecutors are withholding evidence they say they are entitled to  including eyewitness accounts  that could help their clients.

title: Britain: Pearson Acquires an Educator
description: Pearson, the education publisher, agreed to buy eCollege.com for $538 million to add online degree courses in the United States. Shareholders of eCollege will receive $22.45 a share, Pearson said, an 8.9 percent premium over its closing price on Friday. ECollege, founded in 1996 and based in Chicago, works with about 180 United States colleges and universities to offer degree, certificate and diploma programs.

title: Teaching vs. Research (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paper Mill Playhouse Announces Multifeatured Plan for Survival
description: The financially floundering Paper Mill Playhouse announced a plan yesterday that it said would allow it to finish its season on schedule and continue operating next year. The plan is a mixed bag that includes administrative restructuring, a sizable bank loan and help from the government of Millburn, N.J., where the theater is situated.

title: Ghosts of Chocolate Cigars to Waft Over Hungry Minds
description: Even seasoned New Yorkers may be unfamiliar with Jersey Street. Its more alley than avenue, tucked between Mulberry and Crosby Streets like a quaint movie-set reminder of old Manhattan. But those who do know the blocks history will tell you that No. 10 was where the Hawley & Hoops candy factory churned out chocolate cigarettes and cigars starting in the late 19th century.

title: Family Holds Discussion of Dow Bid by Murdoch
description: The far-flung family that controls Dow Jones & Company met by phone yesterday to discuss a pledge by Rupert Murdoch to give them a seat on the board of his News Corporation if it buys Dow Jones, and to guard the independence of the Dow Jones trophy property, The Wall Street Journal.

title: A Bang, a Cloud, a Delay
description: There was a bang and then a cloud of dust.

title: Opposition Parties Paralyze Pakistans Financial Hub
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 14  Opposition parties shut down the southern port city of Karachi and slowed commerce in other parts of the country with a strike on Monday to protest the deaths of at least 39 people in political violence over the weekend.

title: Memo Pad
description: GRIDLOCK AHEAD? With 750 million domestic passengers expected to fly this year, the air transportation system is stretched thin, the Federal Aviation Administration said in a report. It called for increased financing for "major technology upgrades and capacity-improvement projects at major airports" to avoid what the agency said would be aviation gridlock. Last year, the F.A.A. said, airline delays were the worst in history. DELTA HELICOPTER SHUTTLE  US Helicopter, which operates helicopter shuttles with 325 flights a week to Kennedy International and Newark airports and Bridgeport, Conn., is now flying into Delta Air Lines Terminal 3 at Kennedy, rather than American Airlines Terminal 9. One-way fares for the eight-minute trip from Manhattan to Kennedy or Newark start at $159. At Newark, the shuttles land next to Continental Airlines Terminal C.

title: White House Names General to Be War Czar
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  The White House said this afternoon that President Bush ended his lengthy search for a war czar to carry out Iraq and Afghanistan policy by offering the job to an active duty three-star Army general who said in his interview that he had been skeptical of the troop buildup in Iraq.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about an agreement between Russia and two Central Asian countries for a new gas pipeline to Russia rendered incorrectly a word in a quotation from Vice President Dick Cheney on a visit to Kazakhstan in 2006. He said that Russia wields its energy supplies as tools of intimidation or blackmail, not tools for intimidation and blackmail. It also misstated the timing of his visit. It was May of last year, not last summer. The article also misstated the price Russia pays Turkmenistan for gas and the price for which it resells the gas to European customers. It buys the gas for $100 per 1,000 cubic meters and resells it for $250 per 1,000 cubic meters  not $100 and $250 per cubic meter. (Go to Article)

title: Patterns: Moderate Drinking May Ease Effects of Bad Cholesterol
description: Researchers have long known that people who drink moderate amounts of alcohol appear to be less likely to develop heart disease. Much of the benefit has been attributed to the higher levels of HDL cholesterol  often referred to as the good cholesterol  found in moderate drinkers. The lipoproteins in this kind of cholesterol are believed to help the body fight off heart disease.

title: NBC, Tired of Last Place, Turns to Sci-Fi and Fantasy
description: NBC, in a slump and eager to regain its winning ways, is hoping to attract advertisers and viewers with a fall schedule that plays it safe by trying to learn from recent mistakes and build on recent strengths.

title: Landis Takes Doping Case to Court, Hoping to Keep Title
description: MALIBU, Calif., May 14  The hearing that will determine whether Floyd Landis keeps his 2006 Tour de France title started Monday with legal maneuvering, dense scientific testimony and an unusual photo for the family album.

title: Friend or Faux?
description: Dreux, France

title: Creator of Big Brother and Deal or No Deal Is Being Sold
description: LONDON, May 14  A group of investors led by John de Mol, one of the founders of Endemol, which pioneered reality television series like Big Brother and game shows like Deal or No Deal, agreed Monday to buy a controlling stake in the company from Telefnica, the Spanish telecommunications company.

title: Japan to Vote on Modifying Pacifist Charter Written by U.S.
description: TOKYO, May 14  The Japanese Parliament passed a bill on Monday calling for a national referendum on amendments to the countrys pacifist Constitution.

title: Doctors Who Wield the Pen to Heal the Profession
description: Like the racket of dozens of birds on a clothesline, the sound of doctors is filling the air.

title: Rock Star Still Hasnt Found the African Aid Hes Looking For
description: With less than a month to go before the leaders of the Group of 8 nations gather at a Baltic Sea resort in Germany for their annual summit meeting, Bono, the rock star and antipoverty campaigner who helped sweet-talk, cajole and otherwise persuade them to make commitments to double aid to Africa, says most of them have fallen behind on their promise.

title: Writes Thrillers, Flies a Cessna
description: I GREW up in Buffalo, and my dad used to take me out to the airport to watch the planes. I knew then that someday I was going to learn to fly. Im a former United States Air Force captain. There are a lot of great things about the service, but one of the best is that you can take flying lessons pretty inexpensively with the Air Force-supervised civilian-run aero clubs on base. I took my first lesson in high school, but really learned to fly from these guys.

title: A Chief With Union Roots Enters a Proving Ground
description: He comes from a long line of unionized autoworkers, but Thomas W. LaSordas collar is unmistakably white.

title: Mexico: Chief of Drug Intelligence Shot and Killed
description: Gunmen killed Jos Nemesio Lugo, a veteran government intelligence officer and the new chief of the National Center for Analysis, Planning and Information to Combat Crime, a unit of the attorney generals office that gathers and analyzes intelligence on organized criminal organizations, including drug traffickers. He was appointed to the post just a month ago.

title: Pentagon Blocks 13 Web Sites From Military Computers
description: Members of the military will not be allowed to use military computers to communicate through Web sites like YouTube and MySpace under restrictions that the Pentagon imposed yesterday.

title: Deaths and Fraud Reports Mar Philippine Vote
description: MANILA, May 14  Voters went to the polls in the Philippines on Monday to elect their senators, representatives and local officials, amid reports of election-related violence and allegations of fraud.

title: Texas: 4 Suspended in Youth Agency Scandal
description: Superintendents of four detention centers of the troubled Texas Youth Commission have been suspended with pay pending investigations. The suspensions, on charges of failing to report a sexual assault, inappropriate use of state resources, mistreatment and interfering with reporting or investigating incidents, involve centers in Edinburg, Harlingen, Crockett and Roanoke. The latest actions bring to 93 the number of agency employees disciplined since accusations of a cover-up of sexual abuse of juveniles by staff members and other inmates. Earlier, 8 employees were arrested and 81 were dismissed or are in process of termination.

title: Uzbekistan: Europe Eases Sanctions
description: European Union foreign ministers meeting in Brussels removed four names from a list of 12 high-ranking Uzbek officials who have been denied visas as a part of the sanctions imposed on Uzbekistan after the government violently crushed an uprising in the city of Andijon in 2005. An arms embargo remains in effect.

title: How a Vast Ice Sheet Put the Squeeze on Earth (and Its Gravity)
description: To use a very unscientific term, the earth is squishable. Put a heavy weight on it and the crust will deform. Remove the weight and the crust will rebound.

title: Trenton: Increased Penalties for Gas Price Gouging
description: A bill to increase penalties for gasoline price gouging unanimously passed the Assembly Transportation Committee yesterday. The measure, which has passed the Senate, increases fines for a first violation to $1,500 from $50 and for subsequent violations to $3,000 from $200. The previous fines were set nearly 70 years ago. The measure grew out of a rash of violations after Hurricane Katrina, which disrupted oil industry operations in the Gulf of Mexico, sent gasoline prices soaring in 2005. The measure will now go to the full Assembly.

title: A New York Institution Gets a Network Reprieve
description: The honchos at NBC Universal made it official yesterday, announcing that they were not consigning a well-known New York institution to the dustbin of history.

title: A Human Capital Agenda
description: In 1998, the Republican Party was in disarray. G.O.P. Train Careens Out of Control, was the headline on one George Will column. The folks at National Review surveyed the wreckage of the Republican Revolution and asked, What Went Wrong?

title: Justices Vote in Death Case Is Close Again, but Differing
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  For the fourth time in a row, the Supreme Court on Monday decided a death penalty case by a vote of 5 to 4. But this time, contrary to the courts overturning of three Texas death sentences last month, a narrow majority went the other way and reinstated the death sentence of an Arizona man who argued that his lawyer had failed to discover or present crucial evidence that could have persuaded the jury to spare his life.

title: Kazakhstan: Mass Deaths of Seals Linked to Virus
description: The government said distemper appeared to be a cause in the wave of deaths of seals this spring in the Caspian Sea. At least 933 dead seals have washed ashore in Kazakhstan in recent weeks, most of them pups. The deaths have raised concerns about seals in the sea, which contains extensive industrial pollution and is a major transit route for oil and the site of a network of oil-pumping platforms. Laboratory tests confirmed the presence of the distemper virus, the Environmental Protection Ministry announced, according to the Russian news agency Interfax. Environmentalists have warned for years that exposure to oil and heavy metals in the sea had weakened the seals immune systems.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Saturday about the economic historian Alfred D. Chandler Jr. misspelled part of the name of the place of residence of his daughter Mary (Mimi) Chandler Watt. It is Dinas Powys, Wales, not Dina.

title: U. of Texas Fires Officer Over Tie to Loan Company
description: The University of Texas fired the director of financial aid at its Austin campus for improper conduct yesterday, reporting that he had more ties to a student loan company than had been known and had begun recommending the lender to students a few months after he bought stock in its parent company.

title: Barely in Office, but G.O.P. Rivals Are Circling
description: MILFORD, N.Y.  The furniture has yet to arrive for one of the offices that Kirsten Gillibrand, a freshman Democrat in Congress, recently opened here. But the list of Republicans angling to challenge her next year is already growing.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the arrest of two Rutgers University seniors on burglary charges referred incorrectly to their campus. It is the Livingston campus, and it is in Piscataway, N.J.  not in Livingston.

title: Chrysler Workers Surprised After Union Backs Sale
description: WARREN, Mich., May 14  Chrysler workers were warned a few weeks ago by union officials that a private equity owner would be the worst thing that could happen to them. So many were as surprised as anyone Monday to learn that the sale of Chrysler to Cerberus Capital Management had their leaders support.

title: Bombing Kills at Least 22 in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, May 15  Twenty-two people were killed and 30 wounded here today when a suicide bomber struck a crowded restaurant in a busy part of the old city, police and hospital officials said.

title: The New French Presidents Roots Are Worth Remembering
description: ALATTYAN, Hungary

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption last Tuesday with an article about disciplinary action against Los Angeles police officials after a clash at an immigration rally referred incompletely to a scene at the rally, where officers used force to break up the crowd. The man pictured on his knees with police officers standing over him was a photographer for KCAL-TV in Los Angeles, Carl Stein  not one of the people who the police said had tried to provoke them.

title: Intellectual Property Is on the Block at a German Auctioneer
description: BERLIN, May 13  Webasto, an auto parts maker based in a Munich suburb, has spent millions over the last decade negotiating licenses for its products to automakers like Mercedes-Benz, Volvo, Opel, Volkswagen and Audi.

title: Chrysler Group to Be Sold for $7.4 Billion
description: STUTTGART, Germany, May 14  DaimlerChrysler announced today that it will sell a controlling interest in its struggling Chrysler Group to Cerberus Capital Management, a private equity firm that specializes in restructuring troubled companies, for $7.4 billion, mostly in the form of capital that Cerberus will put into Chrysler.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about Patina du Preys Memorial Dress, 1993-2007, at Artists Space in Soho, misidentified the Artists Space Web site. It is artistsspace.org.

title: Case Highlights Sex Abuse at Church, Beyond Priests
description: Beginning in sixth grade and lasting several years, Claudia Vercellotti said she was sexually abused repeatedly by the chief of youth ministries for the 19-county Roman Catholic Diocese in Toledo, Ohio. She said she later found four others who said they were victimized by the same man, although he denied wrongdoing.

title: Delgado Caps Mets Rally With Walk in the Ninth
description: It was one of those delightfully far-fetched situations that, considering the moment, did not seem all that bizarre. With the score tied and two on and two out in the bottom of the ninth inning, the Chicago Cubs intentionally walked Carlos Beltrn to pitch to ... Carlos Delgado?

title: Strapping on the Toe Shoes to Push at Ballets Borders
description: Deborah Lohses Lucy Poems is an example of a phenomenon that crops up every now and again: someone has the worthy thought that he or she will make ballet look contemporary. The most successful practitioner of this genre is Karole Armitage, whose Drastic Classicism  frenzied ballet to an ear-splitting rock score  shocked and thrilled audiences in 1981. (Twyla Tharp and William Forsythe had used rock music for ballet companies well before that, but their subject was not primarily how classical dance inhabits the modern world.)

title: A Giant Takes On Physics Biggest Questions
description: 300 FEET BELOW MEYRIN, Switzerland  The first thing that gets you is the noise.

title: As Demand for Donor Eggs Soars, High Prices Stir Ethical Concerns
description: Samantha Carolan was 23 and fresh out of graduate school when she decided to donate eggs to an infertile couple. Ms. Carolan concedes that she would never have done it if not for the money, $7,000 that she used to pay off some student loans.

title: Ceridian Executive Is Fired
description: The Ceridian Corporation said yesterday that it had fired a top executive, accusing him of disclosing confidential information to Pershing Square Capital Management, a hedge fund that is trying to oust the companys board.

title: Testimony About Delusions With Cosmic Proportions
description: To the prosecution, it was a sinister crime that a troubled but calculating man committed against one terrified woman. But to a defense psychologist, Peter Braunsteins attack on a former colleague in the fashion press was a symbolic attack on the hypocrisy of the fashion industry and of American society.

title: U.S. Tries to Stem Afghan Opium Trade, Belatedly
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a walled compound outside Kabul, two members of Colombias counternarcotics police force are trying to teach raw Afghan recruits how to wage close-quarters combat.

title: Uncle Sam Has His Eye on You: Government Surveillance Today
description: Something about being in government or law enforcement must bring out the Peeping Tom in people. Every couple of decades the amount of Big Brothering being practiced in the United States  by J. Edgar Hoover, for instance, or the Watergate crowd  bubbles to the surface. And once the furor has subsided, we are left with the uneasy sense that such shenanigans are probably the rule rather than the exception.

title: Port Authority Plans to Study Cashless Tolls
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will consider in a few weeks a proposal to remove all toll booths on the bridges and tunnels it operates to reduce traffic and usher in a new pricing system, the authoritys executive director, Anthony E. Shorris, said today.

title: U.S.-Russia Bond Is Far Better Than Before, Rice Says
description: MOSCOW, May 14  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Monday that while Russia and the United States were going through a period of uneasy relations, the problems fell far short of those of the cold war and that the two countries continued to cooperate in a number of important areas.

description: To the Editor:

title: Chicago Is Piniellas Kind of Town
description: Before Lou Piniella left home for spring training in February, he had lunch with an old friend.

title: Red Cross Report Says Israel Disregards Humanitarian Law
description: JERUSALEM, May 14  The International Committee of the Red Cross, in a confidential report about East Jerusalem and its surrounding areas, accuses Israel of a general disregard for its obligations under international humanitarian law  and the law of occupation in particular.

title: Bear Stearns Will Write Down $225 Million
description: Bear Stearns, the securities firm, will write down $225 million in the value of its specialist business as the switch to automated trading at the New York Stock Exchange reduces the need for floor traders.

title: William Becker, 85, Creator of Concept of Motel 6 Chain, Dies
description: William Becker, who after enduring rundown, though not particularly cheap, motel rooms on a cross-country trip in 1960 got the idea for the Motel 6 chain, charging $6 a night for a spare but clean room, died April 2 at his ranch outside Kingman, Ariz. He was 85.

title: Inspectors Cite Big Gain by Iran on Nuclear Fuel
description: VIENNA, May 14  Inspectors for the International Atomic Energy Agency have concluded that Iran appears to have solved most of its technological problems and is now beginning to enrich uranium on a far larger scale than before, according to the agencys top officials.

title: Bob Barker, 50 (on TV), Is to Be in Two Specials
description: LOS ANGELES, May 13  When Bob Barker got out of the Navy at the end of World War II, he thought about becoming a flight instructor. But he had heard about an opening at a radio station and thought it sounded interesting. He had also heard that the station manager liked airplanes.

title: Banks Report Says Wolfowitz Violated Ethics
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  A World Bank committee charged Monday that Paul D. Wolfowitz violated ethical and governance rules as bank president by showing favoritism to his companion in 2005. In response, the Bush administration mounted a last-ditch global campaign to save Mr. Wolfowitz from being ousted from office.

description: To the Editor:

title: Gonzales Pressed Ailing Ashcroft on Spy Plan, Aide Says
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  On the night of March 10, 2004, a high-ranking Justice Department official rushed to a Washington hospital to prevent two White House aides from taking advantage of the critically ill Attorney General, John Ashcroft, the official testified today.

title: 2 Suspended for School Prank That Scared Pupils in Tennessee
description: MURFREESBORO, Tenn., May 14  A teacher and an assistant principal were suspended Monday for a prank in which sixth graders on a sleepover trip were told that a gunman was prowling nearby and were ordered to hide in silence.

title: Now, Parents in Boerum Hill Raise Objections to an Arabic School
description: The Department of Education stood on the firing line last night at a contentious PTA meeting attended by more than 100 Brooklyn parents whose schools are set to share space with the Khalil Gibran International Academy, a new dual-language school that will teach Arabic language and culture.

title: Details Emerge on Battles With Law by Millers Cousin
description: FRANCONIA, N.H., May 14  Liko Kenney, a cousin of the champion ski racer Bode Miller, had at least two confrontations in 2003 with Bruce McKay, the local police officer he killed Friday night in a shooting that left both men dead.
