description: THE FACTS

title: House Democrats Set to Move on New Fund-Raising Rules
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  House Democratic leaders, against stiff resistance in their caucus, have decided to advance a measure to require federal lobbyists to disclose the campaign contributions they collect and bundle for federal political candidates, officials involved in their deliberations said.

title: Utah: Voters Will Decide on Voucher Program
description: State voters will decide in November the future of the nations first statewide school voucher program, which would provide families with $500 to $3,000 per child for private school tuition. The Legislature narrowly adopted the program in February. Opponents, including teachers unions, the National PTA and the N.A.A.C.P., said the program would harm public schools and gathered more than 124,000 signatures to force Utahs first referendum since 1974. Gov. Jon Huntsman Jr., a Republican who initially recommended combining the referendum vote with the primary election on Feb. 5 to save money, signed an executive order last week setting the vote for Nov. 6. The governor has asked legislators to provide money to help local governments pay for the election.

title: Charities Settle Dispute on Split of Surprise Gift
description: A dispute over a $264 million trust that pitted the Salvation Army against Greenpeace was settled last week.

title: After Ordnance Scare, Beachgoers Told to Dig With Care
description: SURF CITY, N.J., May 14  Sun worshipers coming to this Jersey Shore town should be happy that the closed beaches will soon be reopening. But they might want to rethink what they bring.

title: Movement With and Against Music, but Bracingly
description: The Divine Sarah is what they used to call Sarah Bernhardt. The Divine Sara is what some New York dancegoers began to call Sara Rudner in the 1970s. Ms Rudner is one of those rare artists who embody the art form they practice: a born dancer, sensuous and infinitely expressive, with a fluent body gifted in feats of multiple coordination, intense focus and effortless control over long, complex phrases of movement. To borrow the brilliant title of the dance historian Sally Baness definitive history of the New York 1960s generation of experimentalists, Ms. Rudner is Terpsichore in sneakers.

title: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
description: ST. LOUIS, May 14  Miles and miles of bigger and stronger levees have been built along the Missouri and Mississippi Rivers since the deadly floods of 1993, and millions of dollars have been spent on drainage improvements.

title: U.N. Official Says Hes Been Denied Access to U.S. Immigrant Jails
description: A United Nations human rights official said he was barred from visiting an immigration detention center in New Jersey yesterday. It was the second time he was denied access to an American immigration jail on a weeklong monitoring tour.

title: Poor Shooting Night Puts Nets Backs to the Wall
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 14  Vince Carter had the ball in his hands, a roaring crowd on its feet and, it seemed, an entire franchise on edge.

title: An Amputee Sprinter: Is He Disabled or Too-Abled?
description: MANCHESTER, England, May 14  As Oscar Pistorius of South Africa crouched in the starting blocks for the 200 meters on Sunday, the small crowd turned its attention to the sprinter who calls himself the fastest man on no legs.

title: States Fault MySpace on Predator Issues
description: Some of the countrys top law enforcement officials are charging that the online social network MySpace has discovered thousands of known sex offenders using its service, but has failed to act on the information.

title: A Scholar of the Master Distills Beethovens Details
description: When considering an intersection of the pianist Charles Rosen with the late piano music of Beethoven, an old clich comes to mind: Mr. Rosen has forgotten more about Beethoven than most people will ever know. The temptation to use that expression is best avoided. Mr. Rosens 80th-birthday recital at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday afternoon, in which he played Beethovens last three sonatas, made it clear that he has forgotten nothing.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A music review and a picture caption yesterday about the pianist Maurizio Pollini, at Carnegie Hall, misstated the date of the recital. It was Saturday, not Friday.

title: Cable Operators Score Points in Battle With N.F.L.
description: Its been a long time since anyone viewed the National Football League as marginal in any way. Market muscle and viewership explain why the N.F.L. gets more television money than any other league and why the NFL Network was conceived as having nearly limitless appeal.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A television review last Tuesday about When Kids Get Life, a Frontline documentary on PBS, misstated the number of times the voice of the filmmaker, Ofra Bikel, can be heard in the documentary. It is several times, not just in one scene.

title: Oracle Falls as Challenger Semifinals Open
description: VALENCIA, Spain, May 14 (AP)  Emirates Team New Zealand and the Italian boat Luna Rossa earned victories Monday in the first of the Louis Vuitton Cup semifinal races. The semifinals are best-of-nine series.

title: Nash Shows Some Fire, and Suns Show Some Life
description: SAN ANTONIO, May 14  All night, Steve Nash played with his eyes peering out from behind his bandaged nose as he furiously tried to lift his Phoenix Suns from behind and into a tie in their series with the San Antonio Spurs.

title: An Example of the Soft Sell
description: It is not often that consumers want marketers to waffle. When it comes to treats, though, they certainly seem to, if you consider the success of chains like Cold Stone Creamery and MaggieMoos, which sell ice cream in waffle cones and bowls.

title: Trenton: Agency Approves 1 Billion for Tunnel
description: The North Jersey Transportation Planning Authority yesterday approved a proposal by Gov. Jon S. Corzine to spend $1 billion in federal highway funds over 10 years on a new commuter rail tunnel under the Hudson River. The tunnel is expected to cost $7.5 billion to build, and officials have raised $3 billion of that, including the funds approved yesterday. Supporters say the tunnel will double rail capacity between New York City and New Jersey and will reduce highway congestion. New Jersey will also apply for funds from the Federal Transit Administration for the project. Construction of the two-track tunnel is expected to begin in 2009 and end in 2016. To make up for the diverted federal highway funds, New Jersey will use $1 billion from its Transportation Trust Fund on state road work.

title: Prestigious Private Schools Settle Rights Suit by a Non-Hawaiian
description: The private Kamehameha Schools in Hawaii announced yesterday that they had settled a civil rights lawsuit brought against them by a student denied admission because he did not possess Hawaiian ancestry. The settlement avoided the possibility of a decision by the United States Supreme Court on the status of Native Hawaiians.

title: Satellites Show Harvest of Mud That Trawlers Leave Behind
description: Scientists have known for years that when fishing trawlers drag nets and gear across the ocean bottom they trap or kill almost all the fish, mollusks and other creatures they encounter. And the dragging destroys underwater features like reefs, turning the bottom to mud.

title: 2 Former Siemens Officials Convicted for Bribery
description: A German court convicted two former Siemens executives of bribery yesterday and ordered the company to pay a fine of 38 million euros ($51.4 million), the first verdict in a widening corruption scandal that has engulfed the German engineering and electronics giant.

title: Kate Webb, War Correspondent, Dies at 64
description: Kate Webb, a brave, no-nonsense correspondent during the Vietnam War who was erroneously reported to have been captured, killed and cremated in Cambodia  only to emerge from the jungle alive died on Sunday in Sydney, Australia. She was 64.

title: Hotel as Lifestyle
description: What Starbucks did for coffee and JetBlue did for air travel, a growing number of new hotel brands is trying to do for the overnight stay: create an experience that offers something different from the status quo, then replicate it around the globe.

title: Turkish City Counters Fear of Islams Reach
description: KONYA, Turkey, May 12  In the not too distant past here in Turkeys religious heartland, women would not appear in public unless they were modestly dressed, a single woman was not able to rent an apartment on her own, and the mayor proposed segregating city buses by sex.

title: Cameras in the Courts
description: Anybody who has been in a working courtroom knows that a real trial is a long way from Law & Order. But even though trials are often dry, unglamorous events, they are so vested in public interest that the founders required that they be open to the public. Today, the best way to give the public access is to allow court proceedings to be televised. New York has been among the slowest states to allow cameras in, but that could be about to change.

title: A Vibrant Vucciria
description: Every day but Sunday, Palermo's Vucciria market fills with fishermen, shopkeepers and merchants who have come to peddle their goods.

title: Bit of advice
description: For those seeking property in a crazy city like London, where someone told me there are 100 buyers for every house on the market, heres a bit of advice from Cliff Gardiner, head of London buying for professional home-buying service The Buying Solution:

title: 36 Hours in Baltimore
description: A harbor makeover, Colonial history and emerging art galleries give the city reasons for out-of-towners to visit.

title: For Sale: Designer House
description: Christies will offer a small aluminum-paneled house built in 1951 by French designer Jean Prouv.

title: The New Atlantic City
description: With its combination of casinos, beaches, upscale shopping and fine dining, Atlantic City has one of the hottest real estate markets on the Jersey Shore.

title: Greener Acres
description: When it comes to designing buildings that are good for the environment, Europe gets it.

title: Pearson Acquires an Educator
description: Pearson, the education publisher, agreed to buy eCollege.com for $538 million to add online degree courses in the United States. Shareholders of eCollege will receive $22.45 a share, Pearson said, an 8.9 percent premium over its closing price on Friday. ECollege, founded in 1996 and based in Chicago, works with about 180 United States colleges and universities to offer degree, certificate and diploma programs.

title: Regulators Expand Biovail Inquiry
description: Biovail, a Canadian drug maker, said regulators in the United States had expanded their investigation into questionable accounting and possibly misleading financial disclosures. The company said it had received a so-called Wells notice from the Securities and Exchange Commission relating to its 2003 accounting, a 2002 acquisition, and how it accounts for revenue.

title: Cardinal Health Acquires Device Maker
description: The medical products and services company Cardinal Health said on Monday that it would buy the medical technology company Viasys Healthcare for $1.42 billion, an acquisition that would help Cardinal expand in international markets.

title: Swiss Investigating BAE in Money Laundering Case
description: Law enforcement authorities in Switzerland confirmed Monday that they had opened a criminal investigation into possible money laundering at BAE Systems, adding to the international scrutiny of the company, the top British military contractor.

title: G.E. Kicks Off Soccer Partnership
description: General Electric said that its commercial finance division has teamed up with Hermes Sports Partners, a sports finance advisory boutique in London, to help finance soccer club buyouts and other deals related to the sport. G.E. has already helped the Texas oil magnate Malcolm Glazer finance his 790 million pound ($1.6 billion) acquisition in 2005 of Manchester United.

title: Continental Resources I.P.O. Prices Below Expected Range
description: Continental Resources, an oil and natural gas exploration and production company, priced its initial public offering late Monday at $15 per share, below the expected range of $16 to $18. The company sold 8.85 million new shares and Harold G. Hamm, its chairman, sold 20.65 million of his shares in the offering, according to the prospectus.

title: Conrad Blacks Wife Accused of Stealing Chandeliers
description: As her husband, Conrad Black, stands accused of stealing millions from the publishing company Hollinger International at a fraud trial under way in Chicago, Barbara Amiel is having some legal trouble of her own.

title: Ex-Merrill Executives Enron Appeal Is Denied
description: A former executive at Merrill Lynch whose Enron-related fraud and conspiracy convictions were overturned last year by an appeals panel will remain a felon on two other counts. On Monday, the Supreme Court declined, without comment, to review the 2004 convictions of perjury and obstruction of justice in a jury trial against the executive, James Brown.

title: Xstrata Raises Bid for LionOre
description: Xstrata, a Swiss mining company, increased a cash offer for LionOre Mining International by 35 percent, to 6.2 billion Canadian dollars ($5.6 billion), to top a bid from Russias Norilsk Nickel.

title: Jott.com Gets First Taste of Funding
description: Jott.com, a phone-in service that converts voice messages into text messages that can be e-mailed, said it had raised $5.4 million in its first equity financing. The company, founded last year by John Pollard and Shree Madhavapeddi, said the round was led by Bain Capital Ventures.

title: Latin Americas eBay Says Hola to Nasdaq
description: Investors will get a chance to bid on a Latin American online auctioneer, MercadoLibre, after the company, which is backed by eBay, filed to raise as much as $100 million in a proposed initial public offering.

title: Another Tough Day in Court for Former Black Lieutenant
description: Former Chicago Sun-Times Publisher and Hollinger International President F. David Radler spent a third day fending off harsh questions and assertions that he is a liar, as his cross-examination in the criminal fraud trial of ousted Hollinger Chief Executive Conrad Black continued Monday.

title: One Misstep and Theyre Out the Door
description: Misbehaving executives, take note: before you have your day in court, you may already be out of a job.

title: Buyout Battle for EGL Rages On
description: The battle for EGL continued over the weekend, with a company backed by Apollo Management offering $1.95 billion, or $46 a share, Saturday, to top a sweetened management-led buyout proposal for the company.

title: Private Equity Can Go Anyplace
description: Chip makers. Student lenders. Giant regulated utilities. In the last year or so, private equity firms have repeatedly broken the mold, acquiring companies previously thought unsuitable for buyouts. And on Monday, they moved into virtually uncharted territory again, as Cerberus Capital Management agreed to take a majority stake in Chrysler, marking the first time an investment firm has sought control of a Detroit automaker.

title: Swedish Green Tech: Silicon Valleys Next Big Thing?
description: On a recent trip to Silicon Valley, Michael Wood, the United States ambassador to Sweden, pitched 30 Swedish green tech companies to 18 venture capitalists during a meeting at Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: IAC In Deal for Front Line Stake, Report Says
description: In a bid to expand its already-considerable influence in the live-music industry, Ticketmasters parent, IAC/InterActiveCorp, is acquiring a significant stake in one of the biggest artist-representation businesses, Front Line Management, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Pershing Square Battles With Ceridian Over Fired Executive
description: A battle for control of Ceridian is heating up between the companys management and Pershing Square Capital, an activist hedge fund that owns 14.2 percent of the provider of payroll and human resources services.

title: Forget Wall Street: Bankers Head to Moscow for Big Pay
description: In Moscow, within a mile of the tomb of Vladimir Lenin, who vowed to destroy capitalists, investment bankers are now earning double the pay of their counterparts anywhere else. Deal makers from banks like UBS and Lehman Brothers are now commonly offered between $7 million and $10 million a year in Moscow, industry recruiters said.

title: British Lobbying Group Defends Private Equity
description: Despite recent slamming by public shareholders, labor unions and lawmakers, it seems that private equity still has one ally.

title: HSBC USA Reports Lower Profit
description: HSBC USA, a unit of British bank HSBC Holdings, said on Monday profit fell 11 percent in the first quarter, hurt by rising credit losses. Net income for the New York-based unit fell to $273 million from $308 million, HSBC USA said in its quarterly report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: HeidelbergCement to Buy British Rival for $15.8 Billion
description: Germanys HeidelbergCement said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy a British rival, Hanson, for 8 billion pounds ($15.8 billion) in a deal that will create the worlds second-largest construction materials group.

title: Societe Generale Denies Imminent Deal
description: The chief executive of Socit Gnrale, the French bank that has been at the center of takeover speculation for weeks, denied Monday any immediate plans for a merger. But he left the door open for a future deal as banks in Europe look to consolidate across borders.

title: Bear Stearns Will Write Down $225 Million
description: Bear Stearns will write down $225 million in the value of its specialist business as the switch to automated trading at the New York Stock Exchange reduces the need for floor traders.

title: Bancrofts Hold Discussion of Revised Bid by Murdoch
description: The far-flung family that controls Dow Jones & Company met by phone on Monday to discuss a pledge by Rupert Murdoch to give them a seat on the board of his News Corporation if it buys Dow Jones and to guard the independence of the Dow Jones trophy property, The Wall Street Journal.

title: Another Couples Sweet Nothings Lead to Insider Trading Charges
description: In the latest crackdown on illicit pillow talk, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday accused a former Oracle vice president of improperly profiting from his wifes knowledge about two deals engineered by her boss, Oracles chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison.

title: Carlyle Confirms Its Next Fund Will Be Publicly Traded
description: The Carlyle Group confirmed Monday that it would offer shares of an affiliate, Carlyle Capital Corporation Limitedm on Euronext Amsterdam in the second or third quarter of the year. Carlyle Capital is seeking to raise $400 million in the offering, giving the private equity shops affiliate a total capitalization of about $1 billion following the listing, the buyout shop said.

title: Thomson and Reuters Agree to $17 Billion Merger
description: Reuters Group and the Thomson Corporation said Tuesday that they had agreed to a $17.2 billion combination that will create one of the worlds largest financial news providers. The announcement came less than two weeks after the two companies said they were in talks about a possible merger. The deal is not without obstacles, however. Antitrust regulators, and especially those in the European Union, are likely to take a close look at the transaction and its effects on competition. An analyst in London told Bloomberg News there was a 75 percent chance the deal would go through.

title: Tyco to Pay Nearly $3 Billion to Settle Lawsuits
description: Tyco International agreed on Tuesday to pay $2.98 billion to settle investors lawsuits accusing the company of artificially inflating revenue, a move that helps clear the way for the firm to split into three companies. The agreement will resolve securities-fraud suits alleging that the company overstated its income by more than $5 billion under its former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski.

title: Evercore Says Adjusted Income Doubled
description: Evercore Partners said Tuesday that its net income fell 84 percent to $4.2 million in the first quarter. But after factoring in the effects of last years initial public offering and other accounting adjustments, Evercores profit more than doubled from a year earlier to $16 million, lifted by strength in its merger advisory business, the investment bank said.

title: 2008: G.O.P. Rumble in Columbia
description: Republican candidates gather tonight in Columbia, S.C. for their second debate. Sponsored by the states Republican party and  Fox News, the event can be seen on the network at 9 p.m. On FoxNews.com, the networks Griff Jenkins will talk with students from the University of South Carolina before, during and after the debate.

title: The Future of New Yorks Past
description: A walk through Lower Manhattan yields scant evidence of the 17th century Dutch and English settlements. Many of the buildings now seen as timeless masterpieces, like the Flatiron Building (1902) and Grand Central Terminal (1903), are very young by Old World standards. In a city where change is the only constant, is there sufficient respect for the past?

title: Hagel-Bloomberg: A Threat to Which Party?
description: While Barack Obamas TV appearance got the most attention over the weekend, Republican Senator Chuck Hagel may have made the most interesting splash, telling Face the Nation that he is interested in a third-party run for president, likely paired with Mayor Mike Bloomberg: Its a great country to think about  a New York boy and a Nebraska boy to be teamed up leading this nation.The conservative blogger John Hinderaker at Power Line doesnt find this to be much of threat to the G.O.P., however: Maybe people at NPR are yearning for a candidate like Hagel; I know some Republicans who are yearning for a new candidate, but it isnt Hagel: its Fred Thompson or Newt Gingrich.Which brings us to the question: if Hagel runs, will he hurt the Republican candidate, or the Democrat? I find the suggestion that Hagels run would hurt a Republican presidential candidate, which Ive seen in a couple of places, rather ludicrous. Hagel is widely despised within the party, and the last poll I saw had him at 1% among Republicans. My guess is that a large majority of those yearning for a Hagel candidacy would otherwise vote for the Democrat.

title: Ches Fans in Iraq
description: Che Guevara may not live, as one of the latest installments in his T-shirt line claims, but he still has fans leading South American nations, and now, starting insurgent groups in Iraq.

title: Charming Cape May
description: Cape May, N.J., offers families a traditional Jersey shore experience, restored Victorian homes and ample outdoor recreation.

title: Seattle's Mix Master
description: For the design guru Brian Balmert, Seattle is equal parts laid-back and luxe.

title: Point Pleasant Beach
description: A destination for family-friendly seaside recreation, Point Pleasant Beach is located at the top of the Intercoastal Waterway in Ocean County, N.J.

title: Ingersoll-Rand May Sell Bobcat Unit
description: Ingersoll-Rand, the industrial conglomerate, said on Tuesday that it is exploring strategic alternatives for its Bobcat farm equipment and construction units, including a possible sale or spinoff. The move was announced alongside an expansion of the companys share-repurchase plan to $4 billion from $2 billion.

title: Yahoo Hires Thomas Weisel Co-founder as Finance Chief
description: Even as rumors swirl that Yahoo might be heading for some kind of deal with Microsoft, the Internet giant has picked a technology deal maker as its next chief financial officer. Yahoo announced Tuesday that it had hired Blake J. Jorgensen, a co-founder of the technology-focused investment bank Thomas Weisel Partners, as its finance chief. He will succeed Susan L. Decker, who took control of the companys advertising operations in December amid mounting competition from its archrival Google.

title: Paris  Travel Basics
description: THE AIRPORT: Jet-lagged visitors may not notice, but Charles de Gaulle International Airport  familiarly known as Roissy for the nearby town - was explicitly conceived as an architectural entry point to France.

title: Greek Islands for 20-somethings
description: My daughter and 3 female friends (22-23 years old) would like to spend aweek in the Greek islands this summer. They would like to take a boat from Athens and return there. They would like to meet other young peoplebut also enjoy the history and culture.

title: Discovering Modern Marvels
description: Last Thursday, I served as one of the judges for the Modern Marvels Invent Now Challenge.

title: $600,000 Homes
description: A two-bedroom condo in Boston, a house on Wisconsin's Door County Peninsula and a two-bedroom stucco home in Taos, N.M.

title: From Behind the Scenes to Behind the Wheel
description: As the business world continues to examine every nook and cranny of the $7.4 billion acquisition of Chrysler, many are wondering about the driving force behind the deal: Cerberus Capital Management. The hedge fund and private equity firm has many reputations, including that of hard-charging negotiator and behind-the-scenes operator, loath to step into the spotlight. Both qualities could be said to apply to Cerberuss founder, Stephen A. Feinberg, a Drexel Burnham Lambert alumnus, Princeton graduate and former Army paratrooper.

title: Republican Presidential Debate in South Carolina
description: The following is a transcript of the Republican presidential primary debate at the University of South Carolina on May 15, 2007, as recorded by the Federal News Service:

title: Tony Nominations: Plays
description: A look at the 2007 Tony Award nominations for best play and best revival of a play.

title: Bangkok  Travel Basics
description: AIRPORTS: For years flying into Thailand meant stepping into the charmless, somewhat crusty hallways of Don Muang airport. It was a quick and dirty experience but surprisingly efficient. Now things are more complicated. If youre on an international flight youre likely to arrive at the sprawling new airport, Suvarnabhumi (airport code BKK), which is east of the city. Don Muang carries the airport code DMK and is used mainly for domestic flights. Study your tickets carefully, especially if youre changing planes (it takes at least an hour to travel between airports). Heres the most important thing to know about Suvarnabhumi: its pronounced Sawana-phoom. If you pronounce it the way its spelled, no one will understand you. Peak time for international flights at Suvarnabhumi is the evening. Check-in lines, especially for Thai Airways, which now uses the single check-in line system, can be very long. This system apparently saves Thai Airways money, but at peak times you can wait an hour or longer.

title: Tony Nominations: Musicals
description: Photos of the 2007 Tony Award nominees for best musical and best revival of a musical.

title: Rome  Travel Basics
description: The Colosseum. (The Associated Press)

title: A Normandy Dream Home
description: 18th-century Chteau de Livry in Normandy.

title: South Americas Next Big Thing
description: Cartagena has beaches, architecture and never sleeps.

title: The Tonys: Spring Awakening Leads the Field
description: In a season rich with contenders, Spring Awakening, a dark rock musical, led the field of Tony nominations.

title: Hong Kong  Travel Basics
description: THE AIRPORT: The Hong Kong International Airport, also known as Chek Lap Kok, (www.hongkongairport.com) is organized and fast, with clear English signage. On good days, Ive made it from plane to taxi in less than half an hour. (Tip: Though others say the exchange rate is better in town, I usually do the most convenient thing and change my money right after leaving customs). Facilities, including toilets, are wheelchair-friendly, and there are services for the hearing- or seeing-impaired.

title: Is the Key to Dow Jones in the Bancrofts Wallets?
description: Given his repeated entreaties to the Bancroft family and his recent promises to shield The Wall Street Journals newsroom from his own meddling as owner, News Corporation chief Rupert Murdoch seems almost desperate to buy Dow Jones. He has written three letters to pitch his proposal and offered to hold tetes-a-tetes with the family members, who have a controlling stake in the company  all this on top of the rich premium contained in his $5 billion offer. But there is something else the media mogul can do, according to Breakingviews: Throw more bags of money at the Bancrofts, while leaving common shareholders with his current offer.

title: Mediterranean Style
description: Fashion inspired by the hidden gems of the Mediterranean Sea.

title: Berlin  Travel Basics
description: Berlins main train station. (Associated Press)

title: London  Travel Basics
description: AIRPORTS: This is a good introduction to London, as it will get you used to the idea that everything seems to cost more, take more time and be more complex here than elsewhere. For starters, London has five airports, so pay attention to where youre landing!

title: A Tour of South African Wineries
description: The town of Tulbagh is at the forefront of the countrys wine revolution.

title: WELCOME TO OUR WORLD!
description: Globespotters is a new site where International Herald Tribune reporters and editors (and readers too!) can share up-to-the-minute tips and recommendations about whats happening in the places they live and visit. Let Globespotters help you get the most out of the worlds great cities.

title: NoSpace at the Pentagon
description: In what borders on news of the weird, YouTube.com, MySpace.com and 11 other Web sites have been banned by the Department of Defense.

title: Joshua Tree National Park and Beyond
description: The man-made outcroppings in the California desert.

title: Angry Giuliani Aide Lashes Back
description: The other day on Fox News Sunday, Rudolph W. Giuliani blamed a former aide for the decision to put the citys emergency command center at 7 World Trade Center, where it was destroyed on 9/11. Now the aide, Jerome M. Hauer, the former director of emergency management, has fired back, giving Lloyd Grove of New York magazine a February 1996 memo that shows he argued for a Brooklyn location. He says the mayor overruled him.

title: The Super Bowls of Tokyo
description: A trip across Japan's culinary universe.

title: The Sources of Pakistani Chaos
description: Before Mullah Dadullah, one of the Talibans top commanders, was killed over the weekend, he was able to leave a warning behind for his enemies.

title: War Games in Taiwan
description: Taiwans military is testing out some new moves this week in drills meant to prepare for the possibility of a Chinese attack. Today, six fighter jets landed on a highway for a scenario that left official runways destroyed in the fighting.China and Taiwan, which split in 1949 after a civil war, appear to be far from conflict, although there are plenty of political frustrations over Taiwans attempts to be recognized as an independent nation. China has threatened invasion if Taiwan goes too far on that count.

title: Bargain Spotting in the Software Sector
description: Media deals may be all the rage these days, but some analysts are seeing fodder for potential takeovers in the software industry as well. Kirk Materne and Daniel Cummins of Bank of America ran the numbers and found eight big software companies with low-enough stock values to make them attractive takeover candidates, even if the acquirer shelled out a 25 percent premium to the current price. The analysts emphasized they had no reason to believe a specific deal for any of them was in the works, but they also argued that consolidation in the software industry looked inevitable.

title: TV Upfronts: Second Thoughts on NBC
description: Manhattan is steaming up as the weather prepares, maybe, for ABCs presentation at 4 p.m. in tony Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center.

title: Rev. Jerry Falwell, Moral Majority Founder, Dies at 73
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, who founded the Moral Majority and built the religious right into a political force, has died. Rev. Falwell credited his Moral Majority with getting millions of conservative voters registered, electing Ronald Reagan and giving Republicans Senate control in 1980.

title: For Blackstone Co-Founder, a Deal With Park Views
description: When Peter G. Peterson retires at the end of next year, he will be able to relax in some luxurious digs. The co-founder of private equity giant Blackstone Group has just shelled out $37.5 million to buy media mogul David Geffens 12-room duplex penthouse on Fifth Avenue in New York, city records show. The New York Observer, which noted the deal on its real estate blog, points out that Mr. Geffen bought the apartment last year for $31.5 million. Thats a 19 percent markup in a year  a respectable return even in private equity circles.

title: Brunos Upstate Plan
description: Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno rolled out a lengthy plan to revitalize the upstate and used the occasion to tweak Gov. Eliot Spitzer for not doing likewise.

title: More on Chrysler
description: Perusing the comments from Micheline Maynards last post on the Chrysler sale, I noticed three recurring themes. Two of them dealt with Chryslers poor interior design and reliability. But by far, most of the comments mentioned something about the hybrid issue.

title: Fixing Our Economy By Fixing Up Our Workers
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his May 14 column, Divided Over Trade.

title: 04 Wiretapping Talks at Hospital
description: An extraordinary meeting in March 2004 in the hospital room of Attorney General John D. Ashcroft has been reported before. Today, Mr. Ashcrofts deputy, James B. Comey, recounted the meeting for the first time.

title: Clues to Watching Tonights G.O.P. Debate
description: Republicans are gathering in Columbia, S.C. today for what will be their second debate. It begins at 9 p.m. Eastern time, and is being broadcast on Fox News Channel. Weve learned long ago not to try to make predictions about what can happen in these very free-for-all events, but there are a few things to watch for.

title: Inventions That Make Life Easier
description: I mentioned earlier today that Id be describing some of the good ideas that made the finals in the Modern Marvels Invent Now competition. Later this week, Ill describe a few of them in more detail, but heres a quick sweep to show you the kind of brilliance that was on display:

title: Zambrano (No, Not That One) to the Mets?
description: The ace of the Mets in 2008 could be pitching at Shea Stadium tonight. Not John Maine, although he is certainly pitching like one. Were talking about Carlos Zambrano, the Cubs burly right-hander who, if he cannot work out an extension with Chicago, will become the most coveted pitcher on the free-agent market come November.

title: A Not-So-Fond Farewell for Falwell
description: In the good old days when print was king, nobody spoke ill of the dead, and if someone did, nobody else would know about it until the obituaries came out the next day. As we all know, with the rise of the blogosphere things have changed; still, the death of Jerry Falwell today seems to have set new heights in terms of both haste and venom. Here is a sampling:

title: Limited Sells Stake in Express, Explores Sale of Chain
description: Limited Brands announced Tuesday that it was selling its 67 percent stake in Express for $548 million and that it would weigh a sale of its Limited Stores business. With the sale to the private equity firm Golden Gate Capital, the company will focus on its Victorias Secret and Bath & Body Works businesses, among others. The streamlining plan was announced as the company also lowered its guidance for the first quarter. In afternoon trading, Limited shares were down 4 percent.

title: TV Upfronts: Help Change  What, Exactly?
description: ABCs upfront is different right off the bat. Exit the subway at 66th Street and someone pleads Help change TV! and gives anyone with hands a card with many mixed messages on it: a duct-taped girl, the word help! and then some advocacy about  ah, the absence of Latinos on TV. The George Lopez thing.

title: A New Direction for Republicans

And if you dont know what that means  the embrace  ignore it; but if you do, youre a very loyal ABC fan, and yes it was a spoiler. At least I assume it was. Sorry about that.

title: TV Upfronts: The Black Ball, contd.
description: Theyre crows, ravens, littles birds of death, flying off the ABC black ball. Its too cold in here. Why is this horrible? I hate this upfront. Im seriously disturbed by the logo stuff, which is not incidental. I know that someone designed this Blair Witch thing thinking that the little, um, items might call to mind the digital extensions that shows now offer. But if ABC sees those as evil little sick viral  ugh, they just turned seborrheic white!!  theyre either not getting it, or the future looks deranged.

I can already see the cancellation notice for it on zap2it.com, but with my frozen fingers it is my pleasure to type these words: I plan to watch the pilot.

title: Hocus-Pocus, and a Beaker of Truffles
description: A TRUFFLE by any other name may smell as sweet, but what if that name is 2,4-dithiapentane? All across the country, in restaurants great and small, the truffle flavor advertised on menus is increasingly being supplied by truffle oil. What those menus dont say is that, unlike real truffles, the aroma of truffle oil is not born in the earth. Most commercial truffle oils are concocted by mixing olive oil with one or more compounds like 2,4-dithiapentane (the most prominent of the hundreds of aromatic molecules that make the flavor of white truffles so exciting) that have been created in a laboratory; their one-dimensional flavor is also changing common understanding of how a truffle should taste.

title: Manhattan: Judgment Against Police Is Overturned
description: A state appeals court has dismissed a civil judgment against the Police Department that stemmed from a 1992 altercation between police officers and demonstrators in Orchard Beach, in the Bronx. The original verdict, in which a jury awarded $81 million to seven plaintiffs, was reduced by the trial judge in 2004 to $635,000, city officials said. In a ruling released yesterday, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court found that videotapes of the confrontation did not support the contention that the police had acted improperly. After reviewing the tapes, the judges said that the police were justified in their belief that the protest could escalate and that officers appropriately tried to quell a quickly unfolding, potentially explosive situation. Mark Kressner, the plaintiffs lawyer, said they would appeal on the grounds that the trial jury made the correct decision after carefully reviewing the evidence. The jury had the opportunity to see those tapes over a three-week period in slow motion, with explanation of what occurred off camera, he said.

title: Mets Expect Hernndez Back Soon

The action was in response to a request from Fouad Siniora, the current prime minister, whose government is locked in a struggle with pro-Syrian forces that are against an international court. A United Nations investigation has linked the assassination to the Syrian security services. Saying he endorsed the decision to act now, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said, I am of the view that there should be no impunity for the perpetrators of political assassinations.

title: Settlements Under Student Loan Inquiry

Cuomo, has reached agreements with two more universities under which they will adopt a code of conduct governing relations they may have with student loan companies. Mr. Cuomos office found that Drexel University, in Philadelphia, was due to receive more than $250,000 from a loan company. That money will now be distributed to students who borrowed from that lender, according to Mr. Cuomos office. The investigation also found that Timothy Lehmann, the director of financial aid at Capella University, an online institution based in Minneapolis, received more than $12,000 as a consultant to one lender. Twenty-four colleges and universities have adopted Mr. Cuomos code of conduct.

title: Correction: For the Record

title: Brooklyn: Cobble Hill Firehouse Will Not Be Sold
description: The city has agreed not to sell a vacant firehouse in Brooklyn, ending a four-year battle between the Bloomberg administration and community activists and local leaders. Engine Company 204 on Degraw Street in Cobble Hill was one of five units closed or relocated during budget cuts in 2003, leaving their firehouses empty. The changes set off emotional debates over the future of the buildings, whose communities prized their distinctive structures and histories. Yesterday, Councilmen Bill de Blasio and David Yassky, both of Brooklyn, and the borough president, Marty Markowitz, announced that the city had agreed to put the Degraw Street building up for lease for a community use to be determined. The City Councils land use subcommittee approved the deal and the potential sale of three of the other firehouses, with a provision that the buildings be used to benefit their communities. The fifth closed firehouse, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, has been approved for sale to the Henry Street Settlement for moderate-income housing.

But Mr. Benson admits that for all his success as a musician  nine Grammys worth  he wasnt the all-around businessman he aimed to be.

title: Canada:  Iamgolds Profit Falls as Costs Rise
description: The Iamgold Corporation, a Canadian gold producer, said first-quarter net income fell 43 percent on losses from derivatives and higher mining costs. Profit declined to $11.3 million from $19.9 million a year ago, Iamgold said. Profit per share fell to 4 cents, from 13 cents, as Iamgold issued shares to pay for its acquisition last November of its rival Cambior for $1.1 billion. Sales more than tripled, to $146.4 million. Iamgolds cash cost of producing an ounce of gold rose 54 percent, to $416, from a year ago on higher labor and fuel costs.

title: Tyco to Pay $3 Billion to Settle Investor Lawsuits
description: Tyco International, whose two top executives were imprisoned for fraud, has agreed to pay almost $3 billion to settle class-action lawsuits brought by investors, the company announced yesterday.

title: Poppy Fields Are Now a Front Line in Afghan War
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a walled compound outside Kabul, two members of Colombias counternarcotics police force are trying to teach raw Afghan recruits how to wage close-quarters combat.

title: We Try Harder (but Whats the Point?)
description: Seattle

title: Culinary Institute Receives $35 Million
description: PACE picante sauce, one of the first salsas sold commercially, made Christopher Goldsbury a billionaire. Now the salsa fortune will pay for a push to deepen the United States relationship with food from Latin America, and help restaurant workers move ahead in the kitchen.

title: Bush Picks General to Coordinate War Policy
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  The White House said Tuesday that President Bush ended his lengthy search for a so-called war czar to carry out Iraq and Afghanistan policy by offering the job to an active duty three-star Army general who said in his interview that he had been skeptical of the troop buildup in Iraq.

title: Jerry Falwell, Moral Majority Founder, Dies at 73
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, the fundamentalist preacher who founded the Moral Majority and brought the language and passions of religious conservatives into the hurly-burly of American politics, died yesterday in Lynchburg, Va. He was 73.

title: Among the Rich, a New Dispute Over Air Rights
description: Its not the war against third world debt, but still.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports graphic yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about Oscar Pistorius, a South African athlete who wants to be the first amputee runner to compete in the Olympics, carried incorrect renderings in some copies of the take-off phase of running. A corrected version can be found online.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Donna Murphy Healing

title: Clemens Readies Arm While Others Pick His Brain
description: TAMPA, Fla., May 15  The young pitchers gathered around the mound like ducklings to see and hear Roger Clemens, who obliged them with a tutorial that took more time than he planned.

title: New Motorola Phones Aim at High-End Market
description: Motorola, the mobile phone giant, is hoping to revive its business prospects with some slick new phones and a little celebrity gloss.

title: Proxy Fights More Muted, for Most Part
description: Fireworks have so far been rare at annual shareholder meetings this year. With stock indexes near their record highs, investor anger, not surprisingly, has been muted.

title: Web Site May Be Liable for Some User Postings
description: A Web site that matches roommates may be liable for what its users say about their preferences, a fractured three-judge panel of the federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled yesterday.

title: Death-Squad Scandal Circles Closer to Colombias President
description: CALI, Colombia, May 15  President lvaro Uribe, the Bush administrations closest ally in Latin America, faces an intensifying scandal after a jailed former commander of paramilitary death squads testified Tuesday that Mr. Uribes defense minister had tried to plot with the outlawed private militias to upset the rule of a former president.

title: U.N. Emissions Program (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Soccer: Right Coach Is Right Here
description: With national soccer coaches, the job is always interim. Coaches can win the World Cup and still turn back the job, weary of the entire country camping on their doorstep, critiquing their choice of midfielders.

title: Shares of Anemia Drug Makers Slide as Medicare Threatens to Cut Reimbursement
description: Amgen shares were battered again yesterday after Medicare proposed to sharply curtail reimbursement for the companys biggest selling product, the anemia drug Aranesp.

title: Soviet Architects and Their Edifice Complex
description: The nonprofit Storefront for Art and Architecture has been around for a quarter-century now. A tiny wedge-shaped space on a noisy street at the edge of Chinatown, it built its reputation on managing to work its many limitations to its advantage. Its best shows, typically thrown together on a shoestring budget, had a raw immediacy that the bigger art institutions can rarely match.

title: Inflation Tame Despite Rising Gas Cost
description: The slowing economy helped tone down inflation last month, even as rising energy prices threatened to send it higher.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about the resignation of Paul J. McNulty, the deputy United States attorney general, misstated the given name of another Justice Department official, the former director of the executive office for United States attorneys, who left his job over the departments handling of the firings of several federal prosecutors. He is Michael A. Battle, not William.

title: Handling House Calls in a Managed-Care World
description: THE day when doctors treated patients at home disappeared decades ago in most of America as house calls gave way to more cost-effective office visits. But a small company that devised a way to charge for doctors house calls could encourage a return to the practice  not just as a service for the rich, but as the most economical way for Medicare and private insurers to care for their frailest patients.

title: A School Frees Low-Income Boys From the Pressures of the Streets
description: Where are the boys?

title: Bush Opens Door to Wolfowitzs Resigning
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  The Bush administration, shifting strategy in the face of mounting opposition to Paul D. Wolfowitz, opened the door Tuesday to his resigning voluntarily as World Bank president if the bank board dropped its drive to declare him unfit to remain in office.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The About New York column on Saturday, about the relationship between the New York Yankees and former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, misspelled the surname of a Yankees spokeswoman in some copies. She is Alice McGillion, not McGillon.

title: A Little Company May Help Some Big Ones Grow Bigger
description: AESOPS mouse, who chewed away the ropes binding a lion to set him free, proved that powerful beasts sometimes benefit from having small friends. Cambridge Heart, a tiny maker of heart stress test equipment, may be living out a similar story.

title: France: Vivendi Profit Increases 32
description: Vivendi said its first-quarter profit rose 32 percent, spurred by demand for its World of Warcraft video game and subscriber growth at the pay-television unit. Net income rose to 932 million euros ($1.27 billion) from 707 million euros ($957.5 million) a year earlier, Vivendi said. First-quarter sales rose 5.3 percent, to 5.02 billion euros ($6.8 billion) from 4.77 billion euros ($6.47 billion) a year earlier. Profit at Vivendi Games surged to 107 million euros ($145 million) from 23 million euros ($31.1 million) a year earlier. The unit sold almost 2.4 million copies of the expansion pack to World of Warcraft the first day it went on sale in January. Profit at the pay-television unit Canal Plus jumped fivefold, to 164 million euros ($222.1 million). Profit at the mobile phone unit SFR, Vivendis largest business, slipped 3.5 percent, to 643 million euros ($871 million). Profit was down at the Universal Music Group, hurt by falling CD sales.

title: After Rainout, Yankees Need Another Starter
description: CHICAGO, May 15  The Yankees, who have already used 10 starting pitchers, are searching for a starter again. A rainout here Tuesday night leaves an open spot in the rotation for Sunday nights game against the Mets.

title: Cust Finally Gets a Chance to Show He Hits for Power
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 15  (AP)  Jack Cust had the reputation of a power hitter for almost a decade, impressing scouts with his ability to wait for his pitch and drive it over the fence with ease.

title: Of Spring and Fair Harbors
description: Everyone has a ritual to shake off winter, a gesture to prove to ourselves that the bleak days of biting wind are over for now. For some, its baseball practice, or buying bathing suits. Others just itch to turn over the warm earth and rake off the detritus of leaves and branches from already-forgotten February storms. Yardwork that seems like a chore in autumn has a liberating feel, a necessary rite to welcome the warmer months.

title: Workshop Hamlet: Free, Indoors, Uncut (Hes Still Angry)
description: It seems to take a gimmick to stage Shakespeare these days. For the last 15 years Gorilla Reps has been to offer free outdoor productions around New York City: A Midsummer Nights Dream in Washington Square Park; Macbeth in Fort Tryon Park. The companys next project is an outdoor Hamlet, scheduled for 2008, and it is now holding indoor workshops of it at the Times Square Arts Center.

title: Afghanistan: Afghan Soldiers Die in Ambush
description: A joint Afghan and American patrol was ambushed in eastern Nuristan, the most remote province, leaving seven Afghan soldiers dead, four missing, and five American and three Afghan soldiers wounded, NATO said.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times yesterday, about the vaccine for human papillomavirus, misstated a condition caused by two variants of the virus. They cause 90 percent of cases of genital warts, not genital herpes.

title: Its Not Just Honey
description: ONE Friday last month, thousands of New York City commuters on their way home from work stopped to sample fruity-smelling hand lotions and macadamia body butter inside a big yellow tent next to Grand Central Terminal.

title: Couple Held Two Servants Captive for Years, U.S. Says
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y., May 15  Federal prosecutors charged a wealthy Long Island couple on Tuesday with keeping two Indonesian domestic workers as virtual prisoners in their home for more than five years under conditions they called modern-day slavery, beating one severely and paying them very little.

title: From Maine, Small Business Stories to Inspire
description: STATISTICS can suggest trends, but they cant tell stories. They cannot, for instance, describe Carolann Ouellettes mashed-potato issue. They cannot convey the odd pleasure that Jane Barron felt when she realized someone was probably stealing her work. They cannot follow the unlikely trail that Lisa Burns and Karen King blazed when they bought a tractor.

title: Germany: Concrete Maker Buys a Supplier
description: HeidelbergCement, a German concrete maker, has agreed to buy Hanson, a British supplier of building materials, for 7.85 billion ($16 billion). HeidelbergCement will pay 11 ($21.80) a share for Hanson, a premium of 29 percent over Hansons share price on May 2 when HeidelbergCement first said it might bid. With the purchase, HeidelbergCement will increase its revenue by two-thirds, expanding in the United States and bolstering output of aggregates, pipes and bricks. The companies are a perfect fit and overlaps are minimal, HeidelbergCements chief executive, Bernd Scheifele, above, said in a conference call with analysts. Hanson strengthens our operations in the U.S., U.K. and Europe and adds a business in Australia. Hanson has 26,000 workers in 14 nations and derives half its sales from North America.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A map of Central Asia yesterday with the Jibek Joly Journal article, about the large number of Uzbek migrants who pass through the Kazakhstan border town of Jibek Joly to seek work, misidentified the country in the lower left corner, bordering Afghanistan and Turkmenistan. It is Iran, not Iraq.

title: C.I.A. Officer Testifies He Was Given Qaeda Pledge Form Said to Be Padillas
description: MIAMI, May 15  A covert officer in the Central Intelligence Agency, apparently using a false name and partial disguise, told the jury in the trial of Jose Padilla on Tuesday how the government acquired a document in Afghanistan that it later identified as Mr. Padillas application to train at a camp run by Al Qaeda.

title: Gliding Through the Classics With a Sample of Whats Ahead
description: I come from centuries-old agricultural stock. Why do I mention this when starting to review the Monday night gala that opened American Ballet Theaters spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House? I once groaned, Ive got to go to a gala, to my brother, who had then been specializing in pigs for 15 years. He replied, You said that in just the same tone as I use when I say, Ive got to clear the pig slurry.

title: Your Ad Goes Here
description: THE Internet search engine is an indispensable tool of modern life and an advertising gold mine for Google, the favorite first stop on the Web.

title: Hedge Fund Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (Dow Jones)  Hedge fund advisers would be required to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission under a bill intended to give regulators new tools to oversee the fast-growing industry.

title: Giving Morels the Caviar Treatment
description: AS anyone with a hard-core shopping habit knows, theres a moment after youve zeroed in on your object of desire when all reason ebbs. It doesnt matter that those strappy sandals are a little too tight, a little too high-heeled and a lot too expensive. A euphoric cloud obscures common sense, especially if theyre on sale.

title: Sometimes, Whats Needed Is a Nudge
description: I was walking through the intensive care unit of a San Francisco hospital earlier this year when I noticed a jarring sight. Most of the patients in the unit were sitting up in their beds. Some of them were gravely ill, drifting in and out of consciousness, but their mechanical beds were still propped up, much as the bed of an alert patient receiving visitors might be.

title: Bush Intervened in Dispute Over N.S.A. Eavesdropping
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  President Bush intervened in March 2004 to avert a crisis over the National Security Agencys domestic eavesdropping program after Attorney General John Ashcroft, Director Robert S. Mueller III of the F.B.I. and other senior Justice Department aides all threatened to resign, a former deputy attorney general testified Tuesday.

title: Bringing Lobbyists to Heel
description: Its crunch time for House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to deliver on the Democrats vow to rein in power lobbyists who sully Congress by purchasing privileged access with outsized campaign donations. There are worthy remedies, but members are balking. If the House resorts to mere cosmetic changes, the Democrats will risk the same voters ire that cost the Republicans control last year.

title: Lottery Numbers
Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: Germany: Big Expansion for Nursery Schools
description: The government agreed on a $16 billion plan that will triple the number of day care centers for children under age 3 to 750,000 by 2013. Germany now lags behind its neighbors in providing day care, with just 13.5 percent of toddlers under 3 in nursery schools, compared with the European average of 35 percent.

title: A Swedish Band With a Yen for the Olden, Golden Days
description: Between Mando Diaos set and its encore at the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night, the band members went backstage, shook up their beer bottles and returned to spray them across the stage and their closest fans. That was the kind of old-school boisterousness they also showed in their songs, which embrace 1960s garage-rock as if it might grow up to be punk.

title: Vornado Goes Both East and West for a Deal
description: Steven Roths hopes of establishing a beachhead on the West Coast were dashed earlier this year when he lost the high-stakes contest to acquire Equity Office Properties and its nationwide portfolio of prime office buildings to the Blackstone Group, a private equity firm.

title: Whos Watching What We Eat?
description: ELIZABETH ARMSTRONG did not give the Food and Drug Administration much thought until her children became ill from eating contaminated bagged spinach.

title: Gauging Viewer Tastes: A New Dose of Escapism
description: ABC is joining the other broadcast networks in lightening up for the 2007-8 season.

title: London May Be Baby Step for N.F.L.
description: Steve Tisch, one of the Giants owners, said the teams October game against the Miami Dolphins in London  the first N.F.L. regular-season game to be played outside North America  would serve as a litmus test for the leagues plan for more international games.

title: Judge Lifts Seal on Secret Police Convention Files
description: A federal judge today lifted a stay that paved the way for the release of about 600 pages of secret documents relating to police preparations for the 2004 Republican National Convention, held in New York.

title: The Unkept Promise on Voting
description: Congress has done a terrible job of regulating electronic voting: It allowed A.T.M.-style voting machines to proliferate without requiring them to produce a paper trail that can be audited to ensure that the results are accurate. That has meant wasted time and money for the states, confusion for voters, and questionable election results. Fortunately, the nations delinquent lawmakers have a chance to set things right  through a bill introduced by Representative Rush Holt, Democrat of New Jersey, that would finally impose a paper trail requirement. There are some details that need fine-tuning, but Congress should move quickly to pass it.

title: Wolfowitz Said to Be Working on Deal for His Resignation
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 After six weeks of fighting efforts to oust him as president of the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz began today to negotiate the terms of his possible resignation, in return for the bank dropping or softening the charge that he had engaged in misconduct, bank officials said.

title: Oracle Uses Late Charge to Tie Series
description: VALENCIA, Spain, May 15 (AP)  BMW Oracle Racing, the only entry from the United States in the Louis Vuitton Cup, rallied to defeat Luna Rossa of Italy on Tuesday to tie their best-of-nine semifinal series after two flights.

title: How an Invisible Man Was Seduced by His Visibility
description: In June 1933 Ralph Ellison, riding the rails like a hobo, traveled to the Tuskegee Institute in search of a new life. Left fatherless at 3, he gravitated toward authority figures in a position to help him, but at Tuskegee he received a cold reception from a man he idolized, a composer named W. L. Dawson, who kept him at arms length. He would later describe his trip to Tuskegee as a journey into the heart of darkness, adding, My Kurtz was W. L. Dawson: the artist corrupted by his environment.

title: Greek Again, With Even More Passion
description: ONE of the real pleasures of dining in New York over the last few years has been keeping tabs on Michael Psilakis, whose path to success hasnt been conventional and whose goal  a quest, really  isnt ordinary. And one of the real pleasures of his newest restaurant, Anthos, is its affirmation of how far hes come and how fast hes done it.

title: CBS Lineup to Offer Vampires and a Mystery With Singing Casino Workers
description: CBS will follow its stated goal of taking its prime-time schedule in unexpected directions with fall series hopefuls exploring unusual themes like vampires, swingers and even singing casino workers.

title: The Men Are in Leotards, but Dont Call It Dancing
description: ST. PAUL, May 14  At the end of The Baron, a play about old-school professional wrestling currently running at the History Theater here, the eternal question that is as much a part of the sport as heels and bad accents is finally raised.

title: Democrats Signal End to Impasse on War Spending
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  Congressional Democratic leaders signaled today that they were ready to give ground to end an impasse with President Bush over war spending after the Senate soundly rejected a Democratic plan to block money for major combat operations in Iraq beginning next spring.

title: Defense Links Sex Attack to Contempt for Firefighters
description: The heroism of firefighters on 9/11 has been etched into the memories of most New Yorkers. But not for Peter Braunstein, a defense psychologist testified at his trial yesterday.

title: Study Finds College-Prep Courses in High School Leave Many Students Lagging
description: Only a quarter of high school students who take a full set of college-preparatory courses  four years of English and three each of mathematics, science and social studies  are well prepared for college, according to a study of last years high school graduates released yesterday by ACT, the Iowa testing organization.

title: A Team Player, Once Its Off the Vine
description: Pinot noir demands much of both vine grower and winemaker, wrote Jancis Robinson in The Oxford Companion to Wine. But as challenging as the grape may be, once it is in the bottle, it often becomes the most forgiving of wines.

title: Fatah Officials Home Stormed in Gaza Clashes
description: JERUSALEM, May 16  The combat in Gaza appeared to intensify today, with an Israeli air strike on what officials called a Hamas command center and a Hamas raid on the home of a senior Palestinian security official from the rival Fatah faction.

title: Devil Rays 4, Rangers 3
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., May 15 (AP)  The night was already a success for the Tampa Bay Devil Rays. Brendan Harriss game-winning hit made the teams debut at Disney World that much sweeter.

title: Strong Tax Figures Improve Prospects for Corzines Budget
description: TRENTON, May 15  Legislative analysts reported on Tuesday that there had been unexpected growth in corporate income taxes over the past two months, buoying chances for passage of Gov. Jon S. Corzines proposed $33 billion budget.

title: Analysis Finds Large Antarctic Area Has Melted
description: While much of the world has warmed in a pattern that scientists have linked with near certainty to human activities, the frigid interior of Antarctica has resisted the trend.

title: In N.B.A., for Some Actions, Theres an Overreaction
description: With a man of David Sterns worldliness  as a Johnny Appleseed on an odyssey to sprinkle the N.B.A. throughout the planet  it is remarkable how Global Dave just ignored climate change.

title: Parents of Dan Snyder Forgive but Cant Forget
description: ELMIRA, Ontario, May 10  Dany Heatley was playing hockey about two hours down the road and across the border. One of the best players in the N.H.L., a top scorer in the playoffs, Heatley helped the visiting Ottawa Senators to a playoff victory over the Buffalo Sabres on Thursday. HSBC Arena was sold out, and millions across the continent saw the game on television.

title: DNA in Murders Frees Inmate After 19 Years
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., May 15  A man who served 19 years in prison for the sadistic murders of his companions two children walked out of the Union County Courthouse flanked by his family members after a judge vacated his convictions on Tuesday.

title: Both Sides Claim Victory in Long Case of Failed Film
description: LOS ANGELES, May 15  A knock-down, drag-out trial over the failed big-budget movie Sahara mercifully ended on Tuesday after three and a half months. But it had an unsatisfying Hollywood ending.

title: Inflation and Wages Show Slower Growth
description: Businesses kept a lid on prices again last month, and wage gains were scant for most working Americans, signs consistent with an economy in the midst of a slowdown.

title: Some Gay New Yorkers Gain in Ruling on Marriages
description: BOSTON, May 15  A little-noticed resolution to a case involving same-sex couples from New York will allow dozens of them to be considered legally married in Massachusetts, and apparently in their home state as well.

title: Good Medicine, Under Attack (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkey: Erdogan Urges Sarkozy to Drop Prejudices
description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said he hoped that Nicolas Sarkozy, who takes over as Frances president today, would drop his opposition to Turkeys joining the European Union. Mr. Sarkozy, who argues that Turkey is culturally not a part of Europe and that most of its territory is in Asia, vehemently opposes Turkeys membership. This approach of Mr. Sarkozy comes from prejudices, Mr. Erdogan said, addressing a media conference in Istanbul. Mr. Sarkozy has to overcome these prejudices. Mr. Erdogans remarks were the first to directly address the implications of Mr. Sarkozys election for Turkey. Turkeys E.U. membership is the peace project of the 21st century, Mr. Erdogan said, an alliance of East and West.

title: Recipe: Octopus and Potato Stew
description: Adapted from Martin Pescator

title: $72.8 Million for a Rothko
description: Mark Rothkos White Center (Yellow, Pink and Lavender on Rose), a dreamy abstract painting from 1950, sold for $72.8 million  more than three times the previous auction record for the artist  at Sothebys major spring auction of contemporary art last night.

title: G.I.s Who Were Ambushed Were Based in New York
description: BAGHDAD, May 15  The seven American victims of a deadly weekend ambush south of Baghdad were soldiers from the 10th Mountain Division, based in upstate New York, military officials said Tuesday, as thousands of troops continued an intensive search for three of the men, who were presumed captured by Sunni Arab insurgents.

title: Deadly Day of Violence Wracks Much of Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, May 16  Sprawling street battles between militia gunmen and Iraqi security forces erupted in three cities in Iraq on Wednesday on a day of wide-ranging violence that underscored the grave security situation across much of Iraq.

title: Obama and Clinton Back Ending Iraq Combat by March 31
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton said for the first time on Tuesday that they would support legislation to curtail major combat operations in Iraq by March 31, 2008, cutting off financing for all but a limited mission of American forces.

title: Germany: Report on Africa Aid Disputed
description: The Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development disagreed with the contention of Bono and his antipoverty advocacy group, DATA, that Germany has gone off track in meeting its promise to double aid to Africa by 2010. The ministry said the groups decision to exclude debt relief as a form of aid was factually unjustified. It said the debt relief it provided had helped African governments put more children in school and improve health. France, too, has disputed the organizations exclusion of debt relief.

title: Ivy League Crunch Brings New Cachet to Next Tier
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa.  Lehigh University has never been as sought after as Stanford, Yale or Harvard. But this year, awash in applications, it churned out rejection letters and may break more hearts when it comes to its waiting list.

title: Philadelphians Pick Nominees for Mayor
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 15  Michael Nutter, a former member of the City Council, won the Democratic primary for mayor Tuesday, effectively guaranteeing him the position in a city that has not had a Republican mayor since 1952.

title: A Bluestocking Route From Gridiron to Commerce
description: AT 33, Lance Johnstone is hardly old, but his days are numbered  playing days, that is. As he enters his 12th season with the National Football League, he knows that soon he will need to make a living beyond professional sports.

title: Thomson Adds Reuters in $17 Billion Bid to Be Giant
description: TORONTO, May 15  In the information age, content may be king. But the real power lies in what you can do with it.

title: Wiccans Keep the Faith With a Religion Under Wraps
description: DUMFRIES, Va.  Above the womans fireplace hangs her wedding picture, taken in a Lutheran church years ago. Below it, on the mantelpiece, is a small Wiccan altar: two candles, a tiny cauldron, four stones to represent the elements of nature and a small amethyst representing her spirit.

title: Former Soldier, Now a Professor, Loses His Only Son to a War He Actively Opposed
description: BOSTON, May 15  The father, a longtime military man, from West Point to Vietnam to the first Persian Gulf war, became an early public critic of the war in Iraq, writing frequently and potently about its causes and effects.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A map of Central Asia yesterday with the Jibek Joly Journal article, about the large number of Uzbek migrants who pass through the Kazakhstan border town of Jibek Joly to seek work, misidentified the country in the lower left corner, bordering Afghanistan and Turkmenistan. It is Iran, not Iraq. (Go to Article)

title: A Choreographer Goes Video, Featuring a 99-Year-Old Star
description: These days lots of choreographers are trying their hands at video  lots more, unfortunately, than are good at it or even seem to know what its about. Those artists might consider ambling over to the Kitchen, where Ralph Lemons quiet but richly layered video installation is the central element in (The efflorescence of) Walter. Organized by guest curators, Anthony Allen and Claire Tancons, this mixed-media exhibition is his first solo show in New York, and a graceful public foray into visual art.

title: Manhattan: Former Interfaith Official Charged
description: The former office administrator of the Interfaith Center of New York, a nonprofit educational organization, was charged yesterday with stealing more than $55,000 from the group by charging personal expenses to business credit cards, prosecutors said. Denyce Norment, 58, of Brooklyn, was charged with grand larceny, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, and she pleaded not guilty at her arraignment. Prosecutors said Ms. Norment charged personal expenses, including a cruise and tickets to a Beyonc concert, to Interfaith credit cards from April 2000 until October 2004. The bills were discovered after Ms. Norment was laid off in 2004, Mr. Morgenthau said. Ms. Norments lawyer, Frederica L. Miller, said yesterday that some of the charges were approved by Interfaith and that documentation concerning some of the bills was lost when the office changed locations. She is absolutely not guilty, she said. I am confident the charges will eventually be dismissed.

title: Food Calendar
description: Wine Tastings

title: 3 Suspects Freed in London Transit Attacks
description: LONDON, May 15  The British police on Tuesday released three of four people arrested a week ago in connection with the London bombings of 2005, including the widow of one of the bombers.

title: Plan for Middle-Class Homes on Queens Bank of East River Prompts Ideas and Protest
description: Stephen M. Ross wants some of the wealthiest developers in the city to come together to build 5,000 apartments for nurses, teachers, firefighters, construction workers and other middle-class employees on the bank of the East River  at no profit.

title: Failing by Example
description: If you want to know why we are losing in Iraq, go back and read this story that ran on the front page of The Times on Saturday. It began like this:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on May 3 about plans to redevelop Pier 40 on the Hudson River into an entertainment complex misstated the year the pier was built as a commercial shipping terminal for the Holland America Line. It was 1963, not 1954.

title: Health Insurance and Other Benefits: A Primer
description: BUSINESS owners who want to offer benefits like health insurance and tax-deferred retirement plans for themselves and their employees face two daunting hurdles: high costs and complicated federal laws intended to prevent plans from discriminating in favor of top employees.

title: Microsoft to Release New Version of Halo Video Game on Sept. 25
description: Microsoft plans to announce today that the third installment of Halo, the companys biggest video game franchise, will be released on Sept. 25.

title: Kennedy Airport, Dining Destination
description: Delta Airlines has provided new food options at Terminal 2 at Kennedy Airport. A Balduccis satellite, the stores first such outlet, has self-service units with salads and first-rate sandwiches (including smoked salmon on baguette and smoked chicken and avocado), as well as yogurts, small containers of seasoned couscous and cold Asian noodles, pastries and fruit. Balthazar croissants are sold, and breakfast egg specialties and hot pressed sandwiches can be ordered at the service counter. But on a recent morning a well-stuffed hot corned beef and pastrami sandwich that needed more mustard was not heated through. Salads and sandwiches are mostly $6.49 to $7.49. A Todd English Bonfire steakhouse is to open in the terminal next month.

title: Bronx Man Convicted of Killing Girl
description: A Bronx man who opened fire at a crowded playground two years ago has been convicted of fatally shooting a 10-year-old girl during the attack, prosecutors said yesterday. Rene Bonilla, 22, was convicted of murder and attempted murder on Friday in State Supreme Court for killing the girl, Naisha Pearson, and wounding Leonardo DEaza, 19, during a Labor Day block party on Sept. 5, 2005. Prosecutors said that Mr. Bonilla went to the playground in Mott Haven to kill Mr. DEaza because Mr. DEaza had beaten him in front of Mr. Bonillas girlfriend. After Mr. Bonilla started firing  striking the girl once and hitting Mr. DEaza five times  a crowd chased Mr. Bonilla to the roof of a building, where he was arrested, prosecutors said.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the daily closing of the stock market misstated the given name of a strategist at JPMorgan Private Bank who discussed factors that could affect the performance of shares. He is Jack Caffrey, not James.

Some people, including lawmakers and labor groups, have recently questioned whether the carry deserves to be taxed at the lower capital gains rate (as it usually is) or whether it should be taxed as ordinary income (which the private equity industry naturally thinks is an awful idea).

title: American Dreamin
description: I was sitting with Alix Browne of the Times Magazine the other night at the Dior resort show at 7 World Trade Center when I had the thought that John Gallianos clothes were not really about India or Marrakech at all. Rather, they were about the American West and the Middle West of Arkansas and Oklahoma. There was a great vibrant redneck couture quality about the clothes  and those of you who follow Gallianos work know he has a taste for raw country. Remember the trashy Dior shows of few years back? Anyway, thats what I saw in the show, a kind of couture sensibility that never made it to Dallas or Fort Worth but maybe got as far as Oklahoma. All those turquoises, and lemon yellows, and pinks done in a kind of corn-haired babe stiffness.

title: Four Killings in the City in 12 Hours
description: Four people were killed in unrelated cases in less than 12 hours Tuesday night and early yesterday, the police said. The figure is unusually high for a year in which an average of less than one homicide per day has occurred, though Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly pointed out yesterday that one day doesnt make a trend. In the first killing, Donnell McFarland, 18, of Brooklyn was shot in the head at 7:30 p.m. at the corner of Linden Street and Knickerbocker Avenue in Bushwick, the police said; James Kelly, 16, of Linden Street has been arrested. In the second, a young man of 18 who was not identified by the police was shot in the back shortly before 11 p.m. on Tuesday in front of 570 Blake Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn. Three hours later, Emrand Hossain, 19, of Queens was stabbed in the chest at the corner of 28th Street and Hoyt Avenue in Astoria. And shortly before 3 a.m., a man of 19 was shot on University Avenue in the Bronx. There were no arrests as of last evening.
