title: Just a Ride in the Park
description: Single-track mountain-biking trails have long been a fixture of the backwoods. But a push for trails closer to home has prompted municipalities like Seattle, Minneapolis, Pittsburgh, Tucson and Salt Lake City to legitimize the sport in parks within city limits. In New York, $100,000 in government financing built four miles of single-track path in Highbridge Park in upper Manhattan, where a grand opening will be celebrated this Saturday. The face of the sport is changing, said Chris Bernhardt, a consultant with the International Mountain Bicycling Association. Urban terrain is receiving more attention than traditional wilderness trails in some areas. At Highbridge, New York Citys first legal mountain-biking area, twisting trails, jumps, banked turns and stunts occupy woods formerly famous for homeless encampments and used hypodermic needles.

title: Iraqis Admit Ambush Roles as U.S. Searches for 3 G.I.s
description: YUSUFIYA, Iraq, May 16  Four days into a huge manhunt for three American soldiers abducted in an ambush a few miles from here, military officials said Wednesday that they had detained several local residents who confessed to taking part in the attack and that they had recovered equipment that might have belonged to the missing soldiers.

title: Manhattan: Harlem Food Shops Chided
description: A report released yesterday by the citys Department of Health and Mental Hygiene found that residents in East and Central Harlem have far less access to healthful food in stores than their nearby counterparts on the Upper East Side. The report, based on a survey that department researchers conducted in 2005, found that stores in Harlem were half as likely to stock low-fat dairy products and seven times less likely to sell common vegetables, said Andrew Tucker, a Health Department spokesman. Mr. Tucker said city officials were working with store owners to encourage them to offer more healthful foods.

title: Democrats Seek No-Confidence Vote on Gonzales
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzaless standing in Congress became even shakier today as Senate Democrats called for a vote of no confidence in him, and the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee and others predicted that the furor over Mr. Gonzaless leadership of the Justice Department would end with his resignation.

title: Orthodox Jews Come to a Well-Worn City, Pleased to Find a Piece of Paradise
description: WATERBURY, Conn.  The 7-Eleven on Cooke Street in this central Connecticut city now offers kosher Slurpees. A deli offering Shabbat specialties like cholent and kishke sits on a blighted street where the police frequently block off vandalized homes. An abandoned synagogue that was nearly sold to a church about seven years ago is now a bustling yeshiva where 200 young men study the Talmud.

title: Fast, Loud and Savage: Hey, Hey, Theyre Arctic Monkeys
description: Alex Turner always acts as if hes trying hard to stave off boredom and barely succeeding. Onstage at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Tuesday night with his band, Arctic Monkeys, he glanced at the heaving crowd and said, Nice to see youre on your feet. Nice, maybe, but not surprising: there are no chairs on the main floor.

title: Bausch & Lomb Accepts $4.5 Billion Takeover Bid
description: Bausch & Lomb, a troubled leader in the eye care industry, said yesterday that it had accepted a $4.5 billion takeover offer from investment groups controlled by Warburg Pincus, a private equity firm known for backing a wide range of health care companies.

title: In Bid for Better Care, Surgery With a Warranty
description: What if medical care came with a 90-day warranty?

title: Street Battles in Iraqi Cities Point to Dire Security Status
description: BAGHDAD, May 16  Sprawling street battles between militia gunmen and Iraqi security forces erupted in three cities on Wednesday on a day of wide-ranging violence that underscored the grave security situation across much of Iraq.

title: Newly Released
description: Judging by some of this months new books, the transition from childhood to the adult world remains as rich a vein for writers as it was when Holden Caulfield first wandered around New York (and one of the authors goes the ducks one better by giving his protagonist a job at the Central Park Zoo). In these books, children are beset by their parents, by demons and by first love, among other things. Elmore Leonard, on the other hand, writes strictly about adults.

description: Pros and Cons

title: Deal Is Reached in Senate on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Senators from both parties announced an agreement this afternoon on immigration-reform legislation that would bring illegal immigrants and their families out of the shadows and into the sunshine of American life, as Senator Edward M. Kennedy put it.

title: In Time for Summer Parties, an Amplifier Geared for MP3
description: Ion Audios mission, it seems, is to bring old-school technology into the 21st century. For those with a collection of vinyl records, it has turntables that connect directly to computers to digitize tracks from the likes of Jefferson Airplane and the Ohio Players.

title: Resignations Leave Trentons Pension-Investment Board at Quorum Plus One
description: A flurry of resignations has left the board that oversees New Jerseys pension investments perilously close to not having enough members to conduct its business.

title: With Bad Suit Splits, Go With No-Trump
description: The fifth and final session of the Cavendish Invitational Pairs, which took place last Sunday in Henderson, Nev., turned into a close race. The Norwegians Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness had led after the fourth session but suffered a couple of disasters and dropped to fifth. The Americans Bobby Levin of New York City and Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y., who had been in front after the second session, moved up steadily on the rail, putting their noses in front near the end and holding off the challengers. Second were Drew Casen and Mike Passell of Las Vegas, with Bruce Rogoff of Upper Grandview, N.Y., and Louk Verhees from the Netherlands third.

title: Chrysler Sale Unavoidable, Chief Says
description: STUTTGART, Germany, May 16  On Monday evening at Chryslers offices in Auburn Hills, Mich., Dieter Zetsche held what is likely to be his last, and most poignant, session of Ask Dr. Z.

title: Pennsylvania Voters Reject Tax Plan to Finance Schools
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 16  Pennsylvania voters overwhelmingly rejected a plan to reduce property taxes in return for higher local income taxes as a way of financing school districts, officials said Wednesday.

title: Clash of Hope and Fear as Venezuela Seizes Land
description: URACHICHE, Venezuela  The squatters arrive before dawn with machetes and rifles, surround the well-ordered rows of sugar cane and threaten to kill anyone who interferes. Then they light a match to the crops and declare the land their own.

title: Dollar Coin of John Adams Is to Be Released Today
description: The second design in the presidential one-dollar coin series, featuring John Adams, is to be released today by the United States Mint.

title: Why Is Income Inequality in America So Pronounced? Consider Education
description: The most commonly cited culprits for the income inequality in America  outsourcing, immigration and the gains of the super-rich  are diversions from the main issue. Instead, the problem is largely one of (a lack of) education.

description: A federal magistrate judge yesterday released about 600 pages of secret documents relating to police preparations for the 2004 Republican National Convention, held in New York.

description: He is no Spider-Man, but Papageno held his own at the movies this season.

title: Amazon to Sell Music Without Copy Protection
description: Amazon.com, the biggest online seller of CDs, is joining the movement against copy-protection software for digital music. It plans to sell songs that can be freely copied to any computer, cellphone or music player, including the iPod from Apple.

title: Storms Knock Out Power for Thousands
description: Heavy thunderstorms across the region last night caused nearly 30,000 customers in Westchester County to lose power, Consolidated Edison officials said. The hardest-hit towns were Cortlandt, New Castle, Bedford, Ossining and Mount Vernon. In northern New Jersey, Public Service Electric and Gas reported that about 7,000 customers lost power.

title: For Wolfowitz, a 2nd Chance Dissolves Into Failure
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Paul D. Wolfowitz was ready to move on from the Pentagon in early 2005. But he had been thwarted in his effort to become defense secretary or national security adviser. The war in Iraq, meanwhile, had deteriorated. So when the World Bank presidency came open, he jumped at the opportunity.

title: Ooh, That Face! Its Model Behavior, Online
description: Kate Moss was discovered by a modeling scout as she waited for a plane at Kennedy International Airport. Twiggy was noticed in a suburban London hair salon. Claudia Schiffer began modeling after she was spotted dancing in a Dsseldorf nightclub.

title: Danger: Plant Sales Ahead
description: LANCASTER, Pa.

title: Older, Better, but Harder to Dress
description: AT the start of any fashion writers career there is, waiting at the end, the dreaded article about older women and how they can never find clothes appropriate for their age. I swore on a stack of Vogues I would never write such a piece. It was totem journalism, predictable, worked at. Even the term appropriate has always seemed to me old hat, with violets on top.

title: Awaiting Defining Pitchers
description: Pressed and spotless, their uniforms hang neatly in the clubhouses at Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium, but neither pitcher is there. Their lockers are as empty as the slots in their teams rotations. And until Roger Clemens and Pedro Martnez each reappear, neither the Yankees nor the Mets will really know how high (or how low) they can go this season.

title: Investors Plan New Monorail Linking Soweto to Johannesburg
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 16  A Malaysian investor pledged on Wednesday to link central Johannesburg to its famous suburb, Soweto, via a 27-mile, $1.7 billion monorail to be built and operated entirely with private money.

title: Psychiatrist Says Defendant in Sex Case Wanted to Die
description: A psychiatrist said yesterday that Peter Braunstein, a writer accused of sex abuse, was suicidal after his arrest. She said he told her he did not care how his trial turned out because he was going to kill himself anyway.

title: Inconspicuous Drama, Now Playing at the World Financial Center
description: All the worlds a stage, as two uniformed police officers discovered yesterday. For about 30 seconds at the World Financial Center, Officer John Monteforte and Officer Jason Lagnese were walk-ons in a play called Remembrance.

title: Needing to Win in the Worst Way, the Nets Do It
description: CLEVELAND, May 16  Late-game pratfalls put the Nets on the edge of playoff elimination, and a disastrous fourth quarter should have ended their season Wednesday night. Only a strange brew of stout defense, good mojo and striking ineptitude by the Cleveland Cavaliers saved them.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the extensive medical care that Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey received at Cooper University Hospital in Camden after a traffic accident on April 12 misstated the date of Mr. Corzines release in some copies. It was April 30, not May 1.

title: Blair Bids Farewell to Bush in Bittersweet Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The poignancy of Prime Minister Tony Blairs final White House news conference was perhaps summed up best today when a British reporter asked President Bush, his own time in office winding down, whether he was partly responsible for Mr. Blairs leadership ending sooner than either man might have liked.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some copies yesterday about the debate by the 10 Republican presidential candidates at the University of South Carolina in Columbia referred incorrectly to support for the war in Iraq among the candidates. One of them, Representative Ron Paul of Texas, opposes it; they do not all support the war. The article also misidentified the home state of another candidate, Representative Tom Tancredo, in some copies. It is Colorado, not Arizona.

title: Taller, Faster Officers on Patrol as Police Dept. Gets 10 Segways
description: A city already patrolled by police horses and bicycles, police speedboats and helicopters, and all manner of cars, vans and armored vehicles bearing the emblem NYPD, now has a new crime-fighting tool: the rolling lollipop known as the Segway.

title: Mr. Gonzaless Incredible Adventure
description: There were many fascinating threads to the testimony on Tuesday by the former deputy attorney general, James Comey, who described the night in March 2004 when two top White House officials tried to pressure an ailing and hospitalized Attorney General John Ashcroft into endorsing President Bushs illegal wiretapping operation.

title: A Defense We Just Dont Need (Yet)
description: Washington

title: Paying More for a Printer, but Less for Ink
description: In some ways, the world of electronics is a great big game of Us vs. Them, filled with imbalances of power that the little people cant do anything about. Through learned helplessness, weve come to accept that the gadget we buy today will be pass in a year  period. Calling technical support is going to be a nightmare  tough rocks. Buying cartridges for an inkjet printer will cost twice as much as the printer itself  each year.

title: Energy Standards Needed, Report Says
description: Energy saving opportunities in American homes are immense with current technology, but new product standard mandates will be needed, according to a study by the McKinsey Global Institute.

title: Senate Rejects Iraq Troop Withdrawal
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  Congressional Democratic leaders signaled on Wednesday that they were ready to give ground to end an impasse with President Bush over war spending after the Senate soundly rejected a Democratic plan to block money for major combat operations in Iraq beginning next spring.

title: Wealth Is a Common Factor Among 2008 Hopefuls
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, who just six years ago told a divorce court he had only $7,000 in assets under his control, has amassed a net worth of more than $30 million, much of it from paid speeches.

title: Coalition to Make Buildings Energy-Efficient
description: A coalition of 16 of the worlds biggest cities, five banks, one former president and companies and groups that modernize aging buildings on Wednesday pledged investments of billions of dollars to cut urban energy use and releases of heat-trapping gases linked to global warming.

title: Belarus Blocked From Membership in U.N. Human Rights Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, May 17  Belarus, one of the worlds most repressive states, was blocked from gaining membership on the United Nations Human Rights Council today after being outvoted in favor of Bosnia, a late entry.

title: Doctors, Drugs and the Poor
description: Its one of those questions no one tells you about when you enter medical practice. What do you do when patients come who cant pay? Some doctors decline to see them. I have expenses to pay and a family to feed, theyll argue.

title: After Baby, Boss Comes Calling
description: AMY STEPNOWSKI spent 12 years as a banker specializing in Latin America. Which means she spent the better part of 12 years on airplanes. While pregnant with the second of her three children, she decided that that kind of globetrotting didnt allow her a family life, so she left JPMorgan Chase & Company in 2002. In the years that followed she didnt have time to think about work, or going back to work, or actually much of anything at all that didnt involve children, she says.

title: Fixing the Student Loan Mess
description: Colleges that have been caught steering students to loan companies in exchange for kickbacks and goodies have often blamed financial aid officers, insisting they were violating school policy. Congress, which clearly knows better, is fashioning bills that would explicitly outlaw collusion between lenders and schools while closing loopholes that the two have routinely used to enrich themselves at the expense of students.

title: Giulianis Abortion Figures Are Compared to National Trend
description: In the first two Republican presidential debates, Rudolph W. Giuliani has addressed questions about his stand on abortion by citing figures showing that abortions declined when he was mayor of New York, while adoptions increased.

description: My name is Philip. If we are lucky, then by the time you receive this, I will be dead.

title: Actor, Star, Singer, Raconteur: Baby, Its Crowded Inside
description: Peter Gallagher has the gift of gab. This New York actor, born into the Irish storytelling tradition, spins amusing yarns with an ease that turns the kind of polished after-dinner remarks usually accompanied by brandy and cigars at a black-tie function into yarns swapped by regular guys over beers in the local pub.

title: Lawmakers Near Agreement on New Immigration Rules
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  Senators from both parties said Wednesday that they were close to agreement on a new system of selecting immigrants that would give greater weight to education and to job skills deemed helpful to the economy.

title: Mother and Daughter, Each Coming Into Her Own
description: On Tuesday night Gilmore Girls ended its seven-season run, and its departure, I predict, will in some small way serve to boost the collective self-esteem of a certain population of American parents.

title: Bronx: Probation for Charter School
description: The Department of Education has placed a turbulent Bronx charter school on probation to address problems of teacher turnover, a department spokeswoman said yesterday. The International Leadership Charter School, a high school on Exterior Street in Kingsbridge, is under investigation by its trustees after complaints that resulted in a student walkout last week. Since the school opened in September, all eight of its original teachers have resigned or been fired. All have been replaced. The principal, Elaine Ruiz Lopez, was removed from management duties last week and is currently handling long-term projects like fund-raising, a school spokesman said. The Department of Education oversees 31 publicly financed but privately managed charter schools in the city. Twenty-seven other charter schools are authorized by the state or the State University of New York.

title: When the Small Nations Get the Biggest Weapons
description: William Langewiesche begins The Atomic Bazaar with a reference to Hiroshima and a chilling, methodical description of exactly how a nuclear blast destroys a city. Literally and figuratively this is overkill. He did not need such a drastic way of attracting attention to his books true subject: the illicit and unstoppable spread of nuclear weapons to some of the worlds most volatile nations. His book insightfully examines the perils created by this leveling of the global playing field.

title: Manhattan: Developer for Hospital Site
description: The Rudin family has been selected as the developer for a site on Seventh Avenue owned and occupied by St. Vincents Hospital, which is relocating, hospital officials announced yesterday. Under the plan, the hospital will move from its current location, on Seventh Avenue between 11th and 12th Streets, to Seventh Avenue between 12th and 13th Streets, said Michael Fagan, a hospital spokesman. He said a modern hospital would replace the current collection of buildings. Once the new building is open, the current site will be redeveloped and the Rudins will pay St. Vincents an amount to be determined in part by the type of project approved by the city, Mr. Fagan said. He said the money would go toward the cost of the new hospital, estimated at $650 million.

title: Norman Frank, 82, Public Relations Adviser, Dies
description: Norman Frank, the public relations executive who in 1966 devised the strategy by which New York Citys police union turned back Mayor John V. Lindsays attempt to create a civilian complaint review board, died Friday near his home in Miami. He was 82.

title: A Collision Course for Physics
description: Excitement is building among high-energy physicists as construction in Europe of a huge new particle accelerator nears completion, with the first experiments scheduled for next year. It will be the purest exercise of pure science with researchers spending billions of dollars pursuing knowledge with no practical use, but that could add to our understanding of the universes fundamental constituents.

title: Gay Youths Find Place to Call Home in Specialty Shelters
description: DETROIT  One girl said she started living on the streets after her mother beat her for dressing like a boy. Another said she ran away from home after her father pulled a gun on her for hanging around with so many tomboys. A third said she left home after a family acquaintance raped her because she was a lesbian and he wanted to straighten her out.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A theater review in Weekend on Friday about Couples, a group of eight short plays at WorkShop Theater Company on West 36th Street in Manhattan, misidentified the actors in Right Sensation and misidentified a character. The actors are Jacqueline M. Raposo and Michael Anderson  not Cailin McDonald and Anthony Aibel, who appear in Invisible Woman. The character played by Ms. Raposo is Paula  not Susanne, a character in Invisible Woman that is played by Ms. McDonald.

title: The Lower (Far) East Side
description: ST. Marks Place and neighboring Ninth Street, long a mecca to punkers of every stripe, has become a magnet to a new generation of hipsters. Pouring into this grotty swath of Manhattan from cities as far-flung as Tokyo, Singapore and Seoul, they take time to sample local confections like green tea tiramis and to show off a style that is largely defined by wild-child hair and incongruously fancy footgear.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column yesterday about plans for three Tintin movies misspelled the given name of one of the filmmakers. He is Steven Spielberg, not Stephen.

title: Watching a Show Live, With 72 Hours to Do It
description: AS the big broadcast networks complete a week of previews for Madison Avenue of their schedules for the coming season, the same words are on everyones lips: not the title of an appealing new series or the name of a promising young star, but the phrase live plus three.

title: East Orange: Ex-Clerk Is Sentenced
description: A former clerk at the State Motor Vehicle Commission office in East Orange has been sentenced to five years in state prison for selling drivers licenses to unauthorized people, Attorney General Stuart Rabner announced yesterday. The clerk, Lawrence McCross, 29, of East Orange, pleaded guilty last June to conspiring to commit official misconduct. He admitted to issuing about 25 licenses to people who did not present any of the required identification documents, for an average fee of $2,500.

title: With Help From Hypnotist, St. Johns Goes to Regional
description: In his first time on a golf course this year, after two weeks of winter hibernation, George Zolotas shot a 61 for St. Johns. That pleased the teams sports hypnotist because Zolotas, his prize pupil, had stayed calm during and after a stretch of eagle-birdie-eagle-birdie.

title: Decades Later, a Guilty Plea in 3 Murders in the Buffalo Area
description: BUFFALO, May 16  A 49-year-old factory worker pleaded guilty Wednesday to murdering three women, effectively closing a case that involved at least a dozen rapes dating back about a quarter century and the wrongful imprisonment of another man for more than two decades.

title: As the Networks Order New Shows, Fox Moves to Consolidate Its Gains
description: With its prime-time lineup in its strongest position ever, the Fox network has ordered a new slate of programming intended to consolidate recent overall gains and shore up the networks weak point, the early months of the television season.

title: 2 Russian Churches, Split by War, Reuniting
description: MOSCOW, May 16  The atmosphere was tense, laced with nearly a century of mistrust and bitter feelings, when President Vladimir V. Putin met in New York in 2003 with leaders of an migr church that had broken with the Russian Orthodox Church after the Bolshevik Revolution. The breakaway church had vowed never to return as long as the godless regime was in power.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some copies yesterday about primary voting for mayor of Philadelphia misstated the last year the office was held by a Republican. It was 1952, not 1948.

title: Yolanda King, 51, Actor and Dr. Kings Daughter, Dies
description: Yolanda King, the eldest child of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. who melded her fathers message of racial equality and nonviolence with her own calling as an actor and a motivational speaker, died on Tuesday in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 51.

title: Korean Train Crossing Seen as Sign of Progress
description: MUNSAN, South Korea, May 17  Trains crossed the border between North and South Korea today for the first time in 56 years, in what was hailed by both countries as a key step toward reconciliation on the divided Korean Peninsula.

title: A Bright Future in Shades
description: LIKE pens and umbrellas, I usually buy sunglasses in the $20-or-less range because I know I will lose or destroy them. The last pair I had were plastic shades from a farmacia in Mexico. I sat on them, they cracked, the end.

title: For 08 Rsums, Dont Ask Them to Fill in Blanks
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  Stealing a page from the Soviet playbook, the current crop of presidential candidates has taken to eliminating whole chapters of their histories.

title: Dubai Investment Unit Acquires a 2.2% Stake in Deutsche Bank
description: DIFC Investments, the investment arm of the Dubai International Financial Center, has become one of the largest shareholders in Deutsche Bank with a 2.2 percent stake, Dubai officials said yesterday.

title: Wolfowitz Said to Push for Deal to Quit
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  After six weeks of combating efforts to oust him as president of the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz began Wednesday to negotiate the terms under which he would resign, in return for the dropping or softening of the charge that he had engaged in misconduct, bank officials said.

title: Israel Strikes at Hamas Compound
description: JERUSALEM, May 17  Israel continued its attacks on Hamas today with three airstrikes, killing at least three Palestinians, while five more Palestinians died in factional fighting despite a new cease-fire between the Hamas and Fatah factions.

title: Sarkozy Gets Off to a Fast Start as President of France
description: PARIS, May 16  Nicolas Sarkozy is proud of his reputation as an impatient politician driven by big ambitions and limitless energy, and on his first day as president of France, it was not enough to step back and savor the moment.

title: Waiting for Thabo Mbeki
description: Will Robert Mugabes outrages never stop? For months he has been jailing and brutalizing opposition leaders and trampling the rule of law in order to guarantee himself another rigged victory in next years presidential elections.

title: Amazon to Sell Music Without Copy Protection
description: After years of industry speculation, Amazon.com is getting into the digital music business.

title: Wolfowitz to Resign From World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Paul D. Wolfowitz this evening ended weeks of furor over charges of favoritism toward a bank employee who is his female companion and announced his resignation as president of the World Bank, effective June 30.

title: New Demographic Racial Gap Emerges
description: With the number of nonwhite Americans above 100 million for the first time, demographers are identifying an emerging racial generation gap.

title: A Vigorous Art Sale Makes Auction History
description: Buyers from all over the world spent millions of dollars at Christies last night as if it were play money. Together they made auction history: the most successful sale of postwar and contemporary art ever. Records were set for 26 artists, including Andy Warhol, Jasper Johns, Gerhard Richter and Damien Hirst.

title: Magazine Suspends Its Run in History
description: After more than 50 years American Heritage, the magazine that furnished not just the minds but, in its original hardcover format, the dens of generations of American history buffs, is suspending publication, its editor, Richard F. Snow, said last week.

title: For New Transit Chief, Is Frost on the Pumpkin?
description: The new boss man of subways and buses, Howard H. Roberts Jr., is said to be partial to the poetry of Robert Frost. Not a bad choice of a muse, even if Frost was a rural type who may have thought  assuming he dwelt on the matter at all  that BMT was shorthand for a kind of sandwich.

title: Brown to Take Labor Nomination Unopposed
description: LONDON, May 17  Opening a new era in British politics, the ruling Labor Party confirmed today that Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, had emerged as the sole candidate to assume the party leadership and thus succeed Tony Blair as prime minister when he steps down in June.

title: The President and Wolfowitz
description: As Paul Wolfowitz is to the World Bank, the U.S. is becoming to the world.

title: With Suspensions, Series Gains Another Layer of Heat
description: PHOENIX, May 16  Throughout this series, the Phoenix Suns have been the smaller, quicker younger brothers eager to be recognized by the N.B.A. hierarchy.

title: Mets Minor Leaguer Barred 50 Games for Drug Violation
description: Lino Urdaneta, a minor league pitcher who was on the Mets 25-man roster two days ago, tested positive for a performance-enhancing substance and was suspended for 50 games, Major League Baseball said yesterday.

title: Two Old Masters, Partnered Perhaps With New Ones
description: To find any ballet that brings tears to the eyes is cause for celebration, but in New York City Ballets quadruple bill Four Voices I find two. Not that these are tearjerkers. If tears come at all here (and doubtless I am in a minority), then they do so in a spontaneous sense of emotional recognition. A feeling we have known in life is happening again onstage, writ large to music.

title: Democrats Agree on a $2.9 Trillion Budget
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  House and Senate Democratic leaders reached agreement on Wednesday on a $2.9 trillion budget for 2008 that envisions a return to budget surpluses by 2012 and assumes that some of President Bushs tax cuts will be allowed to expire.

title: For Teen Pitcher, New Team, Same Dream
description: On a nationally prominent team of 12-year-old baseball sensations, Jarrod Petree was the kid with the golden arm. When PLAY visited with him last year in Apopka, Fla., Jarrod and his travel-ball team, the Central Florida Express, were midway through what would be a stellar season, ending with 60 wins and just 6 losses. Jarrod would go 14-0 on the mound and hit .412. Yet the pile of victories was not enough to convince the overworked volunteer head coach, Ben Nichols, to take the Express into another year. The team dissolved last fall, but has been mostly reconstituted for 2007 under the leadership of Tim Petree, Jarrods dad, and Joe Winker, the father of a talented outfielder named Jesse, who is Jarrods best friend.

description: BOUNCE-N-SLIDEThe Fitness Guru, 77 Front Street, Brooklyn;www.fitnessgurunyc.com. $25 for a single class.

description: FORT WORTH, May 16  Shareholders of AMR, the parent company of American Airlines, rejected at the annual meeting on Wednesday two proposals aimed at setting controls on executive pay.

title: Lawyers on Haditha Panel Peer Into Fog of War
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 16  On its face, the military hearing that ended here Tuesday concerned just one issue: whether an inexperienced Marine lawyers failure to question the killing of Iraqi civilians in Haditha 18 months ago constituted a criminal dereliction of duty.

title: A Fishing Hole Turns Into a Morass
description: MAHWAH, N.J.

title: Myer Shark, Lawyer Who Fought Utility, Is Dead at 94
description: Myer Shark, a Minnesota consumer lawyer whose last case sought to recover $300 million of taxes that electric customers paid a utility but that federal and state governments never received, died yesterday in a suburb of Minneapolis, days after filing the final papers in the case. He was 94.

title: Googles One-Stop Search to Yield Text and Images
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., May 16  Google said on Wednesday that it was changing its approach to Internet searches by combining results from its established Web search service with offerings that help users find videos, images, maps and other content.

title: Unity Fractures as Palestinians Battle in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, May 16  Gaza City was shuttered on Wednesday as gunmen took over rooftops and top-floor apartments. Most everyone else huddled fearfully indoors on the fourth day of factional Palestinian fighting that is drawing in the Israeli military.

title: Sderot Residents Evacuate to Escape Rocket Attacks
description: SDEROT, Israel, May 17  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert paid an unannounced visit to this border town on Thursday night to show solidarity with its residents after days of rocket fire from the nearby Gaza Strip.

title: A Point-and-Shoot Camera Thats Quicker on the Shutter
description: Some pocket point-and-shoot cameras may skimp on extras, especially when compared with pricier models aimed at professionals, but Canons new PowerShot SD850 IS Digital Elph packs in quite a few features.

title: South Koreans Jostle to Take an English Test
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 16  Thailand has its attractions for foreign visitors: its famed temples, seaside resorts, tom yum soup. But what drew Oh Sun-yee to Bangkok recently for a three-day stay was something considerably less recreational. Like an increasing number of South Koreans, Ms. Oh went to take the Test of English as a Foreign Language, or Toefl.

title: Parallel Paths Diverging Sharply
description: On a hot evening this week in the Museum of Modern Arts garden, Marie-Jose Kravis, the museum president, and her husband, Henry, played host to more than 900 guests who mingled near two giant Richard Serra sculptures. Her presence was cool and reserved, and her outfit of a shimmering sequin top and dark slacks struck a conservative tone amid the sun-fired skin and tummy-hugging gowns that the wives of other moguls favored.

title: Spain: Madrid Bombing Suspects on Hunger Strike
description: Nine defendants in the Madrid train-bombing trial began a hunger strike, joining four others who stopped eating last Thursday to protest the trial, the prison authority and a lawyer for the suspects said. Javier Gmez Bermdez, the presiding judge, ejected two of the original hunger-strikers from the Madrid courtroom yesterday after they slumped to the floor, apparently weak from dehydration. He said he would authorize prison officials to force-feed them, if necessary. He added that the trial would not be suspended under any circumstances. The 13 men, mainly Moroccans, are among 29 suspects who have been on trial since Feb. 15 on charges connected to the bomb attacks on Madrid commuter trains that killed 191 people in 2004.

title: Fans Cram Into Disney Bandbox for a Major League Attraction
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., May 16  At Bostons Fenway Park, the Green Monster is a tall, hard wall in left field. At The Ballpark, in Disneys Wide World of Sports complex, the big green thing in left field is a soft, grassy hillside rising from the fence to a row of bushes and a grove of trees.

title: Loyal to Bush but Big Thorn in Republicans Side
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  For a loyal George W. Bush Republican, James B. Comey has made a remarkable amount of trouble for the White House.

title: Sosa Pitches Mets Past Cubs After Long Wait
description: The start of the Mets game against the Chicago Cubs last night was delayed because of rain for 3 hours 7 minutes. The first pitch was thrown at 10:17 p.m., and the last out was made at 12:53 this morning.

title: Albany Agrees on Law Against Sexual and Labor Trafficking
description: ALBANY, May 16  State lawmakers and Gov. Eliot Spitzer said Wednesday that they had agreed to make labor- and sex-trafficking felonies, breaking a deadlock on an issue many thought should have been resolved long ago.

title: Pieces Come Together Slowly for the Yankees
description: CHICAGO, May 16  When the Yankees evened their record last week, they hoped it would be the start of their climb. Instead, they have played so unevenly that a .500 record was a mirage by Wednesday afternoon.

title: New Research on Athlete Hydration
description: As they sweat and drip through a summer workout, few athletes fret about overdrinking. (Theyre probably more concerned about parched shriveling.) But even in hot weather, some people develop hyponatremia  or water overload. During the London Marathon, held on an unseasonably warm day in April, the lone fatality was due to brain swelling from overdrinking.

title: Traveling Light, but Still Pretty
description: LISA HOFFMANS line, Night & Day 24 Hour Skincare, packages products in sizes that can probably pass muster with even the most ornery airport security agents. Other brands that help skirt the roadblocks of modern travel:

title: Financial Angels Band Together
description: Two weeks ago, 40 successful businesspeople sat around a horseshoe table in a university lecture hall firing questions at four aspiring entrepreneurs. The aspirants were giving 20-minute presentations about their start-up companies to the Los Angeles chapter of Tech Coast Angels, a group that invests in new businesses.

title: High, Low and in Between
description: THIS years Kitchen and Bath Industry Show, held last week in Las Vegas, brought together more than 1,000 manufacturers from around the world, but the wares they showed were playing to very different audiences.

title: As Giuliani Strays From G.O.P. Base, He Sticks to 9/11
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  The most striking moment of the Republican presidential debate on Tuesday night may not have been the back-and-forth on abortion or immigration. It was arguably when Rudolph W. Giuliani won resounding applause for rebutting another candidates suggestion that American policies might have helped incite the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report by The Associated Press in the Metro Briefing column on Monday, about the arrest of a man from Glen Cove, N.Y., on homicide charges in connection with a fatal six-car crash on Long Island, gave the incorrect name in some copies for the town where the crash occurred. It is Old Brookville, not Old Brookfield.

title: Hardly Shocking, Derby Winner Street Sense Is Favorite
description: BALTIMORE, May 16  There is a field of nine signed on for the 132nd running of the Preakness Stakes, but eight horses are running for second-place money behind the Kentucky Derby winner, Street Sense. Or at least that is what the trainers and owners here at the post-position draw were suggesting Wednesday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about the Maison Tropicale, a small house built in 1951 by the French designer Jean Prouv that is on display in Long Island City, Queens, pending an auction in June, referred incorrectly to another Maison Tropicale at the Centre Pompidou in Paris. It is in fact already on exhibit; the exhibition is not pending.

title: A Suspected Serial Arsonist Rattles Nerves in Newport
description: NEWPORT, R.I., May 16  Volunteers are spending nights patrolling the grounds of the 281-year-old Trinity Episcopal Church here. The Hill Association, a neighborhood group, is urging residents to watch for suspicious people in the shadows. Bruce Rader now makes sure to keep a light on in his backyard.

title: Higher Taxes Rejected in Oregon, and Counties Will Trim Services
description: SEATTLE, May 16  Voters in southwestern Oregon on Tuesday rejected proposals to increase local taxes to offset the loss of federal subsidies.

title: Big Storm Helps Shrink New Jersey Wildfire
description: A powerful thunderstorm that drenched much of the Northeast last night helped shrink a huge wildfire that has burned through 14,000 acres of pine forest in southern New Jersey since Tuesday.

title: Computer Sales Lead H.P. to Strong Revenue
description: Led by surging computer sales, Hewlett-Packard reported a 12.8 percent increase today in its quarterly revenues.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Afghans Say Gunfire From NATO Soldiers Wounded 5 Civilians
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, May 16  NATO soldiers driving through this southern city shot and wounded five civilians late Tuesday, local residents and police officials said Wednesday. The spokeswoman for the NATO forces, Lt. Col. Angela Billings, said, though, that they had no information that such shootings had occurred.

title: U.S.  Ambassador to Iraq Ready to Talk to Iran
description: BAGHDAD, May 17  The United States ambassador to Iraq said today that he was ready to sit down any time with Iranian officials for talks on ways of stabilizing Iraq.

title: Pants in a Twist? Try Some Knickers
description: URBAN cyclists cant win. Snug-fitting Lycra shorts offer a padded chamois and seams that dont chafe, but lack style. Regular pants with rolled-up cuffs may be more fashionable but can become clammy for anything longer than a short ride.

title: For Ochoa, Being a Role Model Comes With the Territory
description: CLIFTON, N.J., May 16  When Lorena Ochoa left Mexico seven years ago to attend college in the United States, she gave up a cocoon of familiarity for long bouts of homesickness.

title: Mr. Right, It Turns Out, Does Not Take Classes
description: AFTER more than two years of disheartening online dating, Charlotte Kullen resolved to spend less time pursuing men and more time pursuing her hobbies. She plunged into tennis, running, sailing, horseback riding, fitness boot camp and scuba diving classes, assuming that somewhere between the situps and the strapping on of fins she might meet some eligible prospects.

title: A Fire-Breathing Laptop Powered Up for Entertainment
description: If you nickname your companys new laptop the Dragon, it had better be impressive. The Hewlett-Packard Pavilion HDX lacks wings and scales, but it does have a 20-inch screen and can handle HD DVD discs and HDMI video.

title: Britain: Browns Only Challenger Pulls Out
description: Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the Exchequer, cemented his bid to replace Tony Blair as Labor Party leader and prime minister when he steps down next month. Mr. Brown, left, the partys overwhelming favorite, had faced the outside possibility of a symbolic challenge from John McDonnell, a leader of the left wing. Late yesterday, Mr. McDonnell conceded that he had been unable to muster sufficient backing from party lawmakers for his challenge, leaving Mr. Brown as the only candidate. The final tally of support for Mr. Brown among the Labor Party legislators is to be announced today.

title: Cuban Music, Good for Dancing, and for Thinking About as Well
description: Cuban music can withstand endless revisions, and the singer-songwriter Jose Conde is taking his turn, as he suggested at Joes Pub on Tuesday night. Born in Miami to Cuban parents, Mr. Conde has been working in New York for the last 10 years, slowly formulating a kind of Afro-Cuban music with an enlarged frame. It now brings together son, guajira, guaracha with New Orleans funk, Nigerian Afrobeat, South American cumbia, James Brown rhythms, Haitian compas, Brazilian afoxe, New York City boogaloo and even jam-band stuff predicated on electric guitars as much as hand drums.

title: Fire Spotlights Concerns of Living Near Fighter Jets
description: As hundreds of firefighters battled for the second day to control a huge wildfire touched off by a flare at a military firing range on the edge of the Pine Barrens in southern New Jersey, some of those who live near the blaze questioned yesterday whether more safety precautions should be put in place.

title: New Producer at Nightly News Seeks to Regain NBC Dominance
description: Alexandra Wallace, who got the equivalent of a battlefield commission when she was named executive producer of NBC Nightly News with Brian Williams two months ago, keeps her plans for the broadcast on a to-do list streaked with tight scribbles from a black, felt-tip marker. She calls it her crazy person list, and she is continually cutting and pasting it, as if it were a worn map to buried treasure. (Mr. Williams has another analogy: Its like her blankie, he says.)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about clashes between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza referred incorrectly in some copies to the unidentified Palestinian shown standing in the burned offices of Fatah in Gaza City. The person is a woman.

title: Pakistan Judicial Crisis Adds to Pressure on Media
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 16  Legal and political wrangling over the suspension of the chief justice of Pakistans Supreme Court by President Pervez Musharraf appears to be leading to new pressures on the media, news organizations and media advocacy groups say.

title: Room to Improve
Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,390 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans this week:

title: Secret Ingredients: Their Husbands
description: JO WOOD, wife of the Rolling Stones guitarist Ron Wood, spent 30 years touring with the band, and apart from being a mother, her only occupation was helping to dress her husband for his shows. Now that their children are out of the house, she has launched Jo Wood Organics, a line of oils, creams and candles that she sells in New York at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Feeling Short of Real Heroes, Thus Fond of a Fake One
description: PLZEN, Czech Republic  Zdenek Sverak, dressed in a professorial gray suit with a red club tie, nodded a greeting to the sold-out crowd in a theater here and began his lecture about Jara da Cimrman, the greatest Czech of all time.

title: Brooklyn: Principals Ratify Contract
description: The union representing New York City school principals and assistant principals voted overwhelmingly yesterday to ratify a contract deal with New York City. The new contract provides raises of more than 23 percent and also establishes a new executive principal position that will pay bonuses of up to $25,000 a year to principals who agree to work for up to three years in a troubled school. The union, the Council of School Supervisors and Administrators, said that the ratification vote was 3,633 to 266. The deal, which is retroactive to July 1, 2003, and runs through March 5, 2010, will increase the starting salary of elementary school principals to $123,456 from $100,242. The maximum base pay for high school principals will rise to $154,295 from $125,282. Starting salaries for assistant principals who work all year rather than just the 10 months that schools are in session will rise to $108,869 from $88,398, and their maximum salary will be $130,100, up from $108,869.

title: Bradley Takes Reins as Coach of U.S. Team
description: Bob Bradley  tall, slender and plain talking  shrugged off the long process that ultimately led to his selection yesterday as the head coach of the United States mens national soccer team. And he said his style would remain unchanged as he took charge through the 2010 World Cup.

title: Gas May Have Harmed Troops, Scientists Say
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  Scientists working with the Defense Department have found evidence that a low-level exposure to sarin nerve gas  the kind experienced by more than 100,000 American troops in the Persian Gulf war of 1991  could have caused lasting brain deficits in former service members.

title: Unfriendly Views on U.S.-Backed Arabic TV
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  Toward the end of a Congressional hearing on Wednesday on American efforts to win more popular support in the Arab world, Representative Gary L. Ackerman, Democrat of New York, got sidetracked.

title: Leaving Her Mark, Sometimes With Tape
description: The art industry requires that at least one young artist be shot into the stratosphere every few years. The painter Dana Schutz was the choice in 2002, when she was in her mid-20s and barely out of school. Shes been producing and selling like mad ever since. Last year she had a museum career retrospective. It covered four years.

title: Yankees Are Working on a Settlement With Swindal
description: CHICAGO, May 16  The Yankees are negotiating a buyout of the general partner Steve Swindal in which the team would pay him about $5 million for what he is owed contractually in exchange for his leaving the organization.

title: Follow the Bouncing Ball  to Oden or Durant?
description: Its time for the N.B.A. draft lottery, when the dregs of the league gaze to the heavens  and watch the Ping-Pong balls flutter  in hope of a quick fix. For this go-round, coming on Tuesday, one question hovers over the proceedings: Greg Oden or Kevin Durant? A dominating big man or a perimeter wizard who can also excel inside?

title: Sony Expects Recovery After Big Quarterly Loss
description: TOKYO, May 16  Sony posted its worst quarterly loss in four years on Wednesday, but said strong television sales and hit movies like Spider-Man 3 will put it back on course by year-end when it expects a record profit.

title: 19th-Century Vision of India, With Room for Two Ballets
description: There is nothing quite like La Bayadre. That may be a good thing, given the foolishness that jostles for predominance with exquisite classicism in this spectacle of late-19th-century ballet. That American Ballet Theater chose the work to open its spring season proper on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House can be seen as a statement of belief. That is, for all the adventurousness of its repertory over the years, Ballet Theater has been one of the worlds great classical troupes. La Bayadre provides a bridge from the narrative-heavy extravaganzas of the mid-19th century to the pure-dance choreography of George Balanchine, an heir, after all, to Russian ballet tradition through his early training.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Monday with a sports article about the reaction of a community in New Hampshire to the deaths of a police officer and a cousin of the ski racer Bode Miller in a violent confrontation misspelled the cousins given name. It was Liko Kenney, not Leko. The error also appeared in the article in some copies.

title: Soup Up Your Everyday Computer With a Blu-ray Drive
description: PCs, like automobiles, can become something entirely different with just a few tweaks and additions. Take the Pioneer BDC-2202. Today your PC is just a DVD-playing, file-storing computer. Tomorrow, with the help of this Blu-ray drive, it becomes a high-def hot rod.

title: Racecourse Experience Could Decide Preakness
description: BALTIMORE, May 16  Mario Pino knows almost everything about Pimlico Race Course. He knows every nook, cranny, nuance and trick to get into the winners circle, something he has done quite often in the 28 years he has been around Maryland racing.

title: All Cooped Up in a Manhattan Co-op
description: LET me explain why my 12-year-old had a chicken coop in her bedroom.

title: With Hussein Gone, Other Iraqi Trials Lose Impact
description: BAGHDAD, May 16  When the man Iraqis know as Chemical Ali made a final plea of innocence to the Iraqi High Tribunal last week, the courts public galleries were all but empty, and there was not a single Iraqi or foreign reporter on hand.

title: Sales Practices at Dell Draw New York Suit
description: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, announced yesterday that his office had filed a lawsuit against Dell Inc. and its Dell Financial Services unit, accusing them of deceptive business practices and of failing to provide adequate customer service.

title: Biggest Building Site in Manhattan Up for Auction
description: It is the largest building site left in Manhattan, 26 acres on the Far West Side, where the Bloomberg administration envisions the equivalent of five Empire State Buildings rising on $1 billion worth of concrete columns over bustling railyards.

title: Students Gain Only Marginally on Test of U.S. History
description: Federal officials reported yesterday that students in 4th, 8th and 12th grades had scored modestly higher on an American history test than five years earlier, although more than half of high school seniors still showed poor command of basic facts like the effect of the cotton gin on the slave economy or the causes of the Korean War.

title: Shimmering Anthems to the Apocalypse
description: Everything blurred when the Silversun Pickups played a sold-out Webster Hall on Tuesday night. Brian Auberts guitar playing was a haze of tremolo strumming, distortion and reverb, while his voice was high and hoarse, all frayed edges. Nikki Monningers bass lines stayed low, providing as much rumble as tone, and Joe Lesters keyboards were usually just a looming, amorphous texture. The songs direction was set by clear, terse melodies, and their momentum came from Christopher Guanlaos drumming, with his hefty beat topped by washes of cymbals.

title: Queens Man Arraigned in Guards Injury
description: A Springfield Gardens man was arraigned in Queens Criminal Court yesterday on charges that he robbed a clothing store on Monday and critically injured a security guard during the getaway, prosecutors said. The man, Philip J. Zabriskie, 53, of 133rd Avenue, was charged with first-degree robbery and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Zabriskie is charged with robbing the Pretty Girl clothing store in Jamaica on Monday afternoon, Mr. Brown said. When Mr. Zabriskie and two accomplices tried to flee, a guard, Awali Khouroupra, tried to stop them by holding onto the hood of their minivan, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Zabriskie is charged with knocking Mr. Khouroupra to the pavement as he drove off, causing a severe head injury. Mr. Khouroupra is on life support.

title: Daimler and Cerberus to Invest $1.2 Billion in Pension Fund at Chrysler
description: DETROIT, May 16  DaimlerChrysler and Cerberus Capital Management, which is buying the Chrysler Group, have agreed to invest $1.2 billion in the pension fund of Chrysler workers under terms of the sale, the United Automobile Workers union said Wednesday.

title: G.M. May Sell a Unit
description: General Motors may sell its midsize truck business as it focuses on making profits from cars and light trucks.

title: China Urges U.S. Not to Punish All Food Exporters
description: SHANGHAI, May 16  China has urged the United States not to take punitive action against this countrys exporters of agricultural goods even though Chinese officials have determined that two Chinese companies intentionally contaminated American pet food ingredients with an industrial chemical.

title: Perhaps for God, England and St. George, but Not Harry
description: LONDON, May 16  He had been cast as the warrior prince, the royal who, like a Shakespearean namesake, would lead his troops unto the breach of southern Iraq.

title: A Reality Show Confronts the Reality of Real Estate
description: LOS ANGELES, May 16  So, like, after Daddy died and things stayed rocky with Mom, it was definitely time for a change: new husband, new baby, new business! And why not put it on TV!

title: A: The Theater at the Garden. Q: What Is a WaMu, and Where Is It Found?
description: What would a man of letters  Nabokov, say  make of it?

title: The Dream of Absolute Quiet
description: JONATHAN PRAGER is a 40-something Manhattan comedian and singer whose life experience and worldview, like those of many other comedians, are semitragic. Certainly, his quest to find a quiet home has been laced with pathos.

title: Correction
description: An entry in the Skin Deep column last week, about Beauty on the Vine, a play about plastic surgery, referred incorrectly to an annual list of the celebrity features most in demand among the patients of Drs. Toby G. Mayer and Richard W. Fleming, surgeons in Beverly Hills. Jessica Albas nose and Scarlett Johanssons lips were among this years three most popular for each of those facial features; neither was the most popular.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about clashes between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza referred incorrectly in some copies to the unidentified Palestinian shown standing in the burned offices of Fatah in Gaza City. The person is a woman. (Go to Article)

title: U.S. Championship, Day 2: Three Take the Lead
description: Although it is still early, grandmasters Ildar Ibragimov, Alexander Shabalov and Alexander Stripunsky hold the lead in the Frank Berry United States Championship being played in Stillwater, Okla. Each player has two points after winning their second round games. The games can be seen live or replayed  here  at Monroi.com.

title: A Win in the Windy City
description: Well, the Yankees won the nightcap, 8-1, and all is well again for the moment. Theyre 18-20, and as Derek Jeter said, their next game starts in about 45 minutes.

title: Art Reflecting Life
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: Additional images from "Shrek the Third," including new characters.

description: Chalet

title: Luc Besson Movie Posters
In Bid for Better Care, Surgery With a Warranty
description: Taking a cue from the makers of TVs, washing machines and other products, Geisinger Health System in central Pennsylvania essentially guarantees its workmanship with a 90-day warranty.

title: Everyday America
description: Images from "Biographical Landscape: The Photography of Stephen Shore, 1969-79" at the International Center of Photography.

title: Text: Statements by World Bank and Wolfowitz
description: Following is the text of statements released by the World Bank's executive directors and Paul D. Wolfowitz announcing his resignation.

title: The Goal Is Superimmunity; The Status, Almost There
description: Green tech may capturing all the headlines in venture capital deals these days, but a broad renaissance in vaccine research and development is nonetheless capturing the attention (and cash) of V.C.s and big-name charities like the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

title: Walgreen to Buy Operator of In-Store Health Clinics
description: Walgreen said Wednesday that it planned to buy Take Care Health Systems, which operates in-store health clinics, as it moves to offer more patient services in its drugstores. The terms of the all-cash deal, which is expected to close next week, were not disclosed.

title: ValueAct Prevails Over Acxiom
description: Acxiom, a data-management company, is being acquired by two investment firms and will be taken private, the chief executive of Acxiom, Charles D. Morgan, announced Wednesday. In a deal worth $2.25 billion, a partnership being formed by the equity firms ValueAct Capital and Silver Lake Partners will pay $27.10 a share in cash, Mr. Morgan said.

title: Executive Pay Proposals Rejected at AMR
description: Shareholders of AMR, the parent company of American Airlines, rejected at the annual meeting on Wednesday two proposals aimed at setting controls on executive pay. The Allied Pilots Association had sponsored a resolution to give stockholders an advisory vote on executive compensation each year. Votes representing about 59 percent of AMRs shares went against the proposal.

title: Canadian Pension Fund in Chilean Water Deal
description: The Ontario Teachers Pension Plan said it agreed to buy into two water supply and distribution companies in Chile, in what it called its first infrastructure investments in South America. Financial terms were not disclosed. Teachers will acquire Aguas Nuevo Sur Maule and a 50 percent stake in Empresa de Servicios Sanitarios del Bio-Bio.

title: Edwards Discloses Income From Work for Hedge Fund
description: Presidential contender John Edwards earned $479,512 in 2006 for his work advising Fortress Investment Group, a hedge fund and private equity firm, and sold several million dollars in assets to personally invest in Fortress funds, according to personal financial disclosure forms released Wednesday by the Federal Election Commission.

title: Financial Angels Band Together
description: While the sums that angel investors typically provide to hopeful start-ups may be dwarfed by the investments that their later-stage colleagues drum up, their returns are far from bite-sized. In particular, one group of angel investors  individuals who put up seed money for fledgling companies based on a smile and a shoeshine  is seeing its numbers and importance growing.

title: J.P. Morgan Axes China Fund Manager
description: J.P. Morgans asset management joint venture in China announced on Wednesday that it had fired a senior fund manager who is under investigation by a Chinese regulator for allegedly manipulating share prices. China International Fund Management, which is 49 percent owned by J.P. Morgan Asset Management, said in a statement on Wednesday that it had dismissed Tang Jian, the manager of one of the companys main equity funds.

title: Plaza Owner Buys Las Vegas Casino
description: The owner of New Yorks Plaza hotel announced plans Wednesday to buy the New Frontier hotel-casino on the Las Vegas Strip and replace it with a $5 billion multiuse complex.

title: Regulators Serve Biovail Founder
description: Just days after the Securities and Exchange Commission hit Canadian pharmaceutical company Biovail with a so-called Wells notice, the companys embattled founder, Eugene Melnyk, revealed Wednesday that he also received one.

title: Ex-Goldman Head Calls Wall St. Pay Shocking
description: This is bound to be creating some buzz down on 85 Broad: John C. Whitehead, who retired as co-chairman of Goldman Sachs in 1984, called current compensation levels at the giant securities firm shocking and said he was appalled at Wall Street pay in general. In an interview with Bloomberg News, Mr. Whitehead, 85, urged his former employer to curb bonuses, even if it means losing some valued employees. I would take the chance of losing a lot of them and let them see what happens when the hedge fund bubble, as I see it, ends, he told Bloomberg earlier this week.

title: G.M. May Dump Midsize Trucks
description: General Motors may sell its midsize truck business as it focuses on making profits from cars and light trucks. And, according to The Flint Journal, Navistar International might be interested in a deal for the unit. We are considering options for our medium-duty truck business to better position the unit for growth, a spokeswoman, Melisa Tezanos, told Bloomberg News.

title: New Century Unit Receives Second Bid
description: New Century Financial, the largest subprime lender in bankruptcy, received another offer for its loan-servicing unit that tops the initial $133.3 million bid by Carrington Capital Management, a lawyer said. Company attorney Suzzanne Uhland told Bankruptcy Court Judge Kevin J. Carey in Wilmington, Del., that the new offer makes it possible to hold an auction for the unit, considered New Centurys most valuable asset.

title: Boston Scientific in Talks to Settle Guidant Suit, Report Says
description: Boston Scientific is in talks to settle 1,350 product liability suits it inherited when it bought Guidant last year, the Wall Street Journal reported. The suits allege that Guidant sold several models of implantable defibrillators after learning of defects in the devices that caused them to fail, the paper said.

title: A Rosy I.P.O. for Belle International
description: Belle International Holdings and shareholders raised HK$8.7 billion, or $1.1 billion, in the largest initial public offering abroad by a Chinese consumer company, according to Bloomberg News.

title: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
description: Wall Streets largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

title: Like Buffett, Icahns Working on the Railroads
description: Carl C. Icahn has bought a $122 million stake in CSX, joining Warren Buffett and TCI Fund Management in purchasing railroad shares. Mr. Icahn held 2.68 million shares of Jacksonville, Fla.-based CSX, the nations third-largest railroad, as of March 31, according to filings Tuesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway and hedge fund TCI also detailed their purchases in the industry, which they disclosed in the past month.

title: Investors Bet That More Bidders Will Eye Bausch & Lomb
description: Will more bidders emerge for Bausch & Lomb, the troubled eye care firm that said Wednesday it had accepted a $4.5 billion takeover offer from Warburg Pincus?

title: Funds Seek Break-Up of Britains Prudential
description: Yet another group of hedge fund shareholders is on the move, this time urging Prudential Chief Officer Mark Tucker to break up Britains second-biggest insurer. New Star Asset Management Group, Jupiter Asset Management and Canada Life of London, which together oversee about $91 billion, say Prudentials British division is dragging down faster-growing units in Asia and the United Sates. Earnings in Britain fell 7.9 percent in 2006, while profit in Asia jumped 20 percent, according to Bloomberg News.

title: Kodak Printers
description: It's war in the world of inkjet printers and cartridges as Kodak gets into the business.

title: Carlyle to Offer Rival Valentino Bid, Report Says
description: The Carlyle Group is planning to go head to head with European rival Permira Advisers for control of Valentino Fashion Group, the Italian company that controls Hugo Boss, according to Reuters.

title: Clinton on Climate Change
description: Bill Clinton talked to Andrew C. Revkin after announcing his new plan to fight climate change at the Large Cities Climate Summit in New York last May.

title: S.E.C. Poised to Set Course on Business
description: In the coming weeks, the Securities and Exchange Commission must decide a series of critical issues worth billions of dollars to the business community, from how far to cut back accounting rules to whether it should side with investment banks or shareholders in a Supreme Court case.

title: Daimler, Cerberus to Invest $1.2 Billion in Chryslers Pension Fund
description: DaimlerChrysler and Cerberus Capital Management, which is buying the Chrysler Group, have agreed to invest $1.2 billion in the pension fund of Chrysler workers under terms of the sale, the United Automobile Workers union said Wednesday.

title: Chrysler Sale Unavoidable, Zetsche Says
description: On Monday evening at Chryslers offices in Auburn Hills, Mich., Dieter Zetsche held what is likely to be his last, and most poignant, session of Ask Dr. Z. Mr. Zetsche, the chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, became famous last summer as that affable German fellow with a walrus mustache, who answered questions about cars on a Chrysler Web site.

title: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
description: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers Pension Plan is also circling.

title: Is Alwaleed Sizing Up InterContinental?
description: When Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal hits New York to check up on his Citigroup stake, he might have another investment to consider. The Telegraph reported Wednesday that Saudi billionaire was rumored to be making a takeover play for InterContinental Hotels Group, whose stately New York flagship, The New York Post notes, is just steps from the Park Avenue headquarters of Citigroup.

title: For Black and Kravis, Parallel Paths Diverge Sharply
description: Until recently, Marie-Josee Kravis, the economist, charity fund-raiser and wife of private equity bigwig Henry R. Kravis, and Conrad Black, the one-time chief of Hollinger International, on whose board Ms. Kravis once sat, pursued a similar path.

title: Quattrone Raises Profile With Museum Post
description: Hes back.

title: 2008: When Elephants Attack
description: It doesnt take a brilliant strategist to suggest that candidates try to gloss over unfavorable parts of their pasts, but one of the striking features of the 2008 campaigns is the pungency of the various elephants in the various rooms of the leading candidates, writes The Timess Mark Leibovich.

title: Inspecting the Generals
description: Tobin Harshaw

title: Rolling Into History on the Rails of Korea
description: The two Koreas took a long-planned step towards reconciliation today when trains crossed the demilitarized zone for the first time since the armistice that ended the fighting in the Korean War and created the zone in 1953.

title: Masters of the Brush
description: Images from "Ike Taiga and Tokuyama Gyokuran: Japanese Masters of the Brush" at the Philadelphia Museum.

title: Blackstone to Acquire Alliance Data
description: Blackstone Capital Partners said on Thursday it would buy Alliance Data Systems, a provider of transaction, credit and marketing services, for $7.8 billion including debt. It will pay $81.75 per share in cash, which it said was a premium of about 30 percent over Alliance Datas closing share price of $62.96 on May 16 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Sarbanes-Oxley Compliance Costs Drop 23%, Study Finds
description: The costs of complying with Sarbanes-Oxley governance regulations dropped 23 percent last year to $2.9 million for big companies, the second large decline in a row, the Financial Times reported, citing a survey by Financial Executives International of 200 companies.

title: Blackstone to Buy Alliance Data in $7.8 Billion Deal
description: Alliance Data Systems, which administers credit card programs for major retailers, said Thursday it agreed to be acquired by Blackstone Group in a deal it valued at $7.8 billion, including assumed debt. Blackstone will pay $81.75 in cash for each share of Alliance Data, about 30 percent more than the stocks Wednesday closing price. If approved by shareholders, the buyout would end Alliances six-year run as a public company and put it back in the hands of a private equity firm. Alliance was formed in 1996 by Welsh Carson Anderson Stowe, which combined two businesses it bought from J.C. Penney and Limited Brands.

title: Does Pitching Need a Hand?
description: The cry from major league teams for pitching help has rarely seemed so full-throated. Out of necessity, teams must rely on journeymen and young, untested prospects  like the Mets did with Mike Pelfrey, now in the minors after going 0-5 with the big club. At PLAY, we were talking about how serious a problem the dearth of quality pitching is for Major League Baseball, and whether officials need to somehow address it.

title: Family Thanksgiving Trip in the Caribbean
description: My brother turns 40 in a few months and wed like to take a collective vacation to a not-too-expensive Caribbean beach spot during the week of Thanksgiving. Can you recommend a place that is not too hard to get to (parents in their 70s, so not a plane to small plane to ferry, please) and can deal with little kids (mine, ages 11, 9, 6)? None of us require organized activities. We might enjoy the option to take a day trip or two, if theres a town or jungle nearby. Mostly, we just want a beautiful, relaxing beach place where we can enjoy each other. My parents live in Jacksonville, FL, my family lives in Brooklyn, and my brother and girlfriend are in Albuquerque, NM.

title: Simplifying Diabetes Shots
description: Ive been writing this week about the inspirational finalists in the Invent Now competition for amateur inventors. Turns out the second-prize winner ($10,000) was born, as so many inventions are, out of a real-world need.

title: TV Upfronts: CW Takes the Stage
description: The Pussycat Dolls are tramping it up onstage at Madison Square Garden; the ad girls in their DVF wraps are sucking on buckets of Jamba Juice; and various chipper kids in white are wearing free to be helpful T-shirts, just begging to show you to your seat.

title: TechTarget Raises $75 Million in I.P.O.
description: TechTarget, a venture-backed company that produces technology-focused Web sites, magazines and conferences, priced its initial public offering late Wednesday at $13 per share, in the middle of the expected range. The 7.7-million-share offering, representing a stake of about 20 percent in the company, included 6.4 million new shares and 1.3 million sold by existing shareholders. The company said it expected to raise about $75.2 million in the stock sale.

title: Your Comments on my Bush-Wolfowitz Column
description: Im sorry Im late putting this up  Ive been in a plane flying to Hong Kong all these hours, and I forgot to put this up before I got in the plane. But, in any case, please post your comments on my Thursday column about the way the U.S.s position in the world community is beginning to resemble Wolfowitzs position at the World Bank.

title: Reactions to R.N.C. Surveillance
description: The Web is abuzz with reactions today to the release yesterday of 600 pages of documents detailing Police Department surveillance before and during the 2004 Republican National Convention. The Times, which has an article today on the release, has prepared an index with PDF images of all the released records.The response to the new records has varied greatly. Some samples:

title: Advertising Group WPP Takes 24/7 Real Media
description: A week after confirming that it hired an investment bank to explore strategic alternatives, 24/7 Real Media has decided that a sale is the way to go. The company, which provides online marketing services, said it agreed to be bought by advertising and marketing firm WPP Group for $11.75 per share in cash, or about $649 million net of cash acquired. The sale of 24/7 is just the latest in a string of deals involving online advertising companies: Google recently bought DoubleClick for $3.1 billion, and Yahoo  paid $680 million for the part of Right Media that it didnt already own.

title: Green Isnt Clean In the Laundry Room
description: In the battle against global warming, there is no more beloved phrase in Washington than energy efficiency. Mandating energy-efficient appliances costs nothing in the budget and sounds painless to voters. Who could be in favor of energy inefficiency? Congress is working on legislation now to tighten standards further  and touting all the money that consumers will save.

title: Monitor on L.A.P.D. and Protests
description: Of all the opinions raised by the Los Angeles Police Departments handling of an immigration protest early this month, one carries particular weight.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Passing Strange" and "Memory."

title: Deal Makers Expect to Stay Busy, Survey Says
description: Last years record for global deal activity could be a short-lived one, if the predictions of a group of deal makers surveyed by Mergermarket turn out to be correct. Many of the bankers, buyout professionals and chief executives said in the survey that they expect to see continued strength in 2007 in both mergers and acquisitions and leveraged buyouts. In fact, more than half of the respondents are looking for another increase this year in M&A among large-cap companies. Most of the rest believe the level of deals will remain about the same as last years. Just four percent said they expect deal activity to recede.

title: TV Upfronts: Americas Next Top Avatar
description: Dawn Ostroff, the CWs president of entertainment, announces the pickup of The Search for the Next Pussycat Doll. Shes in shiva black and pearls, though she also appears on the screen, turned via photoshop into an ab-proud Pussycat dancer. This is the second time that a CBS-linked network has turned a female executive into a centerfold using tech wizardry. The idea that you might live a separate virtual existence as a size 4 or 0  without having to forfeit the pleasures and advantages of actual flesh-and-blood life  might, Im not kidding, be enough to draw female viewers to the CW, with its sexy modelly gossipy shows.

title: TV Upfronts: Come Back, Marissa, All Is Forgiven
description: The O.C. of N.Y.C., Gossip Girl, is on the big screen. The kids are rich and mean, and they party and steal each others boyfriends.

title: Venture Capitalists: Our Carried Interest is Different
description: Carried interest works in the venture capital business pretty much the same way it works in private equity. But as Congress reconsiders how this income source is taxed, venture capitalists are insisting that for them, its a world apart. Its all part of an effort to escape taxation, Adam Lashinsky writes in Fortune magazine.

title: A Home That Heats and Cools Itself
description: This week, on my blog, Ive been writing about the inventions I saw at last weeks Modern Marvels/Invent Now finals. About 25,000 inventors from all walks of life entered this annual contest, which is run by the History Channel and the National Inventors Hall of Fame. I was among the six judges who were asked to declare a winner from among the 25 finalists still standing.

title: TV Upfronts: What the Internet Is
description: Dawn Ostroff, whos running a brisk show, gets into digital. Its all O.K.: content wraps, avatars, shows to which viewers contribute video. (Content wraps? Whatever.)

title: TV Upfronts: The CW on Safari
description: Im excited about Life Is Wild, because I loved The Wilderness Family and the grim Mosquito Coast, and I basically just love freaky dads who take their families off the grid.

title: TV Upfronts: The Lessons of the Raj
description: Aliens in America looked lousy until Adhir Kalyan appeared, and stole a scene  and seemingly the whole pilot (remember, we only see a clip here).
