As a Pakistani exchange student, he brooks the responses of random American kids to his ethnicity and religion when a wonderfully unctuous middle-school teacher coordinates a discussion of their anger at him for 9/11. As a set piece, its an almost perfect send-up of classrooms being used as encounter groups, as well as the frank contempt that public-school teachers often have for exchange students.

title: TV Upfronts: Geeks and Sweeps
description: Press conference. Nerds are really in right now, Dawn Ostroff is saying, by way of explaining why Big Bang Theory on CBS, which is about two geeks and a girl, wont dilute the power of Ashton Kutchers reality show, Beauty and the Geek, on the CW.

title: Opie and Anthony Fans Bite Back
description: Unhappy with XM Radios decision to suspend Opie and Anthony, fans are canceling subscriptions by the hundreds, smashing satellite radio receivers and posting tons of angry comments. There are also a reports of companies pulling ads.

title: TV Upfronts: Gilmore Girls R.I.P.
description: Were now talking about the Gilmore Girls finale. Ms. Ostroff mentions Lauren and Alexis, and how great they are, and I always feel like whatever you think of the war  the direction of the show and its vision  everyone always says they support the troops, Lauren and Alexis, Lorelai and Rory.

title: Ouch!  Thats Speedy!
description: Anyone want to speculate on how Scott Speed is taking all this talk about him being rejected from the Toro Rosso team and replaced by a Sebastien or a Sebastian? (Bourdais or Vettel.) Just check out his time at Paul Ricard today. It cannot be compared with the times of the previous two days as the track configuration was changed. But here are the results:

title: Questions and Answers: Immigration
description: [ From the editors: The 681 comments and counting, posted in response to an item on illegal immigration, leave no doubt that readers of The Lede have strong opinions on the subject.

title: Content May Be King, but the King Is Also Content
description: Today we visit the realms where YouTube is banned, or at least kept on a very short leash:

title: Charges May Loom in Stock-Loan Investigation
description: Federal prosecutors may soon charge a number of current and former employees of prominent securities firms with taking part in a kickback scheme involving loans of stocks and bonds to short sellers, according to BusinessWeek, which cites undisclosed sources. If they do, it could shed some light on a shadowy but profitable corner of Wall Street. BusinessWeeks Matthew Goldstein writes that the securities-lending business generates about $10 billion in fees for investment banks each year.

title: Greetings From Winter Haven, Err, Shea Stadium
description: Bleary-eyed, the Mets reported to Shea Stadium this morning not long after they left. On his way in, Billy Wagner tapped Jason Vargas, todays starter, on the shoulder and said, Eight and two-thirds innings. Everyone, Im sure, would agree with him.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Stock Market?
description: Dwindling polar ice caps are a good reason to worry. But should the declining number of publicly traded U.S. companies be cause for concern?

title: Podcast: Three Little Words
description: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

title: Yippie Denies Pie-Throwing Intent
description: Aron Kay, a k a Yippie Pie Man, is not surprised that he was among the many individuals and groups monitored by the Police Department in the months before the Republican National Convention in 2004.

title: Immigration Scuffle
description: The Senate has reached a compromise on immigration reform. The blogosphere, naturally, has not.

title: Obama on Clintons War Views
description: In polite but direct remarks, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois took on the Clintons over Iraq this morning, delivering the sort of punch that might always tempt the famous bare knuckles of Clinton operatives. But, by mid-afternoon today, the Clinton camp was responding coolly.

title: Pin the Tail on Iraq
description: Readers respond to Frank Richs May 6 column, Is Condi Hiding the Smoking Gun?.

title: McCain in New York
description: It was an uptown/downtown day of Manhattan fundraisers for Senator John McCain  with a jaunt back down to Washington in the middle of the day, as the Senate reached an agreement on the contentious immigration bill.

title: In Hindsight, Reagan Not So Worthy
description: Readers respond to Frank Richs May 13 column, Earth to G.O.P.: The Gipper Is Dead.

title: Bank Street President Resigning
description: Augusta Souza Kappner, who has been president of the Bank Street College of Education since 1995, will step down at the end of the 2007-08 academic year.Dr. Kappner, known almost universally as Gussie, was the lone mayoral appointee on the Panel for Education Policy three years ago to vote against Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs plan to end social promotion  and distributed research to other panel members showing that, despite their political popularity, policies requiring struggling student to repeat a year do not help their educational outcomes.

title: TV Upfronts: Lets Start Foxs Family Feud!
description: The following takes place between 4 and 5pm.

title: Obama Videos Get Closed-Captioning
description: Web video is helping all sorts of people get connected to the political process  but some have still been left out. For the deaf and hard-of-hearing, YouTube hasnt really done a whole lot of good  until now.

title: TV Upfronts: Sisters and Starting Over
description: Amy Sherman-Palladino, who made the late Gilmore Girls for the late WB, now springs The Return of Jezebel James on us. Its about sisters. One needs, I guess, a surrogate to have a baby for her; the players are Parker Posey and Lauren Ambrose. Oh how I want to say it looks good. But it does not.

title: From the High Court to the Ivory Tower
description: Clerking for the Supreme Court is not part of the traditional career path to become a college president. But when Stephen J. Friedman becomes interim president of Pace University in June, he will join at least two other university presidents in New York who have traveled that route.

title: TV Upfronts: Turning Down the Razzle-Dazzle
description: Fox upfront. Last years at the Armory was a bust: hot, glitchy and loud with scary, bad jokes. (Hi Brad Garrett!)

title: Third M-Tel Masters: Second Half Begins With Three Decisive Games
description: While most of the countrys best players have been competing in the Frank Berry United States Championship, Gata Kamsky has been in Sofia, Bulgaria, playing in what has become one of the elite events on the calendar: The M-Tel Masters.

title: TV Upfronts: The Search for the Next Karen Black
description: With Robert Altman no longer with us, its time to remake Nashville as fluff  except that Foxs reality series Nashville, by the big minds and hearts behind MTVs Laguna Beach, looks pretty great.

title: TV Upfronts: Selling Soap
description: Kville is a PG Wire, just as Cane on CBS is a PG Sopranos. Film actors, cops and bad neighborhoods with a down-and-out, Tom Waits-style soundtrack. But redemptive. And shot in New Orleans, so its got that highly pleasurable guilt-trip factor. Looks like a possible hit.

title: McCain Stops By the Senate
description: John McCain made an appearance in the Senate today. Yes, at least on Capitol Hill, this is a newsworthy item.

title: Lack of Healthy Food in Harlem
description: Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson just issued a statement urging the Legislature to act on the Healthy Schools Act proposed by Gov. Eliot Spitzer.

title: Vows: Jessica and Emile
description: Jessica Rodriquez and Severiano Emile Lisboa IV met while dancing the night away at the South Street Seaport in New York.

title: Succeeding Wolfowitz
description: In the past few days, the Paul D. Wolfowitz Question turned from if he would step down at the World Bank, to when and how. And the answer came this evening.

title: Whos Worse, Nixon or Bush?
description: WASHINGTON  A favorite pastime of political scientists and pollsters is compiling lists of the best presidents. The results vary widely, as the judgments of history conflict with contemporary sentiments. Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln and F.D.R. always finish high on the lists, with more controversial choices like Truman and Reagan often thrown in.

title: Television Upfronts: Fox
description: The Times's Bill Carter reports from City Center, where Fox presented its 2007 fall schedule.

title: A Warm Welcome for Dad Lit
description: Back in 2002 when I was in the thick of conducting interviews with groups of mothers for my book Perfect Madness, I began to think that it would be a great idea to turn the tables and interview groups of dads. After all, I was listening almost daily to mothers venting (in the nicest possible way) about their lazy, self-indulgent, oversexed, under-involved husbands; there had to be, I thought, another side to the story.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about efforts by Paul D. Wolfowitz to retain his job as president of the World Bank referred incorrectly in some copies to a critic of Mr. Wolfowitzs who has accused him of favoritism. The critic, Robert Danio, is a former general counsel at the bank, not the current general counsel.

title: Germany: Ex-C.I.A. Detainee Held in Arson Attack
description: The police arrested Khaled el-Masri, the German citizen of Lebanese descent who says he was subjected to the Central Intelligence Agencys practice of extraordinary rendition, on suspicion of setting a fire at a market in the Bavarian town of Neu-Ulm that caused an estimated $675,000 in damage, his lawyer said. A judge ordered him held in the psychiatric ward of a local hospital. The lawyer, Manfred Gnjidic, said in a telephone interview that Mr. Masri, who says he was seized while on vacation in Macedonia in 2003 and flown to Afghanistan, where he was questioned about ties to terrorist groups and beaten, had had a dispute with the store and that his action was a result of not having received the psychological counseling he had sought. I have asked several times from the beginning for psychological help, but without any luck, Mr. Gnjidic said. The very ironic thing is that he will get psychological help now, after he committed a crime, and as a torture victim didnt get it before, when he asked for it.

title: Democrats Balk Over Pledge of Tighter Rules on Lobbying
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  House Democrats wavered Thursday in their vow to tighten Congressional ethics rules as their leaders scrapped a campaign pledge to double the current one-year ban on lobbying by departing lawmakers and senior staff members.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about the Thomson Corporations acquisition of the Reuters Group misspelled the name of the Ontario town where Thomson was founded. It is Timmins, not Timmons.

title: 22-Foot Pipe Falls 35 Floors Into Firehouse Near 9/11 Site
description: The long-delayed demolition of the former Deutsche Bank building across from ground zero suffered another setback yesterday when a 22-foot metal pipe fell from its 35th floor and crashed through the roof of a firehouse across the street.

title: Dance Listings
description: NEW YORK CITY BALLET/AMERICAN BALLET THEATER Sure, the blossoms and longer days are all right, but for some New Yorkers, spring means opera glasses, Champagne at intermission and having to choose between New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater, which are performing next door to each other at Lincoln Center.

title: En Route to a Mountain Peak, a Stop at the Hudsons Source
description: MOST New Yorkers take the Hudson River for granted. Its simply a fact of life, like alternate-side parking and the Yankees making the playoffs each season. Most only have the vaguest sense of where the river begins. If you told some New Yorkers that the Hudsons source was a hose left running outside someones chalet in the Canadian Rockies, a few of them just might believe you.

title: The Troubles: A Walking Tour
description: Belfast

title: Calls to Remove CVS/Caremark Director
description: An investment advisory firm is calling for the board of CVS/Caremark to remove a director, Roger L. Headrick, amid concern that his re-election was aided by phantom votes, or votes cast without guidance from shareholders.

title: Russia Sues U.S. Bank; Laundering Case Cited
description: The Federal Customs Service of Russia is seeking $22.5 billion in damages from the Bank of New York Company over accusations of money laundering in the 1990s.

title: Bush Asked to Reconsider Safety Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Senate Democrats urged President Bush on Thursday to withdraw his nomination of a top lobbyist from the National Association of Manufacturers to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission, saying the candidate was unqualified and the appointment posed insurmountable conflicts of interest.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Appointed Hobblers of Government
description: Across six years, the Bush administration has mocked all standards of conflict of interest by choosing private industry zealots for high regulatory posts  where they worked to roll back hundreds of rules on transportation, workplace and mine safety, the environment and other issues. The latest in this subversive chain must surely take the fox-in-the-henhouse statuette: President Bush has nominated Michael Baroody, lobbyist for the powerful National Association of Manufacturers, to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: Hunt for 3 G.I.s in Iraq Slowed by False Trails
description: RUSHDIMULLAH, Iraq, May 17  The stories have come in by the dozens.

title: A Renaissance of Charm in a Hub of the Surfing World
description: IF you had walked down Avenida del Mar in San Clemente, Calif., 10 years ago, you would have found a down-at-the-heels beach town that didnt seem to have much going for it. It had a smattering of intriguing boutiques, a longtime surf shop and an excellent deli and a Jamaican restaurant, but many shops along Del Mar stood empty.

title: Mosque Bombing Kills Seven in India
description: NEW DELHI, May 18  A crude bomb exploded during Friday prayers at a 17th-century mosque in Hyderabad, a major city in southern India. At least seven people were killed, and about 35 more were wounded.

title: They Are Inauthentic, Yes, but Beautiful
description: It could have fooled me, as it fooled others. The exquisitely detailed sculpture of St. Michael battling the dragon of the Apocalypse, in half-human scale, wrought in gilt silver with semiprecious stones, is a gorgeous thing, showing the saint looking down in triumph as his lance pierces a loathsome creature writhing at his feet. For a long time it was thought to be an original medieval work, so well regarded that it was once part of a Rothschild collection.

title: Theater Listings
description: KING KONG Why, in a few months, itll be up in lights on Broadway: Kong  the Eighth Wonder of the World,  Carl Denham (Robert Armstrong) said in the 1933 film. King Kong did go on to make a Broadway debut in the movie, before he grabbed Ann Darrow (Fay Wray) and bolted to the top of the Empire State Building.

title: Violence Continues in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, May 18  Israel struck more targets of the Palestinian faction Hamas today, while forces from the groups Palestinian rival, Fatah, fired mortar shells at Hamass Islamic University and exchanged gunfire with fighters inside.

title: Torre Wont Start Wang, So Another Rookie Looms
description: CHICAGO, May 17  Tyler Clippard was pulled after striking out the side in the first inning Thursday for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre, a strong indication that Clippard will start for the Yankees on Sunday. Manager Joe Torre said he would not use Chien-Ming Wang on short rest for that game.

title: Hilfiger Janitors Back on Job After Abrupt Layoffs
description: A week after they were told that they were being replaced by workers earning far lower wages, nine workers who clean the offices of the Tommy Hilfiger clothing company were hired by a different contractor yesterday and went back to work.

title: Army Punished 2 Officers in 06 After Failures in Iraq Ambush
description: An Army general relieved a company commander and a platoon leader of their commands last year after enlisted men were ambushed and killed by insurgents at an isolated observation post south of Baghdad in June 2006, Army officials said yesterday.

title: Financier Says He Is Not Target of Swiss Arms Investigation
description: PARIS, May 17 A Syrian-born financier who helped broker a $79 billion arms contract between BAE Systems and Saudi Arabia two decades ago said Thursday that he was not a target of a money-laundering investigation opened this week by the Swiss authorities.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: The Insurgent Advantage
description: The war on terror has shredded the reputation of the Bush administration. Its destroyed the reputation of Tony Blairs government in Britain, Ehud Olmerts government in Israel and Nuri al-Malikis government in Iraq. And heres a prediction: It will destroy future American administrations, and future Israeli, European and world governments as well.

title: Networks Know That All Rivalries Arent Viewed Equally
description: Interleague play begins today, and guess which two teams Fox and ESPN are featuring this weekend? The Yankees and the Mets. It doesnt matter if theyre at Shea Stadium or at Yankee Stadium, or if both teams are great.

title: Relent on Missile Defense (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: At Cannes, Blueberry Nights and Romanian Days
description: CANNES, France, May 17  As a first course the 60th Cannes Film Festival served its audiences dessert.

title: In Deal for Chrysler, Snows Role Extends a Trend
description: At a news conference this week in Stuttgart, Germany, the usually secretive private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management was in the spotlight, announcing an agreement to take control of Chrysler.

title: President Bush to Replace Wolfowitz Quickly
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  The Bush administration promised today to find someone quickly to succeed Paul D. Wolfowitz as president of the World Bank, and bring management skills to the job of healing an institution battered by the turmoil over Mr. Wolfowitzs tenure.

title: Puns, Not Potshots, as Mayor Faces an Ex-Rival
description: It was a meeting that felt more like a Catskill comedy routine than a reunion of two formerly bitter political rivals:

title: Paradise Preserved in a Restless Continent
description: Gabon: The Last Eden, tonight on the National Geographic Channel, is an example of a currently popular genre that could be called enviroporn. Born from the union of global warming mania and the increasing ease with which anything, anywhere can be photographed in brilliantly colorful detail, it proliferates on outlets like National Geographic, the Discovery Channel and PBS.

title: Rescuers Try to Lure Lost Whales With Sound
description: WEST SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 17  Anxious to save two injured wayward whales, a team of marine rescuers on Thursday played recorded humpback songs, hoping to lure the stranded mammals from the Sacramento River back to the sea.

title: Turnaround Effort Is Challenging at Airbus, a Stew of European Cultures
description: TOULOUSE, France, May 17  Louis Gallois is fed up with flags. When he took over as chief executive of Airbus in October, an early edict was to ban the use of national symbols in PowerPoint presentations.

title: Denis Kuhn, 65, Dies; Restored New York Landmarks
description: Denis G. Kuhn, an architect who oversaw many major restoration and reuse projects in New York City, including the transformation of the Alexander Hamilton Custom House into the Smithsonians National Museum of the American Indian and the conversion of the old Police Department headquarters in Little Italy into elegant apartments, died on May 10 in the Dominican Republic while touring a project site. He was 65 and lived in Manhasset, N.Y.

title: Battling Evildoers From Worldwide Headquarters in Woodside, Queens
description: Youre a good woman, Fay, declares Jallal (Anatole Taubman), an Osama bin Laden surrogate. Someday when all this is over and we have destroyed Western civilization. ... he continues, without finishing the sentence.

title: Louisiana: Wage Laws Cover Foreign Workers, Judge Says
description: Foreign workers brought into the United States by companies facing labor shortages are covered by federal minimum wage laws, a judge in New Orleans ruled May 15. In what he said appeared to be the first federal ruling on this issue, which could affect thousands of workers nationwide, the judge, Eldon E. Fallon of Federal District Court, found that workers hired by Decatur Hotels in New Orleans had the right to sue their employer under the Fair Labor Standards Act. The workers are seeking to be reimbursed for thousands of dollars in travel and other costs to get the hotel jobs, arguing that the companys failure to do so left them working for less than minimum wage.

title: Crisis at Justice Over Wiretapping (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Memories of the Hood and the Mob
description: Brooklyn Rules, the story of three buddies growing up in a mob-infested blue-collar neighborhood, makes you realize how high the bar has been set by The Sopranos. However authentic and heartfelt this films depiction of life on the meaner streets of the Northeast corridor may be, it doesnt begin to match The Sopranos  epic vision of violence, class struggle and upward mobility in a barbarous culture.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: A Grumpy Green Giant Who Would Not Be King
description: For all I know, there may be an endless supply of Shrek sequels in the pipeline. That DreamWorks ogres skin is the color of money after all. But there is nonetheless a feeling of finality about Shrek the Third, a sense that the tale has at last reached a state of completion. In the first movie Shrek (voiced by Mike Myers) met and wooed his lady love, Fiona (Cameron Diaz); in the second he got to know the in-laws. The current installment finds him faced with impending fatherhood and something of a career crisis. Will he take over his father-in-laws business or remain true to his vocation of bellowing and smashing things?

title: Congress and Bush Striving for Compromise on War Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Congressional leaders and the White House began what they said they hoped were the final talks on an Iraq war spending bill on Thursday as Democrats braced for potential defections by lawmakers leery of any compromise with President Bush.

title: Promises to Keep and Miles to Go for Transit Chief
description: The new boss man of subways and buses, Howard H. Roberts Jr., is said to be partial to the poetry of Robert Frost. Not a bad choice of a muse, even if Frost was a rural type who may have thought  assuming he dwelt on the matter at all  that BMT was shorthand for a kind of sandwich.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) THATS THE WAY IT IS: CELEBRATING CRONKITE AT 90 He led the country in mourning when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated, pushed the story of the civil rights movement, publicly expressed his opinion of the Vietnam War and helped to send the United States space program soaring. No wonder Walter Cronkite, above, with George Clooney, became the nightly news anchor to watch. In this hourlong special colleagues including Katie Couric, Barbara Walters, Brian Williams, Charles Gibson, Dan Rather, Ted Koppel and Diane Sawyer as well as friends like Bill Clinton and Mr. Clooney discuss Mr. Cronkites legacy in honor of his 90th birthday.

title: Movie Listings
description: SAM FULLER This retrospective devoted to the work of the tabloid reporter and crime novelist turned director should really be titled Sam Fuller! to reflect both his fondness for appending exclamation points to his titles (Fixed Bayonets!, Verboten!) and his filmmaking, which is so loaded with huge close-ups and percussive editing that Jean-Luc Godard once called it cin-fist. This program at the Museum of the Moving Image in Queens features most of Fullers major films in hard-to-find 35-millimeter archival prints.

title: Zimbabwe: Inflation Hits 3,714 Percent
description: Zimbabwes hyperinflation reached a record annual rate of 3,714 percent in April, the government-run newspaper The Herald reported, a 1,500 percentage-point increase over the March rate. Steep increases in the cost of fuel, food and power drove the rate higher, the Central Statistical Office was quoted as stating. The new rate effectively means that average prices in Zimbabwe rose 36-fold between April 2006 and April 2007.

title: Life That Brings Out the Beast in Humanity, and a War Thats Far From Civil
description: The rustics in the French director Bruno Dumonts fourth film, Flanders, are tragic beasts. Farmers who live a hardscrabble life surrounded by animals, woods and muddy fields, they are elemental beings ruled by primal emotions they can barely express and would never dream of analyzing.

title: Life Beyond the Lux et Veritas Zone (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz Listings
description: Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.

title: Canada: Bank of Montreal Revises Trade Loss
description: Bank of Montreal, stung by a huge loss from natural gas trading, said the debacle would cost at least 50 percent more than originally forecast and started an investigation into potential irregularities. Bank of Montreal said it would record pretax losses of 680 million Canadian dollars ($618 million) from the trades, compared with an April 27 forecast of 350 million to 450 million Canadian dollars. Two New York-based bankers involved in the trades have left the firm. The bank said the losses were bigger than it originally forecast after it adopted a different pricing model to better assess the value of its natural gas options contracts. The revision also reflects increased concerns about the reliability of quotes from its main broker.

title: Republican Renewal: A Long Road Ahead (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ordinary People, in the Flesh and on the Screen
description: How on earth to watch Doug Varones Dense Terrain? Running 75 minutes without a break at the BAM Harvey Theater, this numbingly tedious and relentlessly earnest show (a New York premiere) passed like an ice age. Dense terrain? Deserts are more varied and vivacious.

title: Lukas, Still Active, Could Play the Spoiler
description: BALTIMORE, May 17  D. Wayne Lukas does not want to hear about how he is in the twilight of an unparalleled career as a horse trainer. He is 71 but still looks good in a cowboy hat and jeans or a $3,000 bespoke suit. He no longer has hundreds of horses in his charge, but he still pops up and wins important races.

title: Monsoon Rains Could Moderate Drought in Southwest
description: Federal forecasters said the extreme drought in the Southwest, just one step from the top of the scale, could moderate in Arizona in July as monsoon rains build but is likely to persist in Southern California into the fall. The similarly intense drought in the Southeast, partly set up by the lack of hurricanes last summer, is unlikely to break any time soon except in Florida, where increasing thunderstorm activity later this month could moisten vegetation, but add to wildfire risks through more lightning strikes. More information is at www.drought.noaa.gov.

title: G.E. Nears a Deal to Sell Plastics Unit
description: General Electric is close to reaching an agreement to sell its plastics division for about $11 billion to Saudi Arabias largest public company, the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation, according to people briefed on the negotiations.

title: $11.45 Million Awarded in N.Y. Church Abuse Case
description: A jury in State Supreme Court in Nassau County today awarded $11.45 million to two people who said they had been abused by the youth minister at a Roman Catholic church on Long Island during the 1990s.

title: Mets Makeshift Lineup Jells in Ninth
description: After hearing that the Mets starting lineup did not include Jos Reyes, Carlos Beltrn, David Wright or Paul Lo Duca, the thousands of children who crammed the upper decks of Shea Stadium might have asked their teachers, We missed school for this?

title: Labor Party Picks Brown to Succeed Blair in Britain
description: LONDON, May 17  Opening a new era in British politics, the governing Labor Party confirmed on Thursday that Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the Exchequer, had emerged as the sole candidate to assume the party leadership and thus succeed Prime Minister Tony Blair when he steps down in June.

title: Not Just Any Port for Migrating Snowbirds
description: WHEN Albert Gallatin, the United States Treasury secretary under Thomas Jefferson, first dreamed up what would become, more than a century later, the Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway, he envisioned a series of linked rivers, canals, bays and deep-water channels that would provide an easy way to transport cargo and troops back and forth between the North and the South.

title: For Fairer Trade Deals (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombia: Escaped Hostage Says Americans Are Alive
description: Emerging from 17 days in the jungle after fleeing from guerrillas, Jhon Frank Pinchao, a police officer, stunned Colombians with his tale of escape after more than eight years in captivity. Mr. Pinchao, left, looking rawboned, said he shimmied off his chains, waded through rivers and endured dehydration, sunburn and insect bites before stumbling across a police patrol. He also offered news of three Americans held hostage by the guerrillas, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia for four years  Marc Gonsalves, Thomas Howes and Keith Stansell  as well as of Ingrid Betancourt, kidnapped in 2002 while running for president. All are still alive, Mr. Pinchao said.

title: People
description: People

title: Fed Chief Addresses Foreclosures
description: The Federal Reserve does not foresee a broader economic impact from the growing number of mortgage defaults and home foreclosures, its chairman said yesterday. And he cautioned that heavy-handed regulation of lenders could have the unintended effect of adding to the strain on the troubled housing market.

title: Man Held in Midtown Killing Is Implicated in Chicago Death
description: A New Jersey man arrested this week on charges of strangling a companion in a Midtown hotel in the summer of 2003 and stuffing her body into a suitcase is wanted in another grisly death: the killing of a college student in Chicago nine days ago, the authorities said.

title: How to Survive in Cambodia: For a Turtle, Beneath Sand
description: SAMBOR, Cambodia  With the self-confidence of tens of millions of years of instinct, 12 tiny turtles raced down a mud bank of the Mekong River on a recent day, plopped into the water and disappeared with a wriggle under the sand.

title: Olmert Visits Israeli Town Where Residents Flee Rocket Fire
description: SDEROT, Israel, May 17  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert paid an unannounced visit to this border town on Thursday night to show solidarity with its residents after days of rocket fire from the nearby Gaza Strip.

title: E-stonia Accuses Russia of Computer Attacks
description: MOSCOW, May 18  The computer attacks, apparently originating in Russia, first hit the Web site of Estonias prime minister on April 27, a day the country was mired in protest and violence. The Estonian presidents site went down, too, and before long so did those of several other government departments, in a wired country that is proud of its paperless government and likes to call itself E-stonia.

title: In Game of Games, Wii Outshoots PlayStation
description: The sales gap between the Nintendo Wii video game console and Sonys competing PlayStation 3 widened during April, according to industry performance figures released yesterday.

title: In Search for a New Sheriff, One Stands Out
description: As New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer won national attention by becoming the new sheriff in finance, taking on Wall Street and mutual funds and the insurance industry.

title: Bill Would Increase Health Spending in Poor Countries
description: Senators Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, and Gordon H. Smith, Republican of Oregon, introduced a bill to sharply increase spending on child and maternal health in poor countries to $600 million next year and $1.6 billion by 2011 from $350 million a year. A companion bill was introduced with bipartisan support in the House last week. Save the Children, the U.S. Fund for Unicef and the Campaign to Make Poverty History, co-founded by the rock star Bono, are supporting the legislation. A recent Save the Children report found that some of the worlds poorest countries have sharply reduced child deaths with practical, inexpensive solutions, but that progress globally has slowed. More than 10 million children die every year before their fifth birthdays, most of them from preventable causes.

title: Mets Say Relievers Demotion Wasnt Based on Positive Test
description: When the Mets sent reliever Lino Urdaneta to Class AAA New Orleans on Tuesday, they had been told that he had tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs. General Manager Omar Minaya said that he was notified last Friday, but Major League Baseball delayed the announcement until Wednesday because of the minor league appeals process.

title: Wolfowitz Resigns, Ending Long Fight at World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Paul D. Wolfowitz, ending a furor over favoritism that blew up into a global fight over American leadership, announced his resignation as president of the World Bank Thursday evening after the banks board accepted his claim that his mistakes at the bank were made in good faith.

title: Manhattan: Budget Increases for New Subway
description: The construction budget for the first phase of the Second Avenue subway crept over $4 billion this month after the Federal Transit Administration asked the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to add $160 million to a reserve fund for unexpected costs. At the request of the federal agency, the authority also pushed back its projected completion date for the long-awaited subway project to 2014 from 2013. The revised budget and timeline were included in material distributed to the authoritys board members this week. The changes came about in response to a risk assessment of the construction costs and schedule prepared by the federal agency. The federal government is expected to provide $1.3 billion in financing.

title: Dozens in School Are Sickened After Free Drink Is Distributed
description: Dozens of sixth and seventh graders in the Lakeland Central School District in northern Westchester County reported becoming sick on Wednesday after many of them drank free samples of fortified milk drinks given out during lunchtime, school officials said yesterday.

title: Bronx: Man Slain Outside His Restaurant
description: A Bronx man was shot and stabbed to death yesterday outside a restaurant he owned, the police said. The man, Douglas Mills, 36, was killed about 2:30 p.m. outside the D&R Jamaican and American Restaurant at Morris Avenue and East 151st Street. The police said they did not know what led to the killing, adding that an investigation was under way. John Mills, Mr. Millss father, said his son was one of 17 siblings, only 12 of whom are still alive. People raise their kids so they can take care of you when youre old, not so you can take care of them and bury them, he said.

title: A Gallery of Gamblers, Each With an Unlucky Number to Be Called
description: Even Money, a scare movie about gambling addiction, is as grim and lurid as any in the recent spate of films about the evils of crystal meth. Once youre hooked, it suggests, youre a goner. The zombie face of Kim Basinger, her vacant eyes glued to a slot machine, tells you all you need to know. The elusive quest of her character, Carolyn Carver, for a cascade of jangling silver soon leads to roulette, blackjack and high-stakes bets placed with a murderous bookie.

title: Qantas Chairwoman Decides to Retire
description: Margaret A. Jackson, the chairwoman of Qantas Airways, who was one of the proponents of a failed attempt to take the airline private, will retire, a company spokesman said. Ms. Jackson, 54, told the board that she would not seek re-election at the airlines annual meeting in October, said Simon Rushton, a spokesman for Qantas. The buyout attempt, led by the Macquarie Bank and TPG, collapsed two weeks ago when investors rejected a cash offer of 5.45 Australian dollars a share as too low. The buyout group says it will not make another bid. Ms. Jackson joined the board in July 1992 and was appointed chairwoman in August 2000.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A Whats on Tonight television listing on May 5 about the film The Day of the Jackal misidentified the actor who played the French detective who pursues the Jackal. He was Michael Lonsdale (also known as Michel Lonsdale), not Terence Alexander, who played Lloyd in the film.

title: Passing Mile Markers, Snapping Pictures
description: In 1973 Stephen Shore set out from New York to photograph the United States for what became a book called Uncommon Places. He shot his motel room in Idaho Falls. He shot a pancake breakfast at the Trails End Restaurant in Kanab, Utah. He shot a rainbow arching over a rain-soaked parking lot in Lovell, Wyo.

title: Three Sculptures Sell for Record Prices and Warhol Stars Again at Phillips Auction
description: Three sculptures  one fashioned from a dozen African masks, a dead deer cast in bronze, and a ball of painted and chromium-plated steel mangled as if hit by a truck  by some of todays most popular artists brought record prices last night at Phillips de Pury & Company. After a week of records at the auction giants Christies and Sothebys, the contemporary-art sale at Phillips, the Chelsea-based boutique firm, had a mix of lower-priced works. Still, the lust to collect continued.

title: Not for Kids Only: Seeking Buccaneer Bliss
description: BLUE BAYOU, Anaheim, Calif.: Caroline Treadwell, 34, stepped gingerly into a boat, then was launched into the bayou darkness to the soothing sounds of crickets, bullfrogs and the distant strumming of a banjo. It seemed like a nocturnal paradise. But avast! Around the next bend Ms. Treadwells boat was sucked into a subterranean waterfall only to emerge in a blue-lighted grotto inhabited by skeletons. Somewhere out there, a drunken chorus was singing, Yo ho, yo ho, a pirates life for me.

title: Senators in Bipartisan Deal on Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Senate negotiators from both parties announced Thursday that they had reached agreement on a comprehensive immigration bill that would offer legal status to most of the nations 12 million illegal immigrants while also toughening border security.

title: Manhattan: Slight Increase in Unemployment
description: New York Citys unemployment rate edged up to 4.4 percent in April, from 4.3 percent in March, the states Department of Labor reported yesterday. The citys jobless rate, which is adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, was lower than the national rate of 4.5 percent but higher than the rate for the rest of the state, which was 4.1 percent. Statewide, the number of private-sector jobs declined for the first time since July, dipping by 7,900, or 0.1 percent, to 7.18 million.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Principals Act in Plan to Reduce Bureaucracy
description: More than a third of New York Citys public school principals embraced a challenge from Chancellor Joel I. Klein to free themselves as much as possible from outside oversight under a new reorganization and become full stewards of their individual schools, the city said yesterday.

title: For Nets, Winning Ugly Looks Pretty Good
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 17  After testing the limits of basketball aesthetics, and the tonal quality of their opponents rims, the Nets returned home Thursday and considered their good fortune again.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about efforts by Paul D. Wolfowitz to retain his job as president of the World Bank referred incorrectly in some copies to a critic of Mr. Wolfowitzs who has accused him of favoritism. The critic, Robert Danio, is a former general counsel at the bank, not the current general counsel. (Go to Article)

title: Whats Happened to the Lawyers Who Worked for Spitzer?
description: After reining in Wall Street analysts, curbing mutual fund trading abuses and corralling some of the biggest insurance companies in the industry, what do you do for an encore?

title: Life Resettles for Survivors of Bronx Fire
description: A 7-year-old girl played with a construction-paper butterfly. Her 5-year-old cousin came and went from the kitchen, trying to distract her mother as she fried potato wedges on the stove. A teenager focused on a homework assignment, sitting in front of the computer in the living room.

title: Goshen: Cleanup for Orange County Landfill
description: The United States Military Academy at West Point, the City of New York and 74 other municipalities, organizations and corporations in the region have agreed to pay nearly $5 million to help clean up hazardous waste in an Orange County landfill. The agreement was part of a consent decree filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan and announced yesterday by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo. Orange County operated the landfill, situated on 300 acres in Goshen, from 1974 to 1992. The landfill was declared a hazardous waste site and was capped in the late 1990s under an agreement with the state in which those responsible for disposing of the waste would eventually help pay for the cleanup. The defendants agreed to contribute toward the cleanup costs, even though they deny wrongdoing.

title: A Tenderhearted Introvert, Crooning in Eclectic Company
description: Two-thirds of the lineup made obvious sense at the Highline Ballroom show on Wednesday night, which was curated by David Bowie. Daniel Johnston, the headliner, and the Legendary Stardust Cowboy, who opened, are two Texas characters with longtime cult followings.

title: An Export Boom Suddenly Facing a Quality Crisis
description: SHANGHAI, May 17  Weeks after tainted Chinese pet food ingredients killed and sickened thousands of dogs and cats in the United States, this country is facing growing international pressure to prove that its food exports are safe to eat.

title: Manhattan: Port Authority Urged to Cut Emissions
description: The chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Anthony R. Coscia, called on his agency yesterday to reduce carbon emissions at its ports and airports by 80 percent over the long term. That goal, he said, could be met by using geothermal energy to heat and cool buildings, installing fuel cells and harnessing wind and solar energy. Equipment used to service aircraft at airports could use electricity and alternative fuels. The strategy, said Mr. Coscia, above, would help reduce global warming and benefit the renewable energy industry.

title: Park Feels Right at Home Among Sybase Leaders
description: CLIFTON, N.J., May 17  On an L.P.G.A. Tour rife with translators and passports, Angela Park may have the most diverse background of all.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Lottery Numbers
No Sleep Is Part of the Ordeal
description: BLAME Mark Burnett, the reality-television producer best known for Survivor. In the mid-90s, he created the Eco-Challenge race and accompanying TV series, and an exotic new sport called adventure racing was stamped on the American consciousness. Today, hundreds of adventure races are attended by thousands of Eco-Challenge wannabes each year, on wilderness courses in the mountains and deep woods from Maine to Alaska.

title: Obelisk Mobility in Central Park
description: OBELISK MOBILITY

title: The Tyranny of the 2nd Home
description: IN his book Acres and Pains, S. J. Perelman recalled his notion of becoming a country squire in Bucks County with nothing but a high heart, a flask of citronella and a fork for toasting marshmallows. But after 15 years of part-time rusticating, he ended up with a superb library of mortgages, mostly first editions, and the finest case of sacroiliac known to science.

title: A Game Show, and Bingo Is Its Name-O
description: There is at least one game of chance loaded with particularly hateful hazards. Players are rapt, tingling with hope and growing confidence, and then across the room a complete stranger stands up and ruins everything. Bingo.

title: In West Oakland, a Second Freeway Collapse Threatens a Fragile Recovery
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 17  To get a sens0e of the problems in West Oakland, a rough-and-tumble corner of a city known for having a few, you need look no farther than places like 14th Street, where a house floats in midair.

title: Citigroup Works Both Sides of Distiller Deal
description: DELHI, India, May 17  Bankers at Citigroup may celebrate the latest Indian cross-border takeover with a few extra drams of Scotch.

title: WPP Group to Acquire Online Ad Company
description: In an effort to catch up with Googles fast-growing online advertising business, the WPP Group, the advertising holding company that owns traditional ad agencies like JWT and the Grey Global Group, agreed yesterday to pay about $649 million to acquire 24/7 Real Media, an advertising network and technology company.

title: Colleges Offering Campuses as Final Resting Places
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Want to recapture those undergraduate years? Colleges and universities are offering the chance  for eternity.

title: Obama Disputes Claim of Sharing Clintons Stance on War
description: Senator Barack Obama yesterday directly challenged former President Bill Clintons assertions that Mr. Obama and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton hold the same essential positions on the Iraq war.

title: When a Crocodile Eats the Sun
description: The title of Peter Godwins haunting and beautifully written new memoir, When a Crocodile Eats the Sun, comes from an African tribal belief, which holds that an eclipse of the sun occurs when a crocodile eats it: This celestial crocodile, they say, briefly consumes our life-giving star as a warning that he is much displeased with the behavior of man below. It is the very worst of omens. At the turn of this millennium, Mr. Godwin reports, two total eclipses occurred within less than two years, something no one he knows can recall, even in the stories handed down through the generations. People are saying that the celestial crocodile must be truly furious to be back so soon, threatening us again with perpetual darkness.

title: Russian Police Detain Opposition Leaders
description: MOSCOW, May 18  The police detained more than a dozen opposition leaders and journalists here on Friday, preventing them from flying to a provincial city to take part in anti-Kremlin protests. The action followed a wave of harassment of the protests organizers.

title: Democrats and White House Remain at Odds on Iraq Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  Congressional Democrats and the White House remained at odds over a war spending measure Friday after a crucial negotiating session ended with both sides expressing disappointment and accusing the other of being intractable.

title: Making Fast Work of a Second Chance
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., May 14  The open-heart surgery did not frighten her, Kayleigh Lotti said. But three weeks later, when she tried to throw a softball again, the ball fell out of her hand because there was no muscle strength to lift her arm. Then she cried.

title: Online Invitation to Help Yourself Surprises the Stuffs Owner
description: SEATTLE, May 17  The offer had sure seemed strange. Then again, it appeared on Craigslist, the online marketplace that has made its name by upending conventional classified advertising.

title: Those Hard-Luck Ranch Hands, After 70 Years
description: This is the 70th anniversary of John Steinbecks novella Of Mice and Men, and the play he adapted from it, also in 1937, is being honored in a tiny theater on a West Side street where drunks and derelicts roam. Perhaps in some way that suggests the books diminished status in the American canon.

title: A Charming Slacker Fights the Power in a Retirement Home
description: Venture capitalist: thats the misleading job description preferred by the title character of the slight and silly Wendell Baker Story. Wendell (Luke Wilson), a cheerful Texan slacker, runs a profitable operation on the Tex-Mex border selling fake drivers licenses to illegal migrant workers.

title: Soldiers Smallpox Inoculation Sickens Son
description: A 2-year-old boy spent seven weeks in the hospital and nearly died from a viral infection he got from the smallpox vaccination his father received before shipping out to Iraq, according to a government report and the doctors who treated him.

title: Senate Democrats Plan a Resolution on Gonzales
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzaless standing in Congress weakened further on Thursday as Senate Democrats arranged to hold a no-confidence vote and the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee predicted that the furor over Mr. Gonzaless stewardship would end with his resignation.

title: Bostons Early-Music Hegemony, Reasserted
description: New York early-music performers get terribly exercised when reviewers suggest that Boston has more period-instrument activity than New York. And Bostons musicians, happy to drive the point home, have established the Boston Early Music Festival series at the Morgan Library & Museum as a New York outpost. To some extent, this is sleight of hand: The festival itself is held in Boston every other spring (this years runs from June 11 to 17), but its administration also presents concerts during the season by both Boston and international ensembles, some of which make their way to the Morgan series as well. To be fair, New York presenters like Music Before 1800 do the same.

title: Private Equity Goes Prime Time
description: Ready or not, its time for private equitys close-up. The announcement earlier this week that Cerberus Capital Management was taking control of Chrysler has made the clubby, backroom industry the center of attention like never before.

title: Family Income and Brain Development
description: Children develop most of their basic verbal, memory and abstract reasoning skills from ages of 6 to 10, and the effect of family income on these abilities may be smaller than previously thought, scientists are reporting. The findings, which appear online in The Journal of the International Neuropsychological Society, are from a large, continuing government study tracking changes in cognitive abilities and brain structure. The difference in I.Q. scores between low-income and high-income was about 10 points, when youngsters with learning disabilities were excluded; previous studies have found differences of 15 to 20 points. The purpose is to provide a large, public database of healthy, normal brain development, said the lead author, Dr. Deborah P. Waber, a pediatric researcher at Childrens Hospital Boston and Harvard University.

title: 8 Israeli Airstrikes in Gaza Kill at Least 7
description: JERUSALEM, Friday, May 18  Israel moved a small number of tanks and soldiers over the Gaza border and hit Hamas with eight airstrikes on Thursday and early Friday, killing at least seven Palestinians, while five other Palestinians died in factional fighting despite a new cease-fire.

title: Mexico: Economic Growth Rate Slips in Quarter
description: Mexicos economy grew in the first quarter at its slowest rate in more than a year as construction fell and automobile output declined on slumping demand in the United States. Gross domestic product grew 2.6 percent from a year earlier, the government reported. A growth rate of less than 3 percent suggests Mexico is failing to reduce dependence on exports to the United States, the destination for about 80 percent of the countrys sales abroad. Last years 4.8 percent growth, Mexicos fastest in six years, was driven by strong United States demand, while the weakening economy last quarter similarly tracked the United States slowdown.

title: A Fired Boss Seeks His Revenge
description: If a chief executive is fired for fraudulently taking travel money from the company, and then turns out to have been involved in backdating options grants, should his fellow shareholders let him pick new directors to replace those who ousted him?

title: 3 Department Store Chains Exceed Estimates
description: J. C. Penney, Kohls and Nordstrom reported first-quarter profits yesterday that surpassed analysts estimates, and they increased their full-year earnings forecasts.

title: Making Some Waves
description: WHO Michael Morgan, 44, a physician, from Odessa, Fla.

title: A Town That Has a Way With Words
description: IN the 19th century, Concord, Mass., was a peaceful country village and home to best-selling writers. In the 21st, Concord is a bustling, upscale Boston suburb and still home to best-selling writers.

title: Different Challenges for Yankees and the Mets
description: You begin to see the makings of something seismic over the next few days, with the Yankees at Shea Stadium this weekend before going home to play the Red Sox. Tonight, its the soaring Mets against the slumping Yankees, the commencement of a Subway Series that is always a crush of impassioned, impossible humanity, but is perfectly timed this season to match irresistible force against movable object.

title: Ads That Are Too Fast for a Fast-Forward Button
description: A BROADCAST network will soon offer advertisers two more ways to try holding the attention of viewers throughout those commercial breaks that consumers love to hate.

title: From Out of the Shadows, Whistle-Blowers Convene
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The whistle-blower, a species in Washingtons peculiar zoology as well established now as the talk-show pundit or the campaign consultant, is enjoying an unusual spell in the sunshine. It is Whistle-Blower Week, so declared by a coalition of advocacy groups, and there is unusual acclaim for those whose leaks make possible Congressional hearings and newspaper exposs.

title: Publisher and Authors Parse a Term: Out of Print
description: When is a book out of print?

title: Second Chance at Career Goes Sour for Wolfowitz
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Paul D. Wolfowitz was ready to move on from the Pentagon in early 2005. He had been thwarted in his effort to become defense secretary or national security adviser. And the war in Iraq had deteriorated. So when the World Bank presidency came open, he jumped at the opportunity.

title: U.N. Rejects Belarus for Seat on Its Rights Panel
description: UNITED NATIONS, May 17  Belarus, one of the worlds most repressive states, was blocked Thursday from gaining membership on the United Nations Human Rights Council after being outvoted in favor of Bosnia and Herzegovina, a late entry.

title: Utah Mall Shootings Lead to Indictments
description: SALT LAKE CITY, May 17  Four men are accused of helping a teenager illegally obtain weapons that were used in a shooting rampage on Feb. 12 at a Salt Lake City mall, the United States attorney for Utah said Thursday.

title: Michelle Obama Adds New Role to Balancing Act
description: It was a triumphant moment for Barack Obama: He was walking through the Capitol for the very first time as a United States senator in January 2005, trailed by photographers, hangers-on, and finally, his amused wife. Rolling her eyes as she pulled a reporter aside, Michelle Obama said, Maybe one day, he will do something to warrant all this attention.

title: G.M.s Advertising Chief to Step Down
description: General Motors said yesterday that its North American marketing and advertising chief, Mike Jackson, would leave the company June 15.

title: Brooklyn: Atlantic Yards Suit Filed in Wrong Court
description: A judge yesterday dismissed a lawsuit filed by tenants challenging the Atlantic Yards construction project, saying they had filed their suit in the wrong court. The suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, accused the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency that shepherded the project to approval, of condemning two apartment buildings on the project site without permission from state housing officials to cancel the tenants rent-stabilized leases. Justice Walter B. Tolub said the suit should have been filed directly in the Appellate Division of Supreme Court. A. J. Carter, a spokesman for the development corporation, said the agency was pleased with the decision. George Locker, a lawyer for the tenants, said he would file his suit in the appellate court even though he believed the Supreme Court had jurisdiction.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Tuesday about the success of Yankees catcher Jorge Posada referred incorrectly to the career standing of the former catcher Tony Pea, the Yankees first-base coach, who spoke favorably about Posadas potential longevity in baseball. Four catchers in major league history  not three  have spent more games behind the plate than Pea. (Ivn Rodrguez of the Detroit Tigers passed Pea on the career list earlier this season; the others are Carlton Fisk, Bob Boone and Gary Carter.)

title: Rudeness, Realism and Russia
description: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and the German foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, held back-to-back meetings with Vladimir Putin on Wednesday to try to calm overheated East-West tensions. The Russians obliged with soothing pronouncements, including an agreement that mutual recriminations should be toned down.

title: Wartime Furniture Draws Unusual Attention
description: WARTIME FURNITURE

title: Union Plans Advisory Tool for Young Workers
description: Helped by start-up money from the Rockefeller Foundation, the Service Employees International Union has created a nonprofit organization that plans to help young workers who lack health insurance and are saddled with debt.

title: The Reclusive Rich Neighbor and Her Report of Intruders
description: SOUTH KENT, Conn.  The road to Anne Basss country estate here in the northwest corner of Connecticut overlooks spectacular vistas of clear ponds, rolling hills and fields of wildflowers. It is as picturesque and unspoiled a setting as one is likely to find within two hours drive from Manhattan.

title: Stalemate Appears Broken in Dispute Over Dredging the Delaware Channel
description: CAMDEN, N.J., May 17  Gov. Edward G. Rendell of Pennsylvania announced on Thursday that he and Gov. Jon S. Corzine had agreed on a plan to deepen the Delaware River shipping channel in a $300 million effort to rejuvenate the once-thriving maritime industry in Philadelphia and South Jersey. The agreement would end a contentious stalemate that had lasted more than 16 months.

title: Rose Garden Charade
description: Confronted with soaring gasoline prices, a Congress growing more restless by the day about oil dependency and a Supreme Court demanding executive action on global warming emissions, President Bush stepped before the cameras in the Rose Garden the other day and said, essentially, nothing.

title: North and South Send Trains Across the Korean Frontier
description: MUNSAN, South Korea, May 17  Trains crossed the border between North and South Korea on Thursday for the first time in 56 years, an event both sides described as a milestone for reconciliation on the divided Korean Peninsula.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A music review in The Arts yesterday about Peter Gallaghers nightclub debut, at Feinsteins at the Regency, misstated the closing date of his engagement. It ends June 2, not tonight.

title: The Suns Forge Ahead Without Stopping for Pity
description: PHOENIX, May 17  Steve Nash was not about to blame the Phoenix Suns last-minute loss to the San Antonio Spurs in Game 5 on bad luck or missing players.

title: Illinois Mass Murderer Is Spared Execution
description: CHICAGO, May 17  A convicted murderer was spared the death sentence on Thursday, instead receiving life in prison without parole for killing seven people in 1993 at a suburban restaurant.

title: Fox to Try Fixing Fall Woes and 24; CW Adding 6 Shows
description: The Fox network, emphasizing its position as the network leader in reaching audiences that most advertisers want to reach, announced a prime-time schedule yesterday aimed at solving its chronic problems in the fall, while maintaining its strength in the winter and spring.

title: Forbidden Games: My Two Sons, My Ex-Husband, My Lover and Me
description: No one bleeds on screen like Isabelle Huppert. Im talking metaphorically, of course, though given her trembling ferocity, the way this pale sliver of a woman seems to pierce the screen with her absolute commitment to the moment at hand, to the radiance and anguish and bile, its hard not to think that she has already sacrificed bits and pieces, gnawing off an arm in one film, opening her veins in another. Watching her in Michael Hanekes Piano Teacher or Private Property, a slow-boiling film from the young Belgian Joachim Lafosse, you wonder how much more she can afford to give, how much she has left.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

title: Mexico: 15 Dead in Police Shootout With Drug Gang
description: The police killed 15 suspected members of a drug gang that had kidnapped and killed five other policeman in Sonora State, just south of Arizona, state officials said. They said the gunmen also killed two civilians. It was the bloodiest gunfight yet in President Felipe Calderns five-month offensive against drug cartels, which has been met with almost daily attacks on police officers and soldiers.

title: Auditing Rule Is Put at Risk by Texas Bill
description: Texas lawmakers are on the verge of rejecting a requirement that state and local governments disclose the cost of the health care they have promised to retired employees.

title: Equal Parts Myth and Foam, Carefully Melded
description: JERSEY CITY  This is my first dragon, Matt Mikas said as he shaped the right foreleg of a 17-foot-long beast he was carving from plastic foam. A plume of fine fuzz rose as he attacked the creature with a wood rasp. At a certain point the dragon will start speaking. Theres always a time when the image begins to come out of the foam.

title: Dont Blame Bush
description: Ive been looking at the race for the Republican presidential nomination, and Ive come to a disturbing conclusion: maybe weve all been too hard on President Bush.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article yesterday, about collecting relics, misstated Napoleons fate at Waterloo. He formally surrendered a month after the battle; he was not captured there.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about a new branch of the New York Public Library on Jersey Street on the edge of SoHo referred imprecisely to the street. It runs from Mulberry Street past Lafayette Street to Crosby Street  not just from Mulberry to Lafayette, the block where the library is located.

title: Struggling Yankees Could Use a Close Shave
description: CHICAGO, May 17  Jason Giambi took out his razor after Thursdays game and shaved the days-old scruff from his face. He stopped at his upper lip, keeping the beginnings of a mustache, the same look he wore last summer when the Yankees were soaring.

title: Evacuees Start to Assess Fire Damage in New Jersey
description: BARNEGAT, N.J., May 17  Two days after fleeing 20-foot flames that licked at their backyards here, residents began returning to their mobile homes Thursday, though some came back to piles of charred rubble where their homes once stood.

title: Wacky Love, in Translation
description: Anyone who has gone off to Europe with a partner to try to perk up a flagging romance, or dreamed of a happy future with an Italian met on vacation, has had a chance to learn that a change of scenery, or even of language, does not necessarily alter the underlying terms of a relationship.

title: Paid Sick Leave (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about a dispute over fireplace smoke at a Manhattan co-op, the San Remo, that involves Bono, the lead singer of U2, and another rocker, Billy Squier, gave an erroneous age in some copies for Mitch Miller, another resident and the host of the 1960s show Sing Along With Mitch. He is 95, not 96.

title: Fed Chairman Sees Mortgage Damage as Limited
description: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, helped soothe concerns that problems in the subprime mortgage market would spread, saying today that the Fed sees no serious broader spillover.

title: And as the Abused Heroine, a Pop Princess
description: As someone who has remained immune to the addictive attractions of American Idol, I was steeling myself to greet the arrival of Fantasia on Broadway with the kind of hand wringing that proud partisans of the theatah often reserve for despised interlopers from television and pop. O the outrage! O the crass commercialism! O the lack of discipline and proper vocal training!

title: Giorgio Cavaglieri, Urban Preservationist, Dies at 95
description: Giorgio Cavaglieri, an architect who took his fascination with how buildings and cities change over time from his native Italy to New York, where he helped start and define the citys preservation movement, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 95.

title: Unlikely Comrades Share Parting Moment
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  There was a moment, as Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and President Bush stood together in the bright sunshine on Thursday for their last joint appearance in the Rose Garden, when the shouts of antiwar protesters gathered outside the gates of the White House threatened to drown out their words.

title: Manhattan: Man Found Dead in Apartment
description: A 70-year-old man was found dead in his Murray Hill apartment Wednesday, having suffered blunt trauma to the head and compression of the neck, Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the chief medical examiner, said yesterday. The man, identified by the police as Jose Prieto, though neighbors knew him as Raul, was a retired graphic designer for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and had lived in the building on East 35th Street for more than 30 years. The police said the death was under investigation.

title: French Leave Resort and Montesoro
description: French Leave Resort

title: In Rare Turn, U.S. and Iran Schedule High-Level Security Talks in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, May 17  The United States and Iran on Thursday announced plans to hold rare face-to-face talks this month about Iraqi security, and the police in Mosul made mass arrests after a wave of bombings.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Paris Hilton Sentence Cut

title: Proof That Things Are People Too (Well, Almost)
description: What do objects want?

title: Sarkozy Chooses Campaign Aide as New French Premier to Help Smooth Way for Reform Plan
description: PARIS, May 17  President Nicolas Sarkozy of France on Thursday named Franois Fillon to be his prime minister in a move intended to smooth the enactment of an ambitious reform program.

title: Art in Review
description: KELLI CONNELL

title: In Japan, When Word Was Wed to Image
description: The 18th-century painter and calligrapher Ike Taiga was something like the Pablo Picasso of Japan. The comparison, while superficial, is hard to resist as you wade into the dazzling, almost daunting retrospective of Taigas work at the Philadelphia Museum of Art and begin to absorb the many sides of his achievement.

title: Seasoned Look at Latest in Police Transport
description: Oh, the toys that grownups have these days. Back in the 20th century, when Officer Wilton Sekzer kept the peace on the blistering Coney Island Boardwalk, he actually had to use his feet to propel himself from one end to the other.

title: Going Like 60 (Tick Tick Tick)
description: George J. Tenet accuses the White House of bungling the Iraq war and setting him up (slam dunk) to take the fall. John McCain says he shopped peacefully in a Baghdad market, then cameras pull back to show him in body armor surrounded by armed guards. John and Elizabeth Edwards explain why her cancer wont stop his run for the presidency. In a prison interview, L. Dennis Kozlowski, Tycos former C.E.O., answers questions about his $6,000 shower curtain.

title: Correction: The Making of Mayberry on the Outer Banks
description: An article last Friday about Manteo, N.C., misspelled the given name of the former director of the school of landscape design at North Carolina State University who worked on in a recent 20-year plan for the town. She is Achva Stein, not Achba.

title: WPP Group to Buy 24/7 Real Media, an Online Ad Company
description: In an effort to catch up with Googles fast-growing online advertising business, the WPP Group, the advertising holding company that owns traditional ad agencies like JWT and Grey Global Group, agreed today to pay about $649 million to acquire 24/7 Real Media, an advertising network and technology company.

title: Votes on Troop Withdrawal Highlight House and Senate Differences
description: Its a given that the House and Senate are different legislative and political animals.

title: Sharing the Thrill, and the Heartbreak on the Racetrack
description: The Little Red Feather Stables horse racing syndicate gathered April 20 to watch its 3-year-old filly Guts Game, a 6-5 favorite, in a $44,000, one-mile race at Aqueduct Race Track. Mets catcher Paul Lo Duca was there, as were Kenny Mayne of ESPN and Bob Brittingham, a partner in Afleet Alex, who won the Preakness Stakes and the Belmont Stakes in 2005.

title: Rising Star Knows What, Not Who, Is Cooking
description: IT is late afternoon, and Momofuku Ssam Bar in the food-fixated East Village is idling in self-service mode waiting for the cocktail crowd  pretty much indistinguishable from the pierced and tattooed waiters  to saunter in.

title: U.S. Championship, Round 3: Some Fireworks on the Top Boards
description: Imaginative attacks ruled the day on the top boards at the Frank Berry United States Championship which is being played in Stillwater, Okla. Alexander Shabalov surged into the lead with his third straight victory, but only a half point behind sit a quartet of strong grandmasters, including Hikaru Nakamura, Alexander Onischuk, Jaan Ehlvest and Gregory Kaidanov. The games can be seen live or replayed  here  at Monroi.com.

title: Big Oil, BP, and Berkeley
description: Robert Malone, BP America Chairman, speaks at Berkeley, California. Paul Sakuma/AP

title: London luxury
description: View

title: Pulse
description: What I'm wearing now, Gola sports shoes, Noko baby clothing and more.

title: Journeys End to End; Moon Turns Green; New Address for the Grinch
description: "Journey's End," the critically acclaimed World War I drama, could take home as many as six Tony Awards on June 10, including one for best revival of a play.

title: Theater  Briefs
description: It will be "110 in the Shade" for a couple of weeks more. The Roundabout Theater Company announced yesterday that its revival of the musical starring Audra McDonald has been extended for two weeks, through July 29, at Studio 54.

title: Russian Developer Plans $2.2 Billion I.P.O.
description: The PIK Group, a Russian residential property developer, said on Friday it planned to raise up to $2.2 billion through an initial public offering in London and Moscow that would value the group at up to $14.1 billion. The I.P.O., which would be one of the largest to date by a European property developer, has been priced at between $25 and $31 a share.

title: Ferrovial to Sell Majority Stake in Naples Airport, Report Says
description: Grupo Ferrovial, the Spanish builder that spent $19 billion buying the British airport operator BAA, is preparing to sell its 65 percent stake in Naples International Airport, Bloomberg News reported. Ferrovial this week asked investment banks to bid for a contract to handle the sale of the stake, which has a value of at least 300 million euros ($409 million), Bloomberg said.

title: Venture-Backed Amicus Sets I.P.O. Price
description: A biopharmaceutical company, Amicus Therapeutics set its planned initial public offering on Thursday at 5 million shares for an estimated $14 to $16 each. Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch, J.P. Morgan, Lazard Capital Markets, and Pacific Growth Equities are underwriting the I.P.O., according to an amended filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Calls to Remove CVS/Caremark Director
description: An investment advisory firm is calling for the board of CVS/Caremark to remove a director, Roger L. Headrick, amid concern that his re-election was aided by phantom votes, or votes cast without guidance from shareholders.

title: Does Blackstone Want the Best of Everthing?
description: Blackstone Groups proposed initial public offering has become a focal point for criticism, in part because its structure gives the impression that the private equity firm wants to have its cake and eat it, too, The Financial Timess Lex column writes. It seems to be pushing the boundaries in order to get favorable tax treatment while seeking to avoid undesired regulatory restraints. There are good reasons for the firm to go public, Lex writes, but the question is on what terms.

title: Institutional Venture Partners Raises $600 Million for Late-Stage Deals
description: A Silicon Valley venture firm, Institutional Venture Partners, raised $600 million in the largest venture fund in its 26-year history, double the size of its previous fund, as it shifts its focus to late-stage investments.

title: Phillips Sells $2.5 Billion in Taiwan Semiconductor Shares
description: Royal Philips Electronics, Europes largest consumer electronics maker, sold $2.56 billion of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing shares as part of a plan to shed its entire stake in the chipmaker within three years.

title: G.E. Nears $11 Billion Deal to Sell Plastics Unit
description: General Electric is close to reaching an agreement to sell its plastics division for about $11 billion to Saudi Arabias largest public company, the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation, according to press reports.

title: Russia Sues Bank of New York Over Money Laundering
description: The Federal Customs Service of Russia is seeking $22.5 billion in damages from the Bank of New York over accusations of money laundering in the 1990s.

title: Ex-Chief of Chip Maker May Lose Proxy Fight
description: The former chief executive of Atmel, George Perlegos, appears unlikely to win back control of his company on Friday when his plan to replace five board members goes before shareholders, according to The San Jose Mercury News.

title: Chilean Retailers in $3.7 Billion Deal
description: SACI Falabella, the biggest operator of department-stores in Chile, agreed to buy a supermarket owner, Distribucion Y Servicio D&S, for $3.7 billion to form one of the biggest retailers in Latin America and to expand internationally.

title: Motorola Rings Up Deal for Modulus
description: Motorola agreed to acquire closely held Modulus Video, a maker of video coding compression systems, for an undisclosed price. Motorola said the Modulus acquisition will complement the companys recent purchases of four other companies involved in the creation and delivery of an integrated, end-to-end video delivery system for multiple network architectures.

title: After Failed Bid, Qantas Chairwoman Decides to Retire
description: Margaret A. Jackson, the chairwoman of Qantas Airways, who was one of the proponents of a failed attempt to take the airline private, will retire, a company spokesman said Thursday. Ms. Jackson, 54, told the board that she would not seek re-election at the airlines annual meeting in October.

title: 2 Banks See Departures at Hedge Fund Businesses
description: Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers have both experienced high-level departures in their hedge-fund-related businesses, the Financial News reported. The turnover comes as investment banks have been trying to capture more business from these private pools of capital. Bear Stearnss co-head of prime brokerage, Leonard Feder, left the firm for personal reasons, while Lehman lost Jin Park, deputy chief investment officer of its fund of hedge funds unit.

title: Ex-Ahold Official Sentenced
description: A former marketing executive of the American-based food distribution unit of the Dutch food retailer Ahold was sentenced to seven years in prison by a federal judge yesterday for his role in an $800 million accounting fraud.

title: Financier Says He Is Not Target of Swiss Arms Investigation
description: A Syrian-born financier who helped broker a $79 billion arms contract between BAE Systems and Saudi Arabia two decades ago said Thursday that he was not a target of a money-laundering investigation opened this week by the Swiss authorities.

title: KB Home in Talks to Sell Stake in French Homebuilder
description: Los Angeles-based KB Home said Thursday it was in exclusive talks to sell its controlling stake in a French homebuilder for 600 million euros ($813 million) to a European buyout shop. Moving quickly to sell an operation that is outperforming its activities in the United States, KB Home said it is in talks to sell the 49 percent stake in the French unit, Kaufman & Broad, for 55 euros a share to PAI Partners, a Paris-based private-equity firm.

title: Bank of Americas Private Banking Chief to Step Down
description: The Bank of America, which expects to complete its $3.3 billion purchase of Charles Schwabs U.S. Trust private banking arm this fall. said Thursday that its private banking chief, Jane Magpiong, plans to leave the company.

title: BP and Rio Tinto Team Up for Venture
description: The Rio Tinto Group, a mining company that is a major producer of coal, will join BP to develop power generation plants that will pump their carbon dioxide emissions underground to help curb global warming. The companies said Thursday that Rio would pay BP $32 million for a 50 percent stake in a new company, to be called Hydrogen Energy. BP will fold its carbon capture and storage operations into the new entity.

title: Citigroup Works Both Sides of Distiller Deal
description: Bankers at Citigroup may celebrate the latest Indian cross-border takeover with a few extra drams of Scotch. The bank played a leading role on both sides of the deal, the buyout of a 163-year-old Scottish distiller by one of Indias most aggressive acquirers.

title: Is EMIs Offer-Soliciting Just a Tease for Warner?
