description: With indications pointing toward the European Unions likely approval of both the SonyBMG merger and the Universal Music Groups purchase of BMG Music Publishing, London-based EMI Group has moved into full sale mode, the New York Post reported citing unidentified sources.

title: In Search for a New Financial Sheriff, One Stands Out
description: As New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer won national attention by becoming the new sheriff in finance, taking on Wall Street and mutual funds and the insurance industry.

title: Iacocca: Hard on Daimler, Cautious on Private Equity
description: Lee A. Iacocca, Chryslers former chairman and cigar-chomping pitchman, is not mincing words on what led to what he calls Chryslers desperation sale to Cerberus Capital Management.

title: A Fractured Heart and a Filthy Mouth
description: A Michael Keaton outing is always cause for celebration, no matter how ramshackle the vehicle ("First Daughter," anyone?) or paper-thin the role. He's an actor who works on the balls of his feet, forever poised for flight or the next reckless opportunity. Unpredictability is his game, and when he's on top of it, he can make you forget that there's a script.

title: Fishing for a Buyer, Trump Entertainment Gets Some Nibbles
description: Trump Entertainment Resorts, the casino company controlled by Donald J. Trump, has received preliminary offers from possible buyers, although details on who the potential suitors might be were not disclosed.

title: The 24/7 Real Media Sale: A Story of Frenemies
description: With the purchase of 24/7 Real Media, WPP Groups chief executive, Martin Sorrell, who called Google a frenemy last fall, is hoping to become a frenemy himself.

title: The Breakdown of a Breakdown
description: Movie audiences hoping to spend a cheery couple of hours with Alzheimer's disease this week will have a choice, as Yukihiko Tsutsumi's "Memories of Tomorrow" joins Sarah Polley's "Away From Her" in theaters. But while Ms. Polley maintains a cool, respectful distance from her victim's suffering, Mr. Tsutsumi would like us to experience every symptom for ourselves.

title: Cerberus May Put Together Bid for BCE, Report Says
description: Cerberus Capital Management, fresh from signing its $7.2 billion deal for Chrysler, is courting Shaw Communications and CanWest Global Communications to join a possible buying group for one of Canadas biggest companies, BCE, according to The Globe and Mail.

title: Cadburys Drinks Unit Attracts a Dozen Bidders, Report Says
description: Britains Cadbury Schweppes has received about a dozen expressions of interest in its United States drinks business, Reuters reported.

title: Whats Happened to the Lawyers Who Worked for Spitzer?
description: After reining in Wall Street analysts, curbing mutual fund trading abuses and corralling some of the biggest insurance companies in the industry, what do you do for an encore? For the lawyers who worked under Eliot Spitzer in the New York attorney generals office, the options have ranged from law firm partnerships to state agency heads, The New York Times found.

title: Germany Stands Alone in Battle to Rein in Hedge Funds
description: Germany will make a last-ditch effort Friday to persuade the worlds top economic powers to tighten their grip on hedge funds and private equity firms. But even before these countries finance ministers convened at a Group of 8 meeting, the push was being written off as futile, illustrating Germanys isolation in its desire to rein in the booming industry.

title: Bernankes Buyout-Lending Blues
description: The struggling United States housing market is not the only thing worrying Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke. Speaking at a conference Thursday in Chicago, Mr. Bernanke sounded his first public warning about potential dangers for banks that are helping to finance the recent run of leveraged buyouts. Eager for the lucrative business brought by private equity deals, many banks have been going the extra mile to make loans on friendly terms.

title: UniCredit May Announce Capitalia Deal, Report Says
description: UniCredit, Italys biggest bank, may be close to announcing plans to acquire a smaller competitor, Capitalia, Bloomberg News reported. Shares were halted for the day on Friday pending news, a Milan stock exchange spokeswoman said.

title: In Deal for Chrysler, Snows Role Extends a Trend
description: At a news conference this week in Stuttgart, Germany, the usually secretive private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management was in the spotlight, announcing an agreement to take control of Chrysler.

title: 2008: Spouses and Race
description: The Timess Jodi Kantor and Jeff Zeleny profile Michelle Obama, calling hers the trickiest of political performances. A part of that trickiness is the ambiguity of races role in the election. The Washington Post reports on the split loyalties that many black lawmakers are grappling with when choosing their favorite candidate:

title: Dead-End Jobs
description: Ever since Bram Stoker gave Count Dracula a Transylvanian lineage, Eastern Europe has been a familiar setting for horror tales. "Severance" continues the tradition by turning a corporate retreat in a Hungarian forest into a bloody game of whack-a-mole. (Team building and paintballing are so last year.)

title: Microsoft Pays Up for Online Advertising Firm aQuantive
description: Microsoft said Friday it would buy aQuantive, an online advertising firm, for $66.50 a share in cash. The deal, valued at $6 billion, was easily Microsofts largest acquisition ever and the price represented an eye-popping 85 percent premium to aQuantives closing price Thursday.

title: Reflections in Super 8
description: The premise of "Rolling Like a Stone" makes it sound like a Christopher Guest comedy: members of the 1960s Swedish rock bands the Namelosers and the Gonks and some of their friends and groupies pore over Super 8 snippets from a 1965 party they attended with the Rolling Stones, trying to remember the event and their lives at that time.

title: The Life of a Trust Fund Punk
description: There may be a point to "The Boy Who Cried Bitch: The Adolescent Years," a purportedly fact-based psychodrama about the teenage evolution of a future serial killer. But the film is so clumsily written and directed, and the performances so one-note, that any potential for enlightenment is suffocated.

title: Closer to War
description: What "Six Days" is doing in theatrical release rather than on the History Channel isn't quite clear; the film, about the 1967 war in the Middle East, is a standard-issue documentary, and a rather plodding one. But at least it makes for an interesting compare-and-contrast exercise.

title: A Whiter Shade of Green
description: Van Jones, writing at the Huffington Post, has an unusual criticism of the environmental movement: that it presents itself as being as white as the polar ice caps its trying to save. I see a disturbing pattern of exclusivity that is starting to set in, Jones writes. And that kind of elitism can sow the seeds for a very dangerous, populist backlash, down the line. To see what I mean, just flip through the pages of Vanity Fairs recent green issue (the one with Leo DiCaprio and that cute polar bear cub on the cover)  Now, count the non-white Americans in the whole magazine. Okay. Now try to find the working-class environmentalists, the ones trying to protect their kids from pollution at the fence-line? Vanity Fair, elitist? Say it isnt so

title: Whos the New Sheriff?
description: The Empire Zones colleagues in the business section ponder who has filled the gap among state attorneys general as the new Sheriff of Wall Street, as Gov. Eliot Spitzer was often called in his previous job.

title: The War on Terror Weakens Our Foundations
description: Readers respond to David Brookss May 18 column, The Insurgent Advantage.

title: Survey Says
description: About two and a half weeks ago I provided a link from this blog to a survey that Sherri Kimes, a professor at Cornell University, is doing. The survey concerns diners attitudes and behavior when it comes to making reservations at restaurants and dealing with the reservation policies that restaurants have. I described it in that blog post, where I also said that from time to time, Professor Kimes would fill me in  and I would in turn fill you in  on bits and pieces of what the survey was showing.

title: Teaching a Door New Tricks
description: Ill wrap up my coverage of this years Modern Marvels Invent Now competition with one more of my favorites.

title: In Cycling, a Race to the Bottom
description: On Thursday, a sports blog called Off Wing Opinion posted a preview of a big day at the trial of Floyd Landis, the Tour de France champion who is accused of doping on his way to the 2006 title.

title: Dance of a Billion Veils
description: Diane Cardwell listened in yesterday as Mark Green, in his new non-politician role, interviewed his former opponent, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, on Air America radio for a program to be broadcast next week. (WNBC has video).

title: Clear Channel Accepts Revised Takeover Bid
description: Clear Channel Communications is hoping that an extra 20 cents a share, plus the option to own a piece of the company, will finally clear the way for its controversial buyout to go through. The radio broadcasting giant said Friday that it had agreed to amend the terms of the buyout to include $39.20 in cash for each Clear Channel share, up from $39, and a provision allowing shareholders to take stock in the post-takeover company instead of cash. The stub equity, as the stock portion is commonly called, would be limited to 30 percent of Clear Channels equity and would not be listed on any exchange, Clear Channel said in a press release.

title: The Rent Went Up $2,100, but Was the Increase Legal?
description: Q I moved into an apartment that a previous tenant lived in for more than 20 years. The rent history I dug up shows that rent was $400 a month and that the apartment was rent-stabilized. I was never told that the unit was stabilized and wasn't provided with any information as to why the rent was increased to $2,500. Do I have any options?

title: Before the aQuantive Deal, Lots of Well-Timed Trades
description: Whether it was because of sheer luck or an inside tip, options traders made some big bets on aQuantive on Thursday  just in time to cash in on the companys $6 billion deal to be acquired by Microsoft. Trading in aQuantives options has been active for weeks, driven in part by the rampant takeover speculation surrounding many independent Web advertising firms since Googles $3.1 billion deal for DoubleClick in mid-April. But according to Jon Najarian, co-founder of OptionMonster, activity in aQuantives call options went through the roof on Thursday, with a volume of 9,363 contracts, or more than five times the average volume on the previous five days.

title: McCain-Giuliani Fan-Fest
description: Love was in the air when Senator John McCain and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani spoke before New York Republicans last night.

title: The Cure for Road Rage?
description: In his weekly call-in radio show on WABC, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said his congestion pricing proposal received a cordial reception in Albany earlier this week but he hinted at a long fight ahead.

title: The People, They Are a-Changin
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Bloomberg on the Guest Worker Deal: Totally Impractical
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has been a staunch advocate of easing immigration restrictions, offered harsh words for the guest-worker provision in the immigration deal struck Thursday between senators and the White House.

title: Treasure Hunt Inc.

More Hellfire From Ford Boycotters
description: Is the Ford Motor Company the top pro-homosexual sponsor on all of network television? Thats what the American Family Association said this week.

title: Microsoft: Tight-Fisted No More?
description: Microsoft had about $28 billion in cash and short-term investment on March 31, an amount the CIA World Factbook tells us is more than twice the gross domestic product of Iceland. But despite its riches, the software giant has shied away from large acquisitions, especially in the past five years or so. That is part of the reason Fridays $6 billion cash bid for online advertising company aQuantive was so surprising. (The 85 percent premium it agreed to pay was something of a shock as well.)

title: Bruno, Steaming
description: Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno spoke after Rudolph Giuliani and before Senator John McCain last night at a Manhattan fund-raiser for the state Republican Party.

title: For Chrysler Workers, Private Equity May Cut Both Ways
description: When United Auto Workers president Ron Gettelfinger annouced Monday that his union supported the sale of Chrysler to Cerberus Capital Management, it case caused whiplash for many industry observers. Before the deal was announced, the U.A.W. had publicly opposed selling the beleaguered auto maker to a buyout firm, citing the potential for waves of layoffs that may follow.

title: Making a Case for Congestion Pricing
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg faces huge hurdles in getting the State Legislature to go along with his congestion pricing proposal, but there were indications at a forum this morning that local officials are sympathetic to his position.

title: For One Hedge Fund, April Was the Cruelest Month
description: For all the talk about how hedge funds are raking in cash and earning double-digit returns all the time, its helpful to remember that they can lose  and lose big. Witness the letter that Jurg Buhler, managing director of Dighton Capital, recently sent to investors in his small ($34 million) fund registered in the Cayman Islands.

title: Weekend Reading: The State of Investment Banks
description: The Economist this week offers a huge package on investment banks, tracing their history and all the thrills and spills along the way to the highly profitable present and the highly uncertain, risk-laden future. According to the magazine, while buyout firms and hedge funds are getting most of the attention, glory and money these days, investment bankers dont mind. When bankers discuss the fabulous fortunes accruing to these firms founders, they do so without envy, The Economist writes.

description: Long before the immigration deal was announced on Thursday, candidates in the 2008 presidential field and indeed, the down-ballot field, had faced a lot of questions inside and outside the border states over the nations policies.

description: Were about four hours from first pitch here at frigid Shea Stadium. Note to fans planning to attend tonights game against the Yankees: dress warmly. Youll thank me later.

description: Where luxury living meets eco-friendly construction. A video tour.

description: There was lots of good news to be found in the new plans.

description: John McCain invokes "Drunken Sailor" at a recent Republican primary debate. (source: FOX News Channel)

description: The New York Post came out swinging today against charges made by a former staffer.

description: Well, we no longer have Paul Wolfowitz to kick around any more, so whos next?

description: Come fall, campaign junkies will have yet another way to get their political news, one that will rely largely on ordinary citizens, not political reporters or media pundits.

title: Frugal Traveler: Seeking the Real in a Desert City Known for Artifice
description: Dubai is place that caters to the super-wealthy, but savvy travelers can find a few welcome bargains if they look hard enough. Do you have tips and suggestions how to enjoy Dubai cheaply? Share your suggestions here.

title: Yankee Math
description: Even if they lose tonight, the Yankees cant fall another full game behind the Boston Red Sox. Thats because the Red Sox have already been rained out.

title: What Precautions Are Necessary for a Safari in Kenya?
description: I am planning a photo safari to Kenya and am told I need vaccinations and malaria protection. My tour guide tells me to see my doctor; Cond Nast Traveler magazine tells me to see Johns Hopkins Travel Medicine; the Department of Health and Human Services refers me to Passport Health travel clinics; my doctor refers me to a Centers for Disease Control Web site (www.cdc.gov/travel) and tells me to look up a member of the International Society of Travel Medicine. Please help; there are too many choices.

title: Third M-Tel Masters: The Race Tightens
description: The M-Tel Masters is proving to be very competitive. Krishnan Sasikiran of India, who surged into the lead in round 7, was beaten in round 8 by the American Gata Kamsky. (The game can be replayed here.) Liviu-Dieter Nisipeanu of Romania also won, beating Michael Adams of England. (Click here to replay the game.) So with two rounds to play, Sasikiran still leads with 4.5 out of 8, followed by Kamsky, Nisipeanu, Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria and Shakhriyar Mamedyarov of Azerbaijan, all with 4, and Adams with 3.5.

title: As Losses Mount, Torre Praises the Effort
description: The first thing I heard Joe Torre say as I wedged my way into the visiting managers office at Shea Stadium tonight was this: Everyones on the top rail. Everyones pulling for everyone else. Thats all we have to hang on to right now.

title: Childress Racing and D.E.I. Plan to Merge Engine Shops
description: CONCORD, N.C., May 18  Richard Childress Racing and Dale Earnhardt Inc., two high-profile Nascar Nextel Cup teams, announced Friday that they would consolidate their engine shops in a move to remain competitive with Ford, Toyota and Hendrick Motorsports.

title: Eviction Notice Is Latest Russian Move Against Journalists
description: MOSCOW, May 18  The largest society of independent journalists in Russia, long critical of the Kremlins curtailment of the independent news media, defied a government eviction notice on Friday, saying it would try to remain in its offices in spite of state pressure.

title: Microsoft to Buy Online Ad Company
description: Microsoft said today that it would buy the online advertising company aQuantive for $66.50 a share, or approximately $6 billion. It is Microsofts largest acquisition ever, and the latest in a flurry of deals for online advertising firms by big Internet and media companies.

title: Atmel Shareholders Vote Down Fired Chiefs Plan to Oust Board
description: Shareholders in the Atmel Corporation rejected a proposal yesterday by the former chief executive, George Perlegos, to remove five directors after the company promised to add two new directors and focus on its semiconductor unit.

title: One Composer, Two Choreographers, Three Geniuses
description: I cherish an old cartoon that depicts an all-Tchaikovsky concert at which cygnets (Swan Lake, of course) are being thwacked by cannonballs (the 1812 Overture). A Tchaikovskys Greatest Hits evening will always draw. But what makes New York City Ballets new program, Three Masters  Tschaikovsky, Balanchine, Robbins, fascinating (yes, City Ballet spells the composers name with an s, as in Tsch ... You know who) is that its a strong triple bill made up of works that, except among balletgoers, arent among the composers best known or most generally admired.

title: Gmez Is Making a Name With His Attacking Style
description: Carlos Gmez has spent less than a week in the major leagues. He has 15 at-bats. He lives in a hotel a few blocks from Shea Stadium.

title: BMW Oracle Falls Further Back
description: VALENCIA, Spain, May 18 (AP)  After dominating the early rounds of the Louis Vuitton Cup, BMW Oracle Racing has stumbled at the worst possible time.

title: Evolution Opponent Is in Line for Schools Post
description: The National Association of State Boards of Education will elect officers in July, and for one office, president-elect, there is only one candidate: a member of the Kansas school board who supported its efforts against the teaching of evolution.

title: Fishing on a Belizean Island and Enjoying a Nice Day
description: PLACENCIA, Belize  The fertile reefs and flats of this Central American nation may be the best place for a flyfisher to score a grand slam, which consists of catching a bonefish, a tarpon and a permit on a fly, all in the same day. But when you are on a family vacation instead of on a mission, and staying in a pleasant, sleepy seaside village instead of Fort Flyfisher, its wiser to set aside those dreams of angling immortality, shove a few beers into the cooler, and just kick back and see what the day brings.

title: New in New York: A Bus Ride on the Hudson River
description: Until this week, tourists in Manhattan who wanted to go for a cruise on the Hudson River had to find the river first. Now, they can simply hail a boat in Times Square.

title: Clemens Takes First Step in His Return to the Mound
description: TAMPA, Fla., May 18  For two innings Friday night, it seemed preposterous to think Roger Clemens could be ready by the end of the month to pitch for the Yankees. As he pitched for the Class A Tampa Yankees, his two-seam fastball had no life and he was throwing curveball after curveball, as if he had nothing else to offer.

title: British Girl Vanishes in Portugal, and Her Country Grieves
description: LONDON, May 18  For 15 days, the wide eyes and waiflike features of a child of 4 have stared out at Britons from television screens and newspaper front pages, T-shirts and posters with a simple message: find me.

title: For Ballets Shifting Casts, a Big Question: Who Will Lift It to the Realm of Poetry?
description: There was lush beauty in the arch of Diana Vishnevas resilient back and in her ethereal arms as she portrayed the doomed temple dancer Nikiya in American Ballet Theaters Bayadre on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. And the hungry passion of her fleeting first-act encounter with Solor, danced by Ethan Stiefel, made his eventual betrayal even more surprising.

description: To the Editor:

description: In the Mets clubhouse, Oliver Prez is about as invisible as anyone 6 feet 3 inches can be. The rare times he is at his locker, Prez sits staring spellbound at his cellphone or portable video game player.

description: PARIS

title: Veterans of Storm Find Relief in Combat
description: HARVEY, La., May 16  For Brett Hughes, the best way to cope with the stresses of life after Hurricane Katrina turned out to be flipping another guy over onto the floor, choking off his blood supply and threatening to mangle his limbs.

title: Shoppers Are Holding Back, but Billionaires Are Buying
description: A PRIVATE equity fund and some well-known billionaires were in acquisitive moods this week. Less affluent shoppers  consumers, that is  were more restrained, as the results of retailers showed, but Amazon hopes to tempt them with music. Tyco is still bleeding.

title: Estonia Computers Blitzed, Possibly by the Russians
description: MOSCOW, May 18  The computer attacks, apparently originating in Russia, first hit the Web site of Estonias prime minister on April 27, the day the country was mired in protest and violence. The presidents site went down, too, and soon so did those of several departments in a wired country that touts its paperless government and likes to call itself E-stonia.

title: Dont Finance Anyone Over 27
description: THE environment for todays entrepreneurs is far different in a number of ways from the boom of the late 90s, Steven Levy noted this week in Newsweek.

title: Macho Meets the Mystical in a Himalayan River Trek
description: The tiny kingdom of Bhutan was ranked the eighth-happiest country on earth in a study last year by a British scientist at the University of Leicester in England. It is probably no coincidence that the Bhutanese do not go in for white-water kayaking. Leave it to the West to import this perilous activity and make a documentary about it.

title: A Television Revolution? Not Shown at Upfronts
description: This years television upfront presentations, where the networks open giant briefcases and introduce samples from their fall lineups to advertisers, came and went with whimpers.

title: The Grace and Humor of the Body Imperfect
description: Lawrence Goldhuber has made a career of defying expectations. He weighs, by varying reports, 300 to 350 pounds, unusual, to say the least, for a dancer. But Mr. Goldhuber had a memorable nine-year career with Bill T. Joness company before establishing a reputation as a witty, touching dance-maker.

title: Their Masters Voice
description: In March 2004, the acting attorney general distrusted Alberto Gonzales so much that he wouldnt meet with him at the White House without a witness. Eight months later, President Bush promoted Mr. Gonzales from White House counsel to attorney general, the top law enforcement job in the land. The president is still standing by his man, ignoring Mr. Gonzaless efforts to mislead Congress, his disregard for the Constitution and his gross neglect of even basic bureaucratic duties.

title: Say-on-Pay Gets Support at Verizon
description: A proposal to give Verizon Communications shareholders a voice in its executive pay practices passed with 50.18 percent of the vote, the company said yesterday  the clearest sign yet of investor irritation over chief executive compensation.

title: China Will Allow Its Currency to Fluctuate More
description: HONG KONG, May 18  Chinas central bank announced late today that it would begin allowing the countrys currency to fluctuate more during each days foreign exchange trading but again rebuffed demands from the United States and Europe for a sustained rise in the currencys value.

description: The war in Iraq may be complicated and confusing, but the Memorial Day story from it told in Act of Honor, tonight on the History Channel, is as basic and noble as war stories get: one soldier chooses to die so that his comrades can live.

description: BEIJING, May 18  A young Chinese couple who have promoted a variety of delicate social and political causes were barred from leaving the country on Friday and placed under house arrest, the couple said.

description: MIAMI, May 18  Explorers for a shipwreck exploration company based in Tampa said Friday that they had located a treasure estimated to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars in what may be the richest undersea treasure recovery to date.

description: The World Bridge Productions Pairs was run alongside the late stages of the Cavendish Invitational Pairs, held outside Las Vegas last weekend. This was a much smaller affair. Only 28 pairs entered the three-session World Bridge event, for which the entry fee was $750 a pair.

title: Recalling the Music and the Spirit of a Mother of Many
description: The musical and the spiritual were inseparable during the Alice Coltrane Ascension Ceremony, a memorial held on Thursday night at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. In a lengthy but carefully organized program, a succession of musicians and speakers attested to a life of devotion. From a screen beside the altar, her projected image cast a beatific gaze.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about a case before the Connecticut Supreme Court that questions whether civil unions for same-sex couples fulfill the states constitutional obligation to treat individuals equally misidentified the legal standard that would be applied if the court found that gay men and lesbians were a suspect class, a status, like membership in a racial minority, that makes laws that categorize on that basis suspect. The standard is heightened scrutiny, which requires the state to prove that discrimination against gay men and lesbians is related to an important or compelling government interest; it is not rational basis, a more relaxed standard in which the state is required to show only that it had such a basis for making a distinction between single-sex and heterosexual couples.

description: Consider the pros and cons for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton:

description: SAN ANTONIO, May 18  Steve Nash tried to fend off elimination as well as thoughts of what if by staging one last desperate rally for the Phoenix Suns.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about the role that Barack Obamas wife, Michelle, is playing in his presidential campaign rendered incorrectly a word in a quotation from Valerie Jarrett, a friend of the Obamas who commented on their decision that he would run. She said in a telephone interview, Barack and Michelle thought long and hard about this decision before they made it  not that they fought long and hard.

title: U.S. Forces Seize 6 Linked to Armor-Piercing Bombs
description: BAGHDAD, May 18  American soldiers on Friday captured six men in northeast Baghdad suspected of involvement in smuggling materials for deadly armor-piercing bombs, the military said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the rising number of abortions among unmarried women in China gave the incorrect location in some copies for Qingdao, a city where a nongovernmental abortion clinic opened in 2003. It is on the Yellow Sea, not the Bohai Sea.

title: Hunt for Fugitive Beset by Confusion, Report Says
description: The biggest manhunt in state history  the five-month search for Ralph J. Phillips last year in the backwoods of western New York  was thwarted time and again by communications problems, command confusion, troopers misjudgments and over-reliance on an elite mobile unit, a state police report says.

title: Sobered by Its PlayStation 3s Tumble, Sony Shows Its New Toys With a Soft Pitch
description: SAN DIEGO, May 16  Dont envy Jack Tretton. As the new chief executive of Sony Computer Entertainment America, Mr. Tretton may have the toughest job in the video game business (with the possible exception of his boss, Kazuo Hirai, who is taking over Sonys global game operation).

title: At a University in India, New Attacks on an Old Style: Erotic Art
description: NEW DELHI, May 18  Its a heady time for Indian contemporary art. Never before has it fetched such extravagant prices and acclaim abroad. Never before have Indians at home been so prosperous as to support a proliferation of galleries, exhibitions and even investment funds devoted to art.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about a partnership of Vornado Realty Trust and Donald J. Trump, which controls two buildings in New York and San Francisco, misstated the role of David H. Pikus in mediation proceedings involving Mr. Trump and his former partners in a development on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Mr. Pikus is the special discovery master, in charge of working out discovery schedules and procedures  not the mediator, who is Simeon H. Baum, president of Resolve Mediation Services Inc.

title: Putting Aside His Past Criticisms, Teamsters Chief Is on Mission to China
description: SHANGHAI, May 18  Three years ago, the head of the Teamsters union, James P. Hoffa, derided China as xenophobic. He said that China did not believe in free trade and that the United States was losing jobs because China was unwilling to buy American goods.

title: Shock Therapy to Resuscitate Rite-Aid Chain
description: Mary Sammons joined Rite-Aid as president and chief operating officer in 1999, part of a team brought in to save the company, the third-largest drugstore chain, from bankruptcy. The former chief executive, Martin L. Grass, eventually went to jail because of an accounting scandal that overstated earnings by $1.6 billion  leading to what was at the time a record profit restatement.

title: 2 Raped by Minister Are Awarded $11.45 Million
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., May 18  In one of the largest judgments in a child sexual abuse suit against the Roman Catholic Church, a Long Island jury on Friday awarded a total of $11.45 million in damages to a young man and woman who were repeatedly raped by a youth minister as teenagers starting in the late 1990s.

description: WASHINGTON, May 18  Hours before a bipartisan deal on immigration policy was to be announced Thursday, a tenuous compromise was threatening to unravel, and tempers flared once again.

description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about concerns in Congress that Al Hurra, an American-financed television channel in the Middle East, was broadcasting the views of militant groups referred incorrectly to comments by Joaquin F. Blaya, a Hurra executive, about the criticism. He said it was ironic that the government was seeking to promote values like democracy and a free press while trying to censor  not censure  what was shown on the station.

title: Clinton Offers Steps to Ease Hurricane Aid
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 18  After touring empty homes that still bear the scars of Hurricane Katrina, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said Friday that bureaucratic red tape was strangling people trying to rebuild here, and proposed steps to speed money to current and former residents of the city.

title: Donald M. Ginsberg, 73, Expert in the Working of Superconductors, Is Dead
description: Donald M. Ginsberg, a physicist who became a leading expert on the production and functioning of superconductors, died on May 7 at his home in Urbana, Ill. He was 73.

title: Thousands of Buildings Lack Required Water Valve, New York Records Show
description: As many as 85,000 large residential and commercial buildings in New York City lack special valves on their water connections that could prevent hazardous substances from being sucked into the public water system, according to city records.

title: Forget the Pitching Woes. Its Hitting Thats Giving the Yankees Problems.
description: The season is teetering on disaster, so it was no surprise that Joe Torre knew the details of Roger Clemenss minor league start only moments after the Yankees loss last night.

title: New Routes and New Risk, as More Haitians Flee
description: PROVIDENCIALES, Turks and Caicos, May 16  There is no conceivable way to get from this island to Miami by bus. But the traffickers who ply Haitis northern coastline in search of those willing to risk their bleak lives for better ones abroad tell some tall tales to fill their rickety boats.

title: After Another Early Playoff Exit, the Rockets Let Van Gundy Go
description: SAN ANTONIO, May 18  On the day that the Houston Rockets fired him as their coach, Jeff Van Gundy was back preparing for a playoff game  once again working as a television broadcaster.

title: Much Muscle, Less Meaning
description: Vasco Wellenkamp, the co-artistic director of Companhia Portuguesa de Bailado Contemporneo, uses a lot of aggressive movement. Sometimes he uses really aggressive movement. If hes feeling especially wild, he throws in a languid pause or two.

title: Great Space, Glass Floor-Through, Canyon Views
description: GRAND CANYON WEST, Ariz.  A visitor to these stark and imposing lands of the Hualapai Indians on the western rim of the Grand Canyon knows what sensation is being promised at the journeys climax. After driving for a half-hour over bone-jolting dirt roads some 120 miles from Las Vegas, you take a shuttle bus from the parking lot, not far from where helicopters are landing, and construction is proceeding. You deposit all cameras at a security desk, slip on yellow surgical booties and stride out onto a horseshoe-shaped walkway with transparent sides and walls that extends 70 feet into space, seemingly unsupported.

title: White House Says It Will Move Quickly to Replace Wolfowitz
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  The Bush administration promised Friday to find someone quickly to succeed Paul D. Wolfowitz as president of the World Bank and bring management skills to the job of healing an institution battered by the turmoil over Mr. Wolfowitzs tenure.

title: Giants Fill Scouting Vacancy
description: The Giants named Marc Ross as their director of college scouting yesterday, filling a vacancy created when Jerry Reese was promoted to general manager in January. Ross, 34, was 27 when the Eagles made him the N.F.L.s youngest college scouting director in December 2000. He spent the past three seasons as the national college scout for the Buffalo Bills.

title: California: Appeal Fails in Terror Case
description: Hamid Hayat, a Lodi man convicted last year of providing material support for terrorism by attending a training camp in Pakistan, lost his appeal for a new trial and will be sentenced Aug. 10. Mr. Hayat, 24, faces up to 39 years in prison, after Judge Garland E. Burrell Jr. of Federal District Court in Sacramento denied the motion for a new trial Thursday. In the appeal, Mr. Hayats lawyer said the trial was unfair because the jury foreman hid a prejudice against Pakistanis. The lawyer also objected to the way testimony from an F.B.I. informant and several expert witnesses was handled.

title: Gangly Exultation, With Punctuation
description: There was a crash course in disco-punk groove construction on Wednesday night, when !!! began its sold-out show at the Bowery Ballroom. First came a beat, kick-started by the no-nonsense drummer Jerry Fuchs. Next, a bass line, audaciously played by Justin Van Der Volgen. Then there were some washy keyboard noises, just a few, before the addition of the singer Nic Offer, who immediately shared a secret of the trade: Only takes a little bit, a gleam or a glimmer/Only just a little bit, a shake or a shiver.

title: Even When Pavano Is Gone, His Presence Is Felt
description: The Yankees are back in New York. Their $39.95 million pitcher is also in New York. But that pitcher, Carl Pavano, did not come to Shea Stadium last night to see his teammates. According to General Manager Brian Cashman, the visitors clubhouse is too small.

description: For the two bidders for Clear Channel Communications, the third time may be the charm.

description: UPPERVILLE, Va., May 15  Bert and Diana Firestone will not be at the Preakness Stakes on Saturday, but they will be watching, and more intently than most. This is the time of year when their memories of the 1980 Triple Crown campaign and their terrific filly Genuine Risk come flooding back.

description: JERUSALEM, May 18  Israel struck more targets of the Palestinian faction Hamas on Friday, while forces from the groups Palestinian rival, Fatah, fired mortars at Hamass Islamic University and exchanged gunfire with fighters inside.

But its clear they havent been serious; the U.S. has 1.3 million abortions a year.

description: MOSCOW, May 18  The police detained more than a dozen opposition leaders and journalists here on Friday, preventing them from flying to a provincial city to take part in anti-Kremlin protests. The action followed a wave of harassment of the protests organizers.

title: Corzine Talks of New Outlook: Seize the Moment
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 18  Saying that his recent brush with death had prompted him to seize the moment, Gov. Jon S. Corzine disclosed on Friday that he planned to select a chief justice of the State Supreme Court who was young enough to leave an indelible stamp, and that his decision would be made public no later than June 4.

title: Can Cities Save the Earth?
description: The mayors of some of the worlds biggest cities have every reason to feel especially anxious about climate change. Their populations are the biggest polluters but also among the most vulnerable to weather-related catastrophes. And they are far ahead of their national governments in giving urgency to global warming. So, for the second time since 2005, the leaders of dozens of cities, representing 400 million people, have stepped up. Meeting in New York this week, they produced a plan that should shame G-8 leaders into at least saying something about the issue at their meeting next month.

title: Singer at the End of Time: The Video Diary of Lisa Lopes

title: A Return to the Land, for Fuel
description: LAHAINA, Hawaii  Here on the West Side of Maui, where lush mountainsides and the warm waters of the Alalakeiki Channel juxtapose increasingly crowded roadways and a spate of new luxury hotels, the push for renewable energy has found an unlikely advocate: the chief executive of one of the most aggressive developers on the island.

title: They Come in Peace, Surrounded by Extension Cords
description: New Yorkers do impatience like pros. Boredom, not so much; the citys denizens are far too overstimulated and attention-fractured to approach anything like the drifty languor of this underestimated state.

title: Schubert and Two 20th-Century Surprises
description: The final concert of the season at the 92nd Street Ys chamber music series, on Wednesday evening, was devoted to works for strings and included a duo, a trio, a quintet and a sextet. But instrumental combinations aside, the most striking aspect of the program was the way warm-toned, comfortably familiar music was juxtaposed with early-20th-century works that had sharper and more ragged edges.

title: Right Time, Wrong Publicity
description: Burgers and alcohol have been an unlucky combination for David Hasselhoff, even more than we knew. First came the leaked video of him that flooded television and the Internet a couple of weeks ago: he sits on the floor, slurring words as he talks to his teenage daughter, so drunk he cant get a burger into his mouth. Now comes this revelation from his just-published autobiography, Dont Hassel the Hoff. After a couple of stints in rehab, one that included a nighttime escape from Betty Ford, he started drinking again and craved a midnight snack.

title: Poetry Holds the Stage for a Whole Day
description: It was not, O worshipers of words, the 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee but rather the 35th Annual Spring Poetry Festival. And 9-year-old Gabriel Nazir Mejia was waxing, yes, poetic  about writers block.

title: Italian Banks Said to Be Near a Merger
description: LONDON, May 18  UniCredit, Italys biggest bank, is expected to announce this weekend that it has agreed to buy a rival, Capitalia, to bolster its business at home after years of expanding abroad.

title: A New Reality in Washington, but Can It Last?
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  Six months after Republicans lost control of Congress, President Bush is learning the rules of a game that, for six years, he seemed to have forgotten: the Capitol Hill edition of Lets Make a Deal.

title: Poisoned Toothpaste in Panama Is Believed to Be From China
description: Diethylene glycol, a poisonous ingredient in some antifreeze, has been found in 6,000 tubes of toothpaste in Panama, and customs officials there said yesterday that the product appeared to have originated in China.

title: Kazakhstan: President Voted In for Life if He Likes
description: Parliament voted to exempt President Nursultan Nazarbayev from a provision in the Constitution limiting presidents to serving two terms. The vote effectively clears the way for Mr. Nazarbayev, a former Communist Party official who has led Kazakhstan since its independence from the Soviet Union, to become president for life. Mr. Nazarbayev has never been elected by a poll judged free or fair by Western election monitors and has long been dogged by corruption allegations and complaints of crackdowns on the opposition and the news media. But Kazakhstan, which gave up its abandoned Soviet nuclear arsenal after independence, has been spared the wars, terrorism, personality cults and much of the disorder of other Central Asian states. Many of Mr. Nazarbayevs critics say he has significant popular support.

title: A Trade by French Brothers, Made for Love, Bien Sr
description: In the 19 years since Yves Abel started LOpra Franais de New York to explore the French opera canon, he has become a master at wringing magnificent performances from the most modest materials. For the companys performance of Rameaus Castor et Pollux at the French Institute Alliance Franaise on Thursday evening, Mr. Abel had no scenery to speak of, but he made do with a table, a few chairs and a small props collection.

Keira Knightley, above, and Orlando Bloom return as Elizabeth Swann and Will Turner, his valiant sidekicks, whose wedding day is torpedoed in the opening scene. description: WASHINGTON, May 18  Congressional Democrats and the White House remained at odds over a war spending measure on Friday after a crucial negotiating session ended with both sides expressing disappointment and accusing the other of being intractable.

title: Giuliani Endorsement Expected

The announcement is significant because the Senate is the Republican Partys last statewide power base and because the states elective influence was bolstered when New York officials recently moved the 2008 primary date to Feb. 5 from March 4. Hes coming up Tuesday and were looking forward to doing some very positive things with him at that time, Mr. Bruno said of Mr. Giuliani.

description: Helen Simpsons short stories read like cautionary tales about the ravages of parenthood, harrowing dispatches from the front lines of middle-class family life. Her previous collection, Getting a Life, dissected modern British domesticity, the tenderness included, with a mordant wit. In her new collection, In the Drivers Seat, child-rearing is still a marathon of compromise and exhaustion  and now illness, as her characters get older. If they remain wry and indomitable, it might be that death is no match for someone whos faced the daily car pool.

title: South Africas Valley High

Boulders glowing like hot coals tumbled down the nearby mountain of Saronsberg. Downtown on Church Street, textbook examples of thatched-roof Cape Dutch architecture were reduced to rubble. I was convinced theyd dropped an atomic bomb on Cape Town, is how Nicky Krone, whose family owns the local winery Twee Jonge Gezellen, describes it. Buck, a distinguished pilot who in the 1930s crossed the continent at record speed, flew a light plane higher than anyone had done before and photographed ancient ruins of the Yucatn from the air for the first time  all by the age of 20  died on April 14 in Berlin, Vt. He was 93 and had continued to fly gliders into his late 80s.

title: 03 Marlin Pitchers: Ones That Got Away

description: In the ocean of biographies, Albert Einstein is the white whale: impossible to ignore, almost as difficult to capture, symbolic as all hell. Who could resist going after the man whose name and face have become synonymous with genius?

description: RICHARD SERRA tells a story from his youth, one that begins to take on the contours of a Greek hero-and-mentor myth.

title: By Air, Boat and Web, a Fiji Getaway
description: It may seem like a combination of Survivor and Gilligans Island, but Tribewanted.com is a real social and environmental experiment. The effort to transform a tiny island in Fiji into a sustainable, democratically run community, is now a year old and has grown to 1,160 tribe members from 35 countries.

title: More Mammograms (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Making the Maestro Collaborator in Chief
description: MANY musicians of high school age have devoted teachers whom they respect and depend on. But only at a conservatory or a university music school do young hot-shot musicians typically encounter teachers of awesome stature like the cellist Janos Starker and the pianist Leon Fleisher. Music students develop transformational relationships with these inspiring, sometimes intimidating masters, more so, in my experience, than students in the visual arts, acting, writing and other creative fields.

title: Condos Tighten the Rules
description: EVERYONE knows that buying a condominium in New York City is supposed to be much easier than buying a co-op. More expensive maybe, but definitely easier.

title: Visible Man
description: Ralph Ellison burned out as an artist under excruciating circumstances. His failure to complete a second novel after his landmark book, Invisible Man, exploded onto the scene in 1952 was already a source of pain just six years later, when he wrote to Saul Bellow about having a writers block as big as the Ritz. His suffering intensified as the years rolled by and contemporaries like Bellow (Ellisons onetime housemate), John Cheever and Bernard Malamud all capitalized on their talents and moved on into prolific maturity. His predicament was worsened by the feeling that he had failed not only himself but the broader black society whose aesthetic he had hoped to champion in a great book that would rival Moby-Dick.

title: Correction: Moyduh, He Watched: Commissioner Turns Critic
description: An article last Sunday about a new DVD version of The Naked City referred incorrectly to the 1948 film. It was considered a prestige release, not a B movie. (B movies were low-budget features that played second on a double bill.)

description: To the Editor:

title: Coming Home
description: PATRICK ONEIL, tall and broad-shouldered, towers over many of his classmates at the New York City College of Technology in Downtown Brooklyn, and at age 31 he is older than many of them. But there is also a less apparent gulf between Mr. ONeil and his fellow students.

title: Putting the Skinned Knees Back Into Playtime
description: JOSEPH GALLO, 10, of Santa Cruz, Calif., is well armed in the battle against childhood boredom, with a bedroom arsenal that includes a computer hooked to the Internet, a DVD player, two Game Boys, as well as an Xbox and a GameCube.

title: Up Front
description: DEBBY APPLEGATE was an undergraduate at Amherst College when she was asked to put together an exhibit on famous Amherst alumni. Applegate, class of 1989, soon discovered Henry Ward Beecher, class of 1834, who became something of an obsession for her. She went on to write a seminar paper about him, then a senior thesis, then a Ph.D. dissertation at Yale, then a Pulitzer Prize-winning biography. Beecher, she said in an e-mail message, is a bit like the Forrest Gump of the 19th century, popping into all the great debates of the era, from the noble, like the antislavery or woman suffrage movements, to the frivolous, like whether women should wear bloomers. Applegate doesnt have a new project in mind yet. In some ways, finishing a book after spending 20 years on a subject is like breaking up with a longtime boyfriend  you need a little breather before jumping back into a new relationship, she said. But she was delighted to write about a book on the art-collecting Clark family because Ive always secretly wished that Id become an art critic. This week, she reviews Nicholas Fox Webers Clarks of Cooperstown.

title: Monica Ferguson, Cameron Murphy
description: Monica Byrne Ferguson, a daughter of Karen and John J. Ferguson of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Cameron Scott Murphy, a son of Suzann and John J. Murphy of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Mark Connolly performed the ceremony at St. Mary Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: The New New List
description: London is the new Rich.

title: Wilsons Gems, Memorys Ocean
description: THE 20th century still had 15 years to go when Aunt Ester died at the age of 366. The news was announced, in August Wilsons drama King Hedley II, as if the apocalypse had arrived. Lock your doors! screamed a backyard prophet of Pittsburgh named Stool Pigeon. Close your windows! Turn your lamp low! We in trouble now. Aunt Ester died!

title: Curlins Feat Lifts Asmussen to Top Echelon of Racing
description: BALTIMORE, May 19  Steve Asmussen has won a lot of races as a trainer, but usually on quiet days at empty racetracks when the spotlight shined elsewhere. The Triple Crown dates had always been someone elses domain.

title: Conspiracy?
description: Within minutes of learning of President John F. Kennedys murder on Nov. 22, 1963, Robert F. Kennedy was working the phones, looking for answers to how his brother had died. Theres so much bitterness, he told a colleague that day. I thought they would get one of us. But who were they? Robert Kennedy gravitated immediately to a shadowy nexus of forces he believed were at odds with the policies of his brothers administration. Was it the C.I.A.? he asked John McCone, the director of central intelligence. Was the assassination the work of anti-Castro Cubans? Was it the American Mafia? Or was it  since there were hidden but important connections among these groups  a combined effort by them all? Before he had ever heard the name Lee Harvey Oswald, Robert Kennedy was considering scenarios that would eventually become the foundation of the myriad conspiracy theories that have haunted the American imagination for more than 40 years; according to David Talbot, he continued to explore those scenarios until his own death in 1968, even while publicly denying his belief in a conspiracy.

title: After Bronx Crash, Minivan Driver Is Fatally Shot by Off-Duty Officer
description: An off-duty police officer shot and killed a driver in the Bronx late Friday night when the man, who had just crashed into another car, began to pull away after the officer confronted him.

title: Chelsea Edges United to Win FA Cup
description: LONDON, May 19 (AP)  Didier Drogba scored during extra time Saturday to give Chelsea a 1-0 victory against Manchester United in the first F.A. Cup final at the rebuilt Wembley stadium.

title: Hollywood and Green
description: His green roots: It started in 1970, because of the first Earth Day. As a Boy Scout Id had exposure to the outdoors, and I grew up in very, very, very smoggy L.A. in the 50s and 60s. Youd have trouble breathing. By 1970 I said, Ive had enough.

title: Matsuzaka Carries Day as Red Sox Hum Along in First Place
description: BOSTON, May 19  In a 13-3 thumping of the Atlanta Braves in the chill and mist of Fenway Park on Saturday afternoon, the first-place Boston Red Sox looked like a juggernaut, worthy of the 9 -game lead they hold in the American League East.

title: Fantasy Baseball
description: A switch-hitting country boy with phenomenal power and a killer smile, Mickey Mantle symbolized the New York Yankees dominance in the 1950s. But he was also a womanizer and an alcoholic who could injure himself in battles with water coolers and golf clubs. (He died at 63, a victim of cancer and his own careless lifestyle.) Like Joe Namath, that other swinger who took New York a decade later, the Mick possessed an endearing fragility that became a part of his resonance. We didnt just root for him, we felt for him, the broadcaster Bob Costas said at Mantles funeral, in 1995. He was our guy.

description: Michael Brecker

title: Another Injury to Another Pitcher Produces Another Loss
description: The Yankees recent plight probably does not generate much sympathy around Queens, not with their 26 World Series titles and their latest one captured at the hands of the locals. But if, if, if there ever were a time when Mets fans could, even for a fleeting second, look deep into their hearts and commiserate with their crosstown rivals, it might have been during the first four innings of yesterdays game.

title: The Road Best Not Taken
description: Oakland, Calif.

description: THIS summer, be sure to pack some extra cash in your carry-on. More airlines are starting to charge for services that used to be free on many carriers.

description: The Presidents Tax Cuts and the Growing Economy

title: Flooding by the Numbers
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency measures disasters in a way that only a statistician could love. It turns out that the agency does not simply assess damage the storm inflicted on, say, each town. It estimates the cost of the damage per capita on the population of each county. If the figure does not reach $3.05 per capita, counties are out of luck in attaining the coveted federal disaster rating that would help pay for damage.

title: Cuomo Tackles Big Projects, Including His Image
description: ALBANY, May 18  The lunch in the Capitol was in Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomos honor, but that did not mean it was necessarily in friendly territory.

title: Israel Strikes Home of Palestinian Lawmaker
description: JERUSALEM, May 20  The Israeli Air Force struck the home of a Hamas Parliament member in Gaza tonight, killing eight people, Palestinian hospital officials said. The Parliament member, Khalil al-Hayya, was not in the house at the time.

title: Writers Take Out Their Knives
description: FOR all those who believe that Moby Dick would be great except for the parts about the whale, the British publisher Orion Books will publish this month a set of pared-down classics, cutting about 40 percent of what it calls padding from works like Anna Karenina, David Copperfield and yes, Moby Dick.

description: The thieves operated from small offices in Toronto and hangar-size rooms in India. Every night, working from lists of names and phone numbers, they called World War II veterans, retired schoolteachers and thousands of other elderly Americans and posed as government and insurance workers updating their files.

title: Breathless, Buoyant
description: THE last practice I remember was during the period between summer and fall, before summer had entirely faded and before autumn had entirely set in. The leaves had just begun to litter the back hills of the cross-country course of Van Cortlandt Park. We had been sent out to run six miles, past the hole in the fence, past the fruit market just outside the park, past the big oak tree; we all knew this was going to be a long run.

title: For Wright, Home Run Derby Continues After a Lengthy Slump
description: David Wright had two home runs in his first two at-bats against the Yankees yesterday, and he smiled when asked if he thought about hitting a third. But as Wright leaned on a wall in the Mets clubhouse, the smile vanished, and he insisted that he did not think about going deep.

title: Kill, Pray, Love
description: Early one morning in 1540, while a 12-year-old Saxon boy, Mattias Tannhauser, is tempering a dagger at his fathers forge, marauding Turks descend on his village in the Carpathian Mountains. Renegade foot soldiers bash his sisters head in and rape and kill his mother. Amid the many victims of this carnage, young Mattias is fortunate only because he can put his new dagger to immediate use  and in doing so he inadvertently shows a Turkish captain that he has a natural gift for the arts of war. Abbas bin Murad spares the boys life, carrying Mattias out of the village and into a life of adventure, amply documented in this first book of a projected trilogy by Tim Willocks. The summer reading season has officially begun.

description: To the Editor:

title: Cornell Remains Undefeated and Advances to the Final Four
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 19  Cornell midfielder Max Seibald spent a majority of the past week in the Big Reds training room. For about four hours every day, Seibald put his sprained left ankle through a combination of ice, whirlpool and electrical stimulation.

title: Duke Lacrosse Is Focal Point Again, This Time for the Good
description: Two seasons ago, when the Duke mens lacrosse team reached the N.C.A.A. tournament championship game for the first time in the teams history, its achievement went largely unnoticed.

title: French Revolution in Paris
description: The closest thing to a tourist attraction in the Paris neighborhood of Belleville is a small plaque commemorating the birth of Edith Piaf, posted on a drab apartment building on a busy street. On the steps of this house, the inscription reads, was born on 19 December 1915, in the greatest destitution, Edith Piaf, whose voice would later turn the world upside down. The story isn't quite true  in fact, Piaf was born in a nearby hospital  but it's a charming myth that evokes both Piaf's legendary rise from street urchin to international stardom and the hard-boiled mystique of her childhood quartier.

title: Gargoyle Man
description: IN 1973, a shy 13-year-old named Randall Dana was biking through the deteriorating landscape of the Lower East Side when he stumbled upon an awesome sight. A trove of architectural ornaments lay before him like ancient ruins: busts of Neptune, fierce lions, chimera, gargoyles and griffins. Embedded in the facades of 19th-century buildings, these victims of decades of neglect were headed into the hands of demolition crews, landfills and certain extinction.

title: The Nuclear Threat
description: One need read only the first three pages of The Atomic Bazaar to be reminded of William Langewiesches formidable talent as a journalist whose cool, precise and economical reporting is harnessed to an invigorating moral and intellectual perspective on the world he describes. In a single paragraph, he lucidly explains the basic physics of the uranium-based atomic bomb that destroyed Hiroshima. Once a professional pilot, and the author of Inside the Sky, Langewiesche then leads the reader inside the pressurized, well-heated cockpit of the Enola Gay, flying at 31,000 feet in smooth air, piloted by the young Colonel Paul Tibbets, and vividly reconstructs the evasive maneuver taken by the B-29 as it banks steeply to minimize the coming shockwaves, while the bomb, named Little Boy, falls for 43 seconds before igniting several miles below, lighting the sky with the prettiest blues and pinks that Tibbets had ever seen. Tibbetss subsequent career, from Air Force general to Internet purveyor of autographed souvenirs of that momentous flight, is adroitly sketched. The bombing of Nagasaki three days after Hiroshima, with a plutonium device, is handled in brisk but sufficient detail. Langewiesche counts the total killed in the two attacks (around 220,000), then delivers his own one-sentence bomb: The intent was to terrorize a nation to the maximum extent, and there is nothing like nuking civilians to achieve that effect.

title: Jennifer Gellmann, Raul Rothblatt
description: Jennifer Stacy Gellmann and Raul Rothblatt are to be married today in Brooklyn. Rabbi Hara E. Person is to officiate at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios, a film production complex at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Tara Pfeifer, Alexander Englander
description: Tara Sue Pfeifer and Alexander Fisher Englander were married last evening by Rabbi Peter Rubinstein at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan.

title: Red Light for Breathing
description: THE Bloomberg administrations proposal to charge cars and trucks to enter Manhattan below 86th Street will help reduce air pollution and improve the health of some New Yorkers, but not all. Indeed, it is likely to worsen the health of many New Yorkers, particularly the poor.

description: HIGH BRIDGE, folded into a valley in the southwestern Bronx, welcomed its first wave of Manhattanites in the 1920s; developers promised them more room for less money.

description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., May 18  Shay Doron waited for her lifes dream to unfold last month at the W.N.B.A. draft.

title: A Coastline Smorgasbord
description: The old towns along the North Shore of Staten Island, with their Victorian and Colonial houses, retain some of their charm from the days before the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge ushered in waves of development. The restaurant scene, meanwhile, has taken on a life its own, with a diverse mix of 15-year standbys like Aesops Tables and newcomers like Nrnberger Bierhaus, open a little more than a year.

title: Trieste, Italy: Buffet da Pepi
description: Among experienced travelers, Trieste is widely considered a town barely worth visiting. I don't get it. With the central square and a broad canal right on the Adriatic, the eclectic architecture, the converging cultures ... O.K., it's not Venice, but neither is it Bridgeport.

title: At the Mall, Mariachi Instead of Muzak
description: ON a sunny day in early May, more than 12,000 people descended on the Plaza Fiesta Mall in Atlanta for a Cinco de Mayo festival celebrating Mexican heritage. Fourteen bands played mariachi; reggaetn, a sort of Latino rap; and banda, which is traditional Mexican brass music. There were carnival rides, and tortillas sizzled on grills.

title: Two Officers Tried to Rob Drug Suspect, Officials Say
description: Two New York City police officers have resigned after being accused of trying to rob the apartment of a suspected drug dealer in New Jersey, a law enforcement official said yesterday.

title: Its a Sleeper (and a Keeper): Small but Big in Choices
description: CHEF Luis on the main shopping street in New Canaan is such a sleeper that several friends begged me not to review it. Its too small, too much business will spoil it.

I am very focused on large-scale deployments of renewable power and how were going to get this done. Imagine our military bases covered with solar thermal collectors that could generate steam and electricity.

title: Correction: In-Town Living in Morristown

description: IN the 1985 movie Pee-wees Big Adventure, the title character turns to a friend and murmurs darkly, There are a lot of things about me, things you wouldnt understand, things you couldnt understand, things you shouldnt understand.

title: Catching Up on a Little Light Reading
description: IN the 1930s the paperback made its appearance. Readers in Germany, Britain and the United States responded enthusiastically to the idea of a small-format book that could be slipped into the pocket and read on the bus or train. What a novelty it seemed, a streamlined leisure product fitting for a scientific age.

title: Emily Sheehy, Reed Carey
description: Emily Jean Sheehy, the daughter of Theresa Towle of Plaistow, N.H., and John Sheehy of River Vale, N.J., was married on Friday to Robert Reed Carey, a son of Roberta and John Carey of Easton, Md. The Rev. Kevin D. Bean, an Episcopal priest, officiated at St. Bartholomews Church in New York.

title: So, Did You Pack the Ticket for the Air Ambulance?
description: WHEN Christopher Peabody, 60, of Laguna Beach, Calif., suffered life-threatening intestinal problems in Morelia, Mexico, last month, her son, Wyatt, flew to her side from Los Angeles. Although he speaks Spanish fluently and calls Mexico a second home, he was horrified when he saw the hospital.

title: What Exactly Is a Condop?
description: PEOPLE often wonder what exactly a condop is.

title: Gettysburgs Martial Plan
description: This summer may be your last opportunity to see the Cyclorama Center, the 1962 visitors center designed by Richard Neutra and Robert Alexander overlooking the battlefields of Gettysburg in Pennsylvania. The building is scheduled for demolition within the next two years. A new visitors center will occupy a structure designed to simulate a round barn from ye olde days  an oddly Virginian conceit for a site where General Lees army went down to bloody defeat.

title: A Basket Case in North Carolina
description: The old Appalachian ballad Lord Daniel is a bracing dose of adultery and murder at 7:45 a.m. Not that we need extra stimuli. Sleeping in is the province of the young, and the average age at John C. Campbell Folk School hovers somewhere around . . . well, to employ the equivalent of describing certain political candidates as clean and articulate, the students do seem to be a spry lot. Easily 80 of us have gathered in the community room to hear Jan Davidson, the director of the school, lead us in our first session of MorningSong, the half-hour of music and stories that starts our day.

title: Spread the Wealth of Spousal Rights
description: WHEN the poet Elizabeth Barrett Browning wrote, How do I love thee? Let me count the ways, little did she know that a century and a half later the list would extend into the thousands  at least for married couples. As of 2005, the Government Accountability Office had identified more than 1,000 legal rights and responsibilities attendant to marriage. The era of big government is clearly not over when it comes to family policy.

title: Seeking the Real in a Desert City Known for Artifice
description: IN many ways, this brunch was like a million others Id had before: poached eggs with hollandaise sauce, fresh orange juice, coffee, buttered toast. The sun was glowing somewhere over the comfy outdoor sofas, and no one seemed in a hurry to finish up and get home.

title: As a Director, Clinton Moved Wal-Mart Board, but Only So Far
description: In 1986, Sam Walton, the founder of Wal-Mart, had a problem. He was under growing pressure from shareholders  and his wife, Helen  to appoint a woman to the companys 15-member board of directors.

description: LOS ANGELES

title: The Soviet Pianist Who Wasnt All Thunder
description: LISTENERS who regularly make their way along the main roads and side streets of New York music know that it wont be long before they come across another young pianist from the former Soviet Union. One hardly needs to open the program. Correct Mozart or Beethoven will be offered as a duty fulfilled. There will be high-powered Chopin or Liszt played with staggering competence.

title: They Eat Horse Sashimi in Tokyo, Dont They?
description: An American chef I know told me about a dream he had in Tokyo after an intense bout of professional eating. Dinner had been an exhausting affair, during which every creature of the sea appeared at the table. The feast ended after 4 a.m. with the entire restaurant staff lined up on the street outside, waving good night. My friend woke in his hotel room later with a vivid memory and an unsettling lump in his gut: he dreamed he'd swallowed his camera.

title: Erin Love, Lawrence Strauss
description: Erin P. Love and Lawrence C. Strauss were married yesterday at the Berkshire Botanical Garden in Stockbridge, Mass. Judge Paul Perachi, the presiding judge of the Berkshire juvenile division of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts trial court system, officiated.

title: The Zero-Energy Solution
description: Mike Strizkis house, the house of the future, the revolutionary house that might very well change our lives forever, is an unremarkable two-story, 3,000-square-foot, white colonial-style kit home in front of which, one rainy day last November, were parked no fewer than seven trucks and cars, a pair of Jet Skis, a speedboat on a trailer, several golf carts, a small tractor, a couple of vans and an old dump truck rusting in the middle of the woods, like a major reworking of a Robert Frost poem. There was nothing odd, or futuristic, or exotically eco about the house  no solar panels to be seen, no giant arrays of thermopane windows passively drinking up light and heat; yet here, Id been told, in the Sourland Mountains in New Jersey, an hour from Manhattan, was a house that had the potential  not long from now, not 20 years from now, but maybe within 5 to 10 years  to help turn millions of American homes into fully self-sustaining power plants, each one capable of producing hydrogen to fuel cars as well.

title: Mr. What-If Is Circling Around My Marriage
description: MY wife and I have been married 27 years, but her first husband still wants her back. When were together at family functions, he tells everyone that hes just waiting for me to die so he and Julie can remarry. He acts like hes joking, but he means every word of it.

title: Nicole Hauptman, Cory Siegel
