description: Floresta

title: Hedge Funds to Manage Part of Illinois Teachers Pension
description: The Illinois Teachers Retirement System said Friday it would allocate more than $1.6 billion of its $39.7 billion pension fund to hedge funds strategies and $425 million to private equity firms as part of a new fund manager mix. Among those chosen to help manage the funds were the hedge funds Bridgewater Associates and AQR Capital Management as well as fund-of-fund groups K2 Advisors and Grosvenor Capital Management.

title: Bad Hair Days Lead to Venture Capital Funding
description: For many entrepreneurs in the first dot-com boom, the name of the game was portal-matic. Spin a wheel, pick a niche interest group, build a comprehensive Web portal aimed at that groups needs and cash a venture capitalists check.

title: Bank of America Faces Discrimination Suit
description: Five black current and former employees of Bank of America have filed a lawsuit that accuses the bank of racial discrimination by steering lucrative clients to their white counterparts. The complaint, filed Thursday in the Federal District Court in Boston, contends that the bank discriminates against African-Americans in pay, promotions, training and support services.

title: Tourists Ogle a Less-Frenetic N.Y.S.E.
description: The Empire State Building, Times Square and now the floor of The New York Stock Exchange. The New York Post reports that the trading floor, once home to 5,000 traders, is now a tourist destination, as electronic trading has substantially cleared the floor of traders and given those who remain more time to give tours to customers.

title: Traffic, Heavy Traffic and Statistics
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was in Albany last week lobbying state lawmakers on his PlaNYC, a raft of measures  many needing state aid and approval  to ensure that New York City grows in an environmentally sustainable way. Legislators were treated to a PowerPoint presentation in which Mr. Bloomberg showed slides depicting a dire future of street traffic and overloaded subways, and he asked for new daytime fees for driving in much of Manhattan, new subway construction and other measures.

title: V.C.s Help Build Gorilla Nation
description: As the Internet advertising frenzy continues, the online ad and marketing firm Gorilla Nation Media said Friday that it had secured a $50 million equity investment from Great Hills Partners, which will take a substantial minority position.

title: Sneaker Brands Seen as Ripe for Buyouts
description: Footwear brands Skechers USA and Genesco, which has retail brands such as Lids and Journeys in its stable, are emerging as two leading targets to be taken private in the retail and footwear sectors, according to Womens Wear Daily. In April, Genesco rejected an unsolicited $1.2 billion bid from Foot Locker, saying it undervalued the company.

title: In Congress, Plenty of Work Before Recess
description: Nothing typically motivates a member of Congress like the approach of a recess. Majority Democrats better hope that the impending Memorial Day break is a highly potent incentive given the amount they hope to accomplish in the next few days.

title: Siemens Names New Chief
description: The German engineering giant Siemens on Sunday appointed Peter Lscher, an Austrian-born outsider from the pharmaceutical industry, to lead the scandal-scarred company starting July 1. The announcement ends uncertainty over who will run the biggest engineering and technology company in Europe after the current chief, Klaus Kleinfeld, said he would step down after less than three years running the company.

title: S.E.C. Gets Monthly Briefing from C.I.A.,Report Says
description: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is being briefed monthly by the Central Intelligence Agency about terrorists and other criminals active in global stock markets, according to Barrons, which called them the first regular intelligence briefings in S.E.C. in history. S.E.C. Chairman Christopher Cox told Barrons that he and four other commissioners are briefed each month by the CIA, offering the S.E.C. a somewhat sharper focus to an underworld of murky, illegal dealings that threaten the world capital markets.

title: Spitzer, Nixon and Gonzales
description: As one might expect, Eliot Spitzer, the former New York attorney general turned governor, has some opinions about Attorney General Alberto Gonzales. As one might expect, they are not kind.

title: Too Old to Innovate?
description: The environment for todays entrepreneurs is far different in a number of ways from the boom of the late 90s, Steven Levy noted this week in Newsweek. It is dramatically cheaper to start a company now, he wrote, so it is substantially easier to build a business, sometimes without needing venture capital. Software tools, which used to cost hundreds of thousands, are now largely free, while computer equipment and bandwidth are much less expensive.

title: M&A Extends Markets Bull Run
description: Corporate takeovers helped spur the Dow Jones industrial average to its 24th record close this year on Friday, even as the Standard & Poors 500-stock index came within striking distance of its record high. The latest takeover news, including deals involving marquee names like General Electric and Microsoft, signaled that the enormous amount of liquidity that has lubricated global stock markets in recent months is still in good supply. The M.& A. activity and earnings seem to be holding up better than expected. I think youre going to see more of this, Bill Dwyer, chief investment officer at MTB Investment Advisors, told The Associated Press.

title: Acer May Be Hunting Smaller Game
description: Acerchairman and chief executive J.T. Wang made headlines recently when he said his rapidly expanding PC company planned to make a meaningful acquisition soon. But according to a report from The Deal.com, Acer is far more likely to strike a modest deal outside the U.S.

title: Bill Richardson's Candidacy
description: As he officially declares his candidacy, Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico discusses his run for the White House.

title: Arlingtons Main Line Takes Radio One
description: Radio One has agreed to sell 10 radio stations to Main Line Broadcasting for about $76 million cash. Main Line, a portfolio company of Washington private equity firm Arlington Capital Partners, is buying four stations in Dayton, Ohio, and six in Louisville, Ky.

title: First Stop: Hong Kong
description: Nicholas D. Kristof visits Hong Kong for the first time since the handover.

title: Training Ground for Democracy
description: Images related to the Christoph Bchel exhibit at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art.

title: Goldman and SBI Team Up for Japan Venture
description: Goldman Sachs Group and Japanese venture capital firm SBI Holdings have agreed to form a joint venture to provide growth capital to mid-sized companies Japan and overseas. SBI said Goldman would buy a 40 percent stake in its subsidiary SBI Capital for an undisclosed sum, and the venture would aim to manage 100 billion yen ($825 million) in assets within three years.

title: When Book Reviews Coincide With Deal-Making
description: Former Vice President Dan Quayles byline appeared in this weekends issue of The Wall Street Journal over a chatty, first-person review on the latest book on golf by John Feinstein. And it just so happens that, in what The New York Times describes as an interesting quirk of timing, the review appeared on the same weekend that Cerberus Capital Management  the private equity and hedge fund firm where Mr. Quayle works  was sewing up its landmark deal to buy Chrysler.

title: Hologics $6.2 Billion Deal Cytyc Deal Aimed at Women
description: Patrick J. Sullivan, the chief executive of the Cytyc Corporation, and Jack W. Cumming, the chief of Hologic, like to joke about their companies splitting the geography of the female body. Hologic, a leader in breast cancer diagnostics, focuses on the top half, while Cytyc, a leader in diagnostics for cervical cancer, focuses on the bottom half.

title: Collins Stewart to Buy CE Unterberg, Report Says
description: British broker Collins Stewart, continuing its push into the U.S. market, is buying CE Unterberg, Towbin, the privately owned New York-based investment bank, for $44 million, The Financial Times reported.

title: Monday Morning Motorsports
description: In the WRC, Sebastien Loeb made a rare mistake and crashed out of the Rally dItalia Sardenga on the morning of the third leg. Marcus Gronholm took advantage of the miscue, leading his Ford teammate, Mikko Hirvonen, to a one-two finish as the rally championship series approaches the seasons midpoint. Loeb said he had pace issues from the start and pushed a little too hard. I had a wheel slightly on the verge, he said. I tried to bring the car back in line, but then I hit a big rock with my front left wheel. The win puts Gronholm seven points in front of Loeb in the championship.

title: China to Take Stake in Blackstone
description: The Chinese government said Sunday it would acquire a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group, the private equity firm, in the countrys first effort to diversify its $1.2 trillion in foreign-exchange reserves beyond United States Treasury bills and into commercial enterprise.

title: For Hedge Funds, Treasure Ahoy
description: A number of hedge funds that have significant stakes in Odyssey Marine may reap the rewards of sunken treasure after the company recently gained title to a colonial-era shipwreck.

title: Deal to Form Big Company to Train Prisoners
description: A company based in New Jersey that provides training and treatment programs to prison inmates is announcing today that it has bought a similar Massachusetts company, creating one of the largest correctional services companies in the country. The two companies  Community Education Centers of Roseland, N.J., and CiviGenics of Marlborough, Mass.  are trying to capitalize on the growing number of inmates and tight financing for new prisons that have led federal, state and local governments to contract out more of their operations to private businesses.

title: Does Lehman Need a Big Deal?
description: Lehman Brothers stock price and revenue growth have been lackluster over the last year, helping to drive speculation of a potential merger or even a sale of the giant securities firm, Breakingviews writes. It suggests that a merger with UBSs banking operations or a Cazenove-style venture with HSBC could make sense.

title: Germany Calls for Voluntary Hedge Fund Rules
description: Germany has switched tactics in its efforts to police the fast-growing global hedge fund industry, hoping to overcome skepticism by other Group of Eight member countries by encouraging the industry itself to compile a voluntary code of conduct.

title: As Murdoch Pitches Dow Jones, a Gossip Scandal Heats Up
description: If you were a member of the Bancroft family in the midst of deciding whether to sell Dow Jones & Company to Rupert Murdoch, reading Fridays New York Post might have made you choke on your bagel, The New York Timess David Carr declares.

title: APN Asks Shareholder to Express Itself on Buyout Bid
description: Australias APN News and Media said Monday it wants the fund manager Perpetual, APNs second-largest shareholder, to clarify its position on a planned takeover of APN by a group led by an Irish newspaper publisherIndependent News and Media.

title: Prosecutors Seek to Freeze Nacchio Assets
description: Federal prosecutors have asked a judge to immediately freeze the assets of Joseph Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, who was convicted last month of making $52 million from insider trading. In a motion filed Friday in Denver federal court, prosecutors said Mr. Nacchio and his wife, Anne Esker, have assets derived from the sales of Qwest stock worth more than $100 million, which is subject to forfeiture under federal law.

title: UniCredit to Buy Capitalia for $29.5 Billion
description: UniCredit, the Italian bank, agreed Sunday to buy a rival, Capitalia for 21.8 billion euros, or $29.5 billion, in an all-stock deal that would create Europes second-biggest bank behind HSBC Holdings. The merger also would strengthen the position of Italian lenders as consolidation in Europes banking industry gathers pace.

title: Yahoo Said to Consider Bid for Britains Bebo
description: Yahoo is working on a takeover offer for Bebo, the most popular social networking Web site in Britain, and is willing to pay up to $1 billion to seal the deal, according to The Telegraph.

title: G.E. to Sell Plastics Unit for $11.6 Billion
description: General Electric said Monday it had agreed to sell its struggling GE Plastics business to Riyadh-based chemicals company Saudi Basic Industries in an $11.6 billion cash deal. G.E. said it would receive net after-tax proceeds of about $9 billion, which would be primarily put toward the companys current stock buyback.

title: Buyout Firms Said to Consider Virgin Media Bid
description: Providence Equity Partners is leading a group that is considering a $15 billion bid for Virgin Media, the cable company in which Sir Richard Branson is the largest shareholder, The Observer reported Monday. The United States-based private equity firm is said to be speaking with its partners, including Blackstone, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Cinven, about the possibility of making an approach in the coming weeks.

title: In Iraq, Violence as Propaganda Tool
description: Daveed Gartenstein-Ross files a couple of interesting dispatches from Baghdad for the Counterterrorism Blog. The first is on the increasing deadliness of insurgents mortar attacks inside the IZ or Green Zone in the capital. The second is on the increasing number of journalists killed of late.Gartenstein-Ross feels the two trends are linked. Just as the mortar targeting of the IZ seems clearly part of the militants propaganda war, so too is the targeting of journalists. he writes. If journalists believe the country is falling apart, and feel that their profession places them in constant danger, that pessimism will be reflected in their writing. And just as Iraqi translators who work with U.S. troops need to be disguised while in the field, it has reached the point where Iraqi reporters with strong American sources need to be disguised too.

title: Stages of Cutty Sark Grief
description: They say that grief follows an orderly sequence over a prudent amount of time: denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance. On the Web, they can all happen within hours of an event, and in no particular order.

title: Bush Is Just Following Party Orders
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his May 18 column, Dont Blame Bush.

title: Blackstone I.P.O. Could Reach $4.75 Billion
description: Blackstone Group pulled back the veil a little further on its closely watched initial public offering on Monday, as it filed an amended prospectus with regulators. The major addition was the terms of its planned $3 billion investment from China, but the financial aspects of the offering were fleshed out as well. The private equity giant said that it planned to offer 133.3 million units at a price of $29 to $31 each and was giving underwriters the option of selling 20 million more. At the maximum, the I.P.O. could raise a whopping $4.75 billion (an amount that doesnt include the $3 billion infusion from Chinas investment arm).

title: Top of the Charts for Escaped Gorilla
description: Along with the usual smattering of scantily clad ladies, a gorilla named Bokito is dominating the YouTube charts today with four of the six most-watched video clips of the day.

title: Coast of Utopia, Spring Awakening Honored at Drama Desk Awards
description: "The Coast of Utopia," the Tom Stoppard trilogy about 19th-century Russia, won seven honors, including the accolade for outstanding drama, at the 2006-7 Drama Desk Awards last night at La Guardia Concert Hall at Lincoln Center.

title: Is Murdoch Getting Ready to Walk?
description: Richard Greenfield of Pali Research says he doesnt have any inside knowledge on the matter, but he is speculating that Rupert Murdochs News Corporation is likely to abandon its closely watched effort to acquire Dow Jones  at least for the moment.

title: For States, It May Be Worth It to Wait
description: In todays Web column, Adam Nagourney offers some unsolicited advice to any state still considering joining the rush to vote on Feb. 5 or earlier: Dont. At this point, your best chance for wielding real influence over the nominating process is to go later, not earlier.

title: Misery Chastain Cannot Be Dead!! Or, A Way to Save Jericho
description: Every compelling story produces its own brand of fans, with their own distinct style of story-worship.

title: A Boomtown Revisited
description: In his first stop on the Chinese mainland, Nicholas Kristof meets up with the Communist Party official he first profiled 20 years ago.

title: Merrill Lynch Takes Hedge Fund Stake
description: Merrill Lynch said Monday it would buy a minority interest in GSO Capital Partners, a hedge-fund firm with about $8 billion in assets under management. GSO was founded in July 2005 by Bennett Goodman, Tripp Smith and Doug Ostrover, all of whom had previously been at Credit Suisse.

title: EMI Accepts $4.7 Billion Bid From Terra Firma
description: The EMI Group, the British music giant that has drawn heavy takeover interest in the last year, said Monday it had agreed to be bought by Terra Firma, the private equity firm led by the financier Guy Hands. EMI, whose recent talks with another buyout firm, Permira, ended without a deal, said it was recommending Terra Firmas offer to its shareholders. The bid values EMI at 2.4 billion pounds ($4.7 billion).

title: American Album: Spell Utah
description: Kunal Sah, 13, hopes that winning the Scripps National Spelling Bee will bring attention to the plight of his parents, who were deported to India.

title: Saturday in Flushing
description: We went because we had to. Every once in a while, a need, a want, a hunger, wakes from its slumber and demands immediate and full satiation.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday with an article about the crisis faced by Africa's finest universities because of mismanagement, neglect and policies that favor basic education referred incorrectly in some copies to the broken piece of equipment being used by a chemistry student. It is a graduated cylinder, not a test tube.

title: Video: Hong Kong
description: Nick started his journey across China with a stop in Hong Kong. It was his first trip to the city since the British handed the colony back to the Chinese in 1997. Back then he wrote an article called Year of the Trojan Horse.

title: At Carlyle, a Taste for Designer Goods
description: Carlyle Group seems to have an eye for couture  in more ways than one. Even as the private equity shop vies with Permira Advisors to buy Valentino Fashion Group (which controls the Hugo Boss line), one of the firms employees is getting prominent play in New York magazine for her high-end taste in accessories. The magazines Look Book features an interview with Natasha Mitra, who is described as a private equity associate. (Her firm isnt identified, but Ms. Mitras name appears on Carlyles Web site.) The interview begins with a question that isnt really a question: Such big accessories!

title: Were Paying What in Taxes?
description: If we had been wavering about the need to reduce the construction costs of our dream home, a letter from the Manatee County Taxing Authorities eliminated all doubt.

title: Top Law Firms Look Farther Afield for Recruits
description: As they compete for fresh legal talent, some of the biggest law firms in mergers and acquisitions are apparently looking in some unusual places  like Brooklyn. So says a recent article by Bloomberg News, which uses the New York City borough as a kind of proxy for the so-called second tier law schools (loosely defined as any school not in the top 10) that are getting increased attention from the major firms.

title: Capitalia and the Lone Banker
description: With some companies hiring as many as seven advisory firms to help with one transaction, investment bankers by now must be used to sharing clients. Not so Claudio Costamagna, the former chairman of European investment banking at Goldman Sachs in London.

title: Kurds Fleeing Northern Iraqi City
description: Conflict between Arabs and Kurds is intensifying in Mosul, adding another dimension to Iraq's civil war.

title: To the Editor: Please See Wiki
description: Our colleagues on the opinion side of The New York Times receive about 1,000 letters a day, many seeking to address remarks that should not be suffered to pass unnoticed, as one put it in 1851.

title: MTV Ad
description: An ad for MTV.

title: MTV Ad
description: An ad for MTV.

title: Revving Gores P.R. Machine
description: Al Gore  who recently described himself as an unlikely, but not impossible candidate for president in 2008  is starting a publicity tour this week for his new book, exposing himself to the intensifying questions about his political plans.

title: McCains Way With Words, Still Intact
description: Fresh from his dustup with Republican Senate colleague John Cornyn last week, John McCain used a conference call with bloggers today to take on a more obvious intra-party rival, Mitt Romney. Ryan Sager of The New York Suns Latest Politics blog gives us the details:  Maybe I should wait a couple weeks and see if it changes, Mr. McCain said of Mr. Romneys position on immigration this week. Maybe he can get out his small varmint gun and drive those Guatemalans off his yard.

title: Cell Phone Tip: Use It As a Silent Alarm
description: In a note from my friend Bill Ginsberg, president of the New York PC users group, he passed a long a tip from a buddy of his, a psychology PhD candidate whos writing his dissertation on his Treo smartphone!

title: End of an Era, Captured on Tape
description: Online Videos by Veoh.com

title: A Real Food Fight
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his May 21 column, Fear of Eating.

title: Another Needless Death
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts May 21 column, Young, Ill and Uninsured.

title: High Crimes and Chocolate
description: Relenting after pressure from vegetarians and those who keep Kosher, Masterfoods has flip-flopped on the issue of using animal products in British chocolate bars.

title: Has Kerkorian Put MGM Mirage in Play?
description: Kirk Kerkorian said this afternoon that he planned to pursue strategic alternatives for his controlling stake in MGM Mirage, the giant hotel and casino company. Mr. Kerkorian also said that he planned to enter talks to buy Bellagio Hotel and Casino and City Center properties from MGM Mirage. The brief, three-sentence statement from Mr. Kerkorians holding company, Tracinda, has caused a lot of head scratching at DealBook about his intentions, but that hasnt stopped investors from bidding up shares of MGM Mirage by more than $9, or 15 percent, in after-hours trading. It is unclear whether he plans to put his controlling stake up for sale or whether he is considering buying up the outstanding public shares, either himself or with a partner.

title: Richardson and the Hispanic Factor
description: In spite of his decidedly Anglo-sounding name, Bill Richardson, speaking in Spanish and English, made a big deal out of his Hispanic roots in announcing his presidential bid in Los Angeles today. And thanks to a decision by his father  an American born overseas  there is no question about Mr. Richardsons ability to run for president.

title: Civics Lessons in Albany
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders met in their third public meeting in a month to see what issues they could resolve before the regular legislative session ends on June 21. Not much tangible progress was made.

title: A Good Day at the Office for Citigroup
description: Monday was a big deal for dealmaking. It may have been an even bigger day for Citigroup. Citis investment bank had a role in all the big headline deals of the day  more than $80 billion worth  which propelled it into first place, ahead of Goldman Sachs, in the worldwide merger advisory league tables compiled by Thomson Financial. Among the recent deals in which Citi had a hand were Alltels $27.5 billion sale to TPG and Goldman Sachs; General Electrics sale of its plastics division to Saudi Basic Industries for $11.6 billion; EMIs 3.5 billion pound sale to Terra Firma; UniCredits $29 billion acquisition of Capitalia; Banca Popolare di Milanos purchase of Banca Popolare dellEmilia Romagna for $7.6 billion.

title: The Golden Rule in the Human Jungle
description: News of the past few days and weeks suggests a rather dismal view of humanity. Israelis and Palestinians are again firing rockets at each other. On the streets of Karachi, just over a week ago, Pakistani security forces stood by while 42 people were killed and many more injured at a rally for Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, deposed Chief Justice of the Supreme Court and opponent of President Pervez Musharraf. In the United States, a company compiling data on consumers is making money by helping criminals steal the savings of thousands of retired Americans.

title: When Government Was the Solution
description: For more than a generation, Americans have been told that government is the problem, not the solution. The mantra can be traced back to Barry Goldwaters presidential bid in 1964. It provided the mind-set for the Reagan administration, and it has come to ultimate fruition during the presidency of George W. Bush.On college campuses and at think tanks across the country, libertarian scholars stoke the urge to eliminate government from our lives. This thinking has led to the privatization of vital government functions such as the care of disabled veterans, the appointment to regulatory commissions of members at odds with the regulations they are sworn to enforce, the refusal of the Environmental Protection Agency to protect the environment, and the surrender of the governments management of military operations to profit-seeking contractors.

title: A Democratic Drive to War?
description: In an appearance on the Late Show with David Letterman that will air later tonight, Rudolph W. Giuliani said he believes America might have gone to war in Iraq even if George W. Bush had not been President.

title: Signals From Our Statues
description: When lighting strikes a holier-than-most location like the Mother Cabrini Shrine in Golden, Colo., only small quantities of faith and/or imagination are needed to see the possibilities for divine actions. After all, she was the first American citizen canonized as a Roman Catholic saint.

title: McCains Choice Words for Romney
description: It does not look much like theres a McCain-Romney ticket is in the offing. Consider Senator John McCains latest riposte to Mitt Romney, who has been attacking him lately for his support of the Senates new accord on immigration.

title: Graphic: The Third Way
description: Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, mentioned the possibility of running on an independent presidential ticket with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York last week. Although independent candidates did not win a presidency in the last century, they have changed the dynamic of many races. Party control changed in many elections when there was support for third-party candidates.

title: Ron Pauls Web of Support
description: Representative Ron Paul, the Texas Republican who is running for president, may be barely registering in public opinion polls, but his supporters are making their presence known on the Internet. They were particularly energized after the second Republican debate, held last week in South Carolina.

title: Geek Schedule
description: This past weekend marked the broadcast debut of my Science Channel show, Its All Geek to Me. Thanks to everyone who tuned in! (*Especially* those of you with Nielsen meters.)

title: Telling Bloopers: Oops! I Didnt Mean for You to Find Out This Way
description: In my Findings column, I inveigh against spam from friends. Now its your turn to rail against what Dan Ryan calls violations of notification norms.

title: Fund-Raising Adds to a Democratic Advantage
description: Senate Democrats have raised twice as much money this year as have their Republican counterparts, adding more difficulty to the electoral equation for Republicans next year.

title: Floridas Primary Penalty
description: Signing into law a contentious plan to move up his states presidential primary, Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida said yesterday that he might lobby the national Republican and Democratic Parties to bend their byzantine rules so the state will not be penalized.

title: Were Goin Streaking!
description: Well, not really. But two wins in a row is something. The Yankees have not done that since May 8 and 9. They beat the Red Sox tonight, 6-2, and a win on Tuesday will give them three in a row, matching their longest winning streak of the year.

title: Onetime Giuliani Insider Is Now a Critic
description: As Rudolph W. Giuliani runs for president, his image as a chief executive who steered New York through the disaster of Sept. 11 has become a pillar of his campaign. But one former member of his inner circle keeps surfacing to revisit that history in ways that are unflattering to Mr. Giuliani: Jerome M. Hauer, New York Citys first emergency management director.

title: Legal Victory for Families of Disabled Students
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  A Supreme Court decision on Monday gave parents of children with disabilities the right to go to court without a lawyer to challenge their public school districts individualized plan for their childs education.

title: Transition Leader Is Named for Ailing Roosevelt Schools
description: State education officials have asked a veteran school administrator who is a former president of the New York State Council of School Superintendents to oversee a transition period for the troubled Roosevelt Union Free School District on Long Island.

title: Bloomberg Proposes Energy Efficient Taxi Fleet
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced today a plan to replace the citys entire yellow cab fleet with environmentally friendly hybrid vehicles over the next five years.

title: Idaho Gunman Also Killed Wife, Police Say
description: MOSCOW, Idaho, May 21  The gunman who killed a police officer, a church sexton and then himself in this quiet northern Idaho town over the weekend also apparently shot and killed his wife in the moments before his sniperlike shootings, the authorities said on Monday.

title: For at Least a Night, Wang and the Yanks Have Control
description: Hitters usually know just what to expect from the Yankees Chien-Ming Wang: heavy sinkers begging to be topped into the dirt. David Ortiz, the Boston Red Sox slugger, has faced Wang many times, but he did not quite recognize him last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: California: Wayward Whales Balk
description: Two wayward injured humpback whales were nearly halfway toward the Pacific Ocean after a detour that started on May 13 and took them 90 miles up the Sacramento River. Escorted by the Coast Guard and a 21-vessel flotilla, the whales traveled 30 miles in 20 hours since leaving the Port of Sacramento on Sunday, the authorities said. The two stopped again yesterday and circled a river channel near Rio Vista, apparently hesitant to swim under an open drawbridge, the authorities said. The whales, injured by a boat propeller, have passed the bridge several times, but always retreated upstream. Jim Milbury of the Fisheries Service of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said the whales faced threats like pylons, a series of delta islands and sloughs that could ground them.

title: Film Offers New Talking Points in Health Care Debate
description: Few of them may become Michael Moore fans. But some insurance industry officials and health policy experts acknowledged yesterday that the film documentary Sicko, Mr. Moores indictment of health care in this country, taps into widespread public concern that the system does not work for millions of Americans.

title: Network Shuffle Leaves N.H.L. Out in the Cold
description: This just shouldnt happen to a major sport during its playoffs.

title: Critics in Senate Vow to Alter Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  As the Senate began work on a comprehensive immigration bill, lawmakers from both parties demanded substantial changes in the legislation on Monday and forced Senate leaders to extend debate beyond the Memorial Day recess.

title: 2 Firms Tied to Phone Lists Will Review Their Policies
description: Two companies accused by state and federal regulators of doing business with suspected telemarketing thieves released statements yesterday pledging to examine and change their business practices.

title: Letters
description: The Rewards of Acceleration

title: Iran Accuses American of Revolution Plot
description: The Islamic Republic of Iran yesterday accused a prominent American academic it imprisoned two weeks ago of conspiring to foment a velvet revolution there.

title: Paying for College
description: One of the ways the rich are different is that their children are much more likely to attend college. Nearly 80 percent of high-income high school graduates went directly to college in 2004, versus some 60 percent of middle-income graduates and about half of those who are low income. Inadequate financial aid is not the only reason for such disturbing discrepancies. But its a significant one  and one that Congress can do something about this year.

title: New DVDs: Gary Cooper
description: GARY COOPER

title: Mexican Workers Provide a Resort Islands Backbone
description: AVALON, Calif., May 16  The flames and smoke are gone, the tourists are coming back and the Rufino, Campos and Hernandez families, part of the Latino immigrant work force keeping things running here, are again receding into the background of this island known more for its bison and bungalows than as a center of immigration.

title: Web Sites Listing Informants Concern Justice Dept.
description: There are three rats of the week on the home page of whosarat.com, a Web site devoted to exposing the identities of witnesses cooperating with the government. The site posts their names and mug shots, along with court documents detailing what they have agreed to do in exchange for lenient sentences.

title: China Investigates Contaminated Toothpaste
description: DANYANG, China, May 21  Chinese authorities are investigating whether two companies from this coastal region exported tainted toothpaste as more contaminated product, including some made for children, has turned up in Latin America.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Friday about the dismissal of a lawsuit challenging the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn misidentified the suit in question. It accused the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency that shepherded the project to approval, of condemning two apartment buildings on the project site without permission from state housing officials to cancel the tenants rent-stabilized leases. A separate lawsuit accusing the agency of offering an unfair relocation plan to those tenants is still pending.

title: Trade Talks With China at a Juncture
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  In recent weeks, the Bush administration has negotiated furiously with China to secure some eye-catching new agreements to unlock Chinese markets for American goods. China, in response, has told the United States that it plans new purchases of $30 billion  a shopping spree that dwarfs any China has gone on previously.

title: Commercial-Free TV, With Sponsorship in Show
description: Commercial-Free TV,

title: On an Icy Moon of Saturn, Gravity Causes Plenty of Moving and Shaking
description: When baking a potato, the smart cook pierces the skin in several places. That allows water vapor to escape as the potato heats, avoiding a potentially explosive situation.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on May 14 about Bernard Gordon, a blacklisted Hollywood screenwriter who eventually had some film credits restored, misstated the relationship of the stars of Hellcats of the Navy, a film for which he was later credited. Ronald Reagan had already married Nancy Davis when the film was made in 1957; she was not his future wife.

title: Top Directors See the Future, and They Say Its in 3-D
description: LOS ANGELES, May 21  If some prominent Hollywood directors and an Irish rock band have their way, moviegoers en masse will soon be heading back to the future, wearing newfangled 3-D glasses.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Friday about Denis G. Kuhn, an architect and preservationist, gave an erroneous credit for the master plan for a proposed suburban community in Gaithersburg, Md. The project was overseen by Matthew J. Bell of Ehrenkrantz Eckstut & Kuhn Architects, not by Mr. Kuhn. The obituary also misstated the reopening date of the Alexander Hamilton Custom House on Bowling Green in Lower Manhattan, vacated in the 1970s, which Mr. Kuhn turned into the Smithsonians National Museum of the American Indian. The building reopened in 1987, when the Federal Bankruptcy Court moved into two floors  not in 1994, when the museum opened on three additional floors.

title: New Yorks Annual Estimate of Homeless Is Challenged
description: A Columbia University professor hired by the city to help conduct an annual estimate of homeless people has disavowed the project, saying its methods cause the number to be understated.

title: New Train Station for Stadium
description: A Metropolitan Transportation Authority committee yesterday approved a $91 million plan to build a Metro-North Railroad station that would serve the new Yankee Stadium, which is under construction in the Bronx. The station is expected to open in June 2009, about two months after the Yankees are scheduled to begin playing in their new home. The station will operate as a regular stop on Metro-Norths Hudson line and will have added service for baseball games, M.T.A. officials said. The transportation authority and the city are to share the cost of building the station, which is meant to handle up to 12,000 passengers after a game. The full board of the M.T.A. is expected to approve the plan tomorrow.

title: A Century and a Half Later, a Novel Inspires an Opera
description: Vivid adventure novels like The Three Musketeers and The Count of Monte Cristo made the French author Alexandre Dumas pre one of the best-selling writers of the 19th century. He turned some of his books into plays, and adaptations of works like those must have been a tantalizing prospect for ambitious opera composers. Yet despite attempts to work with Bellini and Meyerbeer, Dumas neither produced nor inspired a libretto of lasting importance. (His son, Alexandre Dumas fils, far less a man of the theater, wrote La Dame aux Camlias, the novel on which Verdi based La Traviata.)

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Cannes Journal article in The Arts yesterday, about new movies at the Cannes Film Festival, referred incorrectly to text at the start of Terrors Advocate, a documentary about Jacques Vergs, a French lawyer. It says that the films view of the protagonist may not correspond with his own, not that it may correspond.

title: Governor and Lawmakers in 3rd Round of Public Talks
description: ALBANY, May 21  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders met on Monday for their third round of public negotiations in as many weeks to see which issues they could resolve before the legislative session ends a month from now.

title: At the End, a Duty to Bear Witness
description: It was nighttime when I first met Madeline and Shana. I knew I had an agenda that night, and I needed to establish trust, to bear witness and not to be thrown out of the room.

title: Baghdad District Is a Model, but Only for Shiites
description: BAGHDAD, May 18  Ice cream shops in the Shiite stronghold of Kadhimiya are flush with sweet-toothed customers. Hospitals have new supplies. Rents have tripled as displaced Shiites flock to the historic districts spacious homes, while pilgrims stream to the golden-domed shrine at its heart.

title: Rated PG, With No Dirty Dancing
description: WANTAGH, N.Y., May 20  Talk about a bait and switch. Surely some of the young people who came to see Gwen Stefani and Akon at Jones Beach on Sunday night had seen the infamous video online. The one that depicted Akon in Trinidad, bumping and grinding and dragging a female fan  a minor, it turned out  all over the stage. The one that inspired a loud chorus of Harrumph! from the harrumphers. The one that spooked Verizon so much that it withdrew its sponsorship of this tour.

title: Phone Company Deal Irks Would-Be Bidders
description: The Alltel Corporations agreement to go private in a $27.5 billion deal, the largest leveraged buyout ever in the telecommunications industry, is not sitting well with some other private equity firms that were lined up to bid for the company.

title: An Old Steel Mill Retools to Produce Clean Energy
description: LACKAWANNA, N.Y., May 21  Empty grain elevators and dormant railroad tracks line the Buffalo River to the east and Lake Erie to the west, interspersed with empty fields overgrown with gnarled shrubbery. Test wells that monitor decades of buried industrial waste dot the landscape. A passenger ship, rust overtaking its aqua paint, sits beside a decaying mill.

title: Where Have You Gone, Gary Sheffield?
description: Where is Gary Sheffield when the Yankees need him? He plays for the Detroit Tigers these days, courtesy of the Yankees. General Manager Brian Cashman traded Sheffield to the Tigers last November rather than give him a contract extension and trade another high-priced right fielder instead.

title: Commissioner Leaves for Port Job
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine yesterday appointed Susan Bass Levin, left, to the post of deputy director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Ms. Levin, 54, has served as the states commissioner of community affairs since 2002 under three Democratic governors, except for a brief period in late 2005, when she worked for Mr. Corzines campaign for governor. She succeeds James P. Fox, a former chief of staff to Gov. James E. McGreevey. Mr. Fox is forming a transportation and economic development consulting firm with George D. Warrington, the former head of New Jersey Transit, and Eric Shuffler, a former top aide to Mr. McGreevey.

title: Success at Career Colleges (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Study of History Isnt Helped by Testing (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Media Equation column in Business Day yesterday, about a disclosure by The New York Post that its staff had accepted money from a restaurant in return for favorable coverage, included incorrect information in some copies about the amount of money and the recipients. The amount was $1,000  not $3,000  and it went to the editor of Page Six, Richard Johnson. No money was given to two other Page Six staff members, Jeanne MacIntosh and Sean Gannon, now the business editor. (The money was spent on an afternoon of drinking by the staff.)

title: Ensure Low-Cost Housing, Meadowlands Panel Is Told
description: NEWARK, May 21  A New Jersey appellate court ruled on Monday that the state Meadowlands Commission is responsible for ensuring that low-income housing is included in the development of 21,000 acres it oversees just west of Manhattan.

title: Ad Limits Seen as Way to Curb Youth Smoking and Drinking
description: Price-cutting and other marketing strategies widely used by the tobacco and alcoholic beverage industries are highly effective in encouraging children and teenagers to smoke and drink, according to two new studies.

title: MySpace to Share Data With States on Offenders
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 21  MySpace and the 50 state attorneys general appear to have made peace.

title: Memo Pad
description: MAJOR AIRPORT INVESTMENT URGED Airports need to spend more than $87 billion for infrastructure and other improvements by 2011 to accommodate increasing passenger and air-cargo demand, according to a study by the Airports Council International North America. Anyone traveling by air today knows that aviation is already stretched to the breaking point, said Greg Principato, president of the council. In a statement, the group said that 2007 is stacking up to be similar to and in some instances worse than 2000, a year which until now had the dubious distinction of being the peak year for air-travel delays. Most airport improvement projects  for runways, terminals, gates and the like  are paid for by the so-called passenger facility charge added to the price of airline tickets. That charge has been capped by Congress at $4.50 since 2000, but the council said Congress should increase the cap.

title: With an Immigration Compromise Committed to Paper, the Time for Scrutiny Begins
description: The debate over a sweeping bipartisan immigration bill got off to a fiery but confused start yesterday, since few lawmakers, and even fewer people around the country, had seen the full text of the proposal.

title: Cocaine Wars Make Port Colombias Deadliest City
description: BUENAVENTURA, Colombia, May 15  Visitors to this city can be forgiven for thinking no place is safe here. Gunfire often echoes through the slums surrounding its port, the countrys most important on the Pacific coast. As larger cities have calmed, Buenaventura has emerged as the deadliest urban center in Colombias long internal war.

title: Outcomes: Alcohol Is Tied to Lower Risk of One Type of Kidney Cancer
description: Scientists have discovered yet another reason that alcohol might be good for you. Using pooled data from 12 studies and more than 750,000 subjects, researchers found that moderate alcohol consumption  about a drink a day  is associated with a decreased risk of renal cell carcinoma, one type of kidney cancer.

title: Torre Says Abreu Is Close to Climbing Out of Slump
description: Maybe it was the giddiness of simply winning a game, but Yankees Manager Joe Torre was emphatic when speaking about Bobby Abreu after Sundays victory. Abreu is back, he said.

title: Attacks in Sunni Areas in Baghdad Kill at Least 29
description: BAGHDAD, May 22  A truck laden with explosives detonated near a market in southwest Baghdad today, killing 25 and wounding more than 100 in the latest in a series of devastating attacks that have set back the American-led effort to stabilize the capital.

title: As the Grapevine Withers, Spam Filters Take Root
description: Thanks to the sociologist Dan Ryan, Im coming to terms with my need for spam filters against my friends e-mail.

title: The Show Will Go On, but the Art Will Be Shielded
description: You enter through a place that looks like the very last picture show, an old movie theater with soda-stained carpet and a busted popcorn machine. Sleeping bags and clothes are scattered around, as if the theater has served as a shelter from some unnamed danger outside its doors.

title: Eighth Graders in N.Y. Show Gains in Reading
description: The number of New York state eighth graders reading on grade level climbed impressively this year for the first time since 1999 when the state adopted tougher educational standards and its modern testing system, according to scores released today from this years statewide English exam.

title: Landis Waits Another Day to Testify
description: MALIBU, Calif., May 21  Floyd Landis, who has waited 10 months to argue his case against the United States Anti-Doping Agency, had to sit and stew for one more day.

title: Supreme Court to Address State Tax Breaks for Bonds
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  In a case with the potential to rattle, if not reshape, the market for state and municipal bonds, the Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether states can continue to exempt interest on their own bonds from their residents taxable income, while taxing the interest on bonds issued by other states.

title: Executive on a Mission: Saving the Planet
description: VININGS, Ga.  What Ray Anderson calls his conversion experience occurred in the summer of 1994, when he was asked to give the sales force at Interface, the carpet tile company he founded, some talking points about the companys approach to the environment.

title: Figuring the Next Field for the Mayor
description: This just in:

title: Raising the Room Temperature With Three Brahms Sonatas
description: The violinist Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg has said she feels possessed when she plays. A recital on Sunday with the pianist Anne-Marie McDermott demonstrated that neither the electric spark nor the eccentricity of her playing has mellowed since she won the Naumburg International Violin Competition in 1981.

title: Fighting in Lebanon Dashes Cease-Fire Hopes
description: NAHR EL-BARED REFUGEE CAMP, Lebanon, May 22  Fierce fighting continued for the third straight day in northern Lebanon today, as the Lebanese Army continued battling militants holed up in a refugee camp on the outskirts of Tripoli, ending a brief cease-fire with a barrage of shelling and gunfire that hampered rescue and aid efforts and raised political tensions in other parts of the country.

title: Study Cites Safety Questions About Diabetes Drug
description: An article released today by The New England Journal of Medicine raised safety questions about the widely-used diabetes pill Avandia. An analysis of clinical trials concluded that the drug might significantly increase the risk of heart attacks.

title: Audit Finds Subway Track Work Safety Violations
description: City transit officials found dozens of safety lapses during spot checks of track work on the subway system just weeks after the deaths of two track workers, officials said yesterday.

title: When Former Presidents Assail the Chief
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  Nothing rattles Washington quite like a good violation of unwritten rules, especially when the violator and the violated are both presidents (past and present, respectively).

title: No Helmet, No Pads, No Escape
description: LAKE FOREST, Calif., May 16  When Johnnie Morton finished playing wide receiver in the National Football League, he carefully reviewed his retirement options: be host of a talk show, expand his real estate profile, maybe work on his golf game.

title: Side Deals in a Gray Area
description: Global deal making is on a tear, accompanied by a surge of insider trading cases.

title: The Immigration Debate, in Full Cry (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Expected to Miss a Shot at Oden or Durant
description: When the N.B.A. has its draft lottery tonight, the team with the ninth-best chance of winning will be the Knicks. But their logo will be absent from the proceedings and their seat on the stage will be filled by a man they have probably never met.

title: EMI Accepts $4.7 Billion Buyout Offer
description: The EMI Group, the worlds third-largest record company, said today that it would recommend to shareholders that they accept a $4.7 billion buyout offer from a private equity firm, Terra Firma Capital Partners.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A map on Friday of the site of two freeway collapses in Oakland, Calif., incorrectly located the site of the 1989 collapse of Interstate 880. The highway was about 3,500 feet east of Maritime Street, not at its present location, about 2,000 feet east of Maritime.

title: China: Formula One Chief Fired in Graft Inquiry
description: The head of Shanghais new Formula One racing track lost his job as part of an investigation into corruption in the city government. Yu Zhifei, the official, was fired and expelled from the Communist Party, state news media said. He oversaw the introduction of the racing circuit in 2005. The track and related infrastructure cost the city more than $1 billion to develop.

title: A Race for Jobs in Police Depts. on Long Island
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  At John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan, as soon as fliers advertising the police academy entrance exams on Long Island are posted, they are routinely ripped down, presumably by applicants for the tests who do not want the word to spread.

title: Darkness With the Light, Inspired by a Buddhist Chant
description: Change is hard. Classical music likes its status quo: the same great music in the same great halls. So the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Centers move to a new location for its final concert of the season on Sunday afternoon  since Alice Tully Hall has closed for renovations  seemed to throw some audience members a curve. Just finding the Frederick P. Rose Hall in the Time Warner Center was evidently a challenge to many, including two couples who stood on the sidewalk, peering anxiously through the glass doors of the mall as if not daring to go in and look around.

title: Harnessing Methane, Cutting Waste, Recycling Tiles
description: LaGRANGE, Ga.  The urge to conserve is obvious at the Interface Corporation, from slogans painted on the factory floor (One Planet/Zero Harm), to prize parking spots reserved for car-poolers, to packing boxes so relentlessly recycled that they sit, wrinkled and battered, festooned with the remains of previously applied masking tape (bought from Germany, because the extra adhesive in American masking tape causes more wear and tear).

title: Macho Mistakes at Ground Zero
description: As more and more workers who inhaled the dust at ground zero fall ill, it has become increasingly clear that much of the problem can be traced to the Giuliani administrations failure to insist that all emergency personnel and construction workers at the site wear respirators.

title: Americas Admissions System
description: Harvard is tough to get into. To be admitted to a school like that, students spend years earning good grades, doing community service and working hard to demonstrate their skills. The system has its excesses, but over all its good for Harvard and its good for the students beginning their climb to opportunity.

title: Harsh Birth Control Steps Fuel Violence in China
description: BEIJING, May 21  An intensive campaign to enforce strict population-control measures, including forced abortions, prompted violent clashes between the police and local residents in southwestern China in recent days, witnesses said Monday, describing the latest incident of rural unrest that has alarmed senior officials in Beijing.

title: To Lead the Jazz Ahead, Boozer Reaches Back to the Past
description: The last time Carlos Boozer of the Utah Jazz struggled in the opening game of a playoff series, he called a friend for solace and advice.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Stallone Fined for Hormone Imports

title: An Energetic Pianistic Program With Wine as Accompaniment
description: Nostalgia for the vanished tradition of salon concerts appears to be on the rise. Two years ago a series of piano recitals at the Rainbow Room put listeners at dinner tables with glasses of wine, and the Baryshnikov Arts Center and Lincoln Center (in its post-Mostly Mozart concerts) has been doing the same. Last year Arium, a hybrid restaurant, gallery and concert space on Little West 12th Street in the West Village, began presenting recitals for which the ticket price included a glass of wine, hors doeuvres before the performance and dessert afterward.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A headline in Business Day on Friday with an article about the sale of 24/7 Real Media, the advertising network and technology company, to the WPP Group misstated the price of the deal. As the article noted, it was $649 million, not $64 million.

title: Richardson Officially Enters 08 Democratic Presidential Race
description: Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico formally kicked off his bid for the 2008 Democratic presidential nomination yesterday, highlighting his Hispanic roots and wealth of experience and issuing a forceful call to end American involvement in Iraq.

title: General Electric to Sell Plastics Division
description: General Electric agreed today to sell its plastics division for $11.6 billion to the largest public company in Saudi Arabia, the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation.

title: Eugen Weber, Authority on Modern France, Dies at 82
description: Eugen Weber, the Romanian-born, English-educated American historian who was one of the worlds foremost interpreters of modern France and an authority on modern Europe, died Thursday at his home in Los Angeles, where he had taught at U.C.L.A. and was a former dean of its College of Letters and Science. He was 82.

title: Marine Is Used to Fighting for His Life
description: When asked to assess his state of mind before stepping into a steel cage for a fight, Brian Stann provides a matter-of-fact reply that also stands as a stark warning.

title: Cleveland to Cairo, in Coach? Ways to Outwit the Body Clock
description: Anyone who has flown across several time zones for business or pleasure has no doubt experienced jet lag  that days-long feeling that all body functions are out of sync with the new environment. And as soon as you become adjusted, you return home and have to go through it again. Its enough to prompt some people to stay home.

title: A Mezzo-Soprano Steps In, With a Wild and Woolly Berlioz
description: I am running out of good things to say about the Met Orchestra and its music director, James Levine. If there is someone out there with a new repertory of complimentary adjectives suitable to this exquisite marriage of taste and heart, I would be glad to give way.

title: Student Sentenced in Hate-Crime Attack
description: A college student from Little Neck was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to five years of probation for his role in an attack on two Asian-American teenagers last year, prosecutors said. Paul A. Heavey, 21, pleaded guilty in March to third-degree assault as a hate crime, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Heavey admitted punching and kicking the two men  John Lu and Reynold Liang, both 19 at the time and both from Little Neck  during an August 2006 altercation in Douglaston, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Heaveys co-defendant, Kevin M. Brown, 19, of Auburndale, was sentenced in March to three and a half years in prison after he admitted beating one of the men with a metal steering wheel lock, prosecutors said.

title: Taking a Dim View
description: Q. Does wearing someone elses prescription glasses for a short time do any damage to a childs eyes?

title: Carnegie Hall Plans Major Expansion, Without Its Tenants
description: The curtain may finally be falling for dozens of tenants of Carnegie Hall, whose studios helped form a Bohemia on 57th Street because of the many musicians, dancers, painters and other artists who lived in them.

title: Comments Make Giambi a Target of Investigators
description: When Major League Baseball investigates Jason Giambis tacit admission that he used steroids, there is no guarantee that Commissioner Bud Selig will meet with him. Selig is planning first to have one of his chief labor executives conduct an interview with Giambi soon.

title: Defendant Pleads Not Guilty in Abduction of Boy
description: POTOSI, Mo., May 21  A man accused of kidnapping, armed criminal assault, forcible sodomy and attempted murder in the abduction of a boy from Richwoods in 2002 quietly asserted his innocence on Monday before a circuit judge here, 56 miles southwest of St. Louis.

title: Putin Prompts Split in German Coalition
description: FRANKFURT, May 21  Germanys relations with Russia were never likely to be as cozy under Angela Merkel as under her predecessor, Gerhard Schrder, who adopted a 3-year-old Russian girl and, on his 60th birthday, invited President Vladimir V. Putin home to celebrate.

title: Worker Program Stays in Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  The Senate this afternoon endorsed the concept of allowing up to 600,000 temporary workers a year to enter the United States under a broad immigration-reform bill, rejecting an amendment that would have scrapped the worker program.

title: Heart Attack Risk Seen in Drug for Diabetes
description: An article in a leading medical journal yesterday raised serious safety questions about the widely used diabetes pill Avandia and renewed skepticism about the vigilance of federal drug regulators.

title: At the Dentists: Vicious Cycle of Gum Disease, Bone Loss and Cancer
description: The bone loss caused by gum disease is associated with an increased risk for tongue cancer, and the more the bone loss, the greater the risk, researchers report.

title: Group Offers a Simple Fix for Alternative Minimum Tax
description: A levy originally intended to ensure that the richest investors cannot live tax-free is taking back a much larger portion of the Bush tax cuts going to those who make less than $100,000 than to those who earn more than $1 million, according to a new analysis by the Joint Committee on Taxation.

title: Kerkorian in New Move in Las Vegas
description: Last month Kirk Kerkorian, the 89-year-old billionaire who buys and sells large positions in corporations like few others on Wall Street, offered $4.5 billion to buy Chrysler from DaimlerChrysler, only to lose out to another bidder.

title: The Rich and Faithful in Africa. Discuss.
description: NEW HAVEN, May 19  It says much about The Unmentionables, a new play by Bruce Norris at the Yale Repertory Theater, that the most likable character in it, an easygoing African doctor, admits he occasionally feels a temptation to plant a tomahawk in the middle of somebodys forehead. Given the company hes surrounded by in this acidic satire of bourgeois venality and hypocrisy, you are tempted to sympathize with this confession.

title: Irans Centrifuges
description: For a U.N.-baiting, diplomacy-bashing crowd, the Bush administration has shown unexpected patience in trying to persuade the Security Council to punish Iran for its nuclear misbehavior. And for a foot-dragging, conflict-averse crowd, the Security Council has moved with alacrity in imposing two sets of sanctions on Iran just since December.

title: Bank Robbery in Chicago Leaves 3 Injured
description: A gunfight broke out during a robbery in a Chicago bank this morning, injuring a security guard, a bank employee and a customer, officials said. The bank employee later died of his injuries.

title: Dame Mary Douglas, 86, a Wide-Ranging Anthropologist, Is Dead
description: Dame Mary Douglas, an anthropologist whose influence ranged beyond the traditional questions of her field to examine areas as diverse as kosher diets, consumer behavior, environmentalism and humor as she described how humans work together to find shared meaning, died Wednesday in London.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 9 P.M. (Fox) ON THE LOT Sixteen aspiring filmmakers compete for their big break  in the form of a $1 million development deal with DreamWorks  in this new reality series with Mark Burnett and Steven Spielberg as executive producers. Carrie Fisher and Brett Ratner, above, as well as Garry Marshall and Jon Avnet are judges for the audition rounds tonight and Thursday. The competitors try their hands at a pitch meeting, then shoot and edit a short film in 24 hours. The series moves into its regular times, Mondays and Tuesdays at 8 p.m., next week.

title: China: Road Accident Kills 20 Farmers
description: Twenty female farmers were killed when the three-wheeled vehicle they were riding overturned on a mountainous road in Liaoning Province. State news media said they were returning from a day of picking herbs and were crowded onto a trailer towed behind the vehicle. Chinas roads are the most dangerous in the world, with 90,000 people losing their lives in accidents in the first quarter of 2007 alone, according to official estimates.

title: Marketers Struggle to Get Folks to Stay Put for the Commercials
description: TO many people, the commercial break is when you use the restroom, change the channel or grab a snack.

title: Lottery Numbers
Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,407 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Columbia Fires Its Director of Student Aid
description: Columbia University dismissed its financial aid director yesterday after the release of documents showing he promoted a student loan company in which he had a stake, sending letters to parents and alumni on three occasions praising the lender.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Week in Review section on Sunday about the conservative movement misstated the outcome of impeachment proceedings in 1998 against President Clinton, whose character conservatives made the focus of the 2000 election. The House of Representatives did indeed impeach him. (The Senate did not convict him of the impeachment charges.) (Go to Article)

title: Supporters Urge Pakistan Leader to Shift Course
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 21  After a series of political blunders in the last two months, Pakistans president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, is being advised by his political supporters to make a dramatic change of course or risk losing power amid more chaos and bloodshed.

title: A Move for Birth Certificates for Stillborn Babies
description: Last summer, three weeks before her due date, Sari Edber delivered a stillborn son, Jacob. He was 5 pounds and 19 inches, absolutely beautiful, with my olive complexion, my husbands curly hair, long fingers and toes, chubby cheeks and a perfect button nose, she said.

title: Rival Books on Hillary Clinton Play Leapfrog on Debut Dates
description: In the latest round of publishing one-upmanship, the two publishers of rival biographies of Hillary Rodham Clinton have moved up their on-sale dates once again.

title: Lebanese Army and Islamists Battle for 2nd Day
description: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, May 21  Lebanese tanks and artillery pounded a Palestinian refugee camp in this northern Lebanese city for the second straight day on Monday, battling members of a radical Islamist group and raising concerns for thousands trapped inside.

title: Is Your Career a Kayak or an Ocean Liner?
description: I normally pay a lot of attention to people striking out on their own. But lately Ive been noticing those who swim against the tide of self-employment. You know, the ones who ditch all that flexibility and autonomy for the life of a steady paycheck, defined hours, in-person colleagues and a bundle of benefits. Put it that way and it doesnt sound so bad after all, does it?

title: Democrats Avoid Vote on Reprimanding Murtha
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  House Democrats flexed their new majority today and avoided having to vote on whether one of their own, Representative John Murtha, a crusty ex-marine from coal-and-steel country, had besmirched the dignity of the chamber through bare-knuckled politics.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A headline on Saturday with the obituary of the physicist Donald M. Ginsberg misidentified his area of expertise. It was superconductors, not semiconductors.

title: General Electric to Sell Plastics Division
description: General Electric agreed yesterday to sell its plastics division for $11.6 billion to the largest public company in Saudi Arabia, the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation.

title: Wealth as a Clue in Running
description: The initial financial disclosure required of the presidential candidates is already shedding light on important questions of wherewithal looming beyond the glare of televised debate. As voters sort through the crowd, which includes 10 millionaires, they should find their finances useful in sizing up the contenders and whom and what they actually work for.

title: Justice Dept. Sues New York City, Citing Bias in Hiring Firefighters
description: The United States Department of Justice filed a civil rights suit against New York City yesterday over the Fire Departments written entrance exam, which black and Hispanic candidates fail at much higher rates than whites. The suit claims that the city has never proved a link between test scores and performance as a firefighter.

title: $4.7 Billion Private Equity Buyout Wins Support at EMI
description: The music company EMI Group, which has been the subject of takeover speculation since the 1990s, said yesterday that its board supported a new $4.7 billion offer from a private investor, Terra Firma Capital Partners.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the National Briefing column on Saturday about an appeal by Hamid Hayat, a Lodi, Calif., man convicted in a terror case, referred incorrectly in some copies to his lawyer. The lawyer, Wazhma Mojaddidi, is a woman.

title: For Less Crowding on L Train, Think 2010, Report Says
description: Riders on the crowded L subway line, who at peak hours frequently have to wait for two or more trains to pass at some stations before squeezing aboard, will have to keep on squeezing for at least a few more years, according to a report released yesterday.

title: In New Role, Myers Is Good News for Phillies
description: Since an ugly off-the-field incident last season, Philadelphia Phillies pitcher Brett Myers has experienced a lot of change  some in private, some in the open.

title: China Says It Made Blackstone Investment to Raise Returns
description: HONG KONG, May 21  From the outside, the Chinese governments $3 billion purchase of a nonvoting stake in the Blackstone Group might look like a prelude to a broader campaign for control of foreign companies.

title: Six Dead in Baltimore Fire
description: Six people died and five others were injured early today as a fire swept through a two-story rowhouse in the northeast section of Baltimore.

title: Alienated Europeans, Through a Cold Lens
description: CANNES, France, May 21  One of the most fertile subjects of contemporary European cinema is the desolation of contemporary European life. The extravagance and high spirits outside the Cannes screening rooms thus frequently stand in jarring contrast to the misery displayed within them, where stories of privation, disconnection and violence hold up a corrective mirror to a continent that likes to present itself to the rest of the world as prosperous, unified and at peace.

title: Kidd Will Understand if Carter Leaves the Nets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 21  Three summers ago, Kenyon Martin was a free agent chasing a big payday. The Nets balked, and Jason Kidd fumed.

title: Democrats Drop Troop Pullout Dates From Iraq Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Congressional Democrats relented today on their insistence that a war spending measure sought by President Bush also set a date for withdrawing troops from Iraq. The decision to back down, described by senior lawmakers and aides, was a wrenching reversal for some Democrats, who saw their election triumph as a call to force an end to the war. A Democratic effort to include timelines prompted Mr. Bushs veto of the original bill last month, producing a political impasse.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Week in Review section on Sunday about the conservative movement misstated the outcome of impeachment proceedings in 1998 against President Clinton, whose character conservatives made the focus of the 2000 election. The House of Representatives did indeed impeach him. (The Senate did not convict him of the impeachment charges.)

title: Al Gore Speaks of a Nation in Danger
description: In The Assault on Reason Al Gore excoriates George W. Bush, asserting that the president is out of touch with reality, that his administration is so incompetent that it cant manage its own way out of a horse show, that it ignored clear warnings about the terrorist threat before 9/11 and that it has made Americans less safe by stirring up a hornets nest in Iraq, while using the language and politics of fear to try to drive the public agenda without regard to the evidence, the facts or the public interest.

title: Mets Look to Future and See the Braves
description: Tom Glavine is many things. A future Hall of Famer, golf nut and the Mets conscience, yes. A soothsayer, probably not. But when Glavine, still an authority on all things Atlanta after five years in a Mets uniform, peers a few months ahead to October, toward the playoffs, he sees two things: the Mets and the Braves.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some copies on May 13 about a request to dismiss a murder case stemming from the killing of a bouncer outside the Palladium nightclub in Manhattan in 1990 referred imprecisely to David Lemus, who was convicted in the case in 1992. That conviction was set aside in 2005 and Mr. Lemus is now awaiting a second trial on the same charges. He is not merely accused of the crime or otherwise being treated as only a suspect.

title: Test Case in Charges That Gas Stations Imperil Water
description: PLAINVIEW, N.Y., May 21  When Paul Granger, the water district superintendent here, came to work one morning in 2000, he spotted a rig test-drilling for pollution at a gasoline station across the road from two wells that pump up to 1.7 million gallons of drinking water a day.

title: Give Them a Break
description: TALKING heads and lawmakers in Washington have a new reason to be exercised about the situation in Iraq  as if any were needed. Theyre in an uproar that the Iraqi Parliament, the Council of Representatives, is planning to take a two-month recess starting on July 1. This is being represented as evidence that the Iraqis would prefer to go off to the seashore rather than try to save their country.

title: Palestinian Militants and Israel Carry Out Deadly Attacks
description: GAZA, May 21  The Israeli Air Force continued its strikes in Gaza on Monday, killing four members of Islamic Jihad who the Israeli Army said were preparing to launch rockets against Israel, and one member of Hamas at what it said was a bomb-making factory.

title: On Search for Comrades, a Bomb Wreaks Havoc
description: MAHMUDIYA, Iraq, May 22  The ground exploded under an ashen sky at dawn. Dust, dirt, blood and military equipment filled the air, clearing after several seconds to reveal a frenzied scene of horror.

title: Patterns: Treatment of Depression May Lead to Longer Life
description: Treating depression in older adults may be a life-saving intervention, a new study suggests.

title: Israel and Militants Trade Deadly Attacks in Gaza
description: GAZA, May 22  The Israeli Air Force mounted three more attacks on Gaza today, as an Israeli woman killed by rocket fire from Gaza on Monday was buried in Sderot, Israel.

title: The Claim: Microwave Ovens Kill Bacteria in Food
description: THE FACTS

title: Ethiopia Detains Times Journalists for Five Days
description: Three journalists for The New York Times were arrested by the Ethiopian military on May 16 in the Ogaden region of Ethiopia, held for five days and interrogated at gunpoint, and then released on Monday without any charges being lodged against them, The Times said today.

title: Ex-Brokers Face Retrial in Eavesdropping Case
description: Three former brokers for Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers face a second trial on charges that they conspired to commit fraud by allowing day traders to eavesdrop on orders on internal squawk boxes.

title: Britain Charges Russian in Poisoning Case
description: LONDON, May 22  The British authorities said today that they would seek the extradition of a Russian businessman, Andrei Lugovoi, to face trial for the murder of Alexander Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. agent who died last November in London of radiation poisoning caused by a rare isotope, polonium 210.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on May 13 about the decision by a powerful Shiite party, the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq, to drop the word revolution from its name omitted the partys new name, and a correction in this space on May 15 incorrectly rendered the English version of the new name. It is the Supreme Islamic Iraqi Council, not the Iraqi Islamic Supreme Council.

title: Bush Scorns Proposed Vote on Gonzales as Theater
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., May 21  President Bush said on Monday that any effort by Congress to hold a no-confidence vote on Alberto R. Gonzales, his embattled attorney general, amounted to the kind of political theater that has caused the American people to lose confidence in how Washington operates.

title: Culinary Adventures in the Customs Lane
description: For our Fairway Market here in New York, I import cheeses, olives, oils and lots of other wonderful stuff from more than a hundred little companies, most of them in Europe.

title: This Is Your Life (and How You Tell It)
description: For more than a century, researchers have been trying to work out the raw ingredients that account for personality, the sweetness and neuroses that make Anna Anna, the sluggishness and sensitivity that make Andrew Andrew. They have largely ignored the first-person explanation  the life story that people themselves tell about who they are, and why.

title: Boards More Likely to Oust Underperforming Chief Executives, a Study Finds
description: A new study examining turnover among top executives has found that corporate boards were nearly three times as likely to pull the trigger on failing chief executives than they were a decade ago.

title: McCain Counters Romney With a Three-Way Riposte
description: It doesnt look much like there is a McCain-Romney ticket in the offing.

title: American Cities and the Great Divide
description: A public high school teacher in Brooklyn told me recently about a student who didnt believe that a restaurant tab for four people could come to more than $500. The student shook his head, as if resisting the very idea. He just couldnt fathom it.

title: The Politics of Eurovision
description: Oxford, England

title: Meet Your Clothes at the Hotel
description: The luggage shipping business has found a convert in Murray Grenville, who runs an investment valuation company in New York and has not flown with bags on business trips in almost a year, even when he goes to the West Coast.

title: Forget Spartacus, I Am Fresno State
description: For the last couple of years, Madison Avenue has been embracing an idea called user-generated content, encouraging consumers to create advertising, promotional video clips and other marketing messages that were once produced solely by professionals. Among the blue-chip marketers taking part in the trend are Chevrolet, Frito-Lay, Geico, Heinz ketchup, KFC, Mr. Clean, the National Football League and Verizon Communications.
