description: To the Editor:

title: Gunmen Kill 5 in Ambush of Minibus in Diyala Province on Day of Scattered Violence in Iraq
description: ERBIL, Iraq, May 21  Gunmen ambushed a minibus passing through a troubled area of Diyala Province on Monday and killed five passengers, including a child, an Interior Ministry official said.

title: Diverse Fashions, Same Statement: Police
description: During the 24 years that Wilfredo Vega Jr. has been working behind the counter of a police equipment shop on East 21st Street in Manhattan, he has made countless sales to veteran officers of the New York Police Department and to the cadets who attend classes close by at the Police Academy.

title: War Proposal Still Stymied Despite Talks
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  Facing a self-imposed weekend deadline, Congressional Democrats said Monday that they remained uncertain how they would shape a war spending measure that has been the center of a political and policy battle with President Bush.

title: A Flute With a Beat, and You Might Dance to It
description: GREG PATTILLO may be the best person in the world at what he does. He may also be the only person in the world who does what he does.

description: To the Editor:

title: Nutrition: A Healthy Diet May Keep Chronic Lung Disease at Bay
description: A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, fish, poultry and whole grain foods may offer protection against chronic lung disease, a new study suggests, in addition to the other benefits of such a regimen.

title: Paintings From Germany, With a Wink and a Sneer
description: Painting may go in and out of fashion, but its many lifesaving graces always keep it afloat. One is its capacity for what might be called beautiful sarcasm, a sly self-parody while still looking good that is cultivated by many young painters today.

title: Judge Says Oneida Indians Deserve a Chance for Redress
description: A federal judge yesterday rejected claims by the Oneida Indian Nation to land in upstate New York, but agreed with the tribe that it deserved a chance to prove it is owed some compensation for property that the state bought 200 or more years ago at unfairly low prices.

title: 2 Ex-Officers Plead Not Guilty in New Jersey Break-In
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 21  Two former New York City police officers accused of trying to rob a reputed drug dealer in New Jersey were each ordered held in $1 million bail on Monday after pleading not guilty in State Superior Court here.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Friday about the resignation of Paul D. Wolfowitz as president of the World Bank referred incorrectly to the pay package for the job. It was the previous World Bank president  not Mr. Wolfowitz  who was paid a salary of $302,470 and expenses of $141,290 in 2004. (Mr. Wolfowitz, who did not arrive at the bank until 2005, was paid an after-tax salary of $391,440 beginning July 1, 2005. )

title: The Attack of the Exhibits, Starring a Spooky Piano
description: BOSTON, May 20  In January the choreographer Mark Morris gave us a world premiere to Bachs Italian Concerto in his own Brooklyn dance center. On May 2 the full production he staged and choreographed of the three-act Gluck Orfeo ed Euridice opened at the Metropolitan Opera. Now this irrepressible artist has knocked off another world premiere, for the new Institute of Contemporary Art, memorably located on the waterfront here.

title: Conviction in Fatal Stabbing
description: A Jamaica man was convicted of murder yesterday in State Supreme Court for fatally stabbing a man during a fistfight two years ago behind a public school in Briarwood, prosecutors said. Dwayne Morrison, 26, stabbed Miguel Restituyo, 23, on July 30, 2005, after Mr. Restituyo began to get the upper hand in the fight, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said that after someone in the crowd tossed Mr. Morrison a knife, Mr. Restituyo raised his hands in a gesture of surrender, and Mr. Morrison stabbed him.

title: New Directions From the AAA: Go to the Web, Then Print
description: YOU remember all those predictions about how technology was going to usher in the paperless office?

title: Convicted Murderer Is Freed in Wake of Tainted Evidence
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, May 21  Its like landing on a new planet, said Curtis E. McCarty, who was freed from death row this month after two convictions for the same murder, and 22 years in prison, 16 of them on death row.

title: In Bubbles and Metal, the Art of Shape-Shifting
description: The next time you stare into a beer, contemplate the bubbles.

title: 19th-Century Looks That Belie a Three-Century Range
description: Dressed in black and crowned by a flowing raven mane, the violinist Nemanja Radulovic looked the part of a dashing 19th-century Romantic virtuoso when he took the stage of Weill Recital Hall on Friday night. Mr. Radulovic, born in the former Yugoslavia and now based in France, came to Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the Rising Stars series, having been nominated by the Cit de la Musique in Paris. His accompanist was Susan Manoff, a New York-born pianist who teaches at the Paris Conservatory.

title: Channeling Spirits From the Good Old Days, When Love Songs Were Love Songs
description: When the indefatigably romantic cabaret performer Andrea Marcovicci turns the tables on herself and waxes cynical, her infatuation with old Hollywood and classic glamour snaps into focus. Thats when you have to ask yourself: Where would you rather live? Inside her Fred and Ginger, Nol and Cole dream world, or somewhere closer to reality?

title: Under the Sea
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Mysteries to Behold in the Dark Down Deep: Seadevils and Species Unknown
description: When, more than 70 years ago, William Beebe became the first scientist to descend into the abyss, he described a world of twinkling lights, silvery eels, throbbing jellyfish, living strings as lovely as the finest lace and lanky monsters with needlelike teeth.

title: Legal Status Brings Security to Some Same-Sex Marriages
description: Officially speaking, same-sex couples who live in New York State cannot be married. Nancy Goldstein and Joan Hilty, a Brooklyn couple who celebrated their third wedding anniversary on Saturday, are an unusual exception.

title: Cancer Care Seeks to Take Patients Beyond Survival
description: As a growing number of Americans are learning, surviving cancer can mean slipping into a rabbit hole of long-term medical problems  from premature menopause and sexual dysfunction to more debilitating side effects of chemotherapy and radiation, like heart disease and even new cancers.

title: Voice of Experience Knows Its Too Soon for Yanks to Panic
description: Ron Guidry is available for counseling, willing to double as pitching coach and staff shrink, one on one or group sessions, no charge for the multimillionaires in the Yankees clubhouse.

title: Abortion Foes See Validation for New Tactic
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  For many years, the political struggle over abortion was often framed as a starkly binary choice: the interest of the woman, advocated by supporters of abortion rights, versus the interest of the fetus, advocated by opponents of abortion.

title: Aeroflot Seeks Loan to Deal for Alitalia
description: MOSCOW, May 21  The Russian airline Aeroflot is seeking up to 900 million euros ($1.2 billion) in loans to finance its bid for all or part of the Italian national airline, Alitalia, in its first merger or acquisition effort outside the former Soviet Union.

title: Afghanistan: Parliament Ousts Leading Critic
description: The lower house of Parliament suspended an outspoken member from Farah Province, Malalai Joya, over a recent interview she gave to a local television station in which she compared Parliament to a stable of animals. Ms. Joya, who has often branded many of her fellow legislators as warlords and war criminals, said that while a cow can give milk and a donkey can carry a load, the lawmakers do nothing.

title: For Pan-Am Games, the Big Race Is to the Starting Line
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 21  At the edge of Copacabana Beach, a giant electronic display is counting down the days to the start of the Pan-American Games here. Whether the organizers and all of the venues will be ready on July 13, when the clock strikes zero and the 17-day competition starts, is another matter altogether.

title: Google Proposes Innovation in Radio Spectrum Auction
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 21  Google filed a proposal on Monday with the Federal Communications Commission calling on the agency to let companies allocate radio spectrum using the same kind of real-time auction that the search engine company now uses to sell advertisements.

title: Web Sites Expose Informants, and Justice Dept. Raises Flag
description: Web sites like whosarat.com expose the identities of witnesses cooperating with the government and provide their names and mug shots.

title: U.S. Championship, Round 7: Two Share the Lead
description: Alexander Onischuk knocked off Hikaru Nakamura today to join Alexander Shabalov in the lead of the Frank Berry U.S. Championship while Sergey Kudrin beat Ildar Ibragimov to get to 5 points, only a half point back. Another seven grandmasters were at 4.5, so with two rounds to play, the championship has become wide open with many players still with a chance to win. The games can be seen live or replayed here at Monroi.com.

description: Living

description: An Iranian friend sent along this photo. It was taken in Hafteh Tir square when a mother and a daughter were beaten for taking pictures of the vice police treating women badly. Some 2000 people gathered in protest.

title: J.W. Childs Duo Said to Launch New Firm
description: Two senior partners of J.W. Childs Associates are leaving the Boston private equity shop to start their own firm, according to The Deal.com. Dana Schmaltz and Ted Yun each joined J.W. Childs shortly after its founding by John W. Childs in 1995. Mr. Schmaltz, who now serves as president, joined in 1997, while Mr. Yun, a partner and chairman of the investment committee, came on board in 1999. Their departure is expected at the beginning of June, sources told The Deal.

title: A New Twist in Merrills Hedge Fund Deal?
description: With its deal to buy a 20 percent stake in the New York hedge fund GSO Capital Partners, Merrill Lynch appears to be buying a piece of the nascent competition, The Financial Times Alphaville blog concluded Monday.

title: New Date for Lonergan Play
description: "The Starry Messenger," a play written and directed by Kenneth Lonergan and starring Matthew Broderick, was scheduled to open on Broadway last month. But Hollywood intervened, specifically Mr. Lonergan's movie "Margaret," which took longer than expected, pre-empting a pre-Broadway tryout at the Old Globe Theater in San Diego.

title: China Says Blackstone Deal Is All About Returns
description: The Chinese governments $3 billion purchase of a nonvoting stake in the Blackstone Group appears to be a move to pounce on a strategy many foreign banks have adopted in China: buy into a company just before it begins its initial public offering. That strategy has given many banks, like Bank of America and Goldman Sachs, significant initial gains, at least on paper, on their early investments, The New York Times writes.

title: An Addams Family Musical
description: A musical of "The Addams Family" is in the works, with a planned premiere on Broadway in the 2009-10 season.

title: More on Health
description: Lots of interesting and thoughtful comments below from readers about health care. A few took a swipe at Leana Wen, the winner of my win-a-trip contest. I had used Leana as an example in my column of someone without health coverage. She posted her comments as No. 133. Here are excerpts:

title: Lawmakers Cut Funding to Armys V.C. Arm
description: The House of Representatives has cut funding for the Armys venture capital affiliate from the 2008 defense appropriations bill amid questions about fees and return on investment, The Red Herring reported. Specifically, a $10 million allocation to OnPoint Technologies from the Army was removed from the bill after Tennessee Representative Jim Cooper raised objections over management fees.

title: Ex-Brokers in Squawk Box Case Face Retrial
description: Three former brokers for Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers face a second trial on charges that they conspired to commit fraud by allowing day traders to eavesdrop on orders on internal squawk boxes. Four current and former executives at the day trading firm A.B. Watley Group will also be retried on charges that they had a role in the scheme, the United States attorneys office in Brooklyn said Monday.

title: Senior Executives Quit Proxy Firm
description: Two senior executives have quit the proxy advisory firm Glass Lewis & Company amid questions over whether its China-based parent, Xinhua Finance Media, withheld unfavorable information about its former chief financial officer. Barrons reported on Sunday that the prospectus of Xinhua Finance Media, controlled by Xinhua Finance, based in Tokyo, withheld details about business dealings of the finance chief, Shelly Singhal.

title: Citadels European Energy Head Resigns
description: Kenneth Griffins $13.5 billion hedge fund, the Citadel Investment Group, said Monday that Karl Robijns, the companys head of European energy trading, had resigned. Hes no longer with the firm, Bryan Locke, a spokesman for Citadel, told The Chicago Tribune. Mr. Robijns joined Citadel in 2005 to begin the companys European energy trading, according to SparkSpread, an energy and commodities news service.

title: Residential Capital Plans $12.5 Billion Debt Offering
description: Residential Capital, a real estate finance company that is part of GMAC, filed with regulators on Tuesday to periodically sell up to $12.5 billion in senior debt securities and subordinated debt securities. In November, a group of investors led by Cerberus Capital Management acquired a majority stake in GMAC from General Motors for $14 billion.

title: Behind Oracles Play for Agile
description: Agile Software had already seen two of its largest rivals snatched up before Oracle acquired it for $495 million. The Agile deal brings Oracle head-to-head with SAP in the manufacturing-related ERP software arena, The 451 Group wrote in a report. Back in August, when Agiles stock was in the low $5 range, The 451 Group said that it expected the company to be acquired. Earlier this month, Oracle agreed to pay $8.10 a share for Agile.

title: Kerkorians Vegas Moves Ignite Talk of MGM Deal
description: What is Kirk Kerkorian up to now?

title: With $10 Million in Hand, Evergrid Goes to Market
description: Evergrid, a data center software developer, received $10 million in new third-round venture funding, which it will use to bring its first product to market. The latest investors including first-time backer Menlo Ventures and return investor Acartha Group.

title: Tesla Motors Gets Battery Deal
description: Tesla Motors, the electric car start-up that has piqued the interest of stars like George Clooney, announced Tuesday that it had created a new division, the Tesla Energy Group, to sell batteries, and that it has received a $43 million order. Think, a Norwegian maker of electric cars, will buy lithium-ion battery packs from Tesla Energy. The deal, reported in the San Jose Mercury News, will bring Tesla $3 million this year and $40 million in 2008.

title: Aeroflot Seeks Loan for Alitalia Bid
description: The Russian airline Aeroflot is seeking up to 900 million euros ($1.2 billion) in loans to finance its bid for all or part of the Italian national airline, Alitalia, in its first merger or acquisition effort outside the former Soviet Union.

title: Cisco Spies Deal in Surveillance Software Maker
description: The networking equipment maker Cisco Systems said Tuesday it would buy privately-held BroadWare Technologies, a provider of Internet-based video surveillance software. Financial terms were not disclosed. The company said BroadWares software allows users to monitor, manage, record and store audio and video online, and helps customers gain access to live and recorded surveillance video for faster investigation response.

title: Chevron Plans Offering of Dynegy Stake
description: Chevron, the oil behemoth, intends to sell what amounts to a stake of about 12 percent in the energy company Dynegy through a public stock offering. Chevron U.S.A. will offer 96.9 million Class A Dynegy shares in a sale that will be managed by Goldman Sachs.

title: Boards More Likely to Oust Failing Chiefs
description: Corporate boards are nearly three times as likely to push out failing chief executives than they were a decade ago, a new study examining turnover among top executives has found. Nearly one of three chief executives who departed last year were either fired or forced out for performance-related reasons, according to the analysis by the global management consulting firm Booz Allen Hamilton. That compared with roughly one in seven departing executives ousted in 1996.

title: Paul Weiss Adds to Investment Funds Group
description: Paul Weiss Rifkind Wharton & Garrison said it hired Jennifer A. Spiegel as counsel in its corporate department. Ms. Spiegel, previously of Debevoise & Plimpton, will be part of Paul Weisss investment funds group, which advises on fund organization, registration and compliance as well as the buying and selling of investment advisers. The investment funds group has grown to more than 20 lawyers, Paul Weiss said.

title: Electronic Arts Takes Stake In Chinese Game Firm
description: In a deal that has been rumored for some time, Electronic Arts announced Monday that it is investing about $167 million to buy a 15 percent stake in The9, a Chinese video game company. As part of the deal, The9 acquired an exclusive license to publish E.A.s FIFA Online soccer game in China.

title: In Acxiom Deal, Its Hedge Fund vs. Hedge Fund
description: When an activist hedge fund makes headlines, its generally raising a ruckus over a companys poor management decisions. But now, two activist hedge funds seemed to poised to go head to head over a deal for software company Acxiom. MMI Investments, Acxioms second-largest shareholder, is objecting to the sale of the company to Acxioms largest shareholder, ValueAct, and the private equity firm Silver Lake.

title: Headwinds for Home Depots Supply Auction?
description: Is Home Depot having trouble selling its supply unit? According to The New York Post, the softening housing market and other complications are creating challenges for Home Depot as it tries to find a buyer for its professional supply business.

title: Unimpeachable Bravery
description: The legacy of the concentration camp survivor and Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal is one of unimpeachable bravery, but "I Have Never Forgotten You," a new documentary, is a suspect monument to his courage.

title: British Airways Signs Onto Iberia Bidding Group
description: British Airways said Tuesday it had joined a consortium led by a private equity firm, the Texas Pacific Group, that is considering a bid for Spains Iberia airline. British Airways is Iberias largest shareholder, with a 10 percent stake, and some analysts saw the move as an attempt to retain some influence over Iberia.

title: Buyout Bid for Outback Steakhouse Is Raised
description: OSI Restaurant Partners, which runs the Outback Steakhouse chain, said Tuesday a group including Bain Capital, Catterton Partners and OSIs founders have raised their buyout offer by 3 percent to about $3.18 billion.

title: 2008: Immigration Draws Out McCain
description: As he faces criticism from members of his own party over his immigration stance, Senator John McCain has begun to stress the differing positions of one of his chief G.O.P. rivals. For example, Michael Cooper reported on a three-pronged jab he took at Mitt Romney on the issue. Mr. McCain may also be feeling the competition from Mr. Romney, whose performance in polls in Iowa and New Hampshire is starting to match his stellar fund-raising capacity.

title: Fighting Spam, Artistically
description: This isnt usually a blog about art, let alone installations. But I thought youd get a kick out of this one from artist Bill Shackelford.

title: Graveyard Travels
description: As Americans choose cremation in record numbers, cemeteries are repositioning themselves for the afterlife: their own.

title: Cooler Climate for NIMBYs?
description: Wind turbines next to a farm house in Kansas, U.S. Lawrence Journal/AP

title: The Meaning of Democrat in Montana
description: If any state symbolizes the new Democratic Congressional majority, it might be Montana: a former Republican bastion that now has two Democrats, Max Baucus and Jon Tester, in the Senate. Matt Singer at Left in the West however, is beginning to have qualms about the sort of Democrats that get elected in conservative states. He considers the two Montanans votes against the Reid-Feingold bill, which would have put a timeline on funding for the war in Iraq, to be partisan treason. Theres a couple problems with this  first and foremost, its misleading. As a staffer from one of their offices told me himself, theres this whole false understanding that passing Feingold-Reid would literally mean that tanks in Iraq would start running out of gas and the like. Thats simply not true  and its not how our government actually operates. Our Senators shouldnt perpetuate myths.Second, theyre both using common right-wing attacks to undermine progressive Democratic leadership. They could have both simply said, My position is that the President and the Pentagon need to come up with a plan. This bill doesnt accomplish that. Instead, they threw in a gratuitous, Leading members of my own party want to pull out the rug on our troops in a way that I believe compromises the safety and security of our troops on the ground.' Those are Mitch McConnells talking points.

title: A Week Among the Sites of Andalusia
description: A friend is providing a resort condo for 7 days in Malaga! There are 3 of us and we have a car with a GPS, but there is so much to choose from in the neighboring cities, towns & beaches. Please recommend an ideal itinerary to see the best of the best while we are in Andalusia. A few great restaurant recommendations would be much appreciated too.

title: State Tax Discrimination
description: Taxing the other guy  not the locals who can vote in local elections has obvious appeal to politicians. It helps to explain the widespread use of discriminatory taxing of municipal bond interest. If you live in New York, bonds issued by that state, and its cities and other agencies, are not subject to state income tax. But those issued by other states are.

title: Wall Street Likes Kerkorians Odds
description: Whatever happens at MGM Mirage, it looks like Kirk Kerkorian will walk away a winner. That is what several analysts suggested Tuesday as they pondered Mondays short but highly suggestive announcement by Tracinda, Mr. Kerkorians investment vehicle, that it would begin negotiating to buy two Las Vegas properties from MGM Mirage and consider alternatives for its majority stake in MGM. Mr. Kerkorian has already hit the jackpot, at least on paper. Shares of MGM Mirage surged 26 percent in early trading Tuesday to $79.32. As a result, the value of Mr. Kerkorians 56 percent stake in the casino company grew by $2.6 billion overnight.

title: Siam meets Las Vegas
description: Im not normally a fan of cultural shows, but Siam Niramit, a huge production of acrobatics and special effects (the producers somehow figured out how to recreate a tropical downpour onstage) is worth the trip. Its sort of Thai culture meets Las Vegas.

title: Life in the Fast Lane
description: Charlie LeDuff interviews Gloria Castillo during her shift at a Burger King in Dallas.

title: Third Man in Russian Poisoning Case
description: Alexander V. Litvinenko, Andrei K. Lugovoi and Dmitri V. Kovtun met in London on Nov. 1. Within hours, Mr. Litvinenko would fall seriously ill, dying later that month from radiation poisoning. The other two would soon become a focus of the investigation.

title: Fremont Sells Commercial Lending Arm
description: Fremont General, a California lender stung by recent weakness in the subprime mortgage market, said Tuesday it had agreed to sell its commercial lending business to iStar Financial for about $1.9 billion, leaving the company to focus on its retail operations. Fremont also said that it would sell a minority stake in the entire company to an investor group led by Gerald Ford, the former chief executive of Golden State Bancorp, who will become its new chairman.

title: Is Jeff Immelt Done With Deal Making?
description: Speaking words that are bound to disappoint a few investment bankers, Jeffrey Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric, said the giant conglomerate is likely to avoid big deals for the time being. Interviewed by The Financial Times after the announcement that a Saudi Arabian company would buy G.E.s plastics business for about $11.6 billion, Mr. Immelt said, I like the company in the current position. We will remain tough-minded about opportunities, but the sale of the plastics business is consistent with our strategy. Instead, he indicated that the company will look to return excess cash to shareholders and expand its current lines of business.

title: Making New Yorkers Stay Put
description: Silda Wall Spitzer, the governors wife, said this morning that she would hold a public meeting to examine why young people are leaving the state, particularly upstate. The I Live New York conference will take place on Sept. 19 at the State University of New York in Cortland, N.Y., with the goal of coming up with a plan to halt or at least slow the exodus.

title: $10 Million Homes
Video: A Boomtown Revisited
description: The second video chronicling Nicks journey across China is from our first stop on the Chinese Mainland. Dongguan about 50 miles north of Hong Kong and Nick had first visited here 20 years ago. He later returned to profile a communist party official.

title: Two Hedge-Fund Heavies Host Obama
description: Presidential candidates in both parties have been wooing the Wall Street set in a big way this election season. Last Friday, it was the turn of Democrat Barack Obama, who touched down in Greenwich, Conn., the unofficial hub of the hedge fund set, for a pair of fundraisers. The first was co-hosted by George Soros, the financier and former hedge fund manager, and Paul Tudor Jones, who runs the giant hedge fund Tudor Investment Corporation. That event, held in Mr. Joness $25 million waterfront mansion  which Vanity Fairs Nina Munk has described as a a cross between Tara and a national monument  collected $2,300 from each of the approximately 300 attendees, the Greenwich Time reported.

title: The Inside-Out Lamburger
description: Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, grills a very un-American burger.

title: Looking for In-Laws
description: Continuing his journey across China, Nicholas D. Kristof visits his wife's ancestral village.

title: The Road From Yellow to Green Taxis
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs announcement today that the entire fleet of New York City taxicabs  more than 13,000 vehicles  will become all-hybrid by 2012 marks a reversal of his administrations earlier slowness in embracing the issue.

title: The Clinton Chronicles
description: Just as the presidential primaries are moving up on the calendar, so, too, are the publication dates of books about the race. And Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign may be most affected, as The Times Motoko Rich writes:

title: CBS Buys Wallstrip, Going Long on Finance Humor
description: Wallstrip, the offbeat financial Web show whose host has been known to frolic with hogs for a segment on pork producer Premium Standard Farms, has found a home with Big Media. CBS on Tuesday confirmed that it bought the quirky start-up, whose backers include venture investor Fred Wilson, for an undisclosed price.

title: The Buyout Boom, Now Even Boomier
description: The explosive growth of private equity deals is a well-documented trend by now, but some new numbers from Thomson Financial underscore just how enormous the volume of buyouts has become. Consider this: So far this year, the volume of global announced deals involving private equity firms is $447 billion, more than double the volume from the same period in 2006  a year that was no slouch was far as buyouts were concerned. In the United States, the rise has been even sharper. At $281 billion, U.S. private equity deals have more than tripled from a year ago, boosted by the recent buyouts of Alltel, First Data and others.

title: New Complaints in Gay-Bias Suit Against Law Firm
description: In the latest twist in a legal battle thats starting to resemble a corkscrew, Aaron Charney, the former Sullivan & Cromwell associate who has sued the law firm alleging gay bias, added several charges to his complaint Monday. To his initial allegations of discrimination based on sexual orientation, Mr. Charney has added claims of emotional distress and conspiracy, according to the New York Law Journal. Before his suit caused a stir in legal circles, Mr. Charney had worked in the mergers and acquisitions group at one of the leading firms that advises in such deals.

title: Google Trends: Hot or Not?
description: The 44th hottest trend in Google search right now is the phrase Google Hot Trends.

description: The Pew Center for the People and the Press has released results from a new poll of Muslim Americans attitudes on the United States. Good news, according to the Dallas Morning Newss headline: Poll: Most Muslim-Americans reject suicide bombings

title: Vive la Tin Snail
description: As French as the Eiffel Tower, or a smoke-filled bistro, the cheap and cheery Citron 2CV was originally built to suit the basic transportation needs of country-dwellers. Somewhere along the way, and during its epic production run of 1948-90, the simple 2CV became a symbol of Gallic coolness. The car has a cultlike following and is affectionately known by a variety of nicknames, including the tin snail, the duck, or the flying ragtop because of its foldable canvas roof.

title: Frugal Traveler: Tell Matt Where to Go in Georgia and Alabama
description: For the next 12 weeks, Matt Gross, the Frugal Traveler, will be on the road from New York City to Seattle. To make his journey a success, he needs your help. His next stops are in Georgia and Alabama.

title: Rudy+John=Friends 4Ever
description: The feud between Senator John McCain and former Gov. Mitt Romney is heating up, but it seems the McCain-Giuliani Mutual Admiration Society is as strong as ever. While Rudolph W. Giuliani and Mr. McCain share a reputation for tough talk, they only seem to have the kindest of words for one another. Lets take a look at a few examples:

description: Julia Preston, The New York Times reporter who answered some immigration questions last week, today wrote an article that outlines the immigration bill before the Senate.

description: Readers respond to David Brookss May 22 column, Americas Admissions System.

description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts May 22 column, American Cities and the Great Divide.

description: Our colleagues over at The Empire Zone are all over this story about Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs plan, announced today, to replace New York Citys entire taxi fleet with hybrid vehicles in the next five years. The Timess Sewell Chan writes:

title: The Frugal Traveler Hits the Road
description: Matt Gross packs up the 1989 Volvo station wagon he bought on Craigslist and heads out for a three-month trip across the continental U.S.

title: Modern Art and Old Rome (1): Schnabel
description: Of course everyone comes here to see the old stones. But this month you can take in Roman history and terrific modern art exhibits in one go. Check out the Julian Schnabel exhibit that just opened in Palazzo Venezia, a grand decaying building that was the first great Renaissance palace in Rome, and later served as a residence for Italian Dictator Benito Mussolini. Schnabels humongous bright abstract paintings are literally leaned up against the chipping frescos of the palaces cave-like chandeliered rooms. The contrast is perfect. In another room, Schnabels large glossy signature portraits are hung over sullied frescos of Roman seals and columns.

title: That Other Kentucky Horserace
description: Yes, the Preakness Stakes outdid the Kentucky Derby in terms of excitement this year with Curlins come-from-behind victory. Then again, were just as happy to watch another horserace in Kentucky today, this one featuring an impressive story of political recoveryeven if its only temporary.

title: A Song, and a Dance
description: The Senate Republicans gathered today at a news conference with law enforcement officers from around the state to demand that Gov. Eliot Spitzer push the Assembly to pass a bill reinstating the death penalty for cop killers. Afterward, Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, said that he had already spoken very directly to his Assembly counterpart, Speaker Sheldon Silver, about moving a death penalty bill to the Assembly floor for a vote.

title: Giulianis Touchdown in Albany
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani swung by Albany today to receive the support of a wide swath of New York state senators and members of the assembly. Well, not so much Albany  he flew into a private air terminal, run by the company Million Air, at Albanys airport, received the endorsements and some enthusiastic praise, then got back on his jet and flew off again.Among other things, the former New York City mayor said the Democratic candidates running for president did not understand the threat of Islamic terrorism and that state Republicans would find a way to retake control of the Assembly, a task that would require them to add a couple of dozen seats to the 40-odd controlled by the Republicans today.

title: Brooklyns Sweetest Landmark?
description: The citys Landmarks Preservation Commission voted today to schedule a hearing on whether to designate the former Domino sugar processing plant in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn as a landmark. The decision today, which was made in a unanimous vote, is the first of three steps required to make a building a landmark in New York City. Next, the commission will hold a hearing, then a final vote.

title: The Dynasty Continues
description: One of the great privileges of this job is the annual media game at Yankee Stadium and Fenway Park. Once a year, early in the morning, the Yankees and the Red Sox open their doors to let the New York media take on the Boston media. Its real hardball: umpires, scoreboards, music, a post-game food spread, the works. Everything but those annoying writers asking us questions after the game.

title: Glavine Not Looking Too Far Ahead
description: In the chat that he inevitably has with Atlanta/New York reporters on the first day of a series down here, Tom Glavine said that victory No. 300 seems much more in reach than it did before.

title: Bush Wars: The Final Frontier
description: With the title of his 1980 book, the journalist Sidney Blumenthal coined a term that has entered the political lexicon: The Permanent Campaign. The phrase denotes the blurring of the line in modern times between campaigning and governing. Presidents, of course, have always made decisions with an eye on their popularity. But with the advent of television, polling, and professional consultants, presidents of the 1970s and 80sNixon, Carter, and Reagan in particularupped the ante by devoting the full arsenal of modern electioneering tools not just to winning office but to holding office as well.Recently, the permanent campaign has added yet another stagea final frontier. This is the fight for history, centered on the presidents libraries. The presidential libraries date from 1939, when Franklin Delano Roosevelt conceived his as a repository for his public papers, to be built with private funds and run by public officials. Since then, chief executives have sought to outdo their predecessors by entombing their archives in extravagant, self-memorializing shrines. These museums extend the permanent campaign by utilizing the same public relations techniques as a race for the White Houseand lately requiring comparable fundraising efforts to boot.

title: U.S. Championship, Round 8: Onischuk and Shabalov Retain Lead
description: Alexander Onischuk and Alexander Shabalov drew their games today but retained their lead in the Frank Berry U.S. Championship in Stillwater, Okla. Three grandmasters  Sergey Kudrin, Gregory Kaidanov and Yury Shulman, last years runner-up  trailed by half a point with only one round to go. All the games can be seen live or replayed here at Monroi.com.

title: Move Over Youngsters
description: Oh, so you want red wine? How does 29 sound, as in 1929? Thats right, and Im talking Beaujolais. You know, that light, fruity inconsequential red thats best drunk within a couple of years. Now lets move onto something serious.

title: Triplex Penthouse at the Plaza Hotel Set to Sell for $56 Million
description: In an era of ever more expensive apartments in Manhattan, a triplex penthouse condominium in the Plaza Hotel has gone into contract for $56 million, in what would quite likely be the most expensive Manhattan apartment sale to date when it closes later this year, according to several real estate executives briefed on the transaction.

title: Bush Says Al Qaeda Seeks Haven in Iraq
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., May 23  President Bush, addressing head-on the criticism that Iraq has turned into another Vietnam, argued today that withdrawing from Iraq would be dangerous because, unlike the enemy in Vietnam, terrorists in Iraq have the capability and desire to strike Americans at home.

It is the Architects & Designers Building on East 58th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, not the Design & Decoration Building. (A building called the Decoration & Design Building, on Third Avenue between 58th and 59th Streets, is owned by the Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation.)

description: The spacious but gas-guzzling Ford Crown Victoria, long the emblematic vehicle of the citys yellow cab fleet, would be replaced by cleaner, more fuel-efficient hybrid vehicles under a five-year plan proposed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday.

description: It seems the more unpopular Pakistans military dictator, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, becomes at home and the less he is willing to fight the Taliban, the more the Bush administration clings to him.

description: LOS ANGELES, May 22  When last seen, in 1995, the New York super-cop John McClane, alter ego of the actor Bruce Willis, was performing barehanded bomb disposal on a downtown train and parrying racist attitude from his partner, Samuel L. Jackson, as he put away a batch of Germanic baddies led by the distinctly British Jeremy Irons.

description: Merrill Lynch said yesterday that Ben Weston, the chief of its hedge fund development and management group, left the firm after two years.

The production of wine, too, connotes an agrarian world of picturesque vineyards, wooden barrels and sage craftsmen.

description: A hammerhead shark that gave birth in a Nebraska aquarium reproduced without mating, a genetic analysis shows.

Understand the South, Yall, Even the Puzzling Parts
description: Ever since Roy Blount Jr. packed his bags and left the South nearly 40 years ago, he has been stuck with the job of explaining himself and his people to Northeastern liberals. It hasnt been easy getting past the redneck, racist, raving fundamentalist stereotypes, patiently explaining that yall is always plural and insisting that, amazingly enough, he does not really care about car racing.

description: BEIJING, May 23  Police in southwestern China arrested 28 people on charges that they instigated riots last weekend over family planning controls. But the government also dispatched officials to the region to deal with complaints about the areas strict measures to enforce birth control measures, reports in state-run news media said today.

description: The Cyclops, hairy and forbidding, arrived last week. Aristotle, literally a talking head, took his place early this month. The Trojan horse, 13 feet tall, came in April. But Odysseus  the voyaging warrior and undisputed hero of this scene  wont make his grand entrance until Friday.

title: Projects Foes Shown Door in Brooklyn
description: The letter arrived in Marilyn Olivas mailbox yesterday from the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz. It thanked her for her dedication to the community as a member of Community Board 6, but informed her that her services were no longer needed.

title: Alcan Rejects a Hostile Bid From Alcoa
description: OTTAWA, May 22  The Canadian aluminum producer Alcan rejected a $27.4 billion hostile bid from a rival, Alcoa, on Tuesday, calling the offer inadequate. Alcan said that it was in talks with other companies and added that it was considering the possibility of turning the tables with a counterbid for Alcoa.

title: Trenton: Troopers Union Chief Suspended
description: The state police yesterday suspended the head of the troopers union, Detective David Jones, for five days because he revealed a radio talk show hosts personal details to reporters this month, the union announced. The suspension came after an investigation by the state attorney general. On May 3, Detective Jones showed reporters a piece of paper containing the home address of the host, Craig Carton  half of the team known as the Jersey Guys  along with Mr. Cartons license plate number and the make and model of his car, the investigation found. The detectives actions came after Mr. Carton and his co-host disclosed Web postings by state troopers that threatened a ticket blitz in response to criticism of troopers role in a car crash involving Gov. Jon S. Corzine in April. Mr. Jones did not use law enforcement databases to obtain Mr. Cartons information, according to the attorney generals office.

title: Louisiana Court Backs Death in Child Rape
description: The Louisiana Supreme Court yesterday upheld the death sentence of a man convicted of raping an 8-year-old girl. Legal experts say the man, Patrick Kennedy, is the only inmate on death row in the United States who was not convicted of committing or participating in a killing.

title: Brooklyn: Probation for Fake Veterinarian
description: A man charged with operating on animals without a license was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to probation and mandatory psychiatric treatment. The man, Steven Vassall, 29, was accused of botching surgery on a Boston terrier. His case drew worldwide publicity for the involvement of a so-called undercover cat named Fred, used in a sting operation by the district attorneys office. Mr. Vassall was sentenced after pleading guilty to scheming to defraud and to the unauthorized practice of veterinary medicine. Under the terms of a plea bargain, he must attend an outpatient mental health program five days a week and refrain from involvement in nursing or animal care.

title: Ex-Writer Guilty of Kidnapping and Sex Attack
description: A former fashion writer was convicted today of a bizarre crime in which he posed as a firefighter and tied up and sexually abused a Manhattan woman he barely knew.

description: Of New York States five largest school systems, Yonkers was the only one whose students performed worse this year than last on the states standardized English tests even as test scores rose statewide, according to data released yesterday.

description: WASHINGTON, May 23  The Justice Departments former liaison to the White House testified before Congress today that she improperly weighed political factors in considering applicants for career positions in the department, and she said she was sorry.

It was the Second SS Panzer-Division, not the Second Panzer Division. It was commanded by Heinz Lammerding  not Heinz Guderian, who had been promoted to another job.

title: Atlanta Plans to Overhaul Narcotics Unit
description: ATLANTA May 22  Chief Richard J. Pennington announced 140 personnel changes in the Atlanta Police Department on Tuesday, including an overhaul of the narcotics unit, which has been under scrutiny since November, when an elderly woman was shot and killed in a botched drug raid.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, MAY 22  In Silicon Valleys version of The Bachelor, Anne Wojcicki not only landed one of Americas richest men, Sergey Brin, a co-founder of Google, but she also got her husbands company to finance her start-up.

title: Bombing Kills Six in Turkish Capitals Shopping District
description: DENIZLI, Turkey, May 22  A powerful explosion tore into a shopping district in Ankara on Tuesday, killing six people and wounding more than 70 in the most lethal attack in this country in months, Turkish officials said.

Now, an appealing proposal for a new train station and development of the area gives Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Mayor Michael Bloomberg the best opportunity in a very long time to correct this historic architectural blunder.

description: WASHINGTON, May 22  A comprehensive immigration bill survived a significant test on Tuesday as the Senate voted to keep a provision that would let hundreds of thousands of temporary foreign workers enter the country each year.

description: For decades, New Jersey developers have been recycling worn-out warehouses near the Hudson River into chic condos and fashionable retail centers. In cities like Hoboken, Jersey City and Weehawken, the value of a view of the Manhattan skyline across a milewide stretch of water overwhelms a sites value as a functional place to store and repackage goods.

description: WASHINGTON, May 23  President Bushs nominee to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission withdrew his name from consideration today, as a growing number of senators questioned both his suitability and a $150,000 departure payment that the National Association of Manufacturers was preparing to pay him. The nominee, Michael E. Baroody, is a senior lobbyist for the association.

title: Russia: Mine Officials Who Turned a Blind Eye to Safety Are Fired
description: The authorities dismissed five mine safety officials for allowing a Siberian coal mine to break safety rules for the benefit of profit, an action they said led to an explosion in March that killed 108 miners, the biggest mine disaster in Russias recent history. An investigation showed that the mines managers deliberately disabled a methane gas detector. A buildup of methane, sparked by a short circuit, caused the blast. The dismissals, reported by the Interfax news agency, were an exception to the usual blanket impunity enjoyed by government officials.

description: DENVER, May 22  The death of a monkey at the Denver Zoo from bubonic plague has prompted officials to change the habitats of some zoo animals and renew efforts to keep visitors from feeding the urban wildlife here.

title: Middletown: Child Bitten by Coyote
description: Police officers and state wildlife officials set traps yesterday to catch a coyote that bit a 5-year-old boy in the face and neck on Monday night, the second time in two months that a coyote had attacked a child in Middletown. The boy, Brayden Gazette, required 46 stitches and rabies shots. Police officers fired a shotgun at the coyote, but could not tell if they had hit it, said Robert M. Czech, the township administrator. On April 6, a 20-month-old boy was bitten by a coyote in another section of the township, but was not seriously injured.

title: Canada: Nortel Settles Accounting Fraud Investigation
description: Nortel Networks said it would pay 1 million Canadian dollars ($921,000) as part of a settlement with the Ontario Securities Commission. The payment is not a fine. The company called it a contribution toward the cost of the commissions investigation into accounting irregularities at the company from 2000 to 2003. Nortel, the communications equipment maker, acknowledged in the agreement that its senior executives had improperly altered accounting policies and provisions to improve the companys apparent financial performance. Under the agreement, the company must give the commission special quarterly and annual reports on efforts to improve its accounting controls. Nortel fired its chief executive, Frank A. Dunn, and two other executives over the bookkeeping issues in 2004. The former executives face separate charges by the Ontario regulator. The Securities and Exchange Commission has also charged the three as well as other former Nortel employees. Law enforcement officials in both Canada and the United States are also investigating the company.

description: With gas prices hitting yet another all-time high, consider this: while history is littered with examples of countries that were forced to change their domestic and foreign policies because of the lack of a natural resource, there are very few notable instances of nations that had the ability to eliminate such a vulnerability but didnt. description: CHESTNUT RIDGE, N.Y., May 23  Ten horses died in a barn fire here early this morning and two were rescued by the barns owner, the police said.

title: Queens: Man Charged in Sex Attack
description: A Jamaica man has been charged with holding an acquaintance captive in his familys garage and sexually assaulting her, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Joseph Burrell, 44, of 171st Street, was arraigned last weekend on charges of attempted rape, criminal sexual acts and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Burrell lured a 42-year-old woman to his familys furnished garage by inviting her to a barbecue last Wednesday and attacked her, beating her and smashing a glass object on her, then tried to rape and sodomize her.

title: Romance Over, Union Chief Has Corzines Number
description: When contract negotiations between Gov. Jon S. Corzines administration and New Jerseys seven major state employee unions reached a standstill last fall, one union president, Carla Katz, sent a message to the governors private e-mail address with a personal appeal to revive the talks.

title: India: Viacom Forms Joint Media Venture
description: Viacom and an Indian media company, the TV18 Group, said they would jointly create Viacom-18, a television, film and digital media company. Viacom-18 will start a Hindi-language entertainment channel later this year, and Viacoms MTV Networks, which is already present in India, will become part of the joint venture. Viacoms movie studios, DreamWorks and Paramount Pictures, will look for opportunities in India over the next few months, Viacom said. "India is one of Viacoms priority markets for expansion internationally," Philippe P. Dauman, above, the president and chief executive of Viacom, said during a news conference in Mumbai.

description: The archbishop of Canterbury sent out more than 800 invitations yesterday to a once-a-decade global gathering of Anglican bishops. But he did not invite the openly gay Episcopal bishop of New Hampshire and the bishop in Virginia who heads a conservative cluster of disaffected American churches affiliated with the archbishop of Nigeria.

title: Court Upholds Suspension of Student in Video Case
description: SEATTLE, May 22  Gregory Requa is not the annoying young man caught on camera making rabbit ears and thrusting his hips behind Joyce Mongs back. Nor is he the student who admitted to secretly filming Ms. Mongs English class at Kentridge High School to mock its clutter, her hygiene and to capture the teacher at unbecoming angles.

title: Stanley Miller, Who Examined Origins of Life, Dies at 77
description: Stanley L. Miller, a scientist whose spectacular discovery as a young graduate student pioneered the study of the origin of life on earth, died Sunday at a hospital near his home in National City, Calif. He was 77.

title: Ethiopia Releases Detained Times Journalists
description: Three journalists for The New York Times were arrested by the Ethiopian military on May 16 in the Ogaden region of the country, held for five days and interrogated at gunpoint, and then released Monday without any charges being lodged against them, The Times said yesterday.

It was last June, not August. (A court date in the case had been scheduled for August.)

title: New York Eighth Graders Show Gains in Reading
description: The number of eighth graders reading at grade level or above in New York State climbed impressively this year for the first time since 1999, when the state adopted tougher educational standards and its modern testing system, according to scores released yesterday from the annual statewide English exam.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some copies on Saturday about an open house at the Islamic Center of South Jersey in Palmyra, the mosque where four of the six men accused of plotting to kill soldiers at Fort Dix had worshiped, misstated the date of their arrests. It was May 7, not May 10.

description: John Edwards, the Democratic presidential candidate, plans today to outline his views on military policy, with a call for greater international strategic partnerships, more aggressive use of diplomacy in place of armed intervention and the creation of a 10,000-member reserve corps to help stabilize troubled nations.

description: In an alternate universe where the avant-garde works of the 1950s and 60s found a huge and enthusiastic audience, the program Petr Kotik conducted on Monday at Zankel Hall might have been a pops concert.

title: Veteran Facing Deportation Wins Hearing for Freedom
description: NEWARK, May 22  A veteran of the Persian Gulf war of 1991 who has been in custody for three years while United States immigration officials have tried to deport him has been granted a hearing to determine if he is being held legally.

title: Democrats Find Ethics Overhaul Elusive in House
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  House Democratic leaders pushing a promised lobbying overhaul are facing resistance from balky lawmakers and fending off accusations that a prominent member is flouting new ethics rules.

title: Corzine Weighs New Plan to Retain State Toll Roads
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 22  Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey said Tuesday that he was considering a plan that could generate billions of dollars from such state assets as toll roads without ceding control to private companies.

title: A Staple From Quebec, Embarrassing but Adored
description: DURING the 2000 presidential campaign, the candidate from Texas fielded a question from Canada: Prime Minister Jean Poutine said you look like the man who should lead the free world into the 21st century. What do you think about that?

title: U.S. Trying to Identify Body Found in Iraq
description: MAHMUDIYA, Iraq, May 23  The American military started examining a body found in the Euphrates River on Wednesday that Iraqi authorities and local residents believe is one of three American soldiers seized in an ambush on May 12.

title: Morgan Stanley to Buy Real Estate Trust
description: Morgan Stanley agreed yesterday to buy the Crescent Real Estate Equities Company, an investment trust founded by the Texas billionaire Richard Rainwater, for $2.78 billion.

title: Hague Court Inquiry Focuses on Rapes
description: DAKAR, Senegal, May 22  The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court in The Hague said Tuesday that he would investigate human rights violations committed during a brutal crackdown after a coup attempt in the Central African Republic in 2002 and 2003.

title: Demotions a Source of Motivation for Youkilis
description: With his shaved head hidden under his helmet but his bushy beard exposed, Kevin Youkilis of the Red Sox dug his feet deep in the batters box against Mike Mussina of the Yankees in the first inning of last nights game at Yankee Stadium.

title: Clinton Staff Memo Urged Skipping Iowa
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  In an indication of how the shifting calendar is forcing the presidential candidates to rethink their strategies, Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign considered  and rejected  a plan to stop competing in Iowa, the traditional kickoff state in the nominating process, and to concentrate instead on later states including the 20 that will vote on a single day in early February.

title: Guatemala: Adoption Protocol Endorsed
description: Lawmakers endorsed an international adoption protocol under pressure from the United States, which has said it will cease allowing Guatemalan children to be adopted by American parents unless reforms are made in Guatemalas largely privatized system. That system has been heavily criticized by international human rights organizations for the high cost charged to adoptive parents and for payments that are sometimes made to girls and women who are putting their children up for adoption. But real changes will not come until Congress passes a law implementing the requirements of the protocol, called the Hague Convention on Intercountry Adoption. The treaty calls for counties to set up a central adoption authority, which has been controversial in Guatemala because of the political clout of private attorneys who now manage adoptions.

title: Wall-to-Wall Books, and All of Them for the Landlord
description: The line outside the Gotham Book Mart in Midtown snaked down the block yesterday morning. Several dozen eager bargain hunters, book dealers, art collectors and former employees of the storied shop waited to bid on a piece of literary history.

title: Iran Isolates Jailed U.S. Scholar Charged With Revolution Plot
description: Swiss diplomats seeking to visit Haleh Esfandiari, a leading Iranian-American academic jailed in Iran, have not been given access to her, the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars said yesterday.

title: Germany: Investor Confidence on the Rise
description: German investor confidence rose to an 11-month high in May as company profits surged and economists raised their forecasts for growth this year. The Center for European Economic Research in Mannheim said its index of investor and analyst expectations increased to 24, the highest since June, from 16.5 in April. The center, known by the German acronym ZEW, said a gauge of investors assessment of the current situation rose to a record 88 from 76.9 last month.

title: Baghdad Truck Bomb Kills 25 and Wounds 100 Others
description: BAGHDAD, May 22  A truck laden with explosives detonated near a market in southwestern Baghdad on Tuesday, killing 25 people and wounding more than 100 in the latest setback for the American-led effort to stabilize this capital city.

title: Its Not That the Boss Seems Distant. Its Just That He Doesnt Exist.
description: To describe The Boss of It All, Lars von Triers acidic corporate comedy, as  The Office Viewed Through the Looking Glass only scratches the surface of the newest film from one of the foremost tricksters of world cinema. At the outset Mr. von Trier, shown standing behind a window, disingenuously announces that the movie is a comedy and harmless as such: no preaching or swaying of opinion.

title: Nascar Plans to Use New Car Full Time in 08
description: Nascar will use the Car of Tomorrow in all 36 Nextel Cup races next season after officials announced yesterday that they had decided to scrap plans to phase in the new racecar over three years.

title: Fire in Baltimore Row House Kills 6 People and Injures 7
description: BALTIMORE, May 22  A fire tore through an East Baltimore row house Tuesday morning, killing six people, including three children, and injuring seven others, the authorities said.

title: 60 Minutes Creator Takes on Rockettes
description: The Radio City Christmas Spectacular, featuring the Rockettes, Santa Claus and a parade of wooden soldiers, will be shown almost in its entirety in a prime-time special on NBC in early December, in what Radio City and the network said yesterday was the first such broadcast in the shows 75-year history.

title: Dining Briefs
description: NEW PLACES

title: To Sleep, Nay, Perchance to Stay Wide Awake
description: Not sleeping is unpleasantly hallucinatory  a perpetually interrupted story suffused with nasty little phantasms and blurs and set to a cloying medley of half-remembered music. Wide Awake, the documentary about insomnia on HBO tonight, is true to this experience.

title: Savannah Adds to the Master Plan of 1733
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.  As one of the oldest planned cities in the country, Savannah is known for compact, walkable streets and beautifully landscaped historic squares. Designed by the citys founder, James Oglethorpe, in 1733, it has remained largely intact even as electricity and cars were introduced, though buildings have changed uses over time.

title: Helped by Imports, Busch Raises Forecast
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies said yesterday that profit would rise more than forecast this year on higher sales of imported beers and fewer discounts of Bud Light and Michelob.

title: Trying to Find the Upside After a Scandal
description: FOR decades, the Marsh & McLennan Companies relied on word of mouth and personal relationships to maintain a client roster of the biggest corporations and to bring in new business. And it grew into the worlds largest insurance broker.

title: N.F.L. Welcomes Whistle-Blowers on Concussions
description: NASHVILLE, May 22  After the 2011 Super Bowl was awarded to Arlington, Tex., on Tuesday, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell addressed a variety of issues, including the handling and treatment of concussions.

title: NBCs Dateline, Its Ratings in Decline, Releases Its Longtime Anchor
description: With an eye toward costs, NBC News yesterday released one of its longtime news anchors, Stone Phillips, announcing that he was leaving the network and would no longer appear on the newsmagazine program Dateline.

title: Portland Wins Lottery and Can Pick the Prize
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., May 22  It was a bad night to be one of the N.B.A.s worst teams. The league held its draft lottery Tuesday, and the three teams that finished with the worst records were bumped out of the drafts top spots.

title: Tracking an Online Trend, and a Route to Suicide
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 22  From their nondescript sixth-floor office, Kim Hee-joo and five other social workers troll the Internet to combat a disturbing trend in South Korea: people using the Web to trade tips about suicide and, in some cases, to form suicide pacts.

title: Marian Radke-Yarrow, Child Psychology Researcher, Dies at 89
description: Marian Radke-Yarrow, a researcher in child psychology who conducted many influential studies on a range of sensitive issues  including prejudice among elementary school pupils, depression in very young children and indications of altruistic impulses even in 1-year-olds  died on Saturday at her home in Bethesda, Md. She was 89.

title: Court Says Paramilitary Commander Must Be Tried in U.S. Before Returning to Haiti
description: Facing deportation to Haiti, where he is wanted for murder, the onetime commander of a paramilitary group was instead ordered in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday to stand trial on charges of grand larceny.

title: Low-Maintenance Yards
description: When landscaping his second home in Santa Fe, N.M., Brad Bealmear knew that a lush green lawn wasnt a feasible option for a harsh desert environment. Inspired by the expansive views of pinon and juniper trees surrounding his three-bedroom house, he planted native vegetation and brought in drought-resistant shrubs like chamisa. Water is getting more expensive and more scarce, Mr. Bealmear said. But now we dont have to worry about the yard. Its low maintenance.

title: As Comrades Search, Fatal Bomb Wreaks Havoc
description: MAHMUDIYA, Iraq, May 22  The ground exploded under an ashen sky at dawn. Dust, dirt, blood and military equipment filled the air, clearing after several seconds to reveal a frenzied scene of horror.

title: Antimissile Test Comes Amid Financing Debate
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  With Congress considering cutting the Pentagons budget for missile defenses and Europe on edge over Bush administration proposals to deploy the system to the continent, much is riding on a test scheduled in the next few days of the antimissile shield based in California and Alaska.

title: Parent of Outback Chain Accepts Higher Bid
description: OSI Restaurant Partners, owner of the Outback Steakhouse chain, has agreed to a higher $3.1 billion takeover offer from a group led by Bain Capital Partners and Catterton Partners.

title: To Cut the Mustard, and More
description: A SUNNY Sunday in spring, and the outdoors beckoned. Armed with a picnic, my husband and I headed for the Cloisters and Fort Tryon Park.

title: Armstrong Strategy, but He Isnt Armstrong
description: Floyd Landis demanded an open hearing to dupe the public with his quaint props, with a symbolic yellow tie under his shirt collar, with his mother in the courtroom wearing a bonnet, with his father all but ready to churn butter for the jury.

description: Dinner, With Commentary
