title: Intel to Form a Flash Memory Venture With a Swiss Company
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 22  In a move to shed an unprofitable business as its turnaround gains traction, the Intel Corporation announced Tuesday that it would join with STMicroelectronics, a Swiss semiconductor maker, to form a new company to sell flash memory chips.

title: Illinois: Teller Is Killed in Bank Robbery
description: Three masked men stormed a community bank on the South Side of Chicago and shot three people, before fleeing with a small amount of money, the police said. A 23-year-old male bank teller died later of his wound. A 48-year-old security guard at the bank and a 73-year-old customer were in critical condition at a local hospital, said Monique Bond, a police spokeswoman. The robbery occurred around 9:30 a.m., when the three masked men entered the Illinois Service Federal Savings & Loan, disarmed one security guard, exchanged gunfire with a second guard, wounding him, and shot the two other victims, the police said. The robbers remain at large.

title: Europeans Approve Vivendi Deal for BMG
description: European regulators approved the estimated $2.1 billion purchase by Vivendi of the Bertelsmann music publishing unit yesterday, a deal that will give Vivendi unmatched market power in determining how much performers and songwriters earn from their creations.

title: Tavrez Treats Himself With a Victory
description: Julin Tavrez had a very happy birthday yesterday. On the day he turned 34, he earned his 34th career victory as a starter in the Red Sox 7-3 win over the Yankees last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: 12 Guilty in Serbian Premiers Death
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo, May 23  A Serbian court found two former paramilitary police officers guilty of the assassination of Zoran Djindjic, the pro-reform prime minister who was gunned down in Belgrade in March 2003.

title: A Chef to the Few Heeds the Call of the Many
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: For Drug Makers, a Downside to Full Disclosure
description: When GlaxoSmithKline settled a lawsuit three years ago with the

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL And the next Idol is ... ? Jordin Sparks, above left, and Blake Lewis learn who will walk away with the title in tonights two-hour season finale, broadcast live from the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles. An American Idol Red Carpet Special, at 7:30, focuses on the action outside the theater. Meanwhile, Melinda Doolittle fans  including Simon Cowell  will be left to wonder what might have been.

title: Letter From California: Some Thoughts on Living the Combustible Life
description: Recently, I flew from Denver to Ontario, Calif. The next-to-last leg of that flight is mostly over desert, and at night the desert floor means darkness. Then we came over the mountains, and in the distance I could see a dim line of lights slowly rising to fill the horizon, the leading edge of the luminosity that is Southern California at night. Before long we were descending, wheels down, over a district of low, flat buildings, enormous in scale, their parking lots and loading bays gleaming under mercury and sodium lamps.

title: CBS Buying Wallstrip, a Web Finance Site
description: CBS has bought Wallstrip, an online company whose Web site mixes finance with humor, to add to its daily financial news Web broadcast. The terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: F.A.A. Warns of Increasing Flight Delays
description: HERNDON, Va., May 23  Although airlines experienced their worst flight delays ever last summer, this year so far looks even worse, Federal Aviation Administration officials said today. But government and airline executives said they hoped that innovations in air traffic software would minimize delays caused by weather.

title: Kazakhstan: President Ends Term Limit for Himself
description: President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev signed several constitutional amendments put forward by Parliament, including an exemption for himself from a provision limiting presidents to serving two terms, effectively clearing the way for him to become president for life. Political opposition groups objected to the provision as the beginning of a Soviet-style personality cult for Mr. Nazarbayev, who came to power in 1989 and whose current seven-year term expires in 2012. Mr. Nazarbayev also signed off on constitutional changes that expand Parliaments responsibilities, including a greater role in choosing the prime minister.

title: Haiti: Switzerland to Return Baby Doc Funds
description: Switzerland will return $6.2 million next month that it seized in bank accounts of the dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier, known as Baby Doc, Swiss officials said. A large part of the money is to be given to Haiti for humanitarian projects. The officials said the remainder would be returned to Mr. Duvalier, who was overthrown in 1986 and lives in exile in France.

title: Brooklyn: Healthful Food Plan for the Poor
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and City Council Speaker Christine Quinn announced a new effort yesterday aimed at improving poor New Yorkers access to healthful food. With a $500,000 grant from the W. K. Kellogg Foundation, city officials are bringing together public and private groups to recommend ways to increase healthful eating and physical activity. In addition, the Human Resources Administration, the citys welfare agency, is expanding a pilot program that allows food stamp offices to process electronic applications taken at food pantries and soup kitchens. Two organizations in Queens will be added to the program, with Manhattan groups to follow, city officials said.

title: For Sosa, Atlanta Is No Place Like Home
description: ATLANTA, May 22  As any good host would, the Atlanta Braves welcomed Jorge Sosa back to town by offering all the comforts of home. For Sosa, that sort of hospitality meant getting hit and hit hard, just as he did before the Braves dumped him nearly 10 months ago.

title: California Wants Strict Auto Emission Rules
description: ARLINGTON, Va., May 22  Officials from California demanded on Tuesday that federal regulators allow the state to impose the strictest automobile and light truck emissions rules in the nation. They said that new regulations were needed to lessen the threat of global warming and threatened to sue if the government did not allow them to go forward.

title: And Now for a Chocolate Break at Bendels
description: Alison Nelson, above, who opened the Chocolate Bar in Greenwich Village five years ago, has added another location, her third, in the Henri Bendel store on Fifth Avenue (56th Street). This airy cafe on the third floor, done in blue, chocolate-brown and ivory, has a bar, banquette seating and a table on the balcony. Boxes of chocolate bars and truffles line the shelves.

title: Finally, Exit From New York
description: As the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge faded in my rearview mirror last Thursday afternoon, I had only one thought in my head: Finally! I had woken up late, had spent way too long packing for this road trip and had been sitting in Brooklyn traffic. Typical. Now, however, my Volvo was zipping over what was once the worlds longest suspension bridge, heading west, and nothing could stop me.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about spousal rights, gave an incorrect name for the federal office that tallied the number of rights and responsibilities connected to marriage. It is the Government Accountability Office, not the Government Accounting Office.

title: Delgado Doesnt Know How to Fix His Problem
description: ATLANTA, May 22  Carlos Delgados name was in the starting lineup Tuesday night for the 41st time this season. Not once in the previous 40, Delgado said, had he felt comfortable at the plate.

title: Troubled Lender Sells Division and Brings in New Leadership
description: The Fremont General Corporation, a financial services company caught up in the subprime mortgage lending mess, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its commercial real estate unit for $1.9 billion and bring in new managers.

title: British Police Seek 3 Missing Terrorist Suspects
description: LONDON, May 23  Britains counterterrorism police today took the highly unusual step of issuing a public appeal for information about three suspected terrorists said to have absconded from a form of house arrest known as control orders.

title: Pope Softens Remarks on Conversion of Natives
description: ROME, May 23  Pope Benedict XVI tried today to quell anger in South America over his recent comments on the conversion of native populations there, acknowledging today that unjustifiable crimes were committed in the European conquest of the continent five centuries ago.

title: Trial to Begin in Fire That Burned Houdini Papers
description: CINCINNATI, May 22  A private collection of Harry Houdini memorabilia was largely destroyed in a house fire that the police said was started when a burglar tried to light his crack pipe. The suspect in the case is scheduled to go on trial on Friday.

title: Immigration Raid Leaves Sense of Dread in Hispanic Students
description: WILLMAR, Minn.

title: Post at Luxury Hotel Awaits Ex-Mayor at End of Prison Term
description: BOSTON, May 22  When he gets out of federal prison next week, Vincent A. Cianci Jr., the former mayor of Providence, R.I., who was convicted of corruption, will not exactly be slumming it.

title: Food Safety Joins Issues at U.S.-China Talks
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Teams of cabinet members from China and the United States held a day of talks Tuesday to reduce economic tensions but ran into familiar disagreements over trade, currency issues and at least one new concern, the safety of Chinese food exports.

title: Democrats Pull Troop Deadline From Iraq Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Congressional Democrats relented Tuesday on their insistence that a war spending measure set a date for withdrawing American combat troops from Iraq. Instead, they moved toward a deal with President Bush that would impose new conditions on the Iraqi government.

title: Recipe: The Best Spinach Dip With Chipotle and Lime
description: 2 10-ounce packages frozen spinach, thawed and drained

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A brief article in Science Times on May 1 about research on migraines and mental decline referred incorrectly to the subjects of the study. The researchers looked at men and women, not just women. In addition, among the approximately 1,400 subjects studied over 12 years, more than 200 of them had a history of migraines  not about 20 of them.

title: As Refugees Flee, Lebanese Army Vows to Crush Militants
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon May 23The stream of Palestinians flowing out of the Nahr al Bared refugee camp on the outskirts of Tripoli continued today, as the Lebanese army reinforced its positions and vowed to crush the militants inside the camp.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Saturday about the Cavaliers victory against the Nets to win their playoff series misstated the age of LeBron James of Cleveland. He is 22, not 24.

title: Debate Raging, Mexico Adds to Consulates in U.S.
description: On the surface, there was nothing extraordinary about a certain government office in Little Rock, Ark., the other day as paperwork was signed, names were called, fees were paid, waits were endured and computer keyboards went tap, tap, tap.

title: Harsh Realities in a World of Fantasy
description: CANNES, France, May 22  Sleaze rarely looks as lovely and plays with such sentiment as it does in Abel Ferraras Go Go Tales, a down-and-dirty story about a nightclub owner and the beauties and beasts who work for him. The film, which unfortunately, if unsurprisingly, is screening out of competition, is easily Mr. Ferraras best since The Funeral (1996) and welcome news for his hard-core, patient admirers. (Its commitment to female pulchritude comes unadorned by self-consciously belabored art and ideas.) An obvious homage to John Cassavetess underbelly classic The Killing of a Chinese Bookie (1976), Go Go Tales also works rather poignantly as a metaphor for the down-and-dirty independence that Mr. Ferrara has pursued his entire filmmaking career.

title: Living History in St. Petersburg
description: As an American expatriate in St. Petersburg, one of the most romantic, historic and difficult cities in Russia, Lisa Kreutz zeroed in on one of its most prestigious areas when she bought an apartment in 2003.

title: Roy De Forest, 77, Painter of Colorful, Comic Scenes, Dies
description: Roy De Forest, a Bay Area artist whose paintings depicted a comical, crowded frontier land of people and animals in patchworks of scorched, textured color, died on Friday in Vallejo, Calif. He was 77 and lived in nearby Port Costa.

title: Giuliani Above the Fray as McCain and Romney Skirmish
description: The contrast could hardly be more striking. Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney have been mixing it up on the trail with increasing intensity ever since their feisty exchange at the last Republican debate. This week their arguments over immigration prompted Mr. McCain to suggest acidly that Mr. Romneys solution might be to get out his small-varmint gun and drive those Guatemalans off his lawn.

title: Yankees Stumble and Lose Momentum
description: There were two wide cardboard boxes stacked on top of each other by the empty locker at the back of the Yankees clubhouse yesterday. Written on the top box, in red marker, was, Attn Rob Cucuzza/Rocket.

title: Search Continues Off Jersey Shore for Missing Fisherman
description: POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N.J., May 22  Another brass plaque will soon be added to the wooden railing surrounding the fishermens memorial here, inscribed with the names of one, and probably two, commercial fishermen.

title: Correction: Whos Watching What We Eat?
description: An article last Wednesday about criticism of the Food and Drug Administrations efforts to protect food safety misstated the agencys explanation for the cause of a recent contamination outbreak. It believes melamine, a chemical used in fertilizers and plastics that has tainted pet food and animal feed, was in wheat flour imported from China  not in wheat gluten or rice protein. (The agencys initial assessment was based on the fact that the flour was mislabeled as wheat gluten or rice protein.)

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on May 8 about a study showing how meditation affects attention referred incorrectly to one group that was studied. The 17 volunteers who meditated for 10 to 12 hours a day as part of the research did have previous meditation experience; they were not new to meditation.

title: Attack Not Disputed at Trial, Just Intent of the Attacker
description: The prosecution and the defense offered contradictory versions yesterday of why  but not whether  a former fashion writer had dressed as a firefighter, tied up a woman he barely knew and sexually molested her in her Chelsea apartment on the night of Oct. 31, 2005.

title: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
description: When Institutional Investors Alpha magazine released its annual list of the highest paid hedge fund managers last month, it allowed the rest of us to play an entertaining little parlor game: what could you buy if you made as much money as those guys?

title: Wie Planning to Resume Her Career Next Week
description: Michelle Wie spent yesterday at RiverTowne Country Club in Mount Pleasant, S.C., an old shrimp boat town on Charleston Harbor and the site of next weeks L.P.G.A. Ginn Tribute.

title: Pilot Strays Near Shuttle
description: A private pilot was chased by a NASA helicopter after his plane flew near the space shuttle Atlantis as the shuttle sat on its launching pad. The incident prompted an F.B.I. investigation, federal authorities said. The pilot, Michael Dunn, 41, of Port St. Lucie, Fla., became disoriented and drifted into restricted airspace above the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, said Chris Bonner, and F.B.I. special agent. The plane, a 50-year-old Aeronca Champ, lacked a radio or working transponder, Mr. Bonner said. He said the F.B.I. decided not to pursue criminal charges after questioning Mr. Dunn.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,415 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans yesterday:

title: During His Funeral, Falwell Is Praised for Activist Style
description: LYNCHBURG, Va., May 22  The Rev. Jerry Falwell was eulogized Tuesday as a daring critic of American life, called by God to his role as a clergyman and political activist.

title: Buffalo: Murder Suspect Dies
description: A man charged with the murder of two women whose remains were found inside sealed barrels on March 31 died on Saturday, four days after being taken to the Erie County Medical Center for a mental health evaluation, the Erie County Sheriffs Office said yesterday. Hours before he was stricken on May 15, the man, Robert J. Henchen, 42, of Colden, pleaded not guilty to charges of killing Geraldine Jackson, 87, and Nancy Phelps, 69, both of whom disappeared months before their remains were found. According to his lawyer, Mr. Henchen suffered a cardiac incident. But the cause of his death remained under investigation yesterday, the Sheriffs Department said. He had been hospitalized because of odd behavior, including refusal to wear clothes, at the Erie County jail, said Undersheriff Richard T. Donovan.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture in Weekend on Friday with an article about the fall prime-time schedules for Fox and CW was published in error. It showed a scene from Supernatural, which will be entering its third season on CW  not Reaper, a new show on that network.

title: Defibrillators Lift Medtronics Profit
description: Medtronic, the biggest maker of electronic heart devices, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose 9.7 percent on higher sales of implantable defibrillators, the companys top product.

title: Everything and the Kitchen Sink: The Memoir of a Dishwasher
description: Until just recently, Pete Jordan hadnt washed a dish professionally in seven years. Now an author, Mr. Jordan used to be a paid dishwasher, following in the steps of literary plongeurs like Theodore Dreiser and George Orwell, who, recalling his time behind the sink in Paris, once wrote:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A music review on Saturday about a performance of Rameaus Castor et Pollux at the French Institute Alliance Franaise in New York, misspelled part of the name of the group that performed. It is LOpra Franais de New York, not Franaise.

title: Palestinian Rivals Meet to Discuss Cease-Fire
description: TEL AVIV, May 23  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, held a private meeting Tuesday night in Gaza with the Palestinian prime minister, Ismail Haniya, to try to secure the cease-fire between their rival factions, and to discuss how to calm down an escalating conflict with Israel, Mr. Haniyas spokesman said today.

title: Sports Briefing
description: pro football

title: Russian Is Accused of Poisoning Ex-K.G.B. Agent
description: LONDON, May 22  The British authorities on Tuesday accused a Russian businessman, Andrei K. Lugovoi, of murdering Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. agent and foe of the Kremlin poisoned six months ago in London with a radioactive isotope, polonium 210.

title: For Yanks and Red Sox, Its Money Well Wasted
description: For nearly a century, the Boston Red Sox and the Yankees have made each other crazy. Lately, it may be more true than ever.

title: The Hollow Promise Reform Act
description: The Houses new Democratic majority is flirting with disaster as it guts key provisions of the strict lobbying reform it promised voters last November. Rebellious lawmakers, worried about their own career path, fought their leaders to defeat tighter restrictions on the sleazy, revolving-door culture by which members of Congress move on from an apprenticeship of merely serving the people to real Washington money as insider lobbyists.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A brief article in Science Times yesterday about a study showing that alcohol consumption can lower the risk of one type of kidney cancer misstated the publication date. It appeared in the May 16 issue of The Journal of the National Cancer Institute; it is not scheduled to be published in the June 16 issue.

title: A Policewoman Looks Back on the Craziest of Love Duets
description: The policewoman who guarded the hospital room, Margaret Powers, had come prepared. I happened to have brought a pack of cards, Mrs. Powers recalled. She introduced herself to the woman in the bed, Linda Riss, whose eyes were bandaged. Lye had been thrown in her face. A jealous ex-boyfriend was responsible, and he was still at large. She was 22. The policewoman was 10 years older.

title: Book Ads: The Golden Age, 1962-1973
36 Hours in Moscow
description: A weekend in a metropolitan city that has maintained its brash and flashy side.

title: Democrats Pull Troop Deadline From Iraq Bill
description: For the first time since taking power in Congress, the Democrats yesterday publicly agreed to allow a vote on Iraq war financing without a timetable for troop withdrawal. The move apparently ended a legislative battle with President Bush, who had refused to accept time constraints.

title: High Art
description: La Paz, Bolivia, might be the Pop Art capital of South America.

title: Clinton Campaign Memo on Iowa
description: The following is the text of a Clinton campaign memo obtained by The New York Times.

title: The Unknown
description: Images from "Mythic Creatures: Dragons, Unicorns and Mermaids" at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Star moves
description: Following a years-long search, Mike Myers, the star of the Austin Powers and Waynes World movies, has finally found his perfect pad in New Yorks SoHo district, according to The New York Post. The celebrity has just purchased a newly constructed penthouse at 72 Mercer Street for $7.95 million. Measuring just over 4,200 square feet, the apartment includes three bedrooms, six bathrooms, a living area with 15-foot ceilings, and a 1,368-square-foot rooftop terrace.

title: A Different Museum
description: Additional images from the Creation Museum in Petersburg, Ky.

title: Photos: Milan Champion of Europe
description: Two years after losing a three-goal lead to Liverpool in the 2005 Champions League final, A.C. Milan defeated the England side to win its seventh European Cup title.

title: Onex to Unload More of Spirit in Offering
description: Canadian buyout firm Onex said Tuesday it plans to sell another billion-dollar share of its stake in Spirit AeroSystems Holdings. Nigel Wright, managing director of Onex, said the sale will come through a secondary offering of about 31.5 million Class A shares at $33.50 each.

title: Its True: Guy Kawasaki Starts Rumor Site
description: The proliferation of cheap software is allowing entrepreneurs to take bigger risks when starting a company with an unproven, or non-existent business model. In the latest such example, Garage Technology Ventures investor Guy Kawasaki, best known for his early Apple evangelism, recently launched Truerumors.com, a forum to post rumors and comments via phone call, text message, or email.

title: Jury Gets a Taste of Blacks Unusual Rhetoric
description: Conrad Black, the former chairman of Hollinger, expressed a desire to blow the asses off investors who complained of boardroom extravagance shortly before what was expected to be a contentious annual shareholder meeting in 2002, according to an e-mail presented Tuesday in a Chicago court.

title: MuleSource Takes $12.5 Million in New Funding
description: MuleSource, a provider of open-source business software, said Tuesday that it had raised $12.5 million in its second round of venture funding, adding to an initial $4 million it raised last fall. This latest round was led by Lightspeed Venture Partners.

title: No Rival Bids Emerge for First Data
description: Private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts can go ahead with its $29 billion takeover of First Data without worrying about another suitor. First Data, one of the nations largest credit-card processing companies, said Tuesday that a period for soliciting competing bids passed without any other takeover proposals.

title: Wall Street Bonuses May Break Record (Again)
description: Wall Street appears to be gearing up for another year of fat bonuses, according to a forecast released Tuesday. Less than halfway through 2007, an executive recruiting firm, Johnson Associates, is predicting that year-end bonuses for investment bankers could exceed last years total by 10 percent to 15 percent in most areas.

title: Dress Codes: Shorts
description: Raising cuffs without raising eyebrows.

title: Hedge Fund Suit Tests Use of Big Boy Letters
description: The use of big boy letters  which often appear in deals where one party has confidential information about a stock or bond  is about to face its first significant legal challenge in the form of a lawsuit filed by R2, a Texas hedge fund.

title: Former Chief of EMI Said to Prepare Rival Bid
description: It took EMI Group years to reach a consensual takeover agreement, but another bidder may emerge much, much sooner. The New York Post reported Wednesday that at around 12:30 p.m. Tuesday  exactly 24 hours after EMI agreed to be acquired by Terra Firma Capital Partners for 265 pence per share  private equity firm Corvus Capital and former EMI chief executive Jim Fifield were in the final stages of preparing a bid of 278 pence per share for the British music company.

title: Fine Points | Keeping Time in Cool Comfort
description: Opening Ceremony in Manhattan introduces its shoe collection that includes suede, canvas and leather jazz shoe styles for men and women.

title: The Meaning of Ill Be Back
description: Angelina Jolie may be going on sabbatical, Rambo is back with a bloody trailer at the Cannes film festival, but what about everyones favorite action hero-turned-governor?

title: Intel to Form a Flash-Memory Venture
description: In a move to shed an unprofitable business as its turnaround gains traction, Intel said Tuesday it would join with STMicroelectronics, a Swiss semiconductor maker, to form a new company to sell flash memory chips. Flash memory is used in cellphones, digital music players and digital cameras and is considered one of the most erratic segments of the semiconductor market.

title: Hedge Fund Executive Leaves Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch said yesterday that Ben Weston, the chief of its hedge fund development and management group, left the firm after two years.

title: Outback Steakhouse Accepts Higher Bid
description: OSI Restaurant Partners, owner of the Outback Steakhouse chain, has agreed to a higher $3.1 billion takeover offer from a group led by Bain Capital Partners and Catterton Partners.

title: Luxury Chiang Mai, a bit guiltily
description: Traveling in Southeast Asia, as in most parts of the developing world, often involves being confronted with jarring contrasts between rich and poor, visitor and local. And the more remote the area, the bigger the disparity.

title: Morgan Stanley to Buy Real Estate Trust
description: Morgan Stanley agreed Tuesday to buy Crescent Real Estate Equities, an investment trust founded by the Texas billionaire Richard Rainwater, for $2.78 billion. At $22.80 a share, the offer is 5.5 percent more than Crescents closing price Tuesday of $21.62. The total value of the transaction is $6.5 billion including debt, Fort Worth-based Crescent said.

title: ...And Do You Take This (Buff) Woman?
description: Determined brides have found one way to cut corners by trying to get in shape for less than $20. Ashley Miller, personal trainer, tests wedding workout DVDs.

title: MGM Mirage Forms Independent Board to Study Kerkorian Offer
description: The casino giant MGM Mirage said Tuesday night that its board had formed an independent committee to study an offer by the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian to buy two MGM Mirage properties and perhaps restructure the company.

title: Europeans Approve Vivendi Deal for BMG
description: European regulators approved the estimated $2.1 billion purchase by Vivendi of the Bertelsmann music publishing unit yesterday, a deal that will give Vivendi unmatched market power in determining how much performers and songwriters earn from their creations.

title: Sallie Mae Says Chief Is Resigning
description: SLM, the student lender commonly known as Sallie Mae, said Tuesday that its vice chairman and chief executive, Thomas J. Fitzpatrick, was resigning to pursue other interests. The move comes after SLM agreed last month to be sold to a consortium led by a private equity firm, J.C. Flowers & Company.

title: Chinese Bookstore Chain Prices I.P.O. Amid Strong Demand
description: Sichuan Xinhua Winshare Chainstore, which will be the first bookstore operator to list in Hong Kong, has priced its initial public offering at the top of the range for a total deal size of 2.2 billion Hong Kong dollars ($274 million).

title: Firms Sell Formica for $700 Million
description: Cerberus Capital Management and Oaktree Capital Management will sell the Formica Corporation, the countertop maker they acquired out of bankruptcy protection, for $700 million to a New Zealand manufacturing company, Fletcher Building.

title: House Votes to Tighten Reins on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
description: Legislation to tighten federal oversight of the two biggest buyers of home mortgages, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, cleared the House on Tuesday. But the bill could lose the support of the Bush administration because of a provision trimming the authority of federal regulators.

title: Bloomberg for Governor?
description: More New York City residents would support Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg if he were to run for governor than if he were to run for president, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released this morning.

title: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
description: When Institutional Investors Alpha magazine released its annual list of the highest paid hedge fund managers last month, the eye-popping sums caused grumblings among some investors about the high fees that hedge fund managers are collecting.

title: Home Depot Plans Kinder, Gentler Shareholder Meeting
description: It was, as even Home Depot executives will concede, a 37-minute fiasco. In a basement hotel ballroom in Delaware, with the board nowhere in sight and huge timers on stage to cut off angry investors, Home Depot held a hasty annual meeting last year that attendees alternately described as appalling and arrogant.

title: The Difficulty of Death
description: In a movie culture filled with fake death and callous killing, "Dying at Grace" is not just a shock to the system; it's an accusation. Filmed over 14 weeks in the winter of 2002, in the palliative care ward of the Salvation Army Toronto Grace Health Center, Allan King's wrenching record of five real deaths is a potent reminder of the fearful gap between fiction and reality.

title: Payless Adds Stride Rite to Its Closet
description: Payless ShoeSource said Tuesday it is buying shoe company Stride Rite for about $800 million as a way to grab a bigger share of the fast-growing branded and childrens footwear sectors.

title: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
description: In Europe, the occasional activist has stirred up a revolt at an annual general meeting, led a no-confidence vote against management and even taken executives to court. Those have been the extreme cases.

title: Google Backs Firm Started by Co-Founders Wife
description: In what The New York Times describes as Silicon Valleys version of The Bachelor, Anne Wojcicki not only landed one of Americas richest men, Sergey Brin, a co-founder of Google, but she also got her husbands company to finance her start-up. Google said Tuesday that it invested $3.9 million this month in 23andMe, the biotech company co-founded last year by Ms. Wojcicki, a former health care industry analyst, The New York Times reported.

title: Oaktree Raises $800 Million in Landmark Offering
description: Oaktree Capital Management, an investment firm that oversees about $40 billion in assets, became the first company to list on a new market created by Goldman Sachs as a way for private firms to raise money without going public. Oaktree raised more than $800 million selling a stake of about 14 percent to fewer than 50 other large investors, The Los Angeles Times reported.

title: Hertz Backers Plan $1 Billion Offering
description: Hertz Global Holdings said Clayton Dubilier & Rice, Merrill Lynch and the Carlyle Group plan to sell shares valued at almost $1 billion after the stock gained 40 percent since its initial offering in November.

title: Norilsk Raises Bid for LionOre Mining
description: Norilsk Nickel on Wednesday raised its bid for LionOre Mining International to 27.50 Canadian dollars a share, valuing the Canadian miner at about 6.8 billion Canadian dollars ($6.3 billion). The Russian companys revised bid for LionOre, the worlds 10th-largest nickel producer, was 10 percent higher than a rival offer from Xstrata, which last week made a bid of 25 Canadian dollars a share, valuing LionOre at 6.2 billion Canadian dollars.

title: An Imperfect Construction
description: In "9 Star Hotel," the Israeli filmmaker Ido Haar draws us into the precarious world of young Palestinian construction workers scrabbling to survive in and around the Israeli city of Modiin. Irregularly and illegally employed, the men hide in the wooded hills above the city, sleeping in shelters made from scraps of Sheetrock and constantly on the alert for Israeli security forces.

title: Alcan Spurns Hostile Bid and Talks to White Knights
description: The Canadian aluminum producer Alcan rejected a $27.4 billion hostile bid from a rival, Alcoa, on Tuesday, calling the offer inadequate. Alcan said that it was in talks with other companies  The Globe and Mail newspaper reported that one of them is the Australian mining giant BHP Billiton  and added that it was considering the possibility of turning the tables with a counterbid for Alcoa.

title: The Color of Dissent
description: In the documentary "Orange Winter" orange blooms throughout Kiev, Ukraine, the epicenter of dissent over that country's stolen 2004 presidential elections. Outraged Ukrainians adopted the color that winter to express support for the pro-Western presidential candidate, Viktor A. Yushchenko, who was poisoned with dioxin by unknown enemies to protect his establishment-supported rival, Viktor F. Yanukovich.

title: 2008: Beautyshop Appeal
description: During a speech before the Council on Foreign Relations today, John Edwards plans to call for greater international strategic partnerships, more aggressive use of diplomacy in place of armed intervention and the creation of a 10,000-member reserve corps to help stabilize troubled nations, reports The Timess Leslie Wayne.

title: Republican Donors, Undaunted
description: Greg Giroux of CQPolitics has a party fundraising update that shows winning isnt everything, at least not in politics:The Democratic victories in last Novembers elections have not  at least not at this early juncture of the 2007-08 cycle  reversed the fundraising advantage the Republican National Committee (R.N.C.) has long held over the Democratic National Committee (D.N.C.).The R.N.C. reported raising $7.4 million in April, compared with $4 million for the D.N.C., according to campaign reports filed late last week with the Federal Election Commission (F.E.C.). That continues a trend: The R.N.C. has outraised the D.N.C. every month this calendar year.The R.N.C. raised $33 million in the first four months of this year and had $14.2 million in cash on hand; the committee was debt-free as May began. The D.N.C. has raised $19.7 million this year and had available cash of $6.1 million, with debts of $3 million.The D.N.C. has lower cash on hand than the R.N.C. because it has spent a greater percentage of its receipts  in part because the D.N.C. pays salaries for party personnel in all 50 states. The D.N.C., which has vowed to be more competitive in traditionally Republican-leaning states and districts, spent about $921,000 on staff salaries in April.

title: Video: Looking for In-Laws
description: In the latest video from China, Nick tries to track down his wifes relatives. Sheryl WuDunns ancestors, like many other Chinese-Americans, hailed from the Taishan region of southeastern China. Theres an audio slide show from Nicks last visit in 2003 and a related column with a very provocative headline.

title: Statue Watch: Bill Clinton Edition
description: Inside the United Nations, the subject of what Kosovo can and cant do is a subject of great debate. It cannot supervise the Serbian province indefinitely, yet plans for effective independence have been hitting hurdles for months.

title: Oilman Tops Hedgie for Manhattan Real-Estate Crown
description: In what may be a sign of the times, oil has trumped hedge funds in New Yorks contest for real-estate bragging rights. The New York Times, picking up on a story on The New York Observers blog, reported Wednesday that an unnamed London-based businessman in the oil business has agreed to pay $56 million for a triplex penthouse condominium at New Yorks Plaza Hotel. If the deal closes, it is likely to be the most expensive sale ever of an apartment in Manhattan. It would also break the record set by Daniel Loeb, the head of the hedge fund Third Point Capital, who is known for his exquisitely barbed letters to corporate managers.

title: Finding Poetry in the Position Paper
The Fertile Territory Beyond Our Own
description: We New Yorkers like to think we live in the best restaurant city in the country, and Ive not seen any compelling evidence to date that we dont.

title: Tracking Illnesses Online
description: A couple weeks ago, I wrote about my desire to see a Web 2.0 site where people could report the details of their illnesses. At a glance, youd be able to see the clouds of color-coded flu bugs or GI bugs moving through your area or even your town. When you got sick, at least youd know what kind of duration and intensity you could expect.

title: Blogroll Update
description: Weve updated our blogroll to include some of the newsier neighborhood blogs from the five boroughs, especially Brooklyn, which seems to be New York Citys blogtopia. Or blogistan.Thanks in particular go to Louise Crawford of Only the Blog Knows Brooklyn, who pointed out that we had not paid enough attention to the list lately.

title: New Ads From Dodd and Romney
description: In a new ad out today, Senator Christopher J. Dodd names names, but in his new ad, Mitt Romney declines to name a place.

title: The Perfect Paris Lunch (3 star)
description: My wifes aunt was in town for her birthday last week, and to mark the occasion she wanted to treat us all to a 3-star restaurant. We had read a while ago that Yannick Allno of Le Meurice just got his third Michelin star this year, and my aunt-in-law liked the idea of a lunch in old-style French elegance.

title: Big Tool Deal in the Works?
description: Illinois Tool Works makes everything from self-drilling screws to commercial meat slicers. But is the 95-year-old industrial conglomerate interested in making a deal? That is what many investors seemed to be wondering Tuesday, as trading in the companys stock and options ratcheted up quite a bit. Shares of the company, which has a market capitalization of more than $29 billion, spiked as much as 6 percent in morning trading Tuesday amid what Jon Najarian, co-founder of OptionMonster, described as way above normal trading volume.

title: Britain delays home sales packet
description: Britain has delayed the requirement that anyone selling a home must provide a packet of information about the property after surveyors mounted a legal challenge, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Same Institute, Different Drummer
description: Ah, how times have changed. After Fernando Ferrer, the former Bronx borough president, lost the Democratic primary for mayor in 2001, he found a safe harbor as president of the Drum Major Institute, a liberal policy group.

title: The State Assemblys Error Message
description: Normally, the New York State Assembly has a lovely little Web site with links to lawmakers home pages, a search function for legislation and more.

title: Diamonds are for luck
description: The last time that McLaren Mercedes drivers carried diamonds around like this in Monaco, in 2005, they finished first and fifth in the race. Obviously the team has no objections to doing all it can to facilitate its sponsor, the Steinmetz diamond company, in its efforts to show off the diamonds again.

title: When Labor and Private Equity Shake Hands
description: Who says buyout firms and unions cant be friends?

title: Roaming for Less, in Europe
description: The European Union placed caps today on mobile-phone roaming charges within its 27 member states, answering a groundswell of complaints that would be easily recognizable to anyone with a cell phone and any semblance of a victims complex.

title: Modern Art and Old Rome (2):Chagall
description: If you are shopping on Via Corso or heading back to town from the Coloseum or the Imperial Forum, stop at the wonderful temporary Chagall retrospective exhibit in the Museo Del Risorgimento. The museum is entered through the back side of Romes ugliest monument, Il Vittoriano, a bright white late 19th Century creation to commemorate Italian unification. (For those who have just done the Schnabel exhibit, Il Vittoriano is the bright white monstrosity right across Piazza Venezia.) The Chagalls could be better organized and displayed, but there are dozens of terrific paintings spanning 6 decades of the artists work. Particularly interesting for those in Rome who are overdosed on traditional religious art, are Chagalls unconventional renderings of the Bible, in which Jesus is shown with all the trappings of Judaism (notice the Torah), placed in what looks like Chagalls birthplace in a village in Russia. To finish your visit, head upstairs to the museums outdoor cafe, on a terrace overlooking the ruins of the Imperial Forum. The coffee is excellent. The sangria not bad. Most important, the terrace has one of the best panoramas of Rome, with excellent signs that help you make sense of the forest of spires and arches you are seeing. Just FYI this outing is very kid-friendly; I did this one with my 15-year-old, who loved both the art and the view.

title: Vlasic Ads
description: The stork that has represented the Vlasic line of pickles since 1974 is returning to television advertising for the first time in many years.

title: Vlasic Ads
description: The stork that has represented the Vlasic line of pickles since 1974 is returning to television advertising for the first time in many years.

title: Blodgets Fateful Amazon Call Comes True Again
description: Henry Blodget, the former Internet analyst, is taking some pride from a little-noticed milestone: For the first time since he agreed to be barred from the securities industry, shares of Amazon have risen back above $400.

title: Testing, 3-4-5, Testing, 6-7-8
description: New York has reported results of English tests in Grades 3-8 taken in all public schools this spring. The tests show that the number of students passing in earlier grades dropped from 2006 levels in most places, but rose compared with last year in middle school grades. The Times unveiled an online tool today that allows readers to look up results by school.

title: The Saga of Toto Constant
description: A Brooklyn judges decision yesterday to hold Emmanuel Constant  a onetime paramilitary leader and C.I.A. informer  for further jail time on grand larceny charges underscores the sad and bizarre aspects of a complex legal case that spans Haiti and the United States and has caught the attention of human and civil rights advocates in both countries.

title: Microsoft: We Dont Need Yahoo
description: With an agreement to buy aQuantive under its belt, Microsoft is playing down rumors  in the air for at least a year, most recently stoked by the New York Post  that it might try to buy Yahoo. We have all of the pieces we need to move forward in the online-advertising business, Yusuf Mehdi, Microsofts chief advertising strategist, said Wednesday at a Goldman Sachs  Internet conference in Las Vegas.

title: Clinton Staff Memo Urges Shunning Iowa
description: A senior official in the campaign for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton wrote an internal memorandum to the campaign advising Mrs. Clinton not to participate in the Iowa caucuses, arguing that she probably could not win them and that she would be better off spending her time and campaign money in places more hospitable to her campaign.

title: Settlement a Boon for Ground Zero
description: The Spitzer administration and a group of major insurers announced a settlement this afternoon of insurance claims at ground zero, ensuring that $4.55 billion will be available for rebuilding the World Trade Center site  about half of what is needed. The settlement provides about $870 million to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the land at ground zero and built the trade center, and $1.13 billion to the developer Larry A. Silverstein, who is to build large office towers on Church Street, between Vesey and Liberty Streets.

title: You Should Hear His Ed Sullivan
description: (mp3)

title: A War Phrase That Pays Less and Less
description: Britain and the House budget committee deserted the war on terror last month, and now candidates for the White House are starting to weigh in.

title: We Respond to Questions About the Layout of the House
description: Dear Readers:

title: Hands Across the Complex
description: It has been 21 years since Hands Across America, when on May 25, 1986, some five million people joined hands in a line to Long Beach, Calif., from New York to raise money to fight hunger and homelessness.

title: So What Was Wrong With the Original Idea?
description: Beyond telling our architect, Greg Huddy, that the latest version of the house was too big and too expensive, I didnt have any ideas on how to fix it.

title: The Peregrine Chicks of Throgs Neck
description: It is a tale that would have been warm enough to touch the heart of Robert Moses  well, maybe not. According to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a population of tiny peregrine falcons was recently born atop the Throgs Neck Bridge, the suspension span that connects the Bronx and Queens and opened in 1961 under Mosess supervision.

title: Et tu, Senator Kerry?
description: The New Republics Michael Crowley has read retired-and-still-eight-time-loser Democratic strategist Bob Shrums new memoir, No Excuses: Concessions of a Serial Campaigner, so you dont have to. [N]o one comes in for rougher treatment in this book than Shrums former client, John Edwards, Crowley writes, who says Edwards is portrayed as an intellectual lightweight and a hyper-ambitious phony.

title: Apple iPhone Commercial
description: An ad for the launch of Apple's iPhone.

title: Avon Commercial
description: An ad for Avon.

title: A New Silent Majority
description: Something seems a little out of whack between the mainstream media and the American people. Take the arguments of the past few days over former President Jimmy Carters remarks about the Bush administration and the consequences of its particular brand of foreign policy. Carter didnt attack President Bush personally, but said that as far as the adverse impact on the nation around the world, this administration has been the worst in history, which cant really be too far out of line with what many Americans think.

title: Dreaming of Citywide Broadband
description: The citys Broadband Advisory Committee, created in 2005, includes representatives of the City Council and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg who are trying to find ways to broaden Internet access across the five boroughs. The committee held a public hearing yesterday at Borough Hall in Brooklyn, led by Councilwoman Gale A. Brewer, a Democrat from Manhattan.

title: Its a Boy for Mary Cheney
description: For such a little guy Samuel David Cheney, weighing in at 8 lbs., 6 oz., sure prompted a hefty debate in the run-up to his birth in Washington this morning. Hes the son of Mary Cheney, and his grandfather is Vice President Dick Cheney.

title: Giuliani Takes on Edwards
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani found a useful foil in Ron Paul during the recent Republican debate, and now hes taking on a Democrat  John Edwards  to make his points on the national security front during an appearance today in New Hampshire.

title: Next Years Budget, This Year
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer, in a speech tonight to the Citizens Budget Commission, plans to announce that he will move up the budget calendar by a couple of months to try to ease the states tight negotiating timetable.

title: A Life in Rim Shots
description: What does it take to be a comedy writer? Some people ask because they want to be one and some (the more fortunate ones) because they merely want to know.

title: Delgado Dropped to Sixth
description: Carlos Delgados struggles have cost him his hold on the cleanup spot in the lineup. Willie Randolph dropped him to sixth, replacing him with David Wright, marking the first time Delgado has started a game and hit that low since May 14, 1997, when he played with Toronto.

title: In Darfur
description: My assistant, Winter Miller, who keeps order as I go gallivanting around the globe, wrote a terrific play called In Darfur  about the ethical issues that arise in reporting in a hellhole like Darfur. It was inspired in part by a trip to the Chad-Darfur border a year ago in which she accompanied me through burned-out villages

title: U.S. Championship, Final: Shabalov Wins
description: Alexander Shabalov beat Sergey Kudrin in the last round of the Frank K. Berry U.S. Championship in Stillwater, Okla., to win the tournament and claim the title of U.S. champion. Alexander Onischuk, last years champion, had a chance to tie for first, but he was held to a draw in the last round by Boris Gulko. Onischuk finished second and Gregory Kaidanov, Yury Shulman Julio Becerra finished in a tie for third. The games can be replayed here at Monroi.com.

title: E-Mail on My Cellphone
description: Who needs a BlackBerry or a Treo? David Pogue reviews three free services that send your e-mail to any cellphone.

title: You Want Yankee News? Tonights Your Night
description: Lots and lots of news out at Yankee Stadium tonight:

title: Your Comments on My China Trade Column
description: My Thursday column takes on China-bashing protectionists but also notes that China is going to face difficult transitions ahead. I tend to think theres a bit too much China exuberance right now and that most people dont adequately allow for the challenges ahead.

title: Factory of the World
description: Nicholas D. Kristof visits a sweatshop in the heart of China's manufacturing region.

title: Subduing Those Streaking Fans
description: George Steinbrenner and the Boy Scouts of America would have been proud.

title: Bright Eyes in the Big City, Sporting a Prada Suit and a Hot Album
description: When Eric Dimenstein, a booker, first approached Conor Oberst  the heartthrob singer-songwriter better known as Bright Eyes  with the idea of playing seven shows at Town Hall, Mr. Oberst reacted like any up-from-the-underground indie rocker: he blanched.

title: In Trinidad, Outdoor Life, Inner Desires
description: Theres no hidin place down here, Sophia Adams sings in Moon on a Rainbow Shawl, and shes right. For Sophia and her neighbors in a crowded, cacophonous yard in Port of Spain, Trinidad, life is lived in public, and passing judgment on one another is as natural as singing.

title: As Law Is Renegotiated, Immigrant Families Are on Edge
description: Amir Nikpouri was struck by love at a family gathering on the first trip he had made in many years to his home country, Iran.

title: Refugees Pour Out of Camp in Lebanon
description: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, May 23  The stream of Palestinians flowing out of the Nahr al Bared refugee camp on this citys outskirts continued Wednesday, as the Lebanese Army reinforced its positions and vowed to crush the militants inside.

title: Study Finds Hurricanes Frequent in Some Cooler Periods
description: Over the last 5,000 years, the eastern Caribbean has experienced several periods, lasting centuries, in which strong hurricanes occurred frequently even though ocean temperatures were cooler than those measured today, according to a new study.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,418 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans yesterday:

title: Kenneth Sokoloff, 54, Economist, Is Dead
description: Kenneth L. Sokoloff, an economic historian who was a leading expert on the role the United States patent system played in technological and productivity advances in the 19th century, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 54.

title: U.S.-China Trade Talks Open With Food Safety an Issue
description: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

title: Bush Wants Tougher Sanctions on Iran
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  President George W. Bush said today that he would seek tougher sanctions against Iran for defiantly pursuing a uranium-enrichment program that Western governments believe is intended to help develop nuclear weapons.

title: Mine Blast Kills at Least 38 in Siberia
description: MOSCOW, May 24  A gas explosion in a coal mine killed at least 38 people early this morning in a part of Siberia notorious for mine accidents, opening fresh wounds in a community scarred by an accident two months ago that claimed more than 100 lives.

title: War Spending Bill Without Timetable Clears Congress
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Congress voted tonight to meet President Bushs demand for almost $100 billion to pay for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan through September, providing a momentary truce in a bitter struggle over war policy.

title: Sticking With the Basics to Stay on the Right Track
description: JOHNNY Gs original Spinning program includes five moves: standing flat, which means standing on the pedals and slightly increasing the resistance; seated flat, which means pedaling during warm-up and cool down; seated climb, which means sitting on the bike with an elevated resistance; standing climb, which means standing out of the saddle with resistance even higher; and jumps, which means moving up and out of the seat.

title: Canada: Profit Up at Bank
description: The Bank of Montreal said second-quarter profit rose 3 percent as higher fees from mutual funds and stock sales offset a big loss in commodities trading. Net income climbed to 671 million Canadian dollars ($618 million) from 651 million Canadian dollars a year earlier, the bank said. Record mutual fund sales and rising demand for loans contributed to a 24 percent increase in consumer banking profit, countering the commodities losses, which were related to natural gas trading. The bank said on May 17 that it would report a pretax trading loss of 680 million Canadian dollars. Bank of Montreal said profit was 1.31 Canadian dollars a share excluding the trading loss and other one-time items, an increase of 3.1 percent from a year ago. Revenue in the quarter, which ended April 30, rose 2.7 percent, to 2.57 billion Canadian dollars from 2.5 billion Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on May 16 about clashes in Gaza between the military wing of Hamas and forces loyal to Hamass rival, Fatah, misidentified the affiliation of seven men who were killed in a jeep and whose weapons were stolen in the attack. They were members of the pro-Fatah National Security Forces, not the Presidential Guard.

title: A Predator Preys Mostly on Our Minds
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.J.

title: Yankees Likely to Cut Ties With Pavano
description: The Yankees all but closed a maddening chapter of their recent history yesterday by admitting that Carl Pavano has probably thrown his last pitch for the team. Doctors have determined that Pavano has a damaged elbow ligament, and Pavano has decided to undergo reconstructive surgery.

title: When They Say You Are a Spammer
description: About a year ago, Scott Madlener, a marketing executive, e-mailed a client several times but his messages were not getting through.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column yesterday about a free folk music series on Governors Island this summer erroneously included a deceased singer among the performers. The concert called Harry Chapin: A Celebration in Song will be performed by friends and family members of Mr. Chapin, who died in 1981.

title: Bronx: Inmate Charged in Murder Plot
description: An inmate at Rikers Island was arraigned yesterday on charges that he tried to arrange the murder of a 31-year-old Queens woman who is scheduled to testify against him, prosecutors said. The inmate, Ashumba Bryan, 29, of Brooklyn, was charged with conspiracy to commit murder, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Bryan is awaiting trial on charges of attacking and robbing the woman in October 2005  beating her and throwing her out of her moving car, prosecutors said. Mr. Brown said Mr. Bryan was captured on audiotape in April trying to arrange the womans murder for $10,000 to prevent her from testifying.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Thursday about concerns in Congress over broadcasts of Islamic militant views by Al Hurra, an American government-financed television network in the Middle East, referred incorrectly to the timing of the appointment of the networks new vice president for news, Larry Register. Mr. Register was already on the job when Al Hurra broadcast a speech by Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, in December; he was not hired to make sure such broadcasts did not recur. The article also misstated the length of Sheik Nasrallahs broadcast speech; it was 67 minutes, not 30 minutes.

title: Real People Meet Real Design
description: MARK CRISPIN MILLER squinted into the hanging, eyeball-high tunnel made by the decorative smashed-glass panels of Yorgos Papadapoulos, a Greek Cypriot living in London and showing at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair last Saturday, and worried aloud. I think these defy the broken-window doctrine of policing, he said. Youd be tempted to run amok in your own house. Who knows where that would lead?

title: Getting a Chance to Fill Up Before the Price Goes Up
description: DETROIT, May 23  A Michigan-based retail chain is trying to help customers save money by warning them several hours beforehand about price increases at its gasoline stations.

title: Top of Throgs Neck Bridge Is Home to Family of Falcons
description: Theres plenty of room for a growing family, and the views cant be beat.
