description: To the Editor:

title: A Rose-Colored Reality Where Everyone Wins
description: There are no sore losers on reality television.

title: Currencys Rise Stokes Concern in India
description: NEW DELHI, May 23  Concerned that the rising value of the Indian rupee is threatening to limit the countrys economic growth, especially in the lucrative outsourcing industry, monetary policy experts here have started putting pressure on the Reserve Bank of India to stem the rupees rise.

title: Senate Narrowly Rejects Changes in Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  - The Senate narrowly rejected two proposals today that would have upset the delicate compromise embodied in a bipartisan bill to overhaul the nations immigration laws.

title: S.E.C. Revises Its Standards for Corporate Audits
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved new guidelines yesterday that try to balance the need for tighter financial controls with the cost of complying with them. It said the new procedures will make it less costly for smaller companies to assess the state of their internal financial controls.

title: Brazil: Minister Quits Under Cloud
description: In a widening corruption scandal, the sixth to strike the government of Luiz Incio Lula da Silva since he took office in 2003, the minister of mines and energy, Silas Rondeau, resigned. Citing wiretapping and videotape evidence, the police say he accepted a $50,000 bribe from a construction company in return for preferential treatment in the awarding of contracts for a rural electric program.

title: City to Pay $2 Million to Parents of Man Fatally Shot by an Officer
description: The city agreed yesterday to pay $2 million to the parents of a young man killed in a Brooklyn stairwell, ending a three-year effort to account for the damage done by a single bullet fired by a police officer.

title: From Israel, N.B.A. Is Still a Long Shot
description: Yotam Halperins bid to become the first Israeli player in the N.B.A., as described in the October 2006 issue of PLAY, has remained in limbo since he returned to Israel and his team there, Maccabi Tel Aviv. The news medias attention on his N.B.A. quest wore on him, his agent says, and he struggled through the first half of the season in the Israeli league. But in the second half he turned things around and led Tel Aviv to the playoffs, where the team is still alive. The Seattle SuperSonics chose Halperin in the second round of the 2006 draft and still own his N.B.A. rights, but will likely not make a decision about his future until June, according to the agent, Jason Levien. For now, Halperin is keeping his thoughts on an N.B.A. career to himself. There was so much media hype and attention about him playing in the N.B.A. that he is not talking to the media about it right now, Levien said. He just doesnt want to talk about it.

title: Turkey Vows to Pursue Militant Kurds Into Iraq
description: ISTANBUL, May 23  Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said in sharp language on Wednesday that Turkey would move against Kurdish militants in northern Iraq if necessary, hours after the Turkish authorities said they had identified the suicide bomber in an attack on Tuesday in Ankara as a man from a predominantly Kurdish city.

title: Prisoner of Her Desires
description: Brussels

title: Truth, Cynicism and the Baseball Way
description: So, Major League Baseball, in its current truth and candor phase, wants to finally dig into the seedy depths of its Steroid Era and reveal who injected what, when they did so and in what dosages. Right. Lets review the current Jason Giambi tempest for what it is: baseball business as usual, which is to say, cynicism as usual.

title: An Owner Gets a Title, but Not His Wish
description: Now that he is no longer prime minister of Italy, Silvio Berlusconi has more time to focus on the truly important things in life  that is to say, the starting formation for his A.C. Milan soccer team.

title: Rethinking Old Age
description: At some point in life, you cant live on your own anymore. We dont like thinking about it, but after retirement age, about half of us eventually move into a nursing home, usually around age 80. It remains your most likely final address outside of a hospital.

title: Crazy, He Calls Me (and Terrified, I Agree)
description: There is a case to be made that Gaslight, Patrick Hamiltons 1938 play, currently the subject of an excellent revival at the Irish Repertory Theater, is the seed from which the Lifetime television channel eventually grew. It established the blueprint for a kind of domestic-peril thriller that has defined that channels identity and purpose. Every time an actress like Lisa Rinna or Heather Locklear portrays the sort of wife who discovers that the greatest threat to her mental and physical safety is the man sitting in her breakfast nook, Mr. Hamiltons estate ought to receive some type of remuneration.

title: After Gains in the North, Sinn Fein Seeks a Louder Voice in Ireland
description: DUBLIN, May 23  Weeks after its return to Northern Irelands power-sharing government, Sinn Fein, the political affiliate of the Irish Republican Army, is trying to extend its influence in the Irish Republic, pursuing its goal of a united Ireland.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A map with a front-page article on Monday about a clash between Lebanese troops and Islamic militants at a Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon misidentified the city shown south of Beirut, the capital. It is Sidon  not Tyre, which is about 25 miles south of Sidon. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/world/middleeast

title: Prez, Using His Full Repertory, Baffles the Braves Again
description: ATLANTA, May 23  After years of experimenting, the Mets have discovered the one ingredient they need to defeat the Braves. His name is Oliver Prez. The Mets have defeated the Braves three times this season. Prez has won all three games, including a 3-0 victory Wednesday night at Turner Field that ensured the Mets will leave town atop the National League East.

title: Morgan Library Chooses Familiar Face for Its Next Chief
description: Four months after Charles E. Pierce Jr. announced plans to retire as director of the Morgan Library & Museum, the institutions board has named a familiar face as his successor: William M. Griswold, who was a curator at the Morgan for six years and is now director and president of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts. He assumes the post in early 2008.

title: With a New Sock, the Red Sox Add Some Distance
description: In 2004 Curt Schillings bloodied socks  the ones he wore that October while he conquered the Yankees and the St. Louis Cardinals on the way to Bostons first World Series championship in 86 seasons  were the symbol of the Red Sox.

title: A House on the Hudson With a Japanese Soul
description: GERMANTOWN, N.Y.

title: Candidate to Lead Consumer Agency Withdraws
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  A senior lobbyist at the National Association of Manufacturers withdrew his nomination to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission on Wednesday as a growing number of senators questioned both his suitability and a $150,000 departure payment that the association was preparing to give him.

title: Pirates and Sanctions
description: DONGGUAN, China

title: Manhattan: Cancer Screening Awareness
description: A group of the citys most powerful women gathered outside City Hall yesterday to promote regular breast cancer screening through mammograms, whose use has been steadily decreasing. The group, which included First Deputy Mayor Patricia E. Harris; the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn; and the public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, announced a public awareness campaign, assisted by Macys, to inform women about how and when to schedule exams. Ms. Harris said fewer women were receiving regular mammograms than in the past. According to a study recently published in the medical journal Cancer, the decline could be a result of a shortage of available testing, questions about the effectiveness of the exam and higher patient co-payments.

title: Lead Lawyer for Landis Describes Errors by Lab
description: MALIBU, Calif., May 23  For nine days, lawyers from the United States Anti-Doping Agency sat next to a wooden easel that displayed Floyd Landiss drug-test results.

title: Free Software to Play DVDs
description: Q. I would like to watch DVDs on my computer with a program that works better than Windows Media Player. Are there any free ones available?

title: The Apprentice: Omaha Edition, Starring Warren Buffett
description: A number of years ago, in a moment of professional weakness, I bought exactly one share of Warren Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway (the Class B share, mind you, not the $100,000 kind). For a brief moment, I thought his track record might disprove the economists mantra that no one can beat the market in the long term so its better to just invest in index funds like one that matches the S.& P. 500.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Monday about Anthony Brooks, a British undercover agent in France in World War II, misidentified a German armored division he sabotaged and its commander at the time. It was the Second SS Panzer-Division, not the Second Panzer Division. It was commanded by Heinz Lammerding, not Heinz Guderian. Because of an editing error, a correction in this space yesterday referred incorrectly to the command Guderian held before a promotion. It was the Second Panzer Division  not the Second SS Panzer Division, which he never commanded.

title: Donovan and Summitt Honored
description: Billy Donovan, who coached the Florida mens team to its second consecutive N.C.A.A. title last month, and Pat Summitt, who coached the Tennessee women to their seventh title in her 33 years on the job, received the annual Winged Foot Awards last night at a dinner at the New York Athletic Club. The award is given annually to the coaches of the mens and womens N.C.A.A. basketball champions, and Summitt may return next season. She lost only two seniors, and she kept the 6-foot-4 Candace Parker, probably the best player in the womens game. The Volunteers also have one of the strongest recruiting classes in the nation with Angie Bjorklund, a 6-1 guard-forward from Spokane, Wash.; Kelley Cain, a 6-6 center from Atlanta; Vicki Baugh, a 6-4 forward-center from Sacramento; and Sydney Smallbone, a 6-0 guard from South Bend, Ind. We have a chance to be a very good team next year, Summitt said at a news conference. Donovan, however, said: Were very young. Were starting over. We lose our top six players. Four of those six were underclassmen who have declared for the N.B.A. draft.

title: Clinton Camp Resists Aides Advice to Skip Iowa
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign has considered  and rejected  a plan to stop competing in Iowa, the traditional kickoff state in the nominating process, and to concentrate instead on later states, including the 20 or so that are slated to vote on a single day in early February.

title: F.D.A. to Test Toothpaste Sent to U.S. From China
description: The Food and Drug Administration will begin testing samples of all toothpaste imported into this country from China, a spokesman for the agency said yesterday.

title: Skin, Lycra, Puppets, Hoops ... With, Oh Right, Movement
description: Several things about Moses Pendletons aesthetic leanings are hammered home in Momix reMIX, the 25th-anniversary show of his popular shape-shifting troupe, Momix.

title: Oil Industry Says Biofuel Push May Hurt at Pump
description: Gas prices are spiking again  to an average of $3.22 a gallon, and close to $4 a gallon in many areas.

title: Spitzer Says He Will Start Budget Talks 60 Days Early
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer said yesterday that he would start negotiations over next years budget in November, two months earlier than is traditional in Albany, arguing that an early start would allow more of the talks to be public and minimize the last-minute horse trading that has hampered the budget process in the past.

title: Love, Money and Clothes
description: WHO is Jorge Yarur Bascun and what does he want with Madonnas bra?

title: Fannie Lee Chaney, 84, Mother of Slain Civil Rights Worker, Is Dead
description: Fannie Lee Chaney, a $28-a-week bakery worker who became a target of racial hatred herself after her son James Chaney and two other civil rights workers were killed by the Ku Klux Klan in Mississippi during the Freedom Summer of 1964, died on Tuesday in Willingboro, N.J. She was 84.

title: Fatah and Hamas Chiefs Meet on Cease-Fire
description: TEL AVIV, May 23  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, met privately Tuesday night with Prime Minister Ismail Haniya of Hamas to try to secure a cease-fire between their factions and to discuss how to calm an escalating conflict with Israel, Mr. Haniyas spokesman said Wednesday.

title: Sunni Clashes With Al Qaeda Escalate
description: BAGHDAD, May 24  The growing confrontation between tribal leaders in Anbar Province and Al Qaeda took a violent turn on Thursday when a suicide bomber drove into a crowd gathering for a funeral procession in the volatile city of Falluja, killing at least 27 people and wounding dozens of others.

title: Saying Cubas Pain Is Ignored, a Mayor Blocks a Cuban Parade
description: WEST NEW YORK, N.J., May 22  For decades, a few small towns wedged into a sliver of northern New Jersey have been a locus of Cuban-American culture. The main commercial strip, Bergenline Avenue, bisects West New York and three other communities. It is an avenue of roasted pork and live-chicken shops, of men in long T-shirts and large jewelry, of elderly men who still want to overthrow Fidel Castro. It is an avenue filled with thumping salsa music coming from low-slung cars.

title: Kiplagat Will Race in New York
description: Lornah Kiplagat of the Netherlands, who has won the New York Mini 10-kilometer run in Central Park three times, will return for this years race June 9. The New York Road Runners also announced yesterday that the field would include such world-class runners as Catherine Ndereba of Kenya, Benita Johnson of Australia, Mara Yamauchi of Britain and Nina Rillstone of New Zealand.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Tuesday about the historian Eugen Weber, a leading authority on modern France, referred incorrectly to his book La Fin des Terroirs. The book (its full title is La Fin des Terroirs: La Modernisation de la France Rurale  1870-1914) is a French translation of Mr. Webers book Peasants Into Frenchmen: the Modernization of Rural France  1870-1914. It is not a separate book.

title: Rumbles Under Your Boots
description: Since it erupted in 2004, Mount St. Helens has been largely closed to all but volcanologists. But this summer, the now sleeping giant is open to anyone with enough enthusiasm to climb it  and enough good sense to reserve a spot well in advance. From now through October, only 100 hikers per day are allowed on Mount St. Helens; permits are available online only  and on a first-come, first-served basis  for $22. The route takes from seven-to-12 hours round-trip, and gains 4,500 feet over five miles to the 8,365-foot high crater rim, into which climbers can peer. Though the hike requires no ropes or crampons, expect to wear hard hats and dust masks, as the mountain still belches. You can hike on your own (with a permit) or with a guide; Oregon Peak Adventures offers day trips from $150 per person, including permits, transportation and food.

title: 12 Serbs Guilty in Killing of Prime Minister
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo, May 23  A Serbian court on Wednesday found two former paramilitary police officers guilty of the assassination of Zoran Djindjic, the pro-reform prime minister who was gunned down in Belgrade in March 2003.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about a federal civil rights lawsuit charging that the New York Fire Departments entrance exam is biased against blacks and Hispanics misstated the percentage of black and Hispanic firefighters in the fire department of another large city, Philadelphia. It is 31 percent, not more than 40 percent. (The New York department is 4.5 percent Hispanic and 3 percent black.)

title: An Assault on Hawaii. On Grammar Too.
description: December 8, 1941, is not normally known as a date which will live in infamy. That phrase of President Franklin D. Roosevelts usually refers to the preceding day, on which the American Naval fleet at Pearl Harbor was savaged by a surprise Japanese air raid. But Pearl Harbor, the war novel that is Newt Gingrich and William R. Forstchens latest foray into what they call active history, deliberately calls attention to the fact that Japan and Hawaii were on different sides of the International Date Line.

title: Yanks Make a Dent as Pettitte Finds Support
description: The Yankees best chance to significantly dent the American League East standings this week would have been to sweep the Boston Red Sox. That did not happen, because the teams split the first two games of their three-game series.

title: Snubbed by U.S., China Finds New Space Partners
description: BEIJING, May 23  For years, China has chafed at efforts by the United States to exclude it from full membership in the worlds elite space club. So lately China seems to have hit on a solution: create a new club.

title: 10 Horses Die in a Barn Fire in Rockland
description: CHESTNUT RIDGE, N.Y., May 23  Awakened by her daughter after midnight, the owner of Shamrock Farms here ran to her burning barn in her pajamas in time to lead two horses to safety, but, the authorities said, the heat was too intense for her to go back to rescue eight ponies and two horses trapped inside.

title: Paulson Cites Limited Progress in China Talks
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. and a team of Cabinet members concluded two days of talks with Chinese leaders today with agreements on limited steps to open Chinese markets but little apparent progress on the more significant disputes over trade and currency.

title: Irish Vote on 3rd Term for Prime Minister
description: DUBLIN, May 24  The Irish voted today on whether Prime Minister Bertie Ahern would receive a third successive term after 10 years in office.

title: Excerpts From Former Justice Dept. Aides Statement on Attorney Firings
description: Following are excerpts from the statement by Monica M. Goodling, former Justice Department counsel and White House liaison aide, and answers to questions by Representatives F. James Sensenbrenner Jr. and Elton Gallegly to the House Judiciary Committee yesterday, as recorded by the Federal News Service Inc.:

title: 2-Way G.P.S.: Psst! Here I Am, 2 Miles West of Your Position
description: Any satellite mapping system can tell you where you are. With a Garmin Rino two-way radio, you can tell other Rino users where you are  and then show them.

title: China Talks Dont Resolve Major Issues
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. and a team of cabinet members unveiled limited accords Wednesday with their Chinese counterparts to open markets in China but made little progress on major disputes over trade and currency.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the health care industrys perception of Michael Moores new movie, Sicko, misstated the educational affiliation of Elizabeth Teisberg, the co-author of a recent book, Redefining Health Care. She is an associate professor at the Darden School of Business at the University of Virginia, not an economist at Stanford University.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q.Im tired of granite countertops. What are some alternatives?

title: New Jersey Man Is Accused as Organized Crime Leader
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., May 23  From his base on a work site underneath the Goethals Bridge, a member of the Gambino crime family gained influence in the affairs of two state unions, ran gambling rings in northern New Jersey and New York and collected a salary from a no-show construction job, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Bill Evans Plus Flamenco Equals Something Else Again
description: Nio Josele, the young Gitano guitarist, is playing Bill Evans music at the Village Vanguard this week  that pianists own compositions, as well as songs by others that Evans brushed up against at various points between the 1950s and the 1970s. But because Nio Josele (born Juan Jos Heredia) is a flamenco musician with only a recent interest in jazz, the tunes were redesigned to suit his strength and temperament. The best parts of the set werent much like flamenco, and they werent much like jazz either. And this was very good.

title: Canada: Youth Shot and Killed at Toronto School
description: A 14-year-old student was killed in a high school shooting in north Toronto, the police said. Students and teachers were locked in classrooms for hours while the police searched for a suspect, but no arrests were immediately made. The police released few other details. The last school shooting in Canada was in September, when a gunman entered a Montreal junior college and killed one student and wounded 19 others before he died from police gunfire.

title: Giambi Meets Baseball Officials Over Steroids
description: Jason Giambi was still wearing a Yankees uniform last night, he was still their designated hitter and he was still immersed in a maelstrom about what he might or might not have put into his muscular body to help him as a player.

title: Pierre-Gilles de Gennes, Nobel Prize Winner in Physics, Dies at 74
description: Pierre-Gilles de Gennes, who received the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1991 for studying the boundary lines between order and disorder in materials like liquid crystals and polymers, died Friday in Orsay, a Paris suburb. He was 74.

title: When the King Takes the Lead
description: In the old days an opening king-lead against a suit contract could have been from a suit headed by the ace-king or king-queen. If an ace was led, it was known to be unsupported (not have the king behind it).

title: Calendar
description: Contemporary Design

title: A Japanese Export: Talent
description: HSINCHU, Taiwan  One of the hottest exports from Japan these days isnt video games or eco-friendly cars.

title: Japan: Export Growth Slows
description: Export growth slowed in April as shipments to the United States fell for the first time in more than two years. Exports overall grew 8.3 percent, slowing from 10.3 percent growth in March, the Ministry of Finance said in a report. Shipments to the United States fell 4.8 percent, after growing 2.4 percent the previous month. The slowest growth in four years in the United States, destination of a fifth of Japanese exports, led to reduced demand for automobiles and electronics. Japans trade surplus in April rose 51.8 percent, to 926.7 billion yen ($7.6 billion).

title: No. 2 Senate Republican Calls for Passage of Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  The No. 2 Republican in the Senate made an all-out pitch for support of a comprehensive immigration bill on Wednesday as the Senate voted to reduce the size of a proposed guest worker program, infuriating employers.

title: We Dont Need No Stinking Jet Set
description: Velvet Revolver is starting to look like a band of preservationists. At the Nokia Theater on Tuesday night the musicians arrived onstage as carefully costumed as any Civil War re-enactors. Scott Weiland, the lead singer, had his policeman-chauffeur hat, sunglasses, open jacket over a bare chest, studded belt and skintight pants. Slash, on guitar, had his Mad Hatter hat, shoulder-length curls, darker sunglasses and black T-shirt complete with four-letter word. To no ones surprise the jacket, and later the T-shirt, came off.

title: Arizona Teenager Wins American Idol
description: Jordin Sparks, a teenager from Glendale, Ariz., won the sixth American Idol singing contest last night in a live finale from Los Angeles.

title: H.P. Is Faulted Over Disclosure
description: Hewlett-Packard, the printer and personal computer manufacturer, broke federal laws when it did not tell investors why a director had abruptly resigned during an inquiry into boardroom leaks last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.

title: Sex and the Mall
description: AS Carrie Bradshaw in Sex and the City, Sarah Jessica Parker flaunted her style sense  and coy sexuality  making Manolo mules, skimpy tanks and ballerina skirts must-haves for aspiring fashion divas. Now Ms. Parker joins Madonna and Kate Moss, among others, as the latest media star to affix her name to a cheap-chic fashion brand.

title: With a Wink, Sprouting Styles From the Heart
description: Medusa desperately wants a cha-cha partner in one of the songs Vinicio Capossela performed at Joes Pub on Tuesday night, but of course theres the petrification problem. Touch but dont look is a good rule to learn/Let me embrace you, she urges. Mr. Capossela wore a golden Medusa mask as he sang, but a smile was doubtless behind it.

title: For Some Participants in Fleet Week, Its a Homecoming
description: Bill Delmar was 15 and living on Staten Island in 1992 when he joined Navy sailors and marines as part of a color guard during Fleet Week, the annual visit to New York City by sailors and other members of the armed services. The service members made a lasting impression.

title: U.S. Opposition to Iraq War at All-Time High, Poll Shows
description: Americans now view the war in Iraq more negatively than at any time since the war began, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Sarkozy Visits Brussels, Signaling Import of European Union Revival
description: PARIS, May 23  President Nicolas Sarkozy of France paid his first official visit to Brussels on Wednesday, signaling that a swift end to the European Unions institutional paralysis was high on his priority list.

title: Dow Jones Management: A Record of Success (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Says Iraq Pullout Would Leave U.S. at Risk
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., May 23  President Bush, addressing head-on the criticism that Iraq has turned into another Vietnam, argued Wednesday that withdrawing from Iraq would be dangerous because, unlike the enemy in Vietnam, terrorists in Iraq had the ability and desire to strike Americans at home.

title: Insurers Agree to Pay Billions at Ground Zero
description: The Spitzer administration announced the settlement of all insurance claims at ground zero yesterday, ensuring that $4.55 billion will be available for rebuilding the World Trade Center site.

title: Delays by Airlines Rise, but F.A.A. Is Hopeful
description: HERNDON, Va., May 23  Last summer was the worst in history for airline delays, and so far 2007 looks worse, Federal Aviation Administration officials said Wednesday. But government officials and airline executives said they hoped weather delays could be minimized by software innovations.

title: A Slimmed-Down Smartphone Thats Not a Lightweight
description: Like Hollywood starlets, smartphones are becoming thinner and thinner. If the original Palm Treo was like the curvaceous Jayne Mansfield, the 755p, with service from Sprint, is more Kirsten Dunst.

title: Graft Mars the Recruitment of Mexican Guest Workers
description: TAMPAMOLN CORONA, Mexico  Cstulo Benavides, a union organizer, came to this forgotten mountain town to tell its men how to get legal jobs in the tobacco fields of North Carolina.

title: Low Pay May Further Hurt Police Recruiting, Officials Warn
description: The chief of personnel for New York Citys Police Department warned yesterday that there might be even fewer recruits for the Police Academy class in January than there are for this summers already diminished class because of the low starting pay.

title: Indoor Cycling Finds Its Way Back With Proper Training
description: IF imitation is a form of flattery, then Spinning  the trademarked indoor cycling workout created by an endurance athlete named Johnny G  has many admirers. These days, any health club worth its sweat offers cycling classes, which entail adding resistance to recreate hills or a blast of wind.

title: For Hot Cafes and Very Cool Offices
description: IT must be amusing to men in places where strict suit-and-tie dress codes do not hold sway to see the urban male tangled up in fashion knots over a simple question. Should you wear shorts to work in the summer?

title: In a Joyless Time, a City Still Savors Its Sweet Old Self
description: CAIRO, Egypt  There appears to be a particular way to drink sugar cane juice. Standing outside the most popular sugar cane shop in Cairo, customers carefully hold the tall, slim glass between thumb and forefinger, examine the milky green liquid as though eyeing something valuable, then chug it down.

title: Witness for the Prosecutors
description: It would have been nave to think that Monica Goodling, a right-wing true believer and onetime Republican opposition researcher, was going to blow the whistle on the United States attorney scandal. But Ms. Goodling made some disturbing admissions yesterday, even as she strained to present every fact in the most favorable light to her Bush administration allies and claimed convenient memory lapses. Ms. Goodling admitted to politicizing the Justice Department in ways that certainly seem illegal; she made clear that Attorney General Alberto Gonzales lied at a critical point in the investigation; and she gave Congress all the reason it needs to compel Karl Rove and Harriet Miers, the former White House counsel, to testify about what they know.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 9 P.M. (VH1) VH1 ROCK HONORS We salute you! In its second year this awards ceremony honors the golden oldies Genesis; Heart; Ozzy Osbourne, right; and ZZ Top, who prove its not over yet in performances at the Mandalay Bay Resort in Las Vegas. Alice in Chains, Queens of the Stone Age, Keane, Nickelback and Gretchen Wilson pay tribute in renditions of the honorees hits. Bam Margera of Jackass infamy is host.

title: Implants Are Back, and So Is Debate
description: WITH silicone breast implants back on the market, a debate over follow-up care is roiling the plastic surgery community, even as more women are choosing to have their breasts surgically enlarged.

title: Dear France, Thanks for Being You. With Gratitude and Affection, the Rest of Us.
description: CANNES, France, May 23  It may not seem surprising that the leading French film festival should feature a number of movies that show France in a flattering light, but the cinematic love letters to the country popping up on Cannes screens this year are not self-addressed billets-doux, even though high self-regard is a longstanding Gallic tradition. Given that a theme of the recent French presidential election was a perceived national identity crisis, it is possible to imagine the present cluster of pro-French movies by non-French directors as a kind of friendly reassurance. Hey, these filmmakers seem to be saying, dont be so down on yourselves. We love you.

title: Suicide Attack and a Bombing Kill 4 and Wound 7 in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 23  Two explosions, one a suicide attack, killed four people and wounded seven on Wednesday, NATO and Afghan officials said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A White House Memo article on Friday, about the last joint appearance by President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain at the White House, misstated the name of the medal Mr. Blair was awarded in 2003. It was the Congressional Gold Medal, not the Congressional Medal of Honor.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A schedule note in The Arts on Tuesday with a music review of the pianist Ursula Oppens, at Arium on Little West 12th Street in the West Village, included outdated information from Arium about the next performance there. The recital by Julia Sakharova, violinist, and Natalia Lavrova, pianist, will take place at a date to be determined  not Sunday. The next concert at Arium will be on June 3, with the cellist Diliana Momtchilova and the pianist Vassily Primakov.

title: A Musical Team of Phone and Speakers, Brought Together by Bluetooth
description: As owners of iPods and other music players often discover, its nice to have speakers for the players so that headphones arent needed all the time. But what if your songs are on your phone?

title: Years Ago, Agency Was Warned of a Drugs Risks
description: A leading diabetes doctor sent the Food and Drug Administration a letter seven years ago that warned of the heart risks of the drug Avandia. And in the next year, the F.D.A. reprimanded the drugs maker for playing down safety concerns, according to documents from 2000 and 2001.

title: Body Found in Iraq May Be  That of Missing G.I.
description: MAHMUDIYA, Iraq, May 23  The American military started examining a body found in the Euphrates River on Wednesday that Iraqi authorities and local residents believe is one of three American soldiers seized in an ambush on May 12.

title: Early Cocktail-Hour Pizazz, From Other Side of the Bar
description: It was noon yesterday, far from the cocktail hour. The assignment was the second annual cocktail throwdown, The Sidewalk Caf Drink Mix-Off.

title: Canada: Alcoa Stands by Bid
description: The aluminum producer Alcoa said in a statement that it would continue to pursue its $27.4 billion cash and stock bid for a rival, Alcan, despite the Canadian companys rejection of the offer. But Alcoas chairman and chief executive, Alain J. P. Belda, said that the company would not enhance the proposal, which Alcan called inadequate. We have studied Alcans response and have not seen anything that would lead us to re-evaluate our offer, Mr. Belda said. He also rejected suggestions by Alcan that Alcoa would have difficulty obtaining antitrust approval for the merger and urged Alcans board to resume its examination of the bid.

title: Big Law Firm Wont Face Criminal Charges in Tax Case
description: A ruling by a federal appeals court yesterday could jeopardize a criminal case against former employees of the accounting firm KPMG  a case that has been cited by prosecutors as the showpiece of a broad investigation into the sale of questionable tax shelters that helped wealthy investors evade billions of dollars in taxes.

title: The Damage Is Done by the Time Schilling Settles In
description: After three batters, the Yankees had a three-run lead over Curt Schilling and it helped carry them to an 8-3 victory against Boston last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: Hispanic Hopeful for 08 Confronts Immigration
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  Of all the candidates running for president, none have weathered more crosscurrents of the immigration battle than Gov. Bill Richardson, the New Mexico Democrat.

title: Celebrating Silent Comedy With a Lot of Loud Effects
description: Anarchy reigns supreme at the New Victory Theater.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Cannes to See Film on Poisoned K.G.B. Agent

title: Limits on Roaming Charges
description: The European Parliament voted to impose retail price caps on roaming charges, fees that mobile phone consumers pay when making or receiving calls outside of their home calling zones. The European Council of Ministers, which has already endorsed the plan, is scheduled to approve the price caps formally June 7. As early as August, the charges will be limited to 0.49 euro (66 cents) a minute for outgoing calls and 0.24 euro for incoming calls, excluding tax.

title: New Hampshire Panel Rejects Seat-Belt Law
description: BOSTON, May 23  An effort to end New Hampshires status as the only state in the country without a law requiring adults to wear seat belts suffered a setback on Wednesday, when the State Senate transportation committee recommended that it not pass.

title: Randolph Slides Delgado Down in the Batting Order
description: ATLANTA, May 23  In what has been a season of unfamiliar struggles, Carlos Delgado fell to an unfamiliar spot in the lineup. Manager Willie Randolph dropped Delgado to sixth from his customary cleanup spot for Wednesdays game against the Braves.

title: Cellphone Banking Is Coming of Age
description: YOURE starting a two-week vacation far from home when you suddenly realize you left the mortgage payment on the kitchen table instead of mailing it on the way to the airport. Or perhaps youre standing in the checkout line of a store, poised to make a debit card payment, but you cant remember if you have enough money in your account to avoid expensive overdraft charges.

title: Queens: Man Convicted of 1999 Rape
description: A Far Rockaway man has been convicted of raping a woman in 1999 after a sample of his DNA, taken in an unrelated case, matched a sample from the crime, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Santiago Lugo, 45, of Beach 32nd Street, was convicted of rape in State Supreme Court on Tuesday, prosecutors said. Mr. Lugo, a former salesman, grabbed a 23-year-old woman as she walked home from work on the night of March 3, 1999, forcing her to accompany him to an isolated spot and raping her, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about a $3.5 billion development planned for Stamford, Conn., that is part of the citys efforts to remain a financial center in the New York region misstated ridership statistics for the Metro-North Railroad. Because of the rise of Stamford and other suburban cities as corporate hubs, Grand Central Terminal is now the final destination of fewer than half the riders at all times  not those on weekday mornings. (During the morning rush, the final destination of most riders is still Grand Central.)

title: Note to Readers
description: WHEN Michelle Slatalla began writing the Online Shopper column seven years ago, the Internet was a relative novelty and shopping was the beachhead for many users. Now almost every chapter of family life has an online component. In the Slatalla household, husband and wife live in I.M. windows on each others screens. The family stores its photos, vacation itineraries and tax records online. Their youngest daughter, 9, cavorts with friends in the virtual universe Club Penguin. Their oldest, 18, has been offered a summer job thanks to videos she posted on YouTube. Starting today, Ms. Slatallas column is acquiring a new name, Cyberfamilias, and a broader scope: the changing landscape of family life under the influence of the Net. It will appear every other week.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Thursday about concerns in Congress over broadcasts of Islamic militant views by Al Hurra, an American government-financed television network in the Middle East, referred incorrectly to the timing of the appointment of the networks new vice president for news, Larry Register. Mr. Register was already on the job when Al Hurra broadcast a speech by Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, in December; he was not hired to make sure such broadcasts did not recur. The article also misstated the length of Sheik Nasrallahs broadcast speech; it was 67 minutes, not 30 minutes. (Go to Article)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article Tuesday about Steel Winds, a wind farm rising on a former toxic waste site in the Rust Belt city of Lackawanna, N.Y., included incorrect information from the project manager about the power capacity of the eight wind turbines that have been built so far. They can produce 56,000 megawatt-hours of electricity per year, not 20 megawatts per year.

title: Michigan: State Sends Out Layoff Notices
description: Michigan, which is trying to close an $803 million deficit in this years budget, has informed state employee labor unions of possible layoffs, a spokeswoman for Gov. Jennifer M. Granholm said. The state has 53,000 employees, with 38,058 represented by unions, the spokeswoman said.

title: A New Spin on the Ball
description: Kelly Kulick, the pioneering bowler-turned-action hero, was pushed backward over a ball return. She would not be dismissed so easily, however, just one place where truth met fiction. She smacked the villainess, Miss Arrow, on the shoulder with a bowling pin. Spiders spilled from the wound. An arachnid shower poured from Miss Arrows mouth.

title: Britain Tracks 3 Who Fled in Terror Case
description: LONDON, May 23  Britains counterterrorism police on Wednesday took the highly unusual step of issuing a public appeal for information about three terrorism suspects said to have absconded from a form of house arrest known as control orders.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Leaping Lilies

title: Lottery Numbers
Madison Avenue Says Hello to Hello, Again
description: IT seems as if Madison Avenue is on some kind of a Hi.

title: Committed to Truth and Justice, and the Pursuit of a Good Time
description: Innocent, the new legal drama on BBC America tonight, makes a fairly good case for the idea that British lawyers simply have a lot more fun than their counterparts here. We may stereotype them as stuffy and austere, but au contraire, au contraire. Not a single one of them seems to go home at night and read Sir William Blackstone  no references to Of Estates in Severalty, Joint-Tenancy, Coparcenary and Common here.

title: Study Sheds Light on College Injuries
description: How do college athletes hurt themselves? For 25 years, researchers with the N.C.A.A. have quietly been compiling data on that subject. This week, with the publication of a special issue of the Journal of Athletic Training, the information is being made public for the first time. Some of the findings are predictable: college baseball players get banged up while sliding, and basketball often causes ankle and knee injuries. But others are eye-opening: female ice hockey players, for instance, sustain almost as many concussions as men, even though they (supposedly) arent allowed to body check.This report should lead to investigations of rule changes or equipment modifications that would increase player safety, says Randall W. Dick, associate director of research for the N.C.A.A. In the meantime, it makes for revelatory, if wince-inducing reading, with its repeated descriptions of sprains, strains, concussions, "acute, traumatic knee injuries," and perhaps most memorably, a call for improved mat hygiene to reduce the incidence of wrestlers skin infections.

title: On Health Care, a Can-Do Attitude (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: For the First Time, New York Links a Death to 9/11 Dust
description: New York Citys chief medical examiner, Dr. Charles S. Hirsch, has for the first time directly linked a death to exposure to dust from the destruction of the World Trade Center.

title: One Bomb, 25 Operations and 363 Days to Return to TV
description: When Kimberly Dozier, a CBS News correspondent, was nearly killed last Memorial Day by a roadside bomb in Baghdad that took the lives of her crew, she became the story instead of reporting it. Now, more than 25 operations later, Ms. Dozier is finally telling her own story, which will be a core part of Flashpoint, a CBS special to be broadcast on Tuesday night about the many lives transformed that day.

title: My Aching, Aging Feet! (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Writer Is Convicted in Sex Attack on Former Colleague
description: Peter Braunstein, a former fashion writer with a bitter grudge against the industry, was convicted yesterday of kidnapping and sexually abusing a woman he barely knew after posing as a firefighter to gain entrance to her Chelsea apartment and tying her to her bed.

title: Hard Drive Shifts Movie Viewing From the Desk to the Couch
description: Watching digital movies stored on a computers hard drive on a TV set is still a relatively new idea, which is why hybrid products like the TrekStor MovieStation maxi t.u are popping up. This external hard drive with a built-in audio and video player puts the best of many technologies into one package.

title: And the Choice of the Judges Was ...
description: THE guests of House & Home were not the only ones assessing the work on display at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair. As usual, a panel of design magazine editors  this year there were 11, from Britain, France, Italy, Canada and the United States  gave out their own awards. (Interestingly, there was little overlap between their picks and those of the impromptu critics.) At right, from top to bottom, are some of the winners of the 2007 Editors Awards.

title: Canada: Cerberus Plans Bell Bid
description: BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, the largest communications company in Canada, said that a group led by Cerberus Capital had joined the bidding for the company. While the other investors were not identified, they will be vital to any deal because Canadian law bans foreign control of telephone companies. Three groups are now vying to take BCE private. BCEs largest shareholder, the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, has allied itself with other institutional investors for a possible bid. The Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts have formed a rival group that may make a bid potentially worth about $45 billion.

title: A Design Store to Love, if It Will Have You
description: I FELT a considerable ache when I entered the Future Perfect, the up-to-the-moment furniture and design store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Silence hovered over the bright white-walled space, which though crowded with delicious objects, still managed to look immaculate and spare.

title: On War Funds, Democrats Saw No Option but to Cede Ground to Bush
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  Congressional contortions over the Iraq spending bill could end up with most House Democrats momentarily occupying the position they were so desperate to vacate: the minority.

title: Back to the Bounding Main
description: The immaterial has become material, announces the East India Companys scheming Lord Beckett (Tom Hollander) early in Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End. He could be referring to the recent resurrection of the pirate Barbossa (Geoffrey Rush), flush with life and his expanded role in the trilogy. Or he could be speaking of his newfound dominion over the Flying Dutchman and its squid-faced captain, Davy Jones (Bill Nighy), whose excavated heart is now in Becketts possession.

title: Carbon Dioxide Emissions Down
description: Emissions of carbon dioxide from fuel burned in the United States dropped 1.3 percent in 2006 compared with an all-time peak reached the year before, according to preliminary data from the Energy Department. The United States remains the leading source of the carbon dioxide, the main emission linked to global warming. The White House quickly hailed the downturn, even in the face of economic growth, as evidence that President Bushs policies for slowing growth in emissions without a mandatory cap were working. Some scientists and private environmental groups noted that the cause, according to the government, was mainly moderate weather and high prices for oil, natural gas and electricity. Over all, emissions were up 17.9 percent since 1990.

title: William Peters, 85, Journalist Who Examined Race in U.S., Dies
description: William Peters, a journalist and award-winning documentary film producer who chronicled American race relations during the turbulent years of the mid-20th century, died on Sunday in Boulder, Colo. He was 85. A resident of Lafayette, Colo., Mr. Peters had lived for many years in Guilford, Conn.

title: Giving Juvenile Offenders a Chance
description: The Connecticut State Senate set a welcome national example this week when it passed a bill that would move 16- and 17-year-old offenders out of the adult courts and back into the juvenile justice system where they belong. Connecticuts House should move quickly to approve the legislation, which would rescue thousands of young people from being trapped in an adult system that, far from reforming them, too often turns them into hardened criminals.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Majority Favor Changing Immigration Laws, Poll Says
description: As opponents from the right and left challenge an immigration bill before Congress, there is broad support among Americans  Democrats, Republicans and independents alike  for the major provisions in the legislation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Adam and Eve in the Land of the Dinosaurs
description: PETERSBURG, Ky.  The entrance gates here are topped with metallic Stegosauruses. The grounds include a giant tyrannosaur standing amid the trees, and a stone-lined lobby sports varied sauropods. It could be like any other natural history museum, luring families with the promise of immense fossils and dinosaur adventures.

title: Killing the Russian Media
description: Journalists from around the world who will gather in Moscow next week are poised to stand up for their colleagues in a country where journalism and journalists are increasingly under attack. The 1,000 media representatives plan to establish a commission to finally investigate the growing number of unsolved murders of journalists in Vladimir Putins Russia.

title: Be Kind to Our Whistle-Blower Friends
description: The most endangered species inside the Washington Beltway is the federal worker who dares to disclose waste and mismanagement by government superiors. The vulnerability of the workers is palpable lately at the Commerce Department, where the inspector general  who is charged with protecting, not silencing, whistle-blowers  was found taking vengeance on two subordinates who dared to question his expense accounts. The Washington Post reports an independent investigation concluded the inspector general, Johnnie Frazier, committed egregious violations by reassigning his top deputy and counsel to peripheral jobs after they refused to sign off on expensive trips and office renovations.

title: Visits to Doctors Who Are Not in, Ever
description: MY children have in recent weeks decided that they have leprosy, irritable bowel syndrome and Lyme disease.

title: Ex-Justice Aide Admits Politics Affected Hiring
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  A former top Justice Department aide testified on Wednesday that she had crossed the line in considering the political beliefs of applicants for nonpartisan legal jobs and suggested that earlier testimony by Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales and another top official about the dismissals of federal prosecutors may have been flawed.

title: SUNY Names Interim Chancellor
description: The State University of New York has nominated John B. Clark to be the interim chancellor of its 64-campus system starting June 1. John R. Ryan, the current chancellor, announced in March that he would leave at the end of this month to head a small nonprofit organization in North Carolina.

title: New Yorks Schools for Pregnant Girls Will Close
description: A dozen girls, some perched awkwardly with their pregnant bellies flush against the desks, were struggling over a high school geometry assignment on a recent afternoon.

title: Clemens Hits Potholes in Road Back to Majors
description: TRENTON, May 23  Roger Clemenss route back to the Yankees was a rocky one Wednesday night. Pitching for the Trenton Thunder, the Yankees Class AA affiliate, Clemens was rusty and wild in an appearance that did not suggest he was immediately ready to jump to the major leagues.

title: How to Make Your Cellphone Act Like a BlackBerry
description: When you whip out a BlackBerry or a Treo in public, what does it say about you?

title: Torre Has Earned Right to Stay in Pinstripes
description: Even with the Yankees 8-3 triumph over the Red Sox last night, its only a matter of the next losing streak until another proclamation of Steinbrenner Support for Joe Torre is heard.

title: ...And Do You Take This (Buff) Woman?
description: EVEN bargain-hunting couples often end up paying retail for a wedding: Designer dresses rarely go on sale and there are no coupons for hand-calligraphy invitations. But determined brides have found one way to cut corners. Instead of signing up for bridal boot camps or grueling-but-pricey private sessions before the big day, these women aim to get in shape for less than $20.

title: Keeping Time in Cool Comfort
description: UNBEKNOWN to many, Serge Gainsbourg, the seminal French singer and style icon, had sensitive feet. Boots hurt him. He hated walking. His only salvation was calfskin jazz shoes made by Repetto, the French dance shoe company. Jane Birkin, then his lover, turned him on to the supple shoes in the early 70s. Serge was looking for gloves for his feet, she told Les Inrockuptibles, the French music magazine. Originally designed by Rose Repetto for her daughter-in-law, the ballet dancer Zizi Jeanmaire, the lace-up shoes served Gainsbourg well. According to Repetto lore, he went through 30 pairs a year  always in white  until his death in 1991.

title: Rodriguez Continues to Stoke Heated Rivalry
description: Before the final game of a three-game series between the Red Sox and the Yankees last night, the umpires crew chief, Joe West, quietly met with both teams managers. He apparently did not want an errant elbow to become an on-field controversy.

title: With the Handkerchief, a Hint of Ice Capades
description: Lar Lubovitchs Othello, a full-length ballet from 1997, calls to mind an anguished line from that Shakespeare tragedy: O heavens forfend!

title: Chinese Police Arrest 28 in Riots Against Family Planning Laws
description: BEIJING, May 23  The police in southwestern China arrested 28 people for instigating riots over family planning controls over the weekend, but officials were also dispatched to the affected regions to deal with complaints about the areas strict measures to enforce limits on family size, state news media said Wednesday.

title: Bush Backs Gonzales in Face of  No-Confidence Vote
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  President Bush once more reaffirmed his confidence in Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales today, while Senate Democrats offered a resolution declaring that they have no confidence in him.

title: The Diligent Undertake the Difficult
description: In recent years the International Contemporary Ensemble has proved itself one of the most adventurous and accomplished groups in new music. This 30-member collective, based in Brooklyn and Chicago, has earned a reputation for stylistic eclecticism, taking on modernism and Minimalism with equal gusto while devoting valuable attention to emerging composers. Lately it has also been very busy. From April 25 to May 5 its members took part in nine separate concerts around New York, and then the group presented a four-hour Steve Reich marathon in Chicago.

title: Weather Delays Missile Test
description: Foul weather in Alaska has prompted the Pentagon to delay, until tomorrow at the earliest, a test of the new missile defense system, military officials said. The system can operate in all weather in a wartime environment, but safety rules governing tests require that the target missile, to be launched from Kodiak Island, be visible to monitors who can push a destruct button if it veers off course.

title: Brooklyn: Two Injured in Collapse
description: Police officers pulled two workers from a building that partly collapsed yesterday, police and fire officials said. The workers, whose names were not disclosed by the police, were inside the three-story building, at 51 Woodhull Street in Red Hook, when the second floor collapsed, pushing the first floor into the basement and trapping the workers, the police said. Officers from the Emergency Services Unit entered the building and rescued the workers, who had back and leg injuries. The workers were taken to hospitals, the police said. The Buildings Department said the collapse was caused by demolition work.

title: Dance Thrives Precariously in New York
description: In sheer numbers New York City is without question the center for modern contemporary dance in America, according to a report being released today by the service organization Dance/NYC. But the report also highlights how fragile that status is.

title: Kazakhstan: Criminal Case Against Leaders Son-in-Law
description: The Interior Ministry said it had begun a criminal investigation into allegations that President Nursultan A. Nazarbayevs son-in-law, Rakhat Aliev, left, who is also the ambassador to Austria, kidnapped and beat two officers of the Kazakh bank Nurbank as part of a real estate and stock extortion scheme. Mr. Alievs wife, Dariga Nazarbayeva, is a high-profile member of Parliament often mentioned as a possible successor to her father. Kazakhstan has a highly capitalized banking sector; several of its larger banks recently held lucrative public stock offerings in London.

title: A Programming Language Like Playing With Blocks
description: Scratch is a creativity tool from the M.I.T. Media Lab that turns abstract programming concepts like recursion into snap-together puzzle pieces. It is like a multimedia sandbox, where children 8 and up are welcomed as media producers, following the same philosophical blueprint that inspired software projects like Logo and Squeak.

title: U.S., Annoyed by U.N. Report on Iran and Uranium, Hopes to Use It to Widen Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  The Bush administration said Wednesday that it would use a new report detailing Irans progress in enriching uranium to encourage European and Asian allies to seek a major expansion of sanctions against Tehran, an economic crackdown that could extend beyond what the United Nations Security Council has authorized.

title: Israel Arrests 33 West Bank Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, May 24  The Israeli Army and internal security agency arrested 33 prominent West Bank Palestinians, including a minister, three lawmakers and three mayors, in raids early this morning, army officials said.

title: Pope Concedes Unjustifiable Crimes in Converting South Americans
description: ROME, May 23  Pope Benedict XVI tried Wednesday to quell anger in South America over his recent comments about the conversion of native populations, conceding that unjustifiable crimes were committed in the conquest of the continent 500 years ago.

title: Congress Passes 1st Minimum Wage Boost in a Decade
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Congress handed a major victory to low-income workers by voting tonight to raise the federal minimum wage for the first time in a decade.

title: New Yorks Nurseries Try a Transplant
description: GARDENING in New York City can require the determination of a weed pushing through a sidewalk. There are hardships of space, light, microclimate and wind, not to mention the pain of hauling supplies across town and, frequently, up several flights of stairs. Add to that the shortage of serious garden centers  the kind with space for 50-pound bags of manure, for instance, or heirloom vegetable seedlings  and the challenges of tending a patch of green in a city known more for its grit than its earth can seem overwhelming.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Silverland," "Gaslight" and "Cirkus Inferno."

title: All Across America
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Oil Industry Says Biofuel Push May Keep Gas Prices High
description: Gas prices are spiking again  to an average of $3.22 a gallon, and close to $4 a gallon in many areas  and some oil executives are now warning that the current shortages of fuel could become a long-term problem, leading to stubbornly higher prices at the pump.

title: A real Thai hill tribe village, or is it?
description: For the sake of the tourism industry, the identities of hill tribes living in northern Thailand have been distilled into the singular term long-neck. (Or, for the many French visitors, giraffe women). Taxi drivers and tour operators offer trips to see the long-necks without any other explanation: most cabbies will drive the 30 kilometers north from Chiang Mai, wait an hour for you and drive back to town for about 400-500 baht. (Im sure that visitors who spend more effort than we did can find even better deals.)

title: With Flowers in Their Hair
description: Images from "Summer of Love: Art of the Psychedelic Era" at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: Heights to Broadway
description: Confirming what has essentially been an open secret, the producers of the musical "In the Heights," now playing Off Broadway at the 37 Arts Theater, announced plans for a Broadway transfer next season.

title: Delay of home sales packets draws jeers
description: This weeks announcement that the introduction of Home Information Packs in Britain would be delayed by two months until Aug. 1 has prompted a collective sigh of exasperation today. (See post below for more info)

title: Google lovers
description: Internet addicts are making use of Google maps to meet their every whim  even to track house prices. For example, people are flocking to www.estateangels.co.uk/house_prices, which displays the cheapest and priciest places to buy a house in Britain using heat maps. At the same time, www.londonlandgrab.com allows you to buy your favorite landmark or other property in a virtual London.

title: H.P.s Disclosure About Resignation Fell Short, S.E.C. Says
description: Hewlett-Packard, the computer maker, put to rest one aspect of the spying scandal that rocked its boardroom last year as it settled an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into how it disclosed the resignation of Thomas Perkins, a prominent venture capitalist, from its board. Though the settlement came with no financial or other penalty, the S.E.C. said it found that Hewlett-Packard failed to disclose the reasons for his resignation as required by federal securities laws after Mr. Perkins left the board in May 2006 because of his objection to an internal investigation into leaks to the press. Hewlett consented to an order that it stop violations of disclosure provisions, but did not admit or deny the commissions findings.

title: Amazon Adds Brilliance to Its Stable
description: Amazon.com announced Wednesday its acquisition of an audio-book publisher, Brilliance Audio, in a move to tighten its tie with book publishers and expand the number of audio-book titles it sells. Amazon is seeking to expand beyond offering only best-sellers under an audio-book format. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Britain Said to Consider Sale of Channel 4
description: The British government is considering selling commercial broadcaster Channel 4 to raise up to 1 billion pounds after Gordon Brown becomes prime minister, according to The Times of London. Treasury officials in Britain are weighing economic and political arguments for privatizing the government-owned channel, even though the Labor party manifesto is committed to keeping Channel 4 in public ownership, according to the report.

title: Opposites Attract
description: Life doesnt always imitate art. But sometimes it comes surprisingly close.

title: The Navy and the Marines Dock for Fleet Week
description: American warships moved up New York Harbor to open the city's 20th annual Fleet Week observance, followed by a week of fun in the city for sailors and marines.

title: Third Point Raises Pressure on Biotech Firm
description: The fight between Daniel Loebs hedge fund, Third Point, and PDL BioPharma, a drug development company, escalated this week as Mr. Loeb, known for his poison-pen letters to some of the companies in which he invests, released a letter to unconflicted directors of PDL, urging them to oust L. Patrick Gage, the companys chairman.

title: G.M. Pledges GMAC Stake for $4 Billion Credit Line
description: General Motors has put up a 49 percent stake in its former financial arm as collateral for a $4.1 billion revolving line of credit, the company said late Wednesday. It also announced plans to replace $1.1 billion in convertible securities with new ones with a later maturity date. After the announcement, Fitch Ratings cut its debt rating for G.M. deeper into junk territory, citing increased leverage from new financing efforts. Separately, G.M. said it received a new request from the Securities and Exchange Commission for information about its accounting practices.

title: 8-Year Sentence in Coca-Cola Secrets Case
description: A former secretary at Coca-Cola was sentenced Wednesday to eight years in prison for conspiring to steal trade secrets from the company, as her tearful plea for mercy failed to sway a federal judge. Judge J. Owen Forrester of Federal District Court told the former secretary, Joya Williams, 42, that he was giving her a longer sentence than recommended by federal prosecutors and sentencing guidelines because this is the kind of offense that cannot be tolerated in our society.

title: British Regulators to Examine BSkyB-ITV Deal
description: The British government ordered the countrys competition regulator Thursday to hold a full inquiry into British Sky Broadcastings purchase of a stake in broadcaster ITV. The Associated Press noted that the order for the Competition Commission investigation marks the first major test of the influence held over the British media by Rupert Murdoch, BSkyBs chairman and largest stockholder.

title: Bisys Settles With S.E.C. for $25 Million
description: Bisys Group, a financial-services provider that recently agreed to be acquired by Citigroup, said Wednesday it would pay $25 million to settle regulators accusations that it had violated financial reporting rules to inflate earnings by $180 million over three years. The Securities and Exchange Commission announced the settlement with Bisys, which was consistent with a tentative agreement that the company and the agencys enforcement staff negotiated in November.

title: Qwest Shareholders Reject Proposals on Pay
description: Qwest Communications Internationals shareholders have rejected three proposals that would have given them more influence in decisions about executive compensation. At the companys annual meeting Tuesday, its chief executive, Richard C. Notebaert, was peppered with questions about salaries and bonuses, including his own, and cuts or caps in benefits for about 49,000 retirees across Qwests 14-state territory.

title: As Bidders Circle LaSalle, Rival Bank Sees Upside
description: Harris Bank, Chicagos third-largest bank, reported a 4 percent decline in second-quarter earnings partly as a result of competition. But the bank said it expects takeover upheaval at the citys No. 2 bank, the LaSalle Bank, to help increase its business and said it is already trying to position itself for the inevitable shakeout.

title: Court Rejects Citigroup Appeal, Parmalat Says
description: Parmalat, the Italian food giant that filed for bankruptcy in 2003, said Wednesday that New Jerseys highest court rejected Citigroups attempt to dismiss its $10 billion lawsuit accusing the bank of helping former management commit fraud. Parmalat, a major producer of milk, said the state supreme court rejected Citigroups appeal on the grounds that Parmalat brought the case in the wrong court.

title: Qantas May Sell Assets After Failed Buyout
description: Australias Qantas Airways, recently the target of a failed $9 billion takeover bid, said Thursday it might split off some businesses or return billions of dollars to shareholders. Qantas told investors that as part of a demerger plan it was considering, it was reviewing options for its frequent flyer program and might sell its express freight joint venture and other operations.

title: Will Private Equity Try Again for Circuit City?
description: Circuit City Stores, whose shares are at their lowest level in more than two years, is one of the most-attractive leveraged buyout candidates in the hardline retailing sector, several analysts say. Its stock has fallen below that $17 buyout offer from a Boston hedge fund that Circuit City rejected in 2005.

title: Summertime Blues: Merrill Reins in Sick Days
description: Merrill Lynch employees may be looking a bit paler than usual this summer. That is because the investment bank has slashed the number of sick days that United States employees can take without consequences each year to three days from 40  an amount that had been unusually generous by American standards  apparently in an effort to keep its bankers, traders and other workers from skipping off for long weekends at the Hamptons.

title: Cerberus Plans Bell Canada Bid
description: BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, the largest communications company in Canada, said that a group led by Cerberus Capital Management had joined the bidding for the company. While the other investors were not identified, they will be vital to any deal because Canadian law bans foreign control of telephone companies. Three groups are now vying to take BCE private. BCEs largest shareholder, the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, has allied itself with other institutional investors for a possible bid.

title: Nasdaq Plans Market for VCs
description: The Nasdaq Stock Market plans to offer venture capitalists and other private equity players a new avenue to liquidity when it rolls out a computerized trading platform intended to market private placements to institutional investors, such as mutual funds and pension funds, The Red Herring reported.

title: Bank of Montreal Reports Higher Profit
description: Bank of Montreal said second-quarter profit rose 3 percent as higher fees from mutual funds and stock sales offset a big loss in commodities trading. Net income climbed to 671 million Canadian dollars ($618 million) from 651 million Canadian dollars a year earlier.

title: Alcoa to Continue Pursuit of Alcan
description: Alcoa said that it would continue to pursue its $27.4 billion cash and stock bid for a rival, Alcan, despite the Canadian companys rejection of the offer. But Alcoas chairman and chief executive, Alain J. P. Belda, said that the company would not enhance the proposal, which Alcan called inadequate.

title: Furniture's Best in Show
description: Biker coffee tables, scary pillow and one very comfortable chair all at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair.

title: Rival Bids for EMI Unlikely, Reports Say
description: The private equity firm Corvus Capital, controlled by the financier Andrew Regan, ruled itself out of the running for EMI Group, the British music group, yesterday, following a report in The New York Post that the company was preparing a rival bid in conjunction with a former EMI executive, Jim Fifield.

title: Coca-Cola Keeps Quiet on Rumors of Water Deal
description: Coca-Colas president, Muhtar Kent, declined to comment Wednesday on speculation that the beverage giant might buy Glaceau, a maker of enhanced water drinks, but said his company was open to making acquisitions. There are some rumors in the marketplace always about us acquiring certain companies, Mr. Kent told reporters attending grand opening events in Atlanta for the new World of Coca-Cola attraction. We do not comment on rumor and thats all I can say.

title: Appeals Court Ruling May Endanger Tax Shelter Case
description: A ruling by a federal appeals court yesterday could jeopardize a criminal case against former employees of the accounting firm KPMG  a case that has been cited by prosecutors as the showpiece of a broad investigation into the sale of questionable tax shelters that helped wealthy investors evade billions of dollars in taxes.

title: Google Close to Buying Feedburner, Report  Says
description: Google is closing in on an agreement to acquire Feedburner, a provider of Web content syndication tools, for about $100 million in cash, according to TechCrunch, which cited an unnamed source close to the deal. The technology blog, which first broke the news that Google would buy YouTube, said the Feedburner deal is expected to close in two to three weeks, and that there is nothing that can really derail it at this point. Feedburner, founded in 2003, has raised $10 million in venture capital from Portage Ventures, Mobius Venture Capital and Union Square Ventures.

title: French Regulators Examine EADS Trading
description: French financial regulators are questioning leading executives at European Aeronautic Defense and Space, including the co-chairman, Arnaud Lagardre, as part of an investigation into possible insider trading at the parent company of Airbus, Le Monde reported Wednesday.

title: Senator Urges F.C.C. to Reject Satellite Radio Deal
description: The chairman of the Senates antitrust subcommittee has urged regulators to block Sirius Satellite Radios proposed acquisition of XM Satellite Radio Holdings.

title: Hong Kong I.P.O. Creates 2 New Billionaires
description: The worlds billionaire ranks became a little more crowded on Wednesday with the listing in Hong Kong of Chinas leading retailer of ladies footwear.

title: Duff & Phelps Plans $200 Million I.P.O.
description: Duff & Phelps, a financial advisory firm and investment bank, said it plans to raise up to $200 million in an initial public offering of stock on the New York Stock Exchange. The New York-based firm has grown through a series of acquisitions in recent years, including the purchase of Standard & Poors Corporate Value Consulting business in 2005 and Chanin Capital Partners, a boutique investment bank with a large restructuring practice, in 2006.

title: S.E.C. Revises Its Standards for Corporate Audits
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved new guidelines on Wednesday that try to balance the need for tighter financial controls with the cost of complying with them. It said the new procedures will make it less costly for smaller companies to assess the state of their internal financial controls.

title: Biodiesel Company to Go Public
description: Imperium Renewables, a Seattle-based biodiesel company, is seeking to raise up to $345 million from a public stock offering to finance a major expansion into the fast-growing alternative-energy market.

title: 2008: Immigration and Race
description: Bill Richardson, the governor of a heavily Hispanic state who would be the first Hispanic to serve in the White House if elected, is the first Democratic candidate to come out against the new immigration bill in the Senate, but hes reticent to be defined by the issue. The Timess Adam Nagourney takes a serious look at the New Mexicans history on the matter and where he stands today:

title: Creepy Crawly Conspiracies
description: There was a time when Ashley Judd seemed poised to take on if not great roles, then at least interesting ones. Her 1993 breakthrough in the delicate drama "Ruby in Paradise" suggested that she could go far in films that called for vulnerable young women with steely underpinnings. Instead she strayed into mediocre thrillers ("Kiss the Girls," "High Crimes") that not even Morgan Freeman's dignified presence could salvage.

title: Bancroft Family Member Opposes Dow Jones Sale
description: A Dow Jones & Company director, Christopher Bancroft, an influential member of the family that controls the publishing company, said in an interview that he opposes a sale to Rupert Murdochs News Corporation. His comments to The Wall Street Journal, which is owned by Dow Jones, came after some members of the Bancroft family met Wednesday in Boston to consider the $5 billion offer.

title: Manhattan vs. the Other Boroughs?
description: Congestion pricing is strongly supported by most Manhattan voters and opposed in roughly equal measure by voters in New York Citys four other boroughs, according to results of a survey of city voters that Quinnipiac University released this morning.
