description: Is a bidding war looming for Bausch & Lomb?

title: Merrill Takes a Stake in Sterling Stamos
description: The brokerage firm Merrill Lynch & Company said Thursday it would take a non-controlling stake in a private investment firm, Sterling Stamos Capital Management. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Finding a Family-Sized Apartment in Rome
description: My brothers family is planning a trip to Rome this summer and they are on a budget. Do you know of any reasonably-priced apartments they might be able to rent, in a fairly central location? Thanks.

title: The Highest Per-Pupil Spending in the U.S.
description: New York State spent $14,119 per student  more than any other state in the nation  in the 2005 fiscal year, according to a national analysis of public school spending that the Census Bureau released today.

title: Toronto Dominions Second Quarter Profit Up 19 Percent
description: The Toronto-Dominion Bank said Thursday its profit rose 19 percent in the second quarter, helped by a strong performance in all business lines except its retail banking in the United States. Toronto Dominion said it earned 879 million Canadian dollars ($814 million), or 1.20 Canadian dollars a share, up from 738 million Canadian dollars, or 1.01 Canadian dollars a share, a year earlier.

title: Banking on the Democrats
description: Whos going to be the big winner in the 08 presidential election? Your bank account  if you follow Greg Mankiws advice, that is. A reader tipped Mankiw off to the fact that for the 2008 elections, [TradeSports.coms Intrade site] has approximately a 40 percent chance of Hillary being president and a 50 percent chance of her being the democratic nominee. With the Democrats having about a 57 percent chance of winning the election and with Obama and Gore having above 50 percent chances of winning, the 80 percent (40/50) that Hillary has looks awfully suspect and I assume someone is manipulating the 40 percent number to make Hillary look better. With the efficient market hypothesis in mind, is this at all possible or is an arbitrage opportunity available?Mankiw tells us how to use this anomaly to our advantage: Sell Clinton (bid is now 38.3), Obama (16.5), Gore (7.3), and Edwards (3.6) for a total of 65.7. Buy a contract for a generic Democratic win (ask is now 56.8). You pocket the difference (65.7-56.8=8.9). You have to pay out on the first contract if one of these four candidates wins, but in that case you are covered by the second contract. The only contingency in which you lose is if Clinton, Obama, Gore, or Edwards end up president as an independent or Republican candidate, which seems completely unlikely.So why am I giving away this arbitrage opportunity for free? I must be either unsure of my analysis, or motivated by the search for truth rather than money. Your call.

title: The One That Got Away (So Far)
description: Despite his spectacular career, Roger Federer is still missing a French Open trophy. That could change in the next few weeks. But, it makes us wonder: Can someone who hasnt won all four major championships be considered the sports greatest player ever?

title: A successful formula for Friday fun in F1
description: The morning and afternoon practice sessions of one and a half hours each were, in Monaco, yet more proof for me that Formula One should be outlawing test sessions on circuits where races will happen any time within a few weeks after the test. Formula One cars had not driven in Monaco since the race last year  obviously, since this is a street circuit and they will not close down Monaco for an F1 practice session in, say, February.

title: A Redefining Moment for McDonalds
description: McDonalds has opened a campaign in Britain to pressure the Oxford English Dictionary to redefine McJobs in a more positive light.

title: Danaher Buys a Water Treatment Company
description: The Danaher Corporation said Thursday it had agreed to buy ChemTreat, a water treatment products and services provider, for $435 million. ChemTreat, based in Glen Allen, Va., had more than $200 million in revenue in its most recent fiscal year. The company focuses on boiler, cooling water and industrial waste water applications.

title: Topps Fields New Takeover Offer from Rival
description: Another player has stepped into the brawl over the baseball card maker Topps, which agreed in March to be acquired by the private equity firm Madison Dearborn and Tornante, the investment vehicle of former chief executive of Disney, Michael Eisner. The new pitch is coming from Upper Deck, a rival baseball card company, which is offering $10.75 a share in cash for Topps  10 percent more than the Madison Dearborn teams $9.75-per-share bid, which had a value of $385 million. Three Topps directors are bitterly opposed to the latter offer, calling it too low, and have urged shareholders to reject it at a June 28 vote.

title: Text of Former Justice Dept. Aides Testimony on Attorney Firings
description: Following is the transcript of testimony given by Monica M. Goodling, former Justice Department counsel and White House liaison aide, to the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday, as recorded by the Federal News Service Inc.:

title: Opposition to Iraq War at All Time High
description: Americans now view the war in Iraq more negatively than at any time since the war began, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: The Isle of Capri
description: A place that served as a constant in Graham Greene's restless existence.

title: The Biggest Hedge Funds? Investment Banks
description: If you are having trouble telling the difference between hedge funds and investment banks these days, the latest ranking from Alpha magazine probably wont help. In a further sign of how deeply Wall Street firms are getting into the hedge-fund business, the hedge fund arms of two bulge-bracket banks, J.P. Morgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, have the No. 1 and No. 2 positions on Alphas annual list of the biggest hedge funds. Top-ranked J.P. Morgan has $33 billion in hedge fund assets, putting it just above last years winner, Goldman, which oversees $32.5 billion.

title: Vows: Elina and Jay
description: Elina Furman attempted to ignore Jay Landauer, but his persistence eventually won her over.

title: The Other Summer Rental
description: When you move to New York City, as I did six years ago, people tell you about the high price of real estate, parking and martinis. No one ever mentions rental cars.

title: Guerrilla Gardening in London
description: The heart of London turned bucolic overnight when its tourism department laid 20,000 square feet of turf in Trafalgar Square. The wall-to-wall job took about 40 tons of sod from northern England, which was rolled out in about 3-foot wide strips, The London Times reported.

title: Getting to Yes: A Guide for Private Equity Buyers
description: Shareholder resistance is growing, in some cases at least, to take-private offers. (Just ask the folks trying to buy radio giant Clear Channel Communications.) Enter the lawyers at Weil, Gotshal & Manges, who are offering some advice on how buyout firms can counter that growing resistance. Many of the suggestions, in the law firms latest Private Equity Alert newsletter, are surely standard practice for buyout shoppers: Do due diligence, know who the big stockholders are, etc. But some points in the article  fittingly titled The Great Pushback  bear highlighting.

title: Following the Money Trail Online
description: The first step to solving a problem is recognizing that you have one.

title: Jericholy War
description: More than 7,000 votes came in to TV.com, a television fan site, in answer to this question: What was the biggest shock when the networks presented their new fall seasons at the upfronts this year?

title: Are There Benefits?
description: The political pressure to make life easier for small companies has culminated this week in a new, watered-down auditing standard on internal controls. The good news is that it will cut costs and that the efforts to exempt such companies from any audits on controls have failed.

title: Home Sales Stabilize
description: The headlines today say that new home sales leaped in April. The reality is not quite as good. The increase reported in partly a matter of seasonal adjustments, and may reflect price-cutting as well. The average and median sales prices were down substantially. The seasonally adjusted annual rate rose from 844,000 sales to 981,000. But actual monthly sales rose by just 12,000, to 92,000.

title: More World Bank Candidates
description: The unofficial, unconfirmed list of Paul D. Wolfowitz successors got a little more interesting, with The Wall Street Journal putting a shiny star next to the name of Bill Frist, the former Senate majority leader.

title: Marijuana Researchers Make Progress in the Lab, But Not in Washington
description: Theres more encouraging scientific news on the use of marijuana to alleviate pain: a study has shown that effective doses of cannabis can be delivered with vaporizers, which enable patients to get the therapeutic benefits without inhaling harmful smoke. Meanwhile, though, researchers are still struggling against their biggest bureaucratic obstacle, the Drug Enforcement Administration.

title: Paul Offers Giuliani a Few Policy Tips
description: Representative Ron Paul held a press conference in Washington today to educate Rudy Giuliani on foreign policy. The intended student, not surprisingly, was absent.

title: Not Just Another Monica
description: It was the show everybody in Washington had been waiting for: the testimony of the former Justice Department official Monica Goodling before the House committee investigating the United States attorney firings. So, was it worth wait? The blog consensus: in terms of new information, no; but in terms of political theater, you betcha.

description: Alix Browne reports on The Wrong Store, a tiny storefront shop in Chelsea featuring limited edition objects by artists and designers.

title: Repairing the Damage Done
description: WASHINGTON  More than three decades ago, Nixon White House Counsel John Dean called the Watergate cover-up a cancer on the presidency. Another one exists today, posing a challenge for the next president to restore the office as a credible voice in foreign policy.

title: What Would Moses Do?
description: A major rethinking of the legacy of Robert Moses is under way, fueled by a three-part exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York, the Queens Museum of Art and Columbia University and a collection of scholarly essays by the Columbia scholars Hilary Ballon and Kenneth T. Jackson. (The three exhibitions have a rich joint Web site.)

title: Words That Wound the Working Mother
description: The story of Madeleine McCann, the British three-year-old kidnapped from her resort apartment during a family vacation in Portugal, has obsessed the British public and media for the past three weeks. Harry Potter author J.K. Rowling, Simon Cowell from American Idol and Virgin founder Richard Branson have offered rewards for her return; a findmadeleine.com Web site has received over 65 million hits; Madeleines aunt, Philomena McCann, has reported more than 2,000 responses to a chain e-mail appeal she sent out internationally in the hopes of increasing the odds of a chance sighting of her niece.

description: A home video -- made for The New York Times Magazine -- of Judd Apatow and Seth Rogen, the director and the star of "Knocked Up."

description: After weeks of private negotiations with the Senate and the Assembly, Gov. Eliot Spitzer this afternoon released his version of legislation to bring more oversight and accountability to the states hundreds of public authorities.

title: A Perfect Night for a Pitching Duel
description: The game-time temperature here was 79 degrees. Theres hardly a cloud in the sky. And on the field are the top two teams in the National League East, only one and a half games separating them, and two of the best pitchers of this era, Tom Glavine and John Smoltz, are pitching. Glavine is five victories from 300, and Smoltz can notch No. 200 tonight. And yet I can see sections on the lower bowl that have a handful of fans, and the upper decks arent much better.

title: At Womens Team Championship, China Is Flexing Its Muscle
description: If anyone had doubts about how far the Chinese women have come, they are being dispelled at the First Womens Team Championship in Yekaterinburg, Russia. After five rounds, the Chinese women lead with 9 points out of a possible 10 (two points are awarded for a victory, one for a tie), followed by Russia with 8 and the Ukraine with 7. The tournament began on May 19 and runs through May 30. The official Web site is  here.

title: Chinese Officials Extol Benefits of U.S. Relations
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Chinese leaders traveled from the White House to Capitol Hill on Thursday, trying to persuade skeptics of the benefits of the Chinese-American relationship. But they appeared to make little headway in quelling Congressional anger over Chinas economic practices.

title: Immigrants and Politics
description: A piece of advice for progressives trying to figure out where they stand on immigration reform: its the political economy, stupid. Analyzing the direct economic gains and losses from proposed reform isnt enough. You also have to think about how the reform would affect the future political environment.

title: For Daredevil Skiing, the Season Is Now
description: AS ski season vanishes to slush in much of the country, its only just beginning at Tuckerman Ravine in New Hampshire. Tens of thousands of skiers, boarders and adventurers from all over the world start arriving there in late April, and work and worry the snowy proving ground until at least June and sometimes into July.

title: Shiite Cleric Resurfaces With Anti-U.S. Sermon
description: BAGHDAD, May 25  The populist Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr appeared in public for the first time in months on Friday, delivering a fiercely anti-American sermon and offering himself in a new guise as a nationalist intent on bridging the divide between Iraqs warring communities of Shiites and Sunnis.

description: ATLANTA, May 24  For two hours, Home Depot executives did not utter his name.

description: With half of New York Citys students failing to graduate on time, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced yesterday that the city planned to shut down some schools and programs for the most troubled students and to bolster others.

description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly is so frustrated by his departments problems with attracting recruits that he took a surprising slap this week at a time-honored city tradition  one supported by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

description: ALGIERS, May 25  In this tradition-bound nation scarred by a brutal Islamist-led civil war that killed more than 100,000, a quiet revolution is under way: women are emerging as an economic and political force unheard of in the rest of the Arab world.

title: Netherlands: Russia Wins a Yukos Round
description: Russia won an incremental victory in the legal struggle for what remains of the foreign subsidiaries of Yukos. A Dutch court approved a request by the Russian bankruptcy administrator, Eduard K. Rebgun, to represent Yukos in court in the Netherlands. While most of Yukoss assets have been unraveled and sold at auction, a company bank account in the Netherlands holding about $1 billion from the sale of a Lithuanian refinery is still in dispute. A Dutch court has yet to rule on Mr. Rebguns claim to the property, according to a statement by Yukos shareholders. The money is also claimed by Yukos shareholders and creditors.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about Gods, Myths and Mortals: Discover Ancient Greece, an exhibition that opens today at the Childrens Museum of Manhattan, misspelled the name of the Cyclops who captured Odysseus and is depicted in the exhibition. He is Polyphemus, not Polymephus.

title: Harvey Weinstein, 82, Kidnapping Victim Who Kept His Cool, Dies
description: Harvey J. Weinstein, a formal wear manufacturer whose kidnapping and survival after 12 days in a barrel-shaped pit near the Hudson River in Manhattan made headlines around the country in August 1993, died on May 13 at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

description: Justice Department investigators have seized records from the headquarters of a large operator of medical helicopters as part of an investigation, apparently into possible health care fraud.

description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Congress handed a major victory to low-income workers on Thursday night by approving the first increase in the federal minimum wage rate in a decade.

title: Lawmakers in New Jersey Advance Bill on Paid Leave
description: TRENTON, May 24  Employees of many New Jersey businesses would be entitled to up to 10 weeks of family leave with partial pay for a new baby, a difficult pregnancy or an ill parent or spouse, under a measure approved on Thursday by a Senate committee.

title: Iraqi Shiite Cleric Reportedly Ends a Sojourn in Iran
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  The powerful Iraqi cleric Moktada al- Sadr has quietly returned to southern Iraq after a four-month sojourn in Iran, according to American intelligence reports.

title: A Death Tied to 9/11 Dust Is Not Cause for Alarm to Others, Experts Say
description: When the New York City medical examiner decided last week that Felicia Dunn-Joness death was directly linked to the dust of the destroyed twin towers, making her the 2,750th victim of the attack on Sept. 11, Mrs. Dunn-Joness husband, Joseph, was relieved beyond words.

title: Selig Weighs Whether to Sanction Giambi
description: Commissioner Bud Selig has received a report from the three lawyers who met with the Yankees Jason Giambi on Wednesday regarding his tacit comments about steroid use. Giambi told USA Today last week, I was wrong for doing that stuff in an article focused on steroids.

title: Young People Arrested When They Gathered to Attend a Wake Ask for an Apology
description: The arrests of about 30 young people on the way to a friends wake on Monday have set off a wave of anger in Bushwick, Brooklyn, with more than 50 teenagers assembling yesterday to demand an apology, and their teachers saying that the police had unfairly made a target of the arrested youths  some as young as 13.

title: Three Women With One Goal at Indy
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 24  Women will drive 3 of the 33 cars in the Indianapolis 500 on Sunday, a first for an event that dates to 1911. Danica Patrick, one of the three women, sounded as if she would be more excited about this moment if it accompanied a big head start.

title: Albany: Interim SUNY Chancellor Nominee
description: The State University of New York nominated John B. Clark yesterday to be interim chancellor of its 64-campus system starting June 1. The current chancellor, John R. Ryan, announced in March that he would step down at the end of May. Dr. Clark, who worked on Wall Street for 17 years and has a doctorate from Teachers College at Columbia University, is currently interim president of the State University College of Technology at Alfred. This will be his sixth interim post at SUNY, including three other campus presidencies. SUNY said that if Dr. Clark is approved by its board on May 31, he will remain through Dec. 31, or until its trustees conclude a national search for a permanent chancellor. Dr. Clark, 56, will earn $340,000, but will not be a candidate for permanent chancellor, the university said.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: In a Crowded Anime Dreamscape, a Mysterious Pixie
description: In Paprika, a gorgeous riot of future-shock ideas and brightly animated imagery, the doors of perception never close. A mind-twisting, eye-tickling wonder, this anime from the Japanese director Satoshi Kon bears little relation to the greasy, sticky kid stuff that Hollywood churns out, those fatuous fables with wisecracking woodland creatures selling lessons in how to be a good child so you can grow up to be a good citizen. Model behavior isnt on the menu in Paprika, and neither are dinky songs and visuals. Here, when a woman sprouts a pair of wings, she doesnt only flit about like Tinker Bell; shes also pinned captive to a table, a mans hand slithering under her skin.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article yesterday about the end of the arbitration hearing between the cyclist Floyd Landis and the United States Anti-Doping Agency referred imprecisely in some copies to Landiss potential place in Tour de France history. He could become the first champion in the Tours 103-year history to be stripped of the title for a doping violation, not the first to be stripped of the title.

title: Ukrainian Political Crisis Escalates
description: MOSCOW, May 25 -- President Viktor A. Yushchenko issued a decree today putting Ukraines interior troops under presidential command, but the Interior Ministry, joined by Prime Minister Viktor A. Yanukovich, declared the move unconstitutional and defied it.

title: U.S. Growth Expected to Cool, Falling Below Pace in Europe
description: FRANKFURT, May 24 Economic growth in Europe and Japan is expected to outpace that in the United States this year for the first time since 2001, as a slowdown in the American housing market curbs growth, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said Thursday.

title: For New York, Big Job Growth in Home Care
description: New York Citys economy has been booming, with unemployment dropping to historic lows and Wall Street getting most of the credit. But the typical new worker in the city is not a pinstriped investment banker or a corporate lawyer. She is a home health aide like Vivienne P. Smith.

title: Documents From Sallie Mae Add to Questions About Timing of $18 Million Stock Sale
description: An internal document from Sallie Mae, the nations largest student lender, showed that the company sought a meeting with President Bushs budget office about two months before the companys chairman, Albert L. Lord, sold more than $18 million in shares.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on May 16 about Robert S. Oelman, former chief executive of NCR, referred incorrectly to Mr. Oelmans support of Nelson Rockefellers efforts to become president. Mr. Rockefeller asked Mr. Oelman to head up his Ohio campaign in 1968  but not in 1972, when Mr. Rockefeller decided against seeking the presidency and instead supported President Nixons re-election.

description: Star Wars, the Way You Like It

title: Spare Times
Chinas Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
College Considers a Plan to Sell Its Art Collection
description: Short on funds and fearful of losing its accreditation, Randolph-Macon Womans College in Lynchburg, Va., is exploring the possibility of saving itself by sharing its most valuable asset: a world-class collection of American art. Worth more than $100 million, it includes paintings by George Bellows, Edward Hopper, William Merritt Chase and Georgia OKeeffe.

title: New Haven: No Bail in Terror Case
description: A federal judge yesterday denied bail to a former Navy sailor held since March on charges that he provided classified information to the owner of a Web site that supported terrorist causes. Prosecutors charge that in 2001, Hassan Abujihaad, 31, of Phoenix, then a signalman aboard the guided missile destroyer Benfold, sent a document detailing the planned movements and vulnerabilities of a group of ships in the Persian Gulf to Babar Ahmad, the owner of the Web site, who ran it in Britain through an Internet hosting company in Connecticut. Mr. Ahmad has been indicted and is awaiting extradition. In denying bail for Mr. Abujihaad, Judge Mark Kravitz of Federal District Court cited the fact that Mr. Abujihaad has a fiance in Morocco and is said to have discussed plans to buy two assault rifles in the months before his arrest. A trial is scheduled for the fall.

title: In This Clash, Both Sides Are Good
description: Few things are more routine in this city than fights over property. But how many of them have people talking about nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, X-ray crystallography or something called cryoelectron microscopy?

title: Senators Accuse Bush of Ignoring Warnings on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  Democrats on a deeply divided Senate Intelligence Committee accused the Bush administration today of ignoring warnings in 2003 from the nations spy agencies that a post-war Iraq could face violence and division and that an invasion could strengthen the hand of Al Qaeda and Iran.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Monday about the efforts of three women in Atlanta to combat mortgage fraud misstated the location of one womans neighborhood. Smoke Rise is east of Atlanta, not west.

title: Ireland Votes on Whether to Give the Prime Minister a Third Term
description: DUBLIN, May 24  Irish voters went to the polls on Thursday in a national ballot that will decide whether Prime Minister Bertie Ahern secures a third successive term after 10 years in office.

title: Where the Road to Renaming Does Not Run Smooth
description: DURBAN, South Africa, May 18  None of South Africas big cities are so redolent of colonialism as this old seaport, namesake of a British major general and headquarters, in the early 1800s, of a British colony at Africas southern tip. Durbans baroque city hall is said to be a clone of Belfasts. From Brighton Beach to Victoria Market, allusions to colonial dominance are inescapable.

title: Get Moving on Traffic Relief
description: Congestion pricing, a system of charging drivers for traveling on a citys most-crowded streets, is a proven success that New York City is right to want to emulate. It has worked in Stockholm and London, where skepticism gave way to resounding support. Residents of both cities were turned around by the unclogged streets, quicker commutes, better public transportation and cleaner air. Now that Mayor Michael Bloomberg wants to give congestion pricing a try, state leaders, starting with Gov. Eliot Spitzer, should get on board.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10:30 P.M. (AMC) 2007 TAURUS WORLD STUNT AWARDS This annual ceremony honors Hollywoods action heroes: the men and women who take the falls  and the bullets, bruises and broken bones  for film stars. Awards will be given for hardest hit and best fight, fire, high work, specialty stunt and work with a vehicle. Nominees include Tony Angelotti, who was seriously injured while doubling for Johnny Depp in the third Pirates of the Caribbean installment. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California will present a lifetime achievement award to Burt Reynolds; Jeannie Epper will be recognized as the godmother of stuntwomen. Dwayne Johnson (the Rock), above, will make a dramatic entrance as host. And since no stunt awards ceremony is complete without a little action, the ceremony will feature a parkour demonstration, a sword fight and a fashion show where the models arent just hot: theyre on fire.

title: Gone With the Windmill Farms, or, a Cape Cod Cautionary Tale
description: Every so often a purely local dispute rises above its station and assumes national importance. This was the case with the Cape Wind project, a proposed wind farm that seemed to have everything going for it: It would deliver badly needed additional electric power to energy-hungry New England, reduce utility bills for everyone and cut down on air pollution. There was just one little problem. The spinning windmills would be located in Nantucket Sound, within view of some very expensive homes and some very wealthy and powerful citizens.

title: People
description: People

title: A Month of Coming-Out Parties
description: IT can be said that all of todays gay rights  from those that allow marriage to those that protect from hate crimes  can be traced to a few tense days in June 1969. Thats when a group of patrons at the Stonewall Inn, an unlicensed gay bar in Greenwich Village, grew fed up with one too many raids on the club. They fought back against the police, setting off the Stonewall riots and spawning the modern gay rights movement.

title: Topics That Make Money Managers Get All Sentimental
description: IT takes all kinds of investors to make a market, or so it seemed at a conference this week of the crme de la crme of money managers. Typically a reclusive bunch, the managers agreed to offer up a few of their investment ideas to a roomful of attentive money managers in an effort to raise money for pediatric cancer and other childhood diseases.

title: Custom Stamps as a Status Symbol
description: MADISON AVENUE used to have high hopes for the lowly postage stamp. For decades, advertisers imagined that if only the legal barriers against commercial images on postage stamps came down, they could do great things on envelopes.

title: Israel Seizes 33 Palestinians in Crackdown
description: JERUSALEM, May 24  Israel stepped up its campaign against Hamas on Thursday, arresting 33 prominent West Bank Palestinians in early morning raids, including a cabinet minister, three legislators and three mayors, and accusing them of terrorist activity, army officials said.

title: In Three Visions of Balanchine, Charm, Romance and Drama
description: We could waste time about whether New York City Ballets new triple bill should really be labeled Essential Balanchine. Although Walpurgisnacht Ballet, which opens the program, is certainly intoxicating, most Balanchinaholics would surely count at least 25 other ballets by the master as more essential than this one. No matter: it, and more indubitably the two that follow, plunge us deep into the essential Balanchine experience, which is one of transformation. Those onstage are seen to change, the place they inhabit is felt to change, and ultimately we know that we too are changed, we know not how.

title: Senate Votes to Keep Plan to Make Immigrants Legal
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  The Senate on Thursday turned aside the most significant challenge to the comprehensive immigration bill now under debate, voting 66 to 29 to keep a provision that offers legal status to most of the nations 12 million illegal immigrants.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted May 18 through May 23 with 1,125 adults throughout the United States.

title: Nascars Rules Tested by Tests on New Car
description: CONCORD, N.C., May 24  Hendrick Motorsports drivers have won all five Nextel Cup races involving the Nascar-designed Car of Tomorrow. Around the garage, there is no secret to their success: The team has tested the car at various tracks as much as or more than any other team, gathering information that has translated into victories.

title: Those Tired, Those Poor: A Journey as Important as Its Destination
description: In its basic outline the story told in Golden Door, Emanuele Crialeses beautiful dream of a film, is hardly unfamiliar. Some version of this immigrants tale  setting out from the old country, crossing the Atlantic in steerage, arriving at Ellis Island  is part of the family history of millions of Americans. But what makes Mr. Crialeses telling unusual, apart from the gorgeousness of his wide-screen compositions, is that his emphasis is on departure and transition, rather than arrival.

title: Art in Review
description: FRANCESCO CLEMENTE Works, 1971-1979  Deitch Projects 76 Grand Street, SoHo Through June 2

title: After 7 Years in Prison, Muslim Cleric Is Deported From Britain
description: LONDON, May 25  The British authorities, grappling with ways to contain suspected terrorists, deported today a Jamaican-born Muslim preacher and convert to Islam accused of influencing one of the attackers in the London bombings of July 2005.

title: Lighting the Way
description: Sometimes thinking small can get things done. To bring artificial light to an isolated village or refugee camp could require building an enormous hydroelectric dam, followed by laying hundreds of miles of cable. Or it could take the donation of a $10 solar flashlight.

title: Coming Soon to Wal-Mart: 2 Dell PCs
description: Dell, in a first step toward transforming its ailing strategy of selling direct to consumers, said yesterday that it planned to offer computers at Wal-Mart Stores, starting in June.

title: Alcohol, Drugs and Abortion (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about a lawsuit over a sale of corporate bonds referred incorrectly to the current status of the Citigroup business that sold the bonds. That business is now owned by Legg Mason; it is not a part of the Smith Barney unit of Citigroup. (Citigroup and its affiliates are defendants in the lawsuit; Legg Mason is not.)

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Closer to Reform
description: With their credibility on the line, House Democrats did the right thing yesterday by mandating disclosure of the lobbying industrys power to purchase Capitol influence with richly bundled campaign donations to pliable lawmakers.

title: Japan: Consumer Prices Slow
description: Consumer prices fell at a slower pace in April, the government reported. Core consumer prices, which exclude fresh food, declined 0.1 percent from a year earlier. The measure of inflation fell 0.3 percent in March, the steepest drop in two years, matching the median estimate of 44 economists surveyed by Bloomberg News. Core prices in Tokyo, a harbinger of nationwide prices, were unchanged for a second month, also in line with economists expectations.

title: When Art Meets Science, Things Dont Go Very Well
description: Carl Djerassi probably doesnt want to hear this, since he has written that he consciously reduces the amount of science in his plays to make them more commercial, but: Theres not enough science in his play Phallacy, which is receiving its American premiere at the Cherry Lane Theater.

title: Ann Taylor and Gap Say Earnings Fell in the Quarter
description: Gap Inc., the largest United States clothing retailer, reported its seventh consecutive quarterly decline in profit yesterday, and the womens apparel retailer Ann Taylor Stores also reported lower first-quarter profit.

title: G.M. Details Delphi Exposure, Gets S.E.C. Request
description: DETROIT, May 24  General Motors said today that it expects to take a $1 billion charge in the second quarter and pay a total of $7 billion to cover retirement costs for workers at the Delphi Corporation, its former parts division.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Ignoring the Warnings, Again?
description: The latest findings on Avandia, a top-selling diabetes drug, raise concerns both about its safety and about the way the manufacturer and the Food and Drug Administration have responded to signs of danger. It would be rash to make definitive judgments until the F.D.A. completes a detailed analysis. But the handling of this case bears disturbing resemblances to the Vioxx debacle, in which early warning signs were ignored by its manufacturer until the evidence of serious harm became inescapable and the drug was pulled from the market.

title: From the Edge of Madness to Fightings Mainstream
description: Mixed martial arts was, in its recent outlaw years, the criminal element of sports, called human cockfighting by Senator John McCain and written into legal exile in New York by a stroke of former Gov. George E. Patakis pen.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about Wynn Handman, an acting teacher and director in New York who was honored on Monday for his 85th birthday by students and protgs, misspelled the given name of one former student and misstated the name of a drama program for high school students produced by American Place Theater, which Mr. Handman founded. The former student is the actress Allison Janney, not Alison, and the program is Literature to Life, not Literacy for Life.

title: Poll Shows View of Iraq War Is Most Negative Since Start
description: Americans now view the war in Iraq more negatively than at any time since the invasion more than four years ago, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: In Need of Income, Cemeteries Are Seeking Breathing Clientele
description: PHILADELPHIA  The dinner was first-class, with butlers serving hors doeuvres and the strains of Blue Danube tastefully muffling the festive din. This nine-course re-creation of the last supper aboard an ill-fated ocean liner was the culmination of Titanic Day at Laurel Hill Cemetery, one of a growing number of historic cemeteries to rebrand themselves as destination necropolises for weekend tourists.

title: Israel Strikes Near Palestinian Leaders Home
description: JERUSALEM, May 25  The Israeli army continued its air campaign against the Hamas infrastructure in the Gaza Strip late Thursday and today, striking at least eight different locations, an army spokesman said.

title: Starring New York, City of Grit and Glamour
description: To walk through the main concourse at Grand Central Terminal is to step onto a real-life movie set. Cary Grant passes through it while escaping his would-be killers in North by Northwest. Jim Carrey grabs Kate Winslets hand and dashes across it in Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, watching people vanish one by one as his memory is erased. Most tellingly, it is the site of a pivotal moment in The Fisher King, when Robin Williams, as a pure-hearted, emotionally unbalanced man, spots the quite plain woman of his dreams heading for her train. Suddenly everyone in the room breaks into a waltz, as this grimy, everyday place becomes a scene of glittering romance.

title: Bush Reaffirms His Support for Gonzales
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  President Bush said Thursday that he would correct any problems uncovered in the investigations of last years dismissals of federal prosecutors, but he added that nothing had undermined his support for Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales.

title: Clinton Revisits Health Care and Affordability
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who endured a major political setback as first lady when she tried to promote universal health care, revived that crusade yesterday but in a more measured way, offering a plan to reduce costs, through programs like disease prevention, to make universal coverage affordable.

title: The Shushing of the Boos
description: CANNES, France, May 24  Whether because of happenstance or hard work, the 60th Cannes Film Festival has presented attendees with an embarrassment of riches. The competition lineup has been notably strong, on occasion galvanizing, resulting in more cheers from the international press than jeers (a beloved tradition) than Ive heard in the past decade. The knives have come out for a few films  the very presence of Quentin Tarantinos extended-play version of Death Proof in the main competition proved an affront to some  but this has been a week in which it has been blissfully easy to confirm your love for cinema, not your pessimism about the state of a beloved art.

title: Take Me Out to the Baggage Check
description: Zeljko Bibic was headed into Yankee Stadium on Wednesday with a Tumi bag slung over his shoulder and his son, Nikola, at his side. Not so fast, he was told at the gate. The bag was too large to be permitted inside.

title: EGL Accepts Buyout Offer From Apollo
description: The logistics company EGL has ended its buyout agreement with its chief, James R. Crane, and has accepted a higher offer from Ceva Logistics, which is owned by Apollo Management.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A caption for a comic-book illustration yesterday with a sports article about the attention that Kelly Kulick received as the first woman to earn a season-long exemption on the Professional Bowlers Association Tour, including a role in a Spider-Man comic, misidentified the character shown in the illustration. It was Miss Arrow  not Kulicks bowler-turned-action hero character. (An illustration showing Kulicks character can be found at nytimes.com/sports.)

title: Rookie Reliever Shows Versatility and Wins Respect
description: ATLANTA, May 24  The other night, Billy Wagner responded to a radio reporters request for an interview by calling out Joe Smiths name.

title: Exploring the Nature of the Unnatural
description: They lure children into dank swamps and devour them. They live in caves or among high rocks or deep in dense forests. They are covered with scales or thick fur. They have hands at the ends of their tails or a single glaring eye. They exhale fire, cause hurricanes with their wings or feast on human eyes, teeth and nails. They might also whimsically help the unwitting, but they are almost all mercurial, unreliable, tricksters.

title: Young String Quartets, Learning From the Masters
description: On Tuesday and Wednesday I heard seven young string quartets coached by two eminent ensembles play music by three composers in two different halls. Five of the seven were all female. The overall demographic was 5 men and 23 women, three of whom showed signs of imminent motherhood. I have no idea what all this means and pass it on without comment.

title: Immigration Bill Provisions Gain Wide Support in Poll
description: As opponents from the right and left challenge an immigration bill before Congress, there is broad support among Americans  Democrats, Republicans and independents alike  for the major provisions in the legislation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: In Market, Hopes for Health and Urban Renewal
description: PHILADELPHIA  It seems that anyone you talk to in the streets around Progress Plaza, a tattered shopping center in a mainly black, poor part of North Philadelphia, is excited.

title: New Effort to Continue Espionage Case
description: Federal prosecutors have offered to provide more classified information in open court to keep alive their prosecution of two former pro-Israel lobbyists charged with violating the Espionage Act. The lobbyists, who had been with the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, are charged with illegally giving national security information to Israeli officials and reporters. Citing national security concerns, the prosecutors had tried to close from public scrutiny a substantial part of the information to be used at trial. But Judge T. S. Ellis III of Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., ruled in April that the governments proposal would not afford a fair trial to the two defendants, Steven J. Rosen and Keith Weissman. The prosecutors new proposal was filed under seal, but other government documents said it would allow greater public disclosure of a significant amount of classified information.

title: At Cannes This Year, the Bankers May Outnumber the Movie Stars
description: CANNES, France, May 24  One morning more than a decade ago, John W. Miller found himself trying to explain the Cannes Film Festival in a conference call to his colleagues at Chemical Bank.

title: Poor Decisions? Knicks Deserve a Mulligan
description: As the N.B.A. playoffs grind forth, Madison Square Garden is dark once again.

title: Iraq Presents Graduating Class at West Point With New Challenges
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., May 22  The graduating cadets of the United States Military Academy spent their final days here like scores of seniors, or firsties, before them: packing foot lockers and showing their mothers around gray buildings and sweeping lawns. All smiles. Even the lone cadet marching in full uniform in a parking lot under the hot sun  a form of punishment called walking the area  flashed a grin when a friend passed.

title: Ukraine Fires Prosecutor
description: MOSCOW, May 24  President Viktor A. Yushchenko of Ukraine dismissed the chief prosecutor on Thursday, news agencies reported.

title: Coca-Cola Is Said to Buy Vitaminwater
description: Directors of the Coca-Cola Company last night approved the purchase of Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, for $4.2 billion in cash and Coke stock, according to an executive involved in the negotiations.

title: Ensuring Food Safety (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Mission for Memorial Day: Always Remember
description: IF you traveled on one of the nations Interstates in these last few days before Memorial Day, you might have encountered an unusual sight: bikers by the dozens stretched half a mile down the highway, their motorcycles flying military banners and spewing exhaust.

title: Risky Bets on Winning Tax Fights
description: Death may still be certain, but taxes are something else entirely.

title: Mayor Has New Plan to Cite Drivers Who Block the Box
description: Ticketing drivers who block intersections would become much easier under a plan announced yesterday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg as part of a broader attack on traffic congestion.

title: U.S. Casualties May Spike This Summer, Bush Warns
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  President Bush warned Thursday that casualties in Iraq could increase over the summer as the United States completes its troop buildup there.

title: Rooftop Blaze on 34th Street Draws 100 Firefighters to Scene
description: More than 100 firefighters responded to a blaze yesterday atop a mixed-use building on West 34th Street. Investigators had not determined a cause last night.

title: Slim for Summer: Good Reading, but Less (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigation Is Said to Open on Dow Chemical
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an inquiry into whether two senior executives at Dow Chemical secretly tried to put the company into play as well as into the unusual trading in its stock that may have resulted, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Search for Vein Delays Execution of Ohio Inmate by 90 Minutes
description: LUCASVILLE, Ohio, May 24 (AP)  An overweight inmate was executed by injection on Thursday after a delay of about 90 minutes while prison medical workers struggled to find suitable veins in his arms.

title: Bronx: Man Wounded in Shootout With Police
description: A man was shot in the shoulder during a gunfight with plainclothes officers in the Bronx early yesterday, the police said. Charges were pending against the man, Ron Tribble, 21, who was treated at St. Barnabas Hospital and released, the police said. The confrontation began at 173rd Street and Webster Avenue shortly before 4 a.m., the police said, when Mr. Tribble and another man flagged down an unmarked car carrying three plainclothes officers, possibly believing the car was a livery cab. After an officer rolled down his window, Mr. Tribble ran, the police said. The officers chased Mr. Tribble, and two of them fired after they saw him readying a gun to fire, the police said. After firing at the officers, Mr. Tribble jumped a fence, and was later found hiding in a yard, the police said.

title: House Votes to Lift Veil Over Lobbyists Donations
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  The House voted Thursday to drag into public view the role that registered lobbyists play in soliciting and collecting contributions for political campaigns, exposing for the first time one of the most effective ways that influence-seekers ingratiate themselves with lawmakers and presidents.

title: Brian Leetch Retires From Hockey
description: Brian Leetch said he knew months ago that he had no comeback left in him. After sitting out the entire season, he finally announced his retirement yesterday, officially ending the 18-year career of arguably the best American-born player in N.H.L. history.

title: At Least Give Giambi Some Credit
description: Imagine if Jason Giambi had gone to the House Government Reform Committee hearing in March 2005 and said what he told a USA Today reporter last week.

title: The Catholic Boom
description: The pope and many others speak for the thoroughly religious. Christopher Hitchens has the latest best seller on behalf of the antireligious. But who speaks for the quasi-religious?

title: At Friends Expense, Smoltz Claims No. 200
description: ATLANTA, May 24  It may come as soon as this weekend, via telephone call or text message. Or after a competitive 18 holes in November. But there will surely come a time when John Smoltz and Tom Glavine will reflect on all that went on at Turner Field and share a good laugh. That is what friends do.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Public Lives column last Friday, about David Chang, the owner of the Momofuku restaurants in the East Village and the winner of this years James Beard Foundation award for best new chef, referred imprecisely to the Japanese name for another restaurant he plans to open, Ko. It is more accurately translated as child than son of.

title: The Tuscany Life, in Croatia
description: FOR vacation-home buyers who want the feel of Tuscany but at lower prices, the peninsula of Istria in northern Croatia is proving to be a popular choice.

title: No Segways Needed (1 Letter)
description: To The Editor:

title: Congress Passes War Funds Bill, Ending Impasse
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Congress voted Thursday to meet President Bushs demand for almost $100 billion to pay for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan through September, providing a momentary truce in a bitter struggle over war policy.

title: WFNY Drops Talk Format and Returns to Rock, Citing Profits
description: New York City regained a rock radio station yesterday afternoon when WFNY-FM (92.3) largely abandoned the low-rated all-talk format it adopted in January 2006. The revamped station heralded its new format just after 5 p.m. when it played All Apologies, by Nirvana.

title: U.S. Opens a Sheltered Path to Asylum for Some Iraqis
description: An obscure program that bypasses the State Departments normal immigration procedures has granted a form of temporary asylum to a former minister who led Iraqs troubled Health Ministry and to more than 100 other Iraqi professionals, witnesses of potential crimes by Americans, and children wounded in the conflict.

title: On the Edge, a Man Finds Hope in a Mystery Woman
description: While watching Luc Bessons comedy Angel-A, in which a leggy blond angel descends from on high to save the soul of a petty criminal who barely comes up to her shoulders, I had an unpleasant thought: if Hollywood got its hands on the story, Uma Thurman and Danny DeVito would be cast as the odd couple. Not much charm there. Or worse: Daryl Hannah and Pauly Shore.

description: ART
