description: MOVIES

title: Erin Go Faster
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: For the Record
description: In the May 23 Editorial Observer about fires in California: John Cheevers journal mentioned burning ghats, not burning gnats. Ghats are stairs from temples to the Ganges River in India, where Hindus traditionally construct funeral pyres. Gnats, of course, are tiny insects.

title: Rooms Without Walls
description: WHO Carrie Wilhite, 40, a stay-at-home mother from Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., shown at rear with her husband, Brad, 42, an investment banker, as their three children play with two friends.

title: Macedonian Is New Assembly President
description: Srgjan Kerim, a former foreign minister of Macedonia who has served as his countrys ambassador to Germany, Switzerland and Lichtenstein, and the United Nations, was elected president of the General Assembly for the 62nd session of the 192-member body, which begins in September. The post rotates by regions, and Mr. Kerims candidacy was put forward by the Eastern European group. He succeeds Haya Rashed al-Khalifa of Bahrain.

title: Trump & Co. Hits Chicago to Drum Up Apartment Sales
description: CHICAGO, May 24  It was a jarring sight for those going about their business in the low-key bustle of downtown on Thursday: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, and his glamorous grown children stepping off Michigan Avenue surrounded by a swirling sea of camera crews he had summoned.

title: For Slain Soldiers Family, 2 Awful Nightmares, One Real
description: LOS ANGELES, May 24  For the family and friends of Pfc. Joseph J. Anzack Jr., found dead Wednesday in Iraq nearly two weeks after being captured with two other soldiers in an ambush, the anguish came with a devastating twist: This was the second time in just four weeks that they had gotten word he was dead.

title: Spain Voting Seen as Test for Premier and His Rival
description: MADRID, May 24  Spaniards go to the polls on Sunday to elect local and regional officials who are responsible for such services as garbage collection, schools and running the village fiestas. But the way the campaign is being run, it feels like an election for the next prime minister.

title: Iraqi Tribal Leader Is Killed, and Mourners Are Attacked
description: BAGHDAD, May 24  The growing confrontation between tribal leaders in Anbar Province and Al Qaeda took a violent turn on Thursday when a suicide bomber drove into a crowd gathering for a funeral procession in the volatile city of Falluja, killing at least 27 people and wounding dozens of others.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about former President Jimmy Carters recent criticisms of the Bush administration, and his subsequent explanation of his remarks, imprecisely described a question that Mr. Carter was asked during an interview with The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette. He was asked: Which president was worse, George W. Bush or Richard Nixon? He answered that the Bush administration was the worst in history for the adverse impact he said its policies had on the way the United States is viewed around the world. He was not asked, as he later told NBCs Today show, to compare Mr. Bushs foreign policy with Mr. Nixons.

title: A Defender of the Controversial, and Now of Imus
description: THAT persistent rumble, somewhere between stentorian and strangulated, is the sound of the lawyer Martin Garbus clearing his throat. Hes a bit under the weather. Dont get too close to me, he says. It is a well-intentioned warning, not censure. Not from him.

title: 38 Die in Methane Blast at a Coal Mine in Siberia
description: MOSCOW, May 24  A methane explosion in a coal mine killed at least 38 people early Thursday, opening fresh wounds in a Siberian region notorious for mine accidents, where more than 100 miners died in a blast two months ago.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Douglas Holmes, Researcher Best Known for Work on Aging, Dies at 73
description: Douglas Holmes, a noted social psychologist who spent his career investigating means of improving social services for people at both ends of the life cycle  children and the elderly  died on Wednesday at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 73 and also had a home in Manhattan.

title: Dell, in Shift, Will Offer PCs at Wal-Mart
description: Dell, in a first step toward transforming its ailing model of selling direct to consumers, said today that it would offer computers at Wal-Mart stores starting in June.

title: Matchmaking: Old Masters Meet Their Modern Soul Mates
description: A six-gallery art walk is in full stride on the Upper East Side, covering some 600 years of endeavor from exquisite medieval gold-ground paintings to rambunctious 20th-century Conceptual photographs. In Masterworks of Six Centuries each participating gallery explores a theme, so that at the end of the three-block stroll you may have earned a pocket briefing in art history and a sense of time well spent.

title: Brotherly Art: The Clarks Who Collected
description: In the art world this is a collectors moment. The market keeps climbing, new galleries continue to open, and records are regularly broken at auctions. Perfect timing then for a museum show highlighting the life and times of collectors.

title: Westport: Ex-Selectwoman Nominated for Bank
description: President Bush has nominated Diane G. Farrell to become a director of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, the White House said yesterday. Ms. Farrell, left, a Democrat, is a former first selectwoman of Westport and last year ran unsuccessfully against Representative Christopher Shays for a congressional seat. If approved by the Senate, Ms. Farrell would serve the remainder of a four-year term expiring on Jan. 20, 2011, the White House said.

title: 150 Years of Gathering Mostly American Treasures
description: Some of New Yorks best-known art galleries began as antiques shops, among them James Graham & Sons, which is celebrating its 150th anniversary this week. It is thought to be the oldest gallery in the city owned by one family.

title: Senator Says F.D.A. Was Lax on Label for Avandia
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (Bloomberg)  Federal regulators did not act on a recommendation from their safety reviewers several months ago that GlaxoSmithKlines diabetes drug Avandia should carry the strongest possible caution about heart attacks, Senator Charles Grassley said Thursday in a statement.

title: Inhabiting the Tortured Soul of a Tennyson Narrator
description: The name Tennyson evokes for me my grandmothers leatherbound book of his collected poems with the name stamped on the front in gold, its thin pages heavy with columns of florid verse: an object more admirable than beloved. There are wonderful things in it, but a little goes a long way.

title: Correction: A Renaissance of Charm in a Hub of the Surfing World
description: A picture with the Havens column last Friday about San Clemente, Calif., was published in error. The house shown in the photograph was recently sold; it was not a two-bedroom house priced at $2,687,500.

title: Theres an Allegory in Those Hills
description: Oh no, oh no, oh no. Setting the Indian on the course to civilization best ensures his survival, says President Ulysses S. Grant (Fred Thompson!), expositorily, on HBO on Sunday night. Gag.

title: Congress Putting Long-Term Care Under Scrutiny
description: A Congressional committee yesterday began looking into business practices in the long-term care insurance industry.

title: Instant Star, Just Add Hype
description: America voted and the new American idol is the dewy-eyed Jordin Sparks. A 17-year-old girl with a big voice and a melting smile, she sings more from the adolescent heart than from the grown-up head.

title: P. M. Kaiser, 93, Diplomat for Democratic Presidents, Is Dead
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Philip M. Kaiser, a former ambassador to Austria, Hungary and Senegal who served as a diplomat or political appointee under every Democratic president from Harry S. Truman to Jimmy Carter, died Thursday in Washington. He was 93.

title: G.M. Expects to Take a $1 Billion Charge for Delphi Costs
description: DETROIT, May 24  General Motors said on Thursday that it expected to take a $1 billion charge in the second quarter and pay a total of $7 billion to cover retirement costs for workers at the Delphi Corporation, its former parts division.

title: Through Rose-Colored Granny Glasses
description: Tear gas, pot and patchouli were the scents of the 1960s. You can almost detect the last two, spicy and pungent, wafting through Summer of Love: Art of the Psychedelic Era at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: Summer Weekends: Get Out and Go
description: MEMORIAL DAY triggers a series of inexorable actions. Beach romances fly off bookshelves. White pants and Hawaiian shirts tumble out of closets. Pools are opened, rooftop parties commence and patio umbrellas are unfurled in a backyard chorus of cranks and squeaks.

title: Queens: Man Sentenced for Nightclub Shooting
description: A Brooklyn man who opened fire at a Queens nightclub in 2004, killing one person and wounding two others, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 75 years to life in prison, prosecutors said. The man, Moises Valerio, 32, of Hull Street in East New York, was convicted on May 4, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Valerio, angry at being ejected from Club Phenomenon in Woodside on May 22, 2004, grabbed a gun from his car, returned to the club and fired on the clubs security officers. One, Francisco Rosa, 35, an off-duty state court officer, was killed.

title: Lottery Numbers
Albany: More Oversight for Authorities
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer released a proposal yesterday to overhaul and provide more monitoring of the states hundreds of public authorities, after weeks of negotiation with legislative leaders. But Mr. Spitzers legislation still differs significantly from proposals in the State Senate and Assembly, which seek greater scrutiny for authorities, including requiring the comptroller to approve all authority contracts and establishing an authority budget office that has the power to subpoena authorities for financial documents.

title: Theater Listings
description: THEATER

title: 2nd Ave. Subways Photo Op Cost the M.T.A. $89,000
description: How much is a little publicity worth?

title: Support Riders in Tour Admit Taking EPO
description: FRANKFURT, May 24  Professional cycling sustained another blow to its credibility Thursday when two German riders admitted in an emotional, nationally televised news conference that they took performance-enhancing drugs while supporting the winning riders in two Tours de France.

title: H.I.V. Testing Bill Starts War Among Assembly Democrats
description: ALBANY, May 24  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and a majority of state lawmakers are backing a bill requiring H.I.V. testing of suspects indicted on rape charges. Nevertheless, its chances of passage are unclear, as the legislation is the subject of contentious debate in the Assembly.

title: ODonnell Leaving The View 3 Weeks Early
description: Rosie ODonnell, who was scheduled to leave the cast of The View on June 22, will not return to the talk show at all after the Memorial Day weekend, ABC announced this afternoon on the Web site of its news division.

title: Senate Panel Approves Rule to State Cost of Spy Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  In a move to reduce secrecy around the nations spy agencies, the Senate Intelligence Committee has approved a measure to make public the total amount spent on spying and to direct the Central Intelligence Agency to release an internal report examining its failure to prevent the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Good or Bad, It All Goes Back to Cashman
description: Brian Cashmans tenure with the Yankees stretches back more than half his life. Cashman, the general manager, started as an intern in the scouting department in 1986, when he was 19. He understands that to lose in New York, with a team built to win, is to invite blame on the architect.

title: A Hybrid Beat With Roots in Both Cuba and Boston
description: Rhythm is an earthy but flexible property for the drummer Francisco Mela. At the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night he created a flickering sort of pulse, animated by both the thrum of Afro-Cuban folk music and the thrust of contemporary post-bop. His band, a quintet, wasnt playing anything recognizable as Latin jazz. What it was after was a hybrid as natural as Mr. Melas propulsion, which generally flowed.

title: Bronx: Ex-School Worker Charged
description: A former accounting assistant at the Riverdale Country School was indicted yesterday on charges of stealing more than $500,000 by skimming cash from school fund-raisers and the cafeteria, prosecutors said. The suspect, Eileen Koranteng, 50, of Peekskill, was charged with grand larceny and forgery, the Bronx district attorneys office said. Ms. Koranteng was an employee at the school from 1997 until 2006. In July 2001, she began embezzling tuition payments and other school money totaling $508,000, prosecutors said.

title: More Than Ever, It Pays to Be the Top Executive
description: Like most companies, Office Depot has long made sure that its chief executive was the highest-paid employee. Ten years ago, the $2.2 million pay package of its chief was more than double that of his No. 2. The fifth-ranked executive received less than one-third.

title: Denmark: Offer for Insurers Shares
description: The Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group, a British nonlife insurer, offered 6.4 billion kroner ($1.2 billion) to buy the stock it does not already own in Codan, a nonlife insurer in Denmark. Royal and Sun bid 605 kroner apiece for the shares, a premium of 15 percent over the closing price Wednesday of 525 kroner. Royal and Sun completed the sale of operations in the United States in March to focus on British and Scandinavian businesses and on emerging markets.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about former President Jimmy Carters recent criticisms of the Bush administration, and his subsequent explanation of his remarks, imprecisely described a question that Mr. Carter was asked during an interview with The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette. He was asked: Which president was worse, George W. Bush or Richard Nixon? He answered that the Bush administration was the worst in history for the adverse impact he said its policies had on the way the United States is viewed around the world. He was not asked, as he later told NBCs Today show, to compare Mr. Bushs foreign policy with Mr. Nixons. (Go to Article)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, about Long Time Leaving, by Roy Blount Jr., a collection of essays on Southern topics, misstated the title of a movie discussed in the book. The movie, based on a novel by the same name, is Raintree County, not Raintree Country.

title: Despite Gas Prices, Drivers Are Hitting the Road
description: Despite near-record gasoline prices, more Americans than ever were expected to travel on the long Memorial Day weekend, most of them by motor vehicle.

title: Openness Sought in British Terror Trials
description: FLORENCE, Italy, May 24  The head of British counterterrorism at Scotland Yard on Thursday criticized what he called excessive secrecy in Britains terrorism trials, and he called for changes that would permit freer reporting and wider discussion of the issue.

title: Two Country Houses and One Romance, Made in Connecticut
description: IN the movies, love always seems to find its way: opposites attract, the hard-working guy marries the girl next door, and coincidence has a way of intervening at just the right moment. Life doesnt always imitate art, as Lucille Masone Smith knows, having spent a career helping to create the artifice of film. But sometimes it comes surprisingly close.

title: Needing Cash, Cemeteries Seek Breathing Clients
description: Historic cemeteries, desperate for money to pay for badly needed restorations, are reaching out to the public in ever more unusual ways, with dog parades, bird-watching lectures, Sunday jazz concerts, Halloween parties and other events.

title: Welcome Home
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Faces of Apatow
description: Scenes from the evolution of Judd Apatow's life and work over the years.

title: Gravity Defying
description: Sexy sofas, not-so-precious metals, homey handwork. At this years Milan Furniture Fair, design lightens up. Seriously.

title: If the Elevator Is Broken, Is a Rent Rebate in Order?
description: Q Our building is a mix of rent-stabilized and free-market apartments. We have two very old and very slow elevators, one of which has been inoperable for almost three weeks. We have received word from the management company that the elevator needs to be replaced and that this will probably take two months or more.

title: Murder and Mistrust
description: Charged with fighting crime in streets saturated with drugs and guns, Newark's police force faces a lack of equipment and cooperation from the public.

title: Pulse | Light as the Breeze
description:
Summer promises to be
fashionably full of holes,
with eyelet showing up as
the latest retail confection.

title: Magnificent mansion
description: Exterior

title: A Closer Vision
description: Additional images of the Netherlands Institute for Sound and Vision.

title: A Century-Old Trade
description: Delivery men called dabbawallas transport home-cooked meals to workplaces all over Mumbai, India, with near-clockwork precision.

title: The Harlem Valley Rail Trail
description: A century and a half ago, it was the northern route of the New York and Harlem Railroad. Today, it is the Harlem Valley Rail Trail, where bicyclists of all skill levels can pedal through the cool forests and sweet-scented farmlands of the Taconic Hills. There is bicycling now on 4- and 12-mile public stretches of paved rail bed, united by country roads where riding is fairly easy. When it is eventually completed, the trail will stretch 46 miles from Wassaic in Dutchess County to Chatham in Columbia County.

title: Midsize Matchups: How Some of the Newest Family Sedans Compare
Old-Time Farming and Baseball
description: Old Bethpage Village Restoration (www.nassaucountyny.gov/agencies/parks) is a 165-acre village and working farm that recreates a 19th-century Long Island hamlet, assembled from more than 50 period homes and commercial structures from surrounding towns. Children can churn butter or scribble on a slate in the one-room schoolhouse, pet farm animals and buy penny candy in the Layton General Store (1866).

title: Museum Row, for Children
description: It's totally hands-on at the Cradle of Aviation (www.cradleofaviation.org), one of a trio of family-oriented museums in Garden City. The aviation museum offers children a chance to climb into a jet simulator and experience G-force. An IMAX theater has eye-popping programs like "Hurricane on the Bayou," which simulates the fury of Hurricane Katrina, and "Magnificent Desolation: Walking on the Moon," which relates the sensation experienced by the 12 men who have set foot on the moon's surface. Over the summer, there are aerospace minicamps devoted to weekly themes like astronomy or space exploration.

title: Down the Brandywine
description: The placid waters of Brandywine Creek provide a welcome respite from life's pressures. On a hot day, nothing beats floating downstream Huck Finn style and dangling your toes in the water as cows moo and blue skies peek through a canopy of oak and maple trees. The Northbrook Canoe Company (northbrookcanoe.com) near West Chester, Pa., rents canoes (beginning at $35), kayaks ($25) and inner tubes ($15). There are seven routes on the meandering west branch of the Brandywine. The shortest trip is an hour, and more ambitious paddlers can journey six and a half hours and end up in Delaware. Paddlers often spot trout and minnows, as well as birds, frogs, turtles and, on rare occasions, foxes. While toweling off back at headquarters, you can order cheeseburgers, hot dogs and chicken nuggets from the Food Shack. There's a picnic grove for those who prefer to pack a lunch.

title: Dow Faces S.E.C. Inquiry Into Deal Talks and Trades
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an inquiry into whether two senior executives at Dow Chemical secretly tried to put the company into play and into the unusual trading in its stock that may have resulted, according to The New York Times.

title: A Treasure in a Barn
Lighthouse Trail
description: You can get a lofty view of New Jersey's rich maritime history by visiting the lighthouses that dot the shoreline from Sandy Hook Lighthouse overlooking Lower New York Bay to Cape May at the southern tip of the state. Eleven lighthouses are open to the public, and New Jersey Tourism (www.visitnj.org) issues a free 17-page booklet outlining their history.

title: Russia Wins a Yukos Round
description: Russia won an incremental victory in the legal struggle for what remains of the foreign subsidiaries of Yukos. A Dutch court approved a request by the Russian bankruptcy administrator, Eduard K. Rebgun, to represent Yukos in court in the Netherlands.

title: Lancaster County Farm Stays
description: Here's your chance to don some overalls and be a farmer for a weekend. More than 30 working farms in Lancaster County, Pa., participate in a farm stay program (www.padutchcountry.com), many in the heart of Amish country, where you can skip across wooden bridges, wave to kids in buggies and spot one-room schoolhouses as you drive through fertile farmlands.

title: UBS Researchers Say Banks May Be in for a Merger Binge
description: Expectations of a spate of bank mergers are the highest since the turn of the millennium, according to UBS research analyst Philip Finch.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Convictions in Adelphia Fraud Case
description: A federal appeals court upheld the criminal convictions yesterday of the founder of Adelphia Communications, John J. Rigas, and his son Timothy, who both face lengthy prison terms for concealing loans and stealing millions from the cable television provider.

title: Apologetic, Home Depot Tries to Move Beyond Nardellis Shadow
description: At Home Depots annual meeting yesterday, investors and management went back and forth on a range of issues as the specter of Robert L. Nardelli, the companys ousted chief executive, continued to haunt the proceedings.

title: Fifield Is Still Interested in EMI, Even If Corvus Isnt
description: Jim Fifield, a former executive of the EMI Group, is still interested in making a bid for the company, which received a takeover offer from Terra Firma Capital Partners this week.

title: Fidelity Starts $500 Million Buyout Fund
description: Fidelity Equity Partners, an arm of Fidelity Investments, has opened a $500 million buyout fund. The new private equity shop, which officially and quietly started operating in January, is funded internally and the vehicles limited partners are Fidelity shareholders.

title: UBS to Dispose of $3.3 Billion Julius Baer Stake
description: UBS, the worlds biggest money manager, plans to sell its 4.1 billion-Swiss franc ($3.3 billion) stake in bank Julius Baer Holding and use the proceeds to buy back shares.

title: Are Online Ad Firms Worth Top Dollar?
description: The recent frenzy of deals for online advertising firms  Googles $3.1 billion deal for DoubleClick, WPPs $649 million purchase of 24/7 Real Media, Microsofts $6 billion move on aQuantive  has some industry observers wondering if a whiff of desperation isnt in the air.

title: Dinosaur and Other Bones
description: A bronze torosaurus, standing two stories high and 21 feet long, guards the entrance to the Peabody Museum of Natural History (www.peabody.yale.edu) at Yale University in New Haven. The torosaurus has friends there, too. Poised in the museums great hall are full-size skeletons of a brontosaurus and stegosaurus and the head of a triceratops. Also notable are the 110-foot long Age of Reptiles mural and its companion, the 60-foot-long Age of Mammals by Rudolph F. Zallinger, whose work is being celebrated there his year. The Discovery Room has hands-on specimens like real dinosaur teeth, as well as live snakes and poison dart frogs that visitors distinctly do not touch. An exhibit called Fossils Fragments: The Riddle of Human Origins features a skeleton of one of the early members of our genus, Homo, discovered in Kenya. The many questions about evolution that are posed here will probably fuel a family discussion all the way home.

title: Powowing
description: Visitors can experience life in a coastal Pequot village of the 16th century and learn to speak a few Algonquin phrases at the tribally owned Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center (www.pequotmuseum.org) in eastern Connecticut. The 85,000-square-foot museum claims to have more exhibition space than any other American Indian center in the country. There are computer-interactive exhibits, dioramas, a children's library, documentary films and live events. The surrounding countryside can be viewed from an 18-story tower and observation deck. A current exhibition, "Fifty Years of Powwow," intersperses photographs with displays of Native American dance regalia.

title: Stock Picks From Hedge-Fund Stars
description: When some of the biggest  and most reclusive  names in hedge-fund land took the podium this week at a charity event, they offered attendees more than just some inspiring words: They gave investment advice.

title: Christianity in China
description: Continuing his journey across China, Nicholas Kristof visits a house church in Shandong province.

title: Sharper Image Jumps on Buyout Speculation
description: A Buyout firm, Sun Capital Partners, has doubled its stake in Sharper Image, raising the prospect that the ailing specialty retailer might be taken private as it tries to bounce back. Sharper Images stock rose 15 percent Thursday after it said in a regulatory filing that an affiliate of Sun Capital had paid $13.78 million for 1.49 million shares held in a trust set up by the companys founder and former chief executive, Richard Thanheimer.

title: Royal and Sun Makes Offer for Remaining Codan Stake
description: The Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group, a British nonlife insurer, offered 6.4 billion kroner ($1.2 billion) to buy the stock it does not already own in Codan, a nonlife insurer in Denmark.

title: LionOre Mining Favors Norilsk Offer
description: LionOre Mining International, the nickel producer, said that the takeover offer of $6.8 billion Canadian dollars ($6.3 billion) from Norilsk Nickel of Russia was superior to a rival offer by Xstrata of Switzerland. Xstratas most recent bid was for $6.2 billion Canadian dollars. Both companies have now made two offers for LionOre. Under the terms of an agreement signed with LionOre, Xstrata has until June 1 to match Norilsks offer.

title: Iberia to Consider Takeover Bid
description: The Spanish airline Iberia said that it had received information on a takeover bid led by the private equity group Texas Pacific Group and that its board would study the offer at its next meeting.

title: EGL Chooses Apollo Over Its Founder
description: The logistics company EGL has ended its buyout agreement with its chief, James R. Crane, and has accepted a higher offer from Ceva Logistics, which is owned by the private equity firm Apollo Management.

title: G.M. Expects $1 Billion Charge for Delphi Costs
description: General Motors said Thursday that it expected to take a $1 billion charge in the second quarter and pay a total of $7 billion to cover retirement costs for workers at Delphi, its former parts division. The company also said that it had received a new request for accounting documents from the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has been investigating G.M.s accounting practices for nearly two years.

title: Gambling Web Site Pleads Guilty in U.S. Case
description: An Internet gambling site, BetonSports, pleaded guilty Thursday to federal racketeering charges and agreed to cooperate in a case against the companys founder and other defendants, a prosecutor said. BetonSports admitted a pattern of racketeering acts, including mail and wire fraud, operating an illegal gambling business and money laundering, a statement from the United States attorney in St. Louis, Catherine L. Hanaway, said.

title: Id Like to Sell the World a Coke
Morgan Stanley Fund Said to Approach $8 Billion
description: Morgan Stanley is reportedly close to completing fundraising for an $8 billion real estate investment fund, The Financial Times reported. It would be the securities firms largest real estate fund to date. The newspaper said that 40 percent of the investment banks sixth real estate fund will be invested in Japan. The fund is expected to close as early as next month amid strong demand from mostly non-Japanese investors, the Financial Times said.

title: Greenlight Capital Re Rises in Market Debut
description: Stock in Greenlight Capital Re, a reinsurance company, jumped more than 20 percent in its market opening Thursday as the its ties to hedge fund manager David Einhorn seemed to be a draw for investors, MarketWatch reported. The companys shares were up 21 percent at $23.03 during afternoon trading Thursday. Greenlight Capital raised $195 million in the initial public offering.

title: Sallie Mae Documents Add to Questions About Stock Sale
description: An internal document from Sallie Mae, the nations largest student lender, showed that the company sought a meeting with President Bushs budget office about two months before the companys chairman, Albert L. Lord, sold more than $18 million in shares. The Securities and Exchange Commission and the House education committee are investigating whether Mr. Lord had inside information about the presidents budget proposal, which was released in February and called for cuts in subsidies for companies participating in the federally guaranteed student loan program.

title: Take My Television  Please!
description: My business of green column today is about the growing options here in Europe for disposing of unwanted electronic equipment in an eco-friendly manner. The European Union as well as a number of electronics companies like Dell and Nokia are pioneering new thinking in the field.

title: More Than Ever, It Pays to Be the Top Executive
description: As executive pay has surged in most American companies, attention has focused on the growing gap between the earnings of top executives and the average wage of workers in cubicles or on the shop floor. But, notes The New York Times, little noticed, is how much the gap has also widened between the summit and the next few echelons down.

title: Consortium Sets New Deadline for ABN Amro Bid Decision
description: A consortium of banks led by the Royal Bank of Scotland has pushed back the date by which it will decide whether to bid for ABN Amro, not for any complex strategic reason, but because, as it turns out, the date it chose falls around a holiday.

title: Tribune Debt Deal Not as Sweet as Expected
description: Tribune, which last month agreed to go private in an $8.2 billion deal with the real-estate mogul Samuel Zell, completed a tender offer for half its shares, but the media company had to agree to difficult borrowing terms, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: G.E. to Double Down on Clean Tech Investments
description: General Electric plans to double its clean technology venture capital investments from $25 million this year to $50 million a year by 2008. G.E. plans to make investments across the clean-tech sector including solar, biofuels and batteries. In January, G.E. led a $40 million investment round in A123Systems, a company developing lithium ion batteries for plug-in hybrid vehicles.

title: Upper Decks Topps Bid: Sneaky or Sincere?
description: Is Upper Decks bid for venerable bubble gum and card maker Topps really a back-door move to spy on its rival?

title: Biolex Swallows $30 Million from V.C.s
description: Biolex Therapeutics, a privately held biopharmaceutical company, announced the closing of a $30 million Series C financing. The financing was led by Investor Growth Capital of New York and included the participation of two other new investors, JP Morgan Securities and Easton Capital.

title: 2008: Supplemental Cases
description: Congressional passage of a war spending bill, which does not set a withdrawal timeline but requires the Iraqi government to meet a series of benchmarks to continue receiving aid, is drawing a forceful reaction, especially on the Democratic side.

title: Nasdaq in $3.7 Billion Deal for Swedens OMX
description: Robert Greifeld can breathe a little easier. The chief executive officer of the Nasdaq Stock Market, who has been trying for at least 14 months to buy a European exchange, has finally gotten his deal with an agreement to buy Swedens OMX for 25.1 billion Swedish kronor ($3.7 billion).

title: In Cannes, Bankers May Outnumber Movie Stars
description: Amid the glamour and the French Riviera sun, more and more Wall Street banks, private equity firms and hedge funds are coming to the 12-day Cannes festival  the worlds largest international film market  to try to arrange and finance entertainment deals. Merrill Lynch, Citigroup, and JPMorgan Chase, as well as hedge funds like Atticus Capital and various companies backed by the likes of Providence Equity Partners and the Texas Pacific Group, are all here this year, competing for deals.

title: The Lies People Tell
description: The Portuguese filmmaker Manoel de Oliveira's "Magic Mirror," a dreamy satire about class, is centered on a rich woman named Alfreda (Leonor Silveira), who has been praying for a sighting of the Virgin Mary her whole life and is baffled and annoyed that it hasn't happened.

title: test
Movie Memories and Gender Confusion
description: A gentler, more wistful Henry Jaglom wrote and directed "Hollywood Dreams," his 15th and perhaps most accessible film. Filled with movie memories and gender confusion, the story shows one of our most polarizing independent filmmakers in a nostalgic mood, musing over the burdens of fame and the price of success  which would be love, as if you didn't know.

title: A Smoggy Start to a Long Weekend
description: As New Yorkers prepare for the Memorial Day weekend, they can look forward to the usual routines: schools letting out, lazy summer weekends and frequent ozone warnings.

title: This Land: A Soldier's Story
description: Dan Barry reports on the death of Sgt. James E. Dean, who was shot by a Maryland police sniper three weeks before his redeployment to Iraq.

title: A Study of Male Family Dynamics
description: There's bad news for absentee dads: It is apparently no longer sufficient to buy your grown child a car as penance for missing all those Little League games. The outsize guilt trip that Carl Lee (John Heard) imposes on himself for being a lousy parent hurts the credibility of "Steel City," an otherwise absorbing study of male family dynamics written and directed by Brian Jun.

title: Hes Back
description: So it seems that Moktada al-Sadr, the firebrand anti-American cleric at the center of radical Shiite politics and armed violence in Iraq, is back from a four-month hole-up in Iran, and is leading Friday prayers today at the mosque in Kufa, near Mr. Sadrs base in Najaf.

title: Tales of the Somewhat Surprising
description: Mark Noonan at Blogs for Bush is (somewhat surprisingly) pleased that the Democratic House passed a law against gasoline price gouging.

title: The Personal Within the Political
description: "Amu," the ambitious debut feature by Shonali Bose, wears its political heart on its sleeve and is unafraid to tackle big topics: identity, history, truth, injustice.

title: MGM Mirage Sets Advisers for Kerkorian Talks
description: Negotiations with your own controlling investor are bound to be complicated. To help navigate its talks with majority shareholder Kirk Kerkorian, MGM Mirage has enlisted some help. The casino company said Friday that a special transaction committee of independent directors has hired UBS and the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges as advisers as it considers the recent proposal from Mr. Kerkorians investment firm, Tracinda.

title: Giulianis Yankees Chair
description: Yankee fan extraordinaire Rudolph W. Giuliani might be getting accustomed to answering questions about the team paraphernalia he owns.

title: McCain on Clinton, Obama War Votes
description: This didnt take long. Senator John McCain of Arizona just took a break from his week of skirmishing with fellow Republican Mitt Romney to issue a statement denouncing two of the leading Democratic candidates, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton, for their votes against the Iraq war funding bill.

title: Talking Turkey: A Reader Nominates OnStar
description: And now, a note from reader Steve B:

title: Bias Attack or Juvenile Brawl?
description: [Update, 7 p.m.: The police have come down on the side of calling the attack on a Sikh student in Queens a hate crime. At a press briefing following a promotions ceremony at police headquarters this morning, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said investigators deemed the attack a hate crime because the Pakistani students remarks were religiously biased.

title: Gore Sees No Reason to Run
description: At times provocative, at other times surprising  yet still not a candidate for president  former Vice President Al Gore spoke and took questions on the state of American politics and his new book, The Assault on Reason, at Manhattans 92nd St. Y last night.

title: Algerian Womens Growing Participation in Society
description: In a tradition-bound nation, women are emerging as an economic and political force unheard of in the rest of the Arab world.

title: Not a Mothers Milk
description: On several occasions over the last few years, Ive run across the phrase milk-fed in relation to a bird.

title: Coca-Cola Pulls Out the Stops for Glaceau Deal
description: The Coca-Cola Company said Friday it would buy Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, for $4.1 billion. It would be Cokes largest acquisition ever, and the price tag is more than the amount of cash Coke had on hand at the end of last quarter, meaning it will need to use debt to finance the all-cash deal. Shareholders seemed to find the deal refreshing: They bid up Coke shares by 1.4 percent in late-morning trading.

title: For New M.B.A.s, Diplomas and Deal Wisdom
description: Stephen M. Case has been making a lot of public apologies lately. Less than a year ago, in an interview with TV talk-show host Charlie Rose, the co-founder of America Online conceded that he was sorry for advocating the ill-fated 2000 merger of AOL and Time Warner.

title: California Freeway Rebuilt in a New York Minute
description: Your blogger has the good fortune to have three close relatives in the civil engineering profession, and thus ample opportunity to watch a civil engineers mind at work and play, often at the same time.

title: Friday off in Monaco  sort of
description: As most fans know, nothing much happens in Monaco on Friday. This morning, however, the GP2 series held its qualifying session, and I just had to draw attention to this. I recommend watching the GP2 race tomorrow if you have access to it on television, or here at the track. Thanks to an oil slick on the track the last seven minutes of the qualifying session were useless. The session had been stopped to clean up the oil, but seven minutes was not enough time for the 26 cars to get a good shot at setting a good lap time. The result is that the grid has been hugely shaken up, and some of the usual last-place starters are now at the front. The championship leader, Timo Glock, starts eighth, and Bruno Senna starts ninth. This promises a great race.

title: Plenty of Homes for Sale
description: There are now more than 4 million single-family homes for sale in the United States, and that is a record. As recently as the end of 2005, the figure was fewer than than 3 million.

title: The What Ifs
description: The other day, a colleague asked me what Paul and I refer to as The Question: Arent you guys worried about building a house in the middle of hurricane territory? Her query was no doubt prompted by NOAAs cheerful prediction that the 2007 hurricane season  which runs from June 1 to Nov. 30  will be above average, with 13 to 17 named storms. (The average is 9.6.)

title: Napa Name Recognition
description: This week Napa Valley became the first American wine region to receive protection for its name by the European Union.

title: Tour de France Champion Admits Doping
description: One of the safes hanging over Floyd Landiss head as he fights doping allegations is the prospect of becoming the first Tour de France winner to be stripped of the title for doping. Today, another candidate volunteered.

title: The Clinton-Obama Two-Step
description: There was no real suspense about whether the Iraq spending bill would pass the Senate last night. But in the final minutes, everyone was waiting to see how the two main contenders for the Democratic presidential nomination, Senators Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama, would vote.

title: Immigration Poll Interviews
description: As the debate over new immigration legislation rages around the country and in Congress, The Times and CBS News published a new poll on the issue at the end of this week.

title: McCain Gives Obama Flak
description: The oldest presidential candidate isnt cutting the youngest any slack over the latters no vote on the Iraq funding supplemental bill.

title: The Olympics' First Losers
description: Nicholas D. Kristof visits a woman who says she may be jailed during the Beijing Games. The encampment for petitioners like her was already demolished in preparation for the Olympics.

title: Goldman Alum Keeps the Hedge in Hedge Fund
description: When Dinakar Singh isnt giving investment tips at charity events, the former head of Goldman Sachss proprietary equities trading desk runs a long/short-oriented hedge fund.

title: Blogtalk: Holiday Reading
description: The fire on the West Side yesterday means Coach employees can start the holiday weekend early. No more smoking on the roof, though. [Fashionista]

title: Immigration Nation
description: Heres what happens when you poll people on a complex, emotional issue the vagaries of which they know little about, writes Allahpundit at Hot Air who, having already parsed the views of Muslim Americans, now dissects The New York Times/CBS News expansive poll on attitudes toward immigration reform.

title: Governor vs. Game Warden in South Dakota
description: Suppose you were a game warden for the federal Fish and Wildlife Service. A big part of your job would be tramping the woods and marshes to check up on hunters  strangers with loaded guns who shoot things for recreation  and then writing them up when you find them breaking the law.

title: 2008: Times/CBS News Poll Results
description: The latest nationwide New York Times/CBS News poll included at look at how the top 2008 Democratic and Republican candidates are faring.

title: U.S. Troops Train for Paralympics
description: Retired and active duty troops attended the 2007 Paralympic Military Sports Camp in Colorado and discovered unknown athletic talent.

title: An Opening Gambit With an Odd Acronym
description: When the legendary basketball coach Bobby Knight was pushed out of Indiana University, Texas Tech University in Lubbock jumped to welcome him, in hopes of raising the schools national profile. Perhaps that move did not reap enough public attention (or maybe it was not the right kind), because the school is now trying another visibility-building leap in a different kind of competitive endeavor: Chess.

title: A Benefit for The Kitchen
description: Melena Ryzik of The Times attends a benefit gala held at the Puck Building for the performance space The Kitchen.

title: About Kalmykia, Home of the Candidates Matches
description: Tomorrow is the opening ceremony for the candidates matches that will determine four participants for the world championship tournament in September and October in Mexico City. The matches, like so many other recent events (including last years title contest between Veselin Topalov and Vladimir Kramnik), are taking place in Elista, the capital of Kalmykia, a Russian republic on the Caspian Sea. Why Kalmykia? It is the home of Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, the president of the World Chess Federation, who is also the president of Kalmykia. Ilyumzhinov is providing $320,000 of the $480,000 prize fund for the matches and the federation is providing the rest.

title: Video: Christianity in China
description: On an architectural level, this house church in Shandong province is far from the awe-inspiring splendor of Notre Dame or St. Peters Cathedral. But, as Nick reports in his latest video from his journey, house churches are sweeping across China.

title: Deciding Whether a Window Shade Is Open or Closed
description: On a recent trans-Atlantic flight with Air France, I was asked to pull down my window shade by the stewardess. I refused, as it was daytime and I had no desire to sleep. She insisted, but I held my ground and told her to take the matter up with the captain. She left me alone after that. Was I within my rights to keep my window shade open? Can flight attendants order passengers to close their shades?

title: Down and Out in Roslyn, Long Island
description: The Roslyn Village Motel, a $175 per week flophouse, is an unusual sight among the glitter and wealth of the North Shore town's "miracle mile."

title: Green-Wood Remembers Civil War Dead
description: A volunteer effort at Brooklyn's historic Green-Wood Cemetery honors nearly 3,000 Civil War veterans buried there with new gravestones.

title: Tools for Better Living
description: An exhibit at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in New York features inventions designed to help the world's poor move out of poverty.

title: Say Amen, Everybody, 15 Years Down the Line
description: When Wynton Marsalis unveiled his sanctified long-form composition In This House, on This Morning 15 years ago, it marked a breakthrough for him as well as for Jazz at Lincoln Center, where he had recently begun his tenure as artistic director. So it might be tempting to view the pieces revival this week as an act of misty nostalgia, the equivalent of dusting off a scrapbook, or a treasured hymnal, and gingerly turning pages.

title: As Condos Rise in South Florida, Nervous Investors Try to Flee
description: MIAMI, May 25  As dozens of condominium towers conceived during Floridas real estate boom near completion, investors who snatched up units in the preconstruction phase in hopes of turning a quick profit are increasingly trying to break contracts, even walking away from fat deposits.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Books of The Times review on Thursday, about Pearl Harbor, by Newt Gingrich and William R. Forstchen, misstated the phrase that President Franklin D. Roosevelt used in referring to Dec. 7, 1941, the day of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. He called it a date which will live in infamy, not a day that will live in infamy.

The British attorney general, Peter Goldsmith, responded that British justice should decide the matter. This murder was committed on U.K. soil, he said in a statement. title: Two Social Ethicists and the National Landscape

Niebuhr, who taught social ethics at Union from 1928 to 1961, was the most prominent and influential American theologian of the last hundred years. His evolving notion of Christian realism shaped the outlook of Depression-era radicals, World War II interventionists, anti-Communist cold warriors and early civil rights militants. He lectured across the country on a weekly basis, as does Dr. Dorrien, who, like Niebuhr, often arrives at his last class on Thursday with my bags packed.

title: Inside the List
description: LEONARDS FINAL FOUR: Whats Elmore Leonards best novel? In the right bar, that question could start a rumble. But Mark Reiter tackles it with elegance and wit in his recent book The Enlightened Bracketologist: The Final Four of Everything, which he wrote with Richard Sandomir and Nigel Holmes. According to Reiter, the novels that make it to Leonards final four are Hombre (1961), Swag (1976), LaBrava (1983) and Killshot (1989). Its hard to quibble with that list. LaBrava got there by defeating, in the second round, Get Shorty. (Reiter calls this an ironic matchup, since Leonard wrote Get Shorty to get back at Dustin Hoffman for torturing him during the writing of the LaBrava screenplay.) The final matchup, in Reiters bracket, is between Swag and Killshot. Ill let Reiter describe which book wins:  Swag is great because you root for the crooks. Killshot goes it one better with Leonards best-ever opening chapter, a cast of kinky characters who are both menacing and sympathetic, and the rarity of a happily married couple as the novels action heroes. Even the blunt title is perfect. Leonards new novel, Up in Honeys Room, is at No. 15.

title: Cleaning Up the Clean Water Act
description: A series of murky Supreme Court decisions have left the agencies responsible for enforcing the Clean Water Act in a state of confused paralysis, exposing millions of acres of wetlands and thousands of miles of streams to illegal and destructive development. Companion bills in the House and Senate would solve this problem by reaffirming the broad protections intended by Congress when it passed the law nearly 35 years ago. These bills deserve prompt passage.

title: Season in the Sun
description: Corsica is not  how shall I say it  is not well known for its allegiance to the laws of the continent, the owner of a seaside Corsican auberge tells a young American without working papers, proposing to let him do odd jobs in exchange for room and board and a little something at the end of the season. This is precisely what John Hanson Mitchell, trying to deflect the insistent letters from his draft board, is eager to hear. But hes not alone. Just about everyone in his memoir of the Rose Caf in the summer of 1962 is a fugitive of some sort: political refugees, con men, Gypsies, aged members of the underground with long-distance eyes  even a shy deliveryman whose father, a scruffy old donkey herder , may, it is whispered, be a mazzeri, a Corsican version of a zombie .

title: Queen of Hearts
description: Lovely to look at and ornery to handle, artichokes are  like roast turkey and hand-wrapped tamales  ideal ritual food. The rites that artichokes serve, of course, are springs, the annual cleaning and regreening of the palate after the long winter. (Even in their oddball alcoholic form  the Italian digestivo Cynar  artichokes serve as a quasi-medicinal cleanser.) Other greens and tender young herbs are there as part of the vernal celebration, but artichokes are almost alchemical in their appeal. What other food would you forgive for pricking your fingertips, overflowing your compost bucket and killing your best wines? The artichoke makes up for all this, of course, with its distinctive flavor  a nutty, herbal fusion with an everlasting finish.

title: With Marco and Michael, Andrettis Hope Luck Turns at Indy
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 26  Marco Andretti was a rookie, and still a teenager, when he nearly won the Indianapolis 500 last May. He drove a nearly flawless race, even when he lost the lead to Sam Hornish Jr. at the end and finished second, drawing raves from his father and grandfather, who also lug an often burdensome last name that suggests speed.

title: Sister Acts
description: The 13th century was a very long time ago. But youd never know it from Nancy Goldstones breezy account of the careers of four sisters  Marguerite, Eleanor, Sanchia and Beatrice  born to Raymond Berenger V, the Count of Provence, and his wife, Beatrice of Savoy. Some might call that a victory. After all, making the past accessible to present-day readers is the goal of any popular historian. But Goldstones method raises some questions. Four Queens, she explains, is the story of a family of four sisters who had risen from near obscurity to become the most celebrated and powerful women of their time. But just how obscure was this family?

title: Prisoner of War
description: Twenty years ago last month, Primo Levi plunged headlong into the stairwell of the apartment building in Turin where he had been born and to which he had returned after liberation from Auschwitz. At the time, there was a great deal of debate about the nature and meaning of his death: was it an accident or a suicide, illness or cosmic despair? But it is surely the way he lived and wrote in the four decades after the war that matter most. If the ancient Greeks were right that it is the manner of ones death as much as the substance of ones life that determines its ultimate meaning, then much of European Jewry, not to mention European culture, would need to be written off as an abject failure.
