title: Over Here
description: Washington

title: Perpetual-Motion Maestro
description: JAMES LEVINE could hardly wait to show off his physical agility. A year ago he missed four months of work after tripping on the stage at Symphony Hall in Boston during a concert with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, severely injuring his right shoulder.

title: After Forest Fires, Resiliency and Growth
description: WHILE television sets across the country were showing forests ablaze and firefighters frantically dousing flames during the weeklong inferno that burned more than 17,000 acres in the New Jersey Pinelands, a few more subtle events were happening far from the cameras lenses.

title: Appeals Court Affirms an Eviction
description: A RECENT New York appeals court ruling provides vivid evidence that even an experienced real estate lawyer is no match for the power of a co-op corporation to control the quality of life in its building.

title: Sturm und Drang Over a Memorial to Heinrich Heine
description: NOWHERE are the tensions between art and politics drawn more sharply than in the strange case of the Heine Memorial, intended in 1899 for one of the most prominent sites in Manhattan but finally unveiled in the Bronx, where it stands at 161st Street and the Grand Concourse.

title: From a Bad Marriage, Pretty Babies
description: AS Daimler and Chrysler negotiate their separation, the sedan widely regarded as the best design to come from their marriage, the Chrysler 300, might imagine itself in a movie moment: She is a lovely daughter at the prom. In a bittersweet scene, the divorcing mom and dad are ruefully proud: At least our marriage produced her!

title: Lens Solution Is Pulled Over Link to Infection
description: A contact lens solution manufacturer voluntarily withdrew one of its products yesterday after federal health officials said an investigation had linked it to a rare but potentially blinding eye infection.

title: Tuscan Summer: Food, Wine and Music Galore
description: Tuscany will be alive this summer with classical music, lots of it. Three music festivals will be inaugurated this year near Siena, an area that already has three other summer festivals.

title: Up Front
description: In the 1980s and 90s, Steven Pinker established himself as one of his generations leading experimental psychologists. But with the publication, in 1994, of The Language Instinct, his study of the biological sources of speech, Pinker attracted nonspecialist readers. He enlarged his following with How the Mind Works and The Blank Slate: The Modern Denial of Human Nature, books that bring the psychological perspective to bear on art, politics and morality, among other subjects.

title: Red Carpets Through History
description: THE Cannes Film Festival presents its awards today, bringing out the brightest stars in the Hollywood and international firmaments for a red-carpet barrage of photos, speculation on the winners and generally profound discourse. But was the pre-show interview always this glamorous?

title: A Tour With Head Tilted Up
description: TO see 25 of America's 150 favorite architectural structures in a day, you could hire a private plane and try to spot the Sears Tower, the St. Louis Arch, the Milwaukee Art Museum and 22 more from the air as you cross the country.

title: And You Call That a Blockbuster
description: Hollywood may turn out a slew of blockbuster movies this summer, but will they measure up against the blockbusters of the past?

title: How Idol Helped One Sitcom Cheat Death
description: WHEN Fox Broadcasting introduced its comedy series  Til Death to potential advertisers one year ago, the show and its star, Brad Garrett, were immediately the subject of cocktail-party chatter.

title: Bushs Fleurs du Mal
description: WASHINGTON

title: Just So Stories
description: Avant-garde fiction in America can seem something of an oxymoron, operating less as a forward movement than as a separatist cult that neither desires nor expects to have any influence on mainstream literature. But the absence of influence is also the presence of freedom, a characteristic easily discernible in the work of Lydia Davis. Known for her translations from the French, especially for her version of Swanns Way, the first volume of Prousts monumental modernist novel, Davis seems to work on the margins as a writer. Her spare, elliptical short fiction is critically acclaimed, but it forms a challenging body of work, dispensing with straightforward narrative in favor of a microscopic examination of language and thought.

title: Christina Calcagni, August Sack VI
description: Christina Beck Calcagni, a daughter of Patricia Belle Dantzler Calcagni and Stephen M. Calcagni of Roxbury, Conn., was married yesterday in Chestnut Hill, Mass., to August Albert Sack VI, the son of Mr. Sack IV of Wainscott, N.Y., and the late Susan Van Wyck Sack. The Rev. William McInnes performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius of Loyola on the campus of Boston College, from which the bride graduated.

title: Because Were Not There Yet
description: THE 1950s are considered the golden age of the automobile. Sales climbed. Fins, after-burner taillights and other jet-age accoutrements appeared on family cars. Drive-in restaurants, movies and even churches and funeral parlors became part of the landscape.

title: 36 Hours in Moscow
description: OLD-TIMERS always marvel about how much Moscow has changed since the stultifying days of the Soviet Union. That's ancient history. What's really worth marveling about is how much the city has changed in the last year or two. Few places in the world have undergone such a rapid, dizzying and cacophonic transformation as Moscow, and it shows no sign of abating. The gangster Moscow of the 1990s has given way to something tamer, more metropolitan, perhaps, but it is still brash and flashy. The city, like Russia itself, seems to be in search of its identity  embracing the past, though often ironically, while plunging full-speed ahead. What the future holds is uncertain, but meantime, Muscovites are indulging in what an energy-fueled boom has bestowed on them.

title: Shellen Wu, Steven Chin
description: Shellen Xiao Wu, the daughter of Xiang Fan He and Heng Lin Wu of Setauket, N.Y., is to be married today to Steven Coffee Chin, the son of Chui Fong Chin and Woon Ping Chin of New York. The Rev. William C. F. Yip, a cousin of the bridegroom and a nondenominational Protestant minister, is to officiate at Beach Club Estate, a caterer in Ronkonkoma, N.Y.

title: The Unintended Consequences of Hyperhydration
description: Its easy to find, in the mightily expanding iconography of American waste, the monumental (a ziggurat of flattened cars), the sinister (ocher sludge foaming on a riverbank) and the sublime (a plastic bag fluttering in a Japanese maple). The empty bottle and crushed aluminum can are none of these. They are almost too commonplace to notice, too dreary to evoke anything at all. Foundered on a roadside or slumped in a bag of spent Chinese takeout, the can without its Mountain Dew and the bottle without its Bud are unremarkable things. Theyre just trash: something we once wanted and now cant be bothered with.

title: In One Town, Intersections of Sacrifice
description: Carlstadt, N.J.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The approaching hurricane season doesnt seem to be intimidating the Mexico Tourism Board (www.visitmexico.com). On May 17, it announced the opening of a new terminal at the Cancn International Airport, its third. It also announced preliminary plans for a new international airport down the coast in Tulum. ... Think youve done everything in Venice? Think again. How about enjoying an opera al fresco under the cypress trees on San Giorgio Maggiore island? The newly reopened Teatro Verde, a 1,500-seat open-air theater built in 1954 (below), has just undergone a $3.3 million refurbishment. For the next five years, the Teatro Verde (www.teatro-verde.de), accessible by boat from St. Marks Square, will be the summer home for productions of Johann Strausss Night in Venice. Tickets start at 59 euros, about $81 at $1.38 to the euro. ...Last Thursday, JetBlue began direct flights to Nantucket from Kennedy Airport in New York to Nantucket, and starting June 14, Delta will offer the same. Travelers who want to take advantage of the new flights before the high season might be interested in several deals, all valid through June 21. For example, the Wauwinet (www.wauwinet.com), which recently opened a new spa, has rates starting at $260. Travelers with dogs might be interested in Harbor House Village (www.harborhousevillage.com, see special packages), which has a new, adjoining Woof Hotel with 12 pooch-friendly rooms. Starting rates are $117. Other preseason starting rates include $235 at the White Elephant (www.whiteelephanthotel.com) and $109 at the Jared Coffin House (www.jaredcoffinhouse.com). ... The Hyatt Regency Maui Resort and Spa (www.maui.hyatt.com) is offering a Kids Eat Free special. The promotion applies to families with children 12 and under who stay at least four nights there from June 11 to Aug. 25. For each paid adult meal, one free childrens meal will be provided  whether its breakfast, lunch or dinner  at four of the resorts restaurants; nightly room rates start at $414.

title: Give Me a Home Where the Lizards Can Roam
description: Larchmont

title: Danburys Freedom Fighters
description: In a fitting Memorial Day tribute, Danbury unveiled a monument yesterday to the 90 African-Americans from the city who fought in the Civil War, making it one of the few memorials in the state to mention the important role of black Americans in fighting for their freedom.

title: U.S. and British Airstrikes Hit Iraqi Militia
description: BAGHDAD, May 26  American, British and Iraqi forces battled fighters from the Mahdi Army militia in Baghdad and the southern port city of Basra on Saturday, with commanders resorting to airstrikes to suppress the militia in both cities, officials said.

title: South Korea Joins Rush to Build Ever Taller Buildings
description: INCHEON, South Korea  On a stretch of reclaimed land, near where Gen. Douglas MacArthurs forces came ashore during the Korean War, this city will build a towering monument to its rising ambitions: twin skyscrapers reaching 2,013 feet into the sky, higher than the tallest building in the world today.

title: A Handful of Soldiers, on Patrol
description: MAHMUDIYA, Iraq

title: Rebecca Kristol, Elliot Silver
description: Rebecca Louise Kristol, a daughter of Susan S. Kristol and William Kristol of McLean, Va., is to be married today to Elliot Adam Silver, a son of Dr. Orli R. Etingin and Dr. Jonathan S. Silver of New York. Rabbi David Kalender is to officiate at the National Building Museum in Washington.

title: For Idle Cabbies, a Healthy Way to Wait
description: Tanvir Ahmad, a 53-year-old taxi driver, was walking the perimeter of the four-acre lot that is reserved for cabs waiting for business at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Mets Green Still Hoping to Avoid Disabled List
description: MIAMI, May 26  A day after fracturing a bone in his right foot, Shawn Green said he remained hopeful that he would not need to go on the disabled list. But Green will not know for sure until Tuesday, when doctors in New York are scheduled to perform additional tests.

title: Where Every Generation Is First-Generation
description: Last June, Seyran Ates, a lawyer, was waiting for a U-Bahn train in Berlins Mockernbrucke subway station with a client for whom she had secured a divorce when the clients husband stormed onto the platform. He began beating up his ex-wife. Then he turned on Ates. Ates recalls seeing a number of men standing around, watching it all happen, as she danced from side to side with her attach case, trying to fend off his heavy punches and kicks. It was not the first time she had been attacked in the line of duty.

title: Baby Boomers Are Cashing In. So What?
description: WILL stocks suffer a multidecade bear market as the baby-boom generation sells its shares to support its retirement? Some have predicted such an outcome, but a new study  which projects huge growth in 401(k) assets in future decades  paints a far more sanguine picture.

title: Native Son
description: Fifteen is a terrible age for a boy, especially a boy with no parents, a trail of abusive foster homes, a predilection for arson and a face so full of acne even his friends call him Zits.

title: Correction: The Week Ahead: May 20 - 26
description: The Art entry last Sunday in the Week Ahead report misspelled the name of the school of art that includes Neo Rauch, whose work is the subject of a Met show. It is the New Leipzig School, not Liepzig.

title: Correction: Evening Hours
description: A picture caption with the Evening Hours column on May 13 misidentified a couple at the Mount Sinai Hospital Crystal Ball on May 3. They are Louise and Edgar Cullman  not Elle and Edgar Cullman Jr., who are the son and daughter-in law of Louise and Edgar.

title: Stocks Fall in a Week of Cloudy Economic News
description: After weeks of gains, the broad stock market gave up ground last week, while trading volumes declined in advance of the Memorial Day weekend.

title: For an Airport With a Past, a Future of Soccer Balls?
description: Hopewell Township

title: Not Going by Car? Get Directions, Anyway
description: Driving in a new city is never easy, particularly if you prefer sightseeing to map reading. But surfacing from a subway miles from your target destination can also be frustrating.

title: Thea Spyer and Edith Windsor
description: Thea Clara Spyer and Edith Schlain Windsor were married in Toronto on Tuesday. Justice Harvey Brownstone of the North Toronto Family Court officiated at the Sheraton Gateway Hotel.

title: A Pause to Refresh a Weary Dogmatist
description: CHARMING, modest and funny are not words usually associated with Lars von Trier, but they are exactly right for his playful new comedy, The Boss of It All. Made in just five weeks, and set mostly in an office building, the film follows a doofus actor hired to masquerade as the owner of a company whose employees have never set eyes on him. Such an engaging film is not what anyone would expect from this Danish director whose international breakthrough came in 1996 with the glorious but emotionally grueling Breaking the Waves and who more recently made two bleak, stylized films set in Depression-era America, Dogville (2003) and Manderlay (2005).

title: Now, Nassau Reconsiders Redistricting
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY has created a nonpartisan commission to redraw legislative districts after the 2010 census. Now it may be Nassau Countys turn.

title: In Just 20 Seconds, a Guitar to Go
description: AN airline pilots life can be a lonely one. Countless nights are spent in austere hotels, far from friends and family, with nothing but room service and cable television to ease the monotony.

title: Bullets in the Beer? Eliot Ness Must Be Back
description: A TRUCK armed with a huge battering ram speeds along a dark, rain-slicked Chicago street, then smashes through the seemingly impenetrable doors of an illegal brewery. Mobsters scatter as federal agents invade. Guns erupt. Bullets splinter vats of beer, flooding the floor. Bodies sprawl in frothy pools. And the gangbuster Eliot Ness notches another victory against the notorious Al Capone.

title: Asked to Serve Again, a Soldier Goes Down Fighting
description: HOLLYWOOD, Md.

title: Kimberly Kissam, David Lucchino
description: Kimberly Elizabeth Kissam, a daughter of Nancy L. Kissam and the late James B. Kissam of Wellesley Hills, Mass., was married yesterday to David Lawrence Lucchino, a son of Roberta F. Lucchino and Judge Frank J. Lucchino of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Shannan R. Vance-Ocampo, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Country Club in Brookline, Mass.

title: An Early Detour for Tour de France
description: In which country will the Tour de France start this year? It may sound like a trick question, but there have been five occasions in the races 104-year history when the route began outside France: in Amsterdam, Brussels, Berlin, Luxembourg and Dublin. This year, the race will start in London on July 7 with the prologue  a 4.9-mile time trial that starts by Trafalgar Square passes Big Ben, the Houses of Parliament, Westminster Abbey and Buckingham Palace.

title: An Ever-So-Tactful Auf Wiedersehen
description: Since DaimlerChrysler agreed to sell off its money-losing Chrysler division, Chrysler executives have had to tread a fine line in expressing their reactions to the automakers return to American ownership. After all, their old bosses in Germany will still be, in a sense, nearly 20 percent their new bosses. The private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management will own the other 80 percent of Chrysler.

title: Happy Campers
description: Whether or not a book can be judged by its cover, thats sometimes where it begins. The cover of My Holocaust resembles a childs board game, like Chutes and Ladders but with sprigs of barbed wire and playful figurines in striped prisoners garb. A cattle car sits near an ice cream truck. Hanging from colorful striped poles are the words Auschwitz and Birkenau. The concentration camp gate, where the Arbeit Macht Frei always went, now says A Novel.

title: Learning to Dance, One Chunk at a Time
description: LAST month in a studio at American Ballet Theater, Angel Corella was studying the former Ballet Theater star Gelsey Kirkland as she showed him sequences from the second act of The Sleeping Beauty, a new production set to have its premiere this week at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: To Love and to Cherish for All Eternity, or Not
description: I am no stranger to divorce. I am a two-time loser, having severed my unions with both the man I married when I was too young to know better and the man I wed when I was too work-obsessed to pay attention.

title: The Clear Blue Sky
description: No matter where you stood in the city, the air was thick after the towers fell: literally thick with the soot and stench of incinerated flesh that turned terror into a condition as inescapable as the weather. All bets were off. New Yorkers who always know where theyre going didnt know where to go. Cab drivers named Muhammad were now feared as the enemy within; strangers on the street were improbably embraced like family under a canopy of fliers for the missing. Such, for a while anyway, was the new normal, though the old normal began to reassert itself almost as soon as that facile catchphrase was coined. Today 9/11 carries so many burdens  of interpretation, of sentimentality, of politics, of war  that sometimes its hard to find the rubble of the actual event beneath the layers of edifice weve built on top of it. (Or built on top of all of it except ground zero.)

title: Remembering Soldiers, by Forgetting About Britney and Paris
description: LONG BEACH, N.Y.

title: Chvezs Move Against Critic Highlights Shift in Media
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 26  Arturo Sarmiento speaks upper-crust English polished at Sandhurst, Britains aristocratic military school. He made fortunes trading oil and importing whiskey. Now Mr. Sarmiento, just 35 and a staunch supporter of President Hugo Chvez, owns an expanding television network here.

title: Hollywood on the Lackawanna?
description: SCRANTON, Pa.

title: Yes, Mold Is Gross. But Is It Dangerous?; Choose Preservation Over Politics; Selecting Books for Children (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: An Artsy Spin on the Grand Tour
description: BASEL, Kassel or Venice? On a recent Thursday night, art collectors and hangers-on were mapping their summer travel plans over plastic glasses of wine at several art openings in New York City's Chelsea gallery district. Just ask David Maupin, co-owner of the Lehmann Maupin Gallery. He's heading to all three.

title: Maybe Sanjaya Was Channeling Her
description: BABY boomers will recall the brief but spectacular career of one Mrs. Miller, a matronly soul whose pitiful recordings of rock hits like Monday, Monday and Downtown became joke best sellers in the late 1960s. Well, she was just a piker compared to Florence Foster Jenkins, whose tune-free singing in the 30s mangled not only pop songs but also the music of Mozart, Verdi and Gounod.

title: Rebecca Antar, Matthew Novick
description: Rebecca Miriam Antar and Matthew Charles Novick are to be married today by Rabbi Michael S. Friedman at the Glen Cove Mansion in Glen Cove, N.Y.

title: Pinpointing the Plays That Really Swing a Game
description: Jeff Ma is best known as a card counter, a member of the rogue blackjack team from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the 1990s that won millions of dollars. Then its elaborate and reckless  if legal  schemes were discovered, and casinos barred Ma and his group from their tables.

title: Scam Artists
description: Fakes and Forgeries: The Art of Deception, at the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich, Conn., brings together more than 60 examples of creative duplicity, from Cycladic and Egyptian sculpture to Renaissance and modern paintings, works on paper and decorative arts. Among them are pieces that constitute some of historys more esteemed feats of artistic deceit, including paintings by the great Dutch forger Han van Meegeren that fooled old master experts for decades.

title: The Alchemists Moment: The Reclusive Mr. Polke
description: Cologne, Germany

title: Blood and Crashes? Sounds Like Lynch
description: Regina, Saskatchewan

title: Jennifer Maskell, Mark Carney
description: Jennifer Lynn Maskell, the daughter of Patricia Maskell and Stephen J. Maskell of McLean, Va., was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Francis Carney, the son of Suga Carney and Joseph P. Carney of Fairfax, Va. The Rev. William J. Donnelly, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the King Family Vineyards in Crozet, Va.

title: Grade-School Girls, Grown-Up Gossip
description: WHEN Britney Spears shaved off her signature blond locks, Alexis Gursky, 9, found herself wondering not why Ms. Spears picked up a razor in the first place, but why she did not do more with the hair she shaved off.

title: How Confidential Are Applications?
description: Q Are there any laws in New York that govern how a co-op board handles buyers private financial information?

title: Darling Likes Being No. 2 on Bondss List
description: Twenty-one years later, Ron Darling still remembers the pitch that he threw to a young, lean rookie on the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Doors Open
description: Chapter 3: The Auction House

title: Middle School Syndrome Undergoes a Reversal
description: SCORES on state tests at Westlake Middle School were disappointing for years, and school officials had largely written them off as middle school syndrome, a mysterious decline in achievement between elementary school and eighth grade that seemed to afflict most schools in the state.

title: Grooming a Handwriting Champion
description: MELVILLE, N.Y.

title: New Yorks Powerful Ghosts
description: New York State government has two parts, one public and one carefully tucked out of sight.

title: 6 Attacks in City Leave 4 Dead and 2 Critically Wounded
description: Four men have been killed and two others critically wounded in a spate of unrelated attacks throughout the city since late Friday, the police said.

title: Lisa Schorr, Alexander Kaplan
description: Lisa Schorr, the daughter of Lisbeth B. Schorr and Daniel Schorr of Washington, is to be married today in Washington to Alexander Isaac Kaplan, the son of Phyllis Kaplan and Edward Kaplan of Memphis. Rabbi David Saperstein is to officiate at Evermay, a Federal-era house.

title: All Hail the Green Cabs
description: By doubling mileage requirements for city taxicabs, Mayor Michael Bloomberg seems to have locked in one piece of a potentially historic environmental legacy  not the most ambitious piece, but a significant one nonetheless. His action will transform New Yorks taxi fleet from the most polluting in the nation to one of the cleanest, and do so in five years, making the city a leader as municipalities compete to cut carbon emissions.

title: Seeking Signs of Literary Life in Iran
description: When I moved to Iran in 2000 to work as a journalist, I aspired to belong to a literary circle not unlike that of the engaged women of Azar Nafisis Reading Lolita in Tehran, who found relief from their authoritarian society in the imaginative world of novels. That bookstores did not exist as such  there were only bookstore/stationery stores, or bookstore/toy stores  was the first sign my plan might not work. I initially mistook Tehrans most popular bookstore, with its windows full of weathered copper pots and other bric-a-brac, for an antique shop. Inside, the floor space dedicated to books was roughly a quarter of that taken up by kilims, cactuses and Lego sets. Im embarrassed to call myself a bookseller, one store owner told me recently, gazing at the wall of Hello Kitty accessories that dominated his shop. In the hour we spent talking, customers came in to buy watch batteries, a condolence card, wrapping paper and a compass. Not a single person bought a book.

title: Bill Adds Fuel to Flames in a Divided Border State
description: PHOENIX, May 23  Here in Arizona, where fighting over immigration comes as naturally as the desert heat, the Senate bill to overhaul immigration laws has ignited a particularly ardent round of fire breathing.

title: Its Spring. Somebody Tell the Buyers.
description: ITS spring, the traditional time for hope and growth in residential real estate sales. But beyond the borders of New York City, there are indications that a wintry chill besets the market in much of the region.

title: To Smoke or Not? Thereby Hangs a Tale
description: CLAUDIA ELMHIRST cant wait to read a novel again. When shes memorizing lines, the British actress doesnt touch a book, though that usually means only a few weeks of burying herself in a script. Since February of 2006, however, she has been immersed in Intimate Exchanges, a 750-page epic by Alan Ayckbourn that asks 2 actors to play 10 characters in 8 interconnected plays. Each play has two possible endings, and Ms. Elmhirst and her co-star, Bill Champion, have committed every variation to memory.

title: Out of Retirement and Into Uncertainty
description: THINK of retirement and a picture emerges of a grand send-off at the office, followed by travel, hobbies, grandchildren, and a pension and a Social Security check to pay for it all. But after awhile, the retirement fund may start to feel a little skimpy, or the golf course a little dull  or both  and the concept of returning to work becomes, well, more than a concept.

title: When the Desert Calls
description: ALAINA DEMARTINI decided to trade the San Francisco chill and fog for palm trees and bright stars in an open sky. So last year, she and her husband, David, a retired electrician, moved to the house in Palm Springs, Calif., that they bought as a second home five years ago.

title: My Year of Vegetables
description: A few years ago, the novelist Barbara Kingsolver packed her husband and two daughters into a car and left their home in Tucson for good, resettling on a farm in southern Appalachia. Their intention was to spend a year of their new rural life eating only what they could grow themselves or buy from local suppliers. The plan was no whim. Kingsolver and her husband, Steven L. Hopp, a biologist who teaches environmental studies, had been raising fruit and vegetables at Hopps farm every summer since they met.

title: Bread and Pastries, Freshly Baked
description: Mozzicato de Pasquale claims to have served generations of customers, and considering that the de Pasquale part of the business (which was bought by the Mozzicato family in 1975) has been baking bread for Hartford residents since 1908, that is no idle boast. The bakery turns out fresh loaves of Tuscan and rye bread, but good as they are, those are just a bit of crust in a wide range of baked goods that have made Mozzicato a much loved establishment.

title: Good News for Middle Schoolers
description: New York moved to the forefront of the state school reform movement when it raised standards for both students and teachers and instituted rigorous tests during the late 1990s. Test scores have risen since then. But the latest reading scores offer the most hopeful sign yet that the reforms are having an impact  not just in the early grades but also in the notoriously troubled middle school years.

title: Familiar Aches Put Damon on Bench
description: The Yankees played most of yesterdays 3-1 loss against the Los Angeles Angels without Johnny Damon, their regular center fielder and leadoff batter. Damon left Friday nights game in the seventh inning with sore calves and pain in his right Achilles tendon.

title: New Jersey Man Back Home After 3-Nation African Ordeal
description: A 24-year-old New Jersey man who traveled to Somalia to help establish an Islamic state there but was instead imprisoned by three different nations, was released Friday and returned home yesterday, his father said.

title: The New Tributes, and an Old Triangle
description: HAVE all the great songs already been written? That might justify the latest outpouring of tributes and tribute albums: remakes, with and without conceptual overlay, of material that other musicians admire but arent afraid to transform. In the age of the sample, the remix and countless YouTube parodies, entire songs and sometimes entire albums are still being recycled and reclaimed, and musicians are presenting themselves as critics, curators and  above all  fans.

title: Creeping Equality, a Bit of Fraternity and a Slick of Asterisks at Indy
description: Weary of being ignored by disc jockeys with man crushes on groups like Aerosmith, Sarah McLachlan and her star crew of femme rockers took the American stage in their own hands as they led a celebration of ovulation in the late 90s.

title: Working Out the Kinks, for a Price
description: ITS mid-May and, at the rehearsal studios at 890 Broadway, 25 actors are presenting the Broadway-bound musical Cry-Baby to an invited audience of about 150. The cast, clad largely in street clothes, performs the show aided by little more than three musicians, five wooden platforms, several tables and some cardboard-cutout-style props.

title: Saluting a Maker (Not a Taker) of Photographs
description: Since his death in 1984, Ansel Adams has earned an almost slavish devotion among photography fans. It is easy to see why.

title: Crashing the Finals Party: The Rowdy Ducks
description: The veteran defenseman Sean ODonnell spoke up during last weeks semifinals, complaining of dirty play and a lack of respect for opponents on N.H.L. rinks.

title: Take This Job and Love It
description: EVERY few months on Rider Diaries, an online forum for New York transit buffs, someone posts a message with a subject line like IVE BEEN CALLED!!!! That particular exclamation appeared in October 2005; its writer, a skinny 20-year-old named Jason Brown, crowed that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had finally reached my number.

title: To See You Again
description: Ailsa Kelman, the heroine of Margaret Drabbles 17th novel, first appears in a dress in which she gleamed and rippled with smooth muscle, like a fish. This costume choice is a happy accident because Ailsa has been asked to announce, in front of a large London gathering and an even larger television audience, the winner of the Plunkett Prize for a general science book with a vaguely defined ecological or environmental message  which turns out to be Hermaphrodite: Sea Change and Sex Change, a study of gender-bending in diverse marine species. While she reads the citation in the hall of a natural history museum, beneath a giant fiberglass manta ray, the jaws of sharks, fixed in the gape of their everlasting grins, display their triple rows of teeth.

title: That Grouper on the Menu? Turns Out It Was a Fish Tale
description: MADEIRA BEACH, Fla., May 23  On the weathered deck of Dockside Daves, a table of tourists waits for the sandwich that has long been as much a part of the beach experience here as the sunshine. Then it arrives, a half pound of fried filet of grouper, fresh from the dock, topped with lettuce, a slice of fresh tomato and splayed on an open bun.

title: With Tayshaun Prince
description: Forward Tayshaun Prince is averaging 15.2 points in the playoffs for the Detroit Pistons, who hold a two-games-to-none lead over the Cleveland Cavaliers in the Eastern Conference finals. The 6-foot-9 Prince has a remarkable arm span of 7-2. Among his teammates he is known as the go-to guy for league news, current events and even celebrity gossip. MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

title: Letters
description: Congress and Private Equity

title: Correction: My Dear Fellow Species
description: An article last Sunday excerpting the letters of Charles Darwin misstated the age of The Origin of Species. It will be 150 years old in 2009, not next year.

title: The Gospel of Dobson
description: James Dobson is the Christian rights most powerful leader. While the Moral Majority and the Christian Coalition have crumbled, Dobsons organization, Focus on the Family, has prospered. His multimillion-dollar-a-year media empire includes a daily radio show, with him as the host, that reaches millions of listeners, as well as a rapid-response telephone and letter-writing operation.

title: Sicko, Castro and the 120 Years Club

In fact, her class wasnt suffering through the standardized ordeal, just tiptoeing around while others did. The adequate yearly progress (A.Y.P.) assessments mandated by the No Child Left Behind legislation, which was enacted in 2002 with high hopes of closing the achievement gap for minorities, dont kick in until third grade. But when it comes to tests, N.C.L.B. is fulfilling its inclusive mission all too well: nobody  not even kids too young to be filling in the bubbles yet  escapes the atmosphere of exam-induced edginess.

title: The Perfect Summer: England 1911, Just Before the Storm
description: On the first day of May 1911 temperatures throughout England began to rise, and everyone agreed that the world was becoming exceedingly beautiful. The cold weather of April had held back the flowering of many of the spring bulbs, and with the warmth of the first week of summer there had been a sudden burst of growth. The verges of the country lanes were frothing with cow parsley while late primroses still dotted the roadside banks. Top-hatted men strolling in the London parks had decided it was warm enough to abandon their scarves. Straw-bonneted women had gathered up country bluebells to sell in wilting bunches on street corners in the smarter parts of London, and window boxes were already spilling over with scarlet geraniums and marguerites. Tiny pink flowers covered the branches that would later produce crab apples, while the ocean of white blossoms produced by other fruit trees had prompted Country Life to declare that 'few people can remember any parallel to its profusion.' England was plump with promise.

title: The Occupation of Iraq
description: Conflicts and wars fought on its territory have always been the lot of Iraq. It has had the geographic misfortune of lying across the fault lines of civilisations and empires, and its peoples have suffered the waves of conquerors and battles fought over its lands. The ebb and flow of powers that controlled its destiny always left behind a residue that helped to form the profile of the modern Iraqi. But these were not accretions that melded together to form a common sense of nationhood. The shared history and experiences of Iraqis did not give rise to unifying national myths. The legacy of pre-Islamic civilisations - of Sumer, Babylon and Nineveh - was not one that could be readily adapted to the formation of national identity. The pride that came from knowing that Iraq was the land that gave humanity settled agriculture, its first cities and the alphabet, was not internalised. Iraq's ancient history featured only on the periphery of the identity of Muslim Iraqis. Various modern governments have tried to make the connection and continuity with this heritage - sometimes ludicrously, as when Saddam Hussein appropriated the heritage of the lawmaker Hammurrabi and stuck his name on the (rebuilt) walls of Babylon. But it was never pursued with the intent of forming a national consciousness.

title: The Canon
description: When the second of her two children turned thirteen, my sister decided that it finally was time to let their membership lapse in two familiar family haunts: the science museum and the zoo. These were kiddie places, she told me. Her children now had more mature tastes. They liked refined forms of entertainment - art museums, the theater, ballet. Isn't that something? My sister's children's bodies were lengthening, and so were their attention spans. They could sit for hours at a performance of Macbeth without so much as checking the seat bottom for fossilized wads of gum. No more of this mad pinball pinging from one hands-on science exhibit to the next, pounding on knobs to make artificial earthquakes, or cranking gears to see Newton's laws in motion, or something like that; who bothers to read the explanatory placards anyway? And, oops, hmm, hey, Mom, this thing seems to have stopped working! No more aping the gorillas or arguing over the structural basis of a polar bear's white coat or wondering about the weird goatee of drool gathering on the dromedary's chin. Sigh. How winged are the slippers of time, how immutably forward point their dainty steel-tipped toe boxes. And how common is this middle-class rite of passage into adulthood: from mangabeys to Modigliani, T. rex to Oedipus Rex.

title: The Lizard Cage
description: The boy was twelve years old when he entered the Hsayadaw's monastery school. As the newest novice, his became the smoothest bare head; he was given dark ochre robes and taught how to wear them. With his scavenger's eye for opportunity, he saw how lucky he was. The men here gave him food, and a mat to sleep on beneath a wooden roof. He saw also that the school was a poor place, but the monks who ran it were generous with what little they had.

title: Animal, Vegetable, Miracle
description: This story about good food begins in a quick-stop convenience market. It was our family's last day in Arizona, where I'd lived half my life and raised two kids for the whole of theirs. Now we were moving away forever, taking our nostalgic inventory of the things we would never see again: the bush where the roadrunner built a nest and fed lizards to her weird-looking babies; the tree Camille crashed into learning to ride a bike; the exact spot where Lily touched a dead snake. Our driveway was just the first tributary on a memory river sweeping us out.

title: The Last Tycoons
description: Even among the great Wall Street firms-Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and Merrill Lynch-Lazard Frres & Co. stood apart, explicitly priding itself on being different from, and superior to, its competitors. For 157 years, Lazard had punched above its weight. Unlike other Wall Street banks, it competed with intellectual rather than financial capital and through a hard-won tradition of privacy and independence. Its strategy, put simply, was to offer clients the wisdom of its Great Men, the finest and most experienced collection of investment bankers the world had ever known. They risked no capital, offering only the raw Darwinian power of their ideas. The better the idea, and the insights and tactics required to achieve the result contemplated by it, the greater was Lazard's currency as a valued and trusted adviser-and the larger were the piles of money the Great Men hauled out of the firm and into their swelling bank accounts. The lucky few men-yes, always men-at Wall Street's summit have always been portrayed as ambitious and brilliant on the one hand and unscrupulous and ruthless on the other. But the secret history of Lazard Frres & Co., the world's most elite and enigmatic investment bank, twists parts of this conventional wisdom into knots of unfathomable complexity. The Great Men chronicled herein amassed huge fortunes-to be sure-but they refused to admit to anyone, least of all to themselves, that their pursuit of these riches led to relentless infighting. Instead they spoke, without irony, of being part of a Florentine guild and of advice whispered to heads of state and to CEOs of the world's most powerful corporations, while all the time attempting to preserve the mythical special idea that was Lazard. They also, to a person, craved an equally elusive chimera: the assurance that somehow, despite everything, they alone had remained virtuous.

title: The Sea Lady
description: The winning book was about fish, and to present it, she appeared to have dressed herself as a mermaid, in silver sequinned scales. Her bodice was close-fitting, and the metallic skirt clung to her solid hips before it flared out below the knees, concealing what might once have been her tail. Her bared brown shoulders and womanly bosom rose powerfully, as she drew in her breath and gazed across the heads of the seated diners at the distant autocue. She gleamed and rippled with smooth muscle, like a fish. She was boldly dressed, for a woman in her sixties, but she came of a bold generation, and she seemed confident that the shadowy shoals of her cohort were gathered around her in massed support as she flaunted herself upon the podium. She felt the dominion. It pumped through her, filling her with the adrenalin of exposure. She was ready for her leap.

title: Falling Man
description: It was not a street anymore but a world, a time and space of falling ash and near night. He was walking north through rubble and mud and there were people running past holding towels to their faces or jackets over their heads. They had handkerchiefs pressed to their mouths. They had shoes in their hands, a woman with a shoe in each hand, running past him. They ran and fell, some of them, confused and ungainly, with debris coming down around them, and there were people taking shelter under cars.

While acknowledging that he didnt have the celebrity status or the money of some of his top Democratic rivals, he called himself the insurgent candidate who could bring the country together because of his experiences as a lawmaker, a governor (of New Mexico) and as a former United Nations ambassador and member of the Clinton cabinet.

title: Barack Obama's Basketball Family
description: From 2007: Craig Robinson, basketball coach at Brown University - and Barack Obamas brother-in-law - talks about Mr. Obamas game and its impact on his political career.

title: Candidates Matches Begin With Two Victories and Six Draws
description: There was a great deal of gritty, fighting chess as eight matches to select candidates for the world championship got underway today in Elista, Kalmykia. The winners of the matches will play each other to determine which four will qualify for a championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

title: Stretching Executive Power in Wartime
description: The Constitution has never greatly bothered any wartime president, wrote Francis Biddle, F.D.R.s attorney general during World War II. Biddle was writing about Roosevelts shameful 1942 decision to evacuate Japanese-Americans from the Pacific Coast and place them in internment camps. But Biddles comment applies to all presidents in times of crisis. National survival or, perhaps more accurately, the presidents perception of national survival always takes precedence. George W. Bush has been no exception.

title: Clearly Anti-Competitive
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer vetoed his fourth bill last week, rejecting an extension of a law limiting the number of check-cashing facilities in any one area. Since 1994, new check-cashing facilities have been banned within three-tenths of a mile of an existing one. This year, the Legislature voted to extend a 2002 law that broadened this prohibition to other financial institutions that open branches mainly devoted to check cashing, including banks and credit unions.

title: Sticking Points on Authorities Bill
description: A battle looms this week between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the Legislature over the details of a bill that would bring new levels of disclosure and oversight to the states hundreds of public authorities. Though there is broad agreement on a number of issues, the Legislature favors allowing the state comptroller to approve all authority contracts and giving subpoena power to the office that monitors authorities finances. The Spitzer administration, in private talks with lawmakers, balked at those positions.

title: Drop and Give the Vending Machine 20
description: Watch those vending machines, school hall monitors. A new regulation proposed by the governor says that before students are allowed to buy Gatorade or other sports drinks, they must have engaged in vigorous athletic activity lasting for more than one hour. The requirement is included in Gov. Eliot Spitzers array of proposals aimed at making food served and sold in schools healthier.

title: Resistance on DNA Collection
description: Assembly Democrats are resisting Gov. Eliot Spitzers proposal to expand DNA collection to all misdemeanor convictions without taking more steps that they say will protect the wrongfully accused.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 6 A.M. (TCM) COMMAND DECISION (1948) Turner Classic Movies salutes the armed forces with a Memorial Day marathon starring some A-list heroes, beginning with Clark Gable in this colorized World War II drama about a general who must battle his own government to send his planes deeper into Germany. The tribute continues with Humphrey Bogart in Action in the North Atlantic (1943), at 8; From Here to Eternity (1953), the Oscar-winning romance with Montgomery Clift, Donna Reed and, above, Deborah Kerr and Burt Lancaster, at 10:30; Sergeant York (1941), the Gary Cooper classic, at 12:30 p.m.; Michael Caine and Laurence Olivier in The Battle of Britain (1969), at 3; Where Eagles Dare (1969), starring Richard Burton and Clint Eastwood as fearless fliers, at 5:15; A Soldiers Story (1984), in which Howard E. Rollins Jr. plays an African-American officer assigned to investigate a racially charged murder, at 8; the William Holden classics Stalag 17 (1953), at 10, and The Bridge on the River Kwai, at 12:15 a.m.; and Wake Island (1942), with Brian Donlevy as a Marine major trying to keep the Japanese off his island base, at 3. Day breaks on a more melodic note with Tab Hunter and Frankie Avalon in Operation Bikini (1963) at 4:30.

title: Morning Fire Kills Three in a Home in New Jersey
description: An early-morning fire tore through a home in Spotswood, N.J., yesterday, killing three people inside, including a man and woman who were to be married in a few days, officials and neighbors said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about a decision by a New Hampshire legislative panel to reject a seat belt law misstated the states rate of seat belt use and referred imprecisely to its rank in the nation. The rate is 63.5 percent, not 49.6 percent. New Hampshire and Wyoming  not just New Hampshire  rank last.

title: The Scent of a Man, Bought by a Woman
description: It is an industry rule of thumb that womens perfumes account for two-thirds of annual sales of prestige fragrances  that is, high-end fragrances sold in department stores or boutiques, rather than drugstores.

title: African Energy Celebrated Ebulliently and Symbolically
description: DanceAfrica is always a trip, not only through African nations and their cultures but also into another world that proudly claims those cultures as its own. Chuck Davis, who founded this yearly festival 30 years ago, was the perfect towering, irrepressible guide, easing everyone into chanting, hugging and shaking hands during Friday nights show at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on the Street Scene page of Business Day on Friday about the presence of financial firms at the Cannes Film Festival referred incorrectly to the role of the studio Summit Entertainment in the film Pompeii. While Summit negotiated financing for the film, it did not invest in it.

title: In Queens, Classes in Mandarin Are Also Lessons in Adaptation
description: Something extraordinary happened to Maria Farren of Flushing, Queens, on a recent trip to the grocery store. From the familiar background chatter of people speaking Chinese, a syllable leapt out from nowhere. It was not that she understood the word  she didnt  but the sound was familiar. That was enough of a surprise that she paused in mid-aisle.

title: In Fierce Competition, Google Finds Novel Ways to Feed Hiring Machine
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  On a spring Saturday, about 90 students from Stanford and as many from the University of California, Berkeley, converged on Googles corporate campus for a day of spirited team competition over mind-bending puzzles, Lego building problems and video games.

title: Militants Widen Reach as Terror Seeps Out of Iraq
description: When Muhammad al-Darsi got out of prison in Libya last year after serving time for militant activities, he had one goal: killing Americans in Iraq.

title: Looking Ahead
description: A DAY OFF All banks and stock markets in the United States are closed today in observance of the Memorial Day holiday. They will reopen on Tuesday.

title: Irish Classic Is Still a Hit (in Calfskin, Not Paperback)
description: DUBLIN, May 27  For a manuscript written 1,200 years ago and revered as a wonder of the Western world practically ever since, little is known about the Book of Kells and its splendidly illustrated Gospels in Latin. But the book may be about to surrender a few of its many secrets.

title: A Divide That Begins in Little League
description: As the nation continues to celebrate the desegregation of Major League Baseball in 1947, the enduring question is why African-Americans have all but vanished from the baseball landscape.

title: Giants Look to 2 Intriguing Pitchers
description: The San Francisco Giants will be in town on Tuesday night, and that means that Barry Bonds and his controversial pursuit of home run supremacy will take center stage at Shea Stadium. But anyone spending too much time jeering him in left field may miss the Giants two intriguing pitching attractions, Tim Lincecum and Barry Zito, who are scheduled to start the first two games of this series with the Mets.

title: Sometimes Its Over Even When It Aint
description: Without realizing it, about half a century ago Yogi Berra, baseballs old philosopher, described the perilous situation of these Yankees. Asked about the shadows in left field at Yankee Stadium when all World Series games were played in the afternoon, he shrugged.

title: How Baseball Moved Its 24-Hour Channel Into Scoring Position
description: Major League Baseball plotted for two decades to create a 24-hour channel, and last month it got its way after months of tortuous negotiations with DirecTV and cable operators.

title: The Educated Giant
description: Taishan, China

title: At BET, Fighting the Rerun
description: Last week, executives from Black Entertainment Television walked through the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles, laying out the plans for the annual BET Music Awards on June 26. The broadcast has become the highest-rated award show on cable, topping the MTV Music Awards, ESPNs ESPY Awards and the Nickelodeon Kids Choice Awards.

title: Honoring an Avant-Garde Eminence of the Saxophone
description: I didnt expect to blossom like I did, the saxophonist Sam Rivers said at the Miller Theater on Friday, reflecting on his 60-year career. His quip sent ripples of appreciative laughter through the crowd, which was generously stocked with musicians, and generally skewed toward extreme jazz erudition.

title: Sosa Rebounds as Mets Sweep Marlins
description: MIAMI, May 27  They know that last season was last season, and this year is this year, but the Mets find it instructive to recall their electric start in 2006 and compare it with how things stand after the first 49 games of 2007.

title: Plunge in CD Sales Shakes Up Big Labels
description: Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band, the Beatles album often cited as the greatest pop recording in music history, received a thoroughly modern 40th-anniversary salute last week when singers on American Idol belted out their own versions of its songs live on the shows season finale.

title: Demmes Tales of Ordinary Heroes in New Orleans
description: Victims and despair were what Jonathan Demme expected to find when he headed to New Orleans with his camera. Instead, he said, he discovered tough-minded heroes, who became the stars of his unadorned film Right to Return: New Home Movies from the Lower Ninth Ward. Beginning tonight Tavis Smiley will turn over the entire week of his PBS program, The Tavis Smiley Show, to broadcast parts of the film.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page headline on Saturday about concepts being developed by the Bush administration to reduce United States combat forces in Iraq by as much as half next year referred imprecisely to the overall effect on troop levels. As the story indicated, removing half of the 20 combat brigades now in Iraq by the end of 2008, one of the ideas under consideration, would cut the total number of troops there by about one-third, from 146,000 to roughly 100,000, not by 50 percent. That is because many of the troops that would remain in Iraq are in training or support units, not in combat forces.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Thursday about an announcement by Silverio A. Vega, the Cuban-born mayor of West New York, N.J., that the annual Cuban Parade of New Jersey would not be allowed to pass through his town gave the incorrect date in some copies for Mr. Vegas news conference. It was last Monday, not Wednesday.

title: Charles Nelson Reilly, Tony-Winning Comic Actor, Dies at 76
description: Charles Nelson Reilly, who acted and directed on Broadway but came to be best known for his campy television appearances on talk shows and Match Game, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 76 and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: NBC Said to Be in Talks to Remove Program Chief
description: NBC Universal is in talks to sever its ties with Kevin Reilly, the president of its entertainment division and the networks chief programmer, just three months after extending his contract for three years, several executives informed of the discussions said yesterday.

title: Dance, Gallerina, Dance: A Gimlet-Eyed Look Through an Art World Keyhole
description: The heroine of Danielle Ganeks captivatingly titled novel Lulu Meets God and Doubts Him is a gallerina. That is, she works at a Chelsea art gallery as part of the dcor. The rest of the setting includes a concrete desk, a stainless-steel slab used as a counter, one calla lily in a vase and a white leather guest book where visitors can leave their addresses so the gallery can send them helpful bulletins. In a friendlier art world perhaps the gallery would.

title: Manhattan: Man Fatally Shot
description: A 27-year-old man was shot in the back and killed early yesterday in an East Harlem apartment, the police said. The man, identified as Delvon Hairston, of 2370 Second Avenue, was shot at about 12:20 a.m. in an apartment at 2390 Second Avenue, the police said. He was taken to North General Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. Investigators were seeking three suspects yesterday, the police said.

title: Centereach: Mother Charged With Snorting Heroin Near Her Son
description: A woman was arrested at a Wal-Mart store on Saturday after she was caught snorting heroin while pushing her 3-year-old son in a shopping cart, the Suffolk County police said. The woman, Stacy Roe, 35, of Farmingville, was arrested and charged with endangering the welfare of a child and criminal possession of a controlled substance. She was seen on surveillance video snorting a substance through a straw while pushing the cart inside the store at 6:10 p.m., the police said. When the police confronted her, she admitted she had just snorted heroin and said she had a bag of the substance in her wallet, the police said. The woman told officers she was shopping for a toy train for her son, the police said. The child was removed and placed in the custody of his father, and the case was referred to Child Protective Services, the police said. Ms. Roe was ordered to be in court on July 17.

title: Northwestern Keeps Its Hold on Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 27  After an unexpected start and unaccustomed frailty on defense, Northwestern recovered Sunday night to deliver a familiar result, winning its third consecutive N.C.A.A. championship in womens lacrosse.

title: In Cannes, a Romanian Takes Home the Fronds
description: CANNES, France, May 27  The message from the Cannes Film Festival juries was clear: Romania rules.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on April 26 about the restricted activities of city councilmen chosen in municipal elections in Saudi Arabia two years ago attributed an erroneous distinction to those elections. While they were the first in which all men outside the military could vote (women are not allowed to vote), the elections were not the first ever held in Saudi Arabia. (A far more limited form of voting was introduced in Mecca in 1925, which lasted for roughly a decade. In later years, until the 1960s, some councilmen were elected in selected cities by small groups of voters.) A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message the day the article ran; this correction was delayed for research.

title: Year After Scandal, a Sport Thrives
description: BALTIMORE, May 27  Jim Jennings, the commissioner of the National Lacrosse League, remembers sitting in a meeting with a potential advertiser about a year ago.

title: Memorial Day
description: NEW YORK

title: 3 Afghan Employees of French Aid Group Freed by the Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 27  Three Afghan employees of a French aid organization, who had been held hostage for seven weeks by Taliban insurgents, were freed unharmed after local residents intervened, the governor of Nimruz Province, Ghulam Dastagir Azad, said Sunday.

title: In Ruse, Vancouver Officer Poses as Reporter to Arrest Protester
description: David Cunningham, a prominent protester who heads the Anti-Poverty Committee in Vancouver, British Columbia, recently received a call from someone who said he was a reporter, Peter MacKay, from the free daily 24 Hours Vancouver.

title: Fans of Canceled Jericho Mobilize With a Very Literal Protest
description: Soon after CBS said this month that it had canceled the drama series Jericho, angry fans started sending individual bags of nuts to executives at the networks offices in New York and Los Angeles as a protest.

title: An Even Better Farm Bill
description: For years, reform-minded legislators have been trying to rid the country of a farm subsidy program that lavishes huge amounts of money on relatively few producers, compromises the environment, penalizes third-world farmers and fouls up trade negotiations. With the farm bill set to expire this year, the Bush administration has already proposed several excellent reforms. Now legislators in both houses are offering another approach that actually improves on the administrations.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on May 15 about a study by ACT, the Iowa testing organization, on the effectiveness of college preparatory courses, misstated a finding of the report. In analyzing about 1.2 million high students who took the ACT college admissions test before graduating last June, the study found that 26 percent of those who took the core curriculum were college ready; it did not find that 26 percent of all students tested were college-ready.

title: Wealthy Enclave Offers Windfall for Candidates
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 25  Senator John McCain made his pitch to this gilded shoreline suburb back in April. Former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts came on May 7, followed one night later by former President Bill Clinton on behalf of his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. Last weekend, it was back-to-back appearances by Senator Barack Obama, topped off on Sunday with a visit from Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor.

title: Alone in a Citys AIDS Battle, Hoping for Backup
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  The nations capital is the only city in the country barred by federal law from using local tax money to finance needle exchange programs. It is also the city with the fastest-growing number of new AIDS cases.

title: Trying to Make Move for the Lead, Patrick Runs Out of Time
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 27  Danica Patrick, who caused a stir two years ago by becoming the first woman to lead the Indianapolis 500, did not lead a lap Sunday and finished eighth in the race for the second consecutive year. She was not pleased.

title: What the History of Memorial Day Teaches About Honoring the War Dead
description: Memorial Day got its start after the Civil War, when freed slaves and abolitionists gathered in Charleston, S.C., to honor Union soldiers who gave their lives to battle slavery. The holiday was so closely associated with the Union side, and with the fight for emancipation, that Southern states quickly established their own rival Confederate Memorial Day.

title: From Realm of Pure Dance to Enchanted Fairyland
description: What conjunction of the stars determined that Bach and Handel were both born in 1685, Verdi and Wagner in 1813, and George Balanchine and Frederick Ashton in 1904? Impossible to imagine Western classical music without the first pair, Romantic opera without the second, modern classical ballet without the third. Balanchine, working principally in New York from 1934, and Ashton, working mainly in London from 1926, achieved their finest works when moving in separate orbits, but their paths often crossed over the decades.

title: Living on Iraq Time
description: York, Pa.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Little Older and a Bit Creakier, Skaters Boogie on in Central Park
description: With blasts of disco, tight, flashy costumes and acrobatic flourishes, the skate dancers took over a paved oval in Central Park as rebels. Now, 30 years later, they are part of its establishment, and some of the heavily padded knees are a bit creaky.

description: Doctors at Marthas Vineyard Hospital, the only hospital on the small island off Massachusetts, knew only one drug had been shown to work for stroke, tPA. But, until they adopted a new telemedicine system for hospitals like theirs, they had not been giving it to the 25 or so stroke patients they cared for each year.

title: Militant Hints at Resolution in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 27  As negotiations continued Sunday over the standoff between Lebanese troops and Fatah al Islam militants holed up in a Palestinian refugee camp in northern Lebanon, a spokesman for the militant group signaled that a compromise could be possible to ease the two-week-old siege.

title: A Twosome Reminiscent of the Stockton-Malone Era
description: SALT LAKE CITY, May 27  Outside Energy Solutions Arena, a pair of towering bronze statues cast expansive shadows. Karl Malone, all chiseled muscle, seems to be driving toward the clouds. John Stockton, his gaze fixed in a state of eternal determination, is in midpass.

title: Mr. Spitzers DNA Proposal
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer is right to want to expand New York States use of DNA evidence to solve crimes and exonerate the innocent. But, disappointingly, his proposed plan includes an unrelated  and unworthy  new provision that would seriously undermine his declared goal of minimizing injustice.

title: Facing Inquiry, Japanese Official Commits Suicide
description: TOKYO, May 28  Japans agriculture minister, Toshikatsu Matsuoka, killed himself on Monday, just hours before he was to face parliamentary questioning about a political finance scandal, government officials said.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 27  The actress Ashley Judd, her long hair matted by the third rain shower of a long day, ran barefoot down pit road Sunday night to greet her husband, Dario Franchitti, the lesser known of the celebrity couple.

description: BAGHDAD, May 27  Two more American soldiers have died from roadside bombs, the American military said Sunday, as American forces decided to run DNA tests on a body that could be that of one of the remaining two missing soldiers seized in an ambush on May 12 south of Baghdad.

description: While the situation was certainly not as emotionally charged as when Time magazine darkened O. J. Simpsons mug shot on its cover a decade ago, three magazines were defending themselves against accusations last week that they had doctored their covers  and one retouched celebrity cried foul.

description: CLEVELAND, May 27  Drenched in sweat and his jaw clenched in pure resolve, LeBron James walked off the court without seeing or hearing anybody but himself.

description: ALBANY  Assembly Democrats are resisting Gov. Eliot Spitzers proposal to expand DNA collection to all misdemeanor convictions without taking more steps that they say will protect the wrongfully accused.

description: Lindsay Lohan Arrested in Car Crash

description: WASHINGTON, May 27  When people think, if they ever do, about a Supreme Court justices daily routine, many undoubtedly envision a life spent contemplating the great issues: due process, equal protection and other resonant constitutional concepts.

description: When lawmakers return from their Memorial Day recess, fixing the alternative minimum tax, once and for all, should be at the top of their agenda.

description: PARIS, May 28  Seconds after his match ended today, Nikolay Davydenko wrapped himself in a fuzzy blue towel and ran off the court as the rain began to pour, yet again, at the French Open.

title: Indar Jit Rikhye, 86, U.N. Adviser and Peacekeeper Trainer, Is Dead
description: UNITED NATIONS, May 25  Indar Jit Rikhye, a major general in the Indian Army who was a key military adviser to United Nations peacekeepers around the world and then founding president of a research institute devoted to training peacekeepers, died May 21 in Charlottesville, Va. He was 86.

title: Trust and Betrayal
description: In this place where valor sleeps, we are reminded why America has always gone to war reluctantly, because we know the costs of war. Thats what President Bush said last year, in a Memorial Day ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Wednesday about Ben Weisman, a songwriter, included erroneous information from a family member about his illnesses before his death. He suffered a stroke and had pneumonia; he did not have Alzheimers disease. The obituary also erroneously included a group among the performers for whom he wrote songs. He did not write for the Beatles.

title: Bush Pays Tribute to Fallen U.S. Troops
description: ARLINGTON, Va., May 28  President Bush used his traditional Memorial Day address at Arlington National Cemetery today to speak directly, in deeply personal terms, to the families of soldiers killed in Iraq and Afghanistan, assuring them that Americans will never forget the terrible loss you have suffered.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A brief art review in Weekend on Friday about an exhibition of work by Eva Rothschild, at 303 Gallery in Chelsea, misidentified the gallery that represents Liz Larner, a sculptor whose creations Ms. Rothschilds works were said to resemble. Her principal dealers are the Tanya Bonakdar Gallery in New York and Regen Projects in Los Angeles  not 303 Gallery, which she left in 2004.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A brief report in the Circuits pages of Business Day on May 17 about a low-cost camcorder called the Flip Video referred incorrectly to its retail availability. Although CVS, Rite Aid and Wolf Camera are among the locations where video from the cameras can be processed into DVDs, those stores do not sell the cameras.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article last Monday about a further decline in Indias electricity supply, even as its economy has expanded, incorrectly compared the per-capita annual energy consumption between India and the United States. The typical Indian consumes about one-fifteenth as much energy per year as the typical American  not one-fifth.

title: Officers and Counterprotesters Disrupt Gay Rights Rally in Russia
description: MOSCOW, May 27  Police officers and riot troops quashed a gay rights rally in Moscow on Sunday, detaining organizers as well as at least two European lawmakers, while members of Orthodox Christian and nationalist groups badgered the demonstrators with insults, eggs and fists.

title: A Queens Announced Presence Helps Place Another Queen
description: In chess there are prodigies. Of the top 20 teenagers, 18 are grandmasters. In bridge we very rarely have a prodigy. This is partly because our game is not a pure computational exercise; there are hidden cards. There is also a psychological side to the game. You must cooperate well with your partner, and you must be able to read your opponents.

title: Israeli Labor Party Voting to Choose New Leader
description: JERUSALEM, May 28  Initial results did not point to a clear victor in the race for the leadership of the Israeli Labor Party on Monday, but they left no doubt that Defense Minister Amir Peretz would lose the party chairmanship.

description: BEIJING, May 27  A Pentagon report that voiced concerns about Chinas buildup of land- and sea-based ballistic missiles misleads international opinion and tries to spread false fears of a China threat, Chinese state news media said Sunday.

description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, May 27  A Libyan court on Sunday acquitted five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor on charges of slander.

title: Brooklyn: Man Shot Dead in Street
description: A 22-year-old man was fatally shot yesterday afternoon on a street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said. The victim, Christopher Darns, of Brooklyn, was shot at 3:10 p.m. in front of 866 Madison Street, the police said. There have been no arrests, the police said.

title: Manhasset: Body of Man Found

A year ago today Ms. Dozier, a CBS News correspondent, was nearly killed by a roadside bomb in Baghdad after she and her crew left their armored vehicle to report a story about American soldiers working with Iraqi security forces. Her colleagues Paul Douglas, a cameraman, and James Brolan, a soundman, as well as Capt. James A. Funkhouser of the Army and his Iraqi translator, died.
