description: Kimberli Johnsons baby was born much too soon, trading the serenity of the womb after 24 weeks of gestation for the chaotic world of a neonatal intensive care unit.

title: Big Landlord Close to Deal for a REIT in New York
description: The real estate company that bought two prominent apartment complexes on Manhattans Lower East Side is trying to make another major acquisition in the New York market.

title: Finding Some Calm After Living With the Shakes
description: As Sandy Kamen Wisniewski remembers, her hands always shook. She hid them in long sleeves and pockets and wrote only in block letters in school because at least that was readable. The tremor became much worse as she entered her teenage years, and if she was upset or under stress, it grew so bad she cringed with embarrassment and decided that it must all be psychological.

title: Letters
description: The Variable Tales of Life

title: Ducks Put Ottawa in Unfamiliar Spot: Behind in a Series
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 28  When all the hybrids and convertibles rolled into the Honda Center parking lot Monday, they were confronted with a motor home draped in a gigantic Canadian flag.

title: With Hurricanes in the Lab, They Can Blow the House Down
description: Over the years, many people have tried to simulate the winds of hurricanes and measure the effects.

title: Obama Offers Health Care Plan
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa, May 29  Senator Barack Obama proposed a major overhaul of the nations health care system today, aimed at covering the nearly 45 million uninsured Americans, reducing premium costs for everyone else, and breaking what he asserted was the stranglehold that the biggest drug and insurance companies have on the health care market.

title: Forget Ethics, Remember Politics
description: The Bush administrations never-ending push to turn federal agencies into favor-filled partisan clubhouses has just been confirmed in red-handed detail at the General Services Administration, the governments main housekeeping agency. Investigators found that Lurita Doan, the Bush appointee running the agency, violated the Hatch Act, which forbids federal workers from politicking on the job.

title: Change on Immigration Turns Senator Kyl Into Lightning Rod
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  Angry calls poured into Senator Jon Kyls office this week by the thousands, expressing outrage beyond anything he said he had witnessed in his 20-year political career. The callers were inflamed by Mr. Kyls role in shaping the bipartisan immigration compromise announced May 17, which lawmakers continue to debate.

title: Will Warming Lead to a Rise in Hurricanes?
description: When people worry about the effects of global warming, they worry more about hurricanes than anything else. In surveys, almost three-quarters of Americans say there will be more and stronger hurricanes in a warming world. By contrast, fewer than one-quarter worry about increased coastal flooding.

title: At Risk: Where Smokers Congregate Outside Bars, a Cloud Hovers
description: Now that smokers have been pushed out of many bars and restaurants to mill about the door, is it time to send them packing altogether?

title: Google Deal Said to Bring U.S. Scrutiny
description: The Federal Trade Commission has opened a preliminary antitrust investigation into Googles planned $3.1 billion purchase of the online advertising company DoubleClick, an industry executive briefed on the agencys plans said yesterday.

title: A Bridge Restores a Lifeline to a Battered Town
description: BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., May 24  Sometimes a bridge is more than just a bridge. The new span across the copper-colored St. Louis Bay connects todays diminished reality to memories of a more generous past, a hopeful link to the return of better days.

title: Justices Limit Discrimination Suits Over Pay
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  The Supreme Court made it harder today for many workers to sue their employers for discrimination in pay, insisting in a 5-to-4 decision on a tight timeframe to file such cases. Dissenters said the ruling ignored workplace realities.

title: Neither Fire Nor Water Blocks ABC Early Morning Newscast
description: Hours after a fire knocked WABC-TV off the air Sunday night, sending camera crews and journalists fleeing the stations Lincoln Square studios, the news crew pressed through the mess and produced what some called a miracle: a 5 a.m. newscast yesterday.

title: Mother and Three Daughters Found Dead in Texas
description: A mother and three of her daughters were found dead today, hanging in a bedroom closet of a mobile home in Hudson Oak, Texas, about 25 miles west of Fort Worth, according to broadcast reports and Web news sites.

title: With or Without a Petty, a Team Moves Ahead
description: CONCORD, N.C., May 28  Kyle Petty is long past the time in his Nascar career for celebrating top-five finishes or eyeing Nextel Cup championships. Petty will be 47 on Saturday, and in 29 years behind the wheel of a stock car he has been through all of that too many times.

title: 5 British Civilians Abducted in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, May 29  Gunmen wearing police commando uniforms abducted five British civilians from a Finance Ministry complex on Tuesday, British officials said, seizing a business consultant and his four bodyguards in an attack that revived questions about links between official security forces and criminal militias.

title: Memo Pad
description: FEWER TRAVELING TO EUROPE Passenger traffic from the United States to Europe last year was just short of 13 million and the 2000 record of 13.1 million, said Donald N. Martin & Company, quoting new Commerce Department data. European destinations, however, are losing overall market share. In 2006, visits from the United States to all foreign destinations (excluding Canada and Mexico) were up 12.2 percent over the year 2000, to 30.3 million. Last year, Europes share of total overseas traffic from the United States was 43.1 percent, compared with 48.9 percent in 2000.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A music review on Thursday about the International Contemporary Ensemble, at P.S. 122, misstated the surname of the sound engineer. He is Ryan Streber, not Steber.

title: Los Angeles Mayor Expected to Endorse Clinton
description: Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angeles, one of the most influential Democrats in California, will endorse Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York for president on Tuesday, according to two Democrats close to Mrs. Clintons presidential campaign.

title: Barak in Israeli Labor Party Runoff
description: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, May 29  After the final count of votes in Israel early today, no clear victor emerged for the leadership of the Labor Party, ensuring a second-round runoff between the former Labor prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the former Shin Bet security agency chief, Ami Ayalon.

title: Russia Seeks Meeting With U.S. and Europe on Arms
description: MOSCOW, May 28  Russia called Monday for an emergency meeting with the United States and European countries to discuss the future of a conventional arms treaty in Europe, which President Vladimir V. Putin suspended last month and has threatened to withdraw from altogether.

title: The Crime Rate Drops, and a City Credits Its Embrace of Surveillance Technology
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 28  Detective Robert Harris starts patrolling the raw streets of this worn-down city before he even leaves the parking lot at Police Headquarters.

title: Hybrid Yellow Cabs: Dont Forget the Disabled (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Tod H. Mikuriya, 73, Dies; Backed Medical Marijuana
description: Dr. Tod H. Mikuriya, a California psychiatrist who was widely regarded as the grandfather of the medical marijuana movement in the United States, died on May 20 at his home in Berkeley. He was 73.

title: U.S. and Iranian Officials Meet in Baghdad, but Talks Yield No Breakthroughs
description: BAGHDAD, May 28  The United States and Iran held rare face-to-face talks in Baghdad on Monday, adhering to an agenda that focused strictly on the war in Iraq and on ways the two bitter adversaries could help improve conditions here.

title: Lawmakers Push for Big Subsidies for Coal Process
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  Even as Congressional leaders draft legislation to reduce greenhouse gases linked to global warming, a powerful roster of Democrats and Republicans is pushing to subsidize coal as the king of alternative fuels.

title: An Assault in Iraq, a Stage Hit in London
description: LONDON, May 28  Soon after Falluja became a symbol of the horrific violence and aggressive American tactics in Iraq, the theater director Jonathan Holmes listened to a group of British generals and journalists conduct a post-mortem on what had happened during the assault on that town.

title: Bush Focuses on Soldiers Families in Memorial Day Speech
description: ARLINGTON, Va., May 28  President Bush used his traditional Memorial Day address at Arlington National Cemetery on Monday to speak directly, in deeply personal terms, to the families of soldiers killed in Iraq and Afghanistan, assuring them that Americans will never forget the terrible loss you have suffered.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: As the advertising awards season nears a peak, what follows is a special edition of Webdenda, recapping some of the recent winners of industry honors. The regular listing of people and accounts will return next week.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A caption on June 8, 1944, with a photograph of Army officers at mess on the Pacific front, misspelled the given name of the first officer seated at the left side of the table. He was Col. Girard B. Troland of New London, Conn.  not Gerand. The error was called to the attention of the editors by his grandson yesterday.

title: Uranium Windfall Opens Choices for the Energy Dept.
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  The government accumulated vast quantities of uranium when prices were very low and no one else wanted it. But now that uranium prices have increased tenfold, the government has a precious commodity  and some tough questions  on its hands.

title: Vatican City: Pope Restores Muslim Office
description: Pope Benedict XVI signaled a renewed emphasis on relations between Catholics and Muslims, a year after the Vatican seemed to sideline the issue by eliminating a separate office for dialogue with other faiths. The Vaticans second-in-command, Secretary of State Tarcisio Bertone, told the newspaper La Stampa that the Pontifical Council for Interreligious Dialogue would again become a separate department. The councils collapse, in March 2006, into another Vatican department came up against heavy criticism, especially after a speech by the pope a few months later that many Muslims charged was hostile to Islam.

title: Bachs Songs of Innocence and Experience, All in a Day
description: A year ago the Ukrainian pianist Konstantin Lifschitz made a powerful impression on a Town Hall audience with a complete traversal of Shostakovichs 24 Preludes and Fugues, presented in afternoon and evening installments. How to top that feat? If youre Mr. Lifschitz, you turn to Shostakovichs inspiration, Bachs Well-Tempered Clavier, as he did in a Sunday double-header that concluded the Free for All at Town Hall season.

title: In China, a Stake in Blackstone Stirs Uncertainty
description: HONG KONG, May 28  From Washington, the Chinese governments purchase of a $3 billion nonvoting stake in the Blackstone Group looks like a shrewd alliance with a politically connected American private equity fund loaded with financial expertise.

title: Correction
description: A chart last Tuesday in Science Times, with the Personal Health column about jet lag, omitted the recommended dose of melatonin for changing the body clock. The dose should be a half-milligram or less  preferably 300 micrograms  except at bedtime, when 3 milligrams is acceptable.

title: Special Operations: High Profile, but in Shadow
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  Every night in Iraq, American Special Operations forces carry out as many as a dozen raids aimed at terrorist leaders allied with Al Qaeda, other insurgent fighters and militia targets. Their after-action reports are the first thing that Gen. David H. Petraeus, the senior American commander in Baghdad, reads the next day.

title: Barak in Runoff to Lead Israeli Labor Party
description: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, May 29  With 99 percent of the vote counted in Israel early Tuesday, no clear victor had emerged for the leadership of the Labor Party, ensuring a runoff between the former Labor prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the former Shin Bet security agency chief, Ami Ayalon.

title: Getting to a Colombia Trade Deal
description: Free trade agreements with Peru and Panama now seem headed toward Congressional approval, after the Bush administration agreed to incorporate the basic labor standards long insisted upon by House Democrats. But a separate trade pact with Colombia rightly remains in legislative limbo over a much starker labor problem. Colombia leads the world in the killing of labor activists.

title: Spurs Take Control as Jazz Starts to Lose It
description: SALT LAKE CITY, May 28  Jerry Sloans final gestures in a losing effort Monday night were a pointed finger, an angry outburst and a swift march to the Utah Jazz locker room. He disappeared from the court 2 minutes 34 seconds before the final buzzer. The Jazz may soon be gone as well.

title: Bush Tightens Penalties Against Sudan
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  President Bush announced today that he is imposing stiff economic sanctions against Sudan and that he will press the United Nations for additional action to end the violence in Darfur.

title: Alone in a Citys AIDS Battle, Hoping for Backup
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  The nations capital is the only city in the country barred by federal law from using local tax money to finance needle exchange programs. It is also the city with the fastest-growing number of new AIDS cases.

title: Romeo and Juliet Double-Date With Peter and the Nurse
description: Language as finely and as fiercely wrought as Shakespeares can withstand and even prosper while considerable violence is being done to it.

title: Can Science Outwit Storms Like Katrina?
description: Stand atop any levee in the New Orleans area, and one question will offer itself, unbidden, to the mind: Is this pile of dirt tall enough to stand up to the next storm?

title: China Urges Western Nations to Enter Extradition Treaties
description: BEIJING, May 28  China has called for Western countries to put aside their fears that its justice system is unfair and sign extradition treaties, state news media reported Monday, as the Communist Party seeks the return of suspected corrupt officials and criminals who have fled overseas.

title: Flying Above the Traffic but Below Expectations
description: It has been the dream of New Yorkers for as long as there has been traffic on the Van Wyck: whizzing by helicopter from Manhattan to the airport to avoid being at the mercy of the citys highways and clogged crosstown streets.

description: To the Editor:

title: Design That Solves Problems for the Worlds Poor
description: A billion customers in the world, Dr. Paul Polak told a crowd of inventors recently, are waiting for a $2 pair of eyeglasses, a $10 solar lantern and a $100 house.

title: Natures Tricks Help Moths Say Dont Eat Me
description: The gaudy swirls of color on a butterflys wing, the rococo curlicues on its riotously dressed caterpillars, may seem to be delightful examples of natures artistry. But that is to miss natures point.

title: Turning Grease to Fuel, and Despair to Hope
description: The back entrance to Barbounia, a restaurant on Park Avenue South, was open and Joseph Presswood dragged out a 55-gallon barrel of cooking oil. He plunged a vacuum hose into the grease as Edgar Rivera flipped on a switch. Thick brown liquid bubbled up through the hose to a container in a truck parked on 20th Street.

title: Mayor Assails Bill in Congress on Immigration
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, in unusually pointed and broad language, criticized Congress yesterday for parts of a comprehensive immigration bill now being debated in the Senate.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about the addition of Mexican consulates in the United States misspelled the surname of the lead demographer for the Urban Institute, which conducted a study on illegal immigrants in Arkansas, where a new consulate has opened. He is Randy Capps, not Kapps.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article and picture caption on Wednesday about an International Criminal Court investigation of atrocities committed in the Central African Republic in 2002 and 2003 misspelled the surname of a general who seized power there in 2003 and remains president. He is Franois Bozize, not Boizize.

title: Revisiting Rouaults Stained-Glass World
description: You wouldnt call it a full-fledged revival, but Georges Rouault is back in our sights. A few months ago some of his work was at the Metropolitan Museum in a show about his wily dealer, Ambroise Vollard. Now a couple of dozen pictures are at Mitchell-Innes & Nash.

title: Spain Arrests 16 North Africans Accused of Recruiting Militants
description: MADRID, May 28 The police on Monday arrested 16 men, most of them Moroccans, suspected of recruiting volunteers to fight in Iraq and other countries and spreading propaganda calling for Islamic jihad.

title: Danger: Playground Ahead
description: San Francisco

title: Japan Cabinet Minister, Facing Scandal, Hangs Himself
description: TOKYO, May 28  Japans agriculture minister, Toshikatsu Matsuoka, killed himself on Monday, just hours before he was to face parliamentary questioning about a political finance scandal, government officials said.

title: Break a Confidence? Never. Well, Hardly Ever.
description: Anyone who has ever worked in a hospital can attest that doctors are purveyors of information: dry facts, clinical data, medical wisdom. When I was an intern, my hospital had a separate computer system for laboratory results, another for vital signs and nursing notes, and another for medical records. Clinical medicine, it seemed then, wasnt about patient care as much as about data management.

title: Recall Slows Companys Plan to Grow in Eye Care
description: On Thursday, James V. Mazzo, the chief executive of Advanced Medical Optics, appeared to be a step closer to his goal of offering a full suite of products in the eye care market, as his company weighed a takeover bid for its significantly bigger rival Bausch & Lomb.

title: Digital Fears Emerge After Data Siege in Estonia
description: TALLINN, Estonia, May 24  When Estonian authorities began removing a bronze statue of a World War II-era Soviet soldier from a park in this bustling Baltic seaport last month, they expected violent street protests by Estonians of Russian descent.

title: Hazards: Obese Employees More Likely to Be Injured on the Job
description: Companies often encourage their employees to keep their weight down as a matter of improving overall health and medical costs.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on May 20 about a player from Israel who was selected by the Liberty in the W.N.B.A. draft in April misspelled her given name in some copies. As the article noted elsewhere, she is Shay Doron, not Shea.

title: Andy Roddick Crashes Out of French Open
description: PARIS, May 29  To figure out how Andy Roddick was faring in his first-round match of the French Open tennis tournament today, spectators did not have to see the score.

title: Venezuela: Government Sets Sights on Globovisin and CNN
description: The government lashed out at Globovisin, the countrys only remaining television channel that is critical of its policies, accusing it of manipulating images to incite an assassination attempt against President Hugo Chvez. Willian Lara, the communications minister, called for an investigation of Globovisin, a 24-hour news channel, saying semioticians hired by the government had determined that video run by the channel of an assassination attempt in 1981 against Pope John Paul II could be interpreted as hostile to Mr. Chvez. Mr. Lara, who also denounced CNNs coverage of Venezuela, made his claims as the police dispersed protests for a second day against a decision forcing the dissident network RCTV off the air on Sunday.

title: James Beck, 77, Art Scholar and Critic of Conservation, Is Dead
description: James Beck, a Columbia University art historian who became well known as a critic of what he viewed as the ruinous conservation of world masterpieces, including Michelangelos Sistine Chapel ceiling, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 77.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption with a sports article on May 20 about the graduation ceremony at Fordham University in which Mets Manager Willie Randolph received an honorary doctorate misspelled, in some copies, the given name and surname of the faculty member who sponsored Randolph for the degree and who was shown with him. She is Maryanne Kowaleski, not Maryann Howaleski.

title: Bush to Tighten Fiscal Penalties Against Sudan
description: Ahead of a meeting of the Group of 8, President Bush will announce today that he is imposing stiff economic sanctions against Sudan  including penalties against two senior government officials and a rebel leader. He will also press the United Nations for additional actions to end the violence in Darfur, according to senior administration officials.

title: What Kind of Team is Clemens Joining?
description: The good news for the Yankees is that Roger Clemens is probably through with the minor leagues. He went six innings for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre, allowing two hits and no runs.

title: On the North Korean Border
description: How crazy is the situation in North Korea? North Koreans are escaping to China in search of freedom.

title: UK house price growth slows
description: House price growth in England appears to be slowing  at long last. A new survey from Hometrack, a leading property Web site, shows that house prices rose by 0.6 percent in May from April, a slight dip from the previous months growth of 0.7 percent. Annual house price inflation also declined from 6.8 percent to 6.7 percent in May.

title: Differentiating Between Aneurysms and Stroke
description: What is the difference between an aneurysm and a hemorrhagic stroke?  Lynn Bechtold

title: Seeing a Stroke Using M.R.I.s
description: Do strokes always show-up on M.R.I.s?  Janell Fowell

title: Trying to Cut Cost Barriers
description: Would it be practical to cut diagnostic costs, and so expand the reach of effective care, by placing M.R.I. machines in more locations and sending the scans electronically to be read by neurologists at regional centers   or overseas for that matter?  Irv Federer The cost of M.R.I. is not related to reading the scans. In fact, acute stroke damage on a high quality-diffusion M.R.I. is one of the easiest things for a doctor to pick out. The cost is in the M.R.I. machines themselves, with their multi-million dollar price tags, and upkeep and staffing costs. M.R.I. scanning also takes more time to perform and many people  such as those with pacemakers, claustrophobia, confusion with inability to hold still  can not undergo M.R.I. scans.  Dr. Koroshetz

title: Whats Next for Stroke Treatment?
description: Are any new therapeutic advances on the immediate horizon that may improve the efficacy of acute stroke care with fewer side effects than tPA?  Paul Roberts

title: Different Types of Aspirin
description: Are coated and uncoated aspirin equally effective at helping to prevent strokes?  Joel

title: Can Bumps to the Head Cause Stroke Later On?
description: Can significant bumps to the head increase your chances later in life for a stroke or aneurysm?  Julie

title: Is Dizziness a Warning Sign for Stroke?
description: Is mild to severe dizziness considered a possible warning sign for stroke?  John

title: Diagnosing a Stroke
description: In the emergency room, how do doctors diagnose the type of stroke  ischemic or hemorraghic  and decide whether tPA would be useful?  John Niesyn

title: Evaluating Your Local Hospital
description: How can one evaluate a local hospital ERs stroke diagnosis and treatment standards and protocols?  Don Porter

title: The Dangers of tPA
description: If tPA causes bleeding in the brains of 6 percent of people who get it, it does not seem like such a great drug. Would you ever give it to someone who seems to be having a relatively mild stroke? If so, why?  Donna

title: Is Damage Cause by High Blood Pressure Reversible?
description: Can people reverse the possible damage caused from years of high blood pressure? That is, if they lose weight and control their blood pressure, will the buildup in their blood vessels decrease and return to normal?  Maureen Aldakheel

title: The Risks Associated With Valve Replacement
description: Why does aortic valve replacement increase risk for stroke?  Mark Gordetsky

title: Different Symptoms for Different Sexes?
description: What are some of the key differences of stroke symptoms, if any, between men and women?  Sandra Holtzman

title: The Chances of a Second Stroke
description: Does having one stroke increase your chances of having a second?  Edward Yes. Overall, the highest risk factor for stroke is having had a previous stroke. This is why so much research has gone into reducing this risk. A stroke prevention plan between patient and their neurologist is essential in persons with a history of stroke.  Dr. Koroshetz

title: The Role of Cholesterol in Causing Stroke
description: The article says high cholesterol is a risk factor. Could you detail what you mean by high cholesterol? High numbers overall or just high LDL? Or both? How high is too high?  Laura

title: Latest property viewing gimmick: blindfolding
description: Landing in my inbox this week was an email from Hajar Ali, founder of UrbaneSpaces www.urbanespaces.com, a real estate firm in Singapore specializing in unique properties.

title: What You Get for $300,000
Pattern Recognition
description: Evolution provides warning labels for moths in all kinds of patterns.

title: New Contract for Broadway Musicians
description: Local 802, the union representing Broadway musicians, has agreed on a three-year contract with Broadway producers, a deal that was overwhelmingly approved by its members.

title: Living the Athenian Lifestyle
description: Tour Nicholas Pisaris's loft-style apartment in the Psyrri section of Athens.

title: Tishman Speyer Close to Deal for a REIT in New York
description: The real estate company that bought two prominent apartment complexes on Manhattans Lower East Side is trying to make another major acquisition in the New York market. The company, Tishman Speyer Properties, has joined with Lehman Brothers and was close to a deal Sunday night to buy Archstone-Smith Trust, the second-largest public apartment owner in terms of market cap and asset value, for more than $20 billion, The New York Times reported.

title: JPMorgan Back on Board in Nasdaqs Latest Exchange Deal
description: JPMorgan Chase has picked up its first advisory mandate from the Nasdaq Stock Market since standing down as financial adviser on the exchanges hostile bid for the London Stock Exchange to avoid a conflict of interest.

title: Calpers Backs Shareholder Rights Bill at UnitedHealth
description: In a showdown over shareholders rights to be decided Tuesday, the largest public pension fund in the nation is fighting to give investors the power to nominate directors at UnitedHealth Group, the biggest company entangled in the stock-option backdating scandal.

title: Australias Healthscope Bids for Symbion
description: Healthscope, a private hospital operator in Australia, said Tuesday it had offered 2.86 billion Australian dollars ($2.34 billion) for Symbion Health, an acquisition that would make it the countrys largest pathology services provider.

title: LDK Solar to Bow Amid Strong Investor Interest
description: LDK Solar, a Chinese producer of solar cells, tops a calendar of three initial public offerings for the shortened Memorial Day week. Joining the LDK Solar offering are two biopharmaceutical deals with the three expected to raise $537.4 million. Morgan Stanley is the book-runner for all three.

title: 2004s Dewey Defeats Truman
description: Correction Appended

title: Is Ford Gearing Up to Sell Volvo?
description: After unloading its Aston Martin brand in March for $925 million, Ford Motor might be gearing up to sell another unit in its luxury division. According to reports, the money-losing car maker is planning to sell Volvo, possibly to BMW of Germany.

title: Pole Vaulting to a New Crowd
description: Allison Stokke, the 18-year-old high school pole vaulter whose face launched thousands of searches in the past month, was introduced today to a whole new crowd: readers of The Washington Post. A story that chronicles how she struggled with the unwanted attention was played at the most prominent spot on the Web site  the top section of the home page  with a picture of her looking quite serious. Judging by her top ranking on the most viewed articles list, her appeal stretches beyond her almost completely male fan base.

title: For Shareholders, a C.E.O.s Political Largesse Proves Too Much
description: The generosity of the chief executive officer of InfoUSA toward the Clintons has proved so controversial within his firm, a major provider of database-processing services, that it has prompted a shareholder lawsuit complaining that hiring the former president was a waste of corporate assets.

title: Former Citigroup Executives to Launch Asia Hedge Fund
description: Three recently departed executives of Citigroups Global Special Situations Group have announced plans to open a Hong-Kong based hedge fund.

title: In Canada, New Concern Over Foreign Takeovers
description: A recent series of acquisitions or potential acquisitions of Canadian corporations has prompted a growing public debate over foreign control. On Monday, in the latest sign that the takeovers had become a growing political issue, the opposition Liberal Party said that it wanted to freeze foreign takeovers of Canadian companies for three months to allow a review of investment laws.

title: South Korea Examines Credit Suisse Transaction
description: South Koreas financial regulators are looking into whether Credit Suisse violated disclosure rules in its purchase of shares in a small domestic building material company. Credit Suisse said in a public disclosure on Friday that it bought a 5.2 percent stake in Byucksan in mid-December for about 5 billion won ($5.4 million), but gradually sold a 4.3 percent stake for about 4.3 billion won.

title: Apax Ditches V.C. Investments for Latest Fund
description: The British private equity firm Apax Partners will not earmark any of the new fund it is raising for venture capital investment, according to Electronicsweekly.com, instead funneling the cash it raised for such purposes into private equity buyouts.

title: Brazils JBS Beefs Up with Swift Deal, Report Says
description: JBS, Latin Americas biggest meat producer, agreed to buy closely held Swift & Company for $1.4 billion, gaining control of the third-largest seller of beef and pork in the United States, from HM Capital Partners, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Europe Closes the I.P.O. Gap With the U.S.
description: For the first time since World War II, bankers in Europe are on the verge of earning more from initial public offerings than their counterparts in the United States, prompting Bloomberg News to state that the lights may be going out on Wall Street.

title: Spitzer Said to Form Panel on Wall St. Rules
description: New York Governor Eliot Spitzer, who, when he was attorney general, aggressively policed the financial services industry, is forming a committee of Wall Street chief executives, lawyers, consumer groups and regulators to modernize financial-services regulation in New York State, The Financial Times reported.

title: Hedge Fund Managers Comments Irk Macquarie
description: At a charity event in New York last week, during which some of the biggest names in hedge funds offered investment advice, James Chanos, the short seller who catapulted to fame by questioning Enron, offered the Macquarie Bank, the Australian financial group, as a stock that might be in for a fall. He even drew some comparisons between Enron and Macquarie, which has raised a lot of big investment funds that it used to buy assets and sell them to related entities.

title: Tech Retailer CDW Said to Consider Buyout
description: CDW, a computer reseller with a market capitalization of about $6 billion, is in talks with private equity firms about a possible buyout, The Wall Street Journal reported. Madison Dearborn Partners is considered to be in the lead to buy the company, the Journal said.

title: Presidential Candidates Flock to Hedge-Fund Enclave
description: Senator John McCain did it. Former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts did it. President Bill Clinton, on behalf of his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, did it. They all made recent pilgrimages to Greenwich, the leafy Connecticut suburb that is home to an inordinate number of hedge funds and, increasingly, a required stop on the presidential fund-raising tour, The New York Times reports.

title: Morgan Stanley Analyst Defects to Hedge Fund
description: A well-known property analyst at Morgan Stanley in Hong Kong has left the Wall Street firm for an alternative investment manager based in the United States, joining an industry-wide migration in recent years.

title: URS Buys Washington Group for $2.6 Billion
description: URS, a construction design and engineering company based in San Francisco, agreedj to buy Washington Group International, a rival based in Boise, Idaho, for $2.6 billion, to create one of the countrys largest engineering and construction companies, the companies said Monday.

title: To Lure Top Talent, Google Finds Novel Ways to Recruit
description: As competition for top recruits in engineering and other fields intensifies, companies like Google, Microsoft and Yahoo frequently find themselves going after the same candidates, as well as running up against myriad Silicon Valley start-up companies that have been pumped up with venture capital in recent years.

title: Investors Worry as K.K.R. and CVC Pull Out of Coles Bid
description: Two private equity firms have pulled out of a consortium bidding for the Coles Group, the Australian retailer, pushing its shares down sharply as investors worried about the state of the companys financial health.

title: Are Warner and Cerberus Planning a Suprise Attack on EMI?
description: Is Warner Music Group teaming up with Cerberus Capital Management for an 11th-hour surprise bid for the rival music outfit EMI Group? The Sunday Telegraph reported that Warner and the private equity firm have explored a novel two-stage bid for EMI to rival the $4.7 billion recommended offer from Terra Firma, an investment vehicle controlled by the British financier Guy Hands.

title: Silicon Valley Wide-Eyed Over a Bride
description: Silicon Valley is aflutter with the news that Anne Wojcicki, a 33-year-old former health care investment analyst, this month married a handsome young computer scientist, who just happens to be one of Americas richest men.

title: Google Deal Said to Bring U.S. Scrutiny
description: The Federal Trade Commission has opened a preliminary antitrust investigation into Googles planned $3.1 billion purchase of the online advertising company DoubleClick, according to The New York Times.

title: Avaya Is Said to Be Exploring a Sale
description: The telecommunications company Avaya is in negotiations to sell a part or all of itself, in what may be the latest round of deal making in its industry, The New York Times reported.

title: In China, a Stake in Blackstone Stirs Uncertainty
description: From Washington, the Chinese governments purchase of a $3 billion nonvoting stake in the Blackstone Group looks like a shrewd alliance with a politically connected American private equity fund loaded with financial expertise.

title: For John Mack, a Bid to Regain Lost Ground
description: As John J. Mack finds himself two years into his campaign to raise Morgan Stanleys metabolism, The Wall Street Journal takes a look at some of the banks missteps and successes in its bid to regain lost ground.

title: Rival Bidders Offer $95.5 Billion for ABN Amro
description: The takeover battle for the Dutch bank ABN Amro gained momentum Tuesday when a consortium led by the Royal Bank of Scotland, which has openly coveted ABM Amro for weeks, formally offered 71.1 billion euros ($95.6 billion) for it. The proposal trumped ABNs agreed deal with Barclays, already the largest banking takeover.

title: The Newest Bears on Private Equity: Buyout Firms
description: Is the private equity party about to end? Cassandras have sounded warnings for months now  but their ranks are beginning to fill with some big names from the buyout world, the Wall Street Journal reported Monday.

title: Candidates on a Plane
description: Imagine that the top presidential candidates are all at an airport, trying to get on a flight. There is one seat left on the plane, and there are six people ahead of them in line. What does each of the candidates do?

title: BA Shares Rise as Buyout Rumors Mount
description: Shares of British Airways, Europes third-largest airline, rose the most in almost a year on speculation the carrier might attract a private-equity bid, Bloomberg News reported Monday. Shares of the airline advanced as much as 22.5 pence, or 4.9 percent, to 483.5 pence, the biggest gain since June 15, 2006 at midday.

title: 2008: The Changes in Giuliani
description: As he travels around the country seeking the G.O.P. nomination, Rudolph W. Giuliani has offered a calmer side to his personality than what he often displayed while mayor of New York. The Timess Michael Powell looks back on his political journey:

title: Karen Kilimnik in View
description: Additional images from the Karen Kilimnik survey at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia.

title: Bradley Pharmaceuticals C.E.O. Makes Buyout Offer
description: The chief executive of Bradley Pharmaceuticals has bid $21.50 a share to buy the company, valuing it at about $363 million, the company said in a regulatory filing. The chief executive, Daniel Glassman would remain in his position and would retain the current top management, the company said.

title: Fort Dix Tipster Steps Forward
description: The man applauded by an F.B.I. agent as the unsung hero of Fort Dix case stepped into the spotlight today on CNN.

title: Sicko and the Race
description: The presidential race was consumed last week with discussion of the immigration bill and financing of the Iraq war. This week, health care may take center stage, with Senator Barack Obama planning to release his long-awaited health care proposal today.

title: Options for Reimbursement When a Tour Falls Through
description: With overseas travel agencies offering more prepaid tours, is there any insurance policy or credit card coverage for refunds in the event you show up and find the travel agency is no longer in business or unable to provide the promised itinerary?

title: Peace Victim
description: Tobin Harshaw

title: Archstone-Smith Agrees to $22 Billion Takeover
description: Too big for a deal? Not these days.

title: Remarks of Senator Barack Obama
description: The following is the prepared text of Senator Obama's speech on health care, as provided by his campaign.

title: Housing Price Rebound?
description: The latest housing price numbers have a tinge of hope  at least in some bubbly markets. The Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller indexes for March, out today, actually went up in the Boston and San Francisco regions. In each case, the bounce came after nine consecutive monthly declines. And the Portland and Seattle markets, which had shown signs of slipping although their year-over-year gains remained substantial, each showed improving month-over-month numbers.

title: Who Might Take the Wheel at Volvo?
description: Volvo has had plenty of admirers over the years, and we are not just talking about affluent Northeasterners who like its sensibly Swedish version of luxury. Renault of France and Fiat of Italy have, at various times, considered buying or merging with Volvo. With reports percolating that Ford Motor Company might put the business up for sale  it is part of Fords Premier Automotive Group, which has already sold Aston Martin  attention naturally turns to who else might cast an eye Volvos way.

title: Potential New Bidders for Alcan Arise, as Does Politicians Ire
description: As reports surface that more bidders might jump into the fray for Alcan, Canadian politicians are calling for greater protections against takeovers by foreign companies.

title: Obamas Health Plan
description: Fresh off campaign stops in New Hampshire over the weekend, Senator Barack Obama traveled to the University of Iowa to outline his own plan to try to provide health insurance coverage for everyone.

title: Why People Hate, and Love, Jim Cramer
description: Jim Cramer wants to know why he has become a polarizing figure since he started his CNBC stock-picking show, Mad Money, in which he yells and sweats a lot, throws things, and sometimes wears a diaper or jumps into a pile of lettuce to illustrate, he cheekily writes, the finer points of investing.

title: The Animated Life: L'Eau Life
description: A short animated film by artist Jeff Scher. Part of Sightlines, an Op-Ed visual series.

title: Lofty Goals in Higher Education
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed an executive order today creating a commission to look at overhauling the State University of New York system. The goal is a lofty one: to put SUNY on par with elite public university systems in states like California. But it would also be expensive to accomplish that, and the governor would only say that how funding will fit into this I remain to wait and see.

title: Tuesday Motorsports
description: The Indy 500 gave us one of the better feel-good stories in recent IndyCar memory when Dario Franchitti won a rain-shortened race, and the camera found his wife, Ashley Judd, running down the pits, barefoot and wet.

title: Clinton Sees Rising Pessimism
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, pledged in a speech in Manchester, N.H., this morning to reduce corporate tax breaks and eliminate incentives for companies that move overseas in order to combat rising inequality and rising pessimism in our workforce.

title: Look before you leap
description: Blind Light, an exhibit of the work of the British sculptor Antony Gormley, has drawn mixed reviews from the critics. Some observers have found deep meanings in installations like an enormous glass cube filled with a hazy vapor. Others are simply confused.

title: Is Someone Browsing Krogers Aisles?
description: Options traders are on a shopping spree with Kroger, the grocery chain. Trading in the companys options skyrocketed Tuesday, a development that OptionMonster.coms Jon Najarian chalked up to fresh speculation about a possible buyout of the company.

title: Retailers Turn Up on Citis Buyout List
description: Two decades ago, a favorable environment for junk-bond financing helped fuel a wave of leveraged buyouts. Citis equity strategists say they are feeling a bit of a flashback these days, as yields on risky debt are relatively low, making it cheaper to borrow money to take companies private. The atmosphere is reminiscent of the L.B.O. heyday back in the latter 1980s, they wrote in a report published Tuesday. Citis analysts compared companies cash flows with junk-bond yields and found that certain sectors look especially ripe for buyouts: These included the commercial services industry (which includes waste management, employment services, etc.) and retailing.

title: On Gay Marriage, Poll Shows a State Split
description: Forty-seven percent of New Yorkers oppose gay marriage, while 43 percent support the idea, according to a new poll from Siena College.

title: From the Banking World, More Bitter Beach Reading
description: Bankers can be forgiven for being very careful about what they say around the office. Acid-laced books, both fictional and nonfictional, written by former employees of investment banks, seem to have replaced drug-strewn memoirs as the current eras it genre.

title: Fashion Oligarchs
description: Im mildly curious about what people wear (and dont wear) at the Cannes Film Festival, and Im thinking that next year I ought to go and see for myself, and maybe combine the trip with the Grand Prix at Monaco, just to see a different kind of action. Id go for the simple reason that I dont know what to expect from those events, and not from any illusion that I can compete with Hello! for fawning reportage of the latest sequined coated babe. It aint gonna happen. Nonetheless, I will have to deal with the expectation that this is what most people want to read. To write what you are interested in writing, and to succeed in getting editors to pay for it, is a feat that may require pretty close calculation and a good deal of ingenuity. You have to learn to load solid matter into notices of ephemeral happenings; you have to develop a resourcefulness at pursing a line of thought through pieces on miscellaneous and more or less fortuitous subjects; and you have to acquire a technique of slipping over on the routine of editors the deeper independent work which their over-anxious intentness on the fashions of the month or the week have conditioned them automatically to reject. This is from Edmund Wilson, in a 2005 piece by Louis Menand, and I keep its essence in the back of my head. Very often writers dont know what they want to say about subject, only that something deserves to be written which hasnt been sufficiently said.

title: Charles Nelson Reilly, Master Thespian
description: Charles Nelson Reilly appeared on Match Game prefamous. As a kid I believed he must have been very, very famous before I was lucky enough to catch him cooling his heels in the afterschool hours.

description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer had this to say today when asked about Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs congestion pricing plan:

description: An 18-year-old art student has told police that he killed more than 30 people in Moscow, according to reports in Russian newspapers.

description: What does an organization called Ultimate Fighting Championship do when its ultimate fighter is badly beaten in front of tons of adoring fans?

description: In order to cut back the size of the house, we had to lose something  but what?

description: It is the question that every presidential candidate must have a good answer to: Why do you want the job?

description: The conservative editorial cartoonist Allen Forkum offers some illustrated commentary, followed by the more literal kind:

title: China Sweeps to Victory at the Womens Team Championship
description: The Chinese women won the First Womens Team Championship with an undefeated score in nine matches. The only blemish on their record was a tie against Georgia (formerly of the Soviet Union), who were led by former womens world champion Maia Chiburdanidze. The championship, which was held in Yekaterinburg, Russia, began on May 19. The official Web site is here.

title: Cabbages and Condoms, a Winning Idea
description: Mechai Viravaidya was recognized by The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation today with a $1 million award for confronting taboo subjects like sex and HIV/AIDS directly in order to save lives, the foundation said.

title: A Doodle Is Worth $2,000
description: Senator Barack Obama: activist, author, presidential candidate  artist?

title: U.S. Attorney Charges Pakistani Banker with Insider Trading
description: Federal prosecutors on Tuesday charged a high-profile investment banker in Pakistan with taking part in a $7.5 million insider-trading scheme that they say was run by a former Credit Suisse banker. In a new complaint filed in federal district court in Manhattan, the United States attorneys office accused Ajaz Rahim, the former head of Faysal Bank Limited, of profiting from confidential information fed to him by Hafiz Mohammed Zubair Naseem, at the time a junior associate in Credit Suisses energy team.

title: The Soft-Shell Crab Poor-Boy
description: Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, cooks a New Orleans favorite. (Warning: Contains images of violence to crabs.)

title: All Bonds, All The Time
description: Barry Bonds, perhaps one of the most polarizing players in the history of baseball, will be sitting on the bench for the opener of the Giants three-game series at Shea Stadium. The Giants like giving Bonds two consecutive days of rest, and with an off day yesterday and a lefthander, Oliver Perez, starting for the Mets tonight, benching him was the natural move.

title: Chain Reactions
description: The political party that claimed it would restore honor and dignity to the White House has done nothing of the sort. Having on false pretenses led us into the disaster of Iraq, the administration and its supporters are now beginning  cravenly and shamefully  to shift blame onto the Iraqi people. The administration continues to hold hundreds of people without charges in secret prisons around the world, while arguing that torture is O.K. and that President Bush can disregard the laws he doesnt like. I havent even mentioned illegal spying or efforts to keep scientists quiet if theyre saying the wrong thing.

title: Candidates Matches: Two Grab Big Leads
description: Gata Kamsky of the United States and Peter Leko of Hungary took overwhelming leads of 2.5 to 0.5 over their opponents in the candidates matches taking place in Elista, Kalmykia. The matches are to select four qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

title: 2008: P.M. Postscripts
description: Former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney said today in New Hampshire that he would donate to charity at least a part if not more of his presidential salary (should he win)  given that hes the wealthiest among the candidates.

title: Who Pays to Play?
description: Taxpayers are helping to pay for corporate executives to travel to a destination golf resort in the hard-luck town of Bandon, Ore.

title: Frugal Traveler: Tell Matt Where to Go in Tennessee and Kentucky
description: Next stops on the Frugal Travelers itinerary are Tennessee and Kentucky. Have you been or do you live near by? Share a suggestion what Matt should see, eat and do on his way through these states.

title: Its Zoellick
description: Without a mention of the most eye-grabbing names to lead the World Bank (Tony Blair and Bill Frist, anyone?), the White House has picked a man who has plenty of appropriate experience in Republican government, respect abroad and ties to President Bush that date back to the early days of his 2000 campaign, when a group led by Condoleezza Rice known as the Vulcans advised a candidate inexperienced on foreign policy.

title: Aberration, Says L.A.P.D. Chief
description: Commissioner William J. Bratton of the Los Angeles Police Department faced off with his overseers today on the immigration protest gone awry on May Day. At the time, he called it worst incident of this type I have ever encountered in 37 years in law enforcement.

title: CDW Agrees to $7.3 Billion Buyout by Madison Dearborn
description: CDW, a technology products retailer aimed at business, said late Tuesday that it has agreed to sell itself to Madison Dearborn Partners for about $7.3 billion in cash. In a statement Tuesday, CDW said that the deal values the company at $87.75 a share, or a 16.3 percent premium over its closing stock price on Friday.

title: Frugal Traveler: Armuchee, Ga.
description: The Frugal Traveler arrives in Armuchee, Ga., just in time for the Armuchee Bluegrass Festival.

title: Interrogation Methods Are Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  As the Bush administration completes secret new rules governing interrogations, a group of experts advising the intelligence agencies are arguing that the harsh techniques used since the 2001 terrorist attacks are outmoded, amateurish and unreliable.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (22, 26) CRAFT IN AMERICA Three hourlong specials consider the significance of the craft movement in the United States and its impact on the nations cultural heritage, starting with Memory, in which the basketmakers Mary Jackson, above, and Pat Courtney Gold; the woodworker Sam Maloof; and other artisans place their work within crafts larger historical context. At 9, Landscape examines the relationship between artists like the jewelers Kit Carson and Jan Yager and their physical environments. And Community, at 10, honors the connection between artisans and where they live.

title: From Jail, a Panhandler Fights New Yorks Loitering Law as a Violation of Free Speech
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 29  A homeless panhandler arrested here six months ago on loitering charges is contending in court that a state law banning begging violates his right to free speech. The man, Eric Hoffstead, started living on the streets about a year ago and was arrested after asking a police officer for a dollar; he urged his court-appointed lawyer to challenge the arrest after reading a newspaper article about a similar case.

title: Bush Seeks to Double Spending for AIDS Program
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  President Bush asked Congress today to double the amount the United States spends to fight this modern-day plague of AIDS in developing countries. He proposed spending $30 billion over a five-year period beginning in September 2008.

title: Recipe: Fettuccine With Mushroom Rag
description: Time: 40 minutes

title: Rising Star in Israel Hits the Fast Track of English Soccer
description: Ben Sahar did not play a big role in Chelseas run to the English F.A. Cup title. He did not play a part in Chelseas second-place finish in the Premier League. And Sahar did not step on to the field once as Chelsea advanced to the semifinals of the European Champions League.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of editing errors, the Critics Choice column yesterday, about a new box set of DVDs of Katharine Hepburn films, referred incorrectly to a brother of Hepburn who committed suicide, and it misstated his date of birth, part of which Hepburn said for years was her own birthday. He was an older brother, not younger, and was born on Nov. 8, 1905  not 1909. (Katharine Hepburn, whose centenary was May 12 this year, claimed for years that she was two years younger than she actually was and that her birthday was Nov. 8.)

title: Summers for Soft-Shells, With a New Orleans Riff
description: THERE may be no bad way to prepare soft-shell crabs. They contain so much moisture theyre just about impossible to overcook, and they cook so quickly theyre hard to undercook.

title: Ex-Chief of China Food and Drug Unit Sentenced to Death for Graft
description: SHANGHAI, May 29  The former director of Chinas top food and drug safety agency was sentenced to death on Tuesday after pleading guilty to corruption and accepting bribes, the state-controlled news media reported.

title: A Concert Greets the Summer While Giving a Nod to the Past
description: The New York Philharmonic has established a tradition of playing a free concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine on Memorial Day, partly to commemorate the holiday itself  perhaps more acutely now, in wartime  and to inaugurate the summer, when the orchestra also performs free in the parks. On Monday Xian Zhang, the Philharmonics associate conductor, brought those impulses together in a program that began with Dvoraks ebullient Carnival Overture and then settled into Brahmss more solemn, philosophical but ultimately triumphant First Symphony.

title: Ending Our Tobacco Addiction
description: The sharp decline in the prevalence of smoking over the past four decades has been a towering public health achievement. In 1964, some 42 percent of adults in the United States smoked cigarettes. Today, only 21 percent do. But as an expert panel assembled by the Institute of Medicine warned last week, the downward trend shows signs of slowing while the death toll from cigarette smoking remains disturbingly high.

title: Man Posed as Yale Aide in Swindle of Irish Immigrants, Authorities Say
description: NEW HAVEN, May 29  It sounded good enough to be a dream come true, yet practical enough to be possible. The illegal Irish immigrants were eager to get their papers, and someone at Yale Law School was eager to help them.

title: Saffron Power: Yellow, Yet Not Necessarily Mellow
description: AT a symposium on Spanish cuisine last November, I anticipated two days of deconstructed, itsy-bitsy food, the hallmark of molecular cuisine that has captivated top chefs worldwide.

title: An Earthy Mushroom Pasta Sauce With Piquant Cheese for an Earthy, Truffly Wine
description: WHETHER they hail from Alba or Asti, barberas tend to share an earthy profile, striking fruity chords with notes of black truffle. Mushrooms, I thought, as I tasted. And pasta. Perhaps even a beefy red sauce.

title: Pink or Blue? These Bundles of Joy Are Always Green
description: Editors Note: In Advertising comes to you today because of the Memorial Day holiday yesterday. Look for In Advertising next week on June 4, its usual publication day, Monday.

description: Adapted from the Modern

title: Boeing Makes a $2.4 Billion Sale of 787s in Russia
description: MOSCOW, May 29  Boeing sold 15 of its next-generation 787 jets to a private Russian airline today in a deal valued at about $2.4 billion, Boeings largest sale in the former Soviet Union.

title: NBC, in Shake-Up, Names Outsider to a Top Position
description: NBC Universal shook up its entertainment operations yesterday, hiring one of the hottest young production talents in television, Ben Silverman, as a co-chairman of both the entertainment division and its television studio.

title: Ex-Trade Envoy Is Bushs Choice for World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  President Bush has chosen Robert B. Zoellick, a senior diplomat and trade envoy who became a top Goldman Sachs executive last year, to lead the World Bank and try to heal the bitter rifts left by the ouster of Paul D. Wolfowitz, the administration said Tuesday.

title: Russia Hails Test of a New Missile It Says Can Pierce Defense Shields
description: MOSCOW, May 29  Russia held a test launching of a new intercontinental ballistic missile on Tuesday and said it had successfully fired the weapon almost entirely across its northern airspace to the Russian Far East.

description: Adapted from Mara Jos San Romn

title: At Murder Trial, Prosecutors Doubt Police and Each Other
description: Curiouser and curiouser, cried the judge, Gustin L. Reichbach, channeling Alices Adventures in Wonderland as he surveyed the spectacle in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday.

title: Bronx: Four Injured by Gunfire
description: Four teenagers were seriously wounded early yesterday when a gunman walked into a fast-food restaurant on Archer Street and opened fire, the police said. The shooting occurred just after midnight near Taylor Avenue, the police said. The police did not provide a motive for the shooting. The victims were a 17-year-old boy who was hit in the chest, wrist and leg; an 18-year-old woman hit in the leg; a 19-year-old man hit in the leg; and another 19-year-old man who was struck in both legs, the police said. The police did not identify the victims. No arrests had been made yesterday evening, the police said.

title: Sheehan Says Shes Quitting as Face of Peace Movement
description: Cindy Sheehan, the antiwar activist who spent the last two years trying to confront President Bush, courting controversy and traveling around the world in protest of the war in Iraq, says she will now try a final tactic: silence.

title: Young Runner to Go After Family High School Record
description: In 1973, Matt Centrowitz of Power Memorial High School in Manhattan ran a mile in 4 minutes 2.7 seconds. On Saturday, his son, Matthew, will go after the family high school record. Officials of the Reebok Grand Prix announced yesterday that Matthew, an 18-year-old high school senior from Annapolis, Md., would run the mile in their meet Saturday at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island in New York. A month ago, the younger Centrowitz set a Penn Relays high school record of 4:08.38 for the mile. Last weekend, he ran 4:04.09 for 1,600 meters, the equivalent of 4:05.5 for the mile. His father, the track coach at American University, had a career best of 3:54.94 for the mile. The son is bound for the University of Oregon, his fathers alma mater.

title: Palestinian and Israeli Leaders to Meet Next Week, as Tensions Remain High
description: JERUSALEM, May 29  Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, and Ehud Olmert, Israels prime minister, will meet next week, their offices said Tuesday, in a continuation of a Washington-sponsored dialogue that will inevitably focus on another round of Israeli-Palestinian warfare.

title: Oil May Allow Sudan to Escape Sanctions Pain
description: The Bush administrations new sanctions against Sudan aim to squeeze the countrys economy by freezing Sudanese companies out of American financial institutions and curtailing their dollar transactions.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the position of Greenwich, Conn., as a must stop on the campaign fund-raising trail misidentified the birthplace of former President George Bush. He was born in Milton, Mass.  not Greenwich, where President Bush outraised Democrats in the 2004 campaign.

title: Obama Calls for Wider and Less Costly Health Care Coverage
description: IOWA CITY, May 29  Senator Barack Obama proposed a major overhaul of the nations health care system on Tuesday, aimed at covering the nearly 45 million uninsured Americans and reducing premium costs for everyone else.

title: Spitzer Names a Panel to Improve Universities in New York
description: ALBANY, May 29  Gov. Eliot Spitzer named a commission on Tuesday to recommend how to overhaul higher education in New York, saying he wanted to improve the reputation of the states public universities.

title: Gingrich Lambastes President and Rove
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  President Bush has presided over a Republican Party in collapse, and Karl Roves strategy in the 2004 presidential election was maniacally dumb for focusing so heavily on the conservative base.

title: Bush to Meet Putin in July
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  President Bush will be host to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Bush familys oceanside home in Kennebunkport, Me., on July 1 and 2, where the two leaders are to discuss several issues that have curdled relations between Washington and Moscow.

title: TB Patient Is Isolated After Taking Two Flights
description: Federal and international officials are tracking down passengers and crew members on two trans-Atlantic flights earlier this month who may have been exposed to a man infected with an exceptionally dangerous form of tuberculosis.

title: In a Switch, China Triples the Tax on Stock Trades
description: HONG KONG, Wednesday, May 30  In an abrupt reversal, Chinas finance ministry announced early Wednesday morning that it would triple the tax on stock trades, a move aimed at braking what many business executives and economists inside and outside China now see as a stock market bubble.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about a decision by the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, to remove at least five members of Community Board 6 who oppose the Atlantic Yards development project  which Mr. Markowitz supports  misstated the reason for the absence of a response by Mr. Markowitz. At the time the article was being reported, Mr. Markowitz could not be reached by his aides because he was on a ship at sea, had no telephone access and was not regularly checking his e-mail messages. He did not refuse to comment. (Go to Article)

title: End-of-Days Fidelity for Jericho
description: The problem with the proposition that television is an art is that art is meant to be deathless, while television shows are always being canceled.

description: WASHINGTON, May 30  President Bush announced today that he had chosen Robert B. Zoellick, a senior diplomat and trade envoy, to lead the World Bank, where one of his first tasks will be to try to heal the bitter rifts left by the ouster of the banks current president, Paul D. Wolfowitz.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about a clinical study that tests the risk of the diabetes treatment Avandia on the heart misspelled the surname of the F.D.A. spokeswoman who cautioned about misinterpreting data from early findings. She is Julie Zawisza, not Zawisa.

title: U.S. Raising Visa Fees 66% on Average, to Advocates Dismay
description: The federal agency that handles immigration visas confirmed yesterday that it would raise its fees by an average of 66 percent starting July 30. The step made final an increase first proposed in January, and drew a new outcry from immigration lawyers and advocacy groups.

title: A Notion From 9/11 Is Kept Alive
description: The first day of the post-Rosie ODonnell era on The View television show has come and gone, and by any fair accounting, an often useful provocateur has left the building.

description: Man, was I wrong about Iran.
