description: MOSCOW, May 29  The Boeing Company sold 15 of its next-generation 787 jets to a private Russian airline on Tuesday in a deal valued at about $2.4 billion, Boeings largest sale in the former Soviet Union.

title: Up for Auction, Thorpes Letters Make the Past Come Alive
description: Jim Thorpes life after his peak as an Olympic champion and amateur and professional football player until his exit from sports in 1928 has hardly been examined by mainstream historians. But a glimpse of his story and sports performances can be found in private correspondence recently released by his family.

title: Take Note: Computing Takes Up Pen, Again
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 29  For more than two decades, the dream of controlling a computer with a pen has seduced and, more often than not, frustrated some of the biggest luminaries in the technology pantheon, including Bill Gates and Steve Jobs.

title: A Bush Brother Spreads His Vision of Computerized Teaching Programs
description: SPOTSYLVANIA, Va.

title: The Cartridge, Updated, Catches Up to Data
description: If youve ever felt as though you cant keep up with the pace of life, well, it could have been worse. You could have been a computer disk.

title: Some Hitherto Staunch G.O.P. Voters Souring on Iraq
description: WILMETTE, Ill., May 29  Through four elections, Debbie Thompson has supported Representative Mark Steven Kirk, a Republican and staunch backer of the Bush administrations policies in Iraq.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Books of The Times review yesterday, about A Thousand Splendid Suns, by Khaled Hosseini, misspelled a characters name. She is Laila, not Lila.

title: A Crowd-Pleaser of a Trip and a Book to Try at Home
description: The Farmers Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y., has a sure crowd-pleasing exhibition on view until the end of October: Ice Cream: Our Cool Obsession. There are photographs, historical artifacts like antique ice cream machines and old trucks, and a retro ice cream parlor serving treats. The history of the confection, starting with water ices in ancient times, is explored.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about elections in Ireland referred incorrectly to televised endorsements for Bertie Aherns campaign for re-election as prime minister. The broadcasts had Prime Minister Tony Blair and former President Bill Clinton praising Mr. Aherns role in negotiations that led to the 1998 Good Friday peace accords in Northern Ireland. The endorsements did not praise Mr. Clintons role in the talks.

title: Setting the Rent
description: Setting the weekly rental rates for vacation homes on Kiawah Island, S.C., is a balancing exercise for Jeanette Lawson. I look at last years rates, she said. What did I ask, and how did it rent? If it rented too quickly, maybe I had it priced too low.

title: Downtown Landmark Makes a High-End Play
description: In a leap of faith in the Lower Manhattan office market, a group of real estate developers is creating what would be the financial districts first office tower with a country clubs exclusivity  and perhaps its extraordinary membership fees  in the Woolworth Building.

title: New Buildings Are Proposed Among Projects
description: Facing a $225 million budget gap, the City Housing Authority is planning to sharply reduce its staff and sell vacant land in its projects for development into housing, much of it for middle-income residents, officials said yesterday.

title: Trenton: Eight Indicted in Doughnut Shop Robberies
description: Eight people have been indicted on charges of robbing 97 small businesses in New Jersey and southeastern Pennsylvania, including a large number of doughnut shops, prosecutors said yesterday. Members of the group were charged with traveling to the businesses in rental cars, breaking in after they had closed and using crowbars to pry open cash registers, said Attorney General Stuart Rabner. In some cases, they also stole safes. Mr. Rabner said 50 police departments participated in the investigation.

title: Recipe: Papas Bravas
description: Adapted from Mara Jos San Romn

title: Russia: Court Grants Amnesty to Beslan Siege Police
description: A federal court granted amnesty to three policemen accused of negligence in failing to prevent a Chechen terrorist group from seizing a public school and more than 1,100 hostages in Beslan in 2004. Their trial, which began last year, had been seen as another chance to expose official bungling of the three-day siege, in which 333 people died, 186 of them children, and to turn up more information about lingering mysteries. Survivors and relatives, who accuse the government of a whitewash, reacted with dismay, shouting and rushing the judge, who was forced from the courtroom in North Ossetia before finishing reading his decision, according to local reports.

title: Fred Thompson Moves Toward a Run for President
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  Former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee shook up the Republican presidential field today by making clear that he is likely to run for the White House.

title: Weiss N.F.L. Friendships Led Browns to Quinn
description: BEREA, Ohio  When the Cleveland Browns general manager, Phil Savage, visited Notre Dame to watch a football practice last August, he was offered a special vantage point: Charlie Weiss guest-of-honor chair.

title: How Were Animalistic  in Good Ways and Bad
description: The odd thing is that conservatives wear pinstriped suits. They love the ancients so much that they really should be walking around in togas. The main contribution of the Greeks to modern American politics may have been Michael Dukakis, who once climbed the Acropolis in wingtips.

title: From a Pennsylvania Garden Patch, Down-Home Crocus Taste
description: YOU wouldnt think of saffron as a down-home flavoring. But in parts of Pennsylvania Dutch country, any respectable cook making the local specialty, chicken pot pie  really more of a stew than a pie  always uses a pinch of saffron.

title: TB Patient Was Advised Not to Fly
description: A man who may have exposed passengers and crew members on two trans-Atlantic flights earlier this month to a highly drug-resistant form of tuberculosis knew he was infected, and had been advised by health officials not to travel overseas.

title: Recipe: Pennsylvania Dutch Chicken Pot Pie
description: Time: 2 hours

title: Security Council to Vote on Court to Try Suspects in Beirut Slaying
description: UNITED NATIONS, May 29  The United States and its European allies, acting despite opposition from Russia, scheduled a vote for Wednesday on a binding Security Council resolution establishing an international court to try those suspected of killing Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Death Shapes a Reality Show

title: Fighting the Tide, a Few Restaurants Tilt to Tap Water
description: DONT bother asking for Fiji, San Pellegrino or any other designer water at either Incanto, a restaurant that opened in San Francisco in 2002, or at Poggio, which opened in Sausalito, Calif., two years later.

title: Recipe: Vegetable Paella With Wild Mushrooms
description: Adapted from Mara Jos San Romn

title: No More Excuses on Darfur
description: Behind-the-scenes diplomacy has done nothing to stop the slaughter of innocents in Darfur. For months, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations and other international leaders have been claiming that Sudans president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, was ready to halt further attacks by the Sudanese armed forces and its janjaweed militia allies and accept a robust international protective force. Instead, Mr. Bashir and his henchmen have used those months to kill still more people and drive others from their homes.

title: Brooklyn: Woman Fatally Stabbed
description: A 45-year-old woman was found dead in her home at 247 Malcolm X Boulevard in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday, the police said. She had been stabbed several times in the neck. The woman, who was not identified, was found by police officers shortly after 11:30 a.m. No arrests had been made yesterday evening, the police said.

title: In Her Time Away From Golf, Wie Enjoys Being 17 Years Old
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C., May 29  For Michelle Wie, the last four months away from golf have been a rest, a reality check and a chance to enjoy her last taste of high school without cramming it into her normally frantic schedule.

title: New York Is Top State in Dollars Per Student
description: New York again leads all other states in school spending per pupil, according to the latest census figures.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about early and absentee voting in next years presidential primaries misidentified the academic affiliation of Paul Gronke, a professor of political science who is an expert on early voting. He is at Reed College in Portland, Ore., not the University of Oregon.

title: Scattered Stories, Shaken and Stirred
description: PHILADELPHIA  Karen Kilimnik has gotten the survey that her strange, still difficult achievement deserves. For one thing, her show at the Institute of Contemporary Art is appropriately strange itself, beginning with a barren, seemingly empty, partys-over gallery. It goes deep into her woman-child imagination, touching an all-too-American sense of emptiness. It also makes her efforts in installation art, which encompass materials as various as glitter, fake snow and blood, stuffed animals, ballet shoes and piles of party drugs, feel of a piece with her painting, photography, video and drawing.

title: Life in the Sprawling Suburbs, if You Can Really Call It Living
description: In some ways a suburban city can be understood as an intolerant city. If that loaded quotation from the Calgary-based architect Marc Boutin doesnt tell you exactly where Radiant City stands on the issue of suburban sprawl, the filmmakers have plenty more just like it.

title: Parren Mitchell, 85, Congressman and Rights Leader, Dies
description: Parren J. Mitchell, who as the first black elected to Congress from Maryland led the Congressional Black Caucus and spearheaded programs to aid minority-owned business, an effort he viewed as the second phase of the civil rights movement, died on Monday in Baltimore. He was 85.

title: Suicide Poses Old Threat to Japans New Leader
description: TOKYO, May 29  When Prime Minister Shinzo Abe took office last fall, he was a popular leader vowing to end what he called Japans postwar regime. But the suicide of the agricultural minister this week threatens his administration with one of the oldest problems in Japanese politics: money scandals.

title: Earl Ubell, Science Reporter, Dies at 80
description: Earl Ubell, a science reporter and editor familiar to generations of New Yorkers for his wide-ranging reports in the old New York Herald Tribune and on WCBS-TV, died on Tuesday in a nursing home in Englewood, N.J. He was 80 and had been a resident of Hackensack, N.J.

title: Pondering Some Old, Familiar Questions on the Road Across Country
description: The tires whine, and sometimes they moan. Sometimes they send up a whistle I dont even hear until it stops. Now and then the asphalt runs smooth and true. But mostly the interstate is a series of discontinuities  a sharp thump as we hit a shallow overpass, a few miles partly paved with recycled rubber, a long sequence in western Nebraska where the tires make the sound of the special effects in Walter Mittys mind. And then there is Omaha, where the freeway looks smooth but is really a dozen heavily corrugated miles that must drive the truckers insane.

title: Bonds Sits One Out as the Beat Goes On
description: Barry Bonds of the San Francisco Giants did more singing than playing at Shea Stadium yesterday. He rolled into the clubhouse with a digital music player on his arm and headphones over his ears. Soon after his arrival, the Giants announced that Bonds was not starting and not talking.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about a legal immigrant and Persian Gulf war veteran who has been detained in a New Jersey jail for three years while immigration authorities try to deport him for a firearms conviction misstated his surname at one point in some copies. He is Warren Joseph, not Mr. Warren.

title: Pretty Faces With Plenty of Troubles, and Secrets
description: Hidden Palms, the new series from Kevin Williamson making its debut tonight on CW, may be the first teenage soap opera visually dedicated to mid-20th-century Modernism. Remove the sex, sociopathology and possible filicide, and you will still be left with a quite inspiring home design show.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A headline on a report in The Caucus yesterday, about The New York Posts error in reporting that Senator John Kerry had chosen Richard A. Gephardt as his running mate in 2004, misstated the famous headline in The Chicago Daily Tribune in 1948 when the paper declared the wrong winner in the presidential race. The headline was Dewey Defeats Truman, not Dewey Beats Truman. (Go to Article)

title: Dont Point That Menu at My Child, Please
description: IT seems like such a wonderful concept when you encounter it for the first time as a parent. You go to a restaurant as a family, are seated and given menus, and the waitress cheerfully turns to your children and exclaims, And these are for you! Their own special menus  kids menus! Sometimes these are little laminated things, peewee facsimiles of what Mom and Dad are holding. Sometimes these are placemats that not only tell you what foods are available but also contain mazes and word-search puzzles.

title: Digging Deeper Into Darfur
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Lottery Numbers
Experts Say Decision on Pay Reorders Legal Landscape
description: Yesterdays Supreme Court ruling limiting the ability of workers to sue companies for pay discrimination will reorder the legal landscape for employees and employers, workplace experts said.

title: Europe Pushes to Get Fuel From Fields
description: ARDEA, Italy  The previous growing season, this lush coastal field near Rome was filled with rows of delicate durum wheat, used to make high-quality pasta. Today it overflows with rapeseed, a tall, gnarled weedlike plant bursting with coarse yellow flowers that has become a new manna for European farmers: rapeseed can be turned into biofuel.

title: Rice Rejects Link of Iran Arrests and Captures of Guards in Iraq
description: BERLIN, May 29  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice on Tuesday rejected linking Irans charges against three Iranian-Americans in Tehran to the Bush administrations capture of members of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard in Iraq.

title: Telling Indias Modern Women They Have Power, Even Over Their Skin Tone
description: NEW DELHI, May 29  The modern Indian woman is independent, in charge  and does not have to live with her dark skin.

title: Stuck in the Middle With You
description: Even as abortion, the environment and immigration -- some of the perennials in politics -- are being used by interest groups to raise the decibel level and galvanize the left and the right, some of the presidential candidates are playing to the middle. Perhaps theyve been reading the poll numbers.

title: A Garden in Miami, a Loft in Athens
description: For Nicholas Pisaris, an international negotiator and corporate lawyer, life is a tale of two cities. He divides his year between a home hidden in an orchid-filled garden in Miamis historic Coconut Grove and a loft apartment with the Acropolis on the skyline.

title: Malaysian Court Refuses to Recognize Womans Conversion to Christianity
description: PUTRAJAYA, Malaysia, May 30  In a controversial victory for Islamic law over secularism, Malaysias highest court today refused to recognize the conversion of a Muslim-born woman to Christianity, ruling that the matter was beyond the jurisdiction of the countrys civil courts and should be handled by religious authorities.

title: Group Makes $95.6 Billion Bid for ABN Amro
description: LONDON, May 29  The Royal Bank of Scotland Group and two other European banks made a formal $95.6 billion bid today for ABN Amro, the Dutch bank at the center of a bidding war with Barclays in the richest banking takeover.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening Soon

title: Georgia, Alabama and a Bit of Gold Fever
description: IN retrospect, the warning signs were obvious. My heart thudded uncontrollably as I cruised along South Carolinas verdant, rustic Route 72, and I was gripped by waves of boundless enthusiasm and irrational exuberance. Sweat beaded on my forehead and down my back  was the air-conditioning failing, or was my health? By the time I crossed into Georgia, Id diagnosed my problem: I had gold fever  and Id caught it from you, my readers.

title: In First for Britain, U.S. Citizen Is Extradited on Terror Charges
description: An American citizen extradited over the weekend from England pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of conspiring to send money and military gear to associates of Al Qaeda, federal prosecutors said.

title: Summer Breezes in, Sipping Barbera
description: WHATS that noise? Sort of like a whoosh, a collective exhale, a sigh of relaxation? Is it a signal that summer may finally be upon us?

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,449 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Yankees Find a New Way to Lose
description: TORONTO, May 29  The Yankees took infield practice before Tuesdays game, a rare in-season crash course in fundamentals. One play they did not simulate was a runner stealing home.

title: Lens Fluid Maker Says Link to Infection Unsolved
description: Advanced Medical Optics said yesterday morning that it had no explanation yet of why its leading contact lens care product might be contributing to an outbreak of eye infections. And it said it would be next week before it could provide Wall Street with an estimate of the financial impact of its global recall of the lens cleaner.

title: Gunmen in Police Uniforms Kidnap 5 British Civilians
description: BAGHDAD, May 29  Gunmen wearing police commando uniforms abducted five British civilians from a Finance Ministry complex on Tuesday, British officials said. They seized a business consultant and his four bodyguards in an attack that revived questions about links between official security forces and criminal militias.

title: Los Angeles Police Chief Notes Failures of Command at Rally
description: LOS ANGELES, May 29  The clash between the police and demonstrators and journalists at an immigration rights rally on May 1 demonstrated a command and control breakdown so severe that at times officers did not know who was in charge, Chief William J. Bratton of the police said Tuesday.

title: Pakistans Suspended Justice Tells of Facing Down Musharraf
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 29  Pakistans suspended chief justice, challenging his dismissal, said in an affidavit on Tuesday that he had been detained for several hours on March 9 and pressed to resign by the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, as well as senior military and intelligence officials.

title: Overhaul of Immigration Law Could Reshape New York
description: Few places in the United States could be more deeply affected by the proposed overhaul of legal immigration than New York, say scholars and demographers of immigration.

title: Physician, Upgrade Thyself
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Arts Space in Brooklyn to Get New Digs
description: In a move that has greater symbolic significance than mere real estate hopscotch, Galapagos Art Space, the pioneering bar and performing arts space that helped put Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on the cultural map, is moving a few neighborhoods down the East River, to Dumbo.

title: Azerbaijan: BP Denies Playing Role in Coup Attempts
description: An executive of the energy company BP felt compelled to hold a news conference in Baku, the capital of oil-rich Azerbaijan, to deny allegations that the company had tried to stage coups in 1992 and 1993. The executive, Bill Schrader, the country president for BP, said such an action would contradict corporate philosophy, according to a report by the Interfax news agency. Mr. Schrader was responding to articles in Azeri newspapers and the British tabloid Daily Mail citing accusations of a former BP employee.

title: A Rocky Start for Nevadas New Governor
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., May 24  Life these days for Gov. Jim Gibbons of Nevada might kindly be described as suboptimal.

title: Scottish-Led Group Bids $95.6 Billion for ABN Amro
description: LONDON, May 29  The Royal Bank of Scotland Group and two other European banks made a formal $95.6 billion bid Tuesday for ABN Amro of the Netherlands, challenging Barclays in what would be the richest banking takeover.

title: An Uprising Squelched and a Budget in Place, Texas Legislators Head Home to Recover
description: HOUSTON, May 29  Bidding farewell to a raucous legislative session he branded the good, the bad and the ugly, Gov. Rick Perry commended Texas lawmakers in Austin on Tuesday for passing a last-minute budget that cut school property taxes and expanded financing for health care, education and border security.

title: The Rise of Globalization, a Story of Human Desires
description: Globalization has a bad image problem. It is a conceptual tar baby to which every perceived ill in the world attaches: depressed commodity prices, Asian sweat shops, child labor, fast-food imperialism, American cultural hegemony, outsourcing and global warming. A low point for the worlds most unstoppable trend came on Sept. 10, 2003, when Lee Kyung-hae, a distraught Korean farmer protesting at the World Trade Organization summit in Cancn, Mexico, plunged a knife into his own heart after shouting Death to W.T.O.

title: Down to Last Out, the Mets Arent Down at All
description: The scorecard from last nights Mets-San Francisco Giants game featured a bunch of Ks, a few HRs and some on-the-fly notations that, in the end, did little justice to what actually played out on the Shea Stadium grass last night.

title: U.S. Seeks to Break Deadlock in North Korea Talks
description: BEIJING, May 30  Arms control negotiators from the United States and China met here today in an effort to revive a stalled agreement under which North Korea would begin to dismantle its nuclear weapons program.

title: New Jersey Public Advocate Seeks Stronger Eminent Domain Protections for Property Owners
description: TRENTON, May 29  The New Jersey public advocate urged the Legislature on Tuesday to adopt a law that would make the use of eminent domain more equitable, while preserving it as a valuable redevelopment tool for many hard-pressed cities.

title: Brooklyn: Man Sought in Brothers Killing
description: A 46-year-old Brooklyn man was found shot to death in his apartment yesterday afternoon, and his brother was being sought as the leading suspect, the police said. The victim, whose name had not been released pending family notification, was shot several times in the torso. His body was found shortly after 3 p.m. in the apartment at 109 Butler Street in Boerum Hill.

title: Russia to Issue Visas to Georgians
description: Russia resumed accepting visa applications from Georgian citizens, a step toward easing tensions that have strained relations between the countries after Georgia chose to align closely with the West. Russia also suggested the possibility of a meeting between President Vladimir V. Putin and his Georgian counterpart, Mikheil Saakashvili. Disputes remain. Russia has not lifted its import ban of Georgian wine and mineral water, or its block against direct postal service and air traffic with Georgia.

title: The Popes Language Lesson
description: Vatican City

title: Go, Eat, You Never Know
description: THEY come around every few years, these rumors that Katzs Delicatessen is about to close or move or somehow betray itself and those of us who care about it, and our response is always the same.

title: With Financial Tactic, Corzine Would Keep Turnpike Public, Toll Increases and All
description: Who knew that the New Jersey Turnpike, the states congested artery that commuters love to hate, was so beloved?

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A television column on May 19 about the prime-time fall schedules at the major television networks misspelled the surname of the star of a new Fox drama, Canterburys Law. She is Julianna Margulies, not Marguiles.

title: Is Wal-Mart Too Cheap for Its Own Good?
description: Low prices, it turns out, can be bad for business.

title: Truth, Fiction and Lou Dobbs
description: The whole controversy involving Lou Dobbs and leprosy started with a 60 Minutes segment a few weeks ago.

title: Losses All Around for American Men
description: PARIS, May 29  To figure out how Andy Roddick was faring in his first-round match Tuesday at the French Open, spectators did not have to see the score.

title: China Triples Tax on Stock Trades
description: HONG KONG, May 30  Chinese stocks plunged today after Chinas finance ministry announced early this morning that it would triple the tax on stock trades, a move aimed at braking what many business executives and economists inside and outside China now see as a stock market bubble.

title: Agreeing to Code of Conduct on Student Loans
description: Wells Fargo, one of the largest companies in the student loan business, has agreed to follow a code of conduct developed by the New York attorney generals office governing relationships between lenders and universities. The code, which came as a result of a continuing investigation by the attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, prohibits practices including giving a university money or other incentives in exchange for steering students to a particular lender. Mr. Cuomos investigation identified instances in which loan companies paid universities based on the amounts borrowed by students, as well as questionable ties between financial aid administrators and lenders. The latest agreement means that the five largest student loan companies in the country have agreed to follow the code.

title: Woman Accused of Killing Companion With an S.U.V.
description: A Brooklyn woman was charged with murder yesterday after she ran over her companion with her Nissan Pathfinder while he was riding a bicycle, then put the vehicle in reverse and struck him again, the police said.

title: Having a Snack? Make It a Holiday
description: WE are, each and every one of us, standing together on the threshold of National Surimi Seafood Month. June is also the month to celebrate papayas, iced tea, frozen yogurt, candy, soul food, steakhouses and applesauce cake. And whether you eat turkeys or simply admire them, prepare to party. June is Turkey Lovers Month, too.

title: Sadness in Our Hearts (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: James Takes Game Into His Hands in Fourth Quarter
description: CLEVELAND, May 29  LeBron James was on the free-throw line with four seconds remaining in Game 4, his Cleveland Cavaliers holding a 2-point lead after a nail-biting finish worthy of whatever remained at the tip of Jamess fingers.

title: Shots Kill One and Hurt One at Party on S.I.
description: A shotgun-toting partygoer shot and killed a 17-year-old youth and injured a 15-year-old boy early yesterday during a gathering at a Staten Island housing complex, the police said.

title: NBC Brings In Programming Help
description: NBC Universal shook up its entertainment operations today by hiring one of the hottest young production talents in television, Ben Silverman, as a chairman of both its entertainment division and its television studio.

title: The Concerts Found Onstage While Everyone Else Takes a Break
description: For seven years, Christopher DeLaurenti went to orchestral concerts wired, wearing a leather vest with microphones nestled in the shoulders and cables running down the back. Come intermission, when the audience wandered out, Mr. DeLaurenti perked up.

title: Now, Spitzer Is Warming to Wall St.
description: As attorney general of New York, Eliot Spitzer made a name for himself as a tough cop willing to take on deep-pocketed industries like Wall Street and insurance. Now, as governor, he may be making life a little easier for them in an effort to keep financial services in New York competitive in the global market.

title: Clemens Slotted to Face White Sox
description: TORONTO, May 29  The Yankees would be strutting a little more about the arrival of Roger Clemens if they were closer to first place. As it stands, they expect to put Clemens in their rotation on Monday in Chicago, with tempered expectations.

title: Should British Academics, or Rock Bands, Boycott Israel?
description: LONDON, May 29  In what has become an annual rite, British college teachers will debate Wednesday whether they should punish their Israeli colleagues, in solidarity with Palestinians calling for boycotts, and whether it would be anti-Semitic to do so.

title: Correction
description: An article last Wednesday about a decision by the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, to remove at least five members of Community Board 6 who oppose the Atlantic Yards development project  which Mr. Markowitz supports  misstated the reason for the absence of a response by Mr. Markowitz. At the time the article was being reported, Mr. Markowitz could not be reached by his aides because he was on a ship at sea, had no telephone access and was not regularly checking his e-mail messages. He did not refuse to comment.

title: Clinton Secures Endorsement of the Mayor of Los Angeles
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and former President Bill Clinton have delivered another one-two punch that reflects their combined political power: corralling the endorsement of Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angeles, one of the most powerful Democrats in California and among the most influential Hispanics in the nation.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A caption with an article on May 15 about the trial of Jose Padilla, who is charged with conspiring to support terrorism, incorrectly rendered the name of his mother, who was shown outside federal court in Miami. She is Estela Ortega-Lebron, not Estrela Ortega. The article also misstated the year of his transfer from military custody to civilian custody. It was 2006, not 2005.

title: Gretchen Wyler, 75, Actress and Advocate for Animals, Dies
description: Gretchen Wyler, an actress in Broadway musicals in the 1950s and 60s who became known in later years as an animal-rights advocate, died on Sunday at her home in Camarillo, Calif. She was 75.

title: Young Optimists (Up to a Point) (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Ruling Limits Suits on Pay Disparity
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  The Supreme Court on Tuesday made it harder for many workers to sue their employers for discrimination in pay, insisting in a 5-to-4 decision on a tight time frame to file such cases. The dissenters said the ruling ignored workplace realities.

title: What Happens if We Leave Iraq? (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany Leaders Agree to Extend Law Protecting Loft Tenants
description: ALBANY, May 29  Leaders of the State Assembly and Senate agreed on Tuesday to an extension of the loft law, which protects tenants who live in old commercial lofts from eviction, two days before the legislation was set to expire.

title: Immigrants and Prison
description: Near the start of his Nov. 4, 2003, program on CNN, Lou Dobbs said, One-third of the inmates now serving time in federal prisons come from some other country  one-third. Later, he offered more details: Coming up, were going to take a further look at the impact of illegal aliens. And it is an expensive proposition, particularly in our nations prisons. Illegal aliens, those citizens  noncitizens taking up a third of the cells in our federal penitentiaries.

title: Hewlett-Packard Stakes a Claim as an Information Manager
description: Vyomesh Joshi does not think of those trillions of pages crowding the Internet as the screen images they are. He sees them as the printouts they could be.

title: Does the Man Who Put the Fire in Fired! Still Have It?
description: If Brian Cashman is on a big hook, as George Steinbrenner said last week in one of those interviews he rarely grants, would the Boss fire him?

title: All the Right Moves to Annoy the Jazz
description: SALT LAKE CITY, May 29  Manu Ginbili bumped and flailed, Tim Duncan coolly pivoted in the post and Tony Parker darted through every gap. After a dozen minutes of flapping arms, precise footwork and boundless energy, the Utah Jazz was flustered, and just about finished.

title: Irans Giant Shoe Box of Faded Photographs, Full of the Unexpected
description: TEHRAN, May 29  When Shadi Ghadirian was 21, she got a student job printing old photographs at the small photography museum here. She was so drawn by the 19th-century pictures of women with thick black eyebrows wearing head scarves and short skirts over baggy pants that two years later, in 2000, she began incorporating the imagery into her own photography.

title: Equity Firm to Acquire Net Retailer
description: The CDW Corporation, a leading online computer reseller, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell itself to Madison Dearborn Partners for $7.3 billion in cash, the latest big acquisition by a private equity firm.

title: Thai Court Clears One Party but Convicts Another
description: BANGKOK, May 30  A Thai constitutional court found today that members of one of the countrys major political parties violated the countrys voting laws in elections last year, raising the prospect that it may be dissolved. A few hours earlier, the other major party was acquitted by the same court.

title: Bush Takes On Conservatives Over Immigration
description: GLYNCO, Ga., May 29  President Bush took on parts of his conservative base on Tuesday by accusing opponents of his proposed immigration measure of fear-mongering to defeat its passage in Congress.

title: Convictions of Samsung Executives Upheld
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 29  An appeals court on Tuesday upheld the conviction of two senior executives at the Samsung Group on charges that they helped the only son of its reclusive chairman, Lee Kun Hee, inherit control of Samsung, the countrys largest conglomerate.

title: The Coal Trap
description: There is a rule for judging solutions to the twin problems of energy dependence and global warming: A policy designed to solve one problem should not make the other worse. But that is a likely outcome of the many energy independence bills circulating in Congress that aim to build a whole new generation of coal-to-liquid plants to convert coal into automotive fuel.

title: Mother Hangs 4 Daughters and Herself, Police Say
description: HUDSON OAKS, Tex., May 29  A woman who was said to be struggling with depression apparently hanged her four young daughters in their North Texas mobile home early Tuesday morning before hanging herself, the authorities said.

title: Deal for Big REIT Startles Some Experts
description: First real estate specialists were surprised by the deal. Then they were surprised by the price.

title: Tishman Speyer in Deal for Big REIT
description: Tishman Speyer Properties, the real estate company that bought two prominent apartment complexes on Manhattans Lower East Side, has joined with the investment bank Lehman Brothers to buy Archstone-Smith Trust, the second-largest public apartment owner in terms of market capitalization and asset value, for $13.5 billion, the companies said today.

title: At the Ensemble Studio Theater, the Show Must Go On
description: The auditorium at John Jay College was packed, with 600 people gathered for a three-hour memorial service featuring three dozen speakers. Curt Dempster, the founder and artistic director of the Ensemble Studio Theater, was remembered as an idiosyncratic and prickly visionary, someone who not only kept the theater alive for 35 years in its ramshackle 74-seat home on West 52nd Street but also, at times, seemed indistinguishable from it.

title: Three Menus and a Few Sure Things
description: DOES the trolley still run down Eighth Avenue?

title: Touch Screen in a Table Is the Latest Wrinkle in Computers
description: Having just tried its hand at developing a digital music player, Microsoft is working on something new: digital furniture.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about the impact of plunging CD sales on big music companies and the companies efforts to sell more recordings misidentified the electronic file format in which Apples iTunes will sell EMIs music catalog without protection against copying. It is AAC, not MP3.

title: Reading to a Partner That Listens on Command
description: WESTPORT, Conn.  Sofia Weinberg, 9, carefully chose a popular picture book from a table one recent afternoon, then waited in line for her turn to read to Sandy at the Westport Public Library. Within minutes, Sofia and Sandy were snuggling together on a pale blue blanket, poring over the book, Martha Speaks. Sofia pronounced each word carefully, yet softly. And Sandy listened attentively, occasionally panting from the heat of the day.

title: In North Iraq, Sunni Arabs Drive Out Kurds
description: MOSUL, Iraq  The letter tossed into Mustafa Abu Bakr Muhammads front yard got right to the point.

title: At Midday, You See All Types
description: IN the rest of the country I love you may be the three sweetest words in the English language, but in New York nothing beats, My lunch canceled.

title: Mexico: Migrant Jumps to His Death in Immigration Sweep
description: A raid by the authorities on a train carrying undocumented Central American immigrants in southern Mexico ended in tragedy on Monday as a man jumped to his death from a moving rail car and a boy had his leg severed by the trains wheels. We were all on top of the train when the police began chasing us, the boy, Luis Carlos Hernndez, 14, from Honduras, told The Associated Press from a hospital in Veracruz, where he was recovering from an amputated right leg. The unidentified man who jumped fell onto the tracks and was decapitated, officials said.

title: Raids in Baghdad Follow Kidnappings
description: BAGHDAD, May 30  American and Iraqi troops raided Baghdads Sadr City neighborhood on Wednesday, looking for five British citizens abducted a day earlier from a nearby government building, military and diplomatic officials said.

title: Prosecutors Accuse Banker of Fraud and Conspiracy
description: Federal prosecutors charged a high-level investment banker in Pakistan yesterday with earning more than $7.5 million in illegal profit from an insider-trading scheme that they say was run by a former Credit Suisse banker.

title: Bumped Fliers and No Plan B
description: PHOENIX  The summer travel season is under way, and so many planes are expected to be full that, if you are bumped, you could end up waiting days for a seat on another flight to the same destination.

title: The Bonds Paradox: Headphones, Head Games
description: With his unmistakable head bobbing to a beat, an amused Barry Bonds swept through a thicket of news media in the Giants clubhouse as if the music piping through his Bose headphones were more Doris Day than the latest iPod download: Que Ser Ser (Whatever Will Be, Will Be).

title: Waiting for Steinbrenner as Free Fall Continues
description: Between innings here in Toronto, the Blue Jays sometimes run a skit on their scoreboard thats a take-off on the George Steinbrenner character from Seinfeld. The Big Stein is shown from the back, in a wood-paneled office, barking orders at the Blue Jays mascot.

title: Dont Point That Menu at My Child, Please
description: In his early days as a parent he regarded childrens menus as a great thing, David Kamp writes in todays Dining section, but he has come to conclude that the kids menu is regressive, encouraging youngsters to believe that there is a rigidly delineated kids cuisine.

title: Lost City of the Incas
description: Choquequirao, a sister city of similar significance to Machu Picchu, is harder to reach, but still sufficiently free of tourists.

title: Londons sustainable luxury
description: Clareville

title: Kobe Bryant Asks to be Traded
description: Kobe Bryant, the NBA's most dazzling player and the star of three straight championships for the Los Angeles Lakers, has asked to be traded.

title: Splash!
description: You look better in less if you're in pretty good shape. And if you're not, who cares?

title: Looking at Anselm Kiefer
description: Additional images from the Anselm Kiefer exhibition at the Grand Palais in Paris.

title: Fred D. Thompson, in His Own Words
description: A look at what Fred D. Thompson has said on the issues:

title: VeriSigns Chief Executive Resigns Abruptly
description: VeriSign, which manages the dot-com and dot-net domain names registry, said on Tuesday that its chief executive, Stratton D. Sclavos, had resigned for undisclosed reasons. Analysts were startled by the abrupt departure. The company gave little information about the reason for Mr. Sclavoss departure after 12 years as chief executive.

title: I.B.M. Borrows $11.5 Billion to Buy Back Stock
description: I.B.M. disclosed Tuesday that it was taking on $11.5 billion in debt to finance an acceleration of its stock repurchase plan, which the company believes is one of the largest such steps ever.

title: Convictions of Samsung Executives Upheld
description: An appeals court on Tuesday upheld the conviction of two senior executives at the Samsung Group on charges that they helped the only son of its reclusive chairman, Lee Kun Hee, inherit control of Samsung, the countrys largest conglomerate.

title: Are Online Ad Firms Overpriced?
description: The debate continues: Are the recent deals involving online-advertising firms  GoogleDoubleclick, MicrosoftaQuantive, WPP24/7 Real Media  signs of a bubble, or wise, strategic, long-term plays?

title: India Prepares for Its Biggest I.P.O.
description: A real estate developer, DLF, on Tuesday kicked off the sales effort for an initial public offering to raise $2.4 billion, the largest yet in India.

title: Has a Management Buyout Bid Put Bradleys in Play?
description: Bradley Pharmaceuticals founder and chief executive wants to take his company private, but he may have inadvertently put it into play on Tuesday with a $352.6 million bid, Forbes says. Bradleys stock soared 21.2 percent Tuesday, rising $3.91, to $22.35, a premium to the $21.50 offered by the companys chief executive, Daniel Glassman.

title: More Defections from Coles Consortium Are Rumored
description: The private equity consortium bidding for the Australian retailer Coles Group, responding to rumors that two more members had pulled out, said on Wednesday it could not confirm whether all four participants were still in the group.

title: Viacom Said to Sell Famous Music to Sony
description: Viacom has agreed to sell its Famous Music publishing business to Sony/ATV Music Publishing for about $370 million, the Wall Street Journal reported, adding that a deal may be announced Wednesday.

title: Proxy Firm Deals Blow to Biomet Buyout, Report Says
description: In the latest example of resistance to private equity buyouts, the deal for the medical-device maker Biomet got a thumb downs from the influential proxy advisory firm Institutional Shareholder Services, which recommended Biomet holders vote down a $10.9 billion private-equity deal for the company, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Now, Spitzer Is Warming to Wall Street
description: As attorney general of New York, Eliot Spitzer made a name for himself as a tough cop willing to take on deep-pocketed industries like Wall Street and insurance. Now, writes The New York Timess Jenny Anderson, as governor, he may be making life a little easier for them in an effort to keep financial services in New York competitive in the global market.

title: Is Russia the Next V.C. Hot Spot?
description: Thanks in part to such increasingly global and sophisticated management, tech startups in Russia are coming of age, according to BusinessWeek. Indeed, after years of promise and potential, Russia finally looks poised to become the next hot destination for foreign V.C. investment.

title: An Unofficial Fan Club No More
description: The Web site dedicated to the pole vaulting internet star has closed down, apparently bowing to her complaints lodged from the front page of The Washington Post on Tuesday. Renaming itself the Former Unofficial Allison Stokke Fan Page, the site left a message for her:

title: Blacks New York Pad Worth Triple What He Paid, Witness Says
description: A New York real estate appraiser testified Tuesday in the federal fraud trial of Conrad Black that the Manhattan apartment bought by the former media baron in 2000 had a market value nearly three times the $3 million he paid the newspaper company for it.

title: Airband Snags $12.5 Million in venture capital
description: Airband Communications said Tuesday that it had received $12.5 million in its latest round of venture funding. M/C Venture Partners of Boston was the lead investor in Dallas-based Airband, which provides wireless broadband networks for businesses.

title: CBS Said to Buy Last.fm for $280 Million
description: CBS is buying a popular social-networking Website organized around musical tastes for $280 million, combining a traditional broadcast giant with an early leader in online radio, according to the Los Angeles Times. CBS is expected to announce today that it has acquired London-based Last.fm, which claims more than 15 million monthly users, including more than 4 million in the United States, the report said.

title: Dynegy Sells Plant to Gates-Backed Venture
description: A joint venture between Cascade Investments, a private equity firm controlled by Microsofts chairman, Bill Gates, and PNM Resources will buy a gas-fired power plant in Texas from Dynegy for $467.5 million.

title: Scrutiny Aside, Googles DoubleClick Deal Is Likely to Pass Muster
description: There was little doubt that the Federal Trade Commission would thoroughly investigate Googles planned purchase of DoubleClick, but, says BusinessWeek, theres even less doubt that the FTC will eventually sign off on the $3.1 billion deal for the online advertiser.

title: Deutsche Telekom Backs Rival Start-Up
description: Deutsche Telekom said it was backing Web telephone-calling start-up Jajah, embracing a technology that undercuts rates for the German telecommunication giants established long-distance and mobile phone businesses.

title: Cantor Fitzgerald Brings Together Brokers in $1.3 Billion Move
description: Cantor Fitzgerald agreed to sell BGC Partners to its listed ESpeed unit for $1.3 billion in stock, combining the voice and electronic bond trading divisions a month after rejecting a takeover offer for ESpeed.

title: British Want Their Hedge Fund Access
description: The British want more hedge fund access, and that might suit the Financial Services Authority just fine. Just 10 percent of the public in Britain think the asset class should be the sole domain of the professional investor, with the majority favoring wider access, according to a study commissioned by F&C.

title: More Pain at Goldmans Flagship Hedge Fund
description: It often seems as if Goldman Sachs, the highly profitable securities firm, knows how to pluck money from thin air. But the firm is losing its touch with Global Alpha, its flagship hedge fund, which manages money for some of Goldmans wealthiest clients and employees.

title: Backing Up Your Files
description: David Pogue reviews three removable cartridge systems.

title: Kravis Seeks to Allay Canadas Fears on BCE Bid
description: Amid rising political tension in Canada over a recent spate of foreign takeovers, Henry R. Kravis, co-founder of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, sought Tuesday to play down the level of his firms involvement in the bidding war for BCE and offer reassurances he was not masterminding the acquisition of the countrys biggest telephone company.

title: The World Bank and the Goldman Connection
description: Though Tuesdays nomination of Robert B. Zoellick as the new president of the World Bank is newsworthy in its own right, theres a Wall Street angle as well: It marks yet another top political post for a Goldman Sachs alumnus.

title: Jihadists Fill Palestinian Power Vacuum
description: A standoff between the Lebanese Army and Islamists has focused attention on a jihadist element.

title: ICE Sweetens CBOT Offer With Settlement Deal
description: IntercontinentalExchange, hoping to bolster its unsolicited bid for the Chicago Board of Trade, said Wednesday it had reached a deal with the Chicago Board Options Exchange to settle a longstanding dispute over trading rights at the CBOT. The deal applies only if ICE merges with CBOT.

title: 2008: Looking Back on War Votes
description: The New York Times Magazine preview now available is itself a preview of a new book by Jeff Gerth and Don Van Natta Jr., former and current Timesmen, respectively. Their full book, Her Way: The Hopes and Ambitions of Hillary Rodham Clinton, will be published by Little, Brown next week. In the adapted article, the investigative reporters examine Mrs. Clintons Oct. 11, 2002 vote authorizing the use of force in Iraqcalling into question whether she read the national intelligence estimateand the subsequent political fallout and shifts on the issue.

title: Commenting on the Commentators
description: Funny thing happened on the way to last weekends Super Sunday of auto racing telecasts. The announcing crews seemed as if they had been switched in the delivery room.

title: Leak Prosecutor Says Plame Was Covert
description: Valerie Plame Wilsons covert status at the C.I.A. is old news for many observers of the inquiry into the leaking of her identity. One side of the political divide argued that she was actually on desk duty at Langley at the time of Robert Novaks infamous column naming her, which would mean that the leaking of her identity was, if not exactly nice, not illegal either. The other side, and Ms. Wilson herself, said the opposite.

title: Its Not Paranoia If Theyre Really Out to Get You
description: Tobin Harshaw

title: FIA exonerates McLaren and clarifies team orders
description: The FIA has obviously decided to waste no time in keeping anyone in suspense on this McLaren team orders situation by coming to an immediate, categoric and very clear decision on the affair. In fact, it has taken the opportunity to very clearly lay out a policy, it seems to me, that sets a precedent for what is and is not acceptable in the way of team orders. In fact, retrospectively, I suspect that one of the reasons the FIA jumped on this problem was certainly to clear the air over accusations against McLaren and to take this as an opportunity to wipe out any possibility of suspicions.

title: Stuck in the Middle With You
Ernst & Young Wont Face Criminal Charges
description: Update: A grand jury in Manhattan indicted four Ernst & Young employees on charges including conspiracy to defraud the Internal Revenue Service, tax evasion, making false statements to the I.R.S., and impeding and impairing the lawful functioning of the I.R.S. See the updated story by The New York Times here.

title: Thompsons on the Move Toward a Run
description: Weve now confirmed that former Tennessee Senator Fred Thompson is taking formal steps toward a presidential bid, through the formation next week of a testing-the-waters committee that will allow him to do some fundraising.

title: Evercore Bulks Up With Two Bankers
description: Evercore Partners, the boutique investment bank, has wooed two investment bankers away from bulge-bracket firms in what might be the start of an aggressive expansion strategy. The firm, which went public less than a year ago, said Tuesday it had hired Francois Maisonrouge, who had been a managing director and chair of life sciences at Credit Suisse, and Mark Vander Ploeg, who was previously a vice chairman of investment banking at Merrill Lynch. Both join Evercore as senior managing directors.

title: Hedge Fund Signals Support for Clear Channel Deal
description: In their tortured quest to take Clear Channel Communications private, the radio giants two bidders have locked up a key constituent. One of the companys largest shareholders disclosed Wednesday that it would approve the latest version of the deal, which has dragged amid resistance from some investors.

description: The value of a bachelor's degree is plummeting in France's archaic state-owned university system. (Producer: Emily B. Hager)

description: The Times's C.J. Chivers reports on the revival of a dance ritual among  Chechnya's Sufi Muslims, a sect that is also erecting the region's largest mosque.    Producer: Adam B. Ellick

title: Tracking the Spread of HIV
description: A U.N. report indicates that the number of people infected with H.I.V. may have stabilized globally since the 1990s, but the disease is still proliferating in several individual countries.

title: Intense Hunt Ends in Zarqawi's Death
description: The death of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, Al Qaeda's leader in Iraq, came after intense detective work by the American military, The Times's Mark Mazzetti reports. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

title: Good News for Bush on Zarqawi
description: The killing of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi is the best news for the White House on Iraq in months or years, The Times's Jim Rutenberg reports. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

title: Zarqawi's Death May Spur Violence
description: Commanders at the Pentagon predict that Abu Musab al-Zarqawi's death will cause an upsurge in violence in Iraq in coming days, The Times's Thom Shanker reports. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

title: Uprising in Uzbekistan
description: C.J. Chivers examines newly available videotape of the May 2005 uprising in Uzbekistan. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

title: The U.N. Condemns Missile Tests
description: All 15 members of the United Nations Security Council agree to condemn North Korea for firing test missiles into the Sea of Japan. (Producer: Emily B. Hager)

title: Chechen Rebel Chief Is Killed
description: Shamil Basayev claimed responsibility for some of Russia's worst terror attacks, including the Beslan school siege.

title: Bush and Putin's Relationship
description: As President Bush prepares to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin on Friday in Russia, his embrace of the Russian leader has turned chilly. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

title: U.N. Slowly Tackles Lebanon Crisis
description: The United Nations Security Council meets for the third time to discuss solutions to the Lebanon crisis. (Producer: Shayla Harris)

title: Staying Put
description: As Lebanese and foreigners were forced to flee, Israelis in the northern part of their country stayed put as Hezbollah's missiles continued to fall.

title: The West Bank Question
description: With daily rocket fire coming from Lebanon and Gaza, Israel's premier can expect greater resistance in pursuing any plan to withdraw. (Produced by Naka Nathaniel)

title: Arab Nations Hesitant on Cease-Fire
description: Surprisingly, some Arab countries do not seem to be in a hurry to demand a cease-fire in the Middle East conflict, The Times's Helene C. Cooper reports. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

title: Bomb Shelter Wedding
description: What happens when you get married in a town evacuated because of bombardment? The press outnumbers the guests. (Produced by Naka Nathaniel)

description: Arab Israelis in Nazareth are caught in the middle of the conflict after a Hezbollah rocket killed two children. (Producer: Naka Nathaniel)

title: Small Bites in Barcelona
description: A tour of five Catalonian restaurants in Barcelona, Spain.

title: Kobe Bryants Delicate Dance Ends
description: [UPDATE, 4:55 PM ET: Kobe Bryant did away with all the diplomacy this afternoon, demanding a trade during a radio interview in New York. Asked if there was anything the Lakers could do to keep him, he responded: No, bro. More on what he said and the possible deals that would send him away at TrueHoops.]

title: United Nations Calls for Cease-Fire
description: The Times's Warren Hoge details today's United Nations call for a cease-fire. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

title: Getting Ready to Go In
description: A small apple orchard away from the Lebanese border, Israeli troops prepared on Friday to secure an area in Lebanon being used by Hezbollah to launch rockets into northern Israel.

title: Rattling the Border
description: For an eleventh day, the Israeli-Lebanese border shook with their  rocket fire and artillery shells.

title: Smoke and Tears
description: July 23 - Nearly a hundred Hezbollah missiles fell into northern Israel on Sunday setting off brush fires that blanketed the town of Kiryat Shmona in smoke.

description: One debate is whether democratization is spreading, or whether other countries believe the United States is tied down. (Producer: John Files)

title: Paris, via New York, comes to Berlin
description: The posters said it all: The most beautiful French are coming from New York to Berlin. Its true! The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York has lent a fabulous collection of its 19th century French artists to the Neue Nationalgalerie in Berlin. Starting June 1, and lasting until October 7, more than 150 works are on display. They range from Ingres and Corot, Courbet and Manet to Degas, Pissarro, Monet and Cezanne. Its a very, very big exhibition of French Impressionists. MOMA has also lent Berlin sculpturs by Rodin and Maillol. The Nationalgalerie, located close to Berlins famed Philharmonie, home to one of the worlds great orchestras, has had a great relationship with MOMA. Just a warning. Its coming up to the holiday season. Berlin is becoming one of the big tourist attractions. The queues will be long. Check out the museum website for special offers or how to book tickets in advance. Also Tel (00 49) 30 226 2651, or EMail: nng@smb.spk-berlin.de

title: Dragon boating revelry
description: Hong Kongs annual dragon boat races combine a fast, furious sport, ancient Chinese lore and an all-out carnival atmosphere.There will be races all month (more info below), but the Stanley races, which take place June 19, are the biggest and most popular. More than 200 teams compete from 8 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. But the party  on hired junks and yachts ringing the bay, and at packed seaside pubs and restaurants  goes on late into the night.Dragon boating is a little like Western rowing, only spiced up with the chaos of a Chinatown street festival. Up to 20 paddlers cram, in pairs, into long, narrow wooden boats that  to the delight of onlookers  are apt to tipping over at the hands of the unskilled. The front is adorned with a colorful, ornate dragons head. This is also where the drummer sits, to beat out time for the rowers to row to. And whats there not to love about a sport with a designated drummer? At the back is the steerer, like a coxswain.The races are short  sprints, actually  done in heats. Its simple enough that everyone from the little kids playing on the beach to the drunk guys on their yachts can follow the action.

title: Your Comments on my China Religion Column
description: O.K., so the Thursday column is actually about more than China and religion. In a larger sense its about the emergence of a bit more personal space, a bit more rule of law, and the hope that China will follow Taiwan and South Korea toward greater pluralism and freedom. But the most striking manifestation of that trend for now is the boom in religion in China, and the way most people in most of the country can worship freely most of the time. And I agree with Li Baiguang that in 20 or 30 years China could have several hundred million Christians, making it the largest Christian country in the world. In most of the world, economic development has eroded religious faith, but in China its working the other way and theres a considerable parallel with South Korea and its embrace of Christianity in the 20th century.

But Mr. Menotti, who died in February at 95, will be honored in a free concert tomorrow morning, and he has figured prominently in conversation during the festivals early days.

Each weekday, New Jersey Transit serves 857,000 riders, a record high, the agency said.

description: The police arrested four men in the killing of Syed Hammad Raza, who worked as the chief of staff to Pakistans suspended chief justice. The interior minister, Aftab Ahmed Khan Sherpao, said the four belonged to a gang of robbers from Kashmir and shot Mr. Raza when they broke into his house in Islamabad on May 14. The police, who said they had recovered the gun used in the shooting and a stolen watch, maintained from the start that the killing was robbery-related. Mr. Razas wife denied there had been a robbery attempt and termed the shooting politically motivated because of Mr. Razas close association with the suspended justice, Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry.

title: Calendar
description: Growing Roses

title: New York City Expands Test Program in Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced yesterday that the city school system would spend $80 million over five years on a battery of new standardized tests to begin this fall for most of New York Citys 1.1 million public school students.

title: Time Wasted? Perhaps Its Well Spent
description: WASTING time gets a bad rap. We pester our children not to do it; we take pride in the multitasking that ensures we never do it; and we bristle at our fellow workers, shop clerks and just about anyone else who slows us down by doing it.

title: California: Whales Presumed at Sea
description: Two humpback whales may have found their way back into the Pacific Ocean through San Francisco Bay after wandering off their migration path for more than two weeks. The mother and her calf have not been seen since sunset Tuesday, when they were spotted swimming in the bay. They may have slipped under the Golden Gate Bridge overnight and into open sea, said Bernadette Fees, a deputy director with the California Department of Fish and Game. The whales attracted crowds to the banks of the Sacramento River as they meandered upstream starting about May 13.

title: From Hitmaker to Defendant, a Long and Winding Road
description: In December 2002 the British journalist Mick Brown was driven by Phil Spectors chauffeur in Phil Spectors white Rolls-Royce to Phil Spectors gloomy castle in Alhambra, Calif., for a spooky interview with Phil Spector, who wore black silk pajamas and made a grand entrance to the strains of Handel.

title: Palm to Sell Device That Wont Fit in the Palm
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., May 30  Fifteen years after pioneering personal computers that nestled comfortably in a users hand, Palm reversed itself Wednesday and said that it would begin selling a two-handed laptop-size machine called the Foleo.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about a push by lawmakers to pass subsidies for coal misidentified the state represented by the Republican Senator Larry E. Craig, who is a supporter of the coal-to-liquid fuel concept. It is Idaho, not Wyoming.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. Can I use bold color in a small space?

title: The Yankees Try Anything in a Search for an Identity
description: TORONTO, May 30  The Yankees were not required to come to the ballpark Wednesday until an hour before the game, and they canceled batting practice in an effort to relax. Were going to padlock the batting cage, Manager Joe Torre said.

title: Loitering Arrest of Panhandler Is Dismissed as Unlawful
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 30  A homeless panhandler arrested for loitering after asking a police officer for a dollar won a legal battle on Wednesday when a City Court judge dismissed the charge, finding the arrest unconstitutional.

title: Swimmers Who Avoid the Deep Have a New Camcorder Choice
description: Aspiring Cousteaus can now record all of their undersea adventures on video, provided their adventures dont take them deeper than five feet.

title: Israel: Peres Seeks a Chance to Serve Again
description: Shimon Peres, a leading figure of Israeli political life, said he would again ask Parliament to elect him president, a symbolic and largely powerless post. Mr. Peres, 83, is supported by his latest party, the centrist Kadima, but he may not win the secret ballot on June 13. In a shock, Mr. Peres, left, lost in the last election, in July 2000, to Moshe Katsav, 61, a relatively unknown Likud politician who is ending his term accused of rape and sexual misconduct. Other candidates are Colette Avital from the Labor Party and Reuven Rivlin of Likud. The president does not have much authority, Mr. Peres said. But he does have the authority to do good deeds.

title: U.S. and Iraqi Forces Seek Abducted Britons in Raid
description: BAGHDAD, May 30  American and Iraqi troops raided Baghdads Sadr City neighborhood on Wednesday, looking for five British citizens abducted a day earlier from a nearby government building, military and diplomatic officials said.

title: China: U.S. Envoy in Talks About North Korea
description: Assistant Secretary of State Christopher R. Hill arrived in Beijing to work with Vice Foreign Minister Wu Dawei on reviving the stalled agreement under which North Korea would begin to dismantle its nuclear program. Mr. Hill maintained that the impasse was a technical matter and that North Korea remained committed to the deal. He declined to give any details of the talks.

title: The Continuing Saga of SIPP
description: A year ago, the Bush administration decided to kill what is arguably the single most important survey on the effects of government programs on Americans lives. In a rare and welcome reversal, the administration has heeded the protest of policy experts and Congress and has decided to continue the project, known as SIPP, or Survey of Income and Program Participation.

title: Melamine From U.S. Put in Feed
description: Ever since pet food contaminated with an industrial chemical was traced to shipments of wheat flour from China, American officials have concentrated on cracking down on imports.

description: BATCHELOR, La.

title: About Online Surveys, Traditional Pollsters Are: (C) Somewhat Disappointed
description: PARIS, May 27  To traditional pollsters, a random survey adjusted to reflect the general population is the only way to measure public opinion properly.

title: New York City Police Seek Trust Among Immigrants
description: Sidique Wai slipped into a mosque in Harlem as afternoon prayers broke, a wisp of a man swimming upstream against the crush of robed worshipers spilling out. He stepped out of his shoes and walked briskly to the front of the prayer room. A microphone was pressed into his outstretched hand.

title: Rice Clashes With Russian on Kosovo and Missiles
description: POTSDAM, Germany, May 30  The United States and Russia, with relations between them at their most contentious since the collapse of the Soviet Union, openly sparred here on Wednesday at a meeting of foreign ministers of the Group of 8 industrialized nations.

title: Thai Court Disbands Former Prime Ministers Political Party
description: BANGKOK May 30  A constitutional court on Wednesday banned the political party of former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra after finding it guilty of election fraud in a ruling that could throw Thai politics into disarray.

title: Big Disparities in Judging of Asylum Cases
description: Asylum seekers in the United States face broad disparities in the nations 54 immigration courts, with the outcome of cases influenced by things like the location of the court and the sex and professional background of judges, a new study has found.

title: Small Business Not as Usual
description: Hannah Kain, a small-business owner in Fremont, Calif., started her packaging services business, ALOM Technologies, in 1997 with a $250,000 Small Business Administration loan. In 2000, her 70-employee company was singled out as an entrepreneurial success by the agency, complete with a ceremony in San Francisco.

title: F.D.A. Still Unsettled in Wake of New Questions
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., May 30  When Dr. Andrew C. von Eschenbach took over the Food and Drug Administration in 2005, the agency had a crisis over drug approvals that had missed or ignored dangerous side effects in Vioxx, antidepressants and other prominent medications.

title: Albany Close to Agreement to Ease Ticket Resale Limits
description: ALBANY, May 30  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and state lawmakers are close to reaching agreement on dismantling laws that limit the resale of tickets to musicals, plays, concerts and sports events, but concerns raised recently by the Yankees and Mets appear to have held up a final deal.

title: New Yorkers Slip in Survey on Spending
description: New Yorkers earn and spend much more than most other Americans do, but they no longer spend more than the residents of Chicago and Los Angeles, according to federal data released yesterday.

description: I GET calls at all hours of the night, Shlomi Gal-On said recently, describing the vagaries of his work. Usually there are tears involved.

title: New Jersey: Republicans File Suit Against Corzine
description: New Jersey Republicans filed a lawsuit today charging that Gov. Jon S. Corzine was violating the states open records act by refusing to release e-mail messages he exchanged with his ex-girlfriend, the president of a state employees union, during recent contract negotiations. Lawyers for the governor say that the e-mails between Mr. Corzine and Carla Katz, president of the communications Workers of America Local 1034, are protected by gubernatorial privilege. Mr. Corzines attorneys also point out that a state ethics panel has reviewed the e-mails and concluded that the governor acted appropriately. But Mark Sheridan, a lawyer for the state Republican committee, said that the public records law requires Mr. Corzine to disclose any e-mails that discuss the contract negotiations because they involve state business.

title: U.S. Troops Raid Sadr City in Search for 5 Britons
description: BAGHDAD, May 31  The search for five British civilians kidnapped from an Iraqi government building intensified Thursday, with American troops conducting raids in Sadr City and the Iraqi government pledging its support for an investigation.

title: U.N. Approves Court to Prosecute Hariri Killing
description: UNITED NATIONS, May 30  A divided Security Council approved a resolution on Wednesday establishing an international tribunal to prosecute suspects in the assassination of Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister.

description: WITH the chiseled looks of an Italian model and the charm of a politician on the campaign trail, Vincent Longo, the makeup artist, coasted onto the makeup floor at Barneys New York this month for his first personal appearance in two years.

description: LONDON, May 30  The main union representing 120,000 British college teachers voted Wednesday to endorse a Palestinian trades union call for a boycott of Israeli academic institutions.

description: JERUSALEM, May 30  It was 2 a.m. when masked gunmen raided Al Wafa Net in the Khan Yunis camp in Gaza where 17 young men were surfing the Internet.

title: Oral Dissents Give Ginsburg a New Voice on Court
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  Whatever else may be said about the Supreme Courts current term, which ends in about a month, it will be remembered as the time when Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg found her voice, and used it.

title: Suit Over C.I.A. Program
description: The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit against a Boeing subsidiary, alleging that the company provided flight plans for Central Intelligence Agency aircraft transporting terrorism suspects to overseas prisons where they say they were tortured. The latest of several legal challenges to the agencys program of extraordinary rendition, the practice of seizing suspects and delivering them to security services in other countries, was filed in federal court in Northern California against the subsidiary, Jeppesen Dataplan, which provides flight plans, overflight permits and other services. The A.C.L.U.s plaintiffs are Binyam Mohamed, an Ethiopian, and Abou Elkassim Britel, an Italian, who were allegedly taken to Morocco; and Ahmed Agiza, an Egyptian taken to Egypt. A Boeing spokesman declined to comment on the lawsuit or to confirm that the C.I.A. is a customer.

title: Asbestos Award Upheld
description: A federal appeals court in Atlanta upheld a ruling yesterday awarding New York City more than $40 million from the trust for a bankrupt Florida-based asbestos company, the latest development in litigation that has lasted more than two decades. The company, the Celotex Corporation of Tampa, was among the companies sued by the city starting in 1985 to reclaim expenses incurred in removing asbestos from city-owned buildings. Celotex later filed for bankruptcy. New York City filed more than 740 claims in the case, but the Celotex trustees refused to pay some of them, arguing they were wrongly decided. Two judges and a federal court in Florida previously ruled in the citys favor, most recently in April 2005. Yesterday, the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, upheld the lower court rulings, bringing the total payments from Celotex, including $11 million from previous claims, to more than $55 million.

title: Manhattan: Man Sought in Taxi Robberies
description: The police said yesterday that they were seeking a man who had robbed eight taxi drivers since May 17. In one case, the man showed a gun to the driver before demanding money, the police said. The robberies have occurred at various spots in Manhattan, all at night or in early morning, the police said. The suspect is described as a black man, 30 to 40, 6 feet 1 inch to 6 feet 3 inches tall, with a muscular build and a mustache and wearing a baseball cap. Drivers have been alerted to the robberies and urged to take precautions, said Matthew W. Daus, chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Reyes Keeps On Playing Those Mind Games
description: Jos Reyes watched the highlights of Tuesday nights bizarre 12th inning, and the memories came flooding back. Even two years later, they were still fresh.

description: THE prevailing mentality among sneaker enthusiasts, which doesnt seem like a lot of fun, is never to wear the most coveted shoes for fear of a smudge. So a new collection of Nikes that look intentionally distressed could be seen as a reaction against the cult of the pristine.

title: A Clean Start at the World Bank
description: Think how much better it would have been if President Bush had simply named Robert Zoellick to lead the World Bank two years ago instead of putting the bank, his administration and the world through the unnecessary and embarrassing Paul Wolfowitz ordeal.

description: "IT Can Be Done, the motto on the coat of arms awarded last year to Asprey, the British luxury house, in acknowledgment of 225 unbroken years of trading, refers to the ability of its skilled craftsmen to indulge its wealthy customers wildest flights of fancy.

title: Genome of DNA Pioneer Is Deciphered
description: The full genome of James D. Watson, one of the discoverers of the structure of DNA in 1953, has been deciphered, marking what some scientists believe is the gateway to an impending era of personalized genomic medicine.

title: Jamess Confidence Rubs Off On Cavaliers
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., May 30  Beyond the soaring dunks, 3-point fadeaway jumpers and behind-the-back bounce passes that LeBron James used to rally the Cleveland Cavaliers to two playoff victories, he added something more subtle to his highlight package: substance.

title: A 12-Megapixel Camera That Doesnt Mind Working in Low Light
description: Its sad but true: sometimes more megapixels in a camera just means more giant, blurry and generally awful pictures. Luckily the 12-megapixel Panasonic Lumix DMC-FX100 has shake reduction and improved autofocus to sharpen things up.

title: Next Week
description: The June issue of PLAY will be published this weekend in The Times. Next weeks newsletter will follow up on developments concerning our big stories, including Phil Mickelsons performance in the Memorial Tournament and the Americas Cup action in Valencia, Spain.

title: Canada: Japan Tobacco Unit to Face Trial
description: Japan Tobaccos Canadian unit was ordered by an Ontario judge to stand trial on charges it defrauded the Canadian government out of about a billion Canadian dollars ($931 million) in the 1990s by shipping cigarettes to the United States to avoid paying taxes. The judge, David Fairgrieve of Ontario Provincial Court, said in a 29-page ruling that prosecutors had presented enough evidence to warrant a trial of the unit, JTI-MacDonald. The company has denied any wrongdoing.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on May 23 about plans to save a house designed by Paul Rudolph from demolition by moving it to Catskill, N.Y., from Watch Hill, R.I., misspelled the name by which it is known. It is the Cerrito House, not Cerritto.

title: Association to Promote Early Music (Better Late Than Never)
description: For the last 20 years critics and early-music fans in New York have lamented that, despite a growing number of period-instrument ensembles and vocal groups, and the continuing popularity of early music on recordings, it remains a backwater in the citys musical life. Now a new organization, Gotham Early Music Scene, is setting out to change all that.

title: Bush Calls for Global Goal for Cutting Emissions
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  President Bush, fending off international accusations that he is ignoring climate change, proposed today to set a long-term global goal for cutting greenhouse gas emissions, and he called on other high-polluting nations to join the United States in negotiations aimed at reaching an agreement by the end of next year.

title: 2 Marines Deny Suspecting Haditha War Crime
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 30  Two Marine junior officers, in testimony made public on Wednesday, said they had no reason to suspect a possible war crime when they inspected the human carnage, including the bodies of 10 women and children, after an infantry attack that killed 24 Iraqi civilians in Haditha in 2005.

title: Lost Boy of Sudan Chases His American Dream
description: For the Lost Boys of Sudan, five miles was not a long way to run. The boys had run farther than that, trying to escape the Janjaweed Arab militia that continues to kill the dark-skinned tribes.

description: The Ceridian Corporation, a human resources company, said last night that it had sold itself to the private equity firm Thomas H. Lee Partners and the specialty insurer Fidelity National Financial for $5.3 billion in cash.
