description: WASHINGTON, May 30  Former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee has taken new steps that make it clear that he is likely to run for the White House, potentially shaking up a field of candidates that has failed to strike a chord with the Republican base.

title: Judge Decides Against a Mayor Who Banned Cuban Parade
description: JERSEY CITY, May 30  The parade must go on.

description: Jean-Claude Brialy, a dashing leading man of the French New Wave films of the 1960s and 70s, died on Wednesday in Paris. He was 74.

title: Bonds Cannot Saunter Past Suspicions
description: Barry Bonds doesnt walk, he saunters. He sauntered into the Giants clubhouse at Shea Stadium for last nights game with the Mets, sauntered in and out of the trainers room for a half-hour and sauntered into the dugout, where for about 10 minutes he took questions that he never really answered. He then sauntered out onto the field with his black glove and sauntered into the batting cage with his black bat.

description: SHANGHAI, May 30  Chinas stock market plummeted today after Beijing moved to impose higher taxes on trading activity.

description: Jrg Immendorff, a German painter best known for crowded scenes depicting an acidic, often autobiographical comedy of art, politics and history, died on Monday at his home in Dsseldorf. He was 61.

title: Wallkill: Bank to Pay for Environmental Cleanup
description: A bank has agreed to pay New York State for part of the cleanup of a closed chemical factory in Wallkill. The bank, HSBC Bank U.S.A., has agreed to pay $850,000 in penalties and to reimburse the state $68,000 for the cleanup of hundreds of drums and containers at the abandoned Westwood Chemical Company plant in Orange County, said Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo. Mr. Cuomo said that when the bank seized the companys operating funds in 2004, it did not leave enough to pay for environmental measures. The bank denied wrongdoing.

title: For Jobs and Gates, a Night to Reminisce
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., May 30  In a highly anticipated encounter, Bill Gates of Microsoft and Steven P. Jobs of Apple took the stage Wednesday evening to relive old battles and alliances and speculate about the future of digital culture and technology.

title: What's on Tonight
description: 9 P.M. (USA) THE STARTER WIFE Debra Messing stars as Molly Kagan, the buffed-and-Botoxed spouse of a Hollywood studio president who finds herself spiraling into oblivion  both personally and professionally  after she gets dumped for a barely post-pubescent pop star. This six-part mini-series was adapted from the novel by Gigi Levangie Grazer, who has managed to hold on to her own producer husband, Brian Grazer. Judy Davis plays Joan, Mollys oldest friend, sobering up from a stint in rehab; Anika Noni Rose plays Lavender, a security guard and Mollys newest confidante; Miranda Otto is Cricket, divided between loyalty to her girlfriend Molly and to her husband, a director who wants Mollys ex, Kenny (Peter Jacobson), to back his latest project; and Joe Mantegna (above with Ms. Messing) is Lou, Kennys boss, whose flirtatious advances help remind Molly that its not all over. Yet.

title: South Korea: Industrial Output Rises
description: South Koreas industrial output rose in April, helped by increased exports of chips and cars. Manufacturing production jumped 3.1 percent from March, the largest gain in seven months, the National Statistical Office said. Output rose 6.7 percent from a year earlier. Corporate investment in factories surged 15.6 percent in April from a year earlier, the biggest gain since September 2006, the report showed. The figures also showed an index of economic indicators climbed 5.1 percent in April from a year earlier after rising 4.9 percent in March.

title: Veteran Spurs Reach Final, Ending Younger Jazzs Run
description: SAN ANTONIO, May 30  The celebration began shortly after 11 p.m. Fabricio Oberto, a relative unknown in 49 states, left the AT&T Center court to a raucous and sustained standing ovation. When the wave began circling the arena minutes later, it was clear that delirium had taken hold of the city.

title: Council Rejects Street Name for Black Activist
description: In a racially divisive hearing, the City Council yesterday rejected a measure that would have named a street after Sonny Carson, a radical black activist who more than once described himself as antiwhite.

title: Bronx: Man Charged With Gun Trafficking
description: A Bronx man has been charged with gun trafficking after a federal sting operation in which he bought four guns, federal agents announced yesterday. The man, David Gonzalez, 23, was indicted yesterday on charges of buying and reselling guns without a license, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Gonzalez was arrested after agents from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives traced several guns seized by the police to a site in Pennsylvania, said Joseph Green, an agency spokesman. The investigation in Pennsylvania led to Mr. Gonzalez, who was arrested after he bought guns in the sting operation in the Bronx, Mr. Green said.

All of a sudden, he found himself mentioned alongside the heady company of hard throwers like Clemens, Sandy Koufax, Juan Marichal and Bob Gibson. 'The expectations were ridiculous for someone at 20,' Wood says. 'I had pitched five games. I had, like, 17 innings. Its tough when you punch out 20 guys in your fifth start and then everybody expects you to do that from here on out.'"

description: The N.C.A.A. granted a waiver yesterday for an extra year of eligibility to 33 Duke mens lacrosse players, a surprising decision that will reverberate in the sport for the next three seasons.

title: Earl Ubell, Who Enlightened Public on Science, Dies at 80
description: Earl Ubell, a science reporter and editor familiar to generations of New Yorkers for his wide-ranging reports in newspapers and on television, died on Tuesday in a nursing home in Englewood, N.J. He was 80 and had lived in Hackensack, N.J.

title: High Stakes on the High Seas
description: Only three teams remain in contention for this years Americas Cup, but rest assured that there are still plenty of characters. As John Tayman writes in Cast Off, Characters for PLAY: "In the end, the rationale for competing in the Cup remains personal and even egotistical, which, fortunately, tends to ensure the presence of oddballs in the mix." Forget the image of a leisurely weekend sail -- these guys are in it for keeps.

title: Suspect Accuses British in Spys Death
description: MOSCOW, May 31  The suspect in the fatal poisoning of Alexander V. Litvinenko, the former K.G.B. officer and Kremlin critic who died last year in London, said today that a British intelligence agency and a self-exiled Russian tycoon had organized the killing and blamed him to create a political scandal.

title: Morgan Stanley to Buy Real Estate Investor
description: Morgan Stanley has agreed to buy a real estate investor, the Investa Property Group of Australia, for 4.7 billion Australian dollars ($3.9 billion) in cash. Including debt, the offer values Australias biggest publicly traded owner of office buildings at 6.6 billion Australian dollars. The bid is subject to an independent experts report confirming that the offer is in the best interests of shareholders.

title: Bush Requests $30 Billion to Fight AIDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  President Bush called Wednesday for Congress to spend $30 billion to fight global AIDS over the next five years, a near doubling of financing that is part of a White House effort to burnish Mr. Bushs humanitarian credentials before he meets leaders of the Group of 8 industrialized nations next week.

title: In Connecticut, Even Surplus Is No Cure for Budget Battles
description: HARTFORD, May 30  At another time, maybe in another place, this could have been an easy budget. The state is flush with a surplus, the Democrats have a strong majority in both chambers of the legislature, and the Republican governor has staked her reputation on her ability to work with politicians from both parties.

title: Recuperating Sharapova Leads a Russian Advance
description: PARIS, May 30  On her way to the French Open, Maria Sharapova had to make an important decision: face her fear of needles and receive a painful shot in her injured, inflamed shoulder, or take time off and skip one of the biggest tournaments of the year.

title: Sports Briefing
description: soccer

title: Ohio School Fears Cuts Will Rewrite Its Success Story
description: DAYTON, Ohio, May 30  The 32 students who graduated from the Dayton Early College Academy on Wednesday evening were mostly from low-income families. Few of their parents went to college.

title: Manhattan: City to Open Asthma Center
description: The city will open a center in East Harlem to improve the treatment of asthma, officials said yesterday. Observing that East Harlem had the highest asthma rate in the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the East Harlem Asthma Center of Excellence would train health care workers in the most effective treatments, provide walk-in screening and help reduce exposure to environmental factors that worsen the condition. With the resources of this great city, no childs place of birth should determine whether they suffer from asthma, Scott Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, said in a statement.

title: Copyrights That No One Knows About Dont Help Anyone
description: Heres a quiz question for authors: To copyright a written work in the United States, you must (a) register it with the Copyright Office; (b) insert a notice that says Copyright  2007; (c) insert a notice that says All rights reserved.

title: Four Men, but Not Ernst & Young, Are Charged in Tax Shelter Case
description: Four current and former partners of the accounting firm Ernst & Young have been charged with tax fraud conspiracy over their work on questionable tax shelters.

title: Bryant Backpedals on Request for Trade
description: Kobe Bryant issued a trade request yesterday that left the Los Angeles Lakers stunned, and then he made a series of conflicting remarks that left the basketball world mystified.

title: Signs of Dtente in the Battle Between Venus and Mars
description: Like bickering relatives at the end of a long holiday dinner, women have been arguing about whether the gender revolution is over and more mothers are choosing to leave work and stay home with the children.

title: Cute Heroes at War, and Simple Puzzles
description: Odin Sphere has cute bunny shopkeepers and a pretty talking bluebird. It also has war, death, vengeance and a protagonist who hopes her death will finally win her the love of her father.

title: Injustice 5, Justice 4
description: The Supreme Court struck a blow for discrimination this week by stripping a key civil rights law of much of its potency. The majority opinion, by Justice Samuel Alito, forced an unreasonable reading on the law, and tossed aside longstanding precedents to rule in favor of an Alabama employer that had underpaid a female employee for years. The ruling is the latest indication that a court that once proudly stood up for the disadvantaged is increasingly protective of the powerful.

title: A Voice for Small Business
description: Steven C. Preston, 46, a former executive vice president at ServiceMaster, became administrator of the Small Business Administration in July 2006. He sat down recently in his Washington office to discuss his efforts and those of Congress to reform the agency, which has been hit with budget and staffing cuts. Following are excerpts:

title: Knowing Where to Draw the Tan Line
description: WHEN you look at recent publications like The Bikini Book or The Playmate Book: Six Decades of Centerfolds, the barriers to wearing next to nothing seemed lower in the 1960s and 1970s. Bodies were softer, more varied, natural  breasts an average C  and Playboy liked to show a girls tan line, as if to suggest she had just come from the beach and innocently stripped.

title: I.B.M. to Cut Jobs, Mostly in Technology
description: International Business Machines cut about 1,570 jobs yesterday to help improve profit margins in its technology services unit.

title: Bebop in the Present Tense, Drummer in the Drivers Seat
description: Several years ago a group billed as the Mark Turner-Ethan Iverson Quartet made an auspicious debut at the Village Vanguard, with Mr. Turner on tenor saxophone, Mr. Iverson on piano, Ben Street on bass and Billy Hart on drums. This week the same ensemble is back at the Vanguard with a different handle, the Billy Hart Quartet, and a clearer sense of itself, judging by a potent and well-balanced first set on Tuesday night.

title: Protect an iPod and Tame Its Unruly Cord at the Same Time
description: If you carry an iPod around, common sense suggests doing what you can to protect it from accidental meetings with hard surfaces or sharp objects. A new protective case from Digital Lifestyle Outfitters does that and adds a twist: cord management.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column on May 17 about flower arranging classes at some Four Seasons hotels incorrectly described the classes. At Four Seasons hotels in New York, Toronto and Paris, classes are offered to large groups of guests, but not to individual guests. In Dallas, classes for individual guests are offered, but only at Thanksgiving and Christmas.

title: Commuters Cocktail Hour Likely to Keep Rolling
description: The city banned cigarettes in bars, and the smokers trooped out to the sidewalk. Trans fats in restaurants were next, and the French fry addicts mostly shrugged. But since the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced that it was considering banning alcohol on commuter trains, it has been a different story.

title: Who Says Theyre Too Old to Stay in the Game?
description: BALDWIN HARBOR, N.Y., May 30  It was a textbook public relations pitch: Suburban elderly care company donates to local senior softball league. Said center hires top New York City public relations firm (Rubenstein Associates). Said firm touts game of the week, in which 93-year-old pitcher faces 86-year-old rival, noting in a Request for Coverage release that the players had a collective 2,880 years of baseball experience.

title: Novell Posts Loss After Trimming Jobs
description: Novell, which sells networking software and computer consulting services, reported a second-quarter loss after the company cut jobs to compensate for declining sales.

title: Yahoo Technology Chief to Leave in Wake of Company Revamping
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 30  Farzad Nazem, Yahoos chief technology officer and one of its longest-serving executives, said he would leave on June 8 after 11 years at the company.

title: At the lyse, Seeing a New Camelot
description: PARIS

title: Pepsi and Coke Agree to Stop Financing Research That Uses Animals
description: ATLANTA, Ga., May 30  Under pressure from animal rights activists, two soft drink giants, Coca-Cola and Pepsico, have agreed to stop directly financing research that uses animals to test or develop their products, except where such testing is required by law.

title: Isolating an Evasive TB Patient
description: It has been more than 40 years since the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ordered anyone into quarantine or isolation, but the agency was amply justified in taking that extreme action in recent days. It was dealing with a patient infected with a very-hard-to-treat form of tuberculosis who had put his own convenience ahead of the safety of others. The only question is whether health officials should have acted sooner.

title: Street Sense Handlers Ponder Whether to Run at Belmont
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 30  The Kentucky Derby winner Street Sense worked an effortless half-mile Wednesday morning at Churchill Downs, but his trainer, Carl Nafzger, refused to commit the colt to a rematch with Curlin in the Belmont Stakes.

title: Queens: Woman Dies in Fire
description: A Queens woman was killed yesterday at her home in a fire, which officials attributed to careless smoking. The woman was identified as Stephanie Pronchick by her neighbors, who said she was in her late 70s, in failing health and a heavy smoker. She died about 10:45 a.m. in her two-story home at 22-14 43rd Street in Steinway, where the neighbors said she lived alone and rarely had visitors. Employees of a nearby deli said that before the fire they had delivered coffee, newspapers, a sandwich and two packs of cigarettes to Ms. Pronchick.

title: For Those Who Sweat, Some Small Stuff
description: To stay hydrated, athletes must replace electrolytes like sodium and potassium that are lost in sweat. But many triathletes and runners prefer to eat their carbohydrates (like chewy bars) instead of gulping Gatorade or Cytomax, carb-loaded drinks with a hint of electrolytes. This long-distance set now has a new option that leaves carbohydrates out of the equation: electrolyte-drink tablets.

title: Corrections: Real People Meet Real Design
description: An article last week about the International Contemporary Furniture Fair gave an incorrect price for smashed-glass panels by Yorgos Papadopoulos. They cost $22,000 for a set of six, not $22,000 each.

title: Rodriguez Says Ha, but Jays Arent Laughing
description: TORONTO, May 30  Somehow or other, Alex Rodriguez has said, the game always comes down to him. That is an exaggeration, of course, but it seemed inevitable on Wednesday.

title: In Mire of Politics and the Mafia, Garbage Reigns
description: MELITO DI NAPOLI, Italy, May 29  Business at Pizzeria Napoli Nord is down 70 percent, and no one has the slightest doubt why: The reasons include eggshells, scuzzy teddy bears, garlic, hair that looks human, boxes for blood pressure medicine, moldy wine bottles  all in an unbroken heap of garbage, at places 6 feet high, stretching 100 or more yards along the curb to the pizzerias doorstep.

title: Overrated? Not Zito, as Giants Blank Mets
description: The guy named Barry stepped into the batters box last night, and the booing started almost immediately. The chants came a few seconds later. Overrated! Overrated! the crowd screamed.

title: Tax Increase Batters Chinese Stocks, but Theres Little Wider Damage
description: SHANGHAI, Thursday, May 31  Chinese stock markets plummeted Wednesday and continued their decline in early trading Thursday after the authorities in Beijing moved to impose higher taxes on trading activity.

title: Pakistan: 3 Journalists Receive Bullet Threats
description: Unaddressed envelopes, each containing a bullet, were left on or in the cars of three Pakistani journalists in Karachi working for Agence France-Presse and The Associated Press. Journalists groups reacted quickly, describing the act as an attempt to intimidate the press and linking it to a shady group with ties to the Muttahida Quami Movement, the party that controls Karachi and is allied with the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf. According to news reports, the group recently issued a list naming a dozen journalists as enemies, including two who received the bullets.

title: Wies Withdraws from L.P.G.A. Tournament
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C., May 31  Michelle Wie winced as she watched her tee shot soar out of bounds on an uncomplicated par-5 at the L.G.P.A.s Ginn Tribute this morning. She was trying to salvage a disastrous round, her first in a tournament since January. She had already sprayed shots into the woods, fished others out of the tall swooping grass that grows in the swamp here and annoyed her playing partners when her father spoke to her during a previous calamitous hole.

title: Near Misses Allowed Man With Tuberculosis to Fly
description: A series of understandable near misses accounted for a Georgia mans odyssey to Europe in which he might have exposed fellow passengers on a series of commercial flights to an exceptionally dangerous form of tuberculosis, federal officials said yesterday.

title: Comedy Business Turns to the Web
description: LOS ANGELES  For Will Ferrell, who commands up to $20 million for movies like Anchorman and Blades of Glory, starring in a short Web video may not seem like the best use of time.

title: Democracy in Pakistan (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dirty Water Underground
description: OAKLAND, Calif.

title: Breaking the Code, for a Win
description: Its no secret that elite athletes will take extreme measures to improve their performance, sometimes ignoring rules and their own health. Next stop down the performance-enhancing highway: gene doping, the introduction of a specialized gene into a persons DNA. In Outlaw DNA, Gretchen Reynolds reports there have been no confirmed cases of gene doping yet -- and that gene-therapy trials have yielded largely disappointing results. Still, she says, that wont stop the dopers who want it, because "gold medals and multimillion-dollar sponsorship deals rest on such knife-edged differences."

title: 3 Claims Dismissed Against McDonalds
description: McDonalds won dismissal yesterday of three out of five claims in a lawsuit over allergens said to be in French fries and hash browns.

title: Board Blames F.A.A. and Airline for Crash
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  Long before a wing fell off a 58-year-old seaplane in Miami, causing a crash that killed all 20 people on board, the Federal Aviation Administration should have known that the airline was failing to inspect and maintain its antique fleet, other federal safety officials said Wednesday.

title: Concussions Tied to Depression in Ex-N.F.L. Players
description: The rate of diagnosed clinical depression among retired National Football League players is strongly correlated with the number of concussions they sustained, according to a study to be published today.

title: For Lohan, a Mix of Sympathy and Scorn
description: LOS ANGELES, May 30  Its already fairly clear which image of Lindsay Lohan will be most indelible in the summer of 2007, and its not a promotional still from her new movie, Georgia Rule.

title: A Father Asks That We Recall What Truly Matters
description: ROCKAWAY, N.J.

title: Detainee Found Dead in Guantnamo Cell
description: A Guantnamo detainee apparently committed suicide yesterday, military officials said in a succinct announcement last night.

title: Cheer, Then Cover Your Eyes
description: Phil Mickelson, new coach in tow, may be peaking just in time for the United States Open in a few weeks. Along with him for the ride will be his loyal following, and count Charles McGrath among them. In his essay about Mickelson for PLAY, Just Like Us -- Only Better, McGrath explains why Mickelsons daring style of golf resonates with fans. "You can tell how his round is going just by looking at him," he writes. "Always theres the thrilling, unspoken question: Is the knucklehead going to emerge?"

title: Malaysia Top Court Doesnt Honor Muslims Conversion
description: PUTRAJAYA, Malaysia, May 30  Malaysias highest court on Wednesday refused to recognize the conversion of a Muslim-born woman to Christianity, ruling that the matter was beyond the jurisdiction of the countrys civil courts and should be handled by religious authorities.

title: Viacom to Sell Music Publishing Unit to Sony/ATV
description: Viacom has agreed to sell its Famous Music unit, a publishing catalog with rights to roughly 125,000 songs, to Sony/ATV Music Publishing for about $370 million.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: David Bear joined Atmosphere BBDO, New York, as executive director for mobile as the agency adds mobile marketing to its service offerings. He had been vice president for business development at ipsh, New York. Atmosphere BBDO is part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group.

title: Tips for the Tourist: When in Rome ... (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Digital Radio That Costs Less Than Half Its Cheapest Rival
description: The cost of receiving digital AM and FM signals will drop next week as Radiosophy releases its HD100 receiver for less than $60 with a rebate. The HD100 pulls in HD Radio signals, a digital format that is broadcast alongside standard radio by more than 1,200 stations in this country. The next least expensive digital receiver is $160 with a rebate; most start at $300.

title: Bushs Nominee Has New Agenda for Bank
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  The World Bank that Robert B. Zoellick stands ready to inherit may be battered, fractious and rudderless. But he said Wednesday that he saw himself not simply as a healer but as a leader ready to establish a new agenda to help the worlds poor.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about Israeli-Palestinian fighting referred incorrectly to two Palestinian gunmen killed by Israeli police in Jerusalem on Saturday. They were permanent residents of Jerusalem, not Israeli citizens.

title: W.H.O. Seeks More AIDS Tests in Nations at Epidemics Center
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 30  The World Health Organization on Wednesday advised health workers in countries hard hit by AIDS to urge every patient to be tested for H.I.V. rather than to simply offer tests in limited circumstances.

title: An Artist Sets Up House(s) at the Grand Palais
description: PARIS, May 30  Anselm Kiefer thinks big.

title: Prized Possessions
description: LIKE beauty contests, personal appearances have their knockouts and their also-rans in terms of sales. Two winners emerged during store appearances by Trish McEvoy and Vincent Longo.

title: Dont Be So Quick to Hit the Road, One Program Says
description: MOST pared-down marathon programs promise only to get you to the finish line in one piece.

title: Toiling Hard on a Terrain of Paper and Particle Board
description: Its difficult to pinpoint the moment when an endeavor becomes an epic. Often you know it only afterward, when your sense of having traveled, or battled, is found on the worn faces staring back at you. What was tiring becomes transformative.

title: A Trio Winks at the 1940s and Nods at Todays Tunes
description: From deep inside the lavender murk where performance art meets pop-jazz nostalgia with a wink and a smirk come the Puppini Sisters, a British novelty trio that made its North American debut at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Tuesday evening.

title: New Agency for I Love New York
description: The familiar tourism campaign for New York State, known since 1977 by its theme, I Love New York, is getting a new advertising agency as well as an increase in its budget.

title: Columbia Settles Student Loan Case
description: New York State Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced today that Columbia University will pay $1.1 million to a fund to educate students about loans and will overhaul its student loan operation and submit to monitoring by the attorney general for five years.

title: S.&P. 500 Breaks Record Set in 2000
description: Indications that Federal Reserve officials have become more upbeat about the economy set off a rally today that, while modest, pushed the most widely followed benchmark of American stocks, the Standard & Poors 500-stock index, to a record.

title: Ambush Kills 16 Policemen in Afghanistan
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan, May 31  Sixteen Afghan policemen were killed Thursday and six more wounded in an ambush on the main road that runs from the capital to the southern city of Kandahar.

title: Unsportsmanlike Conduct By A-Rod?
description: Thats what John Gibbons, the straight-shooting manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, thought about Alex Rodriguezs verbal interference in the top of the ninth inning of the Yankees 10-5 victory on Wednesday.

title: Time Wasted? Perhaps Its Well Spent
description: American workers, on average, spend 45 hours a week at work, but describe 16 of those hours as unproductive, according to a study by Microsoft.

title: Rooms with a view of Rome  and a terrace
description: If you really want to splurge, I recently visited a couple of hotel rooms in the center of Rome where I would happily spend the rest of my life  thanks to their magnificent views and private terraces.

title: Conflicting stories
description: Todays front page of the Daily Express in London, which bills itself as the worlds greatest newspaper, screams House Prices Still Soaring. The lead article says that the average home in England and Wales shot up by more than 1,200  or $2,400  every month in the past year despite Bank of England attempts to dampen the market with hikes to the base rate.

title: Read (or Scroll) All About It!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Shell and Flower Power
description: Axel Seidemann/AP

title: Currents
description: McKim, Mead & White, reinterpreted by Hass and more.

title: Personal Shopper
description: There's a giraffe in the bedroom, creepy-crawlies in the dining room and birds everywhere.

title: Darfur Sanctions
description: President Bush has finally gotten around to doing what he should have done in April 2004: Imposing sanctions on Sudanese leaders for the genocide in Darfur. Its a step in the right direction, but I still dont see signs that the administration is tackling the issue with the energy and enthusiasm necessary.

title: Learn French by podcast
description: How many times have you arrived in Paris for a leisurely visit, suddenly paralyzed by a well known tourist trauma known simply as: Fear of French. The FOF antidote is relatively painless and as accessible as an mp3 player or iPod (make that eePod if you want to pronounce it correctly in French.)

title: Zoellick at the World Bank
description: President Bush has nominated Bob Zoellick for the World Bank, and I think its a good choice. Zoellick and I have had our differences  he once blasted me publicly for focusing too much on the negative in Darfur  but hes intelligent and really cares about these issues. He also understands trade and private capital flows, and those are the best way to get Africa going again.

title: A Work in Progress
description: The New York painter Hunt Slonem purchases a plantation house in Louisiana that a psychic told him to buy.

title: Wachovia to Buy A.G. Edwards for $6.8 Billion
description: Wachovia said Thursday it would buy A.G. Edwards for $6.8 billion in cash and stock, forming the second-largest retail stock brokerage in the United States after Merrill Lynch. The deal for St. Louis-based A.G. Edwards marks the latest big grab for Wachovia Securities, Wachovias brokerage unit, which nearly doubled in size in 2003 when it took control of Prudential Financials brokerage division.

title: EBay Picks Up StumbleUpon
description: eBay has acquired StumbleUpon, a Web browsing recommendation site, for $75 million in cash. StumbleUpon recommends pages within sites like Flickr, MySpace or YouTube based on thumbs up or thumbs down votes from other Web users with shared interests. It has 2.3 million users and is adding more rapidly.

title: Radian6 Gets $4 Million to Grow
description: Radian6 Technologies, whose software helps public relations firms track blogging and user-generated media coverage of their clients, took in $4 million in seed funding from Brightspark Ventures and BDC Venture Capital.

title: Google Picks Up Two Start-Ups
description: Following its $3.1 billion purchase of DoubleClick earlier this month, Google has gone a mini-shopping spree this week.

title: News Corp. Unit Agrees to Buy Photobucket and Flektor
description: Fox Interactive Media, a unit of the News Corporation, has agreed to acquire the photo-storage site Photobucket, just weeks after a public spat in which the popular networking site MySpace partly blocked content from Photobucket.

title: Prosecutors Rest Case in Conrad Black Trial
description: Prosecutors rested their racketeering and fraud case against the media mogul Conrad M. Black on Wednesday, minutes after announcing they were dropping one money-laundering count against him.

title: Yahoo Technology Chief to Leave in Wake of Company Revamping
description: Farzad Nazem, Yahoos chief technology officer and one of its longest-serving executives, said he would leave on June 8 after 11 years at the company. Yahoo said its co-founder, Jerry Yang, would assume Mr. Nazems responsibilities while it searches for a replacement.

title: Viacom to Sell Music Publishing Unit to Sony/ATV
description: Viacom has agreed to sell its Famous Music unit, a publishing catalog with rights to about 125,000 songs, to Sony/ATV Music Publishing for about $370 million. The deal, which was announced Wednesday, includes a wide range of songs, among them classics like Thats Amore and Moon River and newer hits by songwriters including Linda Perry and Akon.

title: Genzyme Buys Out Bioenvision Stake in Drug Venture
description: As part of its push to become a bigger player in cancer drugs, Genzyme said Wednesday that it would buy out a business partner, Bioenvision, for $345 million, consolidating its ownership of a cancer treatment to which the two companies had been sharing rights.

title: Tax Increase Batters Chinese Stocks
description: Chinese stock markets plummeted Wednesday and continued their decline in early trading Thursday after the authorities in Beijing moved to impose higher taxes on trading activity.

title: CBS Confirms Deal for Last.FM
description: CBS confirmed on Wednesday that it had acquired Last.FM, an online radio and social-networking site, for $280 million to expand its digital offerings. CBS, one of the nations biggest radio broadcasters, said the founders of the five-year-old service would continue to operate it as an independent unit.

title: Small Business Not as Usual
description: Over the last five decades, the Small Business Administration has propelled the likes of Federal Express, Intel, Staples and thousands of lesser-known small businesses. But advocates say recent policy changes and severe budget and staffing cuts in the last six years have left the agency unable to fulfill its mission to provide programs and services to the nations 25 million small companies, which the agency defines as businesses with 500 or fewer workers.

title: The Truth About Kobe Bryant
description: Kobe Bryant said a lot of things in a lot of interviews yesterday. At the end of the day, it was still unclear where he stood:

title: Barclays Settles Insider Trading Charges
description: Barclays Bank, which is competing to buy ABN Amro in the worlds largest banking takeover, has agreed to pay about $10.9 million to settle charges of illegal insider trading in bond securities, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Wednesday.

title: Wachovia Hops on the Green Bandwagon
description: One day before announcing it would spend $6.8 billion to buy the retail brokerage A.G. Edwards, Wachovia talked about a different kind of green. On Wednesday, the nations fourth-largest bank said it would build only environmentally friendly branches by the end of 2008, starting with eight it plans to open soon in southern California. The move follows large green commitments recently announced by the nations largest banks, Citigroup and Bank of America.

title: Ceridian to Be Taken Private in $5.3 Billion Deal
description: Ceridian, a human resources company, said Wednesday night that it had sold itself to the private equity firm Thomas H. Lee Partners and the specialty insurer Fidelity National Financial for $5.3 billion.

title: Maker of a Well-Known but Risky Drug to Sell Shares
description: Is a pharmaceutical company whose biggest-selling drug is considered as dangerous as heroin or LSD a good investment?

title: Bain Follows Suit and Abandons Coles Bid
description: And then there were three. Bain Capital became the third buyout firm this week to quit a team of bidders considering an offer for the Coles Group, Australias second-largest retailer, leaving the Carlyle Group, the Blackstone Group and the Texas Pacific Group in the running.

title: British Government to Sell $4.3 Billion Stake in British Energy
description: The British government said Wednesday that it was selling a 2.2 billion pound ($4.3 billion) stake in British Energy, the nuclear power generator, as the company announced a sharp rise in profit and its first dividend since a state-backed rescue operation in 2002.

title: Saudi Prince Shows Support for Citigroup Chief
description: Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, Citigroups largest individual shareholder and a vocal critic of the banks lagging performance, said he has confidence in Charles O. Prince III, the banks chief executive, and does not want to see a breakup of the bank.

title: Private Equity Said to Circle $1 Billion Deal for Jo-Ann Stores
description: Jo-Ann Stores is on the auction block with a price tag just shy of $1 billion, and final bids for the specialty chain are due in June, according to The Deal.com. Lehman Brothers, which was hired to run the auction for the Hudson, Ohio, company, one of the largest retailers of fabrics and arts and crafts supplies in the United States, has approached a select group of middle-market private equity firms, according to the report.

title: Hedge Funds: With More Money Comes More Post-Nups
description: Post-nuptial agreements, once a novelty, are becoming increasingly more popular  and in some cases mandatory  in the world of hedge funds. The Financial Times reports that the post-nuptial agreement, where the married parties sign on the dotted line after the wedding bells have rung, is soaring in popularity among newly wealthy hedge fund managers.

title: Appeals Court Sides With Overstock in Gradient Suit
description: Californias First District Court of Appeal brushed aside claims Wednesday that Overstock.com, the online retailer, tried to gag a financial analysis company when it sued for libel two years ago.

title: Morgan Stanley to Buy Real Estate Investor
description: As deal-making sweeps through the real estate investment trust sector, Morgan Stanley has a made a bet on a real estate investment trust down under. The bank has agreed to buy the Investa Property Group of Australia, for 4.7 billion Australian dollars ($3.9 billion).

title: Spain Files Suit Against Hedge Funds Treaure Hunter
description: The Spanish government filed a lawsuit in a United States federal court on Wednesday seeking to block claims to any Spanish property recovered from shipwrecks by Odyssey Marine Exploration, whose biggest investors include several hedge funds.

title: Motorola Reveals Extent of Icahns Loss in Proxy Fight
description: Motorola on Wednesday revealed the final tally of votes in the proxy fight waged by the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, and according to the numbers, Mr. Icahn lost soundly.

title: Dow Jones Shareholder Calls Murdochs Bid Attractive
description: Rupert Murdoch got the first show of support on Wednesday for his $5 billion bid for Dow Jones & Company when T. Rowe Price, Dow Jones largest outside shareholder, said that News Corporations $60 a share bid is attractive and should be considered.

title: Soccer Dreams and Family Tensions
description: A familiar underdog story told with unusual sensitivity, Davis Guggenheims Gracie depicts the obstacles faced by a young girl who dreams of playing on her high school soccer team. Yet the movies follow-your-heart simplicity masks deeper concerns; like the recent Flicka, this perceptive family drama is really about a daughters struggle for her fathers attention.

title: Brocade to Settle Backdating Charges for $7 Million
description: Brocade Communications Systems has reached a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission over charges that it illegally backdated its stock options, Bloomberg News reported, citing unnamed sources.

title: Rejoining the Champions of Light and Dark
description: The second installment of Timur Bekmambetovs bustling supernatural trilogy cares not if youre familiar with the first. Save for a brief recap of its overcooked mythology, this movie picks up without explanation a number of years after Night Watch concluded, rejoining the champions of Light and Dark and their forever fragile truce.

title: Tales of a Small-Town Hero
description: Sweetness and whimsy fill the screen to capacity in "I'm Reed Fish," a rural coming-of-age tale that's so laid-back that its cast is almost horizontal. Set in the fictional town of Mud Meadows  a cross between Stars Hollow and Lake Wobegon  this movie is about a guy who makes a movie about his life. Moreover, it was written by the real Mr. Fish, drawing from events in his own life. Try to stay with me now.

title: Beating Writers Block
description: The affable but dull "Four Lane Highway" stars Frederick Weller as Sean, a famous (dead) writer's son who became a writer himself but has been blocked for some time. He lives rent-free in his dad's spacious home, drinks to excess, picks up young women at the college where Dad used to teach and bops around town with his best friend, Lyle (Reg Rogers), a full-blown alcoholic.

title: Northwest Airlines Exits Bankruptcy Protection
description: Northwest Airlines emerged from bankruptcy protection Thursday, and its new shares were set to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Speaking with the Star Tribune, Doug Steenland, the companys chief executive, acknowledged that the airline considered various options during its Chapter 11 stay, including a merger with another airline  such as Delta Air Lines  or bringing in a private equity investor.

title: 2008: What Fred Said
description: USA Today has an interview with Fred D. Thompson, the former Republican senator from Tennessee and Law & Order actor (though not for much longer). Speaking with Susan Page, he not only makes it clear that he plans to run, he describes how he aims to do it, she writes.

title: Much Ado About Microsoft's Surface Computer
description: It was just about the strangest call I'd ever received from Microsoft. "We have a new product we want to show you," said the PR woman (I'm paraphrasing). "But we can't tell you what it is, or even what category. But it's truly revolutionary. It's going to change the way people work with their computers."

title: A Stroll Through Richmond
Buyout Firms Are Said to Court Genesco
description: Genesco, the maker of Johnston & Murphy and Dockers brand shoes, has received several preliminary takeover offers from private-equity firms that could rival a rejected $1.2 billion hostile offer from Foot Locker, the New York Post reported Thursday citing unnamed sources.

title: Friends Like These
description: Who is the big loser if Fred Thompson really joins the Republican presidential race? Taegan Goddard, as usual, has a good guess:The most striking thing about a Thompson candidacy is that his strategy of raising money in June threatens to derail his long time ally, Sen. John McCain, who must show progress in his own fundraising after a disappointing first quarter. Thompson backed McCain in his previous White House bid. The Arizona Republic quotes a resigned McCain: Freds a very good friend. I guess my words are, Come on in, the waters fine.'

title: Wachovia Switches Up on Deal Advisers
description: As Wachovia revs its deal-making machinery, the bank seems to be spreading its advisory work around  though the names are familiar ones for the Charlotte, N.C.-based bank. A year after its $25 billion purchase of Golden West Financial, it turned to some different firms for financial advice and legal counsel on Thursdays $6.8 billion deal for A.G. Edwards.

title: Too Much TV and Too Many Guys
description: that whats wrong with humor videos online.

title: Podcast: From Renters to Owners
description: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

title: Much Ado About Microsofts Surface Computer
description: It was just about the strangest call Id ever received from Microsoft. We have a new product we want to show you, said the PR woman (Im paraphrasing). But we cant tell you what it is, or even what category. But its truly revolutionary. Its going to change the way people work with their computers.

title: Richard Li May Join Bell Canada Bidders
description: Just how Canadian is telecom mogul Richard Li?

title: Chongqing, a Chinese Megacity
description: Chinas rush to build megacities is part of a major push to spread Chinas economic boom to the vast interior.

title: The Best Places to Dine and Stay in Bodrum, Turkey
description: I will be coming to Turkey sometime soon, and I would like to know the best places to eat at and a good hotel in Bodrum.

title: Jailing Your Friendly Neighborhood Spider Man
description: Last week, there were snakes on a plane  almost. The man was stopped at customs. This week, another man stepped boldly into a movie-imitating mission, and succeeded.

title: Those Real-Life PC and Mac Guys
description: It didnt take long for the first joint appearance by Bill Gates and Steve Jobs in 20 years to get around to the latest chapter in their intense, decades-long rivalry: The Apple television ads pitting a cool Mac Guy against a dorky PC Guy.

title: A B  and a D  in Boulud Groups Bonnet
description: Can two measly letters of the alphabet be proprietary? Off-limits? Denied even to someone whose initials match them?

title: Has Delphi Found New Backers?
description: A previous bid to invest in Delphi may have fallen through earlier this year, but the bankrupt auto parts maker may have found a new set of backers. In a regulatory filing on Thursday, Highland Capital Management said that it had reached a confidentiality agreement with the company, the first step in potentially creating an investment plan as Delphi prepares to exit bankruptcy protection.

title: The Race of the Digital Cartographers
description: The competition to digitally map New York City is heating up.

title: Lab Rackets
description: Earthquake-resistance technology! Nanotubes! The latest rackets have far-out features that give players more control, better feel and a hard-to-miss sweet spot.

title: Carl Icahn, $50 Billion and the Mollusk
description: Whether or not the world needed another profile of Carl Icahn (who, depending on the era, is variously described as a financier, a corporate raider or an activist investor), Fortune magazine has a long one in its latest issue. The general thesis is that although the New Icahn may be different from the old one, his, ahem, expansive personality hasnt changed that much through the years.

title: Plaintiffs Lawyer Lerach to Step Down, Reports Say
description: William Lerach, the star plaintiffs attorney who has become a target of a federal investigation into illegal kickbacks by Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, has told clients and others that he will retire, Fortunes Legal Pad reported Wednesday evening and The Washington Post on Thursday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page picture caption on Tuesday with an article about Rudolph W. Giulianis demeanor on the campaign trail gave an incorrect location in some copies for a campaign stop where he laughed at a comment by a crowd member. It was White River Junction, Vt., not Hanover, N.H.

title: Is China Lowballing Its I.P.O.s?
description: Remember when dot-com companies were being criticized for underpricing their initial public offerings in order to create first-day trading pops, and helping expand the market bubble? The World Bank thinks much the same thing is happening now  in China.

title: Par Excellence
description: Enough with the baggy polo. Lose the pleated pants. After years of languishing in the bunkers of fashion, golf gear steps out.

title: Giuliani Getting Freeh Endorsement
description: Louis Freeh, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation under President Bill Clinton, plans to endorse Republican presidential candidate Rudolph W. Giuliani this afternoon, according to officials close to the campaign. The two have been longtime colleagues; both were federal prosecutors in the Southern District, where Mr. Giuliani served as United States Attorney.

title: Daydreamers, If I Could Have Your Attention for A Moment . . .
description: Just how weird are your daydreams?

title: Is Molson Coors a Takeover Play?
description: Shares of Molson Coors Brewing were up more than 2 percent to $92.08 on Thursday, but it was the frothy action in the companys options that raised eyebrows at OptionMonster.com. The Web site noted heavy trading in June options to buy Molson Coors shares at $95 apiece, a move that it attributed to takeover chatter. These options would see a big jump in value if Molson were acquired or taken private at a premium in the next month.

title: (Still) Waiting for Gran Turismo
description: Jason, a reader, has been harassing me to buy an Xbox 360 and download the Forza 2 demo (no longer necessary because Forza 2 hit stores on Tuesday). Hes been sending me links to reviews and interviews with the gamemakers.

title: Whos Next: Regional Brokers
description: After learning of Wachovias plan to buy A.G. Edwards for $6.8 billion, Wall Street immediately set about betting on which regional brokerage firms might be acquired next.

title: Scenes Through the Eye of Google
description: Is that someones cat in a living room window? And a neighbor taking out the garbage? Wait  The Battery Tunnel in Brooklyn. Havent cameras been banned from there since 9/11? And is that a burglary in progress or just another Spider-Man wannabe? O.K., now that is really disturbing: E.T.s ghost!?!

title: Lehman to List Buyout Fund Next Month, Report Says
description: Lehman Brothers plans a $500 million initial public offering of a private-equity fund next month, even after similar vehicles by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Apollo Management have struggled to return investors money, Bloomberg News reported, citing unnamed sources.

title: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: Sophistication, Meet Informality
description: Charleston, S.C.  Last night it was all pungent cynicism and sophisticated wit at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., with a presentation of Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brechts Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny at the Sottile Theater. This stood in sharpest contrast to the mood of a festival concert that had taken place in the afternoon. There, in the Dock Street Theater, a jewel box of an auditorium, Charles Wadsworth presented one of his notorious concerts of chamber music laced with corny palaver.

title: Change in the Weather
description: Seeking to end Americas isolation on the issue of global climate change, President Bush called today for the 15 countries that are major producers of greenhouse gases to confer this fall and adopt a common goal on curbing emissions, The Times tells us.

title: Mercury to Settle Backdating Charges for $28 Million
description: Mercury Interactive became the second company to pay a fine to settle charges that it illegally backdated stock options, regulators announced on Thursday. But the Securities and Exchange Commission said it is also suing four former executives, alleging fraud and deception to to enrich themselves and select employees.

title: The Assault on The Assault
description: Most people have reacted enthusiastically to Al Gores new book, The Assault on Reason. He seems to have hit a nerve with his assessment of what ails our democracy  the unchecked power of special interests backed by big money, the pervasive influence of mindless and addictive television, and the relentless triumph of image and style over content, which makes us read more articles about John Edwards haircuts than about our failing education system. Gore understands our problems, as one reviewer put it, as does no other politician of our time.

title: Giuliani and Bratton, Reunited
description: At his news conference in Manhattan today, Rudolph W. Giuliani revealed a new detail about his rapprochement with his old police commissioner, William Bratton. He said that he met in Los Angeles yesterday with Mr. Bratton, who now is the police chief there.

title: Statestruck
description: Did anyone have the same reaction that I did this past January to President Bushs State of the Union address?

title: Edwards Recants Iraq Report Remark
description: Former Senator John Edwards, a Democratic presidential candidate, told an interviewer on Wednesday that he had read the classified October 2002 National Intelligence Estimate before voting to authorize force in Iraq, even though he had previously maintained that he had not read the report and had only been briefed on it.

title: The Legal Perspective on the D and the B
description: Although I didnt hear back this afternoon from Georgette Farkas, a spokeswoman for Daniel Boulud, I did get a call from Alexandre A. Montagu, a lawyer who represents Mr. Bouluds restaurants, at least in relation to trademarks and in regard to issues like the one I described in a post earlier today.

title: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: Praising Menotti
description: Charleston, S.C.  There is considerable love lost in Charleston for the composer and impresario Gian Carlo Menotti. That much was evident in a memorial concert for Mr. Menotti in the Sottile Theater this morning, an event belatedly arranged after his death in February.

title: On the Red Carpet at Cannes
description: Jessica Michault of the IHT discusses fashion at the Cannes Film Festival.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Knocked Up'
description: The Times's A. O. Scott reviews "Knocked Up" from the director of "The 40-Year-Old Virgin."

title: Bold Leadership or Too Little, Too Late?
description: President Bush outlines his proposal for 15 major nations to agree on a global emissions goal. J. Scott Applewhite/AP

title: Kamsky and Leko Win Candidates Matches, Two Others Are on the Brink
description: Gata Kamsky of the United States and Peter Leko of Hungary won their fourth round games to clinch victories in their preliminary candidates matches. Alexander Grischuk and Evgeny Bareev, both of Russia, also won and now have commanding 3 to 1 leads over their opponents (3.5 points are needed to win a match, with a win worth one point and a draw worth 0.5). The matches are taking place in Elista, Kalmykia, to select four qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

title: Latest Intrigue in Horse Race
description: The seemingly endless bidding process for the states horse racing franchise took its latest turn this evening, as one of the bidders, Empire Racing, accused two of the others, the Excelsior Group and the New York Racing Association, of holding secret talks in violation of state procurement laws.
